body: Private vs public apps

title: Adding an Android app to Bitrise
body: The most important difference between public and private apps is that if your app is public, everyone who has the build URL can see your build logs: Public apps. With a private app, you have full control over who has any access to the app.

title: Adding an Android app to Bitrise
body: Select the Git hosting service that hosts your repository, then find and select your own repository that hosts the project.

title: Adding an Android app to Bitrise
body: When prompted to set up repository access, click No, auto-add SSH key.

title: Adding an Android app to Bitrise
body: Type the name of the branch that includes your project’s configuration - main, for example, - then click Next.

title: Adding an Android app to Bitrise
body: Wait while Bitrise is validating your project. The scanner is looking for your build.gradle and gradlew files. If they are present, the project will be detected as an Android project.

title: Adding an Android app to Bitrise
body: The Bitrise Scanner selects the main module of your project by default. If there are more modules to choose from in the Module list, select a module that works best for your project.

title: Adding an Android app to Bitrise
body: Select a variant for building (you can Select All Variants which will generate all variants in Artifacts) and select a variant for testing too.

title: Adding an Android app to Bitrise
body: Register a webhook when prompted so that Bitrise can start a build automatically when code is pushed to your repository. This also kicks off your first build on the primary Workflow - click the message and it will take you to the build page.

title: Adding an Android app to Bitrise
body: On the build page, you can check out the build logs and if you click Edit Workflow , you can modify the default, automatically generated Workflow that was used to run the build.

title: Managing dependencies for Android apps
body: The Gradle build system allows you include external binaries or other library modules as dependencies. Bitrise can install these dependencies for your app during the build process.

title: Managing dependencies for Android apps
body: Adding build dependencies

title: Managing dependencies for Android apps
body: You can read more about adding dependencies to your Android project: https://developer.android.com/studio/build/dependencies

title: Managing dependencies for Android apps
body: Make sure your project's build.gradle file lists all your dependencies.

title: Managing dependencies for Android apps
body: Open your app on Bitrise.

title: Managing dependencies for Android apps
body: Click the Workflows button on the main page.

title: Managing dependencies for Android apps
body: Select a Workflow from the WORKFLOW dropdown menu.

title: Managing dependencies for Android apps
body: Make sure your Workflow includes the Android Build Step.

title: Managing dependencies for Android apps
body: If the project scanner generated a Workflow called deploy when first adding your app, that Workflow includes the Step. It installs all dependencies listed in the build.gradle file without any additional configuration.

title: Managing dependencies for Android apps
body: Make sure your Workflow includes the Install missing Android SDK components Step.

title: Managing dependencies for Android apps
body: The Step must be BEFORE the Android Build Step in the Workflow. It will install all Android SDK tool that your project might need.

title: Testing your Android app
body: We have several Steps dedicated to assisting you in testing your Android app during the CI process.

title: Testing your Android app
body: The Android Lint Step runs Lint on your Android project source files and detects potential syntax errors to keep your code error free.

title: Testing your Android app
body: The Android Unit Test Step runs your project's unit tests. You can run it for all your different modules and flavors. Android unit tests

title: Testing your Android app
body: The [BETA] Virtual Device Testing for Android uses Firebase TestLab to run Android tests on virtual devices. Device testing for Android

title: Testing your Android app
body: The Android Unit Test Step and the [BETA] Virtual Device Testing for Android Step can both export their results to the Test Reports add-on. To do so, simply make sure that your Workflow includes the Deploy to Bitrise.io Step at the very end of the Workflow.

title: Signing your Android app
body: In order to publish an Android app to Google Play, you need to digitally sign the app. Bitrise can also do this for you: you'll just need to upload a keystore file, and provide the necessary authentication.

title: Signing your Android app
body: Other code signing options

title: Signing your Android app
body: In this section, we'll go through how to sign an Android app with the Android Sign Step. There are other ways to sign your app - check out the other options in our relevant guides: Android code signing

title: Signing your Android app
body: Generate a keystore file.

title: Signing your Android app
body: Open your app on Bitrise.

title: Signing your Android app
body: Click the Workflows button on the main page.

title: Signing your Android app
body: Go to the Code Signing & Files tab.

title: Signing your Android app
body: Drag-and-drop your keystore file to the ANDROID KEYSTORE FILE field.

title: Signing your Android app
body: Fill out the Keystore password, Keystore alias, and Private key password fields and click Save metadata.

title: Signing your Android app
body: Select a Workflow from the WORKFLOW dropdown menu.

title: Signing your Android app
body: Add the Android Sign Step to your Workflow.

title: Signing your Android app
body: And that's it. The next time you'll run a build, the Android Sign Step will sign the generated binary.

title: Deploying an Android app to bitrise.io
body: In this section, we'll go through how to deploy your Android app to bitrise.io.

title: Deploying an Android app to bitrise.io
body: Deploying to bitrise.io means that the build artifacts generated during the build will be available for download once the build is finished. You can use this to test your app on your own test devices, for example.

title: Deploying an Android app to bitrise.io
body: To deploy your app to bitrise.io:

title: Deploying an Android app to bitrise.io
body: Make sure your Workflow contains the Android Build Step to build your app.

title: Deploying an Android app to bitrise.io
body: Optionally, you can build your app with the Gradle Runner Step. This requires a bit more configuration from you but allows for more extensive customization.

title: Deploying an Android app to bitrise.io
body: Add the Deploy to Bitrise.io Step to your Workflow.

title: Deploying an Android app to bitrise.io
body: Notifying other users

title: Deploying an Android app to bitrise.io
body: You can use the Notify: User Roles and the Notify: Emails inputs of the Step to set up notifications about your deploy.

title: Deploying an Android app to bitrise.io
body: Optionally, set the Enable public page for the App? input of the Step to true so the Step enables the public install page for your app.

title: Deploying an Android app to bitrise.io
body: Run a build.

title: Deploying an Android app to bitrise.io
body: The Deploy to Bitrise.io Step will deploy the app. You can share the generated binary with your team members using the build’s URL.

title: Deploying an Android app to bitrise.io
body: A bitrise.yml for deploying an Android app to Bitrise

title: Deploying an Android app to bitrise.io
body: In this example, we're building the debug variant of an Android app, and deploy it to bitrise.io, as.

title: Deploying an Android app to bitrise.io
body:
format_version: '11'
default_step_lib_source: https://github.com/bitrise-io/bitrise-steplib.git
project_type: android
app:
 envs:
 - opts: 
 is_expand: false 
 BITRISE_SOURCE_DIR: /app
workflows:
 docs-example-workflow:
 steps:
 - android-build@1:
 inputs:
 - variant: debug
 - deploy-to-bitrise-io@2: {}

title: Setting up Google Play deployment for the first time
body: Deploying to Google play publishes your app to Google's online store. When you do it for the first time, this requires a bit more work than simply deploying to bitrise.io. Once the necessary configurations are in place, it becomes very simple.

title: Setting up Google Play deployment for the first time
body: When configuring Google Play deployment for the first time, you need to link your Google Play Developer account to an API project, set up API access, and upload the service account JSON key to Bitrise.

title: Setting up Google Play deployment for the first time
body: Upload the first AAB or APK manually to Google Play using the Google Play Console.

title: Setting up Google Play deployment for the first time
body: Link your Google Play Developer Console to an API project.

title: Setting up Google Play deployment for the first time
body: Set up API Access Clients using a service account: Please note when you create your service account on the Google Developer Console, you have to choose json as Key Type.

title: Setting up Google Play deployment for the first time
body: Grant the necessary rights to the service account with your Google Play Console. Go to Settings, then Users & permissions, then Invite new user. Due to the way the Google Play Publisher API works, you have to grant at least the following permissions to the service account:

title: Setting up Google Play deployment for the first time
body: Access level: View app information.

title: Setting up Google Play deployment for the first time
body: Release management: Manage production releases, manage testing track releases.

title: Setting up Google Play deployment for the first time
body: Store presence: Edit store listing, pricing & distribution.

title: Setting up Google Play deployment for the first time
body: As an optional step, you can add translations to your Store Listing: Translate & localize your app.

title: Setting up Google Play deployment for the first time
body: Open your app on Bitrise.

title: Setting up Google Play deployment for the first time
body: Click the Workflows button on the main page.

title: Setting up Google Play deployment for the first time
body: Go to the Code Signing & Files tab and upload the service account JSON key into the GENERIC FILE STORAGE.

title: Deploying to Google Play
body: Deploying to Google Play requires a signed APK or AAB file and the Google Play Deploy Step.

title: Deploying to Google Play
body: If you're trying to deploy your app for the first time, make sure your Google Play configuration is set up correctly.

title: Deploying to Google Play
body: Open your app on Bitrise.

title: Deploying to Google Play
body: Click the Workflows button on the main page.

title: Deploying to Google Play
body: Go to the Code Signing & Files tab and copy the Environment Variable key which stores your uploaded the service account JSON key file’s URL.

title: Deploying to Google Play
body: Copy the Environment Variable key which stores your uploaded file’s URL.

title: Deploying to Google Play
body: For example: BITRISEIO_SERVICE_ACCOUNT_JSON_KEY_URL.

title: Deploying to Google Play
body: Open your Workflow and add the Google Play Deploy Step to it.

title: Deploying to Google Play
body: In the Service Account JSON key file path input, paste the Environment Variable which was generated when you uploaded the service account JSON key in the GENERIC FILE STORAGE. Besides the generated Env Var, you can also add a file path right in the Step’s input field where the file path can be local or remote too:

title: Deploying to Google Play
body: For remote JSON key file you can provide any download location as value, for example, https://URL/TO/key.json.

title: Deploying to Google Play
body: For local JSON key file you can provide a file path url as value, for example, file://PATH/TO/key.json.

title: Deploying to Google Play
body: In the Package name input, add the package name of your app.

title: Deploying to Google Play
body: In the Track input, add the track where you want to deploy your APK (for example, alpha/beta/rollout/production or any custom track you set).

title: Deploying to Google Play
body: That’s all! Start or schedule a build and share the URL with external testers or distribute your app on an app store of your choice!

title: Getting started with React Native apps
body: Get started on Bitrise by signing up via email or a Git provider, connecting a repository, and running the first build for your React Native app.

title: Getting started with React Native apps
body: Expo projects

title: Getting started with React Native apps
body: If you use Expo in a React Native project, we have a dedicated guide: Getting started with Expo apps.

title: Getting started with React Native apps
body: You can easily set up and configure your React Native project on Bitrise. A React Native repo can consist of an Android and an iOS project so configurations should be done as you would normally do with Android and iOS apps. When running a React Native project on Bitrise, you will see that first an Android, then an iOS build gets built.

title: Getting started with React Native apps
body: Do you have a Bitrise account?

title: Getting started with React Native apps
body: Make sure you have signed up to bitrise.io and can access your Bitrise account. There are multiple ways of registering an account:

title: Adding a React Native app to Bitrise
body: This procedure will guide you through the process of adding your app to Bitrise, connecting your repository, setting up your repository access, selecting a branch and validating your project. Below we highlight some React Native-specific configuration as well.

title: Adding a React Native app to Bitrise
body: Go to your Bitrise Dashboard.

title: Adding a React Native app to Bitrise
body: Click the + sign on the top menu bar and select Add New App on web UI, which takes you to the Create New App page.

title: Adding a React Native app to Bitrise
body: Alternatively, you can add your app using a CLI. For more details, check out Adding a new app from a CLI.

title: Adding a React Native app to Bitrise
body: Choose the account you wish to add the app to.

title: Adding a React Native app to Bitrise
body: Set the privacy of the app to either Private or Public and click Next.

title: Adding a React Native app to Bitrise
body: Private vs public apps

title: Adding a React Native app to Bitrise
body: The most important difference between public and private apps is that if your app is public, everyone who has the build URL can see your build logs: Public apps. With a private app, you have full control over who has any access to the app.

title: Adding a React Native app to Bitrise
body: Select the Git hosting service that hosts your repository, then find and select your own repository that hosts the project.

title: Adding a React Native app to Bitrise
body: When prompted to set up repository access, click No, auto-add SSH key.

title: Adding a React Native app to Bitrise
body: Type the name of the branch that includes your project’s configuration - main, for example, - then click Next.

title: Adding a React Native app to Bitrise
body: Wait while Bitrise is validating your project. If your configuration files are available on the selected branch, the scanner will detect your app as a React Native app.

title: Adding a React Native app to Bitrise
body: If your project consists of only one module, that module will be automatically selected for Module. If your project contains more than one module, you can pick a module, but we recommend the main one!

title: Adding a React Native app to Bitrise
body: In the Variant field, select a variant that suits your project. Pick Select All Variants to build all variants. Pick debug or release if you wish to generate an APK or an IPA file.

title: Adding a React Native app to Bitrise
body: In the Project (or Workspace) field, select your Xcode project or Xcode Workspace path.

title: Adding a React Native app to Bitrise
body: In the Select Scheme name, pick a scheme name. The scanner validation will fail if you do not have a SHARED scheme in your project. You can still point Bitrise manually to your Xcode scheme but if it’s shared, we automatically detect it for you.

title: Adding a React Native app to Bitrise
body: In Select ipa export method, select the export method of your .ipa file: ad-hoc, app-store, development or enterprise method. Don't worry, you can change this later.

title: Adding a React Native app to Bitrise
body: You have successfully set up your React Native project on bitrise.io! Your first build gets kicked off automatically. You can check the generated artifacts of the first build on the Artifacts tab of your Build’s page.

title: Installing dependencies for React Native apps
body: If the Bitrise project scanner has successfully scanned your React Native project, Run npm command or Run yarn command Steps will be included in your default Workflows. These Steps can install the missing Javascript dependencies for your app.

title: Installing dependencies for React Native apps
body: For native Android dependencies, you can use the Install missing Android SDK components Step.

title: Installing dependencies for React Native apps
body: For native iOS dependencies, you can use, among others, the Brew install Step or the Run CocoaPods install Step.

title: Installing dependencies for React Native apps
body: To install Javascript dependencies with npm:

title: Installing dependencies for React Native apps
body: Using Yarn instead of npm

title: Installing dependencies for React Native apps
body: In this guide, we're using npm to install Javascript dependencies. However, you can use the Run yarn command Step: it can install missing JS dependencies without any additional configuration required.

title: Installing dependencies for React Native apps
body: Open your app on Bitrise.

title: Installing dependencies for React Native apps
body: Click the Workflows button on the main page.

title: Installing dependencies for React Native apps
body: Select a Workflow from the WORKFLOW dropdown menu.

title: Installing dependencies for React Native apps
body: Make sure your Workflow includes the Run npm command Step.

title: Installing dependencies for React Native apps
body: In The 'npm' command with arguments to run input variable, type install.

title: Installing dependencies for React Native apps
body: Using the npm ci command instead of npm install

title: Installing dependencies for React Native apps
body: If you already have an up to date package-lock.json file in your project, we recommend using the ci command in The 'npm' command with arguments to run input. Using npm ci can not only result in much faster build times compared to npm install but more reliable builds as well.

title: Code signing for React Native apps
body: A React Native app can consists of two projects, an Android and an iOS - both have different signing procedures. If you click the Code Signing tab of your project’s Workflow Editor, all iOS and Android code signing fields are displayed in one page for you. Follow our platform-specific instructions to code sign your app for both iOS and Android.

title: Signing your Android project
body: All Android apps must be digitally signed with a certificate before they can be installed on Android devices. On Bitrise, you can use our dedicated Step for this purpose but first you'll need a keystore file.

title: Signing your Android project
body: Generate a keystore file.

title: Signing your Android project
body: Open your app on Bitrise.

title: Signing your Android project
body: Click the Workflows button on the main page.

title: Signing your Android project
body: Go to the Code Signing & Files tab.

title: Signing your Android project
body: Drag-and-drop your keystore file to the ANDROID KEYSTORE FILE field.

title: Signing your Android project
body: Fill out the Keystore password, Keystore alias, and Private key password fields and click Save metadata.

title: Signing your Android project
body: Select a Workflow from the WORKFLOW dropdown menu.

title: Signing your Android project
body: Add the Android Sign Step to your Workflow.

title: Signing your Android project
body: Prerequisite of the Android Sign Step

title: Signing your Android project
body: Make sure to add the Android Sign Step after a build Step (Android Build Step or Gradle Runner Step) in your Workflow.

title: Creating a signed IPA for Xcode projects
body: You can easily create a signed IPA file for your Xcode project with Bitrise if you have your Apple connection set up correctly and you made code signing files available to your builds.

title: Creating a signed IPA for Xcode projects
body: Overview on iOS code signing in Bitrise

title: Creating a signed IPA for Xcode projects
body: For a comprehensive overview on what Steps are available for code signing asset management, visit the iOS code signing page.

title: Creating a signed IPA for Xcode projects
body: You can easily create a signed IPA file for your Xcode project with Bitrise.

title: Creating a signed IPA for Xcode projects
body: You have set up Apple service connection on Bitrise.

title: Creating a signed IPA for Xcode projects
body: Your code signing files are managed correctly.

title: Creating a signed IPA for Xcode projects
body: You set the relevant inputs of our Xcode Archive and Export for iOS Step.

title: Creating a signed IPA for Xcode projects
body: Upload the distribution AND the development signing certificates

title: Creating a signed IPA for Xcode projects
body: We strongly recommend uploading BOTH the development and distribution signing certificates for your project. If you don't have an uploaded development signing certificate, Steps with automatic provisioning options will generate one on the fly every time you start a build. This can eventually lead to reaching the maximum number of certificates, blocking you from starting new builds.

title: Creating a signed IPA for Xcode projects
body: If you’re all set, proceed to setting up IPA export in your Workflow.

title: Creating a signed IPA for Xcode projects
body: Make sure the necessary code signing files have been collected and uploaded.

title: Creating a signed IPA for Xcode projects
body: Make sure you have the Xcode Archive & Export for iOS Step in your Workflow.

title: Creating a signed IPA for Xcode projects
body: Set the Distribution method input of the Step.

title: Creating a signed IPA for Xcode projects
body: The options are:

title: Creating a signed IPA for Xcode projects
body: auto-detect - Please note that this option is deprecated and will be removed. We do not recommend using it.

title: Creating a signed IPA for Xcode projects
body: app-store: Choose this if you want to deploy the app to the App Store. Requires a Distribution certificate and an App Store provisioning profile.

title: Creating a signed IPA for Xcode projects
body: ad-hoc: Choose this if you want to deploy the app to ad-hoc testers. Requires a Distribution certificate and an Ad Hoc provisioning profile.

title: Creating a signed IPA for Xcode projects
body: enterprise: Choose this if you have an Apple Enterprise account and want to use that to distribute your app.

title: Creating a signed IPA for Xcode projects
body: development: Choose this for internal testing. Requires a Developer certificate and a Development provisioning profile.

title: Creating a signed IPA for Xcode projects
body: Set the Automatic code signing input to the Apple service connection you want to use for code signing. The available options are:

title: Creating a signed IPA for Xcode projects
body: off if you don’t do automatic code signing.

title: Creating a signed IPA for Xcode projects
body: api-key if you use API key authorization.

title: Creating a signed IPA for Xcode projects
body: apple-id if you use Apple ID authorization.

title: Creating a signed IPA for Xcode projects
body: Save the Workflow, and start a new build.

title: Creating a signed IPA for Xcode projects
body: That’s all. Xcode will automatically select the right signing files based on your project’s Bundle ID and Team ID settings, and the export method you set.

title: Signing an IPA file with a different team’s code signing file
body: You might want to sign the IPA file with a different team’s code signing files. For example:

title: Signing an IPA file with a different team’s code signing file
body: If you use your company’s code signing files for internal builds, but your client’s code signing files are used for App Store distribution.

title: Signing an IPA file with a different team’s code signing file
body: If you use Apple ID for automatic code signing and the Apple ID belongs to multiple teams, use The Developer Portal team to use for this export input to specify which team should be used for automatic code signing asset management.

title: Signing an IPA file with a different team’s code signing file
body: To do so:

title: Signing an IPA file with a different team’s code signing file
body: Make sure the right code signing files of the new development team are uploaded to Bitrise.

title: Signing an IPA file with a different team’s code signing file
body: Set the The Developer Portal team to use for this export option as well (in addition to the Distribution method).

title: Signing an IPA file with a different team’s code signing file
body: Set the Distribution method.

title: Testing your React Native app
body: You can use React Native’s built in testing method, called jest to perform unit tests.

title: Deploying a React Native app
body: You can deploy your React Native app to:

title: Deploying a React Native app
body: bitrise.io: This allows you download the generated binary, and to share it with others via the public install page.

title: Deploying a React Native app
body: Online stores: we have integrations for multiple different online stores. In these guides, we'll show you how to publish to Google Play and to Apple's App Store.

title: Deploying a cross-platform app to bitrise.io
body: The Deploy to bitrise.io Step uploads all the artifacts related to your build into the Artifacts tab on your Build’s page.

title: Deploying a cross-platform app to bitrise.io
body: You can share the generated app file (APK for Android or an IPA file for iOS) with your team members using the public install page. The public install page is a URL you can share with others who can install the generated app binary on their device. You can also notify user groups or individual users that your APK or IPA file has been built.

title: Deploying a cross-platform app to bitrise.io
body: Publishing to expo.io

title: Deploying a cross-platform app to bitrise.io
body: The Deploy to Bitrise.io Step does not use Expo commands and doesn’t publish to expo.io. This Step publishes artifacts to Bitrise and is not specific to a particular platform.

title: Deploying a cross-platform app to bitrise.io
body: If you need to publish to expo.io, set the Run expo publish after eject? input of the Eject Expo Step to yes. Be aware that in that case you have to provide your username and password for your Expo account to publish to expo.io.

title: Deploying a cross-platform app to bitrise.io
body: Open your app on Bitrise.

title: Deploying a cross-platform app to bitrise.io
body: Click the Workflows button on the main page.

title: Deploying a cross-platform app to bitrise.io
body: Select a Workflow from the WORKFLOW dropdown menu.

title: Deploying a cross-platform app to bitrise.io
body: Make sure you have the Deploy to bitrise.io Step in your Workflow.

title: Deploying a cross-platform app to bitrise.io
body: In the Notify: User Roles, add the role so that only those get notified who have been granted with this role. Or fill out the Notify: Emails field with email addresses of the users you want to notify.

title: Deploying a cross-platform app to bitrise.io
body: Make sure you set those email addresses as Secrets! These details can be also modified under Notifications if you click the eye icon next to your generated binary in the Artifacts tab.

title: Deploying a cross-platform app to bitrise.io
body: If you want the Step to generate a public install page for you, set the Enable public page for the App? input to true.

title: Deploying the app to App Store Connect
body: Keep in mind that every time you want to push an app to App Store Connect, it must have a unique build and version number: increment either or both before deploying.

title: Deploying the app to App Store Connect
body: Make sure you have a working connection to your Apple Developer account.

title: Deploying the app to App Store Connect
body: Generate an IPA file on your own machine at least once.

title: Deploying the app to App Store Connect
body: Upload all necessary code signing files to Bitrise.

title: Deploying the app to App Store Connect
body: To deploy an app to App Store Connect, you need a Distribution type certificate and an App Store type provisioning profile.

title: Deploying the app to App Store Connect
body: Make sure the Xcode Archive & Export for iOS Step is in your Workflow.

title: Deploying the app to App Store Connect
body: Set the Automatic code signing input to the Apple service connection you want to use for code signing. The available options are:

title: Deploying the app to App Store Connect
body: off if you don’t use automatic code signing, or if you exclusively use Step inputs for Apple service authentication.

title: Deploying the app to App Store Connect
body: api-key if you use API key authorization.

title: Deploying the app to App Store Connect
body: apple-id if you use Apple ID authorization.

title: Deploying the app to App Store Connect
body: Set the Distribution method input of the Step to app-store.

title: Deploying the app to App Store Connect
body: The Step will store the path of the exported .ipa file in the $BITRISE_IPA_PATH Environment Variable.

title: Deploying the app to App Store Connect
body: Add the Deploy to App Store Connect Step to your Workflow.

title: Deploying the app to App Store Connect
body: Fill the required inputs.

title: Deploying the app to App Store Connect
body: Either the app’s Apple ID or its Bundle ID is a required input. One of the two must be provided.

title: Deploying the app to App Store Connect
body: If you set the Submit for Review to true, the Step will wait for your submission to be processed on App Store Connect and then submit the given version of the app for review.

title: Deploying the app to App Store Connect
body: The default value of the Skip App Version Update input is No. Change it only if you incremented the app version number in another way.

title: Deploying the app to App Store Connect
body: If you use an App Store Connect account that is linked to multiple teams, provide either a Team ID or a Team name!

title: Deploying the app to App Store Connect
body: Start a build.

title: Deploying the app to App Store Connect
body: If all goes well, your app will be submitted to App Store and you can distribute it via Testflight or via the App Store!

title: Deploying your Android project to Google Play
body: You can use the Deploy to Google Play Step in your Workflow to upload your digitally signed AAB/APK to the Google Play Store.

title: Deploying your Android project to Google Play
body: Configure code signing for your app.

title: Deploying your Android project to Google Play
body: Configure Google Play access.

title: Deploying your Android project to Google Play
body: You only need to do this for your very first Google Play deployment of the app.

title: Deploying your Android project to Google Play
body: Make sure you have the Deploy to Google Play Step after the Android Sign Step in your Workflow.

title: Deploying your Android project to Google Play
body: Fill out the required input fields as follows:

title: Deploying your Android project to Google Play
body: Service Account JSON key file path: This field can accept a remote URL so you have to provide the Env Var which contains your uploaded service account JSON key. For example: $BITRISEIO_SERVICE_ACCOUNT_JSON_KEY_URL.

title: Deploying your Android project to Google Play
body: Package name: The package name of your Android app.

title: Deploying your Android project to Google Play

title: Getting started with Flutter apps
body: Get started on Bitrise by signing up via email or a Git provider, connecting a repository, and running the first build for your Flutter app.

title: Getting started with Flutter apps
body: Flutter is a mobile app SDK that allows developers to create native apps for both iOS and Android. Bitrise supports Flutter apps: we have dedicated Steps to help you with all your Flutter needs. This guide walks you through setting up, testing, building and deploying a simple Flutter app on Bitrise.

title: Adding a Flutter app to Bitrise
body: Do you have a Bitrise account?

title: Adding a Flutter app to Bitrise
body: Make sure you have signed up to bitrise.io and can access your Bitrise account. There are multiple ways of registering an account:

title: Adding a Flutter app to Bitrise
body: Go to your Bitrise Dashboard.

title: Adding a Flutter app to Bitrise
body: Click the + sign on the top menu bar and select Add New App on web UI, which takes you to the Create New App page.

title: Adding a Flutter app to Bitrise
body: Alternatively, you can add your app using a CLI. For more details, check out Adding a new app from a CLI.

title: Adding a Flutter app to Bitrise
body: Choose the account you wish to add the app to.

title: Adding a Flutter app to Bitrise
body: Set the privacy of the app to either Private or Public and click Next.

title: Adding a Flutter app to Bitrise
body: Private vs public apps

title: Adding a Flutter app to Bitrise
body: The most important difference between public and private apps is that if your app is public, everyone who has the build URL can see your build logs: Public apps. With a private app, you have full control over who has any access to the app.

title: Adding a Flutter app to Bitrise
body: Select the Git hosting service that hosts your repository, then find and select your own repository that hosts the project.

title: Adding a Flutter app to Bitrise
body: When prompted to set up repository access, click No, auto-add SSH key.

title: Adding a Flutter app to Bitrise
body: Type the name of the branch that includes your project’s configuration - main, for example, - then click Next.

title: Adding a Flutter app to Bitrise
body: Wait while Bitrise is validating your project.

title: Adding a Flutter app to Bitrise
body: We look for your configuration files and set up your app based on them. In the case of Flutter apps, you definitely need a pubspec.yaml file in your project.

title: Adding a Flutter app to Bitrise
body: Type the name of the branch that includes your project’s configuration - master, for example - then click Next.

title: Adding a Flutter app to Bitrise
body: If you have an iOS project in your Flutter project, you will have to select an .ipa export method.

title: Adding a Flutter app to Bitrise
body: Register a webhook when prompted.

title: Adding a Flutter app to Bitrise
body: With a webhook, Bitrise can start a build automatically when code is pushed to your repository, or a pull request is created. This also kicks off your first build - click the message and it will take you to the build page.

title: Testing a Flutter app
body: You can write and run unit-, widget-, and integration tests with Flutter. For more information, check out Flutter’s official documentation.

title: Testing a Flutter app
body: You can use our automatically generated primary Workflow to test your Flutter app. It can include the Flutter Test Step that runs Flutter tests and can also generate code coverage reports.

title: Testing a Flutter app
body: Test reports

title: Testing a Flutter app
body: The Deploy to Bitrise.io Step exports the results of the Flutter Test Step to the Test Reports add-on by default: to check your Flutter test results in the add-on, you just need to add the Deploy to Bitrise.io Step at the end of the Workflow.

title: Testing a Flutter app
body: To run tests on a Flutter app:

title: Testing a Flutter app
body: Open your app’s Workflow Editor and open the primary Workflow, or any of your Workflows that you want to use to run tests.

title: Testing a Flutter app
body: In the Flutter Install Step, fill in the Flutter SDK Version input.

title: Testing a Flutter app
body: You can specify either tags or branches of the Flutter SDK’s git repository. The default value is stable. This will use the latest stable branch of Flutter.

title: Testing a Flutter app
body: To find the available version tags, check: https://github.com/flutter/flutter/releases.

title: Testing a Flutter app
body: To see the the available branches, check: https://github.com/flutter/flutter/branches.

title: Testing a Flutter app
body: Add the Flutter Test Step. In the Additional parameters input, enter any flags you wish to use to.

title: Testing a Flutter app
body: The Step runs the flutter test command with the specified flags. To check the available flags, open a command line interface on your own machine and run flutter test --help.

title: Testing a Flutter app
body: Make sure the Project Location input of the Flutter Test Step is correct.

title: Testing a Flutter app
body: The default value is the the Environment Variable (Env Var) created for your Flutter project’s location.

title: Testing a Flutter app
body: If you want to generate code coverage reports, set the Generate code coverage files? input to yes.

title: Testing a Flutter app
body: This runs the flutter test command with the --coverage flag.

title: Testing a Flutter app
body: To export the test results to the Test Reports add-on, add the Deploy to Bitrise.io Step to the end of your Workflow.

title: Testing a Flutter app
body: Run a build!

title: Testing a Flutter app
body: Once it’s done, you can find your test results on the Artifacts tab of the Build’s page of the app.

title: Deploying a Flutter app
body: To build and deploy a Flutter app, a Workflow must contain these Flutter Steps:

title: Deploying a Flutter app
body: Flutter Install

title: Deploying a Flutter app
body: Flutter Build

title: Deploying a Flutter app
body: If you have platforms specified in your repository, a deploy Workflow will be automatically generated when adding the app on Bitrise. The content of this Workflow depends on the platforms: for example, if your app contains only an iOS project, the Workflow will contain the Certificate and profile installer Step.

title: Deploying a Flutter app
body: You can build both iOS and Android projects at the same time or you can build them separately, each using their own Workflow. You can set this in the Platform input of the Flutter Build Step any time. By default, the Step is configured according to the platform or platforms that the scanner detected when adding the app on Bitrise.

title: Deploying a Flutter app
body: Here’s an example Workflow we’ll use in this configuration, with all the necessary Steps:

title: Deploying a Flutter app
body: Pipelines for parallelization

title: Deploying a Flutter app
body: In these examples, we're assuming that you are building and deploying both the iOS and Android versions of your app in the same Workflow, performing the necessary operations serially. However, you can do both versions in parallel with a single build trigger by using Pipelines:

title: Deploying a Flutter app
body: Packages and libraries

title: Deploying a Flutter app
body: We also support building Flutter packages and libraries. Unlike in the case of apps, there is no artifact to build so there is no need for a Flutter Build Step in your Workflow.

title: Deploying a cross-platform app to bitrise.io
body: The Deploy to bitrise.io Step uploads all the artifacts related to your build into the Artifacts tab on your Build’s page.

title: Deploying a cross-platform app to bitrise.io
body: You can share the generated app file (APK for Android or an IPA file for iOS) with your team members using the public install page. The public install page is a URL you can share with others who can install the generated app binary on their device. You can also notify user groups or individual users that your APK or IPA file has been built.

title: Deploying a cross-platform app to bitrise.io
body: Open your app on Bitrise.

title: Deploying a cross-platform app to bitrise.io
body: Click the Workflows button on the main page.

title: Deploying a cross-platform app to bitrise.io
body: Select a Workflow from the WORKFLOW dropdown menu.

title: Deploying a cross-platform app to bitrise.io
body: Make sure you have the Deploy to bitrise.io Step in your Workflow.

title: Deploying a cross-platform app to bitrise.io
body: In the Notify: User Roles, add the role so that only those get notified who have been granted with this role. Or fill out the Notify: Emails field with email addresses of the users you want to notify.

title: Deploying a cross-platform app to bitrise.io
body: Make sure you set those email addresses as Secrets! These details can be also modified under Notifications if you click the eye icon next to your generated binary in the Artifacts tab.

title: Deploying a cross-platform app to bitrise.io
body: If you want the Step to generate a public install page for you, set the Enable public page for the App? input to true.

title: Deploying a Flutter app to App Store Connect
body: To deploy your iOS Flutter project to the App Store, you’ll need to build the app, export an IPA file and submit it to the App Store.

title: Deploying a Flutter app to App Store Connect
body: Unlike testing, this requires code signing files:

title: Deploying a Flutter app to App Store Connect
body: An iOS Distribution Certificate (a .p12 file).

title: Deploying a Flutter app to App Store Connect
body: An App Store Provisioning Profile.

title: Deploying a Flutter app to App Store Connect
body: For Flutter applications, code signing requires setting a Team ID in the project settings in Xcode.

title: Configuring Team ID for Flutter apps
body: Once you created your iOS project locally, you will need to review the project settings for it in Xcode. More specifically, you need to set a valid Team ID: without that, your build will fail on Bitrise.

title: Configuring Team ID for Flutter apps
body: In Xcode, open Runner.xcworkspace in your app’s ios folder.

title: Configuring Team ID for Flutter apps
body: To view your app’s settings, select the Runner project in the Xcode project navigator. Then, in the main view sidebar, select the Runner target.

title: Configuring Team ID for Flutter apps
body: Select the General tab.

title: Configuring Team ID for Flutter apps
body: In the Signing section, find the Team menu and set it to the team associated with your registered Apple Developer account.

title: Configuring Team ID for Flutter apps
body: Commit the change to your repository!

title: Configuring Team ID for Flutter apps
body: Don't forget to commit your changes!

title: Configuring Team ID for Flutter apps
body: If you only set the Team ID locally, your build will still FAIL on Bitrise!

title: Configuring Flutter deployment to the App Store on Bitrise
body: To deploy your app to the App Store, you need to upload the code signing files. You have two options:

title: Configuring Flutter deployment to the App Store on Bitrise
body: Upload the code signing certificate(s) to Bitrise and use automatic code signing with the Manage iOS Code signing Step.

title: Configuring Flutter deployment to the App Store on Bitrise
body: Upload the provisioning profile(s) and the code signing certificate(s) to Bitrise and use manual code signing with the Certificate and profile installer Step.

title: Configuring Flutter deployment to the App Store on Bitrise
body: In this guide, we will focus on the second option, manual code signing:

title: Configuring Flutter deployment to the App Store on Bitrise
body: Make sure you have the Certificate and profile installer Step in your Workflow.

title: Configuring Flutter deployment to the App Store on Bitrise
body: Upload the required code signing files to Bitrise.

title: Configuring Flutter deployment to the App Store on Bitrise
body: Open the Flutter Build Step and find the iOS Platform Configs input group.

title: Configuring Flutter deployment to the App Store on Bitrise
body: Make sure the Additional parameters input has the value --release.

title: Configuring Flutter deployment to the App Store on Bitrise
body: Check the Platform input of the Step: make sure it’s set to either iOS or both.

title: Configuring Flutter deployment to the App Store on Bitrise
body: Set the iOS output artifact type input to archive.

title: Configuring Flutter deployment to the App Store on Bitrise
body: Add the Export iOS and tvOS Xcode archive Step to your Workflow.

title: Configuring Flutter deployment to the App Store on Bitrise
body: It should be after the Flutter Build Step.

title: Configuring Flutter deployment to the App Store on Bitrise
body: Set the Distribution method input of the Step to app-store.

title: Configuring Flutter deployment to the App Store on Bitrise
body: Add the Deploy to App Store Connect Step to the end of the Workflow.

title: Configuring Flutter deployment to the App Store on Bitrise
body: Provide your Apple credentials in the respective input fields.

title: Configuring Flutter deployment to the App Store on Bitrise
body: Apple ID.

title: Configuring Flutter deployment to the App Store on Bitrise
body: password or, if you use two-factor authentication on App Store Connect, your application password.

title: Configuring Flutter deployment to the App Store on Bitrise
body: Don’t worry, the password will not be visible in the logs or exposed .

title: Configuring Flutter deployment to the App Store on Bitrise
body: Start a build!

title: Configuring Flutter deployment to the App Store on Bitrise
body: If all goes well, the Step will submit the app to App Store Connect. You can, from the App Store Connect page, distribute the app to external testers via Testflight, or release it to the App Store itself.

title: Deploying a Flutter app to Google Play
body: To deploy your app to Google Play, you need to export an App Bundle file and sign it. You have two options:

title: Deploying a Flutter app to Google Play
body: You can configure code signing in the app’s build.gradle file and then Flutter will sign your app during the build phase.

title: Deploying a Flutter app to Google Play
body: Sign your AAB or APK file on Bitrise with our dedicated Step.

title: Deploying a Flutter app to Google Play
body: The scope of this guide is the second option: signing your AAB/APK file with the Android Sign Step.

title: Deploying a Flutter app to Google Play
body: Generate a keystore file.

title: Deploying a Flutter app to Google Play
body: The keystore file is required for code signing.

title: Deploying a Flutter app to Google Play
body: Open an app on Bitrise and go to Workflow > Code signing > Android Code Signing.

title: Deploying a Flutter app to Google Play
body: Drag and drop the keystore file, and fill out the metadata.

title: Deploying a Flutter app to Google Play
body: Configure Google Play access.

title: Deploying a Flutter app to Google Play
body: You only need to do this for your very first Google Play deployment of the app.

title: Deploying a Flutter app to Google Play
body: In the Flutter Build Step, find the Android Platform Configs input group and make sure the Additional parameters input has the value --release.

title: Deploying a Flutter app to Google Play
body: In the Android output artifact type input field, select either APK or appbundle depending on your deployment requirements.

title: Deploying a Flutter app to Google Play
body: In the Output (.apk, .aab) pattern input, set the path where the Deploy to Google Play Step will be able to access the generated binary.

title: Deploying a Flutter app to Google Play
body: The path should be relative to the project source directory, stored in the BITRISE_SOURCE_DIR Environment Variable.

title: Deploying a Flutter app to Google Play
body: Make sure you have the Deploy to Google Play Step after the Android Sign Step in your Workflow.

title: Deploying a Flutter app to Google Play
body: Fill out the required input fields as follows:

title: Deploying a Flutter app to Google Play
body: Service Account JSON key file path: This field can accept a remote URL so you have to provide the Env Var which contains your uploaded service account JSON key. For example: $BITRISEIO_SERVICE_ACCOUNT_JSON_KEY_URL.

title: Getting started with Ionic/Cordova apps
body: Get started on Bitrise by signing up via email or a Git provider, connecting a repository, and running the first build for your Ionic/Cordova app.

title: Getting started with Ionic/Cordova apps
body: You can use Cordova and Ionic frameworks to develop cross-platform apps. Bitrise can help you with its automated testing, code signing and deployment procedures so that you can ship your iOS and/or Android app/s to the respective marketplace in no time! If your Workspace has more than one concurrency, you can have Android and iOS builds run simultaneously. Now let us guide you through the process!

title: Getting started with Ionic/Cordova apps
body: Do you have a Bitrise account?

title: Getting started with Ionic/Cordova apps
body: Make sure you have signed up to bitrise.io and can access your Bitrise account. There are multiple ways of registering an account:

title: Adding an Ionic/Cordova app to Bitrise
body: Go to your Bitrise Dashboard.

title: Adding an Ionic/Cordova app to Bitrise
body: Click the + sign on the top menu bar and select Add New App on web UI, which takes you to the Create New App page.

title: Adding an Ionic/Cordova app to Bitrise

body: Choose the account you wish to add the app to.

title: Adding an Ionic/Cordova app to Bitrise
body: Set the privacy of the app to either Private or Public and click Next.

title: Adding an Ionic/Cordova app to Bitrise
body: Private vs public apps

title: Adding an Ionic/Cordova app to Bitrise
body: The most important difference between public and private apps is that if your app is public, everyone who has the build URL can see your build logs: Public apps. With a private app, you have full control over who has any access to the app.

title: Adding an Ionic/Cordova app to Bitrise
body: Select the Git hosting service that hosts your repository, then find and select your own repository that hosts the project.

title: Adding an Ionic/Cordova app to Bitrise
body: When prompted to set up repository access, click No, auto-add SSH key.

title: Adding an Ionic/Cordova app to Bitrise
body: Type the name of the branch that includes your project’s configuration - main, for example, - then click Next.

title: Adding an Ionic/Cordova app to Bitrise
body: Wait while Bitrise is validating your project. We look for your configuration files and set up your app based on them.

title: Adding an Ionic/Cordova app to Bitrise
body: At Project Build configuration, you can select which platform to build your app for. You can select:

title: Adding an Ionic/Cordova app to Bitrise
body: iOS.

title: Adding an Ionic/Cordova app to Bitrise
body: Android.

title: Adding an Ionic/Cordova app to Bitrise
body: iOS and Android (where the Android build gets built first).

title: Adding an Ionic/Cordova app to Bitrise
body: Register a webhook when prompted so that Bitrise can start a build automatically when code is pushed to your repository.

title: Adding an Ionic/Cordova app to Bitrise
body: This also kicks off your first build on the primary Workflow - click the message and it will take you to the build page. The first build does not generate an .apk and an .ipa yet, however, you can already check out the project’s logs on the build’s page.

title: Installing dependencies for Ionic/Cordova apps
body: If the Bitrise project scanner has successfully scanned your Ionic/Cordova project, Run npm command or Run yarn command Steps will be included in your default Workflows. These Steps can install the missing Javascript dependencies for your app.

title: Installing dependencies for Ionic/Cordova apps
body: For native Android dependencies, you can use the Install missing Android SDK components Step.

title: Installing dependencies for Ionic/Cordova apps
body: For native iOS dependencies, you can use, among others, the Brew install Step or the Run CocoaPods install Step.

title: Installing dependencies for Ionic/Cordova apps
body: To install Javascript dependencies with npm:

title: Installing dependencies for Ionic/Cordova apps
body: Using Yarn instead of npm

title: Installing dependencies for Ionic/Cordova apps
body: In this guide, we're using npm to install Javascript dependencies. However, you can use the Run yarn command Step: it can install missing JS dependencies without any additional configuration required.

title: Installing dependencies for Ionic/Cordova apps
body: Open your app on Bitrise.

title: Installing dependencies for Ionic/Cordova apps
body: Click the Workflows button on the main page.

title: Installing dependencies for Ionic/Cordova apps
body: Select a Workflow from the WORKFLOW dropdown menu.

title: Installing dependencies for Ionic/Cordova apps
body: Make sure your Workflow includes the Run npm command Step.

title: Installing dependencies for Ionic/Cordova apps
body: In The 'npm' command with arguments to run input variable, type install.

title: Installing dependencies for Ionic/Cordova apps
body: Using the npm ci command instead of npm install

title: Installing dependencies for Ionic/Cordova apps
body: If you already have an up to date package-lock.json file in your project, we recommend using the ci command in The 'npm' command with arguments to run input. Using npm ci can not only result in much faster build times compared to npm install but more reliable builds as well.

title: Testing Ionic/Cordova apps
body: You can run unit tests for Ionic/Cordova apps on Bitrise by using our Karma Jasmine Test Runner or Jasmine Test Runner Steps.

title: Testing Ionic/Cordova apps
body: If your Cordova/Ionic project has a Karma Jasmine dependency in its package.json file, our scanner will detect it when you're adding your app and automatically insert the respective testing Step into your Workflow. If this dependency is missing from your project, you can manually insert one of our testing steps to your Workflow using our Workflow Editor.

title: Testing Ionic/Cordova apps
body: Open your app on Bitrise.

title: Testing Ionic/Cordova apps
body: Click the Workflows button on the main page.

title: Testing Ionic/Cordova apps
body: Make sure you have a testing Step in your Workflow.

title: Testing Ionic/Cordova apps
body: Installing dependencies

title: Testing Ionic/Cordova apps
body: You must install dependencies before you can run tests.

title: Testing Ionic/Cordova apps
body: You can choose between the Karma Jasmine Test Runner and the Jasmine Test Runner Steps.

title: Testing Ionic/Cordova apps
body: Cordova app configuration with Karma Jasmine Test Runner

title: Testing Ionic/Cordova apps
body: In this example, you can find a bitrise.yml configuration that includes a Workflow called primary. This Workflow includes the Karma Jasmine Test Runner Step.

title: Testing Ionic/Cordova apps
body:
primary:
 steps:
 - activate-ssh-key@4.0.3:
 run_if: '{{getenv "SSH_RSA_PRIVATE_KEY" | ne ""}}'
 - git-clone@4.0.11: {}
 - script@1.1.5:
 title: Do anything with Script step
 - npm@0.9.1:
 inputs:
 - command: install
 - karma-jasmine-runner@0.9.1: {}
 - deploy-to-bitrise-io@1.3.15: {}

title: Code signing Ionic/Cordova apps
body: If you want to build an app for iOS or Android, you need to upload the platform-specific files into the Code Signing tab of the Workflow Editor. You can also generate builds for both platforms which requires uploading all code signing files of the platforms.

title: iOS code signing for Ionic and Cordova projects
body: Bitrise supports both manual and automatic provisioning for the iOS code signing of Ionic and Cordova apps as well.

title: iOS code signing for Ionic and Cordova projects
body: Naturally, Bitrise supports iOS applications built with either Ionic or Cordova. However, the code signing process is slightly different compared to a native Xcode project.

title: iOS code signing for Ionic and Cordova projects
body: Bitrise supports both manual and automatic provisioning for Ionic and Cordova apps as well - and once again, the processes are somewhat different.

title: Ionic/Cordova code signing with manual code signing asset management
body: Generate the native Xcode project locally from your Ionic or Cordova project by calling cordova platform add ios or ionic cordova platform add ios.

title: Ionic/Cordova code signing with manual code signing asset management
body: Use our codesigndoc tool to collect the code signing files.

title: Ionic/Cordova code signing with manual code signing asset management
body: Upload the files to bitrise.io.

title: Ionic/Cordova code signing with manual code signing asset management
body: You can do this either on the website UI or with the codesigndoc tool itself.

title: Ionic/Cordova code signing with manual code signing asset management
body: Make sure you have the Certificate and profile installer Step in your Workflow.

title: Ionic/Cordova code signing with manual code signing asset management
body: Add the Generate cordova build configuration Step to your Workflow. It must come after the Certificate and profile installer Step.

title: Ionic/Cordova code signing with manual code signing asset management
body: Fill in the required inputs for the Step. Please note that both the Code Signing Identity and the Provisioning Profile are required inputs for iOS apps even though they are not marked as such.

title: Ionic/Cordova code signing with manual code signing asset management
body: Build configuration: you can set it to either debug or release.

title: Ionic/Cordova code signing with manual code signing asset management
body: Code Sign Identity: enter a Developer or a Distribution identity.

title: Ionic/Cordova code signing with manual code signing asset management
body: Provisioning Profile: enter the appropriate provisioning profile.

title: Ionic/Cordova code signing with manual code signing asset management
body: Packaging Type: this controls what type of build is generated by Xcode. Set the type of code signing you need.

title: Ionic/Cordova code signing with manual code signing asset management
body: Add the Cordova archive or the Ionic archive step to your workflow.

title: Ionic/Cordova code signing with manual code signing asset management
body: Fill in the required inputs.

title: Ionic/Cordova code signing with manual code signing asset management
body: The Platform input needs to be set to: device.

title: Ionic/Cordova code signing with manual code signing asset management
body: The Build command configuration input must match the Build configuration input of the Generate cordova build configuration Step.

title: Ionic/Cordova code signing with manual code signing asset management
body: This Step must come after the Generate cordova build configuration Step in the Workflow.

title: Ionic/Cordova code signing with manual code signing asset management
body: Run your build!

title: Ionic/Cordova code signing with automatic code signing asset management
body: Make sure your .p12 signing certificates are uploaded to bitrise.io.

title: Ionic/Cordova code signing with automatic code signing asset management
body: If you use codesigndoc to collect the files, note that you can tell the tool to export only the certificates, by calling:

title: Ionic/Cordova code signing with automatic code signing asset management
body: codesigndoc scan --certs-only xcode

title: Ionic/Cordova code signing with automatic code signing asset management
body: codesigndoc can also upload the files to the website, or you can do that manually.

title: Ionic/Cordova code signing with automatic code signing asset management
body: Add the Cordova prepare or the Ionic prepare Step to your Workflow. These Steps call the platform rm and platform add commands.

title: Ionic/Cordova code signing with automatic code signing asset management
body: Add the Manage iOS Code Signing Step to your Workflow. If you have both the Certificate and Profile Installer and the Manage iOS Code Signing Steps in your Workflow, your build might encounter unexpected issues.

title: Ionic/Cordova code signing with automatic code signing asset management
body: The Step will export:

title: Ionic/Cordova code signing with automatic code signing asset management
body: The project’s development team.

title: Ionic/Cordova code signing with automatic code signing asset management
body: The installed codesign identity’s name.

title: Ionic/Cordova code signing with automatic code signing asset management
body: The installed provisioning profile.

body: One code signing Step only

title: Ionic/Cordova code signing with automatic code signing asset management
body: If you have both the Certificate and profile installer and the Manage iOS Code Signing Steps in your Workflow, your build might encounter unexpected issues.

title: Ionic/Cordova code signing with automatic code signing asset management
body: Select the Apple service connection method (based on the Apple service you have set up in Bitrise) and the Distribution method.

title: Ionic/Cordova code signing with automatic code signing asset management
body: Add the Generate cordova build configuration Step to your Workflow.

title: Ionic/Cordova code signing with automatic code signing asset management
body: Configure the Step to use the code signing settings exported by the Manage iOS Code Signing Step:

title: Ionic/Cordova code signing with automatic code signing asset management
body: Development distribution example:

title: Ionic/Cordova code signing with automatic code signing asset management

- generate-cordova-build-configuration:
 inputs:
 - development_team: $BITRISE_DEVELOPER_TEAM 
 - package_type: development 
 - code_sign_identity: iPhone Developer
 - configuration: debug

- generate-cordova-build-configuration:

 - package_type: app-store 
 - code_sign_identity: iPhone Developer
 - configuration: release

title: Android code signing using the Android Sign Step
body: You can create a signed APK using the Android Sign Step in your Bitrise Workflow. This Step is configured to run if you have already uploaded your keystore file on the Code signing tab of the Workflow Editor.

title: Android code signing using the Android Sign Step
body: You can create a signed APK using the Android Sign Step in your Bitrise Workflow. This Step is configured to run if you have already uploaded your keystore file on the Code Signing tab of the Workflow Editor.

title: Android code signing using the Android Sign Step
body: The Android Sign Step is not required if signing is configured in your project’s build.gradle file. If so, running the Android Build Step (or the Gradle Runner Step) signs the output (APK or AAB) automatically. Nevertheless, we recommend that you use the Android Sign Step to sign your project in an easy and secure way.

title: Android code signing using the Android Sign Step
body: jarsign and apksigner

title: Android code signing using the Android Sign Step
body: APKs can be signed with either jarsigner or apksigner. For APKs, if you wish to use apksigner to sign your project, then in the Android Sign Step you have to first set the Enables apksigner input to true and leave the APK Signature Scheme input on automatic. This way apksigner checks your APK’s minimum and target SDK versions and chooses the required schemes. It signs your project with V1 scheme if your minimum supported version is low and it also signs with other schemes for newer systems.

title: Android code signing using the Android Sign Step
body: Please note that AAB files can only be signed with jarsigner. The Step uses jarsigner if it detects a file ending with .aab

title: Android code signing using the Android Sign Step
body: Open your app on Bitrise.

title: Android code signing using the Android Sign Step
body: Click the Workflows button on the main page.

title: Android code signing using the Android Sign Step
body: Go to Code Signing > Android Code Signing.

title: Android code signing using the Android Sign Step
body: Drag-and-drop your keystore file to the Upload file field of the ANDROID KEYSTORE FILE section.

title: Android code signing using the Android Sign Step
body: A keystore URL automatically gets generated once you upload the keystore file. Bitrise assigns an Environment Variable (BITRISEIO_ANDROID_KEYSTORE_URL) to the download URL (which is a time-limited, read-only download URL) of the file as the value. No need to download it manually as the Android Sign Step downloads it automatically.

title: Android code signing using the Android Sign Step
body: Fill out the displayed three input fields with your credentials:

title: Android code signing using the Android Sign Step
body: Keystore password

title: Android code signing using the Android Sign Step
body: Keystore alias

title: Android code signing using the Android Sign Step
body: Private key password

title: Android code signing using the Android Sign Step
body: Click Save metadata.

title: Android code signing using the Android Sign Step
body: When you have successfully uploaded a keystore file to the ANDROID KEYSTORE FILE section, Bitrise will automatically export the following Environment Variables based on your input:

title: Android code signing using the Android Sign Step
body: $BITRISEIO_ANDROID_KEYSTORE_ALIAS

title: Android code signing using the Android Sign Step
body: $BITRISEIO_ANDROID_KEYSTORE_PASSWORD

title: Android code signing using the Android Sign Step
body: $BITRISEIO_ANDROID_KEYSTORE_PRIVATE_KEY_PASSWORD

title: Android code signing using the Android Sign Step
body: $BITRISEIO_ANDROID_KEYSTORE_URL

title: Android code signing using the Android Sign Step
body: Add the Android Sign Step to your Workflow after the Step that builds your APK or AAB file.

title: Android code signing using the Android Sign Step
body: Bitrise uses the above Environment Variables and sets them as inputs into the respective fields of the Android Sign Step. Once the Step runs, it produces either a signed APK or an AAB. The signed APK or AAB is used in deploy Steps, for example, the Google Play Deploy Step or the Deploy to Bitrise.io Step. The latter deploys the APK/AAB on the Artifacts tab. You can also use Ship to deploy your app once you built an APK/AAB file.

title: Android code signing using the Android Sign Step
body: Downloading your keystore file

title: Android code signing using the Android Sign Step
body: You can download your keystore file to the project directory from the ANDROID KEYSTORE FILE section using the File Downloader Step:

title: Android code signing using the Android Sign Step
body:
- file-downloader:
 inputs:
 - source: $BITRISEIO_ANDROID_KEYSTORE_URL
 - destination: "$HOME/keystores/my_keystore.jks" #native android#

title: Android code signing using the Android Sign Step
body: If a Step requires the keystore file, make sure to include that Step AFTER the File Downloader Step.

title: Android code signing using the Android Sign Step
body: After this Step, my_keystore.jks will be available at $HOME/keystores/my_keystore.jks.

title: Deploying Ionic/Cordova apps
body: To build and deploy an Ionic or Cordova app on Bitrise, you need to digitally sign both the Android and iOS project (if you're building both) and then use the Cordova Archive or the Ionic Archive Step to build the app before deploying it.

title: Deploying Ionic/Cordova apps
body: You can deploy the successfully built app to:

title: Deploying Ionic/Cordova apps

title: Deploying Ionic/Cordova apps
body: Bitrise.io: the generated binaries will be available on the Artifacts tab of the build's page. You can download them from there or share them with others via the public install page.

title: Deploying a cross-platform app to bitrise.io
body: The Deploy to bitrise.io Step uploads all the artifacts related to your build into the Artifacts tab on your Build’s page.

title: Deploying a cross-platform app to bitrise.io
body: You can share the generated app file (APK for Android or an IPA file for iOS) with your team members using the public install page. The public install page is a URL you can share with others who can install the generated app binary on their device. You can also notify user groups or individual users that your APK or IPA file has been built.

title: Deploying a cross-platform app to bitrise.io

title: Deploying a cross-platform app to bitrise.io
body: Make sure you have the Deploy to bitrise.io Step in your Workflow.

title: Deploying a cross-platform app to bitrise.io
body: In the Notify: User Roles, add the role so that only those get notified who have been granted with this role. Or fill out the Notify: Emails field with email addresses of the users you want to notify.

title: Deploying a cross-platform app to bitrise.io
body: Make sure you set those email addresses as Secrets! These details can be also modified under Notifications if you click the eye icon next to your generated binary in the Artifacts tab.

title: Deploying a cross-platform app to bitrise.io
body: If you want the Step to generate a public install page for you, set the Enable public page for the App? input to true.

title: Getting started with Expo apps
body: Get started on Bitrise by signing up via email or a Git provider, connecting a repository, and running the first build for your Expo app.

title: Getting started with Expo apps
body: You can generate React Native projects with the React Native CLI or with the Expo CLI. Expo is a toolchain that allows you to quickly get a React Native app up and running without having to use native code in Xcode or Android Studio.

title: Getting started with Expo apps
body: In this guide we discuss how to set up, test, code sign and deploy your React Native project built with the Expo CLI.

title: Adding an Expo app to Bitrise
body: First, let’s see how to add a React Native Expo app to bitrise.io.

title: Adding an Expo app to Bitrise
body: Do you have a Bitrise account?

title: Adding an Expo app to Bitrise
body: Make sure you have signed up to bitrise.io and can access your Bitrise account. There are multiple ways of registering an account:

title: Adding an Expo app to Bitrise
body: Go to your Bitrise Dashboard.

title: Adding an Expo app to Bitrise
body: Click the + sign on the top menu bar and select Add New App on web UI, which takes you to the Create New App page.

title: Adding an Expo app to Bitrise
body: Alternatively, you can add your app using a CLI. For more details, check out Adding a new app from a CLI.

title: Adding an Expo app to Bitrise
body: Choose the account you wish to add the app to.

title: Adding an Expo app to Bitrise
body: Set the privacy of the app to either Private or Public and click Next.

title: Adding an Expo app to Bitrise
body: Private vs public apps

title: Adding an Expo app to Bitrise
body: The most important difference between public and private apps is that if your app is public, everyone who has the build URL can see your build logs: Public apps. With a private app, you have full control over who has any access to the app.

title: Adding an Expo app to Bitrise
body: Select the Git hosting service that hosts your repository, then find and select your own repository that hosts the project.

title: Adding an Expo app to Bitrise
body: When prompted to set up repository access, click No, auto-add SSH key.

title: Adding an Expo app to Bitrise
body: Type the name of the branch that includes your project’s configuration - main, for example, - then click Next.

title: Adding an Expo app to Bitrise
body: Wait while Bitrise is validating your project.

title: Adding an Expo app to Bitrise
body: At Webhook setup, register a webhook so that Bitrise can automatically start a build every time you push code into your repository.

title: Adding an Expo app to Bitrise
body: You have successfully set up your React Native project on bitrise.io! Your first build gets kicked off automatically using the primary workflow. You can check the generated reports of the first build on the Artifacts tab on your Build’s page.

title: Installing dependencies for Expo apps

title: Installing dependencies for Expo apps

title: Installing dependencies for Expo apps
body: For native iOS dependencies, you can use, among others, the Brew install Step or the Run CocoaPods install Step.

body: To install Javascript dependencies with npm:

body: Using the npm ci command instead of npm install

title: Installing dependencies for Expo apps
body: If you already have an up to date package-lock.json file in your project, we recommend using the ci command in The 'npm' command with arguments to run input. Using npm ci can not only result in much faster build times compared to npm install but more reliable builds as well.

title: Getting started with macOS apps
body: In this guide, we’ll walk you through how to add a macOS app to Bitrise, how to run Xcode tests, manage your code signing files and deploy the app to bitrise.io and to the App Store.

title: Adding a macOS app to Bitrise
body: Do you have a Bitrise account?

title: Adding a macOS app to Bitrise
body: Make sure you have signed up to bitrise.io and can access your Bitrise account. There are multiple ways of registering an account:

title: Adding a macOS app to Bitrise
body: Go to your Bitrise Dashboard.

title: Adding a macOS app to Bitrise
body: Click the + sign on the top menu bar and select Add New App on web UI, which takes you to the Create New App page.

title: Adding a macOS app to Bitrise
body: Alternatively, you can add your app using a CLI. For more details, check out Adding a new app from a CLI.

title: Adding a macOS app to Bitrise
body: Choose the account you wish to add the app to.

title: Adding a macOS app to Bitrise
body: Set the privacy of the app to either Private or Public and click Next.

body: Private vs public apps

title: Adding a macOS app to Bitrise
body: The most important difference between public and private apps is that if your app is public, everyone who has the build URL can see your build logs: Public apps. With a private app, you have full control over who has any access to the app.

title: Adding a macOS app to Bitrise
body: Select the Git hosting service that hosts your repository, then find and select your own repository that hosts the project.

title: Adding a macOS app to Bitrise
body: When prompted to set up repository access, click No, auto-add SSH key.

title: Adding a macOS app to Bitrise

body: Wait while Bitrise is validating your project. We look for your configuration files and set up your app based on them.

body: Shared schemes only

title: Adding a macOS app to Bitrise
body: Select the export method. You can modify this later - for now, select development.

title: Adding a macOS app to Bitrise
body: Once you clicked it, you should see your:

body: Export method.

body: macOS stack.
