title: Testing your macOS app
body: Once you created your app, the first build will run based on the automatically created primary workflow. You can check it out in the app’s Workflow Editor: click the app’s name on your Dashboard then click the Workflow tab

title: Testing your macOS app
body: If your app does not have test targets defined, the primary workflow will NOT include the Xcode Test for Mac Step.

title: Testing your macOS app
body: If you have test targets defined, the primary Workflow of a macOS app includes the two Steps you need to run your Xcode tests, and view their results on bitrise.io:

title: Testing your macOS app
body: Xcode Test for Mac

title: Testing your macOS app
body: Deploy to Bitrise.io

title: Testing your macOS app
body: Code signing files

title: Testing your macOS app
body: Running Xcode tests and deploying their results to Bitrise do not require any code signing files. So don’t worry about them just yet!

title: Testing your macOS app
body: The Xcode Test for Mac Step runs the pre-defined Xcode tests. It has a default configuration that does not need to be modified: if the tests are written correctly, they will work. You can find the same configuration options in Xcode, too.

title: Testing your macOS app
body: The Deploy to Bitrise.io will deploy the following to the Logs and Artifacts tab of the build:

title: Testing your macOS app
body: your Xcode test results.

title: Testing your macOS app
body: your raw xcodebuildoutput log.

title: Testing your macOS app
body: The Deploy to Bitrise.io Step also exports the results of the Xcode Test for Mac Step to the Test Reports add-on.

title: Code signing and exporting a macOS app
body: To install and test the app on other physical devices, you will need to create and export an .app or .pkg file. This requires setting up code signing. In the example, we’ll be exporting an app with the development export method: you cannot upload such an app to Testflight but you can test it, for example, on the devices of your internal testers.

title: Code signing and exporting a macOS app
body: Automatic Provisioining

title: Code signing and exporting a macOS app
body: The example procedure described here uses manual provisioning, with the Certificate and profile installer Step. However, Bitrise also supports automatic provisioning but it is not in the scope of this guide.

title: Code signing and exporting a macOS app
body: You will need:

title: Code signing and exporting a macOS app
body: the automatically created deploy workflow.

title: Code signing and exporting a macOS app
body: a Development certificate (a .p12 certificate file).

title: Code signing and exporting a macOS app
body: a Development type Provisioning Profile. For a macOS project, the file extension of the provisioning profile is .provisionprofile.

title: Code signing and exporting a macOS app
body: Set the code signing type of your project in Xcode to either manual or automatic (Xcode managed), and generate the package file locally.

title: Code signing and exporting a macOS app
body: Collect and upload the code signing files with the codesigndoc tool.

title: Code signing and exporting a macOS app
body: The tool can also upload your code signing files to Bitrise - we recommend doing so! Otherwise, upload them manually: enter the Workflow Editor and select the Code signing tab, then upload the files in their respective fields.

title: Code signing and exporting a macOS app
body: Go to your app’s Workflow Editor, and select the deploy workflow in the WORKFLOW dropdown menu in the top left corner.

title: Code signing and exporting a macOS app
body: Check that you have the Certificate and profile installer Step in your Workflow. It must be before the Xcode Archive for Mac Step (you can have other Steps between the two, like Xcode Test for Mac).

title: Code signing and exporting a macOS app
body: Check the Export method input under the app/pkg export configs input group of the Xcode Archive for Mac Step.

title: Code signing and exporting a macOS app
body: If you selected development when you added the app to Bitrise, you don’t need to change the input. Otherwise, manually set it to development.

title: Code signing and exporting a macOS app
body: Start a build.

title: Code signing and exporting a macOS app
body: If you uploaded the correct code signing files, the Certificate and profile installer Step should install your code signing files and the Xcode Archive for Mac Step should export an .app or .pkg file with the development export method. If you have the Deploy to Bitrise.io Step in your workflow, you can find the binary package file on the Artifacts tab of the build page.

title: Deploying the app to the App Store Connect
body: If you set up your code signing files and created an .app or .pkg file for your internal testers, it is time to involve external testers and then to publish your macOS app to the App Store. Let’s see how!

title: Deploying the app to the App Store Connect
body: Developer ID

title: Deploying the app to the App Store Connect
body: If you want to distribute your app outside the App Store, you can sign it with a Developer ID. This method is not in the scope of this guide but on Bitrise, it works the same way: you just need to upload the appropriate code signing files.

title: Deploying the app to the App Store Connect
body: To deploy to the App Store, you will need these code signing files:

title: Deploying the app to the App Store Connect
body: a Mac App Distribution certificate.

title: Deploying the app to the App Store Connect
body: a Mac Installer Distribution certificate.

title: Deploying the app to the App Store Connect
body: On your local machine, set up App Store code signing for your project in Xcode, and export an .app or .pkg file. If this fails locally, it will definitely fail on Bitrise, too!

title: Deploying the app to the App Store Connect
body: Collect and upload the code signing files with the codesigndoc tool.

title: Deploying the app to the App Store Connect
body: Go to the app’s Workflow Editor and create a new Workflow: click the + button next to the Workflow dropdown menu, enter the name of your new Workflow and in the BASED ON dropdown menu, select deploy. This way the new Workflow will be a copy of the basic deploy Workflow.

title: Deploying the app to the App Store Connect
body: Click on the the app/pkg export methods , and set the Export Method input of the Xcode Archive for Mac Step to app-store.

title: Deploying the app to the App Store Connect
body: You can export multiple binaries with different export methods: use the Export macOS Xcode archive Step in your Workflow, to do so.

title: Deploying the app to the App Store Connect
body: Add the Deploy to App Store Connect - Application Loader (formerly iTunes Connect) Step to your workflow, after the Xcode Archive for Mac Step but preferably before the Deploy to Bitrise.io Step.

title: Deploying the app to the App Store Connect
body: Provide your Apple credentials in the Deploy to App Store Connect - Application Loader (formerly iTunes Connect) Step.

title: Deploying the app to the App Store Connect
body: The Step will need your:

title: Deploying the app to the App Store Connect
body: Apple ID.

title: Deploying the app to the App Store Connect
body: password or, if you use two-factor authentication on iTunes Connect, your application password.

title: Deploying the app to the App Store Connect
body: Don’t worry, the password will not be visible in the logs or exposed - that’s why it is marked SENSITIVE.

title: Deploying the app to the App Store Connect
body: And that’s it! Start a build - if everything went well, you should see your app on Testflight. From there, you can distribute it to external testers or release it to the App Store.

title: Infrastructure
body: Bitrise is a platform, above all: you do not have to download anything to use it, you do not have to run it on your own computer or servers - we take care of all of that.

title: Infrastructure
body: That also means you do not have to worry about infrastructure, either: maintenance, tools, virtualization are all our job and our concern.

title: Infrastructure
body: On Bitrise, we use virtual machines (VM) to run your builds: every build runs in a new VM, and each VM is discarded immediately after the build has finished.

title: Infrastructure
body: A stack is the type of virtual machine we can use to run your build. For example, for a native iOS app, the best stack is one of our Xcode stacks. Stacks come with all of the necessary tools pre-installed, and are regularly updated to make sure they will serve all of your needs.

title: Build machines
body: Bitrise offers Intel-based (x86) and Apple silicon M1 stacks. Each stack has a large number of pre-installed tools.

title: Build machines
body: On bitrise.io, we offer two types of build machines:

title: Build machines
body: Apple silicon-based macOS build machines (M1 machines). We recommend using these machines for all Xcode stacks, as they offer significantly improved performance over the Intel stacks.

title: Build machines
body: Intel-based (x86) macOS and Linux build machines.

title: Build machines
body: Each machine type offers several options with varying computing power, depending on your subscription plan. You can configure a default machine type for each of your app and you can also set Workflow-specific machine types.

title: Build machines
body: Each Bitrise build machine has its own IP address range: you can allowlist these IP addresses to be able to access our build machines from, for example, a private cloud: Configuring network access for Bitrise

title: Build machines
body: For more information about build and code security, see Code security.

title: Configuring network access for Bitrise
body: You can access Bitrise virtual machines from behind a private network or a firewall. To do so, allowlist our build machine IP addresses in your network.

title: Configuring network access for Bitrise
body: Our datacenters are behind a set of public static IP addresses, with the virtual machines having their own internal subnets behind these addresses. Depending on your company security policy, you may need to allowlist the public IP addresses to be able to access the build machine: IP addresses for the Bitrise build machines

title: Configuring network access for Bitrise
body: Similarly, the Bitrise website and its background workers are accessible at a set of static IP addresses. Allowlisting these addresses can ensure you can still receive build status updates or that Bitrise can access the bitrise.yml file: IP addresses for the Bitrise website of your app.

title: Configuring network access for Bitrise
body: Connecting via a VPN

title: Configuring network access for Bitrise
body: You can connect to Bitrise via a VPN - but it can cause a conflict if your local network uses the same address space as our build VMs. In such a case, the VPN may detect a clash and return an error. In this case, the only solution is to re-configure your local address space to use different subnets than our virtual machines.

title: Configuring network access for Bitrise
body: Connecting to a VPN during a build.

title: IP addresses for the Bitrise build machines
body: For most users, who host their repositories on cloud-based service providers, there is no need for any network configuration to be able to use Bitrise. All we need is permission to access the repository and for that, an SSH key is enough.

title: IP addresses for the Bitrise build machines
body: However, your company security policy might not allow unknown and unauthorized IP addresses to communicate with the servers where your code is being stored - either on your own datacenter or in a private cloud. In that case, Bitrise won’t work unless the relevant IP addresses are added to your allow list.

For example, 208.52.166.128/28 means all IP addresses between 208.52.166.128 and 208.52.166.143 (208.52.166.128, 208.52.166.129, 208.52.166.130, and so on, all the way to and including 208.52.166.143) have to be allowlisted.

title: Build machine types
body: Bitrise offers multiple build machines with different specifications and credit costs. You can choose between them based on your needs.

title: Build machine types

title: Build machine types
body: Machine availability by subscription plan

title: Build machine types
body: Not all machines are available on all subscription plans. Visit the pricing page to find out which machines are available on your plan!

title: Build machine types
body: Bitrise build machine types

title: Build stacks
body: The Bitrise build stack defines the virtual machine version used to run your builds. The main types are macOS stacks and Android & Docker stacks.

title: Build stacks
body: The build stack indicates the virtual machine version that we will use to run your build. The main stack types are:

title: Build stacks
body: macOS stacks: These stacks run on a macOS operating system and each one includes multiple Xcode versions. Ideal for building iOS apps. They also have Android tools installed if you want to use them to build a cross-platform app.

title: Build stacks
body: The Android & Docker stack: These stacks run on Linux operating system in a Docker environment. They have all Android tools installed and they are ideal for building native Android apps.

title: Build stacks
body: Each build runs in its own virtual machine and the virtual machine is rolled back to a saved state, the “base box” state, after the build is finished. This way your builds are always protected by changes made by others and by your previous builds and you can use a stable environment to define your build workflow, since no state persists between builds.

title: Build stacks
body: Passwordless sudo enabled

title: Build stacks
body: The user account that is used for the builds is configured to have passwordless sudo enabled. This way you are able to install all the extra things you need for your builds and for other automation. If a tool is not preinstalled on your stack of choice, you can install it yourself - see the guide.

title: Build stacks
body: After adding your app to Bitrise we will select an appropriate stack for it. You can change the stack at any time on the Stacks & Machines tab of the Workflow Editor.

title: Build stacks
body: After selecting the stack you want to use, you’ll see a short description of the stack with an additional link to learn more about that specific one (for example, to see what tools are preinstalled, and which versions, on the selected stack).

title: Build stacks
body: Stack status types

title: Build stacks
body: Stack prepare types

title: Stack update policy
body: Bitrise stacks are updated every week: some stacks are completely rebuilt while on others only certain cache archives are updated.

title: Stack update policy
body: Stacks on bitrise.io are updated regularly, on a weekly basis. On some stacks only certain caches are updated and there are stacks which are completely rebuilt, on both macOS and Linux.

title: Stack update policy
body: For more information on what tools are available on the different stacks, check out our relevant guide: Preinstalled tools on Bitrise stacks.

title: macOS stack updates
body: We divide our macOS stacks into categories based on OS, CPU architecture, and Xcode versions.

title: macOS stack updates
body: These stacks include multiple Xcode versions to ensure you always have the right Xcode version on demand and to reduce the time spent migrating between stacks when you need to use a different Xcode version.

title: macOS stack updates
body: For example, we have a stack for macOS 13 Ventura on M1, which includes Xcode 14.2, Xcode 14.1, and Xcode 14.0.

title: macOS stack updates
body: macOS Stable stacks are only updated with Xcode patch versions, Bitrise CLI related updates, dependency manager cache updates and with critical fixes. These stacks are designed so that if a build worked on the stack, the same build should run the same way as long as the stack is available.

title: macOS stack updates
body: The Xcode Edge stack is rebuilt regularly. It includes the latest stable release of Xcode, the same pre-installed tools as on the Stable stack, and the dependency manager cache updates. The stack uses the same scripts we use for creating new Xcode stacks.

title: macOS stack updates
body: Xcode beta versions

title: macOS stack updates
body: Bitrise supports Xcode beta versions. You can check out which specific Xcode versions your stack uses either on the Bitrise System Reports repository or by clicking on the link below the selected stack in the Workflow Editor.

title: macOS stack updates
body: Pinning an Xcode version

title: macOS stack updates
body: Whenever a new Xcode version comes out, we make sure it's available for our users within two working days. But we do not update existing stable stacks with a new Xcode version as that could potentially break builds: instead, we provide a new stack with the new version, and keep maintaining the older versions.

title: macOS stack updates
body: About dependency manager cache updates

title: macOS stack updates
body: All of the macOS stacks receive a dependency manager cache update (brew, cocoapods and bitrise CLI) every week. These cache updates do not change the pre-installed tool versions, they only update the package manager caches for faster dependency installs.

title: Available simulator runtimes on macOS stacks
body: Our policy for available simulator runtimes on macOS stacks is based on Apple's minimum requirements and supported SDKs.

title: Available simulator runtimes on macOS stacks
body: Preinstalled tools on Bitrise stacks

title: Available simulator runtimes on macOS stacks
body: If you are interested in the list of preinstalled tools, such as simulator runtimes on our stacks, you can find every available stack’s System Report on GitHub.

title: Available simulator runtimes on macOS stacks
body: Each Xcode version has a list of supported simulators. We take the latest supported simulator runtime of each Xcode version on our stacks, and where compatible, we make the simulator runtime available on all stacks. We will also support the most recent version of the iOS simulator runtime prior to the oldest major version.

title: Available simulator runtimes on macOS stacks
body: Available iOS simulators on Bitrise stacks

title: Available simulator runtimes on macOS stacks
body: Let's look at an example:

title: Available simulator runtimes on macOS stacks
body: Xcode 12.5 has minimum requirements to work with iOS 10.3.1-14.5 simulator runtimes. The 14.5 simulator runtime is the latest version, so we make it available across all stacks. In this case, the 14.5 simulator is compatible with all our currently active Xcode stacks and so it is available on all those stacks.

title: Available simulator runtimes on macOS stacks
body: Xcode 13.0 has minimum requirements to work with iOS 10.3.1-15.0 simulator runtimes. The 15.0 simulator runtime is the latest version, so just like for iOS 14.5, we make it available for all compatible stacks, which is all of them except for Xcode 12.5.

title: Available simulator runtimes on macOS stacks
body: We continue going through all Xcode versions and taking the latest supported simulator runtime until the last Xcode version, which is Xcode 14.2. When we are done, we also take the most recent version of the iOS simulator runtime prior to the oldest major version. In this case, the oldest major version is iOS 14.5, and the most recent iOS simulator prior to that is iOS 13.7, so that version will also be available for all stacks.

title: Available simulator runtimes on macOS stacks
body: This table illustrates which iOS simulator runtimes are available for which Xcode version on our macOS stacks:

title: Available simulator runtimes on macOS stacks
body: Available simulator runtimes for iOS (X = available)

body: The Android / Linux stacks are prepared with docker, using multiple separate docker images built on top of each other.

title: Stack deprecation and removal policy
body: On Bitrise, Android stacks are supported for around two years; Xcode stacks are deprecated gradually as new Xcode versions are released.

title: Stack deprecation and removal policy
body: We don't keep all stacks around forever: our aim is to provide you with the latest tools to help you build the best app you can. However, we don't expect you to rework your build configuration every time a stack update comes out: you can keep using your reliable older stacks for a long time.

title: Stack deprecation and removal policy
body: At certain points, we deprecate some older stacks. When a stack is deprecated, you can still keep using it but the stack will no longer get any updates and at that point we strongly recommend switching to a newer, non-deprecated stack.

title: Stack deprecation and removal policy
body: Deprecated stacks are eventually removed entirely but don't worry: we'll give you plenty of warning in advance before that happens. We'll send out an update like this on multiple different channels.

title: Maintaining macOS stacks
body: We offer a wide variety of macOS stacks in order to make sure you do not need to immediately switch when a new version comes out. Our policy is as follows:

title: Maintaining macOS stacks
body: Keep the latest patch version of every minor Xcode version for the most recent major Xcode release.

title: Maintaining macOS stacks
body: Keep the latest patch version for the two most recent minor versions from the previous major version.

title: Maintaining macOS stacks
body: Keep the latest patch version for the most recent minor version from the previous -1 major version.

title: Maintaining macOS stacks
body: Stacks will only be deprecated once their global usage falls below 1% of all builds.

title: Maintaining macOS stacks
body: Maintaining macOS stacks

title: Maintaining macOS stacks
body: When the latest Xcode version was 13.4.x, we kept:

title: Maintaining macOS stacks
body: All the latest patch releases for every minor version of Xcode 13:

title: Maintaining macOS stacks
body: The latest versions from the previous two Xcode major versions:

title: Deprecating and removing macOS stacks
body: Deprecating Xcode 14.x on Monterey-based stacks

title: Deprecating and removing macOS stacks
body: On Monday, March 13, 2023, we will be deprecating Xcode 14.x on Monterey-based stacks. The following Xcode versions are affected:

title: Deprecating and removing macOS stacks
body: Xcode 14.0.x, on macOS 12.5 (Monterey)

title: Deprecating and removing macOS stacks
body: Xcode 14.1.x, on macOS 12.5 (Monterey)

title: Deprecating and removing macOS stacks
body: For more information, see Migrate to Ventura from Monterey when on Xcode 14.x.

title: Deprecating and removing macOS stacks
body: If you run into any VPN or DNS related issues on Ventura stacks, check out VPN and DNS issues with macOS Ventura stacks.

title: Deprecating and removing macOS stacks
body: When the first beta of the next major Xcode version is released, we deprecate all the minor versions of the last major version, except the very last version.

title: Deprecating and removing macOS stacks
body: Deprecating stacks when a new Xcode beta version is released

title: Deprecating and removing macOS stacks
body: When Xcode 14 beta was released, we deprecated:

title: Deprecating and removing macOS stacks
body: The oldest major version which was Xcode 11.7.

title: Deprecating and removing macOS stacks
body: The minor versions of the last major version, except for the last couple of minor versions. In practice, this would mean deprecating all macOS Xcode 13 stacks except those with 13.4 and 13.3. However, if any of the older Xcode 13 stacks are still used by more than 1% of all builds, they would NOT be deprecated.

title: Deprecating and removing macOS stacks
body: When the first final (non-beta) version of the new major Xcode version is released, we remove the deprecated stacks; the oldest major version as well as the minor versions of the last major version except the latest minor version.

title: Deprecating and removing macOS stacks
body: Removing stacks when a final Xcode version is released

title: Deprecating and removing macOS stacks
body: When Xcode 14 (final, non beta) was released, the following stacks were scheduled for removal:

title: Deprecating and removing macOS stacks
body: The oldest major version which was Xcode 11.7. In this scenario, Xcode 12.5 will become the oldest major version and the only Xcode 12 version available.

title: Deprecating and removing macOS stacks
body: The minor versions of the last major version except for the last couple of minor versions. This would mean keeping Xcode 13.4 and 13.3. Xcode 13.2, 13.1, and 13.0 will be removed unless they are used by more than 1% of all builds.

title: Deprecating and removing macOS stacks
body: This means that the latest patch release version of Xcode is supported for about 2.5 years, in sync with Xcode major version releases.

title: Deprecating Android & Docker stacks
body: An Android & Docker,on Ubuntu stack is supported for about two years, roughly in sync with Ubuntu LTS (long term support) releases.

title: Deprecating Android & Docker stacks
body: When a previous Android & Docker,on Ubuntu stack reaches end of maintenance, we deprecate the stack and earmark it for removal. At that point you can no longer select the stack for your apps. But the apps that are already using those stacks can keep using them until removal. We will warn you of scheduled removals well in advance so you can plan for them.

title: Preinstalled tools on Bitrise stacks
body: Every Bitrise stack comes up with a large number of preinstalled tools and applications. Check the list in the system reports repository.

title: Preinstalled tools on Bitrise stacks
body: Every Bitrise stack comes up with a large number of preinstalled tools and applications to make sure the build process of your apps is as smooth and fast as possible.

The System Report scripts are also open source, so if you want to run it yourself or you want to add another tool or system check, feel free to send us a pull request!

title: Preinstalled tools on Bitrise stacks

title: M1 stacks
body: Bitrise offers the Apple silicon M1 stacks for all credit-based accounts. We recommend using the latest version of our Steps on the M1 stacks.

title: M1 stacks
body: Apple announced the Apple silicon M1 chip, in 2020. This represents a fundamental change in hardware architecture and it means that in the future, all iOS and macOS development will take place on Macs with Apple silicon. As such, Bitrise is offering a virtualized M1 environment for CI/CD purposes: our Xcode stacks run on M1 machines by default. You can still select Intel-based Xcode stacks but we recommend switching over to M1 machines which offer significantly improved performance.

title: Selecting an M1-based stack for your build
body: You have two options for selecting an M1-based stack, just like with any other stack:

title: Selecting an M1-based stack for your build
body: Selecting it in the Workflow Editor.

title: Selecting an M1-based stack for your build
body: Adding it as a meta property in the bitrise.yml file.

title: Selecting an M1-based stack for your build
body: Workflow Editor

title: Selecting an M1-based stack for your build
body: bitrise.yml

title: Selecting an M1-based stack for your build
body: Open your app on Bitrise.

title: Selecting an M1-based stack for your build
body: Click the Workflows button on the main page.

title: Selecting an M1-based stack for your build
body: Find the relevant stack selector menu:

title: Selecting an M1-based stack for your build
body: If you want to set the default stack for all Workflows, find the Default stacks section.

title: Selecting an M1-based stack for your build
body: If you want to set Workflow-specific stacks, find the Workflow Specific Stacks section and choose a Workflow.

title: Selecting an M1-based stack for your build
body: In the dropdown menu, select an Xcode stack with Xcode version 13 or higher.

title: Selecting an M1-based stack for your build
body: In the Machine type for the default stack section, select one of the M1 machines.

title: Selecting an M1-based stack for your build
body: Click Save in the top right corner.

title: Selecting an M1-based stack for your build
body: Open your app's bitrise.yml file.

title: Selecting an M1-based stack for your build
body: Add a meta entry with a bitrise.io property that contains two properties: stack and machine_type_id, to specify the stack ID and the machine type.

title: Selecting an M1-based stack for your build
body: Find the stack IDs on the system reports page: the filenames without the .log extension are the stack IDs. To use an M1-based stack, you must select one of the stacks with Xcode version 13 or higher.

title: Selecting an M1-based stack for your build
body: Find the machine type here: Build machine types. For M1 machines, you have three options, depending on your subscription plan: g2-m1.8core, g2-m1-max.5core, g2-m1-max.10core.

title: Selecting an M1-based stack for your build
body: You can set a default stack or Workflow-specific stacks:

title: Selecting an M1-based stack for your build
body: For the default stack, add the meta property at the top level of the structure. It should be on the same level as, for example, format_version. We recommend putting it at the end of the file:

title: Selecting an M1-based stack for your build
body:
meta:  
 bitrise.io:       
    stack: osx-xcode-13.4.x    
 machine_type_id: g2-m1.8core

title: Selecting an M1-based stack for your build
body: If you want to set a Workflow-specific stack, you need to add the meta entry under the Workflow itself:

title: Selecting an M1-based stack for your build
body:
workflows:
 deploy: 
 meta:      
 bitrise.io:       
 stack: osx-xcode-13.4.x
  machine_type_id: g2-m1.8core

title: Selecting an M1-based stack for your build
body: In this example, we're setting a Workflow-specific stack for the deploy Workflow.

title: Transitioning to M1 from Intel-based stacks
body: Switching your development environment from Intel-based architecture to Apple silicon is a major change and it affects CI/CD as well. At Bitrise, we've tried to make sure the transition is as seamless as possible: we've updated our Steps and we've installed M1-compatible versions of the most important tools on the M1 stacks.

title: Transitioning to M1 from Intel-based stacks
body: This means that for the most part, if you use the official Bitrise Steps, your builds should work as they always did. Still, we strongly recommend testing everything locally, on your own M1 machines. You can use the Bitrise CLI to do so.

title: Transitioning to M1 from Intel-based stacks
body: Bitrise Step versions

title: Transitioning to M1 from Intel-based stacks
body: Always use the latest version of any Bitrise Step in your Workflow on the M1 stacks! They are designed to be backwards compatible with the Intel-based stacks, too.

title: Transitioning to M1 from Intel-based stacks
body: There are also some limitations, and some changes to be aware of when it comes to transitioning from Intel-based stacks to M1. We'll go through the most important ones.

title: Using Rosetta
body: Rosetta is an emulator/translator designed by Apple to bridge the compatibilities between Intel and Apple silicon processors. It translates Intel-targeting executables so that they can run on M1-equipped machines.

title: Using Rosetta
body: Rosetta has been installed and enabled on our stacks. To use it, add the arch -x86_64 prefix in front of each command you run in your scripts. This tells the system to use x86_64 instructions.

title: Using Rosetta
body: Rosetta limitations

title: Using Rosetta
body: Rosetta can't translate:

title: Using Rosetta
body: Kernel extensions.

title: Using Rosetta
body: Virtual Machine apps that virtualize x86_64 computer platforms.

title: Xcode and MacOS version requirement
body: The most important requirement is that you need to use Xcode 13.0 or above. It is highly recommended to transition to Xcode 13.0 or higher anyway, as Apple no longer accepts apps submitted to the App Store if they were built with older Xcode versions.

title: Xcode and MacOS version requirement
body: As for the operating system, M1 requires MacOS Monterey. Big Sur isn't compatible with Apple silicon. As such, our M1 stacks run on Monterey.

title: Android SDK version requirement
body: All Xcode stacks include the Android SDK, too, as part of our support for cross-platform apps.

title: Android SDK version requirement
body: On M1 stacks, Android 32 is installed, as Google hasn't introduced M1 compatibility to earlier versions.

title: Changes to Homebrew's default path
body: Homebrew is the most popular package manager for macOS and it is of course available on Bitrise, on both Intel-based and M1 stacks.

title: Changes to Homebrew's default path
body: There is one important difference: the default path for packages has changed:

title: Changes to Homebrew's default path
body: On Intel-based Macs, the default path for packages is /usr/local/.

title: Changes to Homebrew's default path
body: On M1-based Macs, the default paths for packages are /usr/local/bin/, /usr/local/share/, and /usr/local/lib/.

title: Changes to Homebrew's default path
body: This is only important if your build uses hard-coded paths to access Homebrew packages. In that case you need to change the path to the M1 version.

title: Caching
body: Caching on Bitrise works on the basis of branches: running the same Workflow on a different branch of a repository creates a different cache archive.

title: Caching
body: The Cache:Pull Step makes sure that the downloadable cache was generated on the same stack and CPU architecture as the currently running build. If, for example, you are trying to run a build on an Intel-based stack and the Step only finds a cache archive that was generated on an M1-based stack, it won't download the cache. This is in order to avoid stability problems that comes from using cache that was generated on the other CPU architecture.

title: Caching
body: This means, in practice, that there is only ever one active cache on a given branch: it's either an M1-based or an Intel-based cache but never both. If you run the Cache:Push Step on a Workflow that has a cache archive from a different architecture, the Step will overwrite that cache archive.

title: Caching
body: Caching Step version requirements

title: Caching
body: The logic of differentiating between cache archives based on the CPU architecture doesn't work on older versions of the caching Steps:

title: Caching
body: The Cache:Pull Step must be version 2.6.0 or higher. Older versions will download any cache archive they find, regardless of CPU architecture.

title: Caching
body: The Cache:Push Step must be version 2.7.0 or higher. Older versions won't add metadata related to the CPU architecture.

title: Other known issues and limitations
body: M1 has some other limitations and known issues. We're working hard at making sure we have a working solution for most use cases.

title: Android emulation is unavailable
body: The M1 stacks don't support using an Android emulator in your builds. This is because Bitrise runs your builds on virtual machines and the Apple silicon architecture doesn't allow nested virtualization.

title: Android emulation is unavailable
body: You can, however, still use Firebase Test Lab to run Android device tests on Bitrise: Device testing for Android.

title: Hanging builds issue
body: There is a bug in Apple's hypervisor framework that can cause issues in virtualized environments like ours. The issue can occur whenever a simulator is launched: for example, our Xcode Test for iOS Step uses an iOS simulator to run tests. Once the simulator starts, your build can hang indefinitely. This doesn't happen every time a simulator is launched so the majority of your builds will be unaffected but the issue can and does happen.

title: Hanging builds issue
body: The issue has been reported to Apple and a fix coming out with macOS Ventura is being tested. In the meantime, we recommend using a workaround.

title: Hanging builds issue
body: Detecting and aborting hanging Steps without output

title: Hanging builds issue
body: If you are experiencing hanging Steps other than the Start Xcode simulator Step, check out our guide on Detecting and aborting hanging Steps without output.

title: Hanging builds issue
body: The workaround is simple: you launch an Xcode simulator at the start of the build, check whether it hangs and if it does, restart the Workflow so that the hanging issue doesn't waste your time and credits.

title: Hanging builds issue
body: Add the Start Xcode simulator Step as the very first Step Workflow.

title: Hanging builds issue
body: It's important to launch the simulator before anything else, even before cloning the repository. If the issue doesn't occur, booting up the simulator should only take a few seconds and you can use it later in the Workflow to run your tests.

title: Hanging builds issue
body: Add a 90-second boot timeout to the Step. You can do it either in the Workflow Editor or in the bitrise.yml file:

title: Hanging builds issue
body: Destination device

title: Hanging builds issue
body: Make sure to also set the simulator destination in the Device destination specifier input of the Step. In the bitrise.yml file, the input's name is destination.

title: Hanging builds issue
body: You can find the available destination devices in Xcode.

title: Hanging builds issue
body: On the graphical UI of the Workflow Editor: find the Simulator boot timeout (in seconds) input and set it to 90.

title: Hanging builds issue
body: In the bitrise.yml, you need to set the wait_for_boot_timeout input to 90:

title: Hanging builds issue
body:
- xcode-start-simulator:
 inputs:
 - destination: platform=iOS Simulator,name=iPhone 8,OS=latest
 - wait_for_boot_timeout: 90

title: Hanging builds issue
body: Add the Trigger Bitrise workflow Step to your Workflow right after the Start Xcode simulator Step.

title: Hanging builds issue
body: We will use this Step to detect whether the previous Step hung and if it did, to restart your build.

title: Hanging builds issue
body: Set the Step to run even if a previous Step failed. You can do it either in the Workflow Editor or in the bitrise.yml file

title: Hanging builds issue
body: In the graphical UI of the Workflow Editor: find the Run if previous Step failed toggle and switch it on.

title: Hanging builds issue
body: In the bitrise.yml file: set the is_always_run attribute to true.

title: Hanging builds issue
body:
- trigger-bitrise-workflow:
 is_always_run: true

title: Hanging builds issue
body: Set the run_if attribute: the Step should only run if the Start Xcode simulator ended up with a hanged status.

title: Hanging builds issue
body: The Start Xcode simulator Step exports an Env Var that stores the status of the simulator. This is what we'll use to detect whether the build hung.

title: Hanging builds issue
body: YAML mode only!

title: Hanging builds issue
body: You can only do this in the bitrise.yml file of your app.

title: Hanging builds issue
body:
- trigger-bitrise-workflow:
 is_always_run: true
 run_if: '{{enveq "BITRISE_SIMULATOR_STATUS" "hanged"}}'

title: Hanging builds issue
body: Configure the API token and the Workflow ID:

title: Hanging builds issue
body: Build Trigger API token: You can find it on the Code tab of your app's page on Bitrise.

title: Hanging builds issue
body: Workflow ID: The name of the Workflow that you want to trigger. In this case, it should be the same Workflow.

title: Hanging builds issue
body: In the bitrise.yml file, the Step should look something like this:

title: Hanging builds issue
body:
- trigger-bitrise-workflow:
 is_always_run: true
 run_if: '{{enveq "BITRISE_SIMULATOR_STATUS" "hanged"}}'
 inputs:
 - api_token: $TRIGGER_TOKEN
 - workflow_id: my-workflow-name

title: Hanging builds issue
body: Full YAML example

title: Hanging builds issue
body:
- xcode-start-simulator:
 inputs:
 - destination: platform=iOS Simulator,name=iPhone 8,OS=latest
 - wait_for_boot_timeout: 90
- trigger-bitrise-workflow:
 is_always_run: true
 run_if: '{{enveq "BITRISE_SIMULATOR_STATUS" "hanged"}}'
 inputs:
 - api_token: $TRIGGER_TOKEN
 - workflow_id: my-workflow-name

title: Hanging builds issue
body: That's it. If your build hangs at the simulator stage, it will automatically restart itself within 90 seconds, ensuring that the issue doesn't end up wasting a huge amount of time.

title: The Android/Linux/Docker environment
body: Bitrise's Android stacks run on Linux-based virtual machines that are created from Docker images. You can find all the image files on GitHub.

title: The Android/Linux/Docker environment
body: For our Linux-based stacks, we use standard Docker images, published on Quay, and the related Dockerfile which you can find on GitHub (see below).

title: The Android/Linux/Docker environment
body: What is a Dockerfile?

title: The Android/Linux/Docker environment
body: A Dockerfile is a file where you describe the docker image / environment and is directly used to build a Docker image.

title: The Android/Linux/Docker environment
body: Pre-installed tools

title: The Android/Linux/Docker environment
body: All stacks have a large number of pre-installed tools available: Preinstalled tools on Bitrise stacks

title: The Android/Linux/Docker environment
body: Right now we have four docker images, built on top of each other:

title: The Android/Linux/Docker environment
body: Bitrise Base image (Link)

title: The Android/Linux/Docker environment
body: Image name ID: quay.io/bitriseio/bitrise-base-20.04.

title: The Android/Linux/Docker environment
body: Includes all the non-Android tools and environment setup.

title: The Android/Linux/Docker environment
body: Ideal to be used for non-Android projects as a base image, if you want to use it locally too, as this is the smallest image.

title: The Android/Linux/Docker environment
body: Ruby, Go, Python, git and the bitrise command line tools are all preinstalled and ready to use.

title: The Android/Linux/Docker environment
body: OS: Ubuntu 20.04, 64 bit.

title: The Android/Linux/Docker environment
body: Check out the related Dockerfile where you can see what’s preinstalled in this image.

title: The Android/Linux/Docker environment
body: Base Android image (Link)

title: The Android/Linux/Docker environment
body: Image name ID: quay.io/bitriseio/android-20.04.

title: The Android/Linux/Docker environment
body: Extends the Bitrise Base image with Android-specific tools and environments.

title: The Android/Linux/Docker environment
body: Multiple Android SDK, build tool and system image versions are preinstalled, as well as gradle and maven.

title: The Android/Linux/Docker environment
body: You can use the $ANDROID_HOME environment variable to point to the location of the pre-installed Android SDK.

title: The Android/Linux/Docker environment
body: Check out the related Dockerfile where you can see what’s preinstalled in this image.

title: The Android/Linux/Docker environment
body: Android NDK image (Link)

title: The Android/Linux/Docker environment
body: Image name ID: quay.io/bitriseio/android-ndk-20.04.

title: The Android/Linux/Docker environment
body: Built on the Base Android image and extends it with the latest Android NDK.

title: The Android/Linux/Docker environment
body: You can use the $ANDROID_NDK_HOME environment variable to point to the location of the preinstalled Android NDK, and it’s also added to $PATH.

title: The Android/Linux/Docker environment
body: Check out the related Dockerfile where you can see what’s preinstalled in this image.

title: The Android/Linux/Docker environment
body: Every build runs in a new VM, not just in a new container. The VM is destroyed right after the build. This allows us to grant you full control over Docker and the whole environment.

title: The Android/Linux/Docker environment
body: When your build starts on the Docker based Stack, we volume mount the /var/run/docker.sock socket into your container (similar to calling docker run -v /var/run/docker.sock:/var/run/docker.sock .... You can find a description about this access granting method here).

title: The Android/Linux/Docker environment
body: The docker binary has to be installed inside the base Docker image because docker started to migrate from a single-binary solution to dynamically loaded components, and simply sharing the docker binary is not sufficient anymore.

title: The Android/Linux/Docker environment
body: We install Docker in every one of our Docker images so that you don’t have to do anything if you use our image, or you base your own image on our Docker images.

title: The Android/Linux/Docker environment
body: This means that you have access to docker in your container, and can use other tools which use docker, like docker-compose. You can, for example, configure and run tests and other automations on website projects using docker-compose.

title: The Android/Linux/Docker environment
body: You can call docker info, docker build, docker run, docker login, docker push exactly how you would on your own machine.

title: The Android/Linux/Docker environment
body: Shared volumes

title: The Android/Linux/Docker environment
body: If you want to run docker in your build and share volumes, please note that only those volumes can be shared that are shared with the base docker container (the one your build is running in). This is due to how docker handles volume sharing. Everything under /bitrise can be mounted as a volume, but no other path is guaranteed to work with --volume mapping.

title: The Android/Linux/Docker environment
body: It means that if you use the standard paths and you use relative paths to mount volumes, it’ll work as expected, as the default source code directory is located inside /bitrise (by default it’s /bitrise/src in our Docker images).

title: The Android/Linux/Docker environment
body: What WON’T WORK, however, is if you change the source code directory to be located outside of /bitrise, or you want to mount a folder with an absolute path outside of /bitrise.

title: Managing Java versions
body: All Bitrise virtual machines have Java 8, Java 11, and Java 17 pre-installed. The default version is Java 17 but you can switch versions at any time.

title: Managing Java versions
body: By default, every Bitrise stack comes with Java 11 pre-installed and ready to use. If you do not switch to another version, your build will use Java 11.

title: Managing Java versions
body: In addition to 11, we have two more Java versions pre-installed on all stacks:

title: Managing Java versions
body: Java 8

title: Managing Java versions
body: Java 17

title: Managing Java versions
body: You can switch between the versions at any time. You can also install a different Java version (for example, 14).

title: Managing Java versions
body: Potential issues with Java versions

title: Managing Java versions
body: Using a new Java version, or switching Java versions during a build might cause unexpected issues:

title: Managing Java versions
body: JAVA_HOME isn't set correctly after switching to Java 11 on macOS-based stacks

title: Managing Java versions
body: Using Android SDK tools with Java 11

title: Managing Java versions
body: java.lang.ClassNotFoundException

title: Setting Java version with the Set Java version Step
body: Each Bitrise stack has three different Java versions pre-installed: 8, 11 (the default version), and 17. You can easily switch between the different Java versions with our Set Java version Step. The Step allows you to set the global Java version of the virtual machine that runs your build.

title: Setting Java version with the Set Java version Step
body: Installing a new Java version

title: Setting Java version with the Set Java version Step
body: This Step cannot install any Java version. It can only switch between the versions that are pre-installed on our stacks. If you want to install a Java version that is not available on our stacks by default, check out Installing a Java version on an Android stack.

title: Setting Java version with the Set Java version Step
body: Add the Set Java version Step to your Workflow. We recommend setting it as the first Step of the Workflow.

title: Setting Java version with the Set Java version Step
body: Find the Java version to be set globally for the build input.

title: Setting Java version with the Set Java version Step
body: Set it to the version you need.

title: Setting Java version with the Set Java version Step
body: The options are:

title: Setting Java version with the Set Java version Step
Setting Java version with the Set Java version Step
body: 11 (the default value)

title: Setting Java version with the Set Java version Step
Setting Java version with the Set Java version Step
body: YAML example

title: Setting Java version with the Set Java version Step
body: In this example, we're setting the Java version to 17 in the bitrise.yml file.

title: Setting Java version with the Set Java version Step
body:
primary:
 steps:
 - set-java-version@1:
 inputs:
 - set_java_version: '17'

title: Setting Java versions with a Script Step
body: If you don't want to use the Set Java version Step to change the default Java version on the build machines, you don't have to: you can accomplish the same thing using a Script Step.

title: Setting Java versions with a Script Step
body: Our Android & Docker stacks run on virtual machines with Ubuntu, while our Xcode stacks run on macOS. The process is a little different for the different stack types but on all stacks, switching to a different Java version requires three things:

title: Setting Java versions with a Script Step
body: Setting Java itself and the Java compiler to the selected version.

title: Setting Java versions with a Script Step
body: Setting the JAVA_HOME Environment Variable with the export command.

title: Setting Java versions with a Script Step
body: Storing this Environment Variable with envman so it can be accessed by all Steps in your Workflow.

title: Setting Java versions with a Script Step
body: Steps and Env Vars

title: Setting Java versions with a Script Step
body: You need envman because without that, Steps can’t access each other’s Environment Variables. If you only set the Java environment for one Step, but do not store it with envman, the other Steps will use the default Java environment, Java 11.

title: On macOS-based stacks
body: Open your app on Bitrise.

title: On macOS-based stacks
body: Click the Workflows button on the main page.

title: On macOS-based stacks
body: Select a Workflow from the WORKFLOW dropdown menu.

title: On macOS-based stacks
body: Add a Script Step to the Workflow before any Step that uses Java in any way.

title: On macOS-based stacks
body: The simplest way to do it is to place it as the first Step of the Workflow.

title: On macOS-based stacks
body: Add one of the following commands to the Script content input of the Step:

title: On macOS-based stacks
body: To set the global Java version for the build to Java 11:

title: On macOS-based stacks
body:
jenv global 11
export JAVA_HOME="$(jenv prefix)"
envman add --key JAVA_HOME --value "$(jenv prefix)"

title: On macOS-based stacks
body: To set the global Java version for the build to Java 8:

title: On macOS-based stacks
body:
jenv global 1.8
export JAVA_HOME="$(jenv prefix)"
envman add --key JAVA_HOME --value "$(jenv prefix)"

title: On macOS-based stacks
body: Click Save at the top right corner.

title: On Ubuntu-based stacks
body: Open your app on Bitrise.

title: On Ubuntu-based stacks
body: Click the Workflows button on the main page.

title: On Ubuntu-based stacks
body: Select a Workflow from the WORKFLOW dropdown menu.

title: On Ubuntu-based stacks
body: Add a Script Step to the Workflow before any Step that uses Java in any way.

title: On Ubuntu-based stacks
body: The simplest way to do it is to place it as the first Step of the Workflow.

title: On Ubuntu-based stacks
body: Add the following commands to the Script content input of the Step:

title: On Ubuntu-based stacks
body: To set the global Java version for the build to Java 11:

title: On Ubuntu-based stacks
body:
sudo update-alternatives --set javac /usr/lib/jvm/java-11-openjdk-amd64/bin/javac
sudo update-alternatives --set java /usr/lib/jvm/java-11-openjdk-amd64/bin/java
 
export JAVA_HOME='/usr/lib/jvm/java-11-openjdk-amd64'
envman add --key JAVA_HOME --value '/usr/lib/jvm/java-11-openjdk-amd64'

title: On Ubuntu-based stacks
body: To set the global Java version for the build to Java 8:

title: On Ubuntu-based stacks
body:
sudo update-alternatives --set javac /usr/lib/jvm/java-8-openjdk-amd64/bin/javac
sudo update-alternatives --set java /usr/lib/jvm/java-8-openjdk-amd64/jre/bin/java
 
export JAVA_HOME='/usr/lib/jvm/java-8-openjdk-amd64'
envman add --key JAVA_HOME --value '/usr/lib/jvm/java-8-openjdk-amd64'

title: On Ubuntu-based stacks
body: Click Save at the top right corner.

title: Installing a Java version on an Android stack
body: If you need a Java or JDK version which is not installed on our Android stacks, follow this guide. The example below will install Java/JDK 1.14 with a Script Step. You can adapt it to the version of your choice.

title: Installing a Java version on an Android stack
body: Open your app on Bitrise.

title: Installing a Java version on an Android stack
body: Click the Workflows button on the main page.

title: Installing a Java version on an Android stack
body: Select a Workflow from the WORKFLOW dropdown menu.

title: Installing a Java version on an Android stack
body: Add the Script Step to your Workflow.

title: Installing a Java version on an Android stack
body: In the Script content input of the Step, add your script:

title: Installing a Java version on an Android stack
body: The example below installs Java 14 but feel free to replace the openjdk-14-jdk and java-1.14.0-openjdk-amd64 parts with your version of choice.

title: Installing a Java version on an Android stack
body:
#!/bin/bash
set -ex
 
add-apt-repository -y ppa:openjdk-r/ppa
apt-get update -qq
apt-get install -y openjdk-14-jdk
update-java-alternatives -s /usr/lib/jvm/java-1.14.0-openjdk-amd64
echo "done"

title: Installing a Java version on an Android stack
body: Start a new build. This Script Step can be the very first Step in the Workflow, as it does not depend on anything else.

title: Code security
body: Every Bitrise build runs in a new virtual machine that has no access to previous builds. We do not store your source code and you can set up how it is accessed.

title: Code security
body: To guarantee the security of your code, every Bitrise build runs in its own, clean virtual machine and we discard the whole virtual machine after the build finishes, erasing every file your build uses and every change you make during your build.

title: Code security
body: This is also true for the Android & Docker stacks, which use Docker containers to run the build. The build itself still gets a full virtual machine where no other Docker container is started, only the one used as the environment of the build. In short, we only use Docker containers to manage the environment, not for build environment isolation - that’s ensured by using full virtual machines for every build.

title: Code security
body: This way your builds are always protected from changes made by others and from your previous builds, no one else can access your code and you can use a stable environment to define your build Workflow. Every build is completed in an isolated environment, unrelated to any previous or parallelly running builds.

title: Source code
body: We don’t store your source code. The source code is only accessed on the build machines (virtual machines) the way you define it in your Bitrise configuration. If you don’t have a Git Clone Step or some other Step that accesses your Git repository in your configuration, then the source code won’t be touched at all. At the end of the build the whole virtual machine is destroyed. As such, any change you made to your source code on the virtual machine will be lost unless you commit your changes and push them to a remote repository.

title: Code signing and other files
body: The files you upload in the Code Signing tab of the Workflow Editor are stored on Amazon S3 in a way that it’s only accessible for the web servers.

title: Code signing and other files
body: The required credentials are not stored in any database, it is only available in the web servers’ environment. Build servers can’t access the files directly either. When a build starts, the web server generates a read-only, time limited access URL for these files, using Amazon S3 pre-signed URLs.

title: Passwords
body: Passwords are stored in a hashed, encrypted form. We are encrypting the passwords with bcrypt algorithm, using multiple stretches.

title: Customizable enterprise build platforms
body: Bitrise offers two types of custom build platforms for enterprises: dedicated build platforms behind the Bitrise firewall and private build platforms on the user's own environment.

title: Customizable enterprise build platforms
body: Using a custom enterprise build platform means running your Bitrise builds on virtual machines (VM) dedicated and specifically configured to your needs. With a private cloud, you have complete control over how and when your builds run.

title: Customizable enterprise build platforms
body: Bitrise offers two types of custom build platforms for enterprises:

title: Customizable enterprise build platforms
body: Dedicated build platform: a set of dedicated machines behind the Bitrise firewall. These machines will have the same public IP address as any Bitrise build machine but they are reserved for your exclusive use.

title: Customizable enterprise build platforms
body: Private build platform: this solution includes your own firewall, storage capacity, and vSphere environment. This allows you to create a custom virtualization configuration, as well as a site-to-site VPN. With the latter, data will never leave your network and you do not have to separately connect to a VPN with each build.

title: Customizable enterprise build platforms
body: The private build platform is an advanced set-up with plenty of configuration options. To learn more about the details, contact us!

title: Customizable enterprise build platforms
body: Check out the most important differences between the dedicated and the private build platforms:

title: Customizable enterprise build platforms
body: Dedicated vs private build platform

title: Using your own Docker image
body: You can use your own Docker image on Bitrise, as well as run custom Docker commands in your Workflow. Use either a custom image from Docker Hub or your own Dockerfile.

title: Using your own Docker image
body: On Bitrise, every single build runs in its own, separate virtual machine that is destroyed at the end of the build. On our Android stacks, we use Docker for this purpose. Our stacks have pre-installed Docker images but you can use your own custom image, and run custom Docker commands in your Workflow. There are two ways to use your own Docker configuration on Bitrise:

title: Using your own Docker image
body: Run docker commands yourself during your build. To do so, use one or more Script Step.

title: Using your own Docker image
body: Set a custom image in the Workflow Editor.

title: Using your own Docker image
body: No Docker on macOS stacks

title: Using your own Docker image
body: Docker isn't installed on any of our macOS-based stacks; our guides related to Docker only apply to Linux-based stacks.

title: Using your own Docker image
body: We recommend that you run docker commands with a Script Step as you should NOT CHANGE the base environment Docker image on the Stack tab unless you really have to! Running the docker commands yourself during the build is more flexible and provides an overall higher level of control.

title: Using your own Docker image
body: GitHub sample repository

title: Using your own Docker image
body: You can find a sample repository on GitHub, which is configured to run on your Mac/Linux using the Bitrise CLI.

title: Running docker commands with a Script Step
body: The recommended way of using a custom Docker configuration both locally and on bitrise.io, is to add a Script Step to your Workflow to run Docker commands. You can use the same Step to authenticate yourself to a service such as Docker Hub and to run your selected image.

title: Running docker commands with a Script Step
body: We provide three examples on how to run Docker commands using our Script Step:

title: Running docker hello-world
body: The official hello-world Docker image is hosted on Docker Hub. If you wish to use any of the images from Docker Hub, you must authenticate first.

title: Running docker hello-world
body: In this example, we’re following the official getting started guide to run the hello-world Docker image. In our example bitrise.yml file, you can see a simple build configuration that can run the image:

title: Running docker hello-world
body:
---
format_version: 11
default_step_lib_source: https://github.com/bitrise-io/bitrise-steplib.git
trigger_map:
- push_branch: "*"
 workflow: primary
- pull_request_source_branch: "*"
 workflow: primary
workflows:
 primary:
 steps:
 - activate-ssh-key@4:
 run_if: ''
 - git-clone@3.4.1: {}
 - script@1:
 title: docker run hello-world
 inputs:
 - content: |-
 #!/bin/bash
 # fail if any commands fails
 set -e
 # debug log
 set -x

 docker login -u $DOCKERHUB_USER -p $DOCKERHUB_TOKEN
 docker run hello-world

title: Building and running a Dockerfile
body: You can use your own Dockerfile on Bitrise in your repository to define the Docker environment:

title: Building and running a Dockerfile
body:
---
format_version: 11
default_step_lib_source: https://github.com/bitrise-io/bitrise-steplib.git
trigger_map:
- push_branch: "*"
 workflow: primary
- pull_request_source_branch: "*"
 workflow: primary
workflows:
 primary:
 steps:
 - activate-ssh-key@4:
 run_if: ''
 - git-clone@3.4.1: {}
 - script@1:
 title: docker run
 inputs:
 - content: |-
 #!/bin/bash
 # fail if any commands fails
 set -e
 # debug log
 set -x

 docker build -t bitrise-minimal-sample .
 docker run --rm bitrise-minimal-sample

title: Building and running a Dockerfile
body: This Workflow will:

title: Building and running a Dockerfile
body: Git clone your repository.

title: Building and running a Dockerfile
body: Run docker build -t bitrise-minimal-sample . and docker run --rm bitrise-minimal-sample in the repository’s root.

title: Building and running a Dockerfile
body: If you have a Dockerfile like this in the root of the repository:

title: Building and running a Dockerfile
body:
FROM alpine:3.3

CMD cat /etc/alpine-release

title: Using docker-compose
body: You can also run a Docker image from your own Docker file using the docker-compose command. With compose, you can configure your application’s services and then you can start all services with a single command.

title: Using docker-compose
body: For example, set up a docker-compose.yml like this in your repository root (where the Dockerfile is):

title: Using docker-compose
body:
version: '2'
services:
 sample-app:
 build: .

title: Using docker-compose
body: Now you can run your services with a single docker-compose call in your Script Step:

title: Using docker-compose
body:
- script@1.1.3:
 title: docker run
 inputs:
 - content: |-
 #!/bin/bash
 # fail if any commands fails
 set -e
 # debug log
 set -x
 docker-compose run --rm sample-app

title: Using docker-compose
body: Docker compose will build and run the image automatically. You don’t have to specify a -t tag since the services name will be used by docker-compose to tag the image automatically.

title: Using a custom Docker image from Docker Hub
body: You can use Bitrise with a Docker image pulled from Docker Hub, as you can see in our Running docker hello-world example. However, on a free plan for anonymous users, Docker Hub only allows a limited number of image pulls. If you set the image in the Workflow Editor, no authentication will be performed: your pull will be a pull by an anonymous user from a Bitrise public IP address. With many of our users going for this option, the Docker Hub rate limit would mean some users wouldn’t be able to start builds.

title: Using a custom Docker image from Docker Hub
body: The workaround is simple: you need to use a Script Step to authenticate yourself with your own Docker Hub account, and use the Step to pull the image from Docker Hub. To do so:

title: Using a custom Docker image from Docker Hub
body: Create a personal access token on Docker Hub.

title: Using a custom Docker image from Docker Hub
body: This will be used to authenticate you instead of your password.

title: Using a custom Docker image from Docker Hub
body: On Bitrise, create two Secret Environment Variables: one for your Docker Hub username and another for the personal access token.

title: Using a custom Docker image from Docker Hub
body: In our examples, we’ll use DOCKERHUB_USER for the Docker Hub username and DOCKERHUB_TOKEN.

title: Using a custom Docker image from Docker Hub
body: Use the docker login command in a Script Step to authenticate, with the Secret Env Vars as arguments:

title: Using a custom Docker image from Docker Hub
body:
- script@1.1.3: 
 inputs: 
 - content: | 
 docker login -u $DOCKERHUB_USER -p $DOCKERHUB_TOKEN

title: Using a custom Docker image from Docker Hub

title: Using a custom Docker image from Docker Hub
