title: Setting a custom Docker image in the Workflow Editor
body: In the Workflow Editor on bitrise.io, you have the option to set a path to a custom Docker image.

title: Setting a custom Docker image in the Workflow Editor
body: If you want to run your build in a custom Docker environment, we strongly recommend basing your own Docker image on one of our base Docker images. Our images have every base tool pre-installed, the standard Bitrise directories created, the environments (such as $BITRISE_DEPLOY_DIR) set, and are pre-cached on the build virtual machines.

title: Setting a custom Docker image in the Workflow Editor
body: However, if you decide to create your own Docker image please read this guide, from start to finish.

title: Setting a custom Docker image in the Workflow Editor
body: Custom Android docker image

title: Setting a custom Docker image in the Workflow Editor
body: Creating and maintaining your own Android Docker image can be quite time consuming! If you only need to install a couple of additional tools, you should do that, for example, with a Script Step instead! For more information, see our Install Any Additional Tool guide. You should only use your own Android docker image if you really have to!

title: Setting a custom Docker image in the Workflow Editor
body: Using an image hosted on Docker Hub

title: Setting a custom Docker image in the Workflow Editor
body: If you wish to use an image hosted on Docker Hub, do not set the image path on the Stack tab of the Workflow Editor! Use a Script Step instead to authenticate your Docker Hub account and run the selected image.

title: Creating your own image from a Bitrise image
body: We have four different Docker image types available. You can base your own image on any of these, depending on your needs.

title: Creating your own image from a Bitrise image
body: Using an image hosted on Docker Hub

title: Creating your own image from a Bitrise image
body: If you wish to use an image hosted on Docker Hub, do not set the image path on the Stack tab of the Workflow Editor! Use a Script Step instead to authenticate your Docker Hub account and run the selected image.

title: Creating your own image from a Bitrise image
body: Bitrise Docker image types

title: Creating your own image from a Bitrise image
body: To base your own image on one of our available images, specify your base image at the very top of your Dockerfile with a FROM instruction and the quay.io ID of the image. In our example, we’ll use the latest version of the Bitrise base image:

title: Creating your own image from a Bitrise image
body: FROM quay.io/bitriseio/docker-bitrise-base:latest

title: Creating your own image from a Bitrise image
body: You have to use the quay.io ID of the image you want to use as the base image. For example, quay.io/bitriseio/android, quay.io/bitriseio/android-ndk, quay.io/bitriseio/android-ndk-lts, or quay.io/bitriseio/bitrise-base.

title: Creating your own image from a Bitrise image
body: Don’t use the alpha images for your builds

title: Creating your own image from a Bitrise image
body: For every Docker image we have on quay.io, we have an alpha tagged version too. The alpha ones are frequently rebuilt and are NOT PRECACHED ON bitrise.io, so you should avoid those.

title: Using your created Docker image in a build
body: You can set your own Docker image in the Workflow Editor if the image can be pulled with the docker pull command. To do so:

title: Using your created Docker image in a build
body: Using an image hosted on Docker Hub

title: Using your created Docker image in a build
body: If you wish to use an image hosted on Docker Hub, do not set the image path on the Stack tab of the Workflow Editor! Use a Script Step instead to authenticate your Docker Hub account and run the selected image.

title: Using your created Docker image in a build
body: Go to your Workflow Editor.

title: Using your created Docker image in a build
body: Click the Stack tab.

title: Using your created Docker image in a build
body: Copy and paste the ID of your app. For example, quay.io/bitriseio/bitrise-base.

title: Using your created Docker image in a build
body: Click Save in the upper-right corner.

title: Using your created Docker image in a build
body: Now you should be able to use your own image to run your builds on bitrise.io.

title: Running your build locally in Docker
body: You can run a Bitrise build in Docker on your own machines: you need Docker, the Bitrise CLI, and a Bitrise Docker image.

title: Running your build locally in Docker
body: To be able to run your Linux stack builds locally, you’ll need docker:

title: Running your build locally in Docker
body: For Linux, just follow the official install instructions.

title: Running your build locally in Docker
body: For Mac, you can use Docker for Mac, which is the easiest way to get started.

title: Running your build locally in Docker
body: In this guide, we’ll use this Bitrise Android sample project.

title: Running your build locally in Docker
body: Large images ahead

title: Running your build locally in Docker
body: The official Bitrise Docker images are quite large because they include a wide variety of preinstalled tools. You’ll need at least 20-25 GB FREE DISC SPACE!

title: Running your build locally in Docker
body: If you’re not familiar with the Bitrise CLI, you should try that first. You don’t have to master the CLI, if you know what bitrise run WORKFLOW does, that should be enough for this tutorial.

title: Downloading docker images from quay.io
body: Install docker.

title: Downloading docker images from quay.io
body: Make sure you have your bitrise.yml in your repository.

title: Downloading docker images from quay.io
body: You don’t have to commit it, but the file must exist in your repository’s root directory.

title: Downloading docker images from quay.io
body: cd into your repository’s directory on your Mac/Linux.

title: Downloading docker images from quay.io
body: Pull the image from its registry:

title: Downloading docker images from quay.io
body: docker pull quay.io/bitriseio/android:latest

title: Downloading docker images from quay.io
body: Run the following command:

title: Downloading docker images from quay.io
body: docker run --privileged --env CI=false --volume "$(pwd):/bitrise/src" --volume "/var/run/docker.sock:/var/run/docker.sock" --rm quay.io/bitriseio/android:latest bitrise run WORKFLOW`

title: Downloading docker images from quay.io
body: If you want to just jump into the container and experiment inside, you can replace --rm quay.io/bitriseio/android:latest bitrise run WORKFLOW with -it quay.io/bitriseio/android:latest bash to start an interactive bash shell inside the container. For example:

title: Downloading docker images from quay.io
body: docker run --privileged --env CI=false --volume "$(pwd):/bitrise/src" --volume "/var/run/docker.sock:/var/run/docker.sock" -it quay.io/bitriseio/android:latest bash

title: Downloading docker images from quay.io
body: In general, if your project is an Android project but you don’t use Android NDK, to preserve precious disk space, you should use the quay.io/bitriseio/android docker image. You can find other official Bitrise docker images on our Quay page. In this example, we’re using the quay.io/bitriseio/android one.

title: Downloading docker images from quay.io
body: Download docker images from the Quay:

title: Downloading docker images from quay.io
body: docker pull quay.io/bitriseio/android:latest`

title: Downloading docker images from quay.io
body: Be aware that this can take quite a bit of time, as this image is over 10 GB. If the download fails or hangs, you can restart it any time by running the same command again.

title: Downloading docker images from quay.io
body: Download your Bitrise build configuration (bitrise.yml) to the root directory of your repository.

title: Downloading docker images from quay.io
body: You can download your project’s bitrise.yml from the bitrise.yml tab of your Workflow Editor on bitrise.io.

title: Downloading docker images from quay.io
body: In your Terminal / Command Line go to (cd) the root directory of your repository. Check if your bitrise.yml is at this location.

title: Downloading docker images from quay.io
body: If you try to reproduce an issue, you should git clone your repository into a NEW DIRECTORY, so that the directory will only contain the files which are committed into the repository! It’s a frequent reproducibility issue that you try to run the commands in your normal working directory, where you most likely have files which are not committed into your repository, for example, files which are in .gitignore.

title: Running the build
body: Run your build with the following command:

title: Running the build
body: docker run --privileged --env CI=false --volume "$(pwd):/bitrise/src" --volume "/var/run/docker.sock:/var/run/docker.sock" --rm quay.io/bitriseio/android:latest bitrise run WORKFLOW

title: Running the build
body: --rm quay.io/bitriseio/android:latest bitrise run WORKFLOW

title: Running the build
body: with -it quay.io/bitriseio/android:latest bash to start an interactive bash shell inside the container.

title: Running the build
body: For example:

title: Running the build
body: docker run --privileged --env CI=false --volume "$(pwd):/bitrise/src" --volume "/var/run/docker.sock:/var/run/docker.sock" -it quay.io/bitriseio/android:latest bash`.

title: Running the build
body: This command will share the current directory (the directory of your repository) as a shared volume with the docker container, and will make it available inside the container at the path /bitrise/src.

title: Running the build
body: After this, you can run bitrise run WORKFLOW, which will run the workflow inside the container. To exit from the container, just run exit.

title: Running the build
body: Don’t forget to replace WORKFLOW with the actual ID of your workflow in your bitrise.yml, with something like primary!

title: Running the build
body: The --env CI=false flag sets the environment variable CI to false - this will make Bitrise CLI skip certain steps that only make sense to run in a CI environment. For example, our Git Clone Step - you already have your code, so there’s no need to git clone it again inside the docker container (that’s why we shared the code directory as a --volume).

title: Running the build
body: The --rm flag tells docker to discard the container after the docker run command finishes. This means that if you run the command again, the only thing which will persist between the docker run .. commands are the files stored at the shared --volume (in your repository’s directory). Every other file that is generated into a temp or any other location will be discarded / won’t be kept.

title: Running the build
body: If you want to debug the container after a failed build, feel free to remove the --rm flag, and check out a Docker tutorial about how you can connect to an existing docker container. Please note that simply running the command again will not use the same container, but will create a new one!

title: Running the build
body: The --privileged flag allows access control of the host from the docker container, so you should never use this flag unless you trust the docker image you will use! This flag is required for allowing VPNs to work (to change network configs of the host), for example.

title: Running the build
body: The --volume "/var/run/docker.sock:/var/run/docker.sock" flag exposes the docker socket from the host for the container - this is required if you want to run other docker containers from within the container, or if you want to run any docker command during your build / inside the container.

title: Accounts
body: When you sign up for Bitrise, you create your own individual user account. By itself, having a user account isn’t enough to add apps and run builds. For that, you must be part of a Workspace.

title: Accounts
body: Your Bitrise account is managed from your account page. From this page, you can:

title: Accounts
body: Edit your profile, including username, email address, password, and avatar.

title: Accounts
body: Set up connection to other services, such as Git providers and Apple services.

title: Accounts
body: Enable two-factor authentication.

title: Accounts
body: Find all Workspaces that you're a part of.

title: Accounts
body: Create and manage personal access tokens used to access the Bitrise API.

title: Accounts
body: Register test devices.

title: Accounts
body: Can't run builds yet!

title: Accounts
body: When you sign up for Bitrise, you create your own individual user account. By itself, having a user account isn’t enough to add apps and run builds. To be able to work on Bitrise, you need at least one of three options:

title: Accounts
body: Creating a Workspace.

title: Accounts
body: Get invited to an existing Workspace.

title: Accounts
body: Get added as an outside contributor to an app’s team.

title: Connecting to services
body: You can connect your Git provider services, such as a GitHub/GitLab/Bitbucket account to your Bitrise account.

title: Connecting to services
body: To use all the features Bitrise offers, you might want to connect to services such as your Git provider or to any of the Apple services you use.

title: Connecting to services
body: Our guides explain how to connect your GitHub/GitLab/Bitbucket account to your Bitrise account (or a self-hosted GitLab instance to your Bitrise account if your Workspace uses it). You can connect only one account from a certain Git provider to Bitrise. You can disconnect and connect a new from another Git provider at any time.

title: Connecting to services
body: You will also learn what authentication methods you can use to connect Bitrise with your Apple services such as App Store Connect or Apple Developer Portal. Whether you use Apple ID and password or API key authentication, we got you covered.

title: The service credential user
body: The service credential is a user whose connected Git provider account (GitHub, GitLab or Bitbucket) is used to access those services for the purposes of Bitrise builds.

title: The service credential user
body: The service credential is a user whose connected Git provider account (GitHub, GitLab or Bitbucket) is used to access those Git services for certain actions that Bitrise can execute.

title: The service credential user
body: You need to set a service credential user, among other things, to:

title: The service credential user
body: Send build status reports back to your Git provider.

title: The service credential user
body: Use the Selective builds feature that allows you to specify certain files or directories in your repository that need to be modified to trigger an automatic Bitrise build.

title: The service credential user
body: Store the bitrise.yml file in your repository.

title: The service credential user
body: Actions and requirements

title: The service credential user
body: For the full list of actions and their access requirements, see Service credential user actions and their required repository access.

title: The service credential user
body: By default, the user who added the app to Bitrise is set as the service credential user. Even if you change it, it should always be a user who has access to the app's repository.

title: The service credential user
body: It isn't mandatory to have a service credential user: you can use the No service credential user setting to not have one. You'll still be able to run builds and trigger builds automatically but Bitrise won't be able to send build status reports to your Git provider, you won't be able to use the Selective builds feature or to store the bitrise.yml file in your repository.

title: Changing the service credential user
body: The service credential user can be changed at any time but each Bitrise user can only set themselves as the service credential user on the app.

title: Changing the service credential user
body: Role requirement

title: Changing the service credential user
body: To change the service credential user, you need to have Admin role on the app's team on Bitrise.

title: Changing the service credential user
body: To change the service credential user:

title: Changing the service credential user
body: Log in to Bitrise with the account that will be the new service credential user.

title: Changing the service credential user
body: Make sure that account has Admin role on the app's team.

title: Changing the service credential user
body: Go to your Workspace's Dashboard.

title: Changing the service credential user
body: Select the app where you want to change the service credential user

title: Changing the service credential user
body: Click on App Settings.

title: Changing the service credential user
body: On the left, select Integrations from the menu options.

title: Changing the service credential user
body: Scroll down to the Service credential user part.

title: Changing the service credential user
body: Click Change to YOUR_USERNAME.

title: Changing the service credential user
body: To confirm, click Set service credential user.

title: Service credential user actions and their required repository access
body: The service credential user allows Bitrise to execute a number of different actions that require access to the app's Git repository. Different actions require different levels of access: for example, to use a bitrise.yml file from the repository requires read access on GitHub while registering a new SSH key requires admin access.

title: Service credential user actions and their required repository access
body: The following table contains all the actions that require the service credential user, as well as the access level of the service credential user's account at the the three main Git providers.

title: Service credential user actions and their required repository access
body: Access requirements for the service credential user

title: Connecting your GitHub/GitLab/Bitbucket account to Bitrise
body: To take full advantage of all the features Bitrise offers, including automatic webhook registration, you need to connect your GitHub/GitLab/Bitbucket account to your Bitrise account.

title: Connecting your GitHub/GitLab/Bitbucket account to Bitrise
body: Connecting your GitHub/GitLab/Bitbucket account to your Bitrise account registers an OAuth application to your Git provider that allows Bitrise access to the repositories belonging to the account. This allows Bitrise to:

title: Connecting your GitHub/GitLab/Bitbucket account to Bitrise
body: List the available repositories when adding a new app.

title: Connecting your GitHub/GitLab/Bitbucket account to Bitrise
body: Automatically register webhooks. Webhooks allow setting up build triggers.

title: Connecting your GitHub/GitLab/Bitbucket account to Bitrise
body: Automatically register SSH keys.

title: Connecting your GitHub/GitLab/Bitbucket account to Bitrise
body: You can connect all three Git provider accounts to your Bitrise account, by one of two methods:

title: Connecting your GitHub/GitLab/Bitbucket account to Bitrise
body: Connecting the account when adding a new app.

title: Connecting your GitHub/GitLab/Bitbucket account to Bitrise
body: Connecting the account from your Profile settings page.

title: Connecting your GitHub/GitLab/Bitbucket account to Bitrise
body: One account per Git provider

title: Connecting your GitHub/GitLab/Bitbucket account to Bitrise
body: Please note that you cannot connect two accounts from the same Git provider (for example, two GitHub accounts) to Bitrise.

title: Connecting your GitHub/GitLab/Bitbucket account to Bitrise
body: Connecting one Git provider account is not final. You can disconnect an account and connect a different one at any time: Linked the wrong Git account to Bitrise.

title: Connecting a Git provider account when adding an app
body: Log in to your bitrise.io account.

title: Connecting a Git provider account when adding an app
body: Click the + symbol on the top menu bar and select Add new app.

title: Connecting a Git provider account when adding an app
body: On the Create New App page, select the account and set the app’s privacy setting.

title: Connecting a Git provider account when adding an app
body: Choose the Git service provider of the app’s repository. If no account with that provider has been connected to your Bitrise account, the UI will display the option to connect.

title: Connecting a Git provider account when adding an app
body: Click Connect GitHub/GitLab/Bitbucket. This will take you to the login page of the Git provider.

title: Connecting a Git provider account when adding an app
body: Log in to the Git provider account.

title: Connecting a Git provider account when adding an app
body: You should be prompted to authorize bitrise.io - do it! If successful, you should be redirected to Bitrise, and a pop-up message should inform you that you successfully linked the account. Click Okay.

title: Connecting a Git provider account from the Profile settings page
body: In the upper right corner, open the account selector dropdown menu.

title: Connecting a Git provider account from the Profile settings page

title: Connecting a Git provider account from the Profile settings page
body: This takes you to the Edit your profile page.

title: Connecting a Git provider account from the Profile settings page
body: On the left menu bar, click the toggle next to the name of the Git provider you wish to connect.

title: Connecting a Git provider account from the Profile settings page
body: Log in to the Git provider account.

title: Connecting a Git provider account from the Profile settings page
body: You should be prompted to authorize bitrise.io - do it! If successful, you should be redirected to Bitrise, and a pop-up message should inform you that you successfully linked the account. Click Okay.

title: Disconnecting a Git provider account
body: In the upper right corner, open the account selector dropdown menu.

title: Disconnecting a Git provider account
body: Select the Profile settings option.

title: Disconnecting a Git provider account
body: This takes you to the Edit your profile page.

title: Connecting self-hosted GitLab instances
body: For Workspaces, Bitrise supports connecting to self-hosted GitLab instances. Once it’s done, you can add apps to Bitrise from privately hosted repositories.

title: Connecting self-hosted GitLab instances
body: For Workspaces, Bitrise supports connecting to self-hosted GitLab instances. Connecting is simple, and once it’s done, you can add apps to Bitrise from privately hosted repositories. All functions that you got used to with publicly hosted repositories will be available!

title: Connecting self-hosted GitLab instances
body: Setting up an app that is in a self-hosted GitLab repository is very simple: Bitrise needs to be authorized as an application for the entire GitLab instance and then the Application Id and the Secret value belonging to the Bitrise OAuth application must be added to the Workspace on bitrise.io.

title: Configuring the GitLab connection
body: To access privately hosted GitLab repositories on Bitrise, you need to create a new OAuth application on your GitLab account, and assign the appropriate credentials to access your server.

title: Configuring the GitLab connection
body: Publicly resolvable IP address

title: Configuring the GitLab connection
body: Your self-hosted GitLab instance must have a publicly resolvable IP address, otherwise Bitrise won’t be able to connect to it.

title: Configuring the GitLab connection
body: Log in to your GitLab instance with root privileges. If you connect to Bitrise without root privileges, your Workspace’s other team members will not have access to the repository on the GitLab instance.

title: Configuring the GitLab connection
body: Go to the admin area by clicking the little wrench icon on the top menu bar.

title: Configuring the GitLab connection
body: On the left menu bar, select Applications, then click New Application.

title: Configuring the GitLab connection
body: In the Name field, enter a name that clearly identifies the application. For the sake of simplicity, we recommend Bitrise.

title: Configuring the GitLab connection
body: In the Callback URL field, enter https://app.bitrise.io/users/auth/gitlab/callback.

title: Configuring the GitLab connection
body: In the Scopes menu, check api.

title: Configuring the GitLab connection
body: Set the Confidential option to No.

title: Configuring the GitLab connection
body: If the newly created app is configured to be confidential, Bitrise won't be able to access it!

title: Configuring the GitLab connection
body: Click Submit. On the next page, you should find the Application Id and a Secret. You’ll need both to connect to your GitLab instance on bitrise.io.

title: Configuring the GitLab connection
body: Log in to Bitrise and open the account selector dropdown menu in the top right.

title: Configuring the GitLab connection
body: Find your Workspace and click the little gear icon next to its name to get to your Workspace's profile page.

title: Configuring the GitLab connection
body: Select the Self-hosted GitLab option on the left menu bar.

title: Configuring the GitLab connection
body: Add your self-hosted GitLab credentials:

title: Configuring the GitLab connection
body: App ID

title: Configuring the GitLab connection
body: Secret

title: Configuring the GitLab connection
body: Self-hosted URL

title: Configuring the GitLab connection
body: You are done! Now you are able to access your privately hosted repositories with Bitrise.

title: Adding a new app from a self-hosted GitLab repository
body: Log in to bitrise.io and click the + symbol on the top menu bar and select Add new app on web UI from the options.

title: Adding a new app from a self-hosted GitLab repository
body: Select the Workspace that will be the owner of the app.

title: Adding a new app from a self-hosted GitLab repository
body: When prompted to select your Git provider, select GitLab. Select the Self-hosted option.

title: Adding a new app from a self-hosted GitLab repository
body: If you haven’t provided your self-hosted GitLab credentials to the Workspace before, you can do it at this stage.

title: Adding a new app from a self-hosted GitLab repository
body: Click Connect.

title: Adding a new app from a self-hosted GitLab repository
body: Once connected, proceed as usual: Adding a new app

title: Apple services connection
body: Connect your Bitrise builds to Apple services using either API key authentication or Apple ID authentication in order to manage iOS code signing and deployment.

title: Apple services connection
body: Your Workflow may contain Steps that need information from the Apple service you use, for example, the App Store Connect or the Apple Developer Portal. These two services are supported by the following Steps:

title: Apple services connection
body: Manage iOS Code Signing

title: Apple services connection
body: Deploy to App Store Connect with Deliver (formerly iTunes Connect)

title: Apple services connection
body: Deploy to App Store Connect - Application Loader (formerly iTunes Connect)

title: Apple services connection
body: fastlane

title: Apple services connection
body: To connect these Steps with the Apple service you wish to use while your build runs on Bitrise, you need to provide authentication data to Bitrise and select the established authentication method for your app.

title: Apple services connection
body: You can authenticate with Apple’s official API key or with Apple ID and password.

title: Apple two-factor authentication requirements
body: Apple’s two-factor authentication (2FA) provides an extra layer of security on your Apple account.

title: Apple two-factor authentication requirements
body: If you have been authenticating with the API key so far, you are not affected by the two-factor authentication requirement.

title: Apple two-factor authentication requirements
body: If, however, you have been authenticating with an Apple ID and a password, and the new 2FA requirement affects you, then you’ll have to reconnect your Apple Developer Account on the Apple Service connection page of your Bitrise profile. You’ll also have to provide the two-factor authentication/two-step verification code and an app-specific password as well. Please find the official Apple documentation on how to generate an app-specific password.

title: Steps that require connecting to your Apple Developer account
body: The following Steps require connection to Apple services (such as App Store Connect or the Apple Developer Portal). If you’re using any of these Steps, make sure you establish connection with the right method.

title: Steps that require connecting to your Apple Developer account
body: Steps requiring Apple authentication

title: Steps that require connecting to your Apple Developer account
body: Depending on which authentication you can use in your project, you have the following options:

title: Steps that require connecting to your Apple Developer account
body: API key authentication: If you can, we recommend you use this authentication method. It does not require two-factor authentication. All it takes is connecting to the Apple services by providing Name, Issuer ID, Key ID and upload a Private Key (.p8), then selecting an account under the Team tab in your app’s settings. The data you give automatically populates the respective fields of the Steps that work with API key authentication.

title: Steps that require connecting to your Apple Developer account
body: Apple ID authentication: If you cannot use the API key authentication, you can authenticate with your Apple ID and password. Provide your Apple ID, password, 2FA code and app-specific password then select an account under the Team tab in your app’s settings. The data you give automatically populates the respective fields of the Steps that work with the Apple ID authentication.

title: Steps that require connecting to your Apple Developer account
body: API key or Apple Id authentication through Step inputs: If you wish to deploy to multiple teams or deploy to a team where authentication is different from the connected one you’ve been using, then you can add your preferred authentication into the Step’s inputs. Some Steps, such as Xcode Archive & Export for iOS, only have an API key authentication override option, while some Steps, like fastlane, have options for both API key and Apple ID Step level authentication override.

title: Apple service permissions
body: In order to successfully connect Bitrise to Apple services, you need to set up the right roles and accesses in your Apple account for your Apple ID and your API keys.

title: Apple service permissions
body: In order to successfully connect Bitrise to Apple services, you need to set up the right roles and accesses in your Apple account for your Apple ID and your API keys. You must set up the appropriate access rights to be able to:

title: Apple service permissions
body: Use automatic code signing.

title: Apple service permissions
body: Deploy your app to the App Store.

title: Apple service permissions
body: The exact roles and accesses you need depend on a number of factors: your authentication method, whether you use Xcode managed signing, and the details of your app deployment process, among other things.

title: Apple service permissions
body: In this guide, we'll list the roles based on the two main authentication methods: API key authentication and Apple ID authentication.

title: Required access with API key authentication
body: To use Bitrise Steps with Apple API key authentication, you need to create an App Store Connect API key with the appropriate access level. The appropriate level depends on what you need to do.

title: Required access with API key authentication
body: If, for example, you use Xcode managed signing in your project and wish to export the generated IPA file with a Distribution certificate and an App Store provisioning profile, the App Store Connect API key must have Admin access.

title: Required access with API key authentication
body: Table 1, “ contains the required access for automatic code signing. In the table, we grouped code signing actions based on the type of the IPA file we're attempting to export. There are two main types:

title: Required access with API key authentication
body: Development IPA: this is an IPA exported with the development method.

title: Connecting to an Apple service with API key

title: Connecting to an Apple service with API key

title: Connecting to an Apple service with API key
body: The API key authentication is the recommended way when connecting Bitrise to Apple Services. You can have 50 API keys added to the Apple Services connection page but your project can use only one.

title: Connecting to an Apple service with API key

title: Adding Apple ID authentication data on Bitrise
body: Your authentication expires in 30 days and you will have to authenticate again. When that happens, go to the Apple Service connection page, it will automatically ask for the two-factor authentication (2FA) code to authenticate again. There will be a list of the Apple Developer accounts that you have defined. To the far right of the Apple ID connection, there are 3 dots. Click the dots and select Re-authenticate (2SA/2FA).

title: Steps requiring Apple authentication
body: Check out all the Bitrise Steps that require a connection to an Apple service using either an API key or an Apple ID.

title: Steps requiring Apple authentication
body: In this guide we list all the Steps that require authentication and the authentication methods that you can choose from depending on your app’s requirement.

title: Manage iOS Code Signing Step
body: This Step takes care of setting up the required code signing assets before your project is built on Bitrise. The Step uses your API key or your Apple ID and password authentication to connect to an Apple service. Once connection is configured, the Step will:

title: Manage iOS Code Signing Step
body: Generate, update and download the provisioning profiles needed for your iOS project.

title: Manage iOS Code Signing Step
body: Verify and register the project's Bundle IDs on the Apple Developer Site.

title: Manage iOS Code Signing Step
body: Register the iOS devices connected to your Bitrise account with the App Store Connect.

title: Xcode Archive & Export for iOS Step
body: The Step archives your Xcode project by running the xcodebuild archive command and then exports the archive into an IPA file with the xcodebuild -exportArchive command. This IPA file can be shared, installed on test devices, or uploaded to the App Store Connect.

title: Xcode Archive & Export for iOS Step
body: The Step can also perform iOS code signing if the Automatic code signing method input specifies a method. By default, it's turned off. To perform iOS code signing, it can use API key or Apple ID authentication.

title: Export iOS and tvOS Xcode archive Step
body: Exports an IPA from an existing iOS and tvOS .xcarchive file. You can add multiple Export iOS and tvOS Xcode archive Steps to your Workflows to create multiple different signed IPA files.

title: Export iOS and tvOS Xcode archive Step
body: The Step can also perform iOS code signing if the Automatic code signing method input specifies a method. By default, it's turned off. To perform iOS code signing, it can use API key or Apple ID authentication.

title: Xcode Build for testing for iOS Step
body: The Step runs Xcode's xcodebuild command with the build-for-testing option. This builds your app and associated tests so that you can, for example, upload it to a third-party testing service to run your tests on a real device. The Step also creates an .xctestrun file. To be able to run your tests on a real device it needs code signing.

title: Xcode Build for testing for iOS Step
body: The Automatic code signing method Step input allows you to log you into your Apple Developer account based on the Apple service connection you provide on Bitrise and download any provisioning profiles needed for your project based on the Distribution method.

title: Deploy to App Store Connect with Deliver Step
body: With this Step, you can upload screenshots, metadata and binaries to https://appstoreconnect.apple.com/ and submit your app for App Store review using the fastlane deliver action. The Deploy to App Store Connect with Deliver (formerly iTunes Connect) Step can connect to your Apple Developer Account either with Apple ID or with the App Store Connect API, or through Step inputs. Please note that in the case of 2FA enabled Apple ID, the Deploy to App Store Connect with Deliver (formerly iTunes Connect) Step can only work with Apple ID authentication which you can set on the Apple Service page of your profile. The default method is the API key authentication. Choose the connection method that works with your project:

title: Deploy to App Store Connect - Application Loader (formerly iTunes Connect) Step
body: With this Step, you can upload binaries (.ipa or .pkg files) to https://appstoreconnect.apple.com/. The Deploy to App Store Connect - Application Loader (formerly iTunes Connect) Step can connect to your Apple Developer Account either with the App Store Connect API, the Apple ID and password, or through Step inputs. Choose the connection method that works with your project:

title: fastlane Step
body: With this Step you can run your fastlane lanes on Bitrise just like you would locally. Check out our guide about Integrating fastlane to Bitrise for more information.

title: fastlane Step
body: Please note that in the case of 2FA enabled Apple ID, the Fastlane Step can only work with Apple ID authentication which you can set on the Apple Service page of your profile.

title: fastlane Step
body: Two-factor authentication fails with the Fastlane Step

title: fastlane Step
body: In some cases, the Fastlane Step doesn't get the value of the FASTLANE_SESSION variable correctly when attempting to connect to the Apple Developer portal, causing two-factor authentication to fail. Check out the potential workaround for this issue.

title: SAML SSO in Bitrise
body: Velocity and Enterprise users can create and log in to a Bitrise Workspace using their own SAML SSO provider’s system to provide an extra layer of security.

title: SAML SSO in Bitrise
body: Workspace members can log in to a Bitrise Workspace using their own SAML SSO provider’s system. With SAML SSO, Workspaces will be able to apply the security guidelines of their SAML SSO provider when accessing their Bitrise Workspace.

title: SAML SSO in Bitrise
body: Managing role level access via SSO is not supported

title: SAML SSO in Bitrise
body: Bitrise does not support user authorization management (assigning roles) via SSO.

title: SAML SSO in Bitrise
body: Bitrise does support user authentication (signup/login) via SSO.

title: SAML SSO in Bitrise
body: Before connecting SAML SSO to your Workspace, make sure:

title: SAML SSO in Bitrise
body: You have a SAML SSO provider (Identity Provider) that you can connect Bitrise to and the administrator to the SAML SSO provider is at hand.

title: SAML SSO in Bitrise
body: Your account on Bitrise has a Velocity or an Enterprise Build Platform plan. If it doesn’t have a Workspace, go ahead and create one. Setting up SAML SSO is the same for existing and brand new Workspaces on Bitrise.

title: SAML SSO in Bitrise
body: Only the Workspace owner can set up SAML SSO to a Bitrise Workspace.

title: Navigating to the Single Sign-On page of Bitrise
body: If you are a Workspace owner on Bitrise, you will have to use the Single Sign-On tab to set up a SAML SSO connection between your SAML SSO provider and your Bitrise Workspace.

title: Navigating to the Single Sign-On page of Bitrise
body: Log in to Bitrise and open the account selector dropdown menu in the top right.

title: Navigating to the Single Sign-On page of Bitrise
body: Find your Workspace and click the little gear icon next to its name to get to your Workspace's profile page.

title: Navigating to the Single Sign-On page of Bitrise
body: The Overview page displays all the Workspaces you’re the owner of. Select the Workspace where you wish to set up the SAML SSO connection.

title: Navigating to the Single Sign-On page of Bitrise
body: On the left menu bar, click Single Sign-On which will take you to the Enable Single Sign-On page.

title: Navigating to the Single Sign-On page of Bitrise
body: Continue with setting up SAML SSO for your Workspace on Bitrise.

title: Authorizing SAML SSO
body: Once the Workspace owner has set up SAML SSO, everyone in the Workspace has to authorize SAML SSO before logging in to their Workspace via SAML SSO.

title: Authorizing SAML SSO
body: Make sure you’re logged into Bitrise in the usual way. Use the same browser window to continue.

title: Authorizing SAML SSO
body: Bitrise sends a verification e-mail to all Workspace members. By clicking the Log In via SAML SSO button or using the provided URL, Workspace members can authorize themselves for SAML SSO login. The email also shows the Workspace owner’s email address (should you need to contact them.) Click the Log In via SAML SSO button or copy-paste the URL to a NEW TAB of the same browser.

title: Authorizing SAML SSO
body: You’re directed to Bitrise to Allow “Workspace name” to sign you in page.

title: Authorizing SAML SSO
body: Click Authorize if you trust the Workspace to control your Bitrise account sign-in process.

title: Authorizing SAML SSO
body: If you’re already logged in to your SAML SSO provider, you’ll be automatically taken to your Bitrise Dashboard.

title: Authorizing SAML SSO
body: If you’re not, you’ll be prompted to log in on your SAML SSO provider’s site, and then taken to your Bitrise Dashboard.

title: Authorizing SAML SSO
body: Click Don’t Allow if the invitation email is from an untrusted source.

title: Authorizing SAML SSO
body: Note that if you are using a different non-matching email address, you will get the below error message. Make sure you log in with the right email address both on Bitrise, as well as on your SSO provider site.

title: Authorizing SAML SSO
body: If all went well, you should be landing on our Bitrise Dashboard.

title: Inviting new Workspace members with SAML SSO
body: Once SAML SSO is set up on a Workspace, you can invite new members to your Workspace using SAML SSO.

title: Inviting new Workspace members with SAML SSO
body: Make sure the new member is already a group member in your SAML SSO provider.

title: Inviting new Workspace members with SAML SSO
body: Make sure the email address associated with the new member is the one that is registered in your SAML SSO provider and you use the same on Bitrise as well.

title: Inviting new Workspace members with SAML SSO
body: Go to your SAML SSO Workspace on Bitrise and click the Groups tab.

title: Inviting new Workspace members with SAML SSO
body: Find the SAML users section and click the + sign to add a new member.

title: Inviting new Workspace members with SAML SSO
body: Enter their email address and click the arrow icon. This will add the member to the SAML user’s list and Bitrise automatically sends out our SAML invitation instructions to the new member.

title: Inviting new Workspace members with SAML SSO
body: You can keep adding new users using the same method or finish the addition(s) by clicking the Done button.

title: Inviting new Workspace members with SAML SSO
body: Until the new member does not go through the invitation process, you will see a REINVITE button next to their name on the Groups page. If they fail to sign up via SAML SSO and their invitation times out, you can resend the invitation by clicking this button. Once they successfully sign up, the button disappears.

title: Joining a SAML SSO Workspace as a new member
body: If a Bitrise Workspace owner invites you to a Workspace, you should get an email invitation to join the Workspace via SAML SSO. Let’s see how!

title: Joining a SAML SSO Workspace as a new member
body: Go to your mailbox and find our email titled Saml invitation instructions.

title: Joining a SAML SSO Workspace as a new member
body: Click the Sign in via SSO button or copy the provided URL and paste it into a new browser. Our Almost there page appears.

title: Joining a SAML SSO Workspace as a new member
body: Provide a Username you would like to use in your Bitrise Workspace. Please use only letters, numbers, underscores (_), dashes (-) and dots (.) in your username. The Email field is non-editable.

title: Joining a SAML SSO Workspace as a new member
body: Click the Finish Sign-up button. If all went well, you’re landing on Bitrise and can add your first app.

title: Checking SAML SSO statuses on Bitrise
body: Now that the Workspace owner has set up SAML SSO for the Workspace, all Workspace members (including the Workspace owner) can check their other Workspace member’s SAML SSO statuses on the People tab.

title: Checking SAML SSO statuses on Bitrise
body: Accessing the Single Sign-on tab

title: Checking SAML SSO statuses on Bitrise
body: The Single Sign-On tab is only available for the Workspace owner.

title: Checking SAML SSO statuses on Bitrise
body: There are two kinds of SAML SSO statuses on Bitrise.

title: Checking SAML SSO statuses on Bitrise
body: SAML SSO IS ENABLED: Login via SAML SSO is enabled.

title: Checking SAML SSO statuses on Bitrise
body: SAML SSO IS DISABLED: The Workspace member has not enabled the SAML SSO connection yet. To enable it, the Workspace member has to follow the instructions in the verification email from Bitrise.

title: Checking SAML SSO statuses on Bitrise
body: Go to your Workspace’s profile page.

title: Checking SAML SSO statuses on Bitrise
body: Click the People tab on the left menu to check the Workspace member’s SAML SSO status.

title: Checking SAML SSO statuses on Bitrise
body: Workspace owners

title: Checking SAML SSO statuses on Bitrise
body: If you are a Workspace owner, you can also click the Group tab on the left menu and look for the SAML users group, where you can check and manage your SAML users.

title: Enforcing SAML SSO on a Workspace
body: Enforcing SAML SSO on your Workspace provides an extra layer of security: you can enforce your own security guidelines to your Bitrise Workspace (for example, password format requirements, two-factor authentication).

title: Enforcing SAML SSO on a Workspace
body: Enforced SAML SSO

title: Enforcing SAML SSO on a Workspace
body: Enforcing SAML SSO in your Workspace makes SAML SSO the only way for logging in/signing up to the Workspace.

title: Enforcing SAML SSO on a Workspace
body: One Workspace only

title: Enforcing SAML SSO on a Workspace
body: You cannot be a member in two Workspaces that enforced SAML SSO on Bitrise.

title: Enforcing SAML SSO on a Workspace
body: Log in to Bitrise and open the account selector dropdown menu in the top right.

title: Enforcing SAML SSO on a Workspace
body: Find your Workspace and click the little gear icon next to its name to get to your Workspace's profile page.

title: Enforcing SAML SSO on a Workspace
body: Go to your Workspace’s Single Sign On tab.

title: Enforcing SAML SSO on a Workspace
body: Toggle the switch to the right to enforce SAML SSO.

title: Enforcing SAML SSO on a Workspace
body: Unable to enforce SAML SSO

title: Enforcing SAML SSO on a Workspace
body: A Workspace owner cannot enforce SAML SSO on the Workspace if Workspace members have not enabled their SAML SSO connection yet or they enabled SAML SSO with another Workspace that enforces SAML SSO.

title: Enforcing SAML SSO on a Workspace
body: Click Save Changes.

title: Enforcing SAML SSO on a Workspace
body: Now Workspace members can only log in via SAML SSO.

title: Adding a new user to a Workspace with enforced SAML SSO
body: Once SAML SSO is enforced on a Workspace, you can still add new users to it. But in this case, it's important to differentiate between the two types of new users:

title: Adding a new user to a Workspace with enforced SAML SSO
body: Users with existing accounts on Bitrise: We recommend that the Workspace admin turns off the enforced SSO and invites the user to the Workspace. The invited Bitrise user has to go through the invitation process and enable their SSO connection. Once that is done, the Workspace admin can turn the Enforce SSO switch back on.

title: Adding a new user to a Workspace with enforced SAML SSO
body: Users who are new to Bitrise and haven't registered an account yet: The Workspace admin doesn't need to turn off enforced SSO: simply invite the new user who should then complete the sign-up procedure as described: Joining a SAML SSO Workspace as a new member.

title: Adding a new user to a Workspace with enforced SAML SSO
body: Alternatively, the new user can go directly to the sign-up page, and click the SAML button then follow the instructions to achieve the same goal.

title: Logging in via SAML SSO
body: If the SAML SSO connection has been already added to your Workspace and you have enabled your SAML SSO connection too, you can easily log in to your Bitrise account without having to use a password and email address.

title: Logging in via SAML SSO
body: Expired SAML SSO certificate

title: Logging in via SAML SSO
body: If your SAML SSO certificate has expired, and you cannot log into Bitrise through SAML SSO, you can contact our Support team to help you log in.

title: Logging in via SAML SSO
body: Click Login via SSO on our login page.

title: Logging in via SAML SSO
body: You will be redirected to the Initiate Single Sign-On page.

title: Logging in via SAML SSO
body: Provide your Workspace name in the Bitrise Workspace’s Name field.

title: Logging in via SAML SSO
body: Click Continue with SSO to log in.

title: Logging in via SAML SSO
body: If you’re logged in on your SSO provider site, you will be automatically landing on your Bitrise Dashboard.

title: Logging in via SAML SSO
body: If you’re logged out on your SSO provider site, you will be redirected there to log in. After the successful login, you will be redirected to your Bitrise dashboard.

title: Disabling a Workspace's SAML SSO
body: If you disable SAML SSO, Workspace members will be able to sign in with the regular sign-in procedure.

title: Disabling a Workspace's SAML SSO
body: Log in to Bitrise and open the account selector dropdown menu in the top right.

title: Disabling a Workspace's SAML SSO
body: Find your Workspace and click the little gear icon next to its name to get to your Workspace's profile page.

title: Disabling a Workspace's SAML SSO
body: Go to the Single Sign-On tab.

title: Disabling a Workspace's SAML SSO
body: If SAML SSO has been enforced on the Workspace before, toggle Enforce SAML SSO off.

title: Disabling a Workspace's SAML SSO
body: Click Disable SSO.

title: Disabling a Workspace's SAML SSO
body: A confirmation pop-up appears where you can confirm/cancel your action. Please note that by clicking the Disable SSO button, you will disable SAML SSO for all Workspace members. Once it’s done, Workspace members will be able to log in through their normal Bitrise credentials.

title: Disabling a Workspace's SAML SSO
body: You will receive an SSO has been disabled email from Bitrise (letsconnect@bitrise.io) which confirms the disabled SAML SSO for the Workspace.

title: Disabling a Workspace member's SAML SSO
body: If you are a Workspace owner, you can disable a Workspace member’s SAML SSO connection to the Workspace on Bitrise. There are three ways to do:

title: Disabling a Workspace member's SAML SSO
body: Remove the user from the SAML users group by clicking the red x symbol next to the name on the Groups tab.

title: Disabling a Workspace member's SAML SSO
body: Remove the user from the Workspace.

title: Disabling a Workspace member's SAML SSO
body: Remove the user from the SAML SSO provider which means the user would not be able to log in with SAML SSO any more.

title: Updating SAML SSO configuration
body: You can update a Workspace’s configured SAML SSO using the Update SSO button on the Single Sign-On page.

title: Updating SAML SSO configuration
body: This comes in handy if your SAML SSO provider’s certificate has expired and you wish to insert the new certificate on Bitrise. Another use case is, for example, if SAML SSO has been configured a while ago and now you wish to check the current configuration details.

title: Updating SAML SSO configuration
body: Accessing the Update SSO button

title: Updating SAML SSO configuration
body: As with other SAML SSO configurations, only the Workspace owner can access and use the Update SSO button.

title: Updating SAML SSO configuration
body: As the owner of the Workspace, click your Workspace’s Single Sing-On tab.

title: Updating SAML SSO configuration
body: Click the Update SSO button. Now you can access the configuration details of Workspace’s SAML SSO.

title: Updating SAML SSO configuration
body: Make the changes and click Save changes.

title: Updating SAML SSO configuration
body: From now on any SAML SSO request will use the new configuration automatically.

title: Setting up Google SSO for Bitrise
body: Add SAML SSO to your Bitrise Workspace using Google Workspace.

title: Setting up Google SSO for Bitrise
body: This guide provides step-by-step instructions on setting up Bitrise as a SAML application on Google Workspace.

title: Setting up Google SSO for Bitrise
body: SAML SSO restrictions

title: Setting up Google SSO for Bitrise
body: SAML SSO is only available for a Workspace with the Velocity or Enterprise Build plans.

title: Setting up Google SSO for Bitrise
body: Since the SAML SSO feature is tied to the above plans, if you decide to downgrade, you will lose this feature. All Workspace members will receive an email about the downgrade and you’ll have two weeks to re-upgrade if you wish to use SAML SSO in your Workspace again.

title: Setting up Google SSO for Bitrise
body: Before connecting SAML SSO to your Workspace:

title: Setting up Google SSO for Bitrise
body: Make sure you have a Google administrator account where you can add Bitrise as a SAML app. The Google Workspace administrator can help setting up SAML SSO on Google Workspace.

title: Setting up Google SSO for Bitrise
body: Be aware that only the Workspace owner can set up SAML SSO to a Bitrise Workspace.

title: Setting up Google SSO for Bitrise
body: Your account on Bitrise has a Workspace with the Velocity or Enterprise plan.

title: Setting up Google SSO for Bitrise
body: You'll need to:

title: Setting up Google SSO for Bitrise
body: Get configuration information from Google Workspace and Bitrise.

title: Setting up Google SSO for Bitrise
body: Enable the Bitrise app for a group or an organizational unit.

title: Getting configuration information from Google Workspace and Bitrise
body: Sign into your Google Admin Console.

title: Getting configuration information from Google Workspace and Bitrise
body: Select Apps on the Admin Console page.

title: Getting configuration information from Google Workspace and Bitrise
body: On the Apps page, click SAML apps.

title: Getting configuration information from Google Workspace and Bitrise
body: On the Web and mobile apps page, click the Add apps button, and select the Add custom SAML app option from the dropdown.

title: Getting configuration information from Google Workspace and Bitrise
body: On the App details page add Bitrise as your app name. Please note it must be Bitrise as no other format is accepted. Click Continue.

title: Getting configuration information from Google Workspace and Bitrise
body: On the Getting Identity Provider details page:

title: Getting configuration information from Google Workspace and Bitrise
body: Copy the SSO URL and paste it on the SAML SSO provider Single Sing-On URL (SSO URL) on Bitrise.

title: Getting configuration information from Google Workspace and Bitrise
body: Copy the whole content of the Certificate field and paste it in the SAML SSO provider certificate field of Bitrise. You can upload the Certificate from your local computer too.

title: Getting configuration information from Google Workspace and Bitrise
body: While you are in Bitrise, click the Copy Link button to copy the Assertion Consumer Service URL (ACS URL). We will need it on Google Workspace in a second. Let’s NOT click the Configure SSO button just now!

title: Getting configuration information from Google Workspace and Bitrise
body: Let’s head back to the Getting Identity Provider details page of Google Workspace. Click Continue.

title: Getting configuration information from Google Workspace and Bitrise
body: On the Service provider details page:

title: Getting configuration information from Google Workspace and Bitrise
body: Paste the Assertion Consumer Service URL (ACS URL) of Bitrise in the ACS URL field on Google Workspace. (Remember, we got the link at Step 7.)

title: Getting configuration information from Google Workspace and Bitrise
body: Type Bitrise in the Entity ID field. Please note it must be Bitrise as no other format is accepted.

title: Getting configuration information from Google Workspace and Bitrise
body: Tick the Signed response checkbox under START URL (optional).

title: Getting configuration information from Google Workspace and Bitrise
body: Click CONTINUE.

title: Getting configuration information from Google Workspace and Bitrise
body: Click the Configure SSO button on Bitrise.

title: Getting configuration information from Google Workspace and Bitrise
body: On Google Workspace’s Attribute mapping page, click Finish - you do not have to configure anything here.

title: Enabling Bitrise app for a group or an organizational unit
body: All there is left to do on G Suite is to enable the newly created Bitrise app for a group or organization of your choice.

title: Enabling Bitrise app for a group or an organizational unit
body: Go to the Web and mobile apps page on G Suite and select Bitrise from the Apps list.

title: Enabling Bitrise app for a group or an organizational unit
body: Click User access to get to the Service status page.

title: Enabling Bitrise app for a group or an organizational unit
body: Select ON for everyone and hit Save.

title: Setting up AD FS SSO for Bitrise
body: Add SAML SSO to your Bitrise Workspace using Microsoft Active Directory Federation Services.

title: Setting up AD FS SSO for Bitrise
body: This guide provides step-by-step instructions on setting up SAML SSO using Microsoft Active Directory Federation Services (AD FS).

title: Setting up AD FS SSO for Bitrise
body: SAML SSO restrictions

title: Setting up AD FS SSO for Bitrise
body: SAML SSO is only available for a Workspace with the Velocity or Enterprise Build plans.

title: Setting up AD FS SSO for Bitrise
body: Since the SAML SSO feature is tied to the above plans, if you decide to downgrade, you will lose this feature. All Workspace members will receive an email about the downgrade and you’ll have two weeks to re-upgrade if you wish to use SAML SSO in your Workspace again.

title: Setting up AD FS SSO for Bitrise
body: Before connecting SAML SSO to your Workspace:

title: Setting up AD FS SSO for Bitrise
body: Make sure the AD FS administrator is at hand during the SAML SSO configuration process.

title: Setting up AD FS SSO for Bitrise
body: Be aware that only the Workspace owner can set up SAML SSO to a Bitrise Workspace.

title: Setting up AD FS SSO for Bitrise
body: Your account on Bitrise has a Workspace with the Velocity or Enterprise plan.

title: Setting up AD FS SSO for Bitrise
body: In this tutorial we will be jumping back and forth between Bitrise and AD FS so it is recommended that both tools are available during this process.

title: Setting up AD FS SSO for Bitrise
body: To configure SAML SSO with AD FS, you'll need to:

title: Setting up AD FS SSO for Bitrise
body: Add the Identity provider sign-on URL from AD FS on Bitrise.

title: Setting up AD FS SSO for Bitrise
body: Export a certificate generated by AD FS and add it on Bitrise.

title: Setting up AD FS SSO for Bitrise
body: Add Bitrise as a relying party trust to AD FS.

title: Setting up AD FS SSO for Bitrise
body: Configure claim rules.

title: Adding the identity provider sign-on URL
body: Log in to Bitrise and open the account selector dropdown menu in the top right.

title: Adding the identity provider sign-on URL
body: Find your Workspace and click the little gear icon next to its name to get to your Workspace's profile page.

title: Adding the identity provider sign-on URL
body: Go to the Single Sign-on tab.

title: Adding the identity provider sign-on URL
body: Add the Identity provider sign-on URL from AD FS in the SAML SSO provider Single Sign-On URL (SSO URL) field.

title: Adding the identity provider sign-on URL
body: For example, a valid value is https://<AD FS URL>.com/adfs/ls.

title: Exporting an AD FS certificate
body: You have to add a certificate generated by AD FS to the SAML SSO provider certificate field of the Single Sign-On page on Bitrise. If you’ve already created a certificate on AD FS, you can export it in PEM format from the AD FS server. If you haven’t created one yet, follow the instructions: Obtain and Configure TS and TD Certificates for AD FS.

title: Exporting an AD FS certificate
body: In Server Manager, click Tools, and select AD FS Management.

title: Exporting an AD FS certificate
body: Select the Certificates folder on the left menu pane.

title: Exporting an AD FS certificate
body: Click a certificate under Token-signing. This brings up the Certificates window.

title: Exporting an AD FS certificate
body: Click Details tab on the Certificate page.

title: Exporting an AD FS certificate
body: Hit Next on the Certificate Export Wizard window.

title: Exporting an AD FS certificate
body: Select the Base-64 encoded X.509 (.CER) the export file format. Click Next.

title: Exporting an AD FS certificate
body: Give it a name in the File name field and hit Save.

title: Exporting an AD FS certificate
body: Have a final look at your certificate settings. If you need to modify any of those, click the backward arrow next to Certificate Export Wizard. Otherwise, click Finish. Make sure you leave the AD FS window open as you will need it in a minute.

title: Exporting an AD FS certificate
body: Open the exported certificate by a text editor and copy/paste its content to the SAML SSO provider certificate field or upload the file itself from your local computer.

title: Exporting an AD FS certificate
body: Save the settings by clicking Configure SSO on Bitrise.

title: Exporting an AD FS certificate
body: Let’s continue the SAML SSO configuration on AD FS by adding Bitrise.

title: Adding Bitrise as a relying party trust to AD FS
body: Once you are finished with exporting the certificate, you can continue with adding Bitrise as a relying party trust to AD FS. The Add Relying Party Trust Wizard guides you through the steps.

title: Adding Bitrise as a relying party trust to AD FS
body: On AD FS, click Relying Party Trust on the left menu bar, then click Relying Party Trust.

title: Adding Bitrise as a relying party trust to AD FS
body: Select Add Relying Party Trust under Actions.

title: Adding Bitrise as a relying party trust to AD FS
body: On the Welcome page, select the Claims aware option and hit Start.

title: Adding Bitrise as a relying party trust to AD FS
body: On the Select Data Source page, click the Enter data about the relying party manually option on the bottom of the page. Click Next.

title: Adding Bitrise as a relying party trust to AD FS
body: On the Specify Display Name page, add a Display name, for example MyCorp. Click Next.

title: Adding Bitrise as a relying party trust to AD FS
body: Specify a token encryption certificate on the Configure Certificate page is optional. Click Next.

title: Adding Bitrise as a relying party trust to AD FS
body: On the Configure URL page, select Enable support for the SAML 2.0 WebSSO protocol and copy paste the Assertion Consumer Service URL (ACS URL) from Bitrise to the Relying party SAML 2. 0 SSO service URL field on AD FS. Click Next.

title: Adding Bitrise as a relying party trust to AD FS
body: On the Configure Identifiers page, add Bitrise in the Relying party trust identifier field. Click Add, then hit Next.

title: Adding Bitrise as a relying party trust to AD FS
body: Do not modify the default access control policy on the Choose Access Control Policy page so that everyone can access this SAML SSO connection. Click Next.

title: Adding Bitrise as a relying party trust to AD FS
body: On the Ready to Add Trust page, review the settings and click Next.

title: Adding Bitrise as a relying party trust to AD FS
body: On the Finish page, tick the checkbox to edit claims issuance policy for Bitrise. Click Close.

title: Adding Bitrise as a relying party trust to AD FS
body: On AD FS, click Relying Party Trust on the left menu bar, then click Relying Party Trust.

title: Adding Bitrise as a relying party trust to AD FS
body: Select Add Relying Party Trust under Actions.

title: Adding Bitrise as a relying party trust to AD FS
body: On the Welcome page, select the Claims aware option and hit Start.

title: Adding Bitrise as a relying party trust to AD FS
body: On the Select Data Source page, click the Enter data about the relying party manually option on the bottom of the page. Click Next.

title: Adding Bitrise as a relying party trust to AD FS
body: On the Specify Display Name page, add a Display name, for example MyCorp. Click Next.

title: Adding Bitrise as a relying party trust to AD FS
body: Specify a token encryption certificate on the Configure Certificate page is optional. Click Next.

title: Adding Bitrise as a relying party trust to AD FS
body: On the Configure URL page, select Enable support for the SAML 2.0 WebSSO protocol and copy paste the Assertion Consumer Service URL (ACS URL) from Bitrise to the Relying party SAML 2. 0 SSO service URL field on AD FS. Click Next.

title: Adding Bitrise as a relying party trust to AD FS
body: On the Configure Identifiers page, add Bitrise in the Relying party trust identifier field. Click Add, then hit Next.

title: Adding Bitrise as a relying party trust to AD FS
body: Do not modify the default access control policy on the Choose Access Control Policy page so that everyone can access this SAML SSO connection. Click Next.

title: Adding Bitrise as a relying party trust to AD FS
body: On the Ready to Add Trust page, review the settings and click Next.

title: Adding Bitrise as a relying party trust to AD FS
body: On the Finish page, tick the checkbox to edit claims issuance policy for Bitrise. Click Close.

title: Configuring claim rules
body: On the Edit Claim Issuance Policy page, click the Add Rule button and hit OK.

title: Configuring claim rules
body: Create a Send LDAP Attributes as Claims claim rule and click Next.

title: Configuring claim rules
body: On the Configure Claim Rule page:

title: Configuring claim rules
body: Add a rule name, for example Send E-mail, in the Claim rule name field.

title: Configuring claim rules
body: Select an Attribute Store which is most likely the Active Directory.

title: Configuring claim rules
body: In the Mapping of LDAP attributes to outgoing claim types field select E-mail Addresses.

title: Configuring claim rules
body: Click Finish.

title: Configuring claim rules
body: Add another new rule that turns an E-mail to a formatter NameID. To do so, click Add rule in the Edit Claim Issuance Policy page again.

title: Configuring claim rules
body: On the Select Rule Template, select Transform an Incoming Claim option in the Claim rule template dropdown. Click Next.

title: Configuring claim rules
body: Give a name to the new rule, for example, Transform E-mail.

title: Configuring claim rules
body: Select E-Mail Address as the Incoming Claim Type.

title: Configuring claim rules
body: Select NameId as the Outgoing claim type.

title: Configuring claim rules
body: Choose Email as the Outgoing name ID format.

title: Configuring claim rules
body: Hit OK to finish the process.

title: Setting up Azure AD SSO for Bitrise
body: Add SAML SSO to your Bitrise Workspace using Azure AD.

title: Setting up Azure AD SSO for Bitrise
body: SAML SSO restrictions

title: Setting up Azure AD SSO for Bitrise
body: SAML SSO is only available for a Workspace with the Velocity or Enterprise Build plans.

title: Setting up Azure AD SSO for Bitrise
body: Since the SAML SSO feature is tied to the above plans, if you decide to downgrade, you will lose this feature. All Workspace members will receive an email about the downgrade and you’ll have two weeks to re-upgrade if you wish to use SAML SSO in your Workspace again.

title: Setting up Azure AD SSO for Bitrise
body: Before connecting SAML SSO to your Workspace:

title: Setting up Azure AD SSO for Bitrise
body: Make sure an Azure AD administrator who is logged into Azure AD is at hand.

title: Setting up Azure AD SSO for Bitrise
body: Be aware that only the Workspace owner can set up SAML SSO to a Bitrise Workspace.

title: Setting up Azure AD SSO for Bitrise
body: Your account on Bitrise has a Workspace with the Velocity or Enterprise plan.

title: Setting up Azure AD SSO for Bitrise
body: You will need to:

title: Setting up Azure AD SSO for Bitrise
body: Add Bitrise to Azure AD as a new application.

title: Setting up Azure AD SSO for Bitrise
body: Add users and groups to the Bitrise app on Azure AD.

title: Setting up Azure AD SSO for Bitrise
body: Set up SAML SSO between Bitrise and Azure AD.

title: Adding Bitrise to Azure AD as a new application
body: Log into Microsoft Azure as an admin.

title: Adding Bitrise to Azure AD as a new application
body: Click the Azure Active Directory icon on the Azure services page.

title: Adding Bitrise to Azure AD as a new application
body: Click Enterprise applications under Manage.

title: Adding Bitrise to Azure AD as a new application
body: Click New Application to add Bitrise as a new app to your account.

title: Adding Bitrise to Azure AD as a new application
body: Type Bitrise in the What’s the name of your app? field. The Integrate any other application you don’t find in the gallery button should be automatically selected. Hit Create.

title: Adding Bitrise to Azure AD as a new application
body: You will find your newly created app listed on the All Applications page.

title: Adding Bitrise to Azure AD as a new application
body: Click the Bitrise app to go to its Overview page.

title: Adding Bitrise to Azure AD as a new application
body: Continue with configuring Bitrise as a SAML app.

title: Adding users/ groups to the app on Azure AD
body: Before setting up SAML to the app, you have to add all the users/groups to the app in Azure AD who will use SAML SSO to log into the Bitrise Workspace. In other words, every Bitrise Workspace member must be added as user in Azure AD.

title: Adding users/ groups to the app on Azure AD
body: Select Users and groups from the left menu.

title: Adding users/ groups to the app on Azure AD
body: Click + Add user/group.

title: Adding users/ groups to the app on Azure AD
body: On the Users page of Add Assignment, select users from the list and click Select. Once it’s done, you can select a role for users under the Select a role dropdown.

title: Adding users/ groups to the app on Azure AD
body: On the Add Assignment page, click Assign to finish adding users.

title: Setting up SAML SSO between Bitrise and Azure AD
body: Click Single sign-on on the left menu. Select SAML.

title: Setting up SAML SSO between Bitrise and Azure AD
body: You will land on the Set up Single Sign-On with SAML page.

title: Setting up SAML SSO between Bitrise and Azure AD
body: Click the pencil symbol at Basic SAML Configuration to edit two fields.

title: Setting up SAML SSO between Bitrise and Azure AD
body: Add Bitrise as the Identifier (Entity ID). Leave this window open! We will come back to it with some information from Bitrise in a second.

title: Setting up SAML SSO between Bitrise and Azure AD
body: Head back to your Workspace on Bitrise.

title: Setting up SAML SSO between Bitrise and Azure AD
body: Click the Single Sign On tab and click the Copy Link button to copy the Assertion Consumer Service URL (ACS URL) from Bitrise.

title: Setting up SAML SSO between Bitrise and Azure AD
body: Let’s head back to the Basic SAML Configuration window of Azure AD.

title: Setting up SAML SSO between Bitrise and Azure AD
body: Paste the Assertion Consumer Service URL from Bitrise to the Reply URL field on the Basic SAML Configuration page of Azure AD.

title: Setting up SAML SSO between Bitrise and Azure AD
body: Click Save and close the Basic SAML Configuration window.

title: Setting up SAML SSO between Bitrise and Azure AD
body: On the Single sign-on page of Azure AD, scroll down to the Set up Bitrise section.

title: Setting up SAML SSO between Bitrise and Azure AD
body: Copy the Login URL and paste it to the SAML SSO provider Single Sign-On URL (SSO URL) field on Bitrise.

title: Setting up SAML SSO between Bitrise and Azure AD
body: On the Single sign-on page of Azure AD, scroll up a bit to the SAML Signing Certificate section.

title: Setting up SAML SSO between Bitrise and Azure AD
body: Click Download next to Certificate (Base64) to download the certificate to your local computer.

title: Setting up SAML SSO between Bitrise and Azure AD
body: Open the certificate file and copy/paste its content into the SAML SSO provider certificate field of Bitrise or you can upload the file itself from your local computer too.

title: Setting up SAML SSO between Bitrise and Azure AD
body: (If manually adding the content, you will need the full content (including ----BEGIN CERTIFICATE----- and -----END CERTIFICATE----- as well).

title: Setting up SAML SSO between Bitrise and Azure AD
body: Hit Configure SSO on Bitrise.

title: Setting up SAML SSO between Bitrise and Azure AD
body: You have successfully set up Bitrise as a SAML SSO app on Azure AD.

title: Setting up Auth0 SSO for Bitrise
body: Add SAML SSO to your Bitrise Workspace using Auth0.

title: Setting up Auth0 SSO for Bitrise
body: This guide provides instructions on setting up SAML SSO using Auth0.

title: Setting up Auth0 SSO for Bitrise
body: SAML SSO restrictions

title: Setting up Auth0 SSO for Bitrise
body: SAML SSO is only available for a Workspace with the Velocity or Enterprise Build plans.

title: Setting up Auth0 SSO for Bitrise
body: Since the SAML SSO feature is tied to the above plans, if you decide to downgrade, you will lose this feature. All Workspace members will receive an email about the downgrade and you’ll have two weeks to re-upgrade if you wish to use SAML SSO in your Workspace again.

title: Setting up Auth0 SSO for Bitrise
body: Before connecting SAML SSO to your Workspace:

title: Setting up Auth0 SSO for Bitrise
body: An Auth0 administrator who is logged into Auth0 is at hand.

title: Setting up Auth0 SSO for Bitrise
body: Be aware that only the Workspace owner can set up SAML SSO to a Bitrise Workspace.

title: Setting up Auth0 SSO for Bitrise
body: Your account on Bitrise has a Workspace with the Velocity or Enterprise plan.

title: Setting up Auth0 SSO for Bitrise
body: You will need to:

title: Setting up Auth0 SSO for Bitrise
body: Create Bitrise as a web application on Auth0.

title: Setting up Auth0 SSO for Bitrise
body: Retrieve SAML SSO information from Auth0.

title: Setting up Auth0 SSO for Bitrise
body: Setting up a mapping rule for your Bitrise app's Client ID.

title: Creating Bitrise as a web application on Auth0
body: Log into Auth0 as an admin.

title: Creating Bitrise as a web application on Auth0
body: Click Applications on the left menu bar then click the + Create Application button on the right hand side of the Applications page.

title: Creating Bitrise as a web application on Auth0
body: On the Create application window, type Bitrise in the Name field. In the Choose application type select Regular Web Applications, and click the Create button.

title: Creating Bitrise as a web application on Auth0
body: You are landing on your newly created Bitrise app’s Quick Start page. Click the Addons tab. Toggle the SAML2 WEB APP’s switch to the right. This will take to to the Addon: SAML2 WEB APP page automatically.

title: Creating Bitrise as a web application on Auth0
body: Copy the Assertion Consumer Service URL (ACS URL) from Bitrise and paste it into the Application Callback URL field on the Settings tab of the Addon: SAML2 WEB APP page. Scroll down to the bottom of the Addon: SAML2 WEB APP page and hit SAVE.

title: Creating Bitrise as a web application on Auth0
body: Go back to the Addons page where you can find the switch turned on.

title: Retrieving SAML SSO information from Auth0
body: Once you have enabled Bitrise as a web application on Auth0, it’s time to grab the certificate and the Identity provider’s unique login URL to finish up the SAML configuration on Bitrise.

title: Retrieving SAML SSO information from Auth0
body: On Auth0, go to Application, then select the Addons tab to find your enabled Bitrise app.

title: Retrieving SAML SSO information from Auth0
body: Click the SAML2 WEB APP web app and select the Usage tab. Click on the Download Auth0 certificate link next to the Identity Provider Certificate label. Open the downloaded certificate file and copy its content into the SAML SSO provider certificate field of Bitrise or upload the file itself from your local computer. Go back to Auth0 and copy paste the Identity Provider Login URL into Bitrise’s SAML SSO provider Single Sign-On URL (SSO URL).

title: Retrieving SAML SSO information from Auth0
body: Click Configure SSO button on Bitrise.

title: Retrieving SAML SSO information from Auth0
body: Now you can close the dialog on Auth0.

title: Setting up a mapping rule for your Bitrise app’s Client ID
body: Bitrise authenticates SAML SSO users via email address so before you’d test SAML SSO, make sure you create a new mapping rule on Auth0. This way you map Auth0 Client ID to email for successful SAML authentication on Bitrise.

title: Setting up a mapping rule for your Bitrise app’s Client ID
body: On Auth0, click the Auth Pipeline on the left menu bar. Click Rules.

title: Setting up a mapping rule for your Bitrise app’s Client ID
body: Click + Create to set up a new mapping rule.

title: Setting up a mapping rule for your Bitrise app’s Client ID
body: On the Pick a rules template page, click <> Empty rule.

title: Setting up a mapping rule for your Bitrise app’s Client ID
body: Add the following codeblock to the Script box: You will need your new Bitrise app’s Client ID which you can get on the Applications’ page.

title: Setting up a mapping rule for your Bitrise app’s Client ID
Setting up a mapping rule for your Bitrise app’s Client ID
body: Click Save changes.

title: Setting up Idaptive SAML SSO for Bitrise
body: Add SAML SSO to your Bitrise Workspace using Idaptive.

title: Setting up Idaptive SAML SSO for Bitrise
body: This guide provides step-by-step instructions on setting up Bitrise as a SAML application on Idaptive.

title: Setting up Idaptive SAML SSO for Bitrise
body: SAML SSO restrictions

title: Setting up Idaptive SAML SSO for Bitrise
body: SAML SSO is only available for a Workspace with the Velocity or Enterprise Build plans.
