title: Setting up Idaptive SAML SSO for Bitrise
body: Since the SAML SSO feature is tied to the above plans, if you decide to downgrade, you will lose this feature. All Workspace members will receive an email about the downgrade and you’ll have two weeks to re-upgrade if you wish to use SAML SSO in your Workspace again.

title: Setting up Idaptive SAML SSO for Bitrise
body: Before connecting SAML SSO to your Workspace:

title: Setting up Idaptive SAML SSO for Bitrise
body: Be aware that only the Workspace owner can set up SAML SSO to a Bitrise Workspace.

title: Setting up Idaptive SAML SSO for Bitrise
body: Your account on Bitrise has a Workspace with the Velocity or Enterprise plan.

title: Setting up Idaptive SAML SSO for Bitrise
body: You must be logged into your Admin Portal on Idaptive to set up Bitrise as a SAML SSO app and establish the connection between Bitrise and Idaptive. If you are using the User Portal, Switch to Admin Portal by clicking your avatar on Idaptive.

title: Setting up Idaptive SAML SSO for Bitrise
body: Log into Idaptive as an Admin.

title: Setting up Idaptive SAML SSO for Bitrise
body: Go to Apps, then to Web Apps. Click the Add Web Apps button on the right.

title: Setting up Idaptive SAML SSO for Bitrise
body: On the Custom tab and select SAML, and click Add. On the Add Web App popup hit Yes. Close the window. You will be automatically directed to the Settings page.

title: Setting up Idaptive SAML SSO for Bitrise
body: Add Bitrise to the Name and Application ID fields on the Settings page and click Save.

title: Setting up Idaptive SAML SSO for Bitrise
body: Click Trust on the left menu bar and select the Manual configuration under Identity Provider Configuration.

title: Setting up Idaptive SAML SSO for Bitrise
body: Click the Signing Certificate dropdown and download the certificate. Open it with a text editor so that you can copy the full content of the certificate. You can also upload the file.

title: Setting up Idaptive SAML SSO for Bitrise
body: Insert the content or upload the file itself in the SAML SSO provider certificate text box on the Enable Single Sign-On page of Bitrise.

title: Setting up Idaptive SAML SSO for Bitrise
body: Copy the Single Sign On URL from the Trust page of Idaptive. Insert it on the SAML SSO provider Single Sing-On URL (SSO URL) field on the Enable Single Sign-On page of Bitrise.

title: Setting up Idaptive SAML SSO for Bitrise
body: While on the Single Sign-On page of Bitrise, copy the Assertion Consumer Service URL (ACS URL) URL and click Configure SSO.

title: Setting up Idaptive SAML SSO for Bitrise
body: Now let’s head back to Idaptive! Under Service Provider Configuration click Manual Configuration. Type Bitrise in the SP Entity ID / Issuer / Audience and paste the Assertion Consumer Service URL (ACS URL) from Bitrise to the Assertion Consumer Service (ACS) URL on Idaptive.

title: Setting up Idaptive SAML SSO for Bitrise
body: Scroll down to NameID Format and select emailAddress. Click Save.

title: Setting up Idaptive SAML SSO for Bitrise
body: Go to Permissions and click the Add button. In the Select User, Group, or Role popup, type the user name you want to add to the SAML app. Select it and hit Add. Save your changes. This will change the status of your Bitrise SAML app to Deployed.

title: Setting up Idaptive SAML SSO for Bitrise
body: You are now ready to use Idaptive as your SAML SSO provider on Bitrise.

title: Setting up Okta SSO for Bitrise
body: Add SAML SSO to your Bitrise Workspace using Okta.

title: Setting up Okta SSO for Bitrise
body: This guide provides step-by-step instructions on setting up Bitrise as a SAML application on Okta.

title: Setting up Okta SSO for Bitrise
body: SAML SSO restrictions

title: Setting up Okta SSO for Bitrise
body: SAML SSO is only available for a Workspace with the Velocity or Enterprise Build plans.

title: Setting up Okta SSO for Bitrise
body: Since the SAML SSO feature is tied to the above plans, if you decide to downgrade, you will lose this feature. All Workspace members will receive an email about the downgrade and you’ll have two weeks to re-upgrade if you wish to use SAML SSO in your Workspace again.

title: Setting up Okta SSO for Bitrise
body: Before connecting SAML SSO to your Workspace:

title: Setting up Okta SSO for Bitrise
body: Make sure you have an Okta administrator who is logged into Okta at hand.

title: Setting up Okta SSO for Bitrise
body: Be aware that only the Workspace owner can set up SAML SSO to a Bitrise Workspace.

title: Setting up Okta SSO for Bitrise
body: Your account on Bitrise has a Workspace with the Velocity or Enterprise plan.

title: Setting up Okta SSO for Bitrise
body: Add Bitrise to Okta.

title: Setting up Okta SSO for Bitrise
body: Configure Bitrise as a SAML app.

title: Adding Bitrise to Okta
body: Bitrise is not an integrated app in Okta. You have to add Bitrise manually to Okta first, then you can configure SAML SSO on it.

title: Adding Bitrise to Okta
body: We will be jumping back and forth from the Bitrise Workspace account to Okta so make sure both pages are available. In practice this means the Workspace owner should be logged into Bitrise and the Okta admin should be logged into Okta.

title: Adding Bitrise to Okta
body: Log into Okta and click Admin.

title: Adding Bitrise to Okta
body: On your Dashboard click Add Applications under Shortcuts.

title: Adding Bitrise to Okta
body: Click the green Create New App button.

title: Adding Bitrise to Okta
body: The Create a New Application Integration screen is displayed.

title: Adding Bitrise to Okta
body: Select SAML 2.0 option at Sing on method and click Create.

title: Adding Bitrise to Okta
body: At General Settings step, type Bitrise into the App name field. (Optionally, you can add an app logo if you wish.) Click Next.

title: Adding Bitrise to Okta
body: Head over to your Bitrise Workspace and click the Single Sign On tab on the left menu.

title: Adding Bitrise to Okta
body: Click the Copy Link button to copy the Assertion Consumer Service URL (ACS URL).

title: Adding Bitrise to Okta
body: Head back to Okta’s SAML Settings and paste the copied URL from Step 7. to the Single sign on URL input field.

title: Adding Bitrise to Okta
body: Type Bitrise at the Audience URI (SP Entity ID).

title: Adding Bitrise to Okta
body: You can download the Okta certificate file now, and paste its content or upload the file itself in the SAML SSO provider certificate field on your Bitrise Workspace’s Single Sign-On page. Even easier if you leave it for later as you will need to fill out the Assertion Consumer Service URL (ACS URL) on Bitrise anyway. You will fetch this while configuring Bitrise as a SAML app on Okta. Do not hit Configure SSO on the Single Sing-On page of Bitrise just yet.

title: Adding Bitrise to Okta
body: Click Next.

title: Adding Bitrise to Okta
body: Fill out the Feedback section. Hit Finish.

title: Adding Bitrise to Okta
body: Congrats! Bitrise has been successfully added to Okta as an app.

title: Configuring Bitrise as a SAML app for Okta
body: Click the Assignments tab of your Bitrise app.

title: Configuring Bitrise as a SAML app for Okta
body: Here you can assign Bitrise to individuals/groups. Make sure you assign Bitrise to all Workspace members who will access the Bitrise Workspace through SAML.

title: Configuring Bitrise as a SAML app for Okta
body: Click the Sign-On tab of your Bitrise app. You will see that SAML setup is not completed yet. Click View Setup Instructions.

title: Configuring Bitrise as a SAML app for Okta
body: The How to Configure SAML 2.0 for Bitrise application page is displayed. It summarizes all the information you need to set up the SAML connection between Bitrise and Okta.

title: Configuring Bitrise as a SAML app for Okta
body: Copy the Identity Provider Single Sign-On URL and paste it in your Bitrise Workspace’s SAML SSO provider Single Sign-On URL (SSO URL).

title: Configuring Bitrise as a SAML app for Okta
body: If you haven’t pasted the Certificate’s content or uploaded the file itself into the SAML SSO provider certificate field of your Bitrise Workspace yet, you can do so now as it is displayed on this page.

title: Configuring Bitrise as a SAML app for Okta
body: Click Configure SSO on your Bitrise Workspace.

title: Setting up Ping Identity SSO for Bitrise
body: Add SAML SSO to your Bitrise Workspace using Ping Identity.

title: Setting up Ping Identity SSO for Bitrise
body: This guide provides step-by-step instructions on setting up Bitrise as a SAML SSO application in Ping Identity.

title: Setting up Ping Identity SSO for Bitrise
body: SAML SSO restrictions

title: Setting up Ping Identity SSO for Bitrise
body: SAML SSO is only available for a Workspace with the Velocity or Enterprise Build plans.

title: Setting up Ping Identity SSO for Bitrise
body: Since the SAML SSO feature is tied to the above plans, if you decide to downgrade, you will lose this feature. All Workspace members will receive an email about the downgrade and you’ll have two weeks to re-upgrade if you wish to use SAML SSO in your Workspace again.

title: Setting up Ping Identity SSO for Bitrise
body: Before connecting SAML SSO to your Workspace:

title: Setting up Ping Identity SSO for Bitrise
body: A PingOne administrator who is logged into PingOne.

title: Setting up Ping Identity SSO for Bitrise
body: Be aware that only the Workspace owner can set up SAML SSO to a Bitrise Workspace.

title: Setting up Ping Identity SSO for Bitrise
body: Your account on Bitrise has a Workspace with the Velocity or Enterprise plan.

title: Setting up Ping Identity SSO for Bitrise
body: To add Bitrise to Ping Identity:

title: Setting up Ping Identity SSO for Bitrise
body: Click APPLICATIONS on the top bar of PingOne.

title: Setting up Ping Identity SSO for Bitrise
body: On My Applications tab, make sure SAML is selected. Click the Add Application drop-down and select New SAML Application.

title: Setting up Ping Identity SSO for Bitrise
body: At Application Details, fill out the required fields and click Continue to Next Step.

title: Setting up Ping Identity SSO for Bitrise
body: At Application Configuration, leave the I have the SAML configuration selected. Fill out the following:

title: Setting up Ping Identity SSO for Bitrise
body: Assertion Consumer Service (ACS) field: Insert the Assertion Consumer Service URL (ACS URL) link here from your Bitrise Workspace’s Single Sign-On tab.

title: Setting up Ping Identity SSO for Bitrise
body: Entity ID field: Type Bitrise.

title: Setting up Ping Identity SSO for Bitrise
body: Signing: Click the Sign Response option.

title: Setting up Ping Identity SSO for Bitrise
body: Here is an overview of the above settings:

title: Setting up Ping Identity SSO for Bitrise
body: Continue to the next step.

title: Setting up Ping Identity SSO for Bitrise
body: At SSO Attribute Mapping, you don’t have to change anything, proceed to the next step.

title: Setting up Ping Identity SSO for Bitrise
body: At Group Access, add the group(s) to your application. These groups will be able to access Bitrise through SAML SSO. Continue to the next step.

title: Setting up Ping Identity SSO for Bitrise
body: At the Review Setup page, you can doublecheck the details you provided in the previous steps. Make sure you download the following files from this review page:

title: Setting up Ping Identity SSO for Bitrise
body: Click Download to get the Signing Certificate and SAML Metadata files.

title: Setting up Ping Identity SSO for Bitrise
body: Click Finish.

title: Setting up Ping Identity SSO for Bitrise
body: Let’s open the two files.

title: Setting up Ping Identity SSO for Bitrise
body: Copy the entire content of the SAML Metadata file and paste it in the SAML SSO provider certificate field of your Bitrise Single Sign-On page.

title: Setting up Ping Identity SSO for Bitrise
body: Open the Signing Certificate file and copy the HTTP-POST SingleSignOnService Location link and paste it in the SAML SSO provider Single Sign-On URL (SSO URL) field on Bitrise.

title: Setting up Ping Identity SSO for Bitrise
body: Click Configure SSO on Bitrise.

title: Setting up Ping Identity SSO for Bitrise
body: Now you have set up SAML SSO on your Bitrise Workspace.

title: Setting up OneLogin SSO for Bitrise
body: Add SAML SSO to your Bitrise Workspace using OneLogin.

title: Setting up OneLogin SSO for Bitrise
body: This guide provides step-by-step instructions on setting up Bitrise as a SAML application on OneLogin.

title: Setting up OneLogin SSO for Bitrise
body: SAML SSO restrictions

title: Setting up OneLogin SSO for Bitrise
body: SAML SSO is only available for a Workspace with the Velocity or Enterprise Build plans.

title: Setting up OneLogin SSO for Bitrise
body: Since the SAML SSO feature is tied to the above plans, if you decide to downgrade, you will lose this feature. All Workspace members will receive an email about the downgrade and you’ll have two weeks to re-upgrade if you wish to use SAML SSO in your Workspace again.

title: Setting up OneLogin SSO for Bitrise
body: Before connecting SAML SSO to your Workspace:

title: Setting up OneLogin SSO for Bitrise
body: Make sure the administrator to OneLogin is at hand while setting up SAML SSO connection on Bitrise.

title: Setting up OneLogin SSO for Bitrise
body: Be aware that only the Workspace owner can set up SAML SSO to a Bitrise Workspace.

title: Setting up OneLogin SSO for Bitrise
body: Your account on Bitrise has a Workspace with the Velocity or Enterprise plan.

title: Setting up OneLogin SSO for Bitrise
body: To configure Bitrise on OneLogin:

title: Setting up OneLogin SSO for Bitrise
body: Log into OneLogin as an Administrator.

title: Setting up OneLogin SSO for Bitrise
body: Click Administration on the top bar.

title: Setting up OneLogin SSO for Bitrise
body: Select Applications and click Add App. This will take you to the Find Applications page.

title: Setting up OneLogin SSO for Bitrise
body: Type Bitrise in the search bar and select the SAML2.0 type from the search results.

title: Setting up OneLogin SSO for Bitrise
body: Click the Configuration tab on the left sidebar. You can change the icon and add descriptions if you wish. Make sure Organization (Bitrise) is ticked. Hit Save.

title: Setting up OneLogin SSO for Bitrise
body: Click the Configuration tab again and paste the Assertion Consumer Service URL (ACS URL) from your Bitrise Workspace’s Single Sign-On tab to the Single Sign-On URL field on OneLogin. Hit Save in OneLogin.

title: Setting up OneLogin SSO for Bitrise
body: Select SSO on the left sidebar.

title: Setting up OneLogin SSO for Bitrise
body: Click the View details for the X.509 Certificate. Copy the content of the X.509 Certificate and paste it to the SAML SSO provider certificate field on the Enable Single Sign-On page of Bitrise.

title: Setting up OneLogin SSO for Bitrise
body: Go back to the SSO page on OneLogin and copy the SAML 2.0 Endpoint (HTTP) link. Paste it in the SAML SSO provider Single Sign-On URL (SSO URL) field on Bitrise.

title: Setting up OneLogin SSO for Bitrise
body: Go back to Bitrise and click Configure SSO.

title: Setting up OneLogin SSO for Bitrise
body: Users on OneLogin and Bitrise

title: Setting up OneLogin SSO for Bitrise
body: Make sure the users in your Bitrise Workspace are all added to the Users page on OneLogin. If not, go to Users, then New User and add the new user. Don’t forget to send out an invite (More actions drop-down menu, Send Invitation) to a new user so that the user can activate their account on OneLogin. Users must be added to the newly created Bitrise app by clicking Applications under User Info and clicking the + sign. Make sure the added users are all Workspace members on Bitrise.

title: Setting up OneLogin SSO for Bitrise
body: If you’ve completed setting up Bitrise on OneLogin and connected it with your Bitrise Workspace, then all Workspace members will get an email from Bitrise which contains a link to activate their SSO connection to the Bitrise Workspace.

title: Editing your profile settings
body: You can edit your profile settings, such as your username, password, account avatar, etc., on the Profile settings page.

title: Editing your profile settings
body: On the Profile settings page, you can:

title: Editing your profile settings
body: Change your username and associated email address.

title: Editing your profile settings
body: Change your password.

title: Editing your profile settings
body: Update your personal and company information.

title: Changing your Bitrise username, email, and password
body: In the upper right corner, open the account selector dropdown menu.

title: Changing your Bitrise username, email, and password
body: Select the Profile settings option.

title: Changing your Bitrise username, email, and password
body: This takes you to the Edit your profile page.

title: Changing your Bitrise username, email, and password
body: To change your username, type in the new username in the Username field.

title: Changing your Bitrise username, email, and password
body: To change your email, type in a new email address in the Email field.

title: Changing your Bitrise username, email, and password
body: To change your password, type in a new password in the Password field, and then type it again in the Confirm password field.

title: Changing your Bitrise username, email, and password
body: When done, click Update.

title: Adding an avatar to your account
body: You can add your own personalized avatar to your Bitrise account.

title: Adding an avatar to your account
body: In the upper right corner, open the account selector dropdown menu.

title: Adding an avatar to your account
body: Select the Profile settings option.

title: Adding an avatar to your account
body: This takes you to the Edit your profile page.

title: Adding an avatar to your account
body: Find your default avatar on the left, above the account name.

title: Adding an avatar to your account
body: Click the image.

title: Adding an avatar to your account
body: Drag and drop your new avatar in the CHANGE AVATAR window, or click Browse to choose an image from your computer.

title: Unselecting notification preferences
body: By default Bitrise sends newsletters and platform updates to the email address you provide under your Profile. You can unselect this setting with 3 simple steps:

title: Unselecting notification preferences
body: Click Profile settings under your avatar.

title: Unselecting notification preferences
body: Click Notification on the left menu bar. You can see that Newsletters and Platform updates are both enabled by default.

title: Unselecting notification preferences
body: If you wish to rather not get any or one of the two, notifications, untick the relevant checkbox/es.

title: Resetting your password
body: If you forgot your password, you can reset it by clicking on the Forgot your Password on the Bitrise Login page. You will receive an email with further instructions.

title: Resetting your password
body: You can log into Bitrise in many ways:

title: Resetting your password
body: with your Bitrise username and password

title: Resetting your password
body: with your Gitlab/Github/Bitbucket account

title: Resetting your password
body: with your Bitrise Workspace name if SAML SSO has been set up to and enforced on it your Bitrise Workspace

title: Resetting your password
body: If you try to log in but you forgot your password:

title: Resetting your password
body: Click Forgot your password on our Login page.

title: Resetting your password
body: Provide your Email or Username so that we know where to send password recovery link.

title: Resetting your password
body: Check your inbox for the Reset password instructions sent by letsconnect.

title: Resetting your password
body: Click Reset Password or copy the URL into your browser.

title: Resetting your password
body: Add your new password and hit Save.

title: Resetting your password
body: Once your password has been changed, click Log in to access our login page again.

title: Resetting your password
body: Add your Username and new Password to log into your Bitrise Dashboard.

title: Resetting your password
body: If you failed to log in for the third time, reCAPTCHA will get enabled to check if you are a human.

title: Resetting your password
body: If you failed to log in for an excessive amount of attempts, you will automatically get locked out. Check your inbox for our Unlock Instructions email!

title: Two-factor authentication
body: You can add two-factor authentication (2FA) on Bitrise as an extra layer of security from the Profile settings.

title: Two-factor authentication
body: We provide an extra layer of security to your account if you enable two-factor authentication (2FA) on your Bitrise account.

title: Two-factor authentication
body: We recommend that you check your connected accounts (GitHub, Bitbucket, GitLab) and enable 2FA if you haven’t already.

title: Enabling two-factor authentication
body: Download and install Google Authenticator on your phone.

title: Enabling two-factor authentication
body: Log in to bitrise.io and go to your Profile.

title: Enabling two-factor authentication
body: Click Profile setting.

title: Enabling two-factor authentication
body: Scroll down and click Security on the left.

title: Enabling two-factor authentication
body: Click on 2FA is enabled under Two-factor authentication.

title: Enabling two-factor authentication
body: Open your Google Authenticator and scan the QR-code that appears on your screen.

title: Enabling two-factor authentication
body: Enter the 6-digit code that was generated.

title: Enabling two-factor authentication
body: Once you have activated your 2FA and saved your recovery codes, you will receive a confirmation email from letsconnect@bitrise.io.

title: Disabling two-factor authentication
body: Follow this procedure to disable two-factor authentication (2FA) if you are already logged into Bitrise.

title: Disabling two-factor authentication
body: Log in to bitrise.io and go to your Profile.

title: Disabling two-factor authentication
body: Click Profile settings.

title: Disabling two-factor authentication
body: Scroll down and click Security on the left.

title: Disabling two-factor authentication
body: Click on 2FA is enabled under Two-factor authentication.

title: Disabling two-factor authentication
body: Provide your Bitrise login password in the pop-up window.

title: Have you lost your authenticator and recovery codes?
body: 2FA protects your account from unwanted login attempts (for example, with a stolen password) by providing an extra security step during the login flow. This also means that if you lose the device with the authenticator app, and you lose your recovery codes, you won't be able to access your account and Bitrise Support will not be able to remove the activated 2FA from your account.

title: Have you lost your authenticator and recovery codes?
body: However, if there has been any third-party service (for example, GitLab, GitHub or Bitbucket) connected to your account before, you can try to log in through that. In the absence of a connected third-party account, we recommend you to create a new account on Bitrise.

title: Have you lost your authenticator and recovery codes?
body: In very special cases, Bitrise can remove 2FA from your account. Please note that Bitrise can only disable the activated 2FA on your account if there is a Git provider account already connected to Bitrise.

title: Have you lost your authenticator and recovery codes?
body: Contact our Support Team using the email address you provided when signing up to Bitrise.

title: Have you lost your authenticator and recovery codes?
body: Explain why you’re requesting us to remove 2FA.

title: Have you lost your authenticator and recovery codes?
body: Our Support Team will ask you to create a new public repo on your git account with the title: bitrise_verification

title: Have you lost your authenticator and recovery codes?
body: Send the link of the created repo to our Support Team.

title: Have you lost your authenticator and recovery codes?
body: Please note that our Support Team can deny your request if they find removing 2FA from the account might pose a security risk on your Bitrise account.

title: Personal access tokens
body: You can use a personal access token to authenticate to the Bitrise API. You can create a new personal access token at any time but once you created it, you can never view or copy its value again.

title: Personal access tokens
body: You can use a personal access token to authenticate to the Bitrise API. You can create a new personal access token at any time but once you created it, you can never view or copy its value again.

title: Creating a personal access token
body: To create a new personal access token:

title: Creating a personal access token
body: In the upper right corner, open the account selector dropdown menu.

title: Creating a personal access token
body: Select the Profile settings option.

title: Creating a personal access token
body: This takes you to the Edit your profile page.

title: Creating a personal access token
body: On the left, select the Security tab.

title: Creating a personal access token
body: Scroll down to the Personal access tokens section, and click on Create token.

title: Creating a personal access token
body: Fill out the Token description field and select the appropriate expiration time (1 hour, 1 day, 1 month or never) for your token.

title: Creating a personal access token
body: Click Next.

title: Creating a personal access token
body: In the Personal Access token pop-up window, you can see your newly generated token.

title: Creating a personal access token
body: Click Copy and close to store token in the clipboard so you can paste it somewhere safe, and to finalize.

title: Regenerating a personal access token
body: You can regenerate an existing personal access token at any time. However, you can't view the value of the previously generated token again, only the new value.

title: Regenerating a personal access token
body: In the upper right corner, open the account selector dropdown menu.

title: Regenerating a personal access token
body: Select the Profile settings option.

title: Regenerating a personal access token
body: This takes you to the Edit your profile page.

title: Regenerating a personal access token
body: Go to the Security tab.

title: Regenerating a personal access token
body: Find your token in the Personal access tokens section.

title: Regenerating a personal access token
body: Click Edit.

title: Regenerating a personal access token
body: Click Regenerate token.

title: Regenerating a personal access token
body: Copy the new token, and then click Done.

title: Deleting your Bitrise account
body: We’re always sad to see you go but if you wish to delete your Bitrise account, you can do so from the Profile settings.

title: Deleting your Bitrise account
body: We’re always sad to see you go but if you wish to delete your Bitrise account, it’s quite simple.

title: Deleting your Bitrise account
body: Workspace ownership

title: Deleting your Bitrise account
body: If you are the only confirmed owner of a Workspace, you must transfer the ownership of the Workspace to another account, or delete it before deleting your account.

title: Deleting your Bitrise account
body: In the upper right corner, open the account selector dropdown menu.

title: Deleting your Bitrise account
body: Select the Profile settings option.

title: Deleting your Bitrise account
body: This takes you to the Edit your profile page.

title: Deleting your Bitrise account
body: On the bottom of the page, click the Delete my account button and follow the instructions.

title: Workspaces
body: A Workspace is an environment that allows you to manage your Bitrise apps and the team members working on the apps. You can create multiple Workspaces, and you can be invited to Workspaces by other Bitrise users.

title: Workspaces
body: A Workspace is an environment that allows you to manage your Bitrise apps and the team members working on the apps. You can create multiple Workspaces, and you can be invited to Workspaces by other Bitrise users.

title: Workspaces
body: To be able to add apps and run builds, you either need to be part of a Workspace, or you have to be an outside contributor on an app's team.

title: Workspaces
body: You also need a Workspace to have a paid subscription plan on Bitrise. Each of your Workspaces can have a different subscription plan which determines how many credits your Workspace's apps can use.

title: Workspaces
body: Legacy users

title: Workspaces
body: Legacy users are users with concurrency-based accounts: you have a concurrency-based account if you do not use credits when running builds. Legacy users can still add apps on their personal account and run builds of those apps without a Workspace.

title: Workspace Team
body: Being the member of a Workspace's Team means being a member in one of the Workspace groups. Groups can be assigned to the apps that are owned by the Workspace.

title: Workspace Team
body: You can categorize your team members into groups using the Workspace Team tab on Bitrise.

title: Workspace Team
body: Workspace team membership is based on groups: A Workspace group works as a wrapper for team members. Workspace owners and admins can manage groups and add multiple members to each app's team at once, making it faster and easier to set up new projects on Bitrise. A given group can be assigned to work on an app with a specific role, and all members of the same group will have the same level of access to the app.

title: Workspace Team
body: Difference between app teams and Workspace groups

title: Workspace Team
body: App teams are handled per app, while Workspace groups are handled globally.

title: Workspace Team
body: A Workspace group has no inherent roles on its own. You can assign groups to app teams and choose their role there, which means the same group can have different roles on different apps.

title: Workspace Team
body: Workspaces can take advantage of SAML Single Sign-On: we have guides for setting it up with several major identity providers.

title: Creating Workspaces
body: Create a Bitrise Workspace to be able to add new apps or run builds. When you sign up for Bitrise, you are automatically prompted to create your first Workspace.

title: Creating Workspaces
body: A Workspace is an environment that allows you to manage your Bitrise apps and the team members working on the apps. You can create multiple Workspaces, and you can be invited to Workspaces by other Bitrise users.

title: Creating Workspaces
body: You must have access to at least one Workspace to be able to use Bitrise. When you create a new account, you can’t add new apps or run builds. To be able to do so, you need to either create a Workspace, or to be invited to an existing one.

title: Creating Workspaces
body: When you sign up for Bitrise, you are automatically prompted to create a new Workspace. If you skip creating a Workspace, or you want to create additional Workspaces later, you can do it:

title: Creating Workspaces
body: Log in to bitrise.io.

title: Creating Workspaces
body: On the top menu bar, click the + symbol.

title: Creating Workspaces
body: Select Create Workspace. This takes you to the Create a new Workspace page.

title: Creating Workspaces
body: Find the Workspace name input field, and add a name.

title: Creating Workspaces
body: Click Create.

title: Creating Workspaces
body: This creates the Workspace - everything that comes after is optional and can be completed at a later point. However, without a subscription plan - either free or paid - your Workspace will be inactive and won't be able to own apps or run builds.

title: Creating Workspaces
body: Choose a plan.

title: Creating Workspaces
body: If you’re interested in the details, or you want to find out more about our other plans, check out our Pricing page for more info.

title: Creating Workspaces
body: Select a paid subscription plan, and follow the instructions to configure the details of the plan and set up payment methods.

title: Creating Workspaces
body: Alternatively, select the Hobby plan for now and add a subscription later.

title: Creating Workspaces
body: And that’s it. You can start adding apps and inviting people to your Workspace.

title: Workspace billing and invoicing
body: You can modify your subscription plan and billing information at any time on the Workspace page. You can also find and download past invoices.

title: Workspace billing and invoicing
body: It’s very simple to set up a subscription plan for your Workspace even if you skipped that step when creating the Workspace. You can also modify your plan and your billing information at any time if you are the owner of the Workspace.

title: Workspace billing and invoicing
body: You can set up a credit card and we’ll bill you automatically; for other payment methods, please contact our support.

title: Workspace billing and invoicing
body: Set up an email address so we can send you your invoices - no need to rummage around the site looking for them, we’ll deliver them straight to your inbox. However, if you wish to download it manually from the site, you can do that, too.

title: Adding and updating billing details for a Workspace
body: Sign in with an account that is a member of the Workspace.

title: Adding and updating billing details for a Workspace
body: Log in to Bitrise and open the account selector dropdown menu in the top right.

title: Adding and updating billing details for a Workspace
body: Find your Workspace and click the little gear icon next to its name to get to your Workspace's profile page.

title: Adding and updating billing details for a Workspace
body: On the left, select Plan & billing from the menu options.

title: Adding and updating billing details for a Workspace
body: If you haven't provided your billing information yet, do so: click Add credit card on the right of the Billing information menu.

title: Adding and updating billing details for a Workspace
body: Fill out the details.

title: Adding and updating billing details for a Workspace
body: Note that only the owner(s) of the Workspace’s has any access to the Workspace’s billing information.

title: Setting up an email address for Workspace invoices
body: By default, a Workspace’s invoices will be sent to the email provided when the Workspace was created. However, the owner(s) of the Workspace can change it at any time.

title: Setting up an email address for Workspace invoices
body: Sign in with an account that is an owner of the Workspace.

title: Setting up an email address for Workspace invoices
body: Log in to Bitrise and open the account selector dropdown menu in the top right.

title: Setting up an email address for Workspace invoices
body: Find your Workspace and click the little gear icon next to its name to get to your Workspace's profile page.

title: Setting up an email address for Workspace invoices
body: On the left, select General settings from the menu options.

title: Setting up an email address for Workspace invoices
body: Locate the Billing email field and click Edit underneath it.

title: Setting up an email address for Workspace invoices
body: Enter the new email address and click Confirm changes.

title: Downloading Workspace invoices
body: Sign in with an account that is an owner of the Workspace.

title: Downloading Workspace invoices
body: Log in to Bitrise and open the account selector dropdown menu in the top right.

title: Downloading Workspace invoices
body: Find your Workspace and click the little gear icon next to its name to get to your Workspace's profile page.

title: Downloading Workspace invoices
body: On the left, select Plan & billing from the menu options.

title: Downloading Workspace invoices
body: Locate the Past statements menu.

title: Downloading Workspace invoices
body: Select the invoice you need and click the download icon on the right.

title: Adding other users to Workspaces
body: Workspace membership is based on groups on Bitrise: add people to Workspace groups so that the groups can be assigned to work on the Workspace's apps.

title: Adding other users to Workspaces
body: Your Workspace isn't just an environment to manage apps: it also allows seamless collaboration with other Bitrise users. You can invite other users to your Workspaces, and of course you can be invited to other Workspaces, too.

title: Adding other users to Workspaces
body: To be able to work with others in your Workspace, you'll need to add them to the groups of the Workspace. The only way to be a part of a Workspace is to be a member in one of the groups of the Workspace.

title: Adding other users to Workspaces
body: Workspace groups and roles

title: Adding other users to Workspaces
body: Workspace groups have no inherent roles at all. You can assign groups to app teams and choose their role there which means the same group can have different roles on different apps.

title: Adding other users to Workspaces
body: A Workspace group's name is not relevant: even if a Workspace group is called Admin, it doesn’t have the Admin role on any app by default and you can assign them to apps with other roles, too.

title: Creating groups for Workspaces
body: Owners only

title: Creating groups for Workspaces
body: Only Workspace owners can create groups for a Workspace.

title: Creating groups for Workspaces
body: Log in to Bitrise and open the account selector dropdown menu in the top right.

title: Creating groups for Workspaces
body: Find your Workspace and click the little gear icon next to its name to get to your Workspace's profile page.

title: Creating groups for Workspaces
body: On the left, select Team from the menu options.

title: Creating groups for Workspaces
body: Select the Groups tab.

title: Creating groups for Workspaces
body: Click the Create group button to bring up a dialogue box.

title: Creating groups for Workspaces
body: Enter a group name in the Enter a unique name field, and click Create.

title: Adding members to a Workspace group
body: In practice, adding members to a Workspace means adding members to a group belonging to a Workspace. Once you have the groups you need for your Workspace, adding members to them is very simple.

title: Adding members to a Workspace group
body: Email addresses with prohibited characters

title: Adding members to a Workspace group
body: Please note that if you want to sign up for Bitrise with an email address, the address cannot contain the character +. Older accounts with such email addresses still exist but they cannot be invited to Orgs using the address. When adding them, use the username instead.

title: Adding members to a Workspace group
body: Log in to Bitrise and open the account selector dropdown menu in the top right.

title: Adding members to a Workspace group
body: Find your Workspace and click the little gear icon next to its name to get to your Workspace's profile page.

title: Adding members to a Workspace group
body: On the left, select Team from the menu options.

title: Adding members to a Workspace group
body: Select the Groups tab.

title: Adding members to a Workspace group
body: Find the group you need and click the 3 dots to the right of the group to bring up the group drop-down menu.

title: Adding members to a Workspace group
body: Click on the + Add member button.

title: Adding members to a Workspace group
body: Enter an email address or add an existing member to the group using the radio buttons in the dialogue box.

title: Adding members to a Workspace group
body: Select Invite a new member to the Workspace and enter an email address. Click Send Invite on the bottom to send the invitation.

title: Adding members to a Workspace group
body: Select Add an existing member and select one of the existing Workspace members from the drop-down menu. Click Add member on the bottom to add the team member to the group.

title: Removing other users from Workspaces
body: Owners only

title: Removing other users from Workspaces
body: Only Workspace owners can remove users from a Workspace.

title: Removing other users from Workspaces
body: Log in to Bitrise and open the account selector dropdown menu in the top right.

title: Removing other users from Workspaces
body: Find your Workspace and click the little gear icon next to its name to get to your Workspace's profile page.

title: Removing other users from Workspaces
body: On the left, select Team from the menu options.

title: Removing other users from Workspaces
body: Select the Members tab.

title: Removing other users from Workspaces
body: Search for the user you would like to remove, and click "".

title: Removing other users from Workspaces
body: Click Remove to remove the selected user from your Workspace.

title: Managing the owners of a Workspace
body: Workspace owners can access and delete all apps linked to the Workspace and can manage the billing details of the Workspace. Only owners can add or remove other owners.

title: Managing the owners of a Workspace
body: Workspace owners can access and delete all apps linked to the Workspace, can manage the billing details of a Workspace and can add or remove other owners.

title: Managing the owners of a Workspace
body: Every Workspace must have at least one owner.

title: Managing the owners of a Workspace
body: Log in to Bitrise and open the account selector dropdown menu in the top right.

title: Managing the owners of a Workspace
body: Find your Workspace and click the little gear icon next to its name to get to your Workspace's profile page.

title: Managing the owners of a Workspace
body: On the left, select Team from the menu options.

title: Managing the owners of a Workspace
body: Select the Owners tab.

title: Managing the owners of a Workspace
body: Click + Add owner to add a new owner to the Workspace.

title: Managing the owners of a Workspace
body: Enter an email address or add an existing member to the owners group using the radio buttons in the dialogue box. The account in question will become an owner of the Workspace.

title: Workspace FAQ
body: The most frequently asked questions about Bitrise Workspaces: what are they, how to manage its apps, what can members and groups do?

title: Workspace FAQ
body: What is a Workspace on Bitrise?

title: Workspace FAQ
body: Workspaces are used to seamlessly manage bigger teams and members inside a company. It is a place to gather all the people working on each of your company’s apps and delegate them through creating different groups.

title: Workspace FAQ
body: How do I add an app to a Workspace?

title: Workspace FAQ
body: First, you have to be added to at least one Group of the Workspace. Then, go to the Add new app page and select the Workspace in the dropdown at the top left.

title: Workspace FAQ
body: You can change this throughout the process of adding the app, or after you finished adding the app, changing the owner is possible through transferring ownership of the app.

title: Workspace FAQ
body: How do I migrate/transfer my existing apps to a Workspace?

title: Workspace FAQ
body: Once you’ve created a Workspace, you can transfer any of your apps to it by going to the Team tab of the app you want to transfer, and clicking the Transfer ownership button at the top right.

title: Workspace FAQ
body: What are Owners inside a Workspace?

title: Workspace FAQ
body: Workspaces can have more than one Owner. Owners can manage billing, delete apps and change the billing email, create, delete and assign groups to apps.

title: Workspace FAQ
body: What can “Members” of a Workspace do?

title: Workspace FAQ
body: Members are displayed on the People tab of the Workspace’s page. One can be added as a member by including them in a group on the Groups tab. These members have the option to add apps to the Workspace and view a list of all of the Workspace’s apps on the Apps tab. Members can only access a Workspace’s app, if they are granted access to the app directly or through a Group, in respect of their assigned role (Admin, Developer or Tester).

title: Workspace FAQ
body: What are groups good for?

title: Workspace FAQ
body: A group is basically a wrapper for members. By creating groups, Owners and Admins can add multiple members to each app’s team at once, making it faster and easier to setup new projects on Bitrise. It also make it faster to reassign, remove and change role of multiple members.

title: Workspace FAQ
body: Each group is handled as one entity on the app’s Team tab. They can be added to an app’s team, the group’s role can be set, and by removing the Group from the app’s Team you can revoke the access of every member of that group from the app. It’s not possible however to add or delete individual members of a group there, only on the Workspace’s page.

title: Workspace FAQ
body: What’s the difference between a Team and a Workspace?

title: Workspace FAQ
body: Teams are handled per app, Workspaces are handled globally.

title: Workspace FAQ
body: A Team of a Workspace’s app can contain members invited directly or through the groups assigned to them. Team members with a direct role can only access the app they were invited to and can’t add an app to the Workspace. Members of a Team always have a role assigned to them (Admin, Developer or Tester).

title: Workspace FAQ
body: Who are the Outside contributors?

title: Workspace FAQ
body: Outside contributors are members of an app’s Team with a direct role, invited only to an app of a Workspace and not to the Workspace itself.

title: Workspace FAQ
body: Can I have multiple Workspaces?

title: Workspace FAQ
body: One user can have as many Workspaces as they like, but each Workspace has to have an active subscription to be able to run builds.

title: Workspace FAQ
body: Can I remove someone from all of my Workspace’s apps?

title: Workspace FAQ
body: If you are an Owner of a Workspace, you can remove members and contributors on the Org’s People tab, with one click. Owners can also remove someone from a group on the Groups tab. In this case the user will be removed from all apps’ team that the group is assigned to.

title: Workspace FAQ
body: How can I leave a Workspace?

title: Workspace FAQ
body: If you are not the Owner of a Workspace, you can leave a Workplace simply by first accessing the Workspace settings (selecting the gear icon next to the Workplace on the top right of your screen), selecting Team from the menu options on the left, selecting the Members tab, and clicking the "" icon next to your email address.

title: Workspace FAQ
body: I cannot see the Remove from Workspace icon next to my email address

title: Workspace FAQ
body: If you are an Owner of the Workspace you want to leave, you must first remove yourself from the list of owners in the Owners tab (you must also add a new Owner if there isn't one already). For more information, see Managing the owners of a Workspace.

title: Apps
body: Apps are the main building blocks of your Bitrise experience: a Git repository that stores source code is added to Bitrise as an app.

title: Apps
body: Apps are the main building blocks of your Bitrise experience: a Git repository that stores source code is added to Bitrise as an app. As such, a Bitrise app isn't necessarily an actual application: it's just the code on which you run builds with Bitrise.

title: Apps
body: Once you have access to a Workspace, you can start adding and managing apps. You can configure pretty much every aspect of your app at any time after the initial setup. Among other things, you can:

title: Apps
body: Change your app's repository URL.

title: Apps
body: Setting up service credentials.

title: Apps
body: Update your app's SSH keys.

title: Apps
body: Register new webhooks and update existing ones.

title: Apps
body: The users invited to work on a Bitrise app make up the app's team. You can invite users individually, or assign Workspace groups to apps. The same Workspace group can have different roles on different app teams.

title: Webhooks
body: Bitrise makes extensive use of incoming webhooks to automatically trigger builds on Bitrise and outgoing webhooks to send reports of build events to other services, such as Slack.

title: Webhooks
body: A webhook is a user-defined callback that is triggered by some event, such as pushing code to a repository. Bitrise makes extensive use of webhooks:

title: Webhooks
body: Incoming webhooks, registered with your Git service provider, are used to automatically trigger builds on Bitrise.

title: Webhooks
body: Webhook issues

title: Webhooks
body: If your builds triggers don't work, there might be a problem with your webhooks: Builds aren't getting triggered.

title: Webhooks
body: Outgoing webhooks are used to send reports of build events to other services, such as Slack.

title: Webhooks
body: You can add an incoming webhook automatically either when creating an app or later; it’s also possible to manually add a webhook to any supported service.

title: Webhooks
body: Outgoing webhooks can be added either on the website or via the Bitrise API.

title: Adding incoming webhooks
body: An incoming webhook on Bitrise serves one purpose: to start builds automatically when a certain code event (code push, Git Tag, pull request) happens. You can setup incoming webhooks manually or automatically when adding your app to Bitrise.

title: Adding incoming webhooks
body: Most source code hosting service provides a feature to register webhooks. A webhook is basically an URL which will be called on specified events.

title: Adding incoming webhooks
body: An incoming webhook on Bitrise serves one purpose: to start builds automatically when a certain code event (code push, Git Tag, pull request) happens. You just need to register an incoming webhook to your repository and configure build triggers.

title: Adding incoming webhooks
body: Webhook issues

title: Adding incoming webhooks
body: If your builds triggers don't work, there might be a problem with your webhooks: Builds aren't getting triggered.

title: Registering an incoming webhook automatically
body: Automatic webhook registration is supported for apps that have their code hosted on GitHub, GitLab and Bitbucket.

title: Registering an incoming webhook automatically
body: If you use one of the above services as your source code hosting provider, Bitrise automatically sets up a webhook for it with a click of a button at the end of your app setup journey.

title: Registering an incoming webhook automatically
body: However, you can always change this webhook later or add a new one if you skipped registering a webhook when adding the app.

title: Registering an incoming webhook automatically
body: You can automatically register a webhook to the repository on the App settings page of the app. Automatic registration means that Bitrise registers the webhook at the repository, so you don't have to manually go there and add it on your Git provider's website. This requires:

title: Registering an incoming webhook automatically
body: That you have admin rights to the repository.

title: Registering an incoming webhook automatically
body: That the account that hosts the repository is connected to your Bitrise account.

title: Registering an incoming webhook automatically
body: To register a webhook automatically:

title: Registering an incoming webhook automatically
body: Make sure your Bitrise account is connected to the Git provider account that hosts the repository and that your Git account has admin rights to the repository.

title: Registering an incoming webhook automatically
body: Admin access only

title: Registering an incoming webhook automatically
body: Only users with the role of admin on the app's team can access all functions of the App Settings page of an app.

title: Registering an incoming webhook automatically
body: Open your app on Bitrise.

title: Registering an incoming webhook automatically
body: On the main page of the app, click on the App Settings icon: .

title: Registering an incoming webhook automatically
body: On the left, select Integrations.

title: Registering an incoming webhook automatically
body: Click Set up webhooks automatically.

title: Registering an incoming webhook automatically
body: Bitrise will automatically register a webhook at the app's repository.

title: Registering an incoming webhook manually
body: You can manually setup or change your webhooks after you registered your app on Bitrise. The process is different depending on your Git provider but on Bitrise, the basic steps are the same for each.

title: Registering an incoming webhook manually
body: Create your own webhook implementation

title: Registering an incoming webhook manually
body: Our webhook processor is Open Sourced. If you are looking for an unsupported solution, you can create an issue on the GitHub page or create a pull request with the implementation. You can also run your own webhook provider behind your own firewall if required.

title: Registering an incoming webhook manually
body: Admin access only

title: Registering an incoming webhook manually
body: Only users with the role of admin on the app's team can access all functions of the App Settings page of an app.

title: Registering an incoming webhook manually
body: Open your app on Bitrise.

title: Registering an incoming webhook manually
body: On the main page of the app, click on the App Settings icon: .

title: Registering an incoming webhook manually
body: Click Set up webhooks manually.

title: Registering an incoming webhook manually
body: In the pop-up window, select your service from the dropdown menu.

title: Registering an incoming webhook manually
body: Copy the webhook URL and register it at your Git provider.

title: Adding a GitHub webhook
body: You can specify webhooks on Github so that Bitrise automatically triggers a build of your app whenever you perform a specified action, such as a code push or a pull request.

title: Adding a GitHub webhook
body: You can specify webhooks so that Bitrise automatically triggers a build of your app whenever you perform a specified action, such as a code push or a pull request. For GitHub, all you have to do is register your bitrise-webhooks URL as a Webhook in your GitHub repository.

title: Adding a GitHub webhook
body: You can register a webhook either automatically or manually. This guide walks you through the process of manually registering a webhook.

title: Adding a Gitlab webhook
body: You can register a webhook either automatically or manually. This guide walks you through the process of manually registering a webhook.

title: Adding a Gitlab webhook
body: Admin access only

body: Only users with the role of admin on the app's team can access all functions of the App Settings page of an app.

title: Adding a Gitlab webhook

title: Adding a Bitbucket webhook
body: You can specify webhooks on Bitbucket so that Bitrise automatically triggers a build of your app whenever you perform a specified action, such as a code push or a pull request.

title: Adding a Bitbucket webhook
body: To have Bitrise automatically start a build every time you push code into your repository, you can set up a webhook at your code hosting service which will automatically trigger a build on Bitrise with the code you push to your repository.

body: You can register a webhook either automatically or manually. This guide walks you through the process of manually registering a Bitbucket webhook.

title: Adding a Gogs webhook
body: You can set up webhooks so that Bitrise automatically triggers a build of your app whenever you perform a specified action. For Gogs, all you have to do is register your bitrise-webhooks URL as a Webhook in your Gogs repository.

title: Adding a Gogs webhook
body: Admin access only

title: Adding a Gogs webhook
body: Only users with the role of admin on the app's team can access all functions of the App Settings page of an app.

title: Adding a Gogs webhook
body: Open your app on Bitrise.

title: Adding a Gogs webhook
body: On the main page of the app, click on the App Settings icon: .

title: Adding a Gogs webhook
body: On the left, select Integrations.

title: Adding a Gogs webhook
body: Click Set up webhooks manually.

title: Adding a Gogs webhook
body: In the pop-up window, select Gogs from the dropdown menu.

title: Adding a Gogs webhook
body: Copy the webhook URL.

title: Adding a Gogs webhook
body: Open your project on your repository’s hosting URL.

title: Adding a Gogs webhook
body: Go to Settings of the project.

title: Adding a Gogs webhook
body: Select Webhooks, Add Webhook, then Gogs.

title: Adding a Gogs webhook
body: Specify the bitrise-webhooks URL (.../h/gogs/BITRISE-APP-SLUG/BITRISE-APP-API-TOKEN) in the Payload URL field.

title: Adding a Gogs webhook
body: Set the Content Type to application/json.

title: Adding a Gogs webhook
body: A Secret is not required at this time.

title: Adding a Gogs webhook
body: Set the trigger to be fired on Just the push event.

title: Adding a Gogs webhook
body: Click Add Webhook.

title: Adding a Gogs webhook
body: And you’re done! From now on, every code push to your Gogs repository will trigger a build on Bitrise.

body: You can set up a webhook on to send automated messages on Slack about your Bitrise builds.

title: Usage: the message format
body: Your message has to be in the format: key:value|key:value|..., where the supported keys are:

title: Usage: the message format
body: At least one of these two parameters are required:

title: Usage: the message format
body: b or branch - example: branch: master

title: Usage: the message format
body: w or workflow - example: workflow: primary

title: Usage: the message format
body: Other, optional parameters:

title: Usage: the message format
body: t or tag - example: branch: master|tag: v1.0

title: Usage: the message format
body: c or commit - example: workflow: primary|commit: eee55509f16e7715bdb43308bb55e8736da4e21e

title: Usage: the message format
body: m or message - example: branch: master|message: ship it!!

title: Usage: the message format
body: Parameter requirements

title: Usage: the message format
body: At least either branch or workflow has to be specified, and you can specify both if you want to. You’re free to specify any number of optional parameters.

title: Usage: the message format
body: You can also send environment variables that will be available in your workflow with the format: env[KEY1]:value1|ENV[KEY2]:value2

title: Usage: the message format
body: An example with all parameters included:

title: Usage: the message format
body: workflow: primary|b: master|tag: v1.0|commit:eee55509f16e7715bdb43308bb55e8736da4e21e|m: start my build!|ENV[DEVICE_NAME]:iPhone 6S|ENV[DEVICE_UDID]:82667b4079914d4aabed9c216620da5dedab630a

title: Adding a Visual Studio webhook
body: You can specify webhooks in Visual Studio so that Bitrise automatically triggers a build of your app whenever you perform a specified action, such as a code push or a pull request.

title: Adding a Visual Studio webhook
body: You can set up webhooks so that Bitrise automatically triggers a build of your app whenever you perform a specified action, such as a code push or a pull request. For Visual Studio, all you have to do is register your bitrise-webhooks URL for a visualstudio.com project as a Service Hooks integration.

title: Adding a Visual Studio webhook
body: Admin access only

title: Adding a Visual Studio webhook
body: Only users with the role of admin on the app's team can access all functions of the App Settings page of an app.

title: Adding a Visual Studio webhook
body: Open your app on Bitrise.

title: Adding a Visual Studio webhook
body: On the main page of the app, click on the App Settings icon: .

title: Adding a Visual Studio webhook

title: Adding a Visual Studio webhook
body: Click Set up webhooks manually.

title: Adding a Visual Studio webhook
body: In the pop-up window, select Visual Studio from the dropdown menu.

title: Adding a Visual Studio webhook
body: Select Service Hooks.

title: Adding a Visual Studio webhook
body: Click Create subscription.

title: Adding a Visual Studio webhook
body: Create a service integration:

title: Adding a Visual Studio webhook
body: In the Service list select the Web Hooks option.

title: Adding a Visual Studio webhook
body: Select the Code pushed event as the Trigger.

title: Adding a Visual Studio webhook
body: In the Filters section select the Repository you want to integrate.

title: Adding a Visual Studio webhook
body: You can leave the other filters on default.

title: Adding a Visual Studio webhook
body: Click Next.

title: Adding a Visual Studio webhook
body: On the Action setup form enter the bitrise-webhooks URL (.../h/visualstudio/BITRISE-APP-SLUG/BITRISE-APP-API-TOKEN) in the URL field. You can leave every other option on default.

title: Adding a Visual Studio webhook
body: Click Finish.

body: You can set up webhooks so that Bitrise automatically triggers a build of your app whenever you perform a specified action, such as a code push or a pull request. For Assembla, you only need to add your bitrise-webhooks URL to your Assembla space.

title: Adding an Assembla webhook
body: Admin access only

title: Adding an Assembla webhook
body: Only users with the role of admin on the app's team can access all functions of the App Settings page of an app.

title: Adding an Assembla webhook
body: Open your app on Bitrise.

title: Adding an Assembla webhook
body: On the main page of the app, click on the App Settings icon: .

title: Adding an Assembla webhook
body: On the left, select Integrations.

title: Adding an Assembla webhook
body: Click Set up webhooks manually.

title: Adding an Assembla webhook
body: In the pop-up window, select Assembla from the dropdown menu.

title: Adding an Assembla webhook
body: Copy the webhook URL.

title: Adding an Assembla webhook
body: Open your space on assembla.com or your organisation’s assembla domain.

title: Adding an Assembla webhook
body: Go to the Webhooks section of the space.

body: Select Create New Webhook.

title: Adding an Assembla webhook
body: Set Title to Bitrise Webhook.

title: Adding an Assembla webhook
body: Specify the bitrise-webhooks URL. (.../h/assembla/BITRISE-APP-SLUG/BITRISE-APP-API-TOKEN) in the External url field.

title: Adding an Assembla webhook
body: Select application/json in the Content type field.

title: Adding an Assembla webhook
body: Paste the following code to Content:

title: Adding an Assembla webhook
body: {"assembla": {"space": "%{space}", "action": "%{action}", "object": "%{object}"}, "message": {"title": "%{title}", "body": "%{body}", "author": "%{author}"}, "git": {"repository_suffix": "%{repository_suffix}", "repository_url": "%{repository_url}", "branch": "%{branch}", "commit_id": "%{commit_id}"}}

title: Adding an Assembla webhook
body: Select Code commits and/or Git Push in the Post updates about: section.

title: Adding an Assembla webhook
body: Click Add.

title: Adding an Assembla webhook
body: That’s all! The next time you push code a build will be triggered (if you have Trigger mapping defined for the event(s) on Bitrise).

title: Adding a Deveo webhook
body: Admin access only

title: Adding a Deveo webhook
body: Only users with the role of admin on the app's team can access all functions of the App Settings page of an app.

title: Adding a Deveo webhook
body: Open your app on Bitrise.

title: Adding a Deveo webhook
body: On the main page of the app, click on the App Settings icon: .

title: Adding outgoing webhooks
body: You can create outgoing webhooks so that Bitrise automatically sends build event notifications to any service you would like.

title: Adding outgoing webhooks
body: You can configure Bitrise to send build event notifications to any service you would like. A build event is:

title: Adding outgoing webhooks
body: When a build is started.

title: Adding outgoing webhooks
body: When a build ends.

title: Adding outgoing webhooks
body: You can use this notification to share build statuses with your git provider if we don’t support it yet, notify only the right team about build success or failure, or use it to automate your in-house release pipeline.

title: Adding outgoing webhooks
body: You can add, remove and edit your webhooks easily on the website interface.

title: Adding outgoing webhooks
body: Accessing services that are behind a firewall

title: Adding outgoing webhooks
body: If you need to access a service that is behind a firewall, you can't use outgoing webhooks: the payload won't get past the firewall. To access such a service, we recommend configuring the firewall to allow the Bitrise build machines to access it, and then make the request from within the build machine. For more information on how to do so, check out the relevant guides:

title: Adding an outgoing webhook to an app
body: You can set up and configure the webhooks sent by Bitrise on the web UI. Let’s see how!

title: Adding an outgoing webhook to an app
body: Admin access only

title: Adding an outgoing webhook to an app
body: Only users with the role of admin on the app's team can access all functions of the App Settings page of an app.

title: Adding an outgoing webhook to an app
body: Open your app on Bitrise.

title: Adding an outgoing webhook to an app
body: On the main page of the app, click on the App Settings icon: .

title: Adding an outgoing webhook to an app
body: On the left, select Integrations.

title: Adding an outgoing webhook to an app
body: Scroll down to Outgoing Webhooks.

title: Adding an outgoing webhook to an app
body: Click Add webhook.

title: Adding an outgoing webhook to an app
body: Enter the URL of the service where you wish to send the notification in the URL field.

title: Adding an outgoing webhook to an app
body: Select either the Send me everything or the Select individual events option.

title: Adding an outgoing webhook to an app
body: Send me everything: every supported event type will trigger the webhook. Currently, only build events are supported but there will be other options in the future!

title: Adding an outgoing webhook to an app
body: Select individual events: you can specify the individual events that should trigger the webhook.

title: Adding an outgoing webhook to an app
body: Optionally, add custom headers to your webhook: in the Headers section, specify a name and a value for the header. When done, click Add header.

title: Adding an outgoing webhook to an app
body: For example, if you have an API listening to the webhook, you can track the requests with API keys set as a custom header.

title: Adding an outgoing webhook to an app
body: Hiding the header value

title: Adding an outgoing webhook to an app
body: You can hide the value of your headers by checking the box under Hide. Please note that if you do this, you won't be able to view or change the value again.

title: Adding an outgoing webhook to an app
body: Click Create Webhook.

title: Adding an outgoing webhook to an app
body: And you’re done! You can modify your webhook at any time by clicking the pencil icon next to the webhook.

title: Adding custom headers to outgoing webhooks
body: You can add extra headers to your outgoing webhooks via the Code tab of the web interface. For example, if you have an API listening to the webhook, you can track the requests with API keys set as a custom header.

title: Adding custom headers to outgoing webhooks
body: You can add custom headers either when:

title: Adding custom headers to outgoing webhooks
body: Creating a new outgoing webhook.

title: Adding custom headers to outgoing webhooks
body: Modifying an existing outgoing webhook by clicking the Edit button next to the URL.

title: Adding custom headers to outgoing webhooks
body: To add the header:

title: Adding custom headers to outgoing webhooks
body: Find the WEBHOOK HEADERS section.

title: Adding custom headers to outgoing webhooks
body: Add a key and a value to the header. You need both to be able to save the header.

title: Adding custom headers to outgoing webhooks
body: Click Add header.

title: Adding custom headers to outgoing webhooks
body: Click Create webhook/Update webhook.

title: Checking outgoing webhook deliveries
body: You can check the recent deliveries of your outgoing webhooks at any time, and resend them if necessary. The deliveries are marked with appropriate status code, depending on whether the delivery was successful.

title: Checking outgoing webhook deliveries
body: Admin access only

title: Checking outgoing webhook deliveries
body: Only users with the role of admin on the app's team can access all functions of the App Settings page of an app.

title: Checking outgoing webhook deliveries
body: Open your app on Bitrise.

title: Checking outgoing webhook deliveries
body: On the main page of the app, click on the App Settings icon: .

title: Checking outgoing webhook deliveries
body: On the left, select Integrations.

title: Checking outgoing webhook deliveries
body: Scroll down to Outgoing Webhooks.

title: Checking outgoing webhook deliveries
body: Find your webhook and select the icon.

title: Checking outgoing webhook deliveries
body: Select a delivery and expand it to show the full request and the response.

title: Checking outgoing webhook deliveries
body: You can redeliver the webhook payload at any time. Find the delivery you need and click the icon next to it.

title: Checking outgoing webhook deliveries
body: Editing the payload

title: Checking outgoing webhook deliveries
body: Before trying to deliver the webhook payload again, you can edit the webhook configuration. Close the Recent deliveries pop-up window and click the icon next to the webhook to edit it. When finished, click Update webhook.

title: Configuring the repository URL and default branch
body: When adding a new app to Bitrise, you specify a repository that is used to store your source code, and a branch that Bitrise uses as the default branch. You can change these at any time from App Settings.

title: Configuring the repository URL and default branch
body: When adding a new app to Bitrise, you specify a repository that is used to store your source code, and a branch that Bitrise uses as the default branch.

title: Configuring the repository URL and default branch
body: Once the app is set up, you can change these at any time.

title: Changing the repository URL
body: The repository URL is the address where your repository can be accessed by Bitrise. It can be either an SSH URL or an HTTPS URL: we strongly recommend using SSH URLs for all private apps for security reasons.

title: Changing the repository URL
body: Using an HTTPS URL

title: Changing the repository URL
body: You can use HTTPS Git URLs: in this case, you don't need an SSH key. However, accessing a private Git repository or a Git submodule via an HTTPS URL requires some extra configuration: Accessing a private Git repository with HTTPS.

title: Changing the repository URL
body: If you move your project's repository, or the URL changes for any other reason, you can update it on Bitrise and continue building without an issue.

title: Changing the repository URL
body: Admin access only

title: Changing the repository URL
body: Only users with the role of admin on the app's team can access all functions of the App Settings page of an app.

title: Changing the repository URL
body: Open your app on Bitrise.

title: Changing the repository URL
body: On the main page of the app, click on the App Settings icon: .

title: Changing the repository URL
body: From the menu on the left, select General.

title: Changing the repository URL
body: Click Edit.

title: Changing the repository URL
body: Find the Repository URL field.

title: Changing the repository URL
body: Enter the new URL.

title: Changing the repository URL
body: Click Save to save changes.

title: Changing the default branch
body: The default branch is the branch of your repository that Bitrise will use if no other configuration indicates otherwise.

title: Changing the default branch
body: You can change the default branch at any time.

title: Changing the default branch
body: Admin access only

title: Changing the default branch
body: Only users with the role of admin on the app's team can access all functions of the App Settings page of an app.

title: Changing the default branch
body: Open your app on Bitrise.

title: Changing the default branch
body: On the main page of the app, click on the App Settings icon: .

title: Changing the default branch
body: From the menu on the left, select General.

title: Changing the default branch
body: Click Edit.

title: Changing the default branch
body: Find the Default branch field.

title: Changing the default branch
body: Type the name of the branch you want to use as default branch.

title: Changing the default branch
body: Click Save to save changes.

title: Configuring SSH keys
body: To access your app's repository, Bitrise needs an SSH key. You can add an SSH key when you first add an app to Bitrise but you can update your keys at any point in App settings.

title: Configuring SSH keys
body: SSH keys are the primary method of authentication. To access your app's repository, Bitrise needs a public-private SSH keypair, with the public key registered to your app's Git repository.

title: Configuring SSH keys
body: Using an HTTPS URL

title: Configuring SSH keys
body: You can use HTTPS Git URLs: in this case, you don't need an SSH key. However, accessing a private Git repository or a Git submodule via an HTTPS URL requires some extra configuration: Accessing a private Git repository with HTTPS.

title: Configuring SSH keys
body: You can add an SSH key when you first add an app to Bitrise but you can update your keys at any point. You can even skip SSH key configuration when adding the app and register SSH keys later.

title: Configuring SSH keys
body: Generating your own SSH key

title: Configuring SSH keys
body: You can generate your own SSH keypair with a simple Command Line/Terminal command:

title: Configuring SSH keys
body: ssh-keygen -t rsa -b 4096 -P '' -f ./bitrise-ssh -m PEM

title: Configuring SSH keys
body: This will generate two files in the current directory (the directory where you run the command):

title: Configuring SSH keys
body: bitrise-ssh (private key)

title: Configuring SSH keys
body: bitrise-ssh.pub (public key)

title: Configuring SSH keys
body: You should copy paste the public key to your Git hosting service (GitHub, Bitbucket, etc.), and when you register your app on bitrise.io, you’ll have to provide the private key.

title: Configuring SSH keys
body: To configure SSH keys on bitrise.io:

title: Configuring SSH keys
body: Admin access only

title: Configuring SSH keys
body: Only users with the role of admin on the app's team can access all functions of the App Settings page of an app.

title: Configuring SSH keys
body: Open your app on Bitrise.

title: Configuring SSH keys
body: On the main page of the app, click on the App Settings icon: .

title: Configuring SSH keys
body: Find the SSH settings section.

title: Configuring SSH keys
body: Click Change SSH keypair.

title: Configuring SSH keys
body: If you haven't had an SSH key added before, the button will show Add SSH keypair instead.

title: Configuring SSH keys
body: Choose from one of three options:

title: Configuring SSH keys
body: Generate SSH keypair and auto-add it to GitHub: Bitrise automatically registers a public SSH key to your GitHub repository. Choose this if you have administrator rights to the repository.

title: Configuring SSH keys
body: Generate SSH keypair: Bitrise generates an SSH keypair for you, and you have to manually register the public key to your Git repository.

title: Configuring SSH keys
body: Use your own SSH keypair: You provide your own SSH keypair for authentication, and you have to manually register the public key to your Git repository.

title: Managing user access to an app
body: To collaborate on an app, users must be part of the app's team. You can add Workspace groups to an app from the Workspace settings' Team page or from the App settings page.

title: Managing user access to an app
body: Each Bitrise app is owned by a Workspace - but this doesn't mean that all members belonging to that Workspace have access to a given app. In order to be able to collaborate on an app, users must be part of the app's team.

title: Managing user access to an app
body: An app's team consists of all users invited to work on an app. There are two ways to add users to an app's team:

title: Managing user access to an app
body: Adding outside contributors.

title: Managing user access to an app
body: Adding one of the groups from the Workspace that owns the app.

title: Managing user access to an app
body: Similarly, there are two ways to revoke access to an app:

title: Managing user access to an app
body: Revoking access from a group.

title: Managing user access to an app
body: Revoking access from a user.

title: Adding an outside contributor to an app team
body: An outside contributor is a user who is a part of an app's team but isn't a member of the Workspace that owns the app.

title: Adding an outside contributor to an app team
body: Admins and owners only

title: Adding an outside contributor to an app team
body: You need to be an admin on the app's team or one of the owners of the Workspace that owns the app to be able to add new team members to an app.

title: Adding an outside contributor to an app team
body: Allowing outside contributors

title: Adding an outside contributor to an app team
body: Workspaces can disable allowing outside contributors. To do so, go to your Workspace's profile page and select the Team tab on the left. Switch to the Outside contributors tab and toggle off Allow outside contributors.

title: Adding an outside contributor to an app team
body: When an app with outside contributors is transferred to a Workspace that doesn't allow outside contributors, the existing outside contributors of the app are automatically removed from the app's team.

title: Adding an outside contributor to an app team
body: Admin access only

title: Adding an outside contributor to an app team
body: Only users with the role of admin on the app's team can access all functions of the App Settings page of an app.

title: Adding an outside contributor to an app team
body: Open your app on Bitrise.

title: Adding an outside contributor to an app team
body: On the main page of the app, click on the App Settings icon: .

title: Adding an outside contributor to an app team
body: From the menu on the left, select Team.

title: Adding an outside contributor to an app team
body: Make sure that you are on the People tab.

title: Adding an outside contributor to an app team
body: Click Add Contributor.

title: Adding an outside contributor to an app team
body: Type their email address and select their role.

title: Adding an outside contributor to an app team
body: If they are not registered on Bitrise, we will send out an invitation email for them.

title: Adding an outside contributor to an app team
body: Click Save.

title: Adding Workspace groups to an app team
body: Workspaces consist of groups: the groups contain all users who belong to the Workspace. To assign users from a Workspace to a certain app, the most convenient way is to assign their group to the app's team.
