title: Adding Workspace groups to an app team
body: An app team consisting of Workspace groups

title: Adding Workspace groups to an app team
body: Let’s say the Workspace called TestSpace owns an app called TestApp. TestOrg has the following groups:

title: Adding Workspace groups to an app team
body: Group Alpha - they are assigned to TestApp with an Admin role. Members of this group can assign other groups to the app or add outside contributors, change app settings, manage roles and workflows.

title: Adding Workspace groups to an app team
body: Group Beta - they are assigned to TestApp with a Developer role. Members of this group can run builds, view build logs and view builds.

title: Adding Workspace groups to an app team
body: Group Gamma - they are assigned to TestApp with a Tester/QA role. They can only view builds.

title: Adding Workspace groups to an app team
body: There are two ways to assign Workspace groups to a Bitrise app's team:

title: Adding Workspace groups to an app team
body: You can assign it from the Team tab of the Workspace's profile settings page.

title: Adding Workspace groups to an app team
body: You can assign it on the App settings page of the app.

title: Assigning a group from the Workspace's profile settings page
body: Sign in with an account that is an owner of the Workspace and open its profile page by selecting the gear icon next to the Workspace's name.

title: Assigning a group from the Workspace's profile settings page
body: On the left, select Team from the menu options and make sure you are on the Groups tab.

title: Assigning a group from the Workspace's profile settings page
body: Choose the group you wish to assign, and click the dropdown menu indicated by the symbol.

title: Assigning a group from the Workspace's profile settings page
body: Click Manage access to apps.

title: Assigning a group from the Workspace's profile settings page
body: You can find the app(s) you need and select the appropriate role for the group, or you can select a role for the group for all current apps using the radio buttons.

title: Assigning a group from the Workspace's profile settings page
body: Role cheatsheets

title: Assigning a group from the Workspace's profile settings page
body: You can check out the role cheatsheet on the User roles on app teams, or find it on any app’s Team tab.

title: Assigning a group from the Workspace's profile settings page
body: Click Save changes to finalize changes.

title: Assigning a group from the App settings page
body: Go to the app’s page on bitrise.io.

title: Assigning a group from the App settings page
body: Click on App Settings.

title: Assigning a group from the App settings page
body: On the left, select Team from the menu options.

title: Assigning a group from the App settings page
body: Make sure that you are on the Groups tab.

title: Assigning a group from the App settings page
body: Click on Grant access for group.

title: Assigning a group from the App settings page
body: Find the group you wish to add and select the role for the group using the drop down menus.

title: Assigning a group from the App settings page
body: Click Save.

title: Revoking access to an app from a group
body: Admin access only

title: Revoking access to an app from a group
body: Only users with the role of admin on the app's team can access all functions of the App Settings page of an app.

title: Revoking access to an app from a group
body: Open your app on Bitrise.

title: Revoking access to an app from a group
body: On the main page of the app, click on the App Settings icon: .

title: Revoking access to an app from a group
body: From the menu on the left, select Team.

title: Revoking access to an app from a group
body: Go to the Group tab.

title: Revoking access to an app from a group
body: Search for the group you would like to remove and click "".

title: Revoking access to an app from a group
body: Click Revoke access in the resulting window to revoke the group's access from the app.

title: Revoking access to an app from a single user
body: Admin access only

title: Revoking access to an app from a single user
body: Only users with the role of admin on the app's team can access all functions of the App Settings page of an app.

title: Revoking access to an app from a single user
body: Open your app on Bitrise.

title: Revoking access to an app from a single user
body: On the main page of the app, click on the App Settings icon: .

title: Revoking access to an app from a single user
body: From the menu on the left, select Team.

title: Revoking access to an app from a single user
body: Go to the People tab.

title: Revoking access to an app from a single user
body: Search for the user you would like to remove and click "".

title: Revoking access to an app from a single user
body: Click Yes in the resulting window to revoke their access from the app.

title: User roles on app teams
body: Roles are very important on Bitrise. They limit what you can and cannot do with an application.

title: User roles on app teams
body: Roles work on an app basis: the same user can have different roles on different applications. As such, Workspaces have no inherent roles, apart from that of the Workspace owners: Workspaces have groups and different groups can be assigned different roles on an app's team.

title: Owners
body: Bitrise apps are owned by Workspaces. On the app's team, users who are owners in the Workspace have the owner access right to the app.

title: Owners
body: Owners have unlimited access to apps. Only owners can destroy apps or transfer the ownership of apps, and only they have access to payment information.

title: Admins
body: Here’s the role cheatsheet for admins of an app's team:

title: Admins
body: An admin cannot delete an app but can invite other members to work on the app. The admin can also give admin rights to other users - however, they cannot transfer ownership of the app!

title: Developers
body: Here’s the role cheatsheet for developers:

title: Developers
body: Developers cannot change team member roles, add new team members, remove existing team members or create, edit or delete workflows. They can, however, run builds and view build logs.

title: Developers
body: They have no access to sensitive data such as payment information, access tokens or even webhooks.

title: Testers/QA
body: Here’s the role cheatsheet for testers/QA:

title: Testers/QA
body: Testers can only view builds. They cannot access build logs and they cannot modify the app in any way or form.

title: Testers/QA
body: They have no access to sensitive data such as payment information, access tokens or even webhooks.

title: Changing the owner of an app
body: You can change the owner of an app from the Workspace profile page or from the app's App settings page.

title: Changing the owner of an app
body: Workspaces own apps. When you add an app to Bitrise, you select the Workspace that will act as the owner of the app. From that point, only the owners of the Workspace can change the ownership of the app.

title: Changing the owner of an app
body: It can happen that you need to transfer an application on Bitrise to another Workspace. This can be done in two ways:

title: Changing the owner of an app
body: You can select the apps you want to transfer from the Workspace profile page's Apps tab.

title: Changing the owner of an app
body: Any given app can be transferred from the app's App settings page.

title: Transferring apps from the Workspace profile page
body: Owners only

title: Transferring apps from the Workspace profile page
body: You must be an owner of the Workspace to transfer its apps to another Workspace.

title: Transferring apps from the Workspace profile page
body: Apps with outside contributors

title: Transferring apps from the Workspace profile page
body: When transferring apps with outside contributors to a Workspace that doesn't allow outside contributors, the existing contributors are automatically removed from the app's team.

title: Transferring apps from the Workspace profile page
body: Log in to Bitrise and open the account selector dropdown menu in the top right.

title: Transferring apps from the Workspace profile page
body: Find your Workspace and click the little gear icon next to its name to get to your Workspace's profile page.

title: Transferring apps from the Workspace profile page
body: On the left, select Apps from the menu options.

title: Transferring apps from the Workspace profile page
body: Click the Transfer ownership (↔) button next to the app's name to select an app.

title: Transferring apps from the Workspace profile page
body: Select a user or Workspace to transfer the app to them.

title: Transferring apps from the Workspace profile page
body: Click Transfer ownership to finalize.

title: Transferring apps from the Workspace profile page
body: Transferring ownership is permanent

title: Transferring apps from the Workspace profile page
body: Only the new owner can change the app's ownership after the transfer has been completed!

title: Transferring an app from App settings
body: Log in with an account that is an owner of the app.

title: Transferring an app from App settings
body: Open the App Settings page.

title: Transferring an app from App settings
body: Make sure that you have General selected from the menu options on the left.

title: Transferring an app from App settings
body: Scroll down to the Danger Zone label.

title: Transferring an app from App settings
body: Click the Transfer app ownership button.

title: Transferring an app from App settings
body: Select a user or a Workspace to transfer the app to them.

title: Transferring an app from App settings
body: Click Transfer ownership to finalize.

title: Transferring an app from App settings
body: Transferring ownership is permanent!

title: Transferring an app from App settings
body: Only the new owner can change the app's ownership after the transfer has been completed!

title: Enabling the Bitrise Support Access for your app
body: You can enable the Bitrise Support Access from the App settings page. This way, our support team can have access to your project, specifically your Workflow, build log, app settings, and your bitrise.yml.

title: Enabling the Bitrise Support Access for your app
body: If you’re stuck with a problem on Bitrise, go to our Support Center page and see what helps you the most: you can browse our Documentation, check out our Knowledge Base or our community pages to find solutions for specific issues. You can also get in touch with our Support team by clicking the Submit a Request button.

title: Enabling the Bitrise Support Access for your app
body: In this article we describe how you can enable the Bitrise Support Access so that our Support team can have access to your app, specifically your Workflow, build log, app settings or your bitrise.yml file. With the toggle function, you can easily turn the Bitrise Support Access on and off. No need to add us as a user to your app's Team.

title: Enabling the Bitrise Support Access for your app
body: The Bitrise Support user, when enabled, has Admin access to your app. That means it can do anything that a regular user with Admin access rights on an app can do: it has access to your builds and can edit your Workflows, modify the inputs of the Team, Code and options in App Settings.

title: Enabling the Bitrise Support Access for your app
body: No access to billing information

title: Enabling the Bitrise Support Access for your app
body: The Bitrise Support user can’t see your Account information or any Billing information. Only the owner of the account has access to this information and has the right to modify any account-related records.

title: Enabling the Bitrise Support Access for your app
body: The Support user can’t see your other apps where the Support user is not enabled. For details, see What the Bitrise Support user can/can't do?

title: Enabling the Bitrise Support Access for your app
body: How long does the Bitrise Support Access remain active?

title: Enabling the Bitrise Support Access for your app
body: Due to security reasons once you toggle the Bitrise Support Access on, it will remain active for two weeks after which it automatically gets revoked.

title: Enabling the Bitrise Support Access for your app
body: Let’s see how to set it up!

title: Enabling the Bitrise Support Access for your app
body: Admin access only

title: Enabling the Bitrise Support Access for your app
body: Only users with the role of admin on the app's team can access all functions of the App Settings page of an app.

title: Enabling the Bitrise Support Access for your app
body: Open your app on Bitrise.

title: Enabling the Bitrise Support Access for your app
body: On the main page of the app, click on the App Settings icon: .

title: Enabling the Bitrise Support Access for your app
body: On the left, select General from the menu options.

title: Enabling the Bitrise Support Access for your app
body: Scroll down to the Support Access and toggle the switch to the right to enable it. It might take a couple of seconds to work and you might need to refresh your page to see the enabled status.

title: Enabling the Bitrise Support Access for your app
body: In case of a failing Workflow, our best practice is to create a new and correct version of the failing Workflow called support-testing. You can compare our support-testing with your own and update yours or keep the support-testing orkflow, rename it as you wish, and develop it further.

title: Apps with submodules or private repo dependencies
body: Bitrise needs access to all repositories or submodules for a successful build, so if your app has submodules or private repo dependencies, you must grant Bitrise access to those as well.

title: Apps with submodules or private repo dependencies
body: If you have a project with one or more submodules or other private repository dependencies (for example, CocoaPods repositories), Bitrise needs access to all repositories or submodules for a successful build. Bitrise uses SSH to access Git repositories of private apps: to grant access, you need to make sure all the repositories can be accessed with the public SSH key generated for your Bitrise app.

title: Apps with submodules or private repo dependencies
body: App privacy

title: Apps with submodules or private repo dependencies
body: The scope of this guide mainly covers private Bitrise apps. The Git cloning submodules and repository dependencies section briefly covers how to access multiple repositories with a public app: the process is much simpler and all you need is to make sure that all repositories have an HTTPS git clone URL. You don’t need to worry about SSH keys with public apps, as they cannot have them.

title: Apps with submodules or private repo dependencies
body: There are two ways to achieve this:

title: Apps with submodules or private repo dependencies
body: Register the same SSH key for every repository you have to access during the build.

title: Apps with submodules or private repo dependencies
body: Register the SSH key with a bot user and add that user to all repositories.

title: Apps with submodules or private repo dependencies
body: Registering the same SSH key for every repository is the best, most secure way - but not all services support it. GitLab and Bitbucket does support it, GitHub, however, doesn’t. If your code is stored on GitHub, read on!

title: Apps with submodules or private repo dependencies
body: We’ll go through the other option, using a bot user or machine user - GitHub calls them machine users - in detail. In brief, the concept is simple: you register the Bitrise public SSH key to a user and add that user to all repositories that have to be accessed for your Bitrise build.

title: Apps with submodules or private repo dependencies
body: Machine user with read only access

title: Apps with submodules or private repo dependencies
body: It is not required to use a special bot/machine user: you can add the SSH key to your own account on the git hosting service. The best practice, however, is to use a machine user, with read only access, for those repositories you want to access during the build.

title: Apps with submodules or private repo dependencies
body: GitHub recommends this method for accessing multiple repositories. Let’s quickly go through an example.

title: Apps with submodules or private repo dependencies
body: The MultiBit app

title: Apps with submodules or private repo dependencies
body: We have a Bitrise app we’ll call MultiBit. It has a main repository and it needs to pull additional data from two other, private repositories during a Bitrise build. Our main user is called BitMan and his GitHub account is linked to his Bitrise account. To access the private repositories during the build, BitMan creates another user on GitHub, called BitBot. BitBot will be the machine user.

title: Apps with submodules or private repo dependencies
body: Now, BitMan accesses the App Settings page of his Bitrise app, and copies the public SSH key from the Current SSH public key field. BitMan then adds the SSH key to the BitBot user on GitHub and adds BitBot to the two private repositories as a collaborator. Now BitBot has the Bitrise public key and has access to the private repositories as necessary. It’s time to test if BitMan’s setup works.

title: Apps with submodules or private repo dependencies
body: BitMan goes to Bitrise and opens the Workflow Editor. He has the Activate SSH Key Step in his repository so the SSH key will work. BitMan adds a Script Step to clone the private repositories - as the Git Clone Step only works with the main repository! Once all that is done, the build should work as expected.

title: Using a machine user to access private repositories
body: A machine or bot user is a GitHub user that is not used by humans, instead it is exclusively used for automation. This is the best way to access a private repository: you create a machine user, add a public SSH key to the user, and then provide the user read access to the repository.

title: Adding the machine user to your repository
body: Create a new GitHub user account, one that will serve as the machine user.

title: Adding the machine user to your repository
body: Go to your repository on GitHub and select the Settings tab.

title: Adding the machine user to your repository
body: On the left side menu, select Collaborators & teams.

title: Adding the machine user to your repository
body: Scroll down to the Collaborators window.

title: Adding the machine user to your repository
body: In the search input field, search for the username of your newly created account.

title: Adding the machine user to your repository
body: Click Add Collaborator.

title: Adding the machine user to your repository
body: Change the user permission to Read.

title: Adding the machine user to your repository
body: By default, the invited collaborator’s permission is Write. You can keep it that way, of course, but a Read permission is enough for Bitrise.

title: Adding the SSH key to the machine user
body: In order for Bitrise to be able to use the machine user to access your repository, you must add the same SSH key to the machine user and the app on Bitrise.

title: When adding a new app
body: Start the process of adding your app on Bitrise.

title: When adding a new app
body: When prompted to setup repository access, you can choose either Automatic or Add own SSH:

title: When adding a new app
body: If you choose Add own SSH, you can generate your own SSH keypair. Provide the generated SSH key for the app and add the public key to your GitHub machine user.

title: When adding a new app
body: If you choose Automatic, click I need to when asked if you need to use an additional private repository. Copy the SSH public key to your GitHub machine user.

title: When adding a new app
body: Finish the process.

title: When your app already exists
body: Admin access only

title: When your app already exists
body: Only users with the role of admin on the app's team can access all functions of the App Settings page of an app.

title: When your app already exists
body: Open your app on Bitrise.

title: When your app already exists
body: On the main page of the app, click on the App Settings icon: .

title: When your app already exists
body: On the left, select Integrations from the menu options.

title: When your app already exists
body: Copy the SSH key from the Current SSH public key field.

title: When your app already exists
body: Add it to your GitHub machine user.

title: Git cloning submodules and repository dependencies
body: You have two options when it comes to accessing multiple repositories during a Bitrise build:

title: Git cloning submodules and repository dependencies
body: Cloning all the repositories on the virtual machine, and accessing them as needed.

title: Git cloning submodules and repository dependencies
body: Adding the additional repositories as submodules to your main repository.

title: Git cloning submodules and repository dependencies
body: In the latter case, you do not need to worry about cloning them: if you set up SSH access correctly, the Git Clone Step will take care of everything.

title: Git cloning submodules and repository dependencies
body: If you don’t want to or can’t add your repository dependencies as submodules, read on: we’ll talk about how to clone them.

title: Git cloning submodules and repository dependencies
body: Public vs private apps

title: Git cloning submodules and repository dependencies
body: There is one important detail to keep in mind when you want to give access to all submodules or private repository dependencies for an app: the app’s privacy settings determine what git URL should you use.

title: Git cloning submodules and repository dependencies
body: If you have a private app: use SSH URLs everywhere! Most services support SSH key based authentication only for SSH URLs (for example, git@github.com:bitrise-io/bitrise.git). Therefore every private repository you want to use have to be addressed with the SSH URL. If you have direct private git repo references in your CocoaPods Podfile, you’ll have to use the SSH URL there as well. The same applies for submodules and every other private git repository URL you want to use with the SSH key you register on bitrise.io.

title: Git cloning submodules and repository dependencies
body: If you have a public app: use HTTPS URLs everywhere! SSH URLs require SSH keys even if the repository is public. For security reasons, public apps CANNOT have SSH keys. As HTTPS git clone URLs do not require any authentication in the case of public repositories, they should be used for public Bitrise apps.

title: Git cloning submodules and repository dependencies
body: The Git Clone Step

title: Git cloning submodules and repository dependencies
body: The Git Clone Step only works with the main repository. If you need to access multiple private repositories, do not add multiple Git Clone Steps. Use Script Steps to clone those repositories on the Bitrise virtual machine.

title: Git cloning submodules and repository dependencies
body: To clone additional private repositories during the build:

title: Git cloning submodules and repository dependencies
body: Make sure you added a user with the Bitrise public SSH key to all the repositories.

title: Git cloning submodules and repository dependencies
body: Make sure you have the Activate SSH Key Step and the Git Clone Step at the start of your Workflow.

title: Git cloning submodules and repository dependencies
body: Add one or more Script Steps to clone the additional private repositories to the build.

title: Git cloning submodules and repository dependencies
body: Run a build.

title: Git cloning submodules and repository dependencies
body: Cloning issues

title: Git cloning submodules and repository dependencies
body: If you encounter issues with git cloning - for example, not all submodules are cloned - try the following command after cloning:

title: Git cloning submodules and repository dependencies
body: git submodule update –recursive –remote –merge –force

title: Public apps
body: To create a public app, simply add a new app to Bitrise and at the start of the process, set the privacy of the app to Public. If your Bitrise app is public, anyone who has the build URL can see the build logs.

title: Public apps
body: Open source projects are great - we all love them! They can be a pain to maintain, however, especially with CI/CD in the picture. That’s why we have introduced the Public Apps feature for Bitrise: to make everyone’s life a lot easier!

title: Public apps
body: If your Bitrise app is public, anyone who has the build URL can see the build logs. For example, if the CI status check on GitHub fails on a pull request, anyone can click on the build URL and view the build logs.

title: Public apps
body: To create a public app, simply add a new app to Bitrise and at the start of the process, set the privacy of the app to Public.

title: Public apps
body: Can't modify privacy later

title: Public apps
body: You can't change this setting later! Once you've added an app as a public app, you can't set it back to private. You would have to add the app again.

title: Public apps
body: When you have a public app, outside contributors can troubleshoot issues easier, find out why, for example, a pull request of theirs resulted in a failed build. They do not have to be invited to a Bitrise team to be able to view Bitrise logs and they do not need the help of a Bitrise team member, either.

title: Public apps
body: Of course, this does not mean anyone can do anything with your public app on Bitrise. If the user viewing the logs is not invited to work on the app in some role, they will only be able to:

title: Public apps
body: View the build logs.

title: Public apps
body: Download the build logs.

title: Public apps
body: View the build’s bitrise.yml file.

title: Public apps
body: Public app’s build logs are available for anyone

title: Public apps
body: Remember: a public app’s build logs and bitrise.yml file can be seen by anyone - make sure these files do not expose anything you do not want to be seen!

title: Creating white label app versions
body: You can create different versions of your white label project and build all or just one version by chaining Workflows and setting differences in Environment Variables.

title: Creating white label app versions
body: This guide explains how to create different versions of your white label project and build all or just one version by chaining Workflows and setting differences in Environment Variables.

title: Creating white label app versions
body: In this article, we’re building three individual versions (red, green, white) of our white label project.

title: Creating white label app versions
body: What you’ll need for this setup:

title: Creating white label app versions
body: A main Workflow that launches each version-specific Workflow.

title: Creating white label app versions
body: One or more version-specific Workflow(s) where you can set all the parameters that distinguish your versions from each other.

title: Creating white label app versions
body: A utility Workflow which describes your build logic, and refers to the version-specific options as parameters. Utility Workflows are Workflows that have an underscore before their Workflow ID. Utility Workflows cannot be executed with the bitrise_run command: you need to reference them with the before_run or after_run properties. You can chain utility Workflows with your regular Workflows in the Workflow Editor.

title: Prepping Workflows of a white label app
body: Add your app to Bitrise in the usual way.

title: Prepping Workflows of a white label app
body: Click your app on the Dashboard and go to Workflows.

title: Prepping Workflows of a white label app
body: Next to WORKFLOW, click + to create your main Workflow.

title: Prepping Workflows of a white label app
body: Add a new Workflow based on an Empty Workflow.

title: Prepping Workflows of a white label app
body: In this example, our main Workflow is called allcolor. This Workflow will start running your version-specific Workflows in the chain.

title: Prepping Workflows of a white label app
body: Click + again to create your version-specific Workflow.

title: Prepping Workflows of a white label app
body: Keep adding as many Workflows as many different versions you wish to create.

title: Prepping Workflows of a white label app
body: Go to the Env Vars tab and add your version-specific parameters to each Workflow you’ve just created.

title: Prepping Workflows of a white label app
body: As you can see in this image we’re adding Workflow Environment Variables to our green, red and white Workflows but leaving allcolor intact.

title: Prepping Workflows of a white label app
body: Go back to the Workflows tab and click Workflow to create your utility Workflow.

title: Prepping Workflows of a white label app
body: Make sure you give a name that starts with an underscore, for example, _runner, otherwise Bitrise CLI will not treat it as a utility Workflow.

title: Prepping Workflows of a white label app
body: Add Steps to your utility Workflow.

title: Prepping Workflows of a white label app
body: In this example, we’re adding a Script Step which will inherit the Environment Variable from the Workflows and print out the value in the build log.

title: Chaining Workflows for a white label app
body: Now that we have a bunch of Workflows ready, it’s time to chain them together in the right order.

title: Chaining Workflows for a white label app
body: Select your main Workflow (allcolor in this example) that is responsive to triggers.

title: Chaining Workflows for a white label app
body: Click Add Workflow after, select the version-specific Workflow, and hit Done.

title: Chaining Workflows for a white label app
body: Click Add Workflow after again and add the utility Workflow right after the version-specific Workflow.

title: Chaining Workflows for a white label app
body: Keep adding Workflows depending on how many versions you’d like to build. In this guide, we’re adding 3 different types of Workflows after allcolor where each Workflow is followed by the same utility Workflow.

title: Chaining Workflows for a white label app
body: This is what the setup looks like on the Workflows tab.

title: Chaining Workflows for a white label app
body: Go back to your Build’s page and click Start/Schedule a build.

title: Chaining Workflows for a white label app
body: In the Build configuration pop-up window, select your main Workflow under Workflow. This will kickstart your chained Workflows and build the app versions of your white label app.

title: Chaining Workflows for a white label app
body: In our simple example, here is the output of the chained Workflows:

title: Steps and Workflows
body: Steps and Workflows are the heart of how Bitrise works. A Bitrise build is simply a series of Steps, defined in a Workflow, executed by the Bitrise CLI on our virtual machines (or your own).

title: Steps and Workflows
body: Steps and Workflows are the heart of how Bitrise works. A Bitrise build is simply a series of Steps, defined in a Workflow, executed by the Bitrise CLI on our virtual machines (or your own).

title: Steps and Workflows
body: A Step contains the code that performs the build task. You can configure the inputs and parameters that define the task, and view and reuse the outputs a Step generates.

title: Steps and Workflows
body: When a build of an app is running, the Steps will be executed in the order that is defined in the Workflow.

title: Steps and Workflows
body: You can easily move Steps around in a Workflow, you can chain different Workflows together, and you can configure your app so that different branches or code events trigger builds with different Workflows.

title: Steps
body: A Step is a block of script execution that encapsulates a build task on Bitrise: the code to perform that task, the inputs and parameters you can define for the task, and the outputs the task generates.

title: Steps
body: Steps are the heart of Bitrise. A Step is a build task: for example, the Git Clone Step clones your Git repository at the start of a build while the Google Play Deploy Step can deploy your finished app to the Play Store.

title: Steps
body: A Step contains the code that performs the build task. You can configure the inputs and parameters that define the task, and view and reuse the outputs a Step generates. Reusing the output means that another Step can use it as the value of one of its inputs.

title: Steps
body: Our Steps are defined in YAML format, and written in either bash or Go.

title: Steps
body: You can find a list of our Steps in:

title: Steps
body: The Integrations page.

title: Steps
body: The Bitrise StepLib.

title: Steps
body: The Workflow Editor.

title: Steps
body: You can also create and run any custom script you want as part of your Bitrise build using the Script Step. All you need to do is specify the script runner (the default is bash), add the script, and run a build. For more information on how to set up these custom scripts, check out Bitrise Script Step - Running (Bash, Python, NodeJS, Ruby, Swift, Kotlin).

title: Steps
body: For the purposes of your builds, Steps can be managed directly from the Workflow Editor. You can rearrange them, set their versions, add or remove Steps at any time.

title: Types of Steps
body: Bitrise has over 300 Steps in its Step Library (StepLib) which third-party companies or open-source teams can enrich with Steps based on their services/tools.

title: Types of Steps
body: There are three different types of Steps at Bitrise. You can identify each one based on their labels on our GUI:

title: Types of Steps
body: Official Bitrise Steps: These Steps are created and maintained by Bitrise. These Steps are labeled by a green badge and a "B".

title: Types of Steps
body: Verified Steps: These Steps are created and maintained by the community, but they are owned by a service or tool or an open-source team that guarantees secure, maintained, consistent, and high-quality performance for any Bitrise user. These Steps are labeled by a blue badge and a check mark. For more information about Verified Steps, check out our guide.

title: Types of Steps
body: Community Steps: These Steps can be created by anyone in the community. These Steps are not labeled and don't have a badge. If you would like to learn how to develop Steps and share them with the Bitrise community, check out Developing a new Step.

title: Adding Steps to a Workflow
body: Steps can be added or removed any time from your Workflows. You can add any Step to your Workflow - there are absolutely no restrictions. It’s possible to add a Step specific to, for example, iOS apps to a Workflow of an Android app.

title: Adding Steps to a Workflow
body: Steps can be added or removed any time from your Workflows. When adding a new app to Bitrise, the project scanner generates at least one Workflow with some default Steps but you don't have to use these at all: it's up to you what Steps you want to include.

title: Adding Steps to a Workflow
body: You can add any Step to your Workflow - there are absolutely no restrictions. Please note that this means that it’s possible to add a Step specific to, for example, iOS apps to a Workflow of an Android app. Always make sure you only add the relevant Steps to your Workflow!

title: Adding Steps in the Workflow Editor
body: Open your app on Bitrise.

title: Adding Steps in the Workflow Editor
body: Click the Workflows button on the main page.

title: Adding Steps in the Workflow Editor
body: Select a Workflow from the WORKFLOW dropdown menu.

title: Adding Steps in the Workflow Editor
body: Click the + symbol between two Steps to insert a Step at that position.

title: Adding Steps in the Workflow Editor
body: Search for the Step you need.

title: Adding Steps in the Workflow Editor
body: Search filter

title: Adding Steps in the Workflow Editor
body: Be aware of the filter to the right of the search field. By default, the filter is set to the platform type of your app. For example, if you want to add a Step to an iOS app, the the search will be filtered to iOS Steps. Click ALL to search among all Steps.

title: Adding Steps in the Workflow Editor
body: Click the Step to add it to the Workflow.

title: Adding Steps from alternative sources
body: Generally, we recommend using Steps that are part of the official Bitrise Step Library. But you can add Steps from other sources, if you want to: you can use either a Git URL or a local path.

title: Adding Steps from alternative sources
body: On the Bitrise website, the git:: special source is the easiest way to use a Step that is not in the Bitrise Step Library. Let’s see how.

title: Adding Steps from alternative sources
body: Open your app on Bitrise.

title: Adding Steps from alternative sources
body: Click the Workflows button on the main page.

title: Adding Steps from alternative sources
body: Go to the bitrise.yml tab.

title: Adding Steps from alternative sources
body: Add the git URL of the Step you want to use.

title: Adding Steps from alternative sources
body: In this example, we’re adding the Script Step from a git source:

title: Adding Steps from alternative sources
body: - git::https://github.com/bitrise-io/steps-script.git@1.1.3:

title: Adding Steps from alternative sources
body: Click Save.

title: Removing a Step from a Workflow
body: You can remove a Step at any time. Be aware, however, that if you add it back at a later date, the Step inputs will be set to the default value - any custom configuration will be gone.

title: Removing a Step from a Workflow
body: Disabling a Step

title: Removing a Step from a Workflow
body: If you don't want a Step to run but want to keep the Step configuration intact, you can disable the Step: Enabling or disabling a Step conditionally.

title: Removing a Step from a Workflow
body: Open your app on Bitrise.

title: Removing a Step from a Workflow
body: Click the Workflows button on the main page.

title: Removing a Step from a Workflow
body: Select a Workflow from the WORKFLOW dropdown menu.

title: Removing a Step from a Workflow
body: Click the Step you want to remove.

title: Removing a Step from a Workflow
body: Click the trash bin icon on the right.

title: Removing a Step from a Workflow
body: Click Save.

title: Step versioning
body: Bitrise Step versions follow semantic versioning: a version number looks like MAJOR.MINOR.PATCH. For example, version 3.2.1 is the first patch of the second minor version of the third major version.

title: Step versioning
body: Bitrise Step versions follow semantic versioning: a version number looks like MAJOR.MINOR.PATCH. For example, version 3.2.1 is the first patch of the second minor version of the third major version.

title: Step versioning
body: You can use any existing version of a Step in your Workflows, and different versions of the same Step in different Workflows.

title: Step versioning
body: We regularly update our Steps to make sure they are fully equipped for our users’ needs. However, you don’t have to use the latest version if you don’t want to: if an old version is stable and compatible with your build, feel free to continue using that, or roll back to it any time.

title: Locking a Step to a major or minor version
body: On the graphical UI of the Workflow Editor, you can choose between locking a Step to either a major version or a minor version in any of your Workflows. This determines what version of the Step your Workflow will use.

title: Locking a Step to a major or minor version
body: Locking a Step to a version means that your Workflow is automatically updated to use the latest release of the Step’s selected version type, either major or minor, but it won’t get updated if a different major or minor version is released.

title: Locking a Step to a major or minor version
body: If a Step is locked to a major version, it is automatically updated if a new minor version or a new patch for that major version is released. If a new major version is released, it won’t be updated.

title: Locking a Step to a major or minor version
body: If a Step is locked to a minor version, it is automatically updated only if a new patch for that minor version is released. If a new minor or major version is released, it won’t be updated.

title: Locking a Step to a major or minor version
body: Version locking

title: Locking a Step to a major or minor version
body: The Example Step’s current version in the Workflow is 2.3.3. A new minor version comes out: 2.4.0.

title: Locking a Step to a major or minor version
body: If the Step is locked to major version 2.x.x, the Step is updated to 2.4.0.

title: Locking a Step to a major or minor version
body: If the Step is locked to minor version 2.3.x, the Step is NOT updated to 2.4.0.

title: Locking a Step to a major or minor version
body: Now let’s say the Example Step gets a new major version: 3.0.0!

title: Locking a Step to a major or minor version
body: In that case, the Step will not be automatically updated either way. If you want to use the new version, you need to lock the Step to either major version 3.x.x or minor version 3.0.x. This way you can be sure that a new update will not break your builds.

title: Locking a Step to a major or minor version
body: To lock a Step to a major or minor version:

title: Locking a Step to a major or minor version
body: Open your app on Bitrise.

title: Locking a Step to a major or minor version
body: Click the Workflows button on the main page.

title: Locking a Step to a major or minor version
body: Select a Workflow from the WORKFLOW dropdown menu.

title: Locking a Step to a major or minor version
body: Select the Step.

title: Locking a Step to a major or minor version
body: Next to the name of the current version, open the dropdown menu.

title: Locking a Step to a major or minor version
body: Select the major or minor version you need: for example, 3.x.x sets it to the third major version.

title: Using a specific Step version
body: You have the option of using a specific, static Step version. For example, version 3.2.2. This means that no matter what new versions are released for the Step, your Step version will not be updated in the Workflow.

title: Using a specific Step version
body: YAML mode only!

title: Using a specific Step version
body: Please note that you cannot set a specific Step version on the graphical UI: you can only lock the Step to either a major or minor version. Setting a specific Step version is only possible in YAML mode.

title: Using a specific Step version
body: To set a specific Step version, you need to add that version to the Step reference in your app’s bitrise.yml file:

title: Using a specific Step version
body: Open your app on Bitrise.

title: Using a specific Step version
body: Click the Workflows button on the main page.

title: Using a specific Step version
body: Go to the bitrise.yml tab.

title: Using a specific Step version
body: Find the Workflow and the Step you need.

title: Using a specific Step version
body: Set the Step version as part of the Step reference.

title: Using a specific Step version
body: In this example, we're setting the Activate SSH key Step of the primary Workflow to version 4.0.3:

title: Using a specific Step version
body:
workflows:
 primary:
 steps:
 - activate-ssh-key@4.0.3:

title: Using the latest available version of the Step
body: Locking on to the latest release of a Step means that if a new version of the Step is released, the user’s Workflow is updated to use that. This includes automatic update to a new major version, potentially breaking the build. So be careful!

title: Using the latest available version of the Step
body: To make sure your Workflow will always use the latest available version of a given Step, all you have to do is remove any version information from the Step reference in the bitrise.yml file of your app:

title: Using the latest available version of the Step
body: Open your app on Bitrise.

title: Using the latest available version of the Step
body: Click the Workflows button on the main page.

title: Using the latest available version of the Step
body: Go to the bitrise.yml tab.

title: Using the latest available version of the Step
body: Find the Workflow and the Step you need.

title: Using the latest available version of the Step
body: Make sure the Step has no version information:

title: Using the latest available version of the Step
body: In this example, we're setting the Activate SSH key Step of the primary Workflow to the latest version:

title: Using the latest available version of the Step
body:
workflows:
 primary:
 steps:
 - activate-ssh-key:

title: Step inputs
body: Step inputs are the way to configure the Steps for your build. Steps have required inputs that must have a valid value and optional inputs that provide more options to customize your build.

title: Step inputs
body: Step inputs are the way to configure the Steps for your build. Steps have required inputs that must have a valid value and optional inputs that provide more options to customize your build.

title: Step inputs
body: Click on a Step to bring up its input variables on the right of the currently selected Workflow. Required inputs are marked as such in the Workflow Editor. If required inputs do not have valid values, the Step will fail.

title: Step inputs
body: Modify a Step input by either:

title: Step inputs
body: Clicking into the input field.

title: Step inputs
body: Clicking the CHANGE option next to the input field.

title: Step inputs
body: You can also use Environment Variables (Env Vars) as Step inputs.

title: Skipping Steps
body: You can configure Steps in your Bitrise builds so that they don't run if the previous Step in the Workflow failed. This can help with avoiding wasting build time and credits.

title: Skipping Steps
body: You can skip certain Steps in your Bitrise build. There is no point in running, for example, a unit test Step if the previous Step failed to build your app.

title: Skipping Steps
body: Of course, there are examples when it’s better to run a Step even if the previous Step failed. For example, if the Cache:Pull Step fails, there is no reason not to run the next Step - in fact, if the next Step is one that installs dependencies then it’s a very bad idea to skip that Step if pulling the cache is unsuccessful.

title: Skipping Steps
body: Enabling a Step conditionally

title: Skipping Steps
body: You can also configure Steps to run only in certain conditions: Enabling or disabling a Step conditionally.

title: Skipping Steps
body: To set a given Step to be skipped if the previous Step failed:

title: Skipping Steps
body: Open your app on Bitrise.

title: Skipping Steps
body: Click the Workflows button on the main page.

title: Skipping Steps
body: Select a Workflow from the WORKFLOW dropdown menu.

title: Skipping Steps
body: Select the Step you want to skip.

title: Skipping Steps
body: On the right, use the toggle to disable the Run if previous Step failed option.

title: Enabling or disabling a Step conditionally
body: You can enable or disable a Step in any given Workflow, and you can also set conditions for Steps. You can do so, either on your own computer, with the Bitrise CLI or by using the bitrise.yml tab of the Workflow Editor.

title: Enabling or disabling a Step conditionally
body: You can enable or disable a Step in any given Workflow, and you can also set conditions for Steps. You can do it either on your own computer, with the Bitrise CLI or by using the bitrise.yml tab of the Workflow Editor.

title: Enabling or disabling a Step conditionally
body: We mostly use run_if expressions to do these things. Check out the examples for possible template expressions: Examples of run_if expressions.

title: Enabling or disabling a Step conditionally
body: You can also view the examples on GitHub: Template expression examples.

title: Enabling or disabling a Step conditionally
body: A run_if can be any valid Go template

title: Enabling or disabling a Step conditionally
body: A run_if can be any valid Go template, as long as it evaluates to true or false (or any of the String representation, for example True, t, yes or y are all considered to be true). If the template evaluates to true, the Step will run, otherwise it won’t.

title: Enabling or disabling a Step conditionally
body: An example run_if to check a custom Environment Variable:

title: Enabling or disabling a Step conditionally
body:
run_if: |-
 	{{enveq "CUSTOM_ENV_VAR_KEY" "test value to test against"}}

title: Enabling or disabling a Step conditionally
body: This run_if will skip the Step if the value of CUSTOM_ENV_VAR_KEY is not test value to test against.

title: Disabling a Step
body: If you do not want to remove a Step from your Workflow but you don’t want it to run, you can disable it, using a run_if expression.

title: Disabling a Step
body: Experimenting with Workflows

title: Disabling a Step
body: To experiment with different configurations for a Workflow, without removing or disabling Steps, we recommend cloning the Workflow. You can modify the cloned Workflow as much as you wish without changing anything in the original.

title: Disabling a Step
body: Open your app’s bitrise.yml file.

title: Disabling a Step
body: Find the Step that you want to disable.

title: Disabling a Step
body: Add run_if: false to it.

title: Disabling a Step
body:
- script:
 run_if: false
 inputs:
 - content: |-
 #!/bin/bash
 echo "This will never run, because of run_if:false"

title: Running a Step only in a CI environment
body: Running a Step only in a CI environment means your build will skip that particular Step for local builds. Like disabling Steps, you can do this with a run_if expression. Use this to debug builds locally.

title: Running a Step only in a CI environment
body: The .IsCI flag

title: Running a Step only in a CI environment
body: Many Steps have this .IsCI flag set by default: for example, the Git Clone Step. However, you can change the run_if property of these Steps, too: just set it to run_if: true.

title: Running a Step only in a CI environment
body: Enabling CI mode locally

title: Running a Step only in a CI environment
body: CI mode can be enabled on your own Mac/PC by setting the CI environment to true (for example, run export CI=true in your Bash Terminal), or by running bitrise run with the --ci flag: bitrise --ci run ....

title: Running a Step only in a CI environment
body: Open your app’s bitrise.yml file.

title: Running a Step only in a CI environment
body: Find the Step that you want to disable.

title: Running a Step only in a CI environment
body: Add run_if: .IsCI to it.

title: Running a Step only in a CI environment
body:
- script:
 run_if: .IsCI
 inputs:
 - content: |-
 #!/bin/bash
 echo "This will only ever run in a CI environment because run_if: IsCI"

title: Running a Step only if the build failed
body: It is possible to run a Step ONLY if the build failed before it got to that particular Step. In addition to run_if, you will need to use the is_always_run property as well.

title: Running a Step only if the build failed
body: Open your app’s bitrise.yml file.

title: Running a Step only if the build failed
body: Find the Step that you want to disable.

title: Running a Step only if the build failed
body: Add run_if: .IsBuildFailed to it.

title: Running a Step only if the build failed
body: Add is_always_run: true to it.

title: Running a Step only if the build failed
body: This enables the Step to run even if a previous Step failed.

title: Running a Step only if the build failed
body:
- script:
 is_always_run: true
 run_if: .IsBuildFailed
 inputs:
 - content: |-
 #!/bin/bash
 echo "Build Failed!"

title: Ignoring a failed Step without failing the build
body: Usually, when a Step fails during a build, the built itself fails, too. This isn't the case with every Step, of course: both the Bitrise.io Cache:Pull and the Bitrise.io Cache:Push Steps can fail without failing the build. You can also configure any other Step to ensure their failure doesn't fail the build.

title: Ignoring a failed Step without failing the build
body: YAML mode only

title: Ignoring a failed Step without failing the build
body: You can't do this on the graphical UI of the Workflow Editor: you have to edit your app's bitrise.yml file.

title: Ignoring a failed Step without failing the build
body: Open your app on Bitrise.

title: Ignoring a failed Step without failing the build
body: Click the Workflows button on the main page.

title: Ignoring a failed Step without failing the build
body: Go to the bitrise.yml tab.

title: Ignoring a failed Step without failing the build
body: Find the Step you need.

title: Ignoring a failed Step without failing the build
body: Add the is_skippable flag to it and set it to true:

title: Ignoring a failed Step without failing the build
body:
- script: 
 is_skippable: true 
 inputs: 
 - content: |- 
 # !/bin/bash 
 echo "Failing Step." 
 exit 1 
 # exit 1 would mark this step as Failed, but it won't break the Build 
 # because of the is_skippable: true flag / property

title: Setting up run_if conditions with Script Steps
body: Sometimes the conditions required to determine whether a Step should run or not are complex and multi-layered. If so, using a complex chain of Go templates in a run_if expression can be overwhelming, especially if you prefer other languages instead of Go.

title: Setting up run_if conditions with Script Steps
body: In such cases, we recommend using a workaround: add a Script Step in your Workflow, and write a script that evaluates to a certain value. Store that value in an Environment Variable, and then the Step with the conditional expression only needs to check that value.

title: Setting up run_if conditions with Script Steps
body: Using a non-Go script for a run_if expression

title: Setting up run_if conditions with Script Steps
body: In this example, we'll create a simple Bash script and store its value, then check whether it matches a preset value.

title: Setting up run_if conditions with Script Steps
body: First, we add a Script Step, and in the script content, we define a value. Once the value is defined, we use envman to store it in an Environment Variable. In this particular case, we define a variable in Bash, and use that variable as the value for our Env Var:

title: Setting up run_if conditions with Script Steps
body:
workflows: 
 example: 
 steps: 
 - script@1:
 title: Do anything with Script step 
 inputs: 
 - content: |- 
 #!/usr/bin/env bash
 # fail if any commands fails 
 set -e
 # debug log
 set -x
 # creating the variable and storing it as an Env Var 
 my_variable='This is the value we need!' 
 envman add --key OUR_CONDITION --value "$my_variable"

title: Setting up run_if conditions with Script Steps
body: We then create a simple run_if expression for the Step for which we need a condition. In this case, our Step is the Save cache Step, and we'll check if the value of the OUR_CONDITION variable matches the value stored in the previous Bash variable:

title: Setting up run_if conditions with Script Steps
Setting up run_if conditions with Script Steps
body: Since the values match, the Save cache Step will run.

title: Examples of run_if expressions
body: There are many different ways of using a run_if expression. The following Workflow contains examples for most of them, with commented explanations. The expressions are used with Script Steps that, when successfully running, print that the used expression was true.

title: Examples of run_if expressions
body: All expressions are valid Go templates. To learn about Go templates, check out the documentation: Go template docs.

title: Examples of run_if expressions
body:
workflows:
 primary:
 steps:
 #
 # Check if an Environment Variable's value is equal to a given string
 - script:
 title: Run-If expression
 run_if: |-
 {{getenv "TEST_KEY" | eq "test value"}}
 inputs:
 - content: |-
 #!/bin/bash
 echo "RunIf expression was true"
 #
 # Use the enveq function to check if an Env Var's value is equal to a given string
 - script:
 title: Run-If expression
 run_if: '{{enveq "TEST_KEY" "test value"}}'
 inputs:
 - content: |-
 #!/bin/bash
 echo "RunIf expression was true"
 #
 # Check if a given Env Var is NOT empty
 - script:
 title: Run-If expression
 run_if: '{{getenv "TEST_KEY" | ne ""}}'
 inputs:
 - content: |-
 #!/bin/bash
 echo "RunIf expression was true"
 #
 # Check if two Env Vars have the same value
 - script:
 title: Run-If expression
 run_if: '{{getenv "TEST_KEY_1" | eq (getenv "TEST_KEY_2")}}'
 inputs:
 - content: |-
 #!/bin/bash
 echo "RunIf expression was true"
 #
 # Use the available expression data properties
 # like IsCI (checks if the build runs in a CI environment) or IsBuildFailed (checks if the build has failed) directly
 - script:
 title: Run-If expression
 run_if: |-
 {{.IsCI}}
 inputs:
 - content: |-
 #!/bin/bash
 echo "RunIf expression was true"
 #
 # You don't have to wrap the expression in {{...}} if it's a simple
 # oneliner
 - script:
 title: Run-If expression
 run_if: $.IsCI
 inputs:
 - content: |-
 #!/bin/bash
 echo "RunIf expression was true"
 #
 # You can even remove the $ sign, it's optional in a simple
 # expression like this
 - script:
 title: Run-If expression
 run_if: .IsCI
 inputs:
 - content: |-
 #!/bin/bash
 echo "RunIf expression was true"
 #
 # If-Else condition, in this example the Step will run if the build runs in a CI environment
 - script:
 title: Run-If expression
 run_if: |-
 {{if .IsCI}}
 true
 {{else}}
 false
 {{end}}
 inputs:
 - content: |-
 #!/bin/bash
 echo "RunIf expression was true"
 #
 # You can use multiple conditions
 - script:
 title: CI and Not Failed
 run_if: |-
 {{.IsCI | and (not .IsBuildFailed)}}
 inputs:
 - content: |-
 #!/bin/bash
 echo "RunIf expression was true"
 #
 # Check if the build is a pull request or not
 - script:
 title: Only if NOT a pull request
 run_if: not .IsPR
 inputs:
 - content: |-
 #!/bin/bash
 echo "RunIf expression was true"
 - script:
 title: Only if it was a Pull Request
 run_if: .IsPR
 inputs:
 - content: |-
 #!/bin/bash
 echo "Pull Request ID: ${PULL_REQUEST_ID}"

title: Setting a time limit for Steps
body: A Step timeout, defined in seconds, sets a maximum time a Step is allowed to run. If the Step exceeds that limit, the Workflow moves on to the next Step.

title: Setting a time limit for Steps
body: Ensure that your builds do not exceed the time limit by setting up Step timeout for Steps that might cause builds to hang.

title: Setting a time limit for Steps
body: A Step timeout, defined in seconds, sets a maximum time a Step is allowed to run. If the Step exceeds that limit, the Workflow moves on to the next Step. This is useful if, for example, your builds hang for not immediately obvious reasons - you can set timeouts for the Step or Steps which are suspected to have caused the problem.

title: Setting a time limit for Steps
body: Find the Step in the bitrise.yml file.

title: Setting a time limit for Steps
body: You can edit the file locally, or on the bitrise.yml tab of the Workflow Editor.

title: Setting a time limit for Steps
body: Add a timeout property before the other Step inputs and specify its value in seconds:

title: Setting a time limit for Steps
body:
- xcode-test@1.18.14:
 timeout: 120
 inputs:
 - project_path: "$BITRISE_PROJECT_PATH"
 - scheme: "$BITRISE_SCHEME"

title: Detecting and aborting hanging Steps without output
body: You can detect and abort hanging Steps that do not produce any log output for a certain amount of time using the No Output Timeout function. You can use this function to automatically abort hung builds after a configurable timeout period to save credits and to enable Bitrise to gather data on hanging builds.

title: Detecting and aborting hanging Steps without output
body: You can use the No Output Timeout function in two ways:

title: Detecting and aborting hanging Steps without output
body: Enable globally for all Steps.

title: Detecting and aborting hanging Steps without output
body: Enable for specific Steps only.

title: Detecting and aborting hanging Steps without output
body: The No Output Timeout function can be used alongside other timeout functionalities, such as the one described in the M1 Hanging builds issue guide or in Setting a time limit for Steps.

title: Enabling the No Output Timeout function globally for all Steps
body: Bitrise 1.50.0 or newer is required

title: Enabling the No Output Timeout function globally for all Steps
body: You must use Bitrise 1.50.0 or a newer version to use the No Output Timeout function.

title: Enabling the No Output Timeout function globally for all Steps
body: To enable the No Output Timeout globally for all Steps:

title: Enabling the No Output Timeout function globally for all Steps
body: Open your app on Bitrise.

title: Enabling the No Output Timeout function globally for all Steps
body: Click the Workflows button on the main page.

title: Enabling the No Output Timeout function globally for all Steps
body: Go to the Secrets tab.

title: Enabling the No Output Timeout function globally for all Steps
body: Add a new secret Env Var: BITRISE_NO_OUTPUT_TIMEOUT and set its value to the number of seconds you want the build to wait for output logs before aborting.

title: Enabling the No Output Timeout function globally for all Steps
body: We recommend setting it to 600 seconds (10 minutes).

title: Enabling the No Output Timeout function globally for all Steps
body: Aborting a hanging build automatically

title: Enabling the No Output Timeout function globally for all Steps
body: Compared to setting a time limit for Steps, the No Output Timeout function only aborts a build no output log is generated for a set amount of time.

title: Enabling the No Output Timeout function globally for all Steps
body: Any log output will reset the timeout. This can result in a Step running longer than the value you set in BITRISE_NO_OUTPUT_TIMEOUT.

title: Enabling the No Output Timeout function globally for all Steps
body: Click Save. You can check the Build log of your build to determine if the function is enabled.

title: Enabling the No Output Timeout function globally for all Steps
body: And that's it! From now on, whenever a Step does not produce an output log for the number of seconds you set in BITRISE_NO_OUTPUT_TIMEOUT , your build automatically aborts with the message: Abort via Bitrise DEN (no output timeout).

title: Enabling the No Output Timeout function globally for all Steps
body: Disabling the No Output Timeout function for a specific Step

title: Enabling the No Output Timeout function globally for all Steps
body: If you enabled the No Output Timeout function globally and want to disable it for specific Steps, you can add the no_output_timeout: 0 Step property just above the inputs: part of the chosen Step(s) in the bitrise.yml.

title: Enabling the No Output Timeout function globally for all Steps
body: For example:

title: Enabling the No Output Timeout function globally for all Steps
body:
steps: 
 - virtual-device-testing-for-ios@1:
 no_output_timeout: 0
 inputs:
 - zip_path: "$BITRISE_PROJECT_PATH"

title: Enabling the No Output Timeout function for specific Steps
body: Bitrise 1.50.0 or newer is required

title: Enabling the No Output Timeout function for specific Steps
body: You must use Bitrise 1.50.0 or a newer version to use the No Output Timeout function.

title: Enabling the No Output Timeout function for specific Steps
body: You can enable the No Output Timeout function for specific Steps by adding the no_output_timeout Step property below a Step in your bitrise.yml file.

title: Enabling the No Output Timeout function for specific Steps
body: To do so with the Workflow Editor:

title: Enabling the No Output Timeout function for specific Steps
body: Open your app on Bitrise.

title: Enabling the No Output Timeout function for specific Steps
body: Click the Workflows button on the main page.

title: Enabling the No Output Timeout function for specific Steps
body: Go to the bitrise.yml tab.

title: Enabling the No Output Timeout function for specific Steps
body: Search for the Step(s) where you would like to use the function.

title: Enabling the No Output Timeout function for specific Steps
body: Insert no_output_timeout: 12 Step property and value just above the inputs: part of the chosen Step(s) to automatically abort a build if the Step does not produce an output log for 12 seconds.

title: Enabling the No Output Timeout function for specific Steps
body: Setting the no_output_timeout Step property to 0

title: Enabling the No Output Timeout function for specific Steps
body: You can disable the No Output Timeout function for a Step by setting the no_output_timeout Step property to 0.

title: Enabling the No Output Timeout function for specific Steps
body: Let's look at an example where a Script Step will always be aborted automatically:

title: Enabling the No Output Timeout function for specific Steps
body:
output_slows_down:
 steps:
 - script@1:
 title: Output is slower and slower
 no_output_timeout: 12
 inputs:
 - content: |-
 #!/usr/bin/env bash
 for i in {1..5}
 do
 DURATION=$((5*i))
 echo "🏃‍step output (sleeping ${DURATION}s)"
 sleep $DURATION
 done

title: Enabling the No Output Timeout function for specific Steps
body: And that's it! Now, if your Step hangs and does not produce a single output log for the number of seconds you specified in the no_output_timeout Step property, the build will be aborted automatically.

title: Developing your own Bitrise Step
body: You can develop your own Bitrise Steps and your own project scanner, and submit them to Bitrise so that other users can use them, too.

title: Developing your own Bitrise Step
body: Contributing to Bitrise is easy: develop an open source integration, submit it and you’re done! In this section, we’ll be focusing on technical contributions: creating a new Step and creating your very own project scanner.

title: Creating your own Step
body: Bitrise offers well over 200 Steps to our users. We maintain many of them ourselves but our users’ community does an outstanding job of contributing to our Step Library (StepLib). Anyone can submit a Step - if approved, it will become part of the official Bitrise StepLib and available to all Bitrise users! Check out how to create your own Step and share it with the world: Creating your own Step.

title: Creating your own scanner
body: Our project scanner automatically detects the project type whenever you add a new app on Bitrise. In this context, type means the platform or framework used to create the app, for example, Android, iOS, React Native or Flutter. Based on the results, we automatically create a configuration, with at least one default Workflow that contains the most frequently used Steps for the detected type.

title: Creating your own scanner
body: Our scanner might not detect your app, for a couple of reasons: either something is missing from your repository (such as a config.xml file in the case of an Ionic app, for example), or we simply don’t have a scanner for your type yet. If it’s the latter, you can configure your app manually, or you can create your own scanner, with its own project configuration: Creating your own Bitrise project scanner.

title: Developing a new Step
body: To develop a Bitrise Step and get it integrated in our Step library, you need to write a code, create the description, and submit everything for review.

title: Developing a new Step
body: Duplicate Steps

title: Developing a new Step
body: Before deciding to develop a new Step, please make sure that there’s no already existing Step that performs the same function.

title: Developing a new Step
body: You can search for Steps on our Integrations page or in the Step Library on GitHub.

title: Developing a new Step
body: A Step is a build task: for example, the Git Clone Step clones your Git repository at the start of a build while the Google Play Deploy Step can deploy your finished app to the Play Store.

title: Developing a new Step
body: A Step contains the code that performs the build task. You can configure the inputs and parameters that define the task, and view and reuse the outputs a Step generates. Reusing the output means that another Step can use it as the value of one of its inputs.

title: Developing a new Step
body: Our Steps are written in Go or Bash. Steps are contained in their own Git repositories: that includes the code and the step.yml file that defines the configuration of the Step. If you wish to make the Step available to other users, the step.yml file needs to be included in the bitrise-steplib repository so that other users can find the Step on our website, in the Workflow Editor.

title: Developing a new Step
body: Sharing Steps

title: Developing a new Step
body: Sharing your custom Steps is optional: a Step with a use case that is specific to a single user will not be much help to others. As you can run a Step from your own machine or from any Git repository, your custom Steps do not have to be part of the Bitrise Step Library.

title: Developing a new Step
body: For more info on sharing Steps with other users, check out the Sharing Steps guide.

title: Developing a new Step
body: For detailed information on how Steps work, see the following guides:

title: Developing a new Step
body: Steps in YAML

title: Developing a new Step
body: Step inputs

title: Developing a new Step
body: Step outputs

title: Developing a new Step
body: Step properties

title: Before you start developing a new Step
body: Before creating a new Step, you will need to install the Bitrise CLI, set it up, and make sure the Step plugin is updated to the latest version.

title: Before you start developing a new Step
body: Install the Bitrise CLI.

title: Before you start developing a new Step
body: Run bitrise setup.

title: Before you start developing a new Step
body: Update the Step plugin to the latest version with the following command:

title: Before you start developing a new Step
body: bitrise plugin update step

title: Creating the Step
body: We will use the Step plugin of the Bitrise CLI to create a new Step. With this, we’ll create the basic structure of the Step. Certain properties and inputs will be generated and assigned automatically. You can change anything later so don’t worry about it yet.

title: Creating the Step
body: The Step plugin

title: Creating the Step
body: Run bitrise :step in a command line interface to check its commands.

title: Creating the Step
body: Creating the basic structure of the Step is simple. We’ll go over the concepts involved in the process in more detail later; for now, just go through the process to create the Step. At the end of this process, you will have a step.yml file, a README.md file and either a main.go or a step.sh file in the repository.

title: Creating the Step
body: Before you start

title: Creating the Step
body: During the Step creation process, you will be prompted to set a number of options. Note that you can change any of these before submitting your Step to Bitrise for review: the data will be included in the generated step.yml file that you can edit at your leisure later. During the initial Step creation process, you can use placeholders if you want to.

title: Creating the Step
body: Open a command line interface, such as the Terminal app on MacOS.

title: Creating the Step
body: Create a new directory for your Step if you haven’t done so yet and enter that directory:

title: Creating the Step
body: Create the Step with the Bitrise Step plugin:

title: Creating the Step
body: When prompted, set the name of the Step’s author.

title: Creating the Step
body: Hit Enter to leave it on the default value.

title: Creating the Step
body: When prompted, set the Step’s name.

title: Creating the Step
body: The plugin automatically generates a Step ID based on this name.

title: Creating the Step
body: Provide a summary: no more than a couple of sentences about what the Step does.

title: Creating the Step
body: Provide a description of the Step.

title: Creating the Step
body: This should contain configuration information and troubleshooting information for the Step.

title: Creating the Step
body: Select the primary category of the Step.

title: Creating the Step
body: To do so, type the number of the preferred option and hit Enter. This can be changed later.

title: Creating the Step
body: Choose the toolkit you want to use: you can choose either Go or Bash.

title: Creating the Step
body: Set up the source code hosting data for the Step:

title: Creating the Step
body: To do so, first decide if you want to host it on GitHub or on any other site and enter the appropriate option:

title: Creating the Step
body: If you chose GitHub, you will be asked to provide the username of the account that will own the repository.

title: Creating the Step
body: If you chose not to store it on GitHub, you have to provide a valid URL for the repository.

title: Creating the Step
body: You are done! If everything went well, the plugin initialized a git repository in the current directory and added a step.yml, a README.md file, and either a main.go or a main.sh file.

title: Creating the Step
body: Now we’ll go through how the step.yml file works and how to set it up.

title: The step.yml file
body: The step.yml file is the Step interface definition, containing dependencies, Step inputs and Step outputs as well as other Step properties. It also points to the location of the Step’s source code. Every Step must have one.

title: The step.yml file
body: If you use the Step plugin to create a new Step, all the required properties will have a value assigned - but you can change any of them at any time. So don’t worry if the title you set during the initial process does not conform to the guidelines below.

title: The step.yml file
body: We’ll look at the most important configuration options of the step.yml file, including naming and describing your Step, as well as setting up Step inputs and Step outputs.

title: Naming and describing a Step
body: Every Step must have at least a title and a summary defined in the step.yml file. These will appear both on the Integrations page and in the Workflow Editor. The description property is optional but we strongly recommend providing one so that other users better understand how your Step works.

title: Naming and describing a Step
body: Description and summary

title: Naming and describing a Step
body: Both description and summary accept Markdown formatting in its values.

title: The title
body: The title property

title: The title
body: The title property is required!

title: The title
body: The title property sets the name of the Step, as it will appear on bitrise.io. It should be short and descriptive. Include the name of the service and the function it fulfils, such as Git Clone. Here’s a few guidelines for your Step titles:

title: The title
body: Do not use the word ‘Step’.

title: The title
body: Use imperative verbs instead of nouns when possible. For example, instead of Script Runner, it should be Run Script.

title: The title
body: Do not include the name of the platform.

title: The title
body: Make sure you use the correct name of a service or tool. For example, GitHub instead of Github.

title: The title
body: Do not include implementation details.

title: The summary
body: The summary property

title: The summary
body: The summary property is required!

title: The summary
body: A single line of the most significant information about the Step. It can’t be longer than a 100 characters.

title: The summary
body: The summary is visible by default on the Workflow Editor. If a user expands the summary, the Step’s description will be presented - if there is one, of course.

title: The description
body: A detailed explanation of the Step. It should include:

title: The description
body: What the Step does.

title: The description
body: The services and tools used by the Step.

title: The description
body: Configuration information, including the most important inputs.

title: The description
body: Troubleshooting information: potential issues and their solutions.

title: The description
body: By default, the Step’s description is collapsed on the Workflow Editor and the summary is presented.

title: Step categories
body: There is another thing we’d like to know about your Step: what type of Step is it? As you can see on our Integrations page or on the Workflow Editor, Steps are sorted into different categories based on two factors: the platforms for which they are available and their functionality.

title: Platforms
body: The available platform types are controlled by the project_type_tags attribute. If your Step is available for every platform or project type, do not specify project_type_tags. In any other case, select all platform types for which your Step is available.

title: Platforms
body: The available values are:

title: Platforms
body: ios

title: Platforms
body: macos

title: Platforms
body: android

title: Platforms
body: react-native

title: Platforms
body: cordova

title: Platforms
body: ionic

title: Platforms
body: flutter

title: Category
body: Functional categories are controlled by the type_tags attribute in the step.yml. One Step should have only a single type tag assigned to it. Use utility only if you believe none of the other types fit your Step.

title: Category
body: The available values are:

title: Category
body: build

title: Category
body: code-sign

title: Category
body: test

title: Category
body: deploy

title: Category
body: notification

title: Category
body: access-control

title: Category
body: artifact-info

title: Category
body: installer

title: Category
body: dependency

title: Category
body: utility

title: Step inputs
body: Step inputs are Bitrise Environment Variables: they consist of a key and value pair that users of the Step can set to control the Step behavior. For example, the Git Clone Step has an input with the key branch:

title: Step inputs
body:
title: Git Clone Repository
summary: Clone a repository to the specified path on the VM
inputs:
- branch: master

title: Step inputs
body: The value of this input - master in the above example - is used to determine which branch of the repository will be cloned.

title: Step inputs
body: Step inputs are visible on the Workflow Editor: they are presented in the order as they appear in the step.yml. As such, required and frequently used inputs should be at the top.

title: Step input keys and values
body: Use lower case snake case style input keys. For example, project_path.

title: Step input keys and values
body: Using opts as an input key

title: Step input keys and values
body: The input key can not be opts, as it is used for the input’s options.

title: Step input keys and values
body: There is no need to add domain-specific prefixes to the input keys, as inputs are only exposed for the Step run process. This means project_path input will not overlap with subsequent Steps’ project_path inputs.

title: Step input keys and values
body: Step input values are strings: the Bitrise CLI exposes the Step inputs as Environment Variables to the Steps.

title: Step input keys and values
