body: Provide default values for Step inputs if possible (and if it makes sense). That makes the Step configuration easier for Bitrise users.

title: Step input keys and values
body: Environment Variables must not be used as default values, unless:

title: Step input keys and values
body: They are exposed by the Bitrise CLI or by bitrise.io.

title: Step input keys and values
body: They are generated as an output by another Step (for example, $BITRISE_IPA_PATH, $BITRISE_AAB_PATH).

title: Step input keys and values
body: This is because the Workflow Editor highlights required inputs without values to express the Step will not work without setting a valid value for the given input. If you set an Env Var, which does not have an automatically assigned value, as the default value for an input, the Workflow Editor will think the required input in question has a valid value set (even if the default Env Var has no value yet).

title: Step input keys and values
body: Also, there is no reason to suggest a certain name for an Environment Variable this way: users might have the same value assigned to an Env Var with a different name.

title: Step input keys and values
body: Let’s talk about how Step inputs are passed to code and how they are presented.

title: Configuring Step inputs
body: Step inputs are defined and configured in the step.yml file.

title: Configuring Step inputs
body: In addition to a key and a value, Step inputs are required to have an opts property. This property contains the different options that define how the inputs are passed to the code of the Step and how it is presented in the Workflow Editor. The possible values of the input can be set in opts as well. Let’s see an example.

title: Configuring Step inputs
body:
- install_defaults: "yes"
 opts:
 title: Installs default Codesign Files
 value_options:
 - "no"
 - "yes"

title: Configuring Step inputs
body: The above input has the key install_defaults, and its default value is yes.

title: Configuring Step inputs
body: The value_options option defines the possible values: in this case, yes and no. Its opts property contains some information about how the input is presented: in this case, it’s just a title option, which is always required. The title is displayed in the Workflow Editor instead of the key of the input.

title: Configuring Step inputs
body: The value_options input

title: Configuring Step inputs
body: The value_options input must contain a string. This means that without the quotation marks, as indicated in the example, the validation will fail.

title: Naming and describing Step inputs
body: A Step input can have a name, a summary, and a description, just like the Step itself. To define these:

title: Naming and describing Step inputs
body: Include an opts property with the Step input.

title: Naming and describing Step inputs
body: Under opts, provide a title, a summary, and a description option.

title: Naming and describing Step inputs
body: Let’s take a look at how these should look like!

title: Naming and describing Step inputs
body: Description and summary

title: Naming and describing Step inputs
body: Both description and summary accept Markdown formatting in its values.

title: Naming and describing Step inputs
body: title: It should be a short and descriptive sentence or half sentence: The Xcode project’s path. It should not be a CLI flag or API parameter name used internally. This makes Step configuration easier, as no preexisting knowledge will be required about the underlying tool or service interfaces. It’s also easier to change the Step’s implementation while maintaining backwards compatibility.

title: Naming and describing Step inputs
body: summary: It is the short version of the description, which provides a quick overview of the input. On the Bitrise Workflow Editor, the summary of the inputs is presented by default when you click on a Step.

title: Naming and describing Step inputs
body: description: It is the user facing description of the Step input: this should provide a deeper, more detailed explanation of the input. By default, it is not visible in the Workflow Editor, unless the user clicks on the input in question.

title: Naming and describing Step inputs
body: Here is an example:

title: Naming and describing Step inputs
body:
- install_defaults: "yes"
 opts:
 description: Installs default (Bitrise) Wildcard Provisioning Profile and
 Certificate files for testing.
 summary: Installs default (Bitrise) Wildcard code signing files.
 title: Installs default code signing files

title: Naming and describing Step inputs
body: Now, let’s talk about some other configuration options for Steps.

title: Required inputs
body: Required inputs must have a valid value, otherwise the Step will fail.

title: Required inputs
body: To mark a Step input as required, use the is_required option of the opts property. It has two values: true and false. If set to true, the input will be displayed as REQUIRED on the Workflow Editor.

title: Required inputs
body:
- keychain_password: $BITRISE_KEYCHAIN_PASSWORD
 opts:
 title: "Keychain's password"
 is_required: true

title: Sensitive inputs
body: You can mark Step inputs as sensitive to make sure their values do not get exposed. Sensitive inputs only accept Secrets as values. This ensures they are not visible in build logs.

title: Sensitive inputs
body: To mark a Step input as sensitive, use the is_sensitive option of the opts property. It has two values: true and false. If set to true, the input will be displayed as SENSITIVE on the Workflow Editor.

title: Sensitive inputs
body: The is_expand option

title: Sensitive inputs
body: If you mark an input as sensitive, the is_expand option of the input also must be true, which is the default setting.

title: Sensitive inputs
body:
inputs:
 - certificate_urls: $BITRISE_CERTIFICATE_URL
 opts:
 title: "Certificate URL"
 is_sensitive: true

title: Using Env Vars as input values
body: As noted earlier, it is possible to use Environment Variables as the value of any given input. By default, the Step will expand the Env Var and pass its value to the Step execution. This is defined by the is_expand option of the opts property.

title: Using Env Vars as input values
body:
- project_path: $BITRISE_PROJECT_PATH
 opts:
 is_expand: true

title: Using Env Vars as input values
body: The is_expand option can have two values: true or false. If set to true - this is the default behavior -, the value of $BITRISE_PROJECT_PATH will be passed to Step execution. If set to false, the string $BITRISE_PROJECT_PATH will be passed (and this particular Step will fail as it will not find the project location).

title: Using Env Vars as input values
body: Env Vars in Step code

title: Using Env Vars as input values
body: Do not use Environment Variables directly in your Step’s code. Instead, expose every outside variable as an input of your Step and set the default value of that input to the Environment Variable you want to use. This way it’s easier to test the Step and the user of the Step can easily declare these inputs, without having to scour through code for the required variable.

title: Grouping inputs together
body: The category option is used to group inputs together. Inputs belonging to the same category are displayed together and collapsed by default in the Workflow Editor.

title: Grouping inputs together
body:
- default_certificate_passphrase: $BITRISE_DEFAULT_CERTIFICATE_PASSPHRASE
 opts:
 category: Default code signing files
 description: |
 Certificate passphrase of the default certificate.
 is_sensitive: true
 title: Default certificate passphrase

title: Grouping inputs together
body: In this case, this input will appear with all the other inputs that have the same category set.

title: Grouping inputs together
body: Categories may be used if the Step has more than six inputs. The suggested maximum number of inputs in a group or in the root is six.

title: Grouping inputs together
body: Please keep in mind, when designing Step categories, that:

title: Grouping inputs together
body: Required inputs should not be grouped!

title: Grouping inputs together
body: Grouped inputs should be displayed after non-categorised inputs.

title: Accepting a list of values for inputs
body: It is absolutely possible to accept a list of values for a given input. If you wish to do so, we strongly recommend adding a list suffix to the key of the input (for example, input_path_list), and expect the values to be provided as a newline character (\n) separated list (for example, first value\nsecond value).

title: Accepting a list of values for inputs
body: Please use this solution unless you really need to use another character for separating values. Based on our experience, the newline character (\n) works really well as a universal separator character, as it’s quite rare in input values (compared to ,, ;, = or other more common separator characters).

title: Accepting a list of values for inputs
body: As a best practice, you should filter out empty items. Use either:

title: Accepting a list of values for inputs
body: first value\n\nsecond value

title: Accepting a list of values for inputs
body: or

title: Accepting a list of values for inputs
body: first value\n \nsecond value

title: Step outputs
body: Steps can generate outputs which can then be used in other Steps as inputs. That means that if a Step generates an artifact, the path to that artifact can be the input of another Step in the build. For example, the Xcode Archive & Export for iOS Step exposes the $BITRISE_API_PATH output which can then be used as an input value for the Deploy to iTunesConnect Step.

title: Step outputs
body: Outputs are also defined in the step.yml file, under the outputs property. They have the same structure as inputs: they consist of a key and value pair. An output’s key can be used as an input value in a subsequent Step, just as Environment Variables exposed by bitrise.io or the Bitrise CLI can be.

title: Step output keys and values
body: For output keys, use upper case snake case style output keys, for example: OUTPUT_PATH.

title: Naming and describing Step outputs
body: Step outputs are always exported as Environment Variables (Env Var). For example, the Xcode Archive & Export for iOS Step generates an IPA file: this output is exported as the BITRISE_IPA_PATH Env Var:

title: Naming and describing Step outputs
body:
outputs:
- BITRISE_IPA_PATH: 
 opts: 
 title: .ipa file path 
 summary: Local path of the created .ipa file

title: Naming and describing Step outputs
body: As the example shows, the output definition contains a key (BITRISE_IPA_PATH) and under the opts property, it also includes a title and a summary. In the Workflow Editor, the key and the title are visible by default: these are required. In addition, you can add a summary and a description:

title: Naming and describing Step outputs
body: title: It should be a short and descriptive sentence or half sentence: Generated IPA path. This is required.

title: Naming and describing Step outputs
body: summary: It is the short version of the description, which provides a quick overview of the output. This is optional, and only visible in the Workflow Editor if you click on the title.

title: Naming and describing Step outputs
body: description: It is the user facing description of the Step output: this should provide a deeper, more detailed explanation of the output. This is optional, and only visible in the Workflow Editor if you click on the title.

title: Outputs with list of values
body: It is absolutely possible to provide a list of values for a given output. If you wish to do so, we strongly recommend adding a LIST suffix to the key of the output (for example, BITRISE_APK_PATH_LIST), and expect the values to be provided as a newline character (\n) separated list (for example, first value\nsecond value).

title: Outputs with list of values
body: Please use this solution unless you really need to use another character for separating values. Based on our experience, the newline character (\n) works really well as a universal separator character, as it’s quite rare in input values (compared to ,, ;, = or other more common separator characters).

title: Setting conditions for running the Step
body: There are three properties that define whether a Step is run in a given Workflow or not: is_always_run, is_skippable and run_if. All of these properties can be set in the step.yml file to govern the default behavior of the Step, or set in a given app’s bitrise.yml file on a case-by-case basis.

title: Setting conditions for running the Step
body: is_always_run: By default, Steps do not run if a previous Step in the Workflow failed. However, if the is_always_run property is set to true, the Step runs regardless of the status of previous Steps in the Workflow. This can be very useful, for example, in the case of Steps that can send notifications about the build: they can send notifications about failed builds.

title: Setting conditions for running the Step
body: is_skippable: As mentioned above, Steps do not run if a previous Step in the Workflow failed. However, if a Step’s is_skippable property is set to true, the build will not fail and subsequent Steps will run even if that particular Step fails. A good example is the Cache:Pull Step: if an app has no build cache to pull from, the Step will fail but that is no reason to fail the build.

title: Setting conditions for running the Step
body: run_if: If you want to make Step execution dependent on a certain condition, use the run_if property to define the run condition. For example, you can configure a Step so that it only runs in a CI environment. Read more in our Enabling or disabling a Step conditionally guide about the possible use cases.

title: Submodules and Step dependencies
body: Do not use submodules, or require any other resource downloaded on-demand in your Step! Try to include everything required for your Step in the Step’s repository. Otherwise you can run into problems if, say, the Step fails to download a resource because of a network error or some authorization problem. In the case of submodules, you should include the content of the other repository instead of using it as a submodule of your Step’s repository.

title: Submodules and Step dependencies
body: You can, however, declare dependencies that you can fetch from an OS dependency manager, such as apt-get or brew. A Step dependency is installed by the Bitrise CLI if it is not available in the PATH Environment Variable.

title: Submodules and Step dependencies
body: As Steps can be run in any environment where the Bitrise CLI can run, list every used dependency, even if you know that they are pre-installed on the Bitrise stacks. Unused dependencies (for example, git and wget added as a sample by default) waste build time.

title: Submodules and Step dependencies
body: Step dependencies should not include toolkit dependencies, as the Bitrise CLI will take care of installing those automatically. A Step written in golang should not list go as a dependency if the Step uses the Go Bitrise CLI toolkit.

title: Submodules and Step dependencies
body: The Bitrise CLI can install Step dependencies available in the Homebrew package manager:

title: Submodules and Step dependencies
body:
deps:
 brew:
 - name: cmake

title: Submodules and Step dependencies
body: It can install apt-get dependencies available in the sources listed in the sources.list file on the host machine:

title: Submodules and Step dependencies
body:
deps:
 apt_get:
 - name: cmake

title: Accessing files in the Step repo with an Env Var
body: If you need to keep a binary, assets or anything else required for your Step that should be bundled in the Step repository, then you can include them beside your step.yml file and the code of your Step. The Bitrise CLI automatically exports an Environment Variable called BITRISE_STEP_SOURCE_DIR that allows you to access these files at any time.

title: Accessing files in the Step repo with an Env Var
body: For example, you can access a .jar file in the root of your Step’s repository like this:

title: Accessing files in the Step repo with an Env Var
body: $BITRISE_STEP_SOURCE_DIR/mytool.jar

title: Adding a Step icon
body: You can add a Step icon to your Step: you will see it in the Workflow Editor and on our Integrations page. If you want to, there are some requirements:

title: Adding a Step icon
body: Its background color should not be transparent.

title: Adding a Step icon
body: Size: 256x256 px.

title: Adding a Step icon
body: Margin: 60 px.

title: Adding a Step icon
body: Format: SVG.

title: Adding a Step icon
body: Verified Steps

title: Adding a Step icon
body: Please note that if you wish to submit a Step for verification so that it becomes a Verified Step, you must add a Step icon.

title: Adding a Step icon
body: To submit your Step’s icon:

title: Adding a Step icon
body: Add the .svg file into your StepLib fork repo at: STEPLIB_FORK_ROOT/steps/YOUR_STEP_ID/assets/icon.svg.

title: Adding a Step icon
body: Create a new pull request to the StepLib repository.

title: Sharing Steps with all Bitrise users
body: If you think your Bitrise Step can be of use to others, you can share it via a CLI command or a Bitrise Workflow. Shared Steps must be actively maintained and they must be open to contributors.

title: Sharing Steps with all Bitrise users
body: If you think your Step can be of use to others, you can share it! Before doing so, however, please check that there are no other Steps that solve the same problem. You can check:

title: Sharing Steps with all Bitrise users
body: In the list of released Steps.

title: Sharing Steps with all Bitrise users
body: In the list of open pull requests in our StepLib.

title: Sharing Steps with all Bitrise users
body: In the list of closed pull requests in our StepLib.

title: Sharing Steps with all Bitrise users
body: If you find a Step which is missing a particular feature, please try to contribute to it before developing or sharing a brand new Step for that feature. You can use our Integrations page to search for Steps in the Bitrise StepLib. By clicking the GitHub source button on a given Step’s page you will be taken to the Step’s repository, where you can submit a feature request or open a pull request.

title: Sharing Steps with all Bitrise users
body: Also, please keep in mind that shared Steps must be actively maintained and they must be open to contributors.

title: Sharing a new Step
body: The sharing process is relatively straightforward - but please make sure to go through the process carefully when sharing a new Step.

title: Sharing a new Step
body: The bitrise share command

title: Sharing a new Step
body: During Step development, you can get help anytime by simply running bitrise share. This will print a short guide on sharing.

title: Sharing a new Step
body: There are two ways to share a Step:

title: Sharing a new Step
body: You can do it manually, using the bitrise share command.

title: Sharing a new Step
body: If you created the Step with the Step plugin, you can run the share-this-step Workflow in your Step’s directory.

title: Before you start
body: Before you start, make sure that:

title: Before you start
body: Your Step is in a public Git repository.

title: Before you start
body: The step.yml file contains a support_url property which points to a valid issue tracker (for example, the Issues page of your Step’s GitHub repository).

title: Before you start
body: The step.yml file contains a source_code_url property which points to the correct Git URL of your repository.

title: Before you start
body: Sharing more than one Step

title: Before you start
body: Sharing more than one Step - that is, adding more than one new step.yml file to the Bitrise StepLib - must be done in separate pull requests! You cannot open a pull request that contains more than one new Step!

title: Before you start
body: If you’re ready, go ahead with your preferred sharing process!

title: Sharing with the bitrise share command
body: Fork the Bitrise StepLib repository.

title: Sharing with the bitrise share command
body: Prepare your forked StepLib locally for sharing:

title: Sharing with the bitrise share command
body: $ bitrise share start -c <https://github.com/[your-username]/bitrise-steplib.git>

title: Sharing with the bitrise share command
body: Add the Step version tag to your Step’s repository.

title: Sharing with the bitrise share command
body: Add the Step to your forked StepLib repository:

title: Sharing with the bitrise share command
body: $ bitrise share create --tag [step-version-tag] --git [step-git-uri].git --stepid [step-id]

title: Sharing with the bitrise share command
body: Optionally, perform a complete health check on your forked StepLib:

title: Sharing with the bitrise share command
body: $ bitrise share audit -c <https://github.com/[your-username]/bitrise-steplib.git>

title: Sharing with the bitrise share command
body: Review your Step’s step.yml file, and if you’re happy with it, finish the share process: This commits and pushes the step.yml file to the forked StepLib repository.

title: Sharing with the bitrise share command
body: $ bitrise share finish

title: Sharing with the bitrise share command
body: This commits and pushes the step.yml file to the forked StepLib repository.

title: Sharing with the bitrise share command
body: Open a pull request in the official Bitrise StepLib repository.

title: Sharing with the share-this-step Workflow
body: The share-this-step Workflow is included in the bitrise.yml file that the Step plugin automatically generates when you create a new Step with it. Using it, sharing a Step is incredibly easy:

title: Sharing with the share-this-step Workflow
body: Fork the Bitrise StepLib repository.

title: Sharing with the share-this-step Workflow
body: Set the required Workflow Environment Variables as app level Environment Variables in the bitrise.yml file:

title: Sharing with the share-this-step Workflow
body: app: envs: - BITRISE_STEP_ID: - BITRISE_STEP_VERSION: - BITRISE_STEP_GIT_CLONE_URL: - MY_STEPLIB_REPO_FORK_GIT_URL:

title: Sharing with the share-this-step Workflow
body: Run the share-this-step Workflow in the Bitrise CLI:

title: Sharing with the share-this-step Workflow
body: $ bitrise run share-this-step

title: Fixing issues in a StepLib pull request
body: Once you submitted your Step version to the StepLib, wait for the Bitrise team to review it. If we ask for changes:

title: Fixing issues in a StepLib pull request
body: Close the pull request.

title: Fixing issues in a StepLib pull request
body: Delete the share branch from your fork of the Bitrise StepLib.

title: Fixing issues in a StepLib pull request
body: Fix the issues in the Step repository.

title: Fixing issues in a StepLib pull request
body: Add a new version tag to the commit that contains your fixes in the Step repository.

title: Fixing issues in a StepLib pull request
body: Run the share process again.

title: Fixing issues in a StepLib pull request
body: Hopefully, after fixing the issues, we’ll be able to merge your pull request and release your Step to the public!

title: Abandoned Steps
body: If you are a Step maintainer, you should be reachable within a reasonable timeframe if anyone submits an issue or a pull request to your Step. If we try to contact you several times regarding an important fix/update in your Step and you refuse to answer for several weeks we might deprecate, remove or replace your Step in the collection! Abandoned Steps can be a threat for those who use it, please keep this in mind if you decide to share your Step with others!

title: Abandoned Steps
body: The repository and issue tracker must not be removed, as there are permanent links to it included in the step.yml that is in the Bitrise StepLib. If they are removed, already shared Step versions will continue to function as they are also shared on a Bitrise managed file hosting service during the share process. A new version of the step may be released, managed by Bitrise.

title: Abandoned Steps
body: If you shared a Step but you’re no longer able or willing to maintain it, please create a GitHub issue in this repository: Bitrise StepLib

title: Reporting Step issues
body: If you’re a user of a Step which has critical (security or functionality) issues, please create a ticket in the Step’s Issue Tracker. Every Step declares the preferred way of reporting issues with the support_url attribute.

title: Reporting Step issues
body: If you don’t get a response from the Step’s maintainer for an extended period (for more than a couple of weeks) please create a GitHub issue in this repository: https://github.com/bitrise-io/bitrise-steplib and we’ll try to resolve the issue, following the Abandoned Step policy. Please be patient and keep in mind that everyone who contributes to this collection does so to help you by providing a Step for you to use!

title: Verified Steps
body: Verified Steps are Bitrise Steps whose owner guarantees secure, maintained, consistent, and high-quality performance for any Bitrise user. To have your Step verified, you must apply for the Verified badge.

title: What are Verified Steps?
body: A Step contains the code that performs a specific build task. Bitrise has over 300 Steps in its Step Library (StepLib) which third party companies or open source teams can enrich with Steps based on their services/tools. This means they have full power to roll out updates to the Step while Bitrise maintains an overlaying control to ensure service quality and security.

title: What are Verified Steps?
body: A Verified Step means that the owner of a service or tool or an open source team guarantees secure, maintained, consistent, and high-quality performance for any Bitrise user. Our official Bitrise Steps are maintained by us, whereas our Community Steps are maintained by the community. It’s easy to decide which type a Step falls into on our GUI.

title: What are Verified Steps?
body: Verified Steps are labeled with a blue badge in Bitrise.

title: What are Verified Steps?
body: Official Bitrise Steps are labeled with a green badge.

title: What are Verified Steps?
body: Community created Steps do not have any badge.

title: What are Verified Steps?
body: In this guide we explain how to get your Step verified by Bitrise.

title: What are Verified Steps?
body: Requirements

title: What are Verified Steps?
body: For company owned services and tools: Your company must be the owner of the service or tool used by the Step to apply for the Verified badge.

title: What are Verified Steps?
body: For open-source services or tools: If you are a member of an open source or other informal team, please confirm with the rest of the team that you may sign this for yourself and that it applies to the Steps you are submitting for the team.

title: What are Verified Steps?
body: Your Step must comply with our Service Level Agreement .

title: What are Verified Steps?
body: Your Step must have its own Step icon.

title: What are Verified Steps?
body: You must include a Workflow Recipe to a Step to become a Verified Step.

title: What are Verified Steps?
body: We strongly recommend that you consult with our Step development guidelines before creating a Step.

title: What is a Workflow Recipe?
body: A Workflow Recipe is a template that anyone submitting a Step to Bitrise must put together when applying for the Verified Step badge. You can develop a Step and decide not to include a Workflow Recipe, but to turn your Step into a Verified one, you have to submit a Workflow Recipe as well.

title: What is a Workflow Recipe?
body: Workflow Recipes are published on Bitrise where our Bitrise community can learn how the Verified Step can be used in a specific setup.

title: What is a Workflow Recipe?
body: Should you have questions, please turn to our partnership team at partners@bitrise.io.

title: Promoting your Verified Step
body: As part of the Verified Step Program, you must commit to taking part in one or more than one of the following co-marketing activities:

title: Promoting your Verified Step
body: In-app messaging.

title: Promoting your Verified Step
body: Dedicated co-branded email campaign, or newsletter mention.

title: Promoting your Verified Step
body: Blog post content.

title: Promoting your Verified Step
body: How-to article, documentation, or help center page.

title: Promoting your Verified Step
body: Social media activities.

title: Promoting your Verified Step
body: Webinars or virtual events.

title: Promoting your Verified Step
body: Podcasts.

title: Promoting your Verified Step
body: Events (panels, fireside chats, video testimonials, or sponsorship).

title: Promoting your Verified Step
body: Case study/whitepaper/ebook/ (shared research, testimonials, co-writing a chapter, publishing on each others’ blogs).

title: Promoting your Verified Step
body: Video content posted on our public YouTube channel.

title: Promoting your Verified Step
body: Joint PR campaigns.

title: Promoting your Verified Step
body: These co-marketing opportunities enable you to increase your product’s content generation output, grow go-to-market plans, and help to drive integration adoption.

title: Promoting your Verified Step
body: You can consult with your Bitrise Partner Manager (partners@bitrise.io) to confirm which co-marketing activities you can do, clarifying what level of involvement you will want to do based on your marketing plans. There can be many interested in a single co-marketing event so your involvement is managed on a first-come, first-serve basis.

title: Applying for a Verified badge
body: Create the Step based on our Step development guideline. The Step’s repository MUST be on GitHub.

title: Applying for a Verified badge
body: Share your Step in our bitrise-steplib and fill out the New Pull Request Checklist.

title: Applying for a Verified badge
body: When the CLAassistant prompts you, sign our Contributor License Agreement. Until this is not completed, merging is blocked on the PR.

title: Applying for a Verified badge
body: Please fill out our Partnership Form!

title: Applying for a Verified badge
body: Once you submitted the form, our Partner Management Team will contact you within 5 business days to discuss the rest of the process.

title: Applying for a Verified badge
body: If at any stage of the process you wonder what happens with a Step candidate that is already covered by another Step in our StepLib, head over to How do we go about Step duplication?

title: Service level agreement for Verified Step authors
body: Anyone can contribute to a Verified Step which is already part of our StepLib by creating an issue or a pull request (PR). The Verified Step author has to manage the contribution (for example, issue, PR, or any maintenance such as third-party system changes) from start to finish. Bitrise monitors open issues and PRs created for Verified Steps and contacts the Verified Step authors if those contributions are not handled. If the Verified Step author fails to manage the contribution as described in our Contributor License Agreement and this SLA, Bitrise withdraws the Verified badge from the Step. This is to ensure Verified Steps in our StepLib are always of high quality and meet Bitrise users’ expectations.

title: Managing contributions
body: The following guidelines aim to help Verified Step authors categorize contributions. The Verified Step author is responsible for any contribution made to the Verified Step. The Verified Step author acknowledges the contribution by adding a label an estimated time to perform the fix, and merge the PR. There are four labels the author can use to categorize the type of contribution:

title: Managing contributions
body: critical-bug label means that the current feature set has abnormal behavior, which blocks users from using the Step and there is no workaround to fix the issue. This critical bug must be fixed by the author.

title: Managing contributions
body: bug label means that the current feature set has abnormal behavior, which does not block users from using the Step and there is a workaround for the issue. This bug must be fixed by the author.

title: Managing contributions
body: feature-request label means that a new feature or Step is being requested. The Verified Step author can decide if the feature is worth implementing.

title: Managing contributions
body: maintenance label means improving the Step’s source code in a way that it does not add new features or potential bugs to the Step. The Verified Step author can decide whether the feature is worth implementing or not.

title: Managing contributions
body: rejected label means the contribution which gets rejected by the Verified Step author must be closed within the first response time, that is 5 business days. When rejecting a contribution, the Verified Step author has to provide an explanation to the contributor within the first response time.

title: Managing contributions
body: accepted contribution means that the given: critical-bug, bug, feature, maintenance will be fixed/merged within the given resolution time.

title: Managing contributions
body: First response time means that there is a 5 day window during which the Verified Step author should respond to the contribution with the accepted or rejected labels.

title: Managing contributions
body: Resolution time means a certain amount of business days during which the contribution (issue or PR) should be completed by the Verified Step author.

title: How do we go about Step duplications?
body: In general we try to keep our StepLib streamlined and avoid Step duplications for the same build task. Here you can find some questions and answers when it comes to any potential Step duplications.

title: How do we go about Step duplications?
body: I was going to submit a Step and apply for the Verified badge, but found out there was an official Bitrise Step for the same build task in the StepLib. What should I do?

title: How do we go about Step duplications?
body: Submit your Step and go through the application process. Once your application is completed, we deprecate the official Bitrise Step and our users can use your new Verified Step.

title: How do we go about Step duplications?
body: I was going to submit a Step and apply for the Verified badge, but found out there was a Community Step for the same build task. What should I do?

title: How do we go about Step duplications?
body: Submit your Step and go through the application process. Your new Verified Step and the Community Step will be both available in our StepLib.

title: How do we go about Step duplications?
body: I was going to submit a Community Step but found out there was a Verified Step for the same build task. What should I do?

title: How do we go about Step duplications?
body: If a Verified Step is already available in our StepLib, we reject Community Step submission for the same build task to avoid Step duplication. We offer to the Community Step developer to work on future updates of the already existing Verified Step.

title: Creating your own Bitrise project scanner
body: A Bitrise project scanner must have a scan result model. Every platform scanner writes its possible options, configurations, and warnings into this model. These will be translated into Step input values by choosing the desired values for the given options.

title: Creating your own Bitrise project scanner
body: The project scanner is a tool that identifies the given project’s type and generates a basic Bitrise configuration. Each supported project type has its own scanner: these scanners are stored as separate packages.

title: Creating your own Bitrise project scanner
body: A project type scanner defines at least two Workflows: one for testing (primary) and one for building (deploy). It includes the minimal amount of Steps to successfully run them.

title: Creating your own Bitrise project scanner
body: Build and test Steps

title: Creating your own Bitrise project scanner
body: Build Steps and test Steps have specific requirements:

title: Creating your own Bitrise project scanner
body: A build Step must build your app so that it is ready for deployment and it must output an Environment Variable that points to the output file(s). For example, a build Step to build an iOS app must output an .ipa file (not, say, .xcodearchive) and the path to this .ipa file.

title: Creating your own Bitrise project scanner
body: A test Step must output the test results so that they are available for viewing on the build page on bitrise.io.

title: Creating your own Bitrise project scanner
body: When adding a new project on the website or initializing a project on your own machine, the bitrise-init tool iterates through every scanner, calls the scanner interface methods on each of them and collects their outputs. Based on these outputs, a basic configuration is generated.

title: Creating your own Bitrise project scanner
body: The possible Workflows are described in a scan result model. The model consists of:

title: Creating your own Bitrise project scanner
body: options

title: Creating your own Bitrise project scanner
body: configs

title: Creating your own Bitrise project scanner
body: warnings

title: Creating your own Bitrise project scanner
body: Here is the basic structure of the model, in YAML:

title: Creating your own Bitrise project scanner
body:
options:
 DETECTED_PLATFORM_1: OptionModel
 DETECTED_PLATFORM_2: OptionModel
 ...

configs:
 DETECTED_PLATFORM_1:
 CONFIG_NAME_1: ConfigModel
 CONFIG_NAME_2: ConfigModel
 ...
 DETECTED_PLATFORM_2:
 CONFIG_NAME_1: ConfigModel
 CONFIG_NAME_2: ConfigModel
 ...
 ...

warnings:
 DETECTED_PLATFORM_1:
 - "warning message 1"
 - "warning message 2"
 ...
 DETECTED_PLATFORM_2:
 - "warning message 1"
 - "warning message 2"
 ...

title: Creating your own Bitrise project scanner
body: Every platform scanner writes its possible options, configurations and warnings into this model. These will be translated into Step input values by choosing the desired values for the given options.

title: Creating your own Bitrise project scanner
body: Every option chain’s last option selects a configuration.

title: Creating your own Bitrise project scanner
body: Warnings display the issues with the given project setup.

title: Options
body: Options represents a question and the possible answers to the question. For example:

title: Options
body: Question: What is the path to the iOS project files?

title: Options
body: Possible answers: List of possible paths to check

title: Options
body: These questions and answers are translated into Step inputs. The scanner should either determine the input value or let the user select or type the value.

title: Options
body: For example, the Xcode Archive & Export for iOS Step has an input called export-method. This informs the Step of the type of .ipa you want to export. The value cannot be determined based on the source code so the scanner collects every possible value and presents them to the user in the form of a list to choose from.

title: Options
body: Selecting an option can start a chain: it can lead to different options being presented afterwards. For example, if you select an Xcode scheme that has associated test targets, it leads to different “questions”. Similarly, selecting a certain option can lead to a different workflow being generated afterwards.

title: The option model
body: The OptionModel represents an input option. It looks like this in Go:

title: The option model
The option model
body: Title: the human readable name of the input.

title: The option model
body: EnvKey: it represents the input’s key in the step model.

title: The option model
body: ChildOptionMap: the map of the subsequent options if the user chooses a given value for the option.

title: The option model
body: For example, let’s see a scenario where you choose a value for the Scheme input. You will have a value_map in the options. The possible values are:

title: The option model
body: SchemeWithTest

title: The option model
body: SchemeWithoutTest

title: The option model
body: By choosing SchemeWithTest, the next option will be related to the simulator used to perform the test.

title: The option model
body: By choosing SchemeWithoutTest, the next option will be about the export method for the .ipa file.

title: The option model
The option model
body: Every option chain has a first option: this is called head. The possible values of the options can branch the option chain.

title: The option model
body: Every option branch’s last options must have a config property set. config holds the id of the generated Bitrise configuration.

title: The option model
body: An options chain’s last options cannot have a value_map.

title: The option model
Scanners
body: Scanners generate the possible options chains and the possible workflows for the options per project type. The ActiveScanner variable holds each scanner implementation. Every specific scanner implements the ScannerInterface.

title: Scanners
Scanners
body: Name() string: This method is used for logging and storing the scanner output (warnings, options and configs). The scanner output is stored in map[SCANNER_NAME]OUTPUT. For example, the options for an iOS project is stored in optionsMap[ios]options.

title: Scanners
body: DetectPlatform(string) (bool, error): This method is used to determine if the given search directory contains the project type or not.

title: Scanners
body: Options() (models.OptionModel, models.Warnings, error): This method is used to generate option branches for the project. Each branch should define a complete and valid option set to build the final bitrise config model. Every option branch’s last Options has to store a configuration id, which will be filled with the selected options.

title: Scanners
body: Configs() (models.BitriseConfigMap, error): This method is used to generate the possible configs. BitriseConfigMap’s each element is a bitrise config template which will be fulfilled with the user selected option values.

title: Scanners
body: DefaultOptions() models.OptionModel and DefaultConfigs() (models.BitriseConfigMap, error) : These methods are used to generate the options and configs without scanning the given project. In this case every required step input value is provided by the user. This way even if a scanner fails, the user has an option to get started.

title: Testing a scanner
body: To test a scanner, we require both unit tests and integration tests.

title: Testing a scanner
body: Unit tests are written using Go’s standard testing library.

title: Testing a scanner
body: For integration tests, we are validating that the project type scanners are generating the desired Bitrise configurations for an instance of the project type. To do this, we use the new scanner to scan the given sample project and we modify the generated scan result to fit our integration tests.

title: Testing a scanner
body: The reason for the modification is that the scanners are adding Steps to the generated config, but the Step versions are updated from time to time. The Step version definitions can be found at steps/const.go.

title: Testing a scanner
body: So we call bitrise-init --ci config in the sample project’s root directory, and in the generated scan_result.yml file we replace the Step versions with %s and we use fmt.Sprintf to inject the latest defined Step versions into the config.

title: Testing a scanner
body: In the integration tests, we are matching the scan_result.yml file generated by the scanner with the previously generated reference scan_result content.

title: Submitting your own scanner
body: You can submit your own scanner to Bitrise: we will review it and integrate it to the bitrise-init tool once it’s approved!

title: Submitting your own scanner
body: The development path for a new scanner starts with your own sample project and ends with updating the existing Steps for your project type. Let’s go through it!

title: Submitting your own scanner
body: Find or create an open source sample app that demonstrates a typical instance of your project type.

title: Submitting your own scanner
body: It should include:

title: Submitting your own scanner
body: a readme file (including tool versions required for updating, building and testing this project).

title: Submitting your own scanner
body: a bitrise.yml file that is generated by your scanner.

title: Submitting your own scanner
body: Build and test your sample app with existing Steps or custom scripts.

title: Submitting your own scanner
body: Create the missing Steps the new project type needs.

title: Submitting your own scanner
body: The PR for these Steps should link the scanner PR once you created the scanner.

title: Submitting your own scanner
body: Create a scanner for your project type.

title: Submitting your own scanner
body: Run the required unit tests and integration tests.

title: Submitting your own scanner
body: Open a scanner pull request to the bitrise-init project.

title: Submitting your own scanner
body: It should:

title: Submitting your own scanner
body: link the new project type’s sample app.

title: Submitting your own scanner
body: link the new project type’s guides for testing and building.

title: Submitting your own scanner
body: include an icon for the new project type - otherwise we will create one for you.

title: Submitting your own scanner
body: recommend the default stack by listing the required tools for building and testing the new project type.

title: Submitting your own scanner
body: Update the existing Steps with the new project type if necessary.

title: Submitting your own scanner
body: The PR for these Steps should link the scanner PR.

title: Workflows
body: A Bitrise Workflow is a collection of Steps. When a build of an app is running, each Step will be executed in the order that is defined in the Workflow.

title: Workflows
body: A Bitrise Workflow is a collection of Steps. When a build of an app is running, each Step will be executed in the order that is defined in the Workflow. Workflows can be created, defined and modified in two ways:

title: Workflows
body: Using the graphical Workflow Editor on bitrise.io, or the offline version on your own device.

title: Workflows
body: Directly editing the bitrise.yml file of your project.

title: Workflows
body: Ultimately, both methods modify the bitrise.yml file - the Workflow Editor is simply a friendlier way of doing so!

title: Workflows
body: By default, a single build is a single Workflow. But you can also chain Workflows together so they run in succession, as well as to trigger multiple Workflow to run simultaneously.

title: Workflows
body: Workflows can also be arranged into Pipelines. A Pipeline consists of multiple Stages and each Stage consists of one or more Workflows which run in parallel.

title: Default Workflows
body: When you add a new app on bitrise.io, one or two Workflows are created automatically, depending on your app. These are the primary and the deploy Workflows.

title: Default Workflows
body: When you add a new app on bitrise.io, one or two Workflows are created automatically, depending on your app. These are the primary and the deploy Workflows.

title: Default Workflows
body: Triggers can be configured so that any other Workflow (including deploy) is automatically triggered when certain code events happen.

title: The primary Workflow
body: The primary Workflow is automatically created when adding a new app. Once the process of adding the app is over, Bitrise triggers the app’s first build automatically: this build runs with the primary workflow.

title: The primary Workflow
body: The primary Workflow is not the same for every app you create: it contains different Steps depending on the project type. For example, an Android project’s primary Workflow will include the Install missing Android SDK components, the Android Lint and the Android Unit Test Steps. But overall, primary is a basic Workflow that always performs the following actions:

title: The primary Workflow
body: Activates the SSH key, if one has been added to the app. The step saves it to file and then loads it into the user’s ssh-agent with the ssh-add command. The Step, by default, does not run if there is no SSH key added.

title: The primary Workflow
body: Clones the Git repository of the project with the Git Clone Repository Step.

title: The primary Workflow
body: Runs the Bitrise.io Cache:Pull and Bitrise.io Cache:Push Steps.

title: The primary Workflow
body: Deploys build artifacts with the Deploy to Bitrise.io Step.

title: The deploy Workflow
body: The deploy Workflow is automatically created when adding a new app if you have tests configured in your app. It is similar to the primary Workflow in a number of ways:

title: The deploy Workflow
body: It has the same basic steps.

title: The deploy Workflow
body: Its specific steps are dependent on the project type.

title: The deploy Workflow
body: The deploy Workflow, however, also contains the Steps that build the project, and, if the build is successful, produces the necessary artifacts for installing the app or deploying it online. For example, an Android project’s deploy Workflow contains the Android Build Step that builds your project with Gradle, and the Android Sign Step that creates a signed APK which can be deployed to Google Play or installed on test devices.

title: Creating a Workflow
body: You can create new Bitrise Workflows based on any of the existing ones, or you can simply create an empty Workflow and add the Steps yourself.

title: Creating a Workflow
body: It’s very simple to create your own Workflow with the Workflow Editor. You can create new Workflows based on any of the existing ones, or you can simply create an empty Workflow and add the Steps yourself.

title: Creating a Workflow
body: If, for example, you create a Workflow based on your primary one, it means that it will be created with the exact same Steps and input values as the primary Workflow.

title: Creating a Workflow
body: Open your app on Bitrise.

title: Creating a Workflow
body: Click the Workflows button on the main page.

title: Creating a Workflow
body: Click + to the right of the name of the Workflow.

title: Creating a Workflow
body: Give your Workflow a name.

title: Creating a Workflow
body: The name can be as long as you wish since longer titles get broken into multiple lines so that you can read the whole title conveniently.

title: Creating a Workflow
body: From the dropdown menu labeled BASED ON, select the Workflow you want to use as the basis for the new one.

title: Creating a Workflow
body: Alternatively, choose the Empty workflow option to create an empty Workflow.

title: Creating a Workflow
body: Add the Steps you need to your Workflow.

title: Creating a Workflow
body: Click the + symbol between two Steps to insert a Step at that position. Remove Steps you do not need by clicking on the Step and clicking the little trash bin symbol.

title: Creating a Workflow
body: Click Save in the top right corner.

title: Managing Workflows
body: You can chain multiple Workflows, rearrange the order of Workflows in a chain, as well as rename Workflows at any time in the Bitrise Workflow Editor.

title: Managing Workflows
body: You can chain multiple Workflows, rearrange the order of Workflows in a chain, as well as rename Workflows at any time in the Bitrise Workflow Editor.

title: Managing Workflows
body: Offline Workflow Editor

title: Managing Workflows
body: The Workflow Editor is available both online and offline:

title: Managing Workflows
body: You can use it online on bitrise.io.

title: Managing Workflows
body: You can use the offline Workflow Editor.

title: Chaining Workflows together
body: You can set up multiple Workflows to run in succession. The order of these Workflows can be rearranged, new Workflows can be added to the chain and existing Workflows can be removed from it at any time.

title: Chaining Workflows together
body: Bitrise Start Build Step

title: Chaining Workflows together
body: Be aware that if you chain Workflows together as described in this guide, all the Workflows will still run on the same virtual machine. However, if you use the Bitrise Start Build Step, each of the triggered Workflows will run on a separate virtual machine: Starting parallel builds with a single trigger.

title: Chaining Workflows together
body: Open your app on Bitrise.

title: Chaining Workflows together
body: Click the Workflows button on the main page.

title: Chaining Workflows together
body: Select a Workflow from the WORKFLOW dropdown menu.

title: Chaining Workflows together
body: Click the ellipsis (...) button to the right of the name of the Workflow.

title: Chaining Workflows together
body: From the dropdown menu, select Insert Workflow before to chain a Workflow before the currently selected one or select Insert Workflow after to chain a Workflow after the currently selected one.

title: Chaining Workflows together
body: Click Save in the top right corner.

title: Chaining Workflows together
body: Chaining Workflows in YAML

title: Chaining Workflows together
body: In this example, we're chaining together three Workflows: test, deploy, and ci, using the before_run and after_run parameters.

title: Chaining Workflows together
body:
workflows:
 test:
 envs:
 - IS_TEST: "true"
 steps:
 # test Steps to run

 deploy:
 before_run:
 - test
 steps:
 # steps to deploy

 ci:
 before_run:
 - test
 after_run:
 - deploy

title: Chaining Workflows together
body: For more information on how to manage Workflows directly in the bitrise.yml file, check Workflow reference.

title: Rearranging chained Workflows
body: Once you have a chain, you can easily rearrange the order of Workflows in a drag-and-drop menu.

title: Rearranging chained Workflows
body: Open your app on Bitrise.

title: Rearranging chained Workflows
body: Click the Workflows button on the main page.

title: Rearranging chained Workflows
body: Select a Workflow from the WORKFLOW dropdown menu.

title: Rearranging chained Workflows
body: Click the ellipsis (...) button to the right of the name of the Workflow.

title: Rearranging chained Workflows
body: From the dropdown menu, select Change Workflow execution orderto bring up a drag-and-drop menu where you can rearrange the Workflows of the chain.

title: Rearranging chained Workflows
body: Click Save in the top right corner.

title: Renaming Workflows
body: Rename your Workflows at any time you feel necessary: it’s quick and simple.

title: Renaming Workflows
body: Open your app on Bitrise.

title: Renaming Workflows
body: Click the Workflows button on the main page.

title: Renaming Workflows
body: Select a Workflow from the WORKFLOW dropdown menu.

title: Renaming Workflows
body: Click RENAME next to the name of the Workflow.

title: Renaming Workflows
body: Type the new name then click the check mark to save the new name.

title: Renaming Workflows
body: Click Save in the top right corner.

title: Utility Workflows
body: Bitrise supports a special type of Workflow called a utility Workflow. A utility Workflow's ID always starts with an underscore character: for example, _setup. They are usually used to perform tasks that are required either at the start or at the end of several different Workflows: for example, you can separate git cloning and activating your SSH key into a utility Workflow instead of adding those Steps to every Workflow of an app.

title: Utility Workflows
body: You can create a utility Workflow the exact same way as you create a regular one. To denote it as a utility Workflow, you just need to prefix the name with an underscore.

title: Utility Workflows
body: Utility Workflows cannot run alone

title: Utility Workflows
body: Utility Workflows cannot be run as standalone Workflows. They need to be chained together with a normal Workflow, either before or after the Workflow: Chaining Workflows together.

title: Utility Workflows
body: Utility Workflow in YAML

title: Utility Workflows
body: In this example, we have two utility Workflows, called _setup and _send-notifications. They are chained together with two Workflows called test and ci using the before_run and after_run parameters.

title: Utility Workflows
body:
workflows:
 _send-notifications:
 steps:
 # send notifications

 _setup:
 steps:
 # setup Steps to run

 test:
 before_run:
 - _setup
 envs:
 - IS_TEST: "true"
 steps:
 # test Steps to run

 ci:
 before_run:
 - test
 after_run:
 - _send-notifications

title: Utility Workflows
body: For more information on how to manage Workflows directly in the bitrise.yml file, check Workflow reference.

title: Copying Workflows from one app to another
body: You can copy an existing Bitrise Workflow from any bitrise.yml file, including your local files.

title: Copying Workflows from one app to another
body: If you have a lot of apps, you might not want to spend time with setting up Workflows for each and every one of them separately, especially if there’s little difference between the Workflows you want to run for them. If so, the easiest thing to do is to simply copy an existing Workflow.

title: Copying Workflows from one app to another
body: YAML mode only

title: Copying Workflows from one app to another
body: Copying a Workflow to another app is only possible in YAML mode. You can create a new Workflow based on an existing one but only for the same app.

title: Copying Workflows from one app to another
body: You can copy a Workflow from any bitrise.yml file, including your local files. To copy an existing Workflow from one Bitrise app to another on our website:

title: Copying Workflows from one app to another
body: Open your app on Bitrise.

title: Copying Workflows from one app to another
body: Click the Workflows button on the main page.

title: Copying Workflows from one app to another
body: Go to the bitrise.yml tab.

title: Copying Workflows from one app to another
body: Select the Workflow you want and copy it.

title: Copying Workflows from one app to another
body: Open the app you want to copy it to.

title: Copying Workflows from one app to another
body: Go to the Workflow tab and then the bitrise.yml tab.

title: Copying Workflows from one app to another
body: Paste the Workflow under the workflows property.

title: (Android) Deploy to Visual Studio App Center
body: (Android) Deploy to Visual Studio App Center

title: Description
body: Build and distribute your app to testers via Visual Studio App Center.

title: Prerequisites
body: An existing Visual Studio App Center project where your app is registered.

title: Prerequisites
body: Adding the API token as a Secret to your Bitrise app with the name APPCENTER_API_TOKEN.

title: Prerequisites
body: If you want to deploy a release build, don't forget to set up code signing on Bitrise to build and sign the APK with your release key.

title: Instructions
body: Add the Android Build Step and set the following inputs:

title: Instructions
body: Build type: set this to apk.

title: Instructions
body: Variant: use release, debug, or one of your custom variants if you have any.

title: Instructions
body: If you build a release variant, add the Android Sign Step.

title: Instructions
body: You can skip this if you plan to deploy an unsigned debug variant.

title: Instructions
body: Add the AppCenter iOS Deploy Step and set the following inputs:

title: Instructions
body: API Token: $APPCENTER_API_TOKEN

title: Instructions
body: Owner name: for example, my-company.

title: Instructions
body: App name: For example, my-app. Use the App Center CLI to get the app name since it might not be the same as the one you can see on the Visual Studio App Center website.

title: Instructions
body: Check out other options in the Step documentation or in the Workflow Editor.

title: bitrise.yml
body:
- android-build@1:
 inputs:
 - variant: release
 - build_type: apk
 - sign-apk@1: {}
 - appcenter-deploy-android@2:
 inputs:
 - owner_name: my-company
 - app_name: my-app
 - app_path: "$BITRISE_APK_PATH"
 - api_token: "$APPCENTER_API_TOKEN"

title: (Android) Deploy to Firebase App Distribution
body: (Android) Deploy to Firebase App Distribution

title: Description
body: Build and distribute your app to testers via Firebase App Distribution. This example builds and deploys an APK, but the Workflow can be tweaked to distribute AAB instead.

title: Prerequisites
body: An existing Firebase project where your exact package name is registered. See the Firebase documentation for details.

title: Prerequisites
body: Obtain a token from Firebase by running firebase login:ci locally. See the Firebase CLI docs for details.

title: Prerequisites
body: Add this token as a Secret to your Bitrise app with the name FIREBASE_TOKEN.

title: Prerequisites
body: Get your Firebase App ID from your project's General Settings page and pass this value as an input to the Firebase App Distribution Step.

title: Prerequisites
body: If you want to deploy a release build, don't forget to set up code signing on Bitrise to build and sign the APK with your release key.

title: Instructions
body: Add the Android Build Step and set the following inputs:

title: Instructions
body: Build type: Set this to apk.

title: Instructions
body: Variant: Use release, debug, or one of your custom variants if you have any.

title: Instructions
body: If you build a release variant, add the Android Sign Step.

title: Instructions
body: You can skip this if you plan to deploy an unsigned debug variant.

title: Instructions
body: Add the Firebase App Distribution Step and set the following inputs:

title: Instructions
body: Firebase token: use the secret Env var previously defined: $FIREBASE_TOKEN.

title: Instructions
body: App path: this should point to the APK that the previous steps have built and signed. By default, it's located at $BITRISE_DEPLOY_DIR/app-release-bitrise-signed.apk, but the exact file name might be different based on your project config.

title: Instructions
body: Firebase App ID: get your Firebase App ID from your project's General Settings page and pass this value as an input to the Firebase App Distribution Step.

title: Instructions
body: Optional: you can define test groups or individual testers in the Step inputs

title: bitrise.yml
body:
- android-build@1:
 inputs:
 - variant: release
 - build_type: apk
- sign-apk@1: {}
- firebase-app-distribution@0:
 inputs:
 - firebase_token: $FIREBASE_TOKEN
 - app_path: $BITRISE_DEPLOY_DIR/app-release-bitrise-signed.apk
 - app: your_app_id_from_firebase
 - testers: email@company.com # optional
 - groups: qa-team #optional

title: (Android) Deploy to Google Play (Internal, Alpha, Beta, Production)
body: (Android) Deploy to Google Play (Internal, Alpha, Beta, Production)

title: Description
body: Build an Android app and upload to Google Play to internal, alpha, beta or production track.

title: Prerequisites
body: An Android keystore file is uploaded to Bitrise.

title: Prerequisites
body: Google Play API Access is set up.

title: Instructions
body: (Optional) Add the Change Android versionCode and versionName Step. Set the input variables:

title: Instructions
body: Path to the build.gradle file: The default value is $PROJECT_LOCATION/$MODULE/build.gradle and in most cases you don't have to change it.

title: Instructions
body: New versionName: for example, 1.0.1

title: Instructions
body: New versionCode: for example, 42.

title: Instructions
body: Add the Android Build Step and set the following inputs:

title: Instructions
body: Build type: Set this to aab.

title: Instructions
body: Variant: Use release, debug, or one of your custom variants if you have any.

title: Instructions
body: Module: for example $MODULE.

title: Instructions
body: Add the Android Sign Step.

title: Instructions
body: Add the Google Play Deploy Step and set the following inputs:

title: Instructions
body: Service Account JSON key file path: $BITRISEIO_SERVICE_ACCOUNT_JSON_KEY_URL.

title: Instructions
body: Package name: for example, com.your.package.name.

title: Instructions
body: Track: Choose one of internal, alpha, beta, or production.

title: Instructions
body: Status: The status of a release. For more information, see the Google API reference. Recommended draft for production and completed for internal test builds.

title: Instructions
body: Check the other options in the Workflow Editor or in the Step documentation.

title: Instructions
body: Deploy to Google Play fails with Error 403

title: Instructions
body: You might experience that Deploy to Google Play Step fails with error:

title: Instructions
body: "error: Failed to perform edit insert call, error: googleapi: Error 403: The caller does not have permission, forbidden"

title: Instructions
body: For possible solutions, check out our Knowledge Base article.

title: bitrise.yml
body:
- change-android-versioncode-and-versionname@1:
 inputs:
 - new_version_name: 1.0.1
 - new_version_code: '42'
 - build_gradle_path: "$PROJECT_LOCATION/$MODULE/build.gradle"
- android-build@1:
 inputs:
 - project_location: "$PROJECT_LOCATION"
 - module: "$MODULE"
 - build_type: aab
 - variant: release
- sign-apk@1: {}
- google-play-deploy@3:
 inputs:
 - service_account_json_key_path: "$BITRISEIO_SERVICE_ACCOUNT_JSON_KEY_URL"
 - package_name: io.bitrise.sample.android
 - status: completed
 - track: internal

title: bitrise.yml
body:
---
format_version: '11'
default_step_lib_source: https://github.com/bitrise-io/bitrise-steplib.git
project_type: android
workflows:
 ci:
 steps:
 - activate-ssh-key@4:
 run_if: '{{getenv "SSH_RSA_PRIVATE_KEY" | ne ""}}'
 - git-clone@6: {}
 - cache-pull@2: {}
 - android-unit-test@1:
 inputs:
 - project_location: $PROJECT_LOCATION
 - variant: $VARIANT
 - android-build-for-ui-testing@0:
 inputs:
 - variant: $VARIANT
 - module: $MODULE
 - virtual-device-testing-for-android@1:
 inputs:
 - test_type: instrumentation
 - android-lint@0:
 inputs:
 - variant: "$VARIANT"
 - android-build@1:
 inputs:
 - project_location: "$PROJECT_LOCATION"
 - module: "$MODULE"
 - variant: "$VARIANT"
 - deploy-to-bitrise-io@2: {}
 - slack@3:
 inputs:
 - channel: "#build-notifications"
 - webhook_url: "$SLACK_WEBHOOK"
 - cache-push@2: {}
app:
 envs:
 - opts:
 is_expand: false
 PROJECT_LOCATION: "."
 - opts:
 is_expand: false
 MODULE: app
 - VARIANT: debug
 opts:
 is_expand: false
trigger_map:
- push_branch: main
 workflow: ci

title: Turn on Gradle build profiling
body: Turn on Gradle build profiling

title: Description
body: Generate and store a performance report of every Gradle build to spot build speed issues or compare different builds.

title: Instructions
body: No matter what Android or Gradle Step you use in your Bitrise Workflow, there is an option to define additional command line arguments for Gradle. Add --profile to the relevant input variable to generate a performance report of the Gradle tasks. In the example below, we are adding the argument to the Android Unit Test Step.

title: Instructions
body: Add the Android Unit Test Step to your Workflow and set the necessary input variables:

title: Instructions
body: Project location: $PROJECT_LOCATION.

title: Instructions
body: Module: $MODULE.

title: Instructions
body: Variant: $VARIANT.

title: Instructions
body: Arguments: --profile2.

title: Instructions
body: Add a Script Step to the end of the Workflow to compress the report files and copy the ZIP file to the deploy directory:

title: Instructions
body:
#!/usr/bin/env bash
# fail if any commands fails
set -e
# debug log
set -x

zip -r $BITRISE_DEPLOY_DIR/gradle-profile.zip $PROJECT_LOCATION/build/reports/profile

title: Instructions
body: Gradle creates the HTML report in build/reports/profile/, so we need to take all files in that folder (HTML, CSS and JS files), compress them, and move the ZIP archive to $BITRISE_DEPLOY_DIR. Files in this folder can be accessed on the build page’s Artifacts tab.

title: Instructions
body: Trigger a manual build of your app.

title: Instructions
body: Download and unarchive the gradle-profile.zip file, then open the HTML report in your browser.

title: Instructions
body: Go to the Artifacts tab and check the various aspects of the build in the report:

title: Instructions
body: The Summary tab shows time spent on things other than task execution.

title: Instructions
body: The Task execution tab lists all tasks sorted by execution time.

title: Instructions
body: Cached tasks are marked as UP-TO-DATE. This helps to fine-tune the Bitrise Cache Steps by comparing the reports of multiple builds.

title: Instructions
body: For Gradle optimization ideas, check out this article by Google.

title: Instructions
body: If you only want to display task execution times only in the build log, you can use the build-time-tracker plugin.

title: bitrise.yml
body:
- android-unit-test@1:
 inputs:
 - project_location: $PROJECT_LOCATION
 - module: $MODULE
 - arguments: "--profile"
 - variant: $VARIANT
- script@1:
 title: Collect Gradle profile report
 inputs:
 - content: |-
 #!/usr/bin/env bash
 # fail if any commands fails
 set -e
 # debug log
 set -x

 zip -r $BITRISE_DEPLOY_DIR/gradle-profile.zip $PROJECT_LOCATION/build/reports/profile
- deploy-to-bitrise-io@1: {}

body: Using the AVD Manager Step

title: Instructions
body: The AVD Manager starts in the background, which can take several minutes. Because of that, we recommend adding the AVD Manager Step at the beginning of your Workflow (before Activate SSH key (RSA private key) Step and the Git Clone Step) to speed up your builds.

title: Instructions
body: Add a Android Build for UI Testing Step, and configure the required inputs.

title: Instructions
body: Add a Wait for Android emulator Step.

title: Instructions
body: Add an Android Instrumented Test Step, and configure the required inputs.

title: Instructions
body: Add an Export test results to Test Reports add-on Step with the following inputs:

title: Instructions
body: The name of the test: Emulator tests.

title: Instructions
body: Test result base path: $BITRISE_SOURCE_DIR/app/build/outputs/androidTest-results.

title: Instructions
body: You might want to adjust the path based on the module name(s) in your project.

title: Instructions
body: Test result search pattern: *.xml.

title: Instructions
body: Add a Deploy to Bitrise.io Step that makes the test results available in the Test Reports add-on.

title: bitrise.yml
body:
- avd-manager@1: {}
- android-build-for-ui-testing@0:
 inputs:
 - module: "$ANDROID_TESTING_MODULE"
 - variant: "$ANDROID_V_DEBUG"
- wait-for-android-emulator@1:
- android-instrumented-test@0: {}
- custom-test-results-export@0:
 inputs:
 - search_pattern: "*.xml"
 - base_path: $BITRISE_SOURCE_DIR/app/build/outputs/androidTest-results
 - test_name: Emulator tests
- deploy-to-bitrise-io@2:

title: bitrise.yml
body:
---
format_version: '11'
default_step_lib_source: https://github.com/bitrise-io/bitrise-steplib.git
project_type: ios
workflows:
 ci:
 steps:
 - activate-ssh-key@4:
 run_if: '{{getenv "SSH_RSA_PRIVATE_KEY" | ne ""}}'
 - git-clone@6: {}
 - cache-pull@2: {}
 - cocoapods-install@2: {}
 - carthage@3:
 inputs:
 - carthage_options: "--use-xcframeworks --platform iOS"
 - recreate-user-schemes@1:
 inputs:
 - project_path: "$BITRISE_PROJECT_PATH"
 - xcode-test@4:
 inputs:
 - log_formatter: xcodebuild
 - xcodebuild_options: "-enableCodeCoverage YES"
 - xcode-archive@4:
 inputs:
 - project_path: "$BITRISE_PROJECT_PATH"
 - scheme: "$BITRISE_SCHEME"
 - automatic_code_signing: apple-id
 - distribution_method: development
 - deploy-to-bitrise-io@2: {}
 - slack@3:
 inputs:
 - channel: "#build-notifications"
 - webhook_url: "$SLACK_WEBHOOK"
 - cache-push@2: {}
app:
 envs:
 - opts:
 is_expand: false
 BITRISE_PROJECT_PATH: BitriseTest.xcworkspace
 - opts:
 is_expand: false
 BITRISE_SCHEME: BitriseTest
 - opts:
 is_expand: false
 BITRISE_DISTRIBUTION_METHOD: development
trigger_map:
- push_branch: main
 workflow: ci

title: (iOS) Deploy to Firebase App Distribution
body: (iOS) Deploy to Firebase App Distribution

title: Description
body: Build and distribute your app to testers via Firebase App Distribution.

title: Prerequisites
body: An existing Firebase project where your exact bundle ID is registered. Follow the Firebase documentation for details.

title: Prerequisites
body: Obtain a token from Firebase by running firebase login:ci locally. See the Firebase CLI docs for more details.

title: Prerequisites
body: Add this token as a Secret to your Bitrise project with the name FIREBASE_TOKEN.

title: Prerequisites
body: Get your Firebase App ID from your project's General Settings page and pass this value as an input variable to the [BETA] Firebase App Distribution Step.

title: Prerequisites
body: You have code signing set up. See iOS code signing for more details.

title: Instructions
body: Add the Xcode Archive & Export for iOS Step and set the required input variables, such as Scheme, Distribution method and the desired code signing method.

title: Instructions
body: Add the [BETA] Firebase App Distribution Step and set the following input variables:

title: Instructions
body: Firebase token: use the secret env var previously defined: $FIREBASE_TOKEN.

title: Instructions
body: Firebase App ID: see the Prerequisites section above for details.

title: Instructions
body: Optionally, you can define test groups or individual testers in the Step input variables.

title: bitrise.yml
body:
- xcode-archive@6:
 inputs:
 - distribution_method: development
 - scheme: # your scheme goes here
 - automatic_code_signing: api-key
- firebase-app-distribution@0:
 inputs:
 - firebase_token: $FIREBASE_TOKEN
 - app: # your app ID from Firebase
 - testers: email@company.com # optional
 - groups: qa-team #optional

title: (iOS) Override the Apple service connection credentials using Step inputs
body: (iOS) Override the Apple service connection credentials using Step inputs

title: Description
body: You can override the Apple service connection credentials configured in the App Settings by setting the inputs under the App Store Connect connection override input group in the Xcode Archive & Export for iOS Step.

title: Description
body: This can be useful if your team uses multiple App Store accounts or if you manage multiple apps in a single Bitrise app and would like to use different Apple service connections based on your Workflow.

title: Prerequisites
body: Before starting, generate or get the following using App Store Connect:

title: Prerequisites
body: App Store Connect API private key.

title: Prerequisites
body: App Store Connect API key ID.

title: Prerequisites
body: App Store Connect API issuer ID.

title: Prerequisites
body: For more information, check out Creating App Store Connect API private keys.

title: Instructions
body: Upload your App Store Connect API private key file (.p8 file) to the Generic File Storage in the Code Signing tab.

title: Instructions
body: Add the Xcode Archive & Export for iOS Step (version 4.6.0 or newer) to your Workflow.

title: Instructions
body: Set the Automatic code signing method input to api-key.

title: Instructions
body: Set the following Step inputs under the App Store Connect connection override input group:

title: Instructions
body: App Store Connect API private key: Local path or remote URL to the private key (.p8 file) for App Store Connect API. Set this input to the automatically generated Env Var connected to the App Store Connect API private key file (.p8 file) you uploaded to the Generic File Storage in step 1.

title: Instructions
body: App Store Connect API key ID: Private key ID used for App Store Connect authentication.

title: Instructions
body: App Store Connect API issuer ID: Private key issuer ID used for App Store Connect authentication.

title: bitrise.yml
body:
- xcode-archive@4:
 inputs:
 - automatic_code_signing: api-key
 - api_key_path: "$BITRISEIO_APP_STORE_CONNECT_API_ID_URL"
 - api_key_id: "$APP_STORE_API_ID"
 - api_key_issuer_id: "$APP_STORE_API_ISSUER_ID"
