title: (React Native) Expo: Build using Turtle CLI
body: (React Native) Expo: Build using Turtle CLI

title: Description
body: Publish an app to Expo's servers and build an iOS App Store .ipa and an Android .aab file from your Expo project using Turtle CLI.

title: Prerequisites
body: Generate an iOS Distribution Certificate and an App Store Provisioning Profile based on the Generating iOS code signing files guide.

title: Prerequisites
body: Generate an Android Keystore by following the Android code signing with Android Studio guide.

title: Prerequisites
body: Make sure you can Publish your Expo project locally.

title: Instructions
body: Open your app on Bitrise.

title: Instructions
body: Click the Workflows button on the main page.

title: Instructions
body: Go to the Code Signing & Files tab.

title: Instructions
body: Make sure that the project's iOS Distribution Certificate and App Store Provisioning Profile are uploaded.

title: Instructions
body: If not, add them in the Add Provisioning Profile(s) and the Add a certificate (.p12 file) for code signing, respectively.

title: Instructions
body: Make sure that the project's Android Keystore file is uploaded.

title: Instructions
body: If not, drag-and-drop your keystore file to the Upload file (max. 5 MB) field of the ANDROID KEYSTORE FILE section.

title: Instructions
body: Go to the Secrets tab.

title: Instructions
body: Create a Secret (IOS_DEVELOPMENT_TEAM) with the ID of the iOS Development Team issued in the project's Certificate and Provisioning Profile.

title: Instructions
body: Store the Expo account's username and password used for publishing in EXPO_USERNAME and EXPO_PASSWORD Secrets.

title: Instructions
body: Go to the bitrise.yml tab.

title: Instructions
body: Copy paste envs from bitrise.yml below to your Workflow.

title: Instructions
body: Copy paste steps from bitrise.yml below to your Workflow.

title: Instructions
body: The built .ipa and .aab files are exposed via BITRISE_IPA_PATH and BITRISE_AAB_PATH Env Vars.

title: bitrise.yml
body:
turtle_build:
 envs:
 - KEYSTORE_PATH: /tmp/keystore.jks
 - KEYSTORE_ALIAS: $BITRISEIO_ANDROID_KEYSTORE_ALIAS
 - EXPO_ANDROID_KEYSTORE_PASSWORD: $BITRISEIO_ANDROID_KEYSTORE_PASSWORD
 - EXPO_ANDROID_KEY_PASSWORD: $BITRISEIO_ANDROID_KEYSTORE_PRIVATE_KEY_PASSWORD
 - PROFILE_PATH: /tmp/profile.mobileprovision
 - CERTIFICATE_PATH: /tmp/certificate.p12
 - EXPO_IOS_DIST_P12_PASSWORD: $BITRISE_CERTIFICATE_PASSPHRASE
 # Define these in your secrets
 - IOS_DEVELOPMENT_TEAM: $IOS_DEVELOPMENT_TEAM
 - EXPO_USERNAME: $EXPO_USERNAME
 - EXPO_PASSWORD: $EXPO_PASSWORD
 steps:
 - script@1:
 title: Install dependencies
 inputs:
 - content: |-
 #!/usr/bin/env bash
 set -ex

 node --version
 fastlane --version

 npm install -g turtle-cli
 turtle --version

 npm install -g expo-cli
 expo --version
 - file-downloader@1:
 title: Download Android Keystore
 inputs:
 - destination: $KEYSTORE_PATH
 - source: $BITRISEIO_ANDROID_KEYSTORE_URL
 - file-downloader@1:
 title: Download iOS Certificate
 inputs:
 - destination: $CERTIFICATE_PATH
 - source: $BITRISE_CERTIFICATE_URL
 - file-downloader@1:
 title: Download iOS Provisioning Profile
 inputs:
 - destination: $PROFILE_PATH
 - source: $BITRISE_PROVISION_URL
 - npm@1:
 title: Install project dependencies
 inputs:
 - command: install
 - set-java-version@1:
 title: Set Java version to Java 8
 inputs:
 - set_java_version: "8"
 - script@1:
 title: Run Expo publish
 inputs:
 - content: |-
 #!/usr/bin/env bash
 set -ex

 expo login -u $EXPO_USERNAME -p $EXPO_PASSWORD --non-interactive
 expo publish
 - script@1:
 title: Run Turtle build
 inputs:
 - content: |-
 #!/usr/bin/env bash
 set -ex

 turtle setup:android
 aab_path=$BITRISE_DEPLOY_DIR/expo-project.aab
 turtle build:android --type app-bundle --keystore-path $KEYSTORE_PATH --keystore-alias $KEYSTORE_ALIAS -o $aab_path
 envman add --key BITRISE_AAB_PATH --value $aab_path

 turtle setup:ios
 ipa_path=$BITRISE_DEPLOY_DIR/expo-project.ipa
 turtle build:ios --team-id $IOS_DEVELOPMENT_TEAM --dist-p12-path $CERTIFICATE_PATH --provisioning-profile-path $PROFILE_PATH -o $ipa_path
 envman add --key BITRISE_IPA_PATH --value $ipa_path

body:
parent-workflow:
 steps:

 inputs:
 - workflows: |-
 workflow-1
 workflow-2
 - access_token: "$BITRISE_API_KEY"
 - script@1:

 - content: echo "Doing something else..."
 - build-router-wait@0:

title: Optimizing cache efficiency for pull request builds
body: Optimizing cache efficiency for pull request builds

title: Description
body: Bitrise caching is branch-based. You can optimize cache efficiency by keeping the cache up-to-date on a given branch.

title: Description
body: If a branch doesn't have a cache entry yet, the repository's default branch is used as a fallback to pull a cache entry. If a pull request targets the main branch, this fallback mechanism is used to pull the default branch's cache (as the pull request branch doesn't have any cache entry yet). This means that caching can still be efficient if the pull request destination is the default branch and the cache is up-to-date on the default branch.

title: Instructions
body: Make sure that any Workflow that runs frequently on the default branch contains the Bitrise.io Cache:Push Step. This will keep the cache up to date with content from successful builds. We recommend one of two approaches:

title: Instructions
body: Run the Workflow after every commit (for example, a merge) to the default branch, triggered by the push event on the default branch.

title: Instructions
body: Run the Workflow as a scheduled nightly build every day. This warms up the cache by pushing content based on the latest state of the default branch.

title: Instructions
body: (Optional) Set the Compress cache input variable to true. This can be useful if your cache folders are large and you are experiencing slow build times.

title: Instructions
body: Make sure that the Workflow which runs the pull requests contains the Bitrise.io Cache:Pull Step.

title: Instructions
body: This pulls the cache from successful builds on the default branch. We don't recommend pushing content into the cache for pull request builds for security and efficiency reasons. Even if the Workflow contains the Bitrise.io Cache:Push Step, it's skipped by default for pull request builds.

title: bitrise.yml
body: Workflow running on the default branch:

title: bitrise.yml
body:
# Add steps that produce the cached content (e.g. dependecies, builds)

- cache-push@2: {}

title: bitrise.yml
body: Pull request Workflow:

title: bitrise.yml
body:
- cache-pull@2: {}

# Add steps that can utilise the restored cache content

title: Builds and Pipelines
body: A Bitrise build is specified by the app’s Workflow which is a collection of Steps. The app’s build configuration can be modified in the bitrise.yml file or in the graphical Workflow Editor.

title: Builds and Pipelines
body: A Bitrise build is a series of jobs, specified by the app’s Workflow which is a collection of Steps. The app’s build configuration is specified in the bitrise.yml configuration file which you can modify in bitrise.io’s graphical Workflow Editor or locally. The file can be stored on bitrise.io or in your app's Git repository.

title: Builds and Pipelines
body: When a build is running, the scripts that define the Steps will be executed in the order you’ve defined in your Workflow, with the input parameters you set. They can produce multiple different outputs that other Steps can use, including but not limited to executable binaries, screenshots, test reports, variables, and so on.

title: Builds and Pipelines
body: The build process is the following:

title: Builds and Pipelines
body: Starting the build, either manually or by an automatic trigger.

title: Builds and Pipelines
body: Environment preparation: A virtual machine will be provisioned and prepared to run the build. Build specific Environment Variables are preset so you can use these in your Steps. You can find more information about the available stacks in the Workflow Editor, on the Stack tab.

title: Builds and Pipelines
body: Workflow execution: Steps in Workflows are executed in the same order as defined in the Workflow Editor of your application, from top to bottom. You can reorder the Steps by dragging them around. The log each Step generates will be displayed on the build’s details page.

title: Builds and Pipelines
body: Cleanup: After the execution of the build, a build log is created and stored on the Bitrise server. The virtual machine running the build is destroyed so your code/files will never fall into the wrong hands.

title: Builds and Pipelines
body: Build retention for 200 days

title: Builds and Pipelines
body: On the Builds page of your app, we only show builds from the last 200 days. The same limit applies if you are searching for specific builds on the page. This limitation also applies to most API calls: the GET/apps/{app-slug}/builds endpoint and related endpoints can only return builds from the last 200 days.

title: Builds and Pipelines
body: However, there are two methods to get a build that is older than 200 days:

title: Builds and Pipelines
body: If you know the exact build URL, you can access the build.

title: Builds and Pipelines
body: You can use the GET/apps/{app-slug}/archived-builds API endpoint: Listing the archived builds of an app.

title: Builds and Pipelines
body: After the build has finished, users can be notified via email, or you can set up your own Slack integration, for example.

title: Builds and Pipelines
body: A Bitrise Pipeline is the top level of our CI/CD configuration. Pipelines can be used to organize the entire CI/CD process and to set up advanced configurations with multiple different tasks running parallel and/or sequentially. For more information, see Build Pipelines.

title: Build Pipelines [BETA]
body: A Bitrise Pipeline is the top level of our CI/CD configuration. Pipelines can be used to organize the entire CI/CD process and to set up advanced configurations with multiple different tasks running parallel and/or sequentially.

title: Build Pipelines [BETA]
body: A Pipeline’s building blocks are:

title: Build Pipelines [BETA]
body: Steps: Blocks of script execution, each defining a single task in a CI/CD process.

title: Build Pipelines [BETA]
body: Workflows: Collections of Steps. When a build of an app is running, the Steps will be executed in the order that is defined in the Workflow.

title: Build Pipelines [BETA]
body: Stages: Collections of Workflows. A Stage can contain multiple Workflows which all run in parallel in the same Stage. If all Workflows are successful in a Stage, the Pipeline moves on to the next Stage. If any of the Workflows fail, the Pipeline ends without running the other Stages unless you configure a given Stage to always run.

title: Configuring a Bitrise Pipeline
body: Currently, configuring a Pipeline is only possible by directly editing the bitrise.yml file. You can create and modify Workflows in the graphical Workflow Editor but you need to define Pipelines and Stages in YAML format.

title: Defining Pipelines, Steps, and Workflows
body: The bitrise.yml file contains the full configuration of your Pipelines. As with all bitrise.yml files, first you need to define the format version and the project type.

title: Defining Pipelines, Steps, and Workflows
body:
---
format_version: '8'
default_step_lib_source: 
project_type: android

title: Defining Pipelines, Steps, and Workflows
body: This is a bare minimum bitrise.yml configuration. To define your Pipelines, you will need to use the pipelines attribute.

title: Defining Pipelines, Steps, and Workflows
Defining Pipelines, Steps, and Workflows
body: In this example, we have a Pipeline called pipeline-successful, with three Stages that will run consecutively. This means that if stage-successful-1 finishes successfully, stage-successful-2 starts. If any of the Stages fail, the subsequent Stage will not start: instead, the Pipeline will be aborted and marked as failed.

title: Defining Pipelines, Steps, and Workflows
body: Each Stage has to be defined separately under the stages attribute. Defining a Stage means specifying the Workflows that are part of the Stage.

title: Defining Pipelines, Steps, and Workflows
Defining Pipelines, Steps, and Workflows
body: In this example, the Stages run the test-1, build-1, build-2, deploy-1, and deploy-2 Workflows.

title: Configuring Pipeline triggers
body: To set up automatic build triggers, you need a trigger map. The trigger map defines what code events should trigger builds. In a Pipeline configuration, you need to specify the Pipeline that should be triggered by certain code events, such as pushes, pull requests and tags.

title: Configuring Pipeline triggers
body: Configuring Pipeline triggers using the Workflow Editor

title: Configuring Pipeline triggers
body: This example focuses on configuring Pipeline triggers using bitrise.yml, but the same configuration can be achieved from the Workflow Editor's Triggers tab.

title: Configuring Pipeline triggers
body:
trigger_map:
- push_branch: "pipe"
  pipeline: pipeline-successful

title: Configuring Pipeline triggers
body: In this example, a code push to the pipe branch of the app’s repository triggers the pipeline-successful Pipeline. In a similar way, you can configure triggers for any code events: you just have to specify the code event, the branch or tag name, and the respective Pipeline. You can use the following attributes:

title: Configuring Pipeline triggers
body: push_branch: A code push to the specified branch triggers the specified Pipeline.

title: Configuring Pipeline triggers
body: pull_request_source_branch: A pull request opened from the specified branch triggers the specified Pipeline.

title: Configuring Pipeline triggers
body: tag: A commit with the specified tag on it triggers the specified Pipeline.

title: Configuring Pipeline triggers
body: Here’s an example of a fully configured Pipeline, including a trigger map:

title: Configuring Pipeline triggers
body:
---
format_version: '11'
default_step_lib_source: https://github.com/bitrise-io/bitrise-steplib.git
project_type: android
trigger_map:
- push_branch: "*"
 pipeline: pipeline-successful
pipelines:
 pipeline-successful:
 stages:
 - stage-successful-1: {}
 - stage-successful-2: {}
 - stage-successful-3: {}
stages:
 stage-successful-1:
 workflows:
 - successful-20s: {}
 stage-successful-2:
 workflows:
 - successful-20s: {}
 - successful-30s: {}
 stage-successful-3:
 workflows:
 - successful-30s: {}
 - successful-20s: {}
workflows:
 successful-20s:
 steps:
 - script@1:
 title: Print secret1
 inputs:
 - content: |-
 #!/usr/bin/env bash
 set -ex 
 echo $secret1
 - script@1:
 title: Print all env vars
 inputs:
 - content: |-
 #!/usr/bin/env bash
 set -ex 
 printenv
 - script@1:
 title: Wait 20 seconds
 inputs:
 - content: |-
 #!/usr/bin/env bash
 set -ex
 sleep 20
 successful-30s:
 steps:
 - script@1:
 title: Wait 30 seconds
 inputs:
 - content: |-
 #!/usr/bin/env bash
 set -ex
 sleep 30

title: Configuring a Stage to always run
body: By default, if a Stage fails - because one of its Workflows failed -, any other subsequent Stages of the Pipeline will not run. However, you can configure your Pipeline to run certain Stages no matter what.

title: Configuring a Stage to always run
body: To do so, you just need to set the should_always_run attribute of the Stage to true:

title: Configuring a Stage to always run
Configuring a Stage to always run
body: In the example above, the Stage called stage-always-run-successful-1 will always run, regardless of the status of previous Stages. The only way these Stages will not run is if the Pipeline is aborted by the user.

title: Aborting the Workflows of a failed Stage
body: By default, if a Workflow in a particular Stage fails, the other Workflows in the same Stage aren’t automatically aborted: these Workflows will run but the next Stage won’t start. However, you can change this behavior to immediately and automatically abort all other Workflows in the same Stage.

title: Aborting the Workflows of a failed Stage
body: To do so, you need to set the abort_on_fail attribute to true:

title: Aborting the Workflows of a failed Stage
Using artifacts from different Stages
body: You might have Workflows that rely on artifacts generated by Workflows in previous Stages. To be able to use them during your subsequent Workflows, you must:

title: Using artifacts from different Stages
body: Specify files to share between Stages.

title: Using artifacts from different Stages
body: Use the Pull Pipeline intermediate files Step.

title: Specifying files to share between Stages
body: You can use the Deploy to Bitrise.io - Apps, Logs, Artifacts Step to push files and directories as intermediate files intended to be used by subsequent Workflows. To do so:

title: Specifying files to share between Stages
body: Add the Deploy to Bitrise.io - Apps, Logs, Artifacts Step to your Workflow (typically to the end of the Workflow) that generates a build artifact.

title: Specifying files to share between Stages
Specifying files to share between Stages
body: Configure the Step’s Files to share between pipeline stages input under the Pipeline Intermediate File Sharing category.

title: Specifying files to share between Stages
body: When you are configuring the Files to share between pipeline stages input, the value you add must be a newline-separated list of colon-separated items using the following structure:

title: Specifying files to share between Stages
body: <file_or_directory_path>:<environment_variable_key>

title: Specifying files to share between Stages
body: file_or_directory_path: is the local file path of the file or directory you want to share with subsequent Stage Workflows.

title: Specifying files to share between Stages
body: Sharing directories

title: Specifying files to share between Stages
body: Directories are archived and uploaded as a single file, but the Pull Pipeline intermediate files Step will extract such archives automatically.

title: Specifying files to share between Stages
body: environment_variable_key: is the environment variable key to be assigned to the given item. This environment variable will hold the local file path of the item after downloaded by the Pull Pipeline intermediate files Step.

title: Specifying files to share between Stages
body: Using environment variable keys

title: Specifying files to share between Stages
body: You don't have to use the default environment variable keys, in fact you can assign any custom environment variable key you want.

title: Specifying files to share between Stages
body: For example, "$BITRISE_IPA_PATH:BITRISE_APP_STORE_IPA_PATH"

title: Specifying files to share between Stages
body: If you want to use the default environment variable keys, you can use a shorthand syntax.

title: Specifying files to share between Stages
body: For example, you can use "BITRISE_TEST_BUNDLE_PATH" instead of "$BITRISE_TEST_BUNDLE_PATH:BITRISE_TEST_BUNDLE_PATH"

title: Specifying files to share between Stages
body: Let's look at an example!

title: Specifying files to share between Stages
body: If you would like to share the directory which contains the build test files ($BITRISE_TEST_BUNDLE_PATH) generated by the xcode-build-for-test Step and keep its default key, and the IPA file ($BITRISE_IPA_PATH) generated by the xcode-archive Step and assign a custom environment variable key, you would need to use the following structure:

title: Specifying files to share between Stages
body:
steps:
 ...
 - deploy-to-bitrise-io@2:
 inputs:
 - pipeline_intermediate_files: |-
 "BITRISE_TEST_BUNDLE_PATH"
 "$BITRISE_IPA_PATH:BITRISE_APP_STORE_IPA_PATH"

title: Using the Pull Pipeline intermediate files Step
body: If you have Workflows, which require access to artifacts generated by Workflows in previous Stages, you can use the Pull Pipeline intermediate files Step:

title: Using the Pull Pipeline intermediate files Step
body: Add the Pull Pipeline intermediate files Step to your Workflow (typically at the beginning of the Workflow, or before any Step that would rely on the shared files):

title: Using the Pull Pipeline intermediate files Step
body:
steps:
 - pull-intermediate-files@1: {}

title: Using the Pull Pipeline intermediate files Step
body: Use the artifact_sources input to specify a set of Stages and Workflows. The input’s syntax is: {stage-name}.{workflow-name}:

title: Using the Pull Pipeline intermediate files Step
body:
steps:
 - pull-intermediate-files@1:
 inputs:
 - artifact_sources: stage-1\..*

title: Using the Pull Pipeline intermediate files Step
body: In the example above, we’re pulling all artifacts from all Workflows in the Stage called stage-1.

title: Using the Pull Pipeline intermediate files Step
body: Setting specific Workflows and using wildcards

title: Using the Pull Pipeline intermediate files Step
body: You can set specific Workflows to pull artifacts from them or use wildcards in other ways:

title: Using the Pull Pipeline intermediate files Step
body: stage1.workflow1 - Gets the artifacts from the stage1's workflow1.

title: Using the Pull Pipeline intermediate files Step
body: stage1\..* - Gets all artifacts from the stage1's Workflows.

title: Using the Pull Pipeline intermediate files Step
body: .*\.workflow1 - Gets workflow1s' artifacts from all Stages.

title: Using the Pull Pipeline intermediate files Step
body: .* - Gets every generated artifact in the Pipeline.

title: Using the Pull Pipeline intermediate files Step
body: When the Step finishes, your files and directories specified via the Deploy to Bitrise.io - Apps, Logs, Artifacts Step should now be restored.

title: Using the Pull Pipeline intermediate files Step
body: For more information and details, check out the Step repository.

title: Sharing Env Vars between Pipeline Stages
body: You can share Env Vars between Stages by creating an artifact with the help of a Script Step and sharing that artifact as a Pipeline intermediate file. For more information, check out Using artifacts from different Stages.

title: Sharing Env Vars between Pipeline Stages
body: Here is a bitrise.yml example:

title: Sharing Env Vars between Pipeline Stages
body:
pipelines:
 share_env_vars:
 stages:
 - pub: {}
 - sub: {}
stages:
 pub:
 workflows:
 - share_env_var_publish: {}
 sub: 
 workflows:
 - share_env_var_receive: {}
workflows:
 share_env_var_publish:
 steps:
 - script@1:
 inputs:
 - content: |
 #!/usr/bin/env bash
 set -e
 set -x
 touch vars.txt
 echo "FIRST=1" >> vars.txt
 echo "SECOND=2" >> vars.txt
 title: Make Env Var File
 - deploy-to-bitrise-io@2:
 inputs:
 - pipeline_intermediate_files: vars.txt:ENV_VARS_FILEPATH
 share_env_var_receive:
 steps:
 - pull-intermediate-files@1: {}
 - script@1:
 inputs:
 - content: |
 #!/usr/bin/env bash
 set -e
 set -x
 while IFS='=' read -r k v; do
 envman add --key k --value $v
 done < "$ENV_VARS_FILEPATH"

title: Running a Pipeline
body: There are two ways to start a Pipeline:

title: Running a Pipeline
body: Trigger the Pipeline automatically.

title: Running a Pipeline
body: Start the Pipeline manually.

title: Running a Pipeline
body: To trigger the Pipeline automatically, you just need to configure triggers as described in Configuring Pipeline triggers.

title: Running a Pipeline
body: To start a Pipeline manually:

title: Running a Pipeline
body: Open the app on Bitrise.

title: Running a Pipeline
body: Go to the Builds tab.

title: Running a Pipeline
body: Click Start/Schedule a Build.

title: Running a Pipeline
body: Scroll down to the Workflow, Pipeline dropdown menu.

title: Running a Pipeline
body: Select the Pipeline you want to run.

title: Running a Pipeline
body: Click Start Build.

title: Running a Pipeline
body: Read more about starting builds manually.

title: Checking your Pipelines
body: You can find your Pipelines on the Dashboard. Your apps’ builds will be marked either as standalone or as Pipeline. Click on a Pipeline build to take you to the Pipeline details page.

title: Checking your Pipelines
body: On the Pipeline details page, you can see the Stages of the Pipeline, as well as the Workflows that make up the Stages and their status. You can also find all the artifacts generated by a Pipeline.

title: Checking the Workflows of a Pipeline
body: On the Workflows tab of the Pipeline build page, you can see all the individual Workflows that make up the Pipeline, with their status. To get to the page and check any particular Workflow:

title: Checking the Workflows of a Pipeline
body: Open your app on Bitrise.

title: Checking the Workflows of a Pipeline
body: Go to the Builds tab.

title: Checking the Workflows of a Pipeline
body: Find a Pipeline build and select it. Pipeline builds are marked with (pipeline).

title: Checking the Workflows of a Pipeline
body: On the Pipeline build page, go to the Workflows tab.

title: Checking the Workflows of a Pipeline
body: Click any Workflow that you want to check.

title: Checking the Workflows of a Pipeline
body: Checking the Workflows of a Pipeline using GitHub checks

title: Checking the Workflows of a Pipeline
body: You can check the details of any Workflow of your Pipeline directly from GitHub Checks: simply click on the Workflow in the Pipeline’s summary.

title: Checking the artifacts of a Pipeline
body: Like any build, Pipelines can generate build artifacts. All build artifacts generated by the Workflows of a Pipeline can be found on the Artifacts tab of the Pipeline details page.

title: Checking the artifacts of a Pipeline
body: Open your app on Bitrise.

title: Checking the artifacts of a Pipeline
body: Go to the Builds tab.

title: Checking the artifacts of a Pipeline
body: Find a Pipeline build and select it. Pipeline builds are marked with (pipeline).

title: Checking the artifacts of a Pipeline
body: On the Pipeline build page, go to the Artifacts tab.

title: Checking the artifacts of a Pipeline
body: Click any Workflow that you want to check.

title: Rebuilding a failed Pipeline
body: When a Pipeline build fails you have two options:

title: Rebuilding a failed Pipeline
body: Rebuild unsuccessful Workflows.

title: Rebuilding a failed Pipeline
body: Rebuild the entire Pipeline.

title: Rebuilding unsuccessful Workflows
body: When you have a failed or aborted Workflow in your Pipeline build, you can opt to modify that failed or aborted Workflow and rebuild it and subsequent Workflows without the need to rebuild your entire Pipeline. The new attempt will start from the first failed or aborted Workflow. If that Workflow is successful this time, the build will continue with subsequent Workflows.

title: Rebuilding unsuccessful Workflows
body: Stages with always run enabled

title: Rebuilding unsuccessful Workflows
body: This new attempt will trigger a Stage with always run enabled again, if that stage comes after the first failed or aborted Workflow of a Pipeline.

title: Rebuilding unsuccessful Workflows
body: This can be great if you have one or more failed or aborted Workflows in your Pipeline and you don’t want to rebuild the entire Pipeline.

title: Rebuilding unsuccessful Workflows
body: These are examples of how you can modify your Workflows in a Pipeline build:

title: Rebuilding unsuccessful Workflows
body: Add a new Step to a Workflow.

title: Rebuilding unsuccessful Workflows
body: Remove a Step from a Workflow.

title: Rebuilding unsuccessful Workflows
body: Update a Step in a Workflow.

title: Rebuilding unsuccessful Workflows
body: Change Step input orders in a Workflow.

title: Rebuilding unsuccessful Workflows
body: Change Step orders in a Workflow.

title: Rebuilding unsuccessful Workflows in a Pipeline build
body: You can use the Rebuild unsuccessful Workflows action to partially rebuild a Pipeline.

title: Rebuilding unsuccessful Workflows in a Pipeline build
body: To use the Rebuild unsuccessful Workflows action:

title: Rebuilding unsuccessful Workflows in a Pipeline build
body: Open your app on Bitrise.

title: Rebuilding unsuccessful Workflows in a Pipeline build
body: Select the Pipeline build you would like to rebuild.

title: Rebuilding unsuccessful Workflows in a Pipeline build
body: On the top right, click on the Rebuild drop-down menu.

title: Rebuilding unsuccessful Workflows in a Pipeline build
body: Select Rebuild unsuccessful Workflows.

title: Rebuilding unsuccessful Workflows in a Pipeline build
body: Rebuild unsuccessful Workflows action limitations

title: Rebuilding unsuccessful Workflows in a Pipeline build
body: Some of the Build Pipeline configurations make it impossible to use the Rebuild unsuccessful Workflows action. See Limitations of the Rebuild unsuccessful Workflows action for more information.

title: Limitations of the Rebuild unsuccessful Workflows action
body: Some of the Build Pipeline configurations make it impossible to use the Rebuild unsuccessful Workflows action. In this case, you still have the option to Rebuild the entire Pipeline with the new configuration.

title: Limitations of the Rebuild unsuccessful Workflows action
body: You will not be able to use Rebuild unsuccessful Workflows action, if you:

title: Limitations of the Rebuild unsuccessful Workflows action
body: Remove a Stage from the Pipeline build.

title: Limitations of the Rebuild unsuccessful Workflows action
body: Add a new Stage to the Pipeline build.

title: Limitations of the Rebuild unsuccessful Workflows action
body: Add a new Workflow to a Stage.

title: Limitations of the Rebuild unsuccessful Workflows action
body: Remove a Workflow from a Stage.

title: Limitations of the Rebuild unsuccessful Workflows action
body: Created the initial Pipeline build more than 30 days ago.

title: Rebuilding entire Pipelines
body: The Rebuild entire Pipeline action can be useful, when you want to create a new Pipeline build with a new build number, or when you changed something in your BuIld Pipeline configuration, which makes it impossible to use the Rebuild unsuccessful Workflows action.

title: Rebuilding entire Pipelines
body: When you have a failed or aborted Workflow during a Build Pipeline run, you can rebuild the entire Pipeline which will create a new Build Pipeline build, and start the Pipeline from the first Stage

title: Rebuilding entire Pipelines
body: To use the Rebuild entire Pipeline action:

title: Rebuilding entire Pipelines
body: Open your app on Bitrise.

title: Rebuilding entire Pipelines
body: Select the Pipeline build you would like to rebuild.

title: Rebuilding entire Pipelines
body: On the top right, click on the Rebuild drop-down menu.

title: Rebuilding entire Pipelines
body: Select Rebuild entire Pipeline.

title: Pipeline Management FAQ
body: Can I build my Pipelines on the Workflow tab of the Workflow Editor?

title: Pipeline Management FAQ
body: No, unfortunately, as of right now, you have to edit the bitrise.yml file.

title: Pipeline Management FAQ
body: Can I use Pipelines if I store my bitrise.yml file in my own repository?

title: Pipeline Management FAQ
body: Yes, absolutely. It makes no difference to Pipelines.

title: Pipeline Management FAQ
body: How can I set the stack for my Pipeline?

title: Pipeline Management FAQ
body: In the current version, you can set the default stack for your app, or you can set Workflow-specific stacks, just like with standalone builds.

title: Pipeline Management FAQ
body: How can I use Environment Variables with a Pipeline?

title: Pipeline Management FAQ
body: You can keep using app-level and Workflow-level Environment Variables.

title: Pipeline Management FAQ
body: Can I rerun a failed Pipeline?

title: Pipeline Management FAQ
body: Yes. Go to the Pipeline details page, and click the Rerun button. From there you have the option to rerun failed and subsequent Workflows or to rerun the entire Pipeline. For more information, see Rebuild a failed Pipeline.

title: Pipeline Management FAQ
body: Does the Rolling Builds feature work on Pipelines?

title: Pipeline Management FAQ
body: Yes! You don’t have to worry about wasting credits with builds that are no longer necessary because of new commits or pull requests.

title: Known issues and limitations of the Pipelines beta
body: Build Pipelines is currently in the beta phase. This means that not all planned functions are available. We will introduce several new features later to make sure we cover as many use cases as possible. For now, we have the following issues and limitations.

title: No visual Pipeline editor
body: In the current iteration, Build Pipelines can be set up and configured in YAML, as detailed in the guide. Visual UI is part of future iterations.

title: Less efficient file management and data transfer
body: Currently, Google Cloud Storage is used for file sharing for all builds. In a future iteration, we plan to use local storage in the Mac datacenters too to keep the data close to the build VMs regardless of the stack type.

title: Currently supported use cases for the Android platform
body: We have prepared some Pipeline recipes based on common Android use cases. These contain some of the most frequent tasks our users need to run. The examples include entire Workflows that can be copied and pasted for the most part.

title: (Android) Run UI tests in parallel on multiple devices or shards
body: (Android) Run UI tests in parallel on multiple devices or shards

title: Description
body: Running the UI (instrumentation) tests of a single module in parallel Workflows utilizing pipelines. You can run the tests in parallel by shards or by devices.

title: Description
body: The Pipeline contains two Stages that are run serially:

title: Description
body: build_for_ui_testing: This Stage executes a Workflow — also named build_for_ui_testing — that runs the android-build-for-ui-testing Step to build APKs for use in testing, and runs the deploy-to-bitrise-io Step to save those APKs for use in the later Stages. Performing this Stage separately from the actual testing allows for each test Stage to use these pre-built APKs rather than having to rebuild them for each test Stage.

title: Description
body: run_ui_tests_on_devices: This Stage executes three UI test Workflows in parallel — ui_test_on_phone, ui_test_on_tablet, ui_test_on_foldable — which use the android-instrumented-test Step to run the UI tests on the APKs built in the previous Workflow on each specific device type.

title: Instructions
body: Select the main branch to scan.

title: Instructions

title: Instructions
body: Enter app as the specified module.

title: Instructions
body: Enter debug as the specified variant.

title: Instructions
body: Continue through the prompts as normal — no changes are needed.

title: (Android) Running unit and UI tests in parallel

title: Description

title: Description

title: Description

title: Currently supported use cases for the iOS platform
body: We have prepared some Pipeline recipes based on common iOS use cases. These contain some of the most frequent tasks our users need to run.

title: (iOS) Run tests in parallel on multiple simulators
body: (iOS) Run tests in parallel on multiple simulators

title: Description
body: This example uses the sample-swift-project-with-parallel-ui-test iOS Open Source sample app, which has some example Unit and UI tests and uses Test Plans to group the tests.

title: Description
body: The example Pipeline config showcases how to run all the test cases of the project on different iOS simulators.

title: Description
body: run_tests_on_simulators Pipeline runs two Stages sequentially:

title: Description
body: build_tests stage that runs the build_tests Workflow. This Workflow git clones the sample project and runs the xcode-build-for-test Step to build the target and associated tests. The built test bundle is transferred to the next Stage (run_tests_on_simulators) via the deploy-to-bitrise-io Step.

title: Description
body: The build test bundle is compressed

title: Description
body: xcode-build-for-test Step compresses the built test bundle and moves the generated zip to the $BITRISE_DEPLOY_DIR. That directory’s content is deployed to the Workflow artifacts by default via the deploy-to-bitrise-io Step.

title: Description
body: Artifact file size limitation

title: Description
body: There is no limitation on the number of files deployed to Artifacts per build. There is a limitation, however, on the file size which is 2GB per file.

title: Description
body: run_tests_on_simulators Stage runs three Workflows in parallel: run_tests_iPad, run_tests_iPhone, and run_tests_iPod. Both of these Workflows use the new xcode-test-without-building Step, which executes the tests based on the previous stage built test bundle. The pre-built test bundle is pulled by the _pull_test_bundle utility Workflow.

title: Description

title: (iOS) Merging test results and deploying to the Test Reports add-on
body: (iOS) Merging test results and deploying to the Test Reports add-on

title: Description
body: Test Reports add-on is tied to Bitrise builds. To make all the test reports generated in different builds appear on a single page in the add-on, the reports must be merged and deployed in an additional build.

title: Description
body: This example uses the sample-swift-project-with-parallel-ui-test iOS Open Source sample app and extends the ‘Run iOS test groups in parallel’ example Pipeline config with merging and deploying test results.

title: Description
body: run_ui_tests and run_unit_tests Workflows are extended with a deploy-to-bitrise-io Step to make the generated test results available for the next Stage.

title: Description
body: run_tests_groups Pipeline is extended with a new Stage: deploy_test_results. This Stage runs the deploy_test_results Workflow:

title: Description
body: artifact-pull Step downloads all the zipped test results previously generated by Stage: run_tests_groups.

title: Description
body: script Step unzips each test result into a new test run directory within the Test Report add-on deploy dir and creates the related test-info.json file.

title: Description
body: deploy-to-bitrise-io Step deploys the merged test results.

title: Configuring build settings
body: The heart of your build is the bitrise.yml file. You can configure the Steps you use, the project type, the trigger map, and specify the app- and Workflow-level Env Vars.

title: Configuring build settings
body: You can configure and customize your builds extensively. Bitrise provides a multitude of options to make sure you can build your app exactly the way you want to.

title: Configuring build settings
body: The heart of your build configuration is the bitrise.yml file: this file contains the configuration of all the Workflows and Steps you use, it specifies the project type, the trigger map, and it contains the app- and Workflow-level Environment Variables you specified. You can store this file on bitrise.io or in your Git repository and you can access the bitrise.yml file of any previous build you ran.

title: Configuring build settings
body: You can configure notifications so that users are immediately notified when a build is finished.

title: Configuring build settings
body: If you don't want to run a build every time a commit is pushed or a pull request is opened, but rather only if certain files are changed, you can do that using the Selective builds feature.

title: Configuring build settings
body: If commits are frequently pushed to your repository, with each commit triggering a new build, you don't have to wait until each triggered build finishes before a new one can start. Use the Rolling builds feature to make sure you don't waste time!

title: Setting the stack for your builds
body: The build stack indicates the virtual machine version that Bitrise will use to run your build. You can set the stack for all your builds, or you can set Workflow-specific stacks, either in the Workflow Editor or in the bitrise.yml file.

title: Setting the stack for your builds
body: The build stack indicates the virtual machine version that we will use to run your build. You can set the stack for all your builds, or you can set Workflow-specific stacks.

title: Setting the stack in the Workflow Editor
body: The simplest way to configure the build stack is in the Workflow Editor. You can set both the default stack and Workflow-specific stacks.

title: Setting the default stack on the Stacks & Machines tab
body: The default stack of your app is the stack that is used if you haven't set a specific stack for a Workflow.

title: Setting the default stack on the Stacks & Machines tab
body: Project type

title: Setting the default stack on the Stacks & Machines tab
body: Note that if you change the project type on the app's Settings tab to a type that isn't compatible with your selected default stack, we'll automatically change the stack to a compatible one.

title: Setting the default stack on the Stacks & Machines tab
body: Open your app on Bitrise.

title: Setting the default stack on the Stacks & Machines tab
body: Click the Workflows button on the main page.

title: Setting the default stack on the Stacks & Machines tab
body: Go to the Stacks & Machines tab.

title: Setting the default stack on the Stacks & Machines tab
body: In the Default Stack section, open the dropdown menu and select the stack you need.

title: Setting the default stack on the Stacks & Machines tab
body: Click Save in the top right corner.

title: Setting a Workflow-specific stack on the Stacks & Machines tab
body: When you set a stack for a Workflow, that Workflow will always run on that stack, regardless of the default stack.

title: Setting a Workflow-specific stack on the Stacks & Machines tab
body: Open your app on Bitrise.

title: Setting a Workflow-specific stack on the Stacks & Machines tab
body: Click the Workflows button on the main page.

title: Setting a Workflow-specific stack on the Stacks & Machines tab
body: Go to the Stacks & Machines tab.

title: Setting a Workflow-specific stack on the Stacks & Machines tab
body: Scroll down to find the Workflow you need.

title: Setting a Workflow-specific stack on the Stacks & Machines tab
body: Select a stack.

title: Setting a Workflow-specific stack on the Stacks & Machines tab
body: Click Save in the top right corner.

title: Setting the machine type in the Workflow Editor
body: You can define the machine type you want to use for your build in the Workflow Editor. The available machine types depend on the type of stack you use: Table 1, “.

title: Setting the machine type in the Workflow Editor
body: To set the machine type:

title: Setting the machine type in the Workflow Editor
body: Open your app on Bitrise.

title: Setting the machine type in the Workflow Editor
body: Click the Workflows button on the main page.

title: Setting the machine type in the Workflow Editor
body: Go to the Stacks & Machines tab.

title: Setting the machine type in the Workflow Editor
body: In the Default Stack section, find the Machine type for the default stack section and choose a machine type.

title: Setting the machine type in the Workflow Editor
body: Optionally, choose a Workflow-specific machine type for any Workflow that has a Workflow-specific stack set.

title: Setting the stack in the bitrise.yml file
body: You can set both the default stack and Workflow-specific tasks in the bitrise.yml file of your app. Use the meta field with the appropriate stack ID:

title: Setting the stack in the bitrise.yml file
body:
meta:      
 bitrise.io:       
 stack: osx-xcode-13.1.x

title: Setting the stack in the bitrise.yml file
body: This is particularly useful if you keep your bitrise.yml file stored in your app's repository.

title: Setting the stack in the bitrise.yml file
body: Stack IDs

title: Setting the stack in the bitrise.yml file
body: An easy way to find the stack IDs is the System Reports page: the filenames without the .log extension are the stack IDs. Alternatively, you can set a stack in the Workflow Editor and then check out the ID on the bitrise.yml tab, by finding the meta field.

title: Setting the stack in the bitrise.yml file
body: The System Reports also show every pre-installed tool that is available on the stack.

title: Setting the default stack in the bitrise.yml
body: The default stack of your app is the stack that is used if you haven't set a specific stack for a Workflow.

title: Setting the default stack in the bitrise.yml
body: Open your app's bitrise.yml file.

title: Setting the default stack in the bitrise.yml
body: Add a meta entry outside the workflows property or at the end of your bitrise.yml file:

title: Setting the default stack in the bitrise.yml
body:
meta:      
 bitrise.io:       
 stack:

title: Setting the default stack in the bitrise.yml
body: Make sure you use double indentation.

title: Setting the default stack in the bitrise.yml
body: Add the stack ID.

title: Setting the default stack in the bitrise.yml
body: You can find the stack IDs on the system reports page: the filenames without the .log extension are the stack IDs.

title: Setting the default stack in the bitrise.yml
body:
meta:      
 bitrise.io:       
 stack: osx-xcode-13.1.x

title: Setting Workflow-specific stacks in the bitrise.yml
body: When you set a stack for a Workflow, that Workflow will always run on that stack, regardless of the default stack.

title: Setting Workflow-specific stacks in the bitrise.yml
body: Open your app's bitrise.yml file.

title: Setting Workflow-specific stacks in the bitrise.yml
body: Find the workflows property and find the name of the Workflow you need within.

title: Setting Workflow-specific stacks in the bitrise.yml
body: Add a meta entry under the Workflow itself:

title: Setting Workflow-specific stacks in the bitrise.yml
body:
workflows:
 deploy: 
 meta:      
 bitrise.io:       
 stack:

title: Setting Workflow-specific stacks in the bitrise.yml
body: Add the stack ID.

title: Setting Workflow-specific stacks in the bitrise.yml
body: You can find the stack IDs on the system reports page: the filenames without the .log extension are the stack IDs.

title: Setting Workflow-specific stacks in the bitrise.yml
body:
workflows:
 deploy: 
 meta:      
 bitrise.io:       
 stack: osx-xcode-13.1.x

title: Setting the machine type in the bitrise.yml file
body: You can also define the machine type you want to use for your build in the bitrise.yml of your app. Machine type refers to the hardware resources used in your build; for example, an Elite machine has more CPU cores and available RAM than a Standard machine.

title: Setting the machine type in the bitrise.yml file
body: To set the machine type in the bitrise.yml file, you need to use the machine_type_id attribute in a meta entry:

title: Setting the machine type in the bitrise.yml file
body: Available machine IDs

title: Setting the machine type in the bitrise.yml file
body: You can find the available machine type IDs here: Build machine types.

title: Setting the machine type in the bitrise.yml file
body: Open your app's bitrise.yml file.

title: Setting the machine type in the bitrise.yml file
body: Find the workflows property and find the name of the Workflow you need within.

title: Setting the machine type in the bitrise.yml file
body: Add a meta entry:

title: Setting the machine type in the bitrise.yml file
body:
# setting an 8-core Gen2 machine for an Xcode stack as the default machine type of the app:
meta:
 bitrise.io:
 machine_type_id: g2.8core
# setting a 12-core Gen2 machine as a Workflow-specific machine type
workflows:
 deploy: 
 meta: 
 bitrise.io: 
 machine_type_id: g2.12core

title: Managing an app's bitrise.yml file
body: The heart of your build is the bitrise.yml file. You can configure the Steps you use, the project type, the trigger map, and specify the app- and Workflow-level Env Vars.

title: Managing an app's bitrise.yml file
body: The bitrise.yml file is the heart of your Bitrise setup: it stores your entire build configuration for an app. It specifies your stack, the trigger map, and what Workflows and Steps are included. When you edit your Workflows on the graphical UI of our Workflow Editor, you actually modify the bitrise.yml file.

title: Managing an app's bitrise.yml file
body: YAML files size limitation

title: Managing an app's bitrise.yml file
body: Please note that the total, combined size of the bitrise.yml and the bitrise.secrets.yml file cannot exceed 400KB.

title: Managing an app's bitrise.yml file
body: There are two ways to manage the bitrise.yml file of your app:

title: Managing an app's bitrise.yml file
body: Keep the file in your Git repository: with this solution, you have full control over maintaining and versioning the bitrise.yml file.

title: Managing an app's bitrise.yml file
body: Keep it on bitrise.io: Bitrise will store your configuration, and you can access it any time on the website. With this solution, the configuration file is fully independent from your repository.

title: Managing an app's bitrise.yml file
body: You can switch between the two solutions at any time.

title: Managing an app's bitrise.yml file
body: bitrise.yml reference

title: Managing an app's bitrise.yml file
body: You can find detailed reference information about the bitrise.yml file in our relevant guide: Basics of bitrise.yml.

title: Storing the bitrise.yml file in your repository
body: Unfortunately, this feature is not yet supported for users who can't use the service credential user integration; for example, if the repository is is only accessible under a private IP subnet. There's a workaround, however: Storing the bitrise.yml in a privately hosted repository.

title: Storing the bitrise.yml file in your repository
body: This workaround works, for example, for GitHub Enterprise and Bitbucket Server users.

title: Storing the bitrise.yml file in your repository
body: When you store the bitrise.yml configuration file in your repository, the build process on Bitrise will use that file to run your builds. This means that:

title: Storing the bitrise.yml file in your repository
body: You have full control over versioning your configuration file.

title: Storing the bitrise.yml file in your repository
body: Every time you make a change to your Workflows or your trigger map, you must commit the changes to the file in the repository.

title: Storing the bitrise.yml file in your repository
body: You don’t need to create your own bitrise.yml file in advance: you can use the file stored on bitrise.io. Let's see how to store the bitrise.yml file in a repository that does not contain one yet.

title: Storing the bitrise.yml file in your repository
body: Multiple apps with the same repository

title: Storing the bitrise.yml file in your repository
body: You can only store a single bitrise.yml file in a given repository. Bitrise will look for the file in the root directory, and as such, currently there’s no way to include two in separate folders.

title: Storing the bitrise.yml file in your repository
body: If you have two or more Bitrise apps connected to the same repository, you can store all their Workflows in the same bitrise.yml file. Of course each Workflow must have a different name: you can’t have two primary Workflows in the same file, for example.

title: Storing the bitrise.yml file in your repository
body: Open the app on Bitrise and go to the Team tab.

title: Storing the bitrise.yml file in your repository
body: Check the Service credential user section. The service credential user must be a Bitrise user who has at least read access to the repository.

title: Storing the bitrise.yml file in your repository
body: Service credential integration

title: Storing the bitrise.yml file in your repository
body: Be aware that if your app uses a repository where the Service credential user integration is not supported - for example, the repository is only accessible under a private IP subnet -, the feature won’t work as the website can’t grab the bitrise.yml due to IP addressing limitations.

title: Storing the bitrise.yml file in your repository
body: Go to the Workflow tab.

body: Download the current bitrise.yml file.

This allows you to use such features as storing the bitrise.yml file in your own repository, or receiving build status updates from Bitrise: IP addresses for the Bitrise website.

title: Storing a bitrise.yml file on multiple branches in the repository
body: When you first add the bitrise.yml to your repository, it must be committed to the default branch. You can check out the app’s default branch on bitrise.io under the Settings tab.

title: Storing a bitrise.yml file on multiple branches in the repository
body: If you choose to store the bitrise.yml file in the repository, the default branch must have a bitrise.yml!

title: Storing a bitrise.yml file on multiple branches in the repository
body: However, once you did the initial configuration to set up using the bitrise.yml from your repository, you can store bitrise.yml files on other branches and use any of them to run builds. If you want to build a branch of your repository on Bitrise, you need to have a bitrise.yml file on that branch. And don’t forget that you always need to keep a bitrise.yml file on the default branch.

title: Storing a bitrise.yml file on multiple branches in the repository
body: Bitrise setup with bitrise.yml files on multiple branches

title: Storing a bitrise.yml file on multiple branches in the repository
body: Let’s say you have an app called FantasticApp. In FantasticApp’s Git repository, the default branch is called main. There is also a deploy branch.

title: Storing a bitrise.yml file on multiple branches in the repository
body: Any code push or pull request to main triggers a Workflow called main-workflow. Any code push or pull request to deploy triggers a Workflow called deploy-workflow.

title: Storing a bitrise.yml file on multiple branches in the repository
body: In the repository, there is a bitrise.yml file on both the main and the deploy branch, containing both Workflows. When making changes to the Workflows, the FantasticApp team commits the modified bitrise.yml file to both branches to ensure that their Workflows are up to date on both.

title: Moving the bitrise.yml file back to bitrise.io
body: The default setting is to store the bitrise.yml file on bitrise.io: when you add a new app, we automatically create a bitrise.yml file for you and it’s stored on our website. If this works for you, then you don’t need to change anything!

title: Moving the bitrise.yml file back to bitrise.io
body: If, however, you changed your storage settings to keep the configuration file in your repository, you can easily change it back any time to store the file on bitrise.io.

title: Moving the bitrise.yml file back to bitrise.io

title: Moving the bitrise.yml file back to bitrise.io
body: You can copy the content of the bitrise.yml file stored in the app’s repository.

title: Moving the bitrise.yml file back to bitrise.io
body: You can copy the last version of the bitrise.yml file that you used on bitrise.io.

title: Moving the bitrise.yml file back to bitrise.io
body: Click Update setting.

title: Moving the bitrise.yml file back to bitrise.io

title: Accessing a build's bitrise.yml file
body: You can access a build's bitrise.yml file by selecting a build from your app's Dashboard and selecting 'show bitrise.yml' from the bitrise.yml drop-down menu.

title: Accessing a build's bitrise.yml file
body: Once you ran a build on Bitrise, you can always check the bitrise.yml configuration the build used. You can download it, compare it to the current bitrise.yml file, and you can even replace the current configuration file with the build's configuration file.

title: Accessing a build's bitrise.yml file
body: To access a build's configuration file:

title: Accessing a build's bitrise.yml file
body: Select an application on your Dashboard and select one of its builds.

title: Accessing a build's bitrise.yml file
body: Select bitrise.yml on the right, above the build status card.

title: Accessing a build's bitrise.yml file
body: In the dropdown menu, select Show bitrise.yml.

title: Checking changes in the bitrise.yml file
body: Once you’ve clicked Show bitrise.yml, you will see the BUILD’S BITRISE YML pop-up window displaying your builds’ configuration details. If the build’s bitrise.yml content differs from the current build’s bitrise.yml, you will see two editors displayed side-by-side in the BITRISE.YML CHANGES pop-up window. The differences between the builds are highlighted in the following colors:

title: Checking changes in the bitrise.yml file
body: Green means added content.

title: Checking changes in the bitrise.yml file
body: Blue means modified content.

title: Checking changes in the bitrise.yml file
body: Red means deleted content.

title: Restoring the current bitrise.yml to the build's bitrise.yml
body: You can always change the current bitrise.yml configuration to the configuration of one of your app's previous builds. To do so:

title: Restoring the current bitrise.yml to the build's bitrise.yml
body: Select an application on your Dashboard and select one of its builds.

title: Restoring the current bitrise.yml to the build's bitrise.yml
body: Select bitrise.yml on the right, above the build status card.

title: Restoring the current bitrise.yml to the build's bitrise.yml
body: In the dropdown menu, select Show bitrise.yml.

title: Restoring the current bitrise.yml to the build's bitrise.yml
body: In the BITRISE.YML CHANGES pop-up window, click the Restore button.

title: Restoring the current bitrise.yml to the build's bitrise.yml
body: Hit OK in the Are you sure? pop-up window to confirm and override the current bitrise.yml.

title: Deleting a build's bitrise.yml file
body: If you wish, you can simply delete a build’s bitrise.yml file. But please note that this action cannot be undone: nobody will be able to view that particular build’s bitrise.yml file once you delete it.

title: Deleting a build's bitrise.yml file
body: Select an application on your Dashboard and select one of its builds.

title: Deleting a build's bitrise.yml file
body: Select bitrise.yml on the right, above the build status card.

title: Deleting a build's bitrise.yml file
body: In the dropdown menu, select Delete bitrise.yml.

title: Deleting a build's bitrise.yml file
body: In the confirmation window, click Yes.

title: Selective builds
body: The Selective builds setting provides change detection for your builds. Enabling it allows you to only trigger a build of an app if certain files or folders have been modified.

title: Selective builds
body: The Selective builds setting provides change detection for your builds. Enabling it allows you to only trigger a build of an app if certain files or folders have been modified.

title: Selective builds
body: You may want to use this setting if:

title: Selective builds
body: You have a monorepo; that is, you build multiple apps from a single repository.

title: Selective builds
body: Multiple apps share common files in your repository.

title: Selective builds
body: Selective Builds with non-Github projects

title: Selective builds
body: The current version of our Selective Builds feature only works with GitHub projects. If your repository is hosted by another Git hosting service, the option will not be available.

title: Selective builds
body: Using the Selective builds feature

title: Selective builds
body: Let's say you want to make sure that a commit to your app's repository triggers a Bitrise build only if the mycode.go file on the develop branch is modified in the commit.

title: Selective builds
body: In this example, you have a branch called develop.

title: Selective builds
body: You have a trigger that starts a build every time a code push happens on the develop branch.

title: Selective builds
body: In the selective builds feature, you specified the mycode.go file in the input field.

title: Selective builds
body: If you make a commit on the develop branch that modifies the mycode.go file, Bitrise will trigger a build. If your commit doesn't modify the file in any way, Bitrise will not trigger a build.

title: Selective builds
body: To configure selective builds:

title: Selective builds
body: Admin access only

title: Selective builds
body: Only users with the role of admin on the app's team can access all functions of the App Settings page of an app.

title: Selective builds
body: Open your app on Bitrise.

title: Selective builds
body: On the main page of the app, click on the App Settings icon: .

title: Selective builds
body: Make sure the appropriate service credential user is set on the Integrations page.

title: Selective builds
body: This user must have admin right for the GitHub repository of the project.

title: Selective builds
body: Click on your app on your Dashboard.

title: Selective builds
body: On the left, select Builds.

title: Selective builds
body: Find the Selective builds section.

title: Selective builds
body: Click the Add path button.

title: Selective builds
body: Can't find the button?

title: Selective builds
body: If you can't find the button - like in the screenshot above -, it is because of two possible reasons:

title: Selective builds
body: The app's repository isn't hosted on GitHub.

title: Selective builds
body: The service credential user isn't set correctly or doesn't have admin rights to the repo.

title: Selective builds
body: In the pop-up window, set the paths you need.

title: Selective builds
body: You can add one path at a time.

title: Using patterns in the file name or file path
body: You do not need to set an exact file name or file path for the Selective builds feature: you can set patterns. Using regular expressions is not supported but the pattern may contain certain metacharacters:

title: Using patterns in the file name or file path
body: *: Matches all files.

title: Using patterns in the file name or file path
body: a*: Matches all files beginning with a.

title: Using patterns in the file name or file path
body: *a: Matches all files ending with a.

title: Using patterns in the file name or file path
body: *a*: Matches all files that have a in them (including at the beginning or end).

title: Using patterns in the file name or file path
body: **: Matches directories recursively.

title: Using patterns in the file name or file path
body: ?: Matches any one character.

title: Using patterns in the file name or file path
body: \: Escapes the next metacharacter.

title: Using patterns in the file name or file path
body: [set]: Matches any one character in set.

title: Rolling builds
body: With the rolling builds feature, you can configure Bitrise to automatically abort on-hold builds or already running builds if another build is triggered on the same branch.

title: Rolling builds
body: You can cancel running builds or builds on hold - no need to abort them manually! If you turn on the Rolling Builds feature, the previous builds of your app can be automatically aborted once a new one is started.

title: Rolling builds
body: Please note that manual and scheduled builds are also cancelled if you start a new build with the Rolling builds option enabled.

title: Rolling builds
body: When is a build aborted?

title: Rolling builds
body: If you trigger a build on a branch where a build is already running, the running build is aborted only if it runs the same Workflow.

title: Rolling builds
body: For example, if you trigger a build on the master branch of your repository with the deploy Workflow, it will NOT cancel a build running on the same master branch with the primary Workflow.

title: Rolling builds
body: You can also set which types of triggered builds you wish to abort. Let’s see how!

title: Rolling builds
body: Admin access only

title: Rolling builds
body: Only users with the role of admin on the app's team can access all functions of the App Settings page of an app.

title: Rolling builds
body: Open your app on Bitrise.

title: Rolling builds
body: On the main page of the app, click on the App Settings icon: .

title: Rolling builds
body: On the left, select Builds.

title: Rolling builds
body: Find the Rolling builds section.

title: Rolling builds
body: Select the type(s) of builds you wish to abort when a new build is started.

title: Rolling builds
body: Enabling the options will do the following:

title: Rolling builds
body: Enabled for Pull Requests: will cancel all previous builds still on-hold for Pull Requests and all related Pushes. Running builds will not be canceled unless Running builds are aborted is also enabled.

title: Rolling builds
body: Enabled for Pushes: will cancel all previous builds still on-hold for Pushes to the same branch. Running builds will not be canceled unless Running builds are aborted is also enabled.

title: Rolling builds
body: Running builds are aborted: will also auto-cancel running builds in addition to on-hold ones.

title: Rolling builds
body: All done! From now on, you don’t have to wait for a triggered build to finish if you do not need it!

title: Configuring email notifications
body: Bitrise's built-in email notification system sends emails about builds to every user who is assigned to work on an application. They are sent when a build is finished and they can be configured for both successful and failed builds.

title: Configuring email notifications
body: Notifications are updates about your activity on Bitrise. Usually, they concern the state of your builds but you can receive notifications about a lot of different things.

title: Configuring email notifications
body: Our built-in email notification system sends emails about builds to every user who is assigned to work on an application. They are sent when a build is finished and they can be configured for both successful and failed builds.

title: Configuring email notifications
body: Watching the app

title: Configuring email notifications
body: To receive automatic email messages, you need to be watching the app. If you turn off watching, you won’t receive the automated emails.

title: Configuring email notifications
body: Email notifications are automatically set up for all applications when first creating them but you can modify these notification settings at any time: Changing your email notification settings

title: Configuring email notifications
body: The alternative solution is to send emails via a dedicated Step. This allows for far more customization regarding the notifications: Sending emails with a Step

title: Watching an app
body: Watching an app means getting email notifications for that app. This is the default setting for every app you create or you are invited to. Turning off watching the app means you will NO LONGER GET AUTOMATIC NOTIFICATIONS.

title: Watching an app
body: To toggle the feature, go to your Dashboard and open the app you want to watch or unwatch. On the top right, you will see a button with the label Watching if you are watching the app currently. If not, the button will show Watch. Toggle it.

title: Changing your email notification settings
body: Email notifications are automatically set up for all applications when first creating them. There are three possible settings for both successful builds and failed builds:

title: Changing your email notification settings
body: Always. This is the default setting for failed builds.

title: Changing your email notification settings
body: Never.

title: Changing your email notification settings
body: Send email when build status changes on the same branch. This is the default setting for successful builds. This means that if build #1 and build #2 both succeeded, you will not get a notification about build #2. However, if build #3 fails and then build #4 succeeds again, you will be notified.

title: Changing your email notification settings
body: You can change your email notification settings at any time - you can even completely disable them.

title: Changing your email notification settings
body: Admin access only

title: Changing your email notification settings
body: Only users with the role of admin on the app's team can access all functions of the App Settings page of an app.

title: Changing your email notification settings
body: Open your app on Bitrise.

title: Changing your email notification settings
body: On the main page of the app, click on the App Settings icon: .

title: Changing your email notification settings
body: On the left, select Notifications.

title: Changing your email notification settings
body: Scroll down to email notifications.

title: Changing your email notification settings
body: Select the settings you need for both successful and failed builds from the appropriate dropdown menu.

title: Changing your email notification settings
body: For example, if you want to disable receiving notifications, set both options to Never.

title: Sending emails with a Step
body: The Send Email with Mailgun Step can send emails to any email address with customized updates, in either HTML or plain text format. You can use environment variables to send information, as well as attach files to the emails.

title: Sending emails with a Step
body: To use the Step, you need:

title: Sending emails with a Step
body: A Mailgun account.

title: Sending emails with a Step
body: A Mailgun API key.

title: Sending emails with a Step
body: Your Mailgun domain name.

title: Sending emails with a Step
body: Make sure the Step runs in every build!

title: Sending emails with a Step
body: If you use the Send Email with Mailgun Step in your workflow, make sure that it is always set to run even if the previous Step failed! This is the default setting of the Step. If you change it, you will not receive emails if your builds fail.

title: Sending emails with a Step
body: Create a Secret Environment Variable that holds your Mailgun API key.

title: Sending emails with a Step
body: We recommend naming the key $MAILGUN_API_KEY. This is the default value of the Step’s relevant input.

title: Sending emails with a Step
body: Create a Secret Environment Variable that holds your Mailgun domain.

title: Sending emails with a Step
body: We recommend naming the key $MAILGUN_DOMAIN. This is the default value of the Step’s relevant input.

title: Sending emails with a Step
body: Add the Send Email with Mailgun Step to the end of your workflow.

title: Sending emails with a Step
body: Find the Send To emails input of the Step. Click on the input and then click Select secret variable.

title: Sending emails with a Step
body: Create a new Secret Environment Variable that contains the list of the email addresses.

title: Sending emails with a Step
body: You can choose any key you want. The addresses should be separated by a comma.

title: Sending emails with a Step
body: Set the email subject, and the two potential email messages: one for a successful build, one for a failed build.

title: Sending emails with a Step
body: You can insert environment variables to any of the inputs (the subject and the messages). In the email, the values of the variables will be displayed.

title: Sending emails with a Step
body: The default messages will send the name of the app, the number of the build and whether the build succeeded or failed.

title: Sending emails with a Step
body: Attach files, if necessary: the File attachments input accepts a file path or an environment variable as input.

title: Sending emails with a Step
body: Multiple files can be attached: separate their paths with commas.

title: Sending emails with a Step
body: Run a build - and check your emails!

title: Configuring Slack integration
body: You can integrate Slack to your app on Bitrise by adding the "Send a Slack message" Step to your app's Workflow.

title: Configuring Slack integration
body: Bitrise supports Slack integration, of course - and it’s quite easy to set it up. Send Slack messages to individual users, groups or channels; customize the messages, include attachments, and link buttons that will take the users to the build page.

title: Configuring Slack integration
body: To use our dedicated Step, you need either a Slack webhook URL or a Slack API token for a Slack bot user.

title: Configuring Slack integration
body: Make sure that the Step runs in every build!

title: Configuring Slack integration
body: If you use the Send a Slack message Step in your Workflow, make sure that it is always set to run even if the previous Step failed! This is the default setting of the Step. If you change it, messages won’t be sent if the build fails.

title: Configuring Slack integration
body: Add the Send a Slack message Step to your Workflow.

title: Configuring Slack integration
body: Find either the Slack Webhook URL or the Slack API token input. Click on the input and then click Select secret variable.

title: Configuring Slack integration
body: Create a new Secret Environment Variable that stores your webhook URL or your Slack API token.

title: Configuring Slack integration
body: You can choose any key you want.

title: Configuring Slack integration
body: Customize your Slack message with the relevant inputs of the Step.

title: Configuring Slack integration
body: There are several options, including but not limited to:

title: Configuring Slack integration
body: Setting the target channel, group or username: this can be a name or an encoded ID.

title: Configuring Slack integration
body: The text of the message to send.

title: Configuring Slack integration
body: The bot’s username for the message

title: Configuring Slack integration
body: The message’s color

title: Configuring Slack integration
body: File attachment

title: Configuring Slack integration
body: Link buttons attached to the message

title: Configuring Slack integration
body: Check out all the inputs in the Workflow Editor to see all the ways in which you can customize your Slack messages.

title: Setting your Git credentials on build machines
body: If you want to push back any commits to your own Git repo from Bitrise while running your build, you can set up your Git credentials on build machines.

title: Setting your Git credentials on build machines
body: The default Git username and user email address on our stacks are the following:

title: Setting your Git credentials on build machines
body:
git config --global user.email "please-set-your-email@bitrise.io"
git config --global user.name "J. Doe (https://devcenter.bitrise.io/builds/setting-your-git-credentials-on-build-machines/)"

title: Setting your Git credentials on build machines
body: If you want to push back (git push) any commits to your own repo from Bitrise while running your build, you have to set your own username and the email address. There are three ways to achieve this:

title: Setting your Git credentials on build machines
body: You can use a custom Script Step to set your credentials with the git config command.

title: Setting your Git credentials on build machines
body: You can set your Git credentials as Env Vars.

title: Setting your Git credentials on build machines
body: You can use the Set Git Credentials Step.

title: Setting your Git credentials using Env Vars
body: Git has various basic Environmental Variables similar to Bitrise Env Vars. If you would like to reduce the amount of Steps in your Workflow, you can set up Env Vars in Bitrise utilizing specific Git Environmental Variables:

title: Setting your Git credentials using Env Vars
body: Open the Workflow Editor.

title: Setting your Git credentials using Env Vars
body: Go to the Env Vars tab.

title: Setting your Git credentials using Env Vars
body: Create the following Env Vars:

title: Setting your Git credentials using Env Vars
body: GIT_AUTHOR_NAME: This is the human-readable name of the “author”.

title: Setting your Git credentials using Env Vars
body: GIT_AUTHOR_EMAIL: This is the email address of the "author".

title: Setting your Git credentials using Env Vars
body: GIT_COMMITTER_NAME: This is the human-readable name of the “committer”.

title: Setting your Git credentials using Env Vars
body: GIT_COMMITTER_EMAIL: This is the email address of the "committer".

title: Setting your Git credentials using the Set Git Credentials Step
body: Add a Set Git Credentials Step as the very first step in your workflow. The Step has to come first before you’d git commit. This way you can make sure any changes you make to the current build will be attached to a commit associated with your username and email address.

title: Setting your Git credentials using the Set Git Credentials Step
body: In the Git Username field, set the value to your own user name.

title: Setting your Git credentials using the Set Git Credentials Step
body: In the Git Email Address field, set the value to your own email address.

title: Setting your Git credentials using the Set Git Credentials Step
body: Start a build.

title: Setting your Git credentials using the Set Git Credentials Step
body: If all went well, you should see the changes in your repository in your Git provider. The new username and email address will be visible for all future commits you push from your builds to your Git provider.

title: Reporting the build status to your Git hosting provider
body: You need to authenticate Bitrise and specify a Service credential user in the App settings page of your app to push back build status reports to your Git provider.

title: Reporting the build status to your Git hosting provider
body: Bitrise can push back build status reports to your Git provider (GitHub/GitLab/Bitbucket). You only need to authenticate Bitrise to communicate towards the Git hosting service. Apart from build status reports, this enables other operations, such as auto-registering SSH keys or webhooks.

title: Reporting the build status to your Git hosting provider
body: Status reports are for automatically triggered builds only

title: Reporting the build status to your Git hosting provider
body: Status reports are sent only for automatically triggered builds, such as builds triggered by a code push or a pull request.

title: Reporting the build status to your Git hosting provider
body: To do this, you need to specify a Service credential user of your app on bitrise.io. You also need to make sure that this user has a connected account with the Git hosting service of your choice on bitrise.io. This account will be used by Bitrise to communicate with the API of the Git hosting provider.

title: Configuring build status reporting
body: Allowlist the Bitrise website IP addresses

title: Configuring build status reporting
body: If you use some form of self-hosted solution for storing your code, you might need to allowlist the static IP addresses of the Bitrise website and its background workers. This allows you to use such features as storing the bitrise.yml file in your own repository, or receiving build status updates from Bitrise: IP addresses for the Bitrise website.

title: Configuring build status reporting
body: To report your status, you need to make sure that the service credential user's Bitrise account is connected to their Git provider account. This Git account must have access to the app's repository.

title: Configuring build status reporting
body: Service credential user restriction

title: Configuring build status reporting
body: You can only set yourself as the service credential user and to do so, you need to have an Admin role on the app's team on Bitrise.

title: Configuring build status reporting
