body: If the service credential user should be a specific Bitrise user, that user must log in and set themselves. For more information, see: Changing the service credential user.

title: Configuring build status reporting
body: To check that build status reporting is possible:

title: Configuring build status reporting
body: In the upper right corner, open the account selector dropdown menu.

title: Configuring build status reporting
body: Select the Profile settings option.

title: Configuring build status reporting
body: This takes you to the Edit your profile page.

title: Configuring build status reporting
body: Make sure your account is connected to the Git provider that hosts the repository: check the CONNECTED ACCOUNTS menu on the left side.

title: Configuring build status reporting
body: Make sure the connected Git provider account has the required level of permission for sending status reports.

title: Configuring build status reporting
body: On GitHub and Bitbucket, Write access is required.

title: Configuring build status reporting
body: On GitLab, Developer access is required.

title: Configuring build status reporting
body: Admin access only

title: Configuring build status reporting
body: Only users with the role of admin on the app's team can access all functions of the App Settings page of an app.

title: Configuring build status reporting
body: Open your app on Bitrise.

title: Configuring build status reporting
body: On the main page of the app, click on the App Settings icon: .

title: Configuring build status reporting
body: On the left, select Integrations.

title: Configuring build status reporting
body: Find the Service credential user section.

title: Configuring build status reporting
body: Click the Test <Git provider> connection button to make sure the selected user’s connection can be used for sending back the build status to the hosting provider.

title: Troubleshooting build status reporting
body: If your builds do not send status reports to your Git hosting provider - GitHub, GitLab or Bitbucket -, you will need to do a little investigating to find out what causes the problem. Let’s take a look at the potential issues!

title: Checking the service credential user
body: The service credential user of the app on bitrise.io must have connected their Bitrise account to their Git hosting account and must have access to the repository of the app on that Git account.

title: Checking the service credential user
body: You can check the service credential user and test their Git connection.

title: Checking the service credential user
body: Admin access only

title: Checking the service credential user
body: Only users with the role of admin on the app's team can access all functions of the App Settings page of an app.

title: Checking the service credential user
body: Open your app on Bitrise.

title: Checking the service credential user
body: On the main page of the app, click on the App Settings icon: .

title: Checking the service credential user
body: Go to your app’s page on bitrise.io.

title: Checking the service credential user
body: Find the Service credential user section.

title: Checking the service credential user
body: Current user

title: Checking the service credential user
body: In the figure, the current active user is the service credential user. If the service credential user is a different user, this looks a little different, including the button's text.

title: Checking the service credential user
body: Click the Test <Git provider> connection button to test the user's Git connection.

title: Checking repository permissions and repository URL
body: Make sure that you granted Bitrise access to your Workspace or team. It might be that you did not grant Bitrise access or denied access to the GitHub Workspace or Bitbucket team that owns the repository.

title: Checking repository permissions and repository URL
body: Make sure the URL repository is up to date:

title: Checking repository permissions and repository URL
body: Admin access only

title: Checking repository permissions and repository URL
body: Only users with the role of admin on the app's team can access all functions of the App Settings page of an app.

title: Checking repository permissions and repository URL
body: Open your app on Bitrise.

title: Checking repository permissions and repository URL
body: On the main page of the app, click on the App Settings icon: .

title: Checking repository permissions and repository URL
body: On the left, select General.

title: Checking repository permissions and repository URL
body: Find the repository URL and make sure it's correct.

title: Starting builds
body: You can start builds on Bitrise in multiple ways: manually, by scheduling, setting up triggers, or by using the API.

title: Starting builds
body: You can start builds on Bitrise in multiple ways:

title: Starting builds
body: With the API: Triggering and aborting builds

title: Starting builds
body: You can also configure Bitrise to skip certain commits or Git Tags, preventing these from triggering builds.

title: Starting builds manually
body: You can start builds manually by selecting the app you need from your Dashboard and clicking the Start/Schedule build button.

title: Starting builds manually
body: Starting a build manually on Bitrise takes literally two clicks - if you leave everything on the default settings. If you do not wish to do that, or at least want to be sure what the default settings are, read on!

title: Starting builds manually
body: To start a build using the basic configuration options:

title: Starting builds manually
body: Go to your Dashboard and select the app you need.

title: Starting builds manually
body: Select Start/Schedule a Build.

title: Starting builds manually
body: This opens the Build configuration pop-up window.

title: Starting builds manually
body: Enter the branch you want to run into the Branch input field.

title: Starting builds manually
body: You can only set one branch. If a pull request to your repository is made from a forked branch, type the name of that branch to run a build of the pull request.

title: Starting builds manually
body: Pull request build

title: Starting builds manually
body: Starting a build of a pull request’s branch is NOT the same as a pull request build. The manually started build of a pull request branch will only build the state of the code on that branch. An automatically triggered pull request build, however, builds the state of the code as it will look like once you merged the pull request.

title: Starting builds manually
body: Optionally, enter a build message in the Message field.

title: Starting builds manually
body: Please note that entering the Git commit message of a specific commit doesn't trigger a build of that commit!

title: Starting builds manually
body: Select a Workflow that will run from the Workflow menu.

title: Starting builds manually
body: If you don't select one, Bitrise will choose a Workflow based on your app's trigger map

title: Starting builds manually
body: Scheduling a build

title: Starting builds manually
body: The Schedule this build option allows you to configure builds to be triggered at specific times. Read more: Scheduling builds.

title: Running Workflows from the Workflow Editor
body: You can manually start a build by running a single Workflow from the Workflow Editor.

title: Running Workflows from the Workflow Editor
body: To do so:

title: Running Workflows from the Workflow Editor
body: Open your app on Bitrise and click the Workflows button to open the Workflow Editor.

title: Running Workflows from the Workflow Editor
body: On the Workflows tab, use the WORKFLOW drop-down menu to select the Workflow you would like to run.

title: Running Workflows from the Workflow Editor
body: Click Run Workflow.

title: Running Workflows from the Workflow Editor
body: Specify the branch that you want to build in the Branch field.

title: Running Workflows from the Workflow Editor
body: Click Run Workflow to start the build.

title: Running Workflows from the Workflow Editor
body: And that's it! As soon as you click the Run Workflow button, your build will be kicked off, and the build's page will open in a new tab.

title: Advanced configuration options for starting/scheduling builds
body: If you choose Advanced in the Build configuration window, you have all the options available with Basic, and a few more:

title: Advanced configuration options for starting/scheduling builds
body: Git Tag: Builds a particular branch or commit that is tagged with the Tag you enter. If you set this, you can't set a commit hash.

title: Advanced configuration options for starting/scheduling builds
body: Git Tags and commit hashes are conflicting options

title: Advanced configuration options for starting/scheduling builds
body: You cannot specify both a Git Tag and a commit hash. When you set one, the other one will disappear. This ensures you cannot enter conflicting input values.

title: Advanced configuration options for starting/scheduling builds
body: Commit Hash: Copy a specific commit’s hash here to build that particular commit. This option can even send a build status update to your git hosting service. If you set this, you can't set a Git Tag.

title: Advanced configuration options for starting/scheduling builds
body: Commit hash takes precedence over the Branch option

title: Advanced configuration options for starting/scheduling builds
body: If the Branch option specifies a branch where the commit hash you chose doesn't exist, Bitrise will find the branch that does have the given commit and run a build with that branch.

title: Advanced configuration options for starting/scheduling builds
body: Custom Environment Variables: Create a custom Environment Variable that is used in the build. See Setting a custom Env Var when starting a build.

title: Advanced configuration options for starting/scheduling builds
body: Generated cURL command: Based on the options you set in the Build configuration window, we provide an automatically generated cURL command. This can be copied and pasted, and you can run it on any platform that has cURL installed.

title: Triggering builds automatically
body: You can configure automatic build triggers on Bitrise by specifying a trigger event and a Workflow. You can trigger builds from code pushes, pull requests or Git tags.

title: Triggering builds automatically
body: You can configure automatic build triggers on Bitrise by specifying a code event that should trigger a build and a destination Workflow that should run. You can define multiple triggers, and add new triggers or remove existing ones any time you wish.

title: Triggering builds automatically
body: There are three types of triggers:

title: Triggering builds automatically
body: Code push: code push to the specified branch of the app's repository triggers a build.

title: Triggering builds automatically
body: Pull request: specify source and/or destination branches where any pull request will trigger a build.

title: Triggering builds automatically
body: Git tag: a commit with a specific tag triggers a build.

title: Triggering builds automatically
body: You can manage the triggers in the Triggers section of the Workflow Editor or you can directly edit the bitrise.yml of your app to set them up. In this guide, we cover how to set up and manage triggers on the website UI.

title: Triggering builds automatically
body: For information on how to set up the triggers in YAML format, check out the relevant guide: Using the Trigger Map to trigger builds.

title: Triggering builds automatically
body: Trigger restrictions

title: Triggering builds automatically
body: By default, one trigger can trigger only one Workflow. If you need to trigger multiple Workflows from a single trigger, there is a couple of workarounds:

title: Triggering builds automatically
body: Chain Workflows together so they run after each other.

title: Triggering builds automatically
body: Use the Bitrise Start Build and the Bitrise Wait for Build Steps.

title: Triggering builds automatically
body: Also, you can't set up two different triggers for the same code event (for example, a code push) on the same branch (for example, main). The Workflow Editor will not allow you to save the configuration if you attempt to do so.

title: Triggering builds with code push
body: By creating a trigger on code push, you can configure Bitrise to automatically start a build every time code is pushed to your repository. You can specify both the branch of the repository and the Workflow that should run.

title: Triggering builds with code push
body: Webhooks for triggering builds

title: Triggering builds with code push
body: Triggering builds automatically requires an incoming webhook set up with the hosting service of your repository. Read more in the Webhooks section.

title: Triggering builds with code push
body: Open your app on bitrise.io.

title: Triggering builds with code push
body: Go to the Workflows tab.

title: Triggering builds with code push
body: Go to the Triggers tab.

title: Triggering builds with code push
body: Select the PUSH option.

title: Triggering builds with code push
body: Click + ADD TRIGGER.

title: Triggering builds with code push
body: In the PUSH BRANCH window, type in the name of the branch (for example, master. Make sure there are no spelling errors, otherwise the trigger won’t work.

title: Triggering builds with code push
body: Using patterns when specifying a branch or tag

title: Triggering builds with code push
body: The * symbol can be used in your configured triggers as a wildcard in branch or tag names. It can also be used in patterns. For example, the pattern *-dev can be used for any branches or tags with the suffix -dev. Please note that when there are multiple triggers, only the first matching trigger will start a workflow.

title: Triggering builds with code push
body: For more information on using wildcards, see: Using wildcards in the trigger map

title: Triggering builds with code push
body: Select the Workflow you wish to trigger (for example, primary).

title: Triggering builds with code push
body: Click Save in the top right corner.

title: Triggering builds with code push
body: You’re done! From now on, if code gets pushed to the selected branch of your app’s repository, Bitrise will trigger a build with the selected Workflow!

title: Triggering builds with pull requests
body: You can set up a trigger so that every time a pull request is opened from a specified source branch to a specified target branch of your repository, a build is automatically triggered on Bitrise.

title: Triggering builds with pull requests
body: Webhooks for triggering builds

title: Triggering builds with pull requests
body: Triggering builds automatically requires an incoming webhook set up with the hosting service of your repository. Read more in the Webhooks section.

title: Triggering builds with pull requests
body: Open your app on bitrise.io.

title: Triggering builds with pull requests
body: Go to the Workflows tab.

title: Triggering builds with pull requests
body: Go to the Triggers tab.

title: Triggering builds with pull requests
body: Select the PULL REQUEST option.

title: Triggering builds with pull requests
body: In the default trigger, click the SOURCE BRANCH and TARGET BRANCH options.

title: Triggering builds with pull requests
body: Click + ADD TRIGGER.

title: Triggering builds with pull requests
body: Type the names of the source branch and the target branch. Make sure there are no spelling errors, otherwise the trigger won’t work.

title: Triggering builds with pull requests
body: You can leave either the source or target branch fields, or both, empty: the trigger will work accordingly. For example, if you leave both empty, as is the default with new apps, every pull request will trigger a build.

title: Triggering builds with pull requests
body: Using patterns when specifying a branch or tag

title: Triggering builds with pull requests
body: The * symbol can be used in your configured triggers as a wildcard in branch or tag names. It can also be used in patterns. For example, the pattern *-dev can be used for any branches or tags with the suffix -dev. Please note that when there are multiple triggers, only the first matching trigger will start a workflow.

title: Triggering builds with pull requests
body: For more information on using wildcards, see: Using wildcards in the trigger map

title: Triggering builds with pull requests
body: Select the Workflow you wish to trigger (for example, primary).

title: Triggering builds with pull requests
body: Click Save in the top right corner.

title: Triggering builds with pull requests
body: And you’re done! From now on, if a pull request is opened in your repository, Bitrise will trigger a build with the selected Workflow!

title: Triggering builds with Git Tags
body: You can specify a pattern for your Git Tags to trigger a specific workflow. This is a good way to build and deploy your app in a specific state. And it’s very easy to set up!

title: Triggering builds with Git Tags
body: Webhooks for triggering builds

title: Triggering builds with Git Tags
body: Triggering builds automatically requires an incoming webhook set up with the hosting service of your repository. Read more in the Webhooks section.

title: Triggering builds with Git Tags
body: Note that certain providers, such as GitLab, require Tag Push events to be specifically enabled in the webhook setup.

title: Triggering builds with Git Tags
body: Open your app on bitrise.io.

title: Triggering builds with Git Tags
body: Go to the Workflows tab.

title: Triggering builds with Git Tags
body: Go to the Triggers tab.

title: Triggering builds with Git Tags
body: Select the TAG option.

title: Triggering builds with Git Tags
body: Click + ADD TRIGGER.

title: Triggering builds with Git Tags
body: In the TAG window, add the tag that you wish to trigger a build.

title: Triggering builds with Git Tags
body: Using patterns when specifying a branch or tag

title: Triggering builds with Git Tags
body: The * symbol can be used in your configured triggers as a wildcard in branch or tag names. It can also be used in patterns. For example, the pattern *-dev can be used for any branches or tags with the suffix -dev. Please note that when there are multiple triggers, only the first matching trigger will start a workflow.

title: Triggering builds with Git Tags
body: For more information on using wildcards, see: Using wildcards in the trigger map

title: Triggering builds with Git Tags
body: Select the Workflow you wish to trigger (for example, primary).

title: Triggering builds with Git Tags
body: Click Save in the top right corner.

title: Triggering builds with Git Tags
body: And you’re done!

title: Scheduling builds
body: You can schedule your builds to run automatically at a specific time of the week.

title: Scheduling builds
body: You can schedule your builds to run automatically at a specific time of the week so that you can check your logs when it’s most convenient for you.

title: Scheduling builds
body: When scheduling a build, you can define custom Environment Variables. You can also set advanced filters for Git Tags and for Git commit hash.

title: Scheduling builds
body: If you have one or more regularly scheduled builds, you can:

title: Scheduling builds
body: Edit their configuration.

title: Scheduling builds
body: Trigger them manually at any time.

title: Scheduling builds
body: Temporarily disable them.

title: Scheduling builds
body: Permanently delete them.

title: Scheduling a build
body: How to schedule a build with the basic configuration options on Bitrise:

title: Scheduling a build
body: Go to your Dashboard and select the app you need.

title: Scheduling a build
body: Select Start/Schedule a Build.

title: Scheduling a build
body: This opens the Build configuration pop-up window.

title: Scheduling a build
body: In the Build configuration pop-up window, toggle the switch to the right to enable Schedule this build feature.

title: Scheduling a build
body: Set the hour and minute in the HH/MM field.

title: Scheduling a build
body: Time format and time zones in scheduled builds

title: Scheduling a build
body: Bitrise uses the 24-hour time format when scheduling builds. The time you set on the Web UI is based on your own time zone, which is then converted and stored as UTC. If team members from other time zones access the scheduled build, they will see the time in their own time zone as well.

title: Scheduling a build
body: On the timeline, select the day(s) when you want your build to run.

title: Scheduling a build
body: Use the Time zone drop-down menu to set the time zone of your scheduled builds.

title: Scheduling a build
body: Daylight saving time

title: Scheduling a build
body: Your scheduled builds automatically adjust between standard time and daylight saving time. So, if you have scheduled your builds to trigger every day at 4 PM, they will trigger at 4 PM before switching to daylight saving time and after switching to daylight saving time. The same applies the other way around.

title: Scheduling a build
body: Enter the branch you want to run into the Branch input field.

title: Scheduling a build
body: You can only set one branch. If a pull request to your repository is made from a forked branch, type the name of that branch to run a build of the pull request.

title: Scheduling a build
body: Pull request build

title: Scheduling a build
body: Starting a build of a pull request’s branch is NOT the same as a pull request build. The manually started build of a pull request branch will only build the state of the code on that branch. An automatically triggered pull request build, however, builds the state of the code as it will look like once you merged the pull request.

title: Scheduling a build
body: Optionally, enter a build message in the Message field.

title: Scheduling a build
body: Please note that entering the Git commit message of a specific commit doesn't trigger a build of that commit!

title: Scheduling a build
body: Select a Workflow that will run from the Workflow menu.

title: Scheduling a build
body: If you don't select one, Bitrise will choose a Workflow based on your app's trigger map

title: Scheduling a build
body: Click Schedule Build at the bottom of the pop-up window.

title: Advanced configuration options for starting/scheduling builds
body: If you choose Advanced in the Build configuration window, you have all the options available with Basic, and a few more:

title: Advanced configuration options for starting/scheduling builds
body: Git Tag: Builds a particular branch or commit that is tagged with the Tag you enter. If you set this, you can't set a commit hash.

title: Advanced configuration options for starting/scheduling builds
body: Git Tags and commit hashes are conflicting options

title: Advanced configuration options for starting/scheduling builds
body: You cannot specify both a Git Tag and a commit hash. When you set one, the other one will disappear. This ensures you cannot enter conflicting input values.

title: Advanced configuration options for starting/scheduling builds
body: Commit Hash: Copy a specific commit’s hash here to build that particular commit. This option can even send a build status update to your git hosting service. If you set this, you can't set a Git Tag.

title: Advanced configuration options for starting/scheduling builds
body: Commit hash takes precedence over the Branch option

title: Advanced configuration options for starting/scheduling builds
body: If the Branch option specifies a branch where the commit hash you chose doesn't exist, Bitrise will find the branch that does have the given commit and run a build with that branch.

title: Advanced configuration options for starting/scheduling builds
body: Custom Environment Variables: Create a custom Environment Variable that is used in the build. See Setting a custom Env Var when starting a build.

title: Advanced configuration options for starting/scheduling builds
body: Generated cURL command: Based on the options you set in the Build configuration window, we provide an automatically generated cURL command. This can be copied and pasted, and you can run it on any platform that has cURL installed.

title: Editing a scheduled build
body: To change the configuration of a regularly scheduled build:

title: Editing a scheduled build
body: Go to the Builds tab of your app.

title: Editing a scheduled build
body: On the top, you should see a list of your scheduled builds.

title: Editing a scheduled build
body: Click Show scheduled.

title: Editing a scheduled build
body: Click the little gear icon to open the settings menu.

title: Editing a scheduled build
body: Click Edit scheduled build.

title: Editing a scheduled build
body: Make the changes you want and click Save changes.

title: Triggering a scheduled build manually
body: To immediately trigger a scheduled build:

title: Triggering a scheduled build manually
body: Go to the Builds tab of your app.

title: Triggering a scheduled build manually
body: On the top, you should see a list of your scheduled builds.

title: Triggering a scheduled build manually
body: Click Show scheduled.

title: Triggering a scheduled build manually
body: Click Trigger now.

title: Disabling a scheduled build
body: To temporarily disable a regularly scheduled build:

title: Disabling a scheduled build
body: Go to the Builds tab of your app.

title: Disabling a scheduled build
body: On the top, you should see a list of your scheduled builds.

title: Disabling a scheduled build
body: Click Show scheduled.

title: Disabling a scheduled build
body: Toggle the Enabled option.

title: Disabling a scheduled build
body: The build will not run until you enable it again.

title: Deleting a scheduled build
body: To permanently delete a regularly scheduled build:

title: Deleting a scheduled build
body: Go to the Builds tab of your app.

title: Deleting a scheduled build
body: On the top, you should see a list of your scheduled builds.

title: Deleting a scheduled build
body: Click Show scheduled.

title: Deleting a scheduled build
body: Click the little gear icon to open the settings menu.

title: Deleting a scheduled build
body: Click Delete and then click Delete again when prompted for confirmation.

title: Approving pull request builds
body: You have the option of requiring manual approval for Bitrise builds started by pull requests if the app contains exposed Secrets. This option cannot be deactivated for public apps.

title: Approving pull request builds
body: Not all pull requests need to be built. After all, for most projects, anyone can create a fork of the repository and submit a pull request. However, if an app on Bitrise is set up with Secrets that are exposed for pull request builds, for example, then you probably don’t want just anyone to be able to access those secrets.

title: Approving pull request builds
body: That is why you have the option to require approval for a pull request build before it can start. This feature works somewhat differently for public and private apps:

title: Approving pull request builds
body: Private apps: by default, pull requests submitted from a fork require approval. The setting can be changed. If your secrets are NOT exposed to PRs, the build will run without asking for approval.

title: Approving pull request builds
body: Public apps: pull requests submitted from a fork require approval by default and it cannot be changed. Public apps CANNOT opt out of this feature.

title: Enabling manual approval for private apps
body: To enable or disable manual approval, you need to be an Admin or an Owner on the application’s team. The application MUST be private: public apps cannot opt out of this feature!

title: Enabling manual approval for private apps
body: Admin access only

title: Enabling manual approval for private apps
body: Only users with the role of admin on the app's team can access all functions of the App Settings page of an app.

title: Enabling manual approval for private apps
body: Open your app on Bitrise.

title: Enabling manual approval for private apps
body: On the main page of the app, click on the App Settings icon: .

title: Enabling manual approval for private apps
body: On the left, select Builds.

title: Enabling manual approval for private apps
body: Scroll down to Manual build approval.

title: Enabling manual approval for private apps
body: Please note that you can only change this setting for private apps! For public apps, this is always enabled.

title: Enabling manual approval for private apps
body: Toggle the switch to enable or disable it.

title: Enabling manual approval for private apps
body: By default, it is set to disabled.

title: Approving the PR build
body: Approving the PR build

title: Approving the PR build
body: Please note that approving a PR build means approving it on Bitrise. Approving a pull request on GitHub, for example, isn't sufficient to start a build on Bitrise: an owner has to approve the build on Bitrise itself.

title: Approving the PR build
body: If a pull request is submitted from a fork, you will be notified that a PR build is waiting for approval:

title: Approving the PR build
body: A notification email will be sent with the name of the app, as well as links to the repository itself and to the app’s Builds page on Bitrise.

title: Approving the PR build
body: On the Git provider, the status of the CI check will show Pending - Waiting for approval

title: Approving the PR build
body: On the Builds page of the app, a confirmation box will be displayed.

title: Approving the PR build
body: To approve and run the build, click the Approve and Run Build button. Clicking Review opens the pull request on the website of your Git provider.

title: Using the Trigger Map to trigger builds
body: On Bitrise, you can create triggers (or webhooks) for events such as code push or pull requests to start a build automatically.

title: Using the Trigger Map to trigger builds
body: When you register a webhook for an event or for multiple events (for example, for code push and for pull request events), your source code hosting service will call the webhook every time the related event happens.

title: Using the Trigger Map to trigger builds
body: On bitrise.io these webhook calls are called triggers, and can be mapped to different Workflows, or not mapped at all. If you don’t map a trigger to any Workflow, then bitrise.io won’t start a build. If you map it to a Workflow, then a build will be started with the selected Workflow.

title: Using the Trigger Map to trigger builds
body: In the following examples, we’ll use a very simple Bitrise configuration (bitrise.yml), which does nothing else just prints the selected Workflow’s ID:

title: Using the Trigger Map to trigger builds
body: What is the bitrise.yml file

title: Using the Trigger Map to trigger builds
body: The bitrise.yml file is the representation of your app’s configuration in YAML format. You can:

title: Using the Trigger Map to trigger builds
body: Edit the file locally and store it in your repository.

title: Using the Trigger Map to trigger builds
body: Edit the file on the bitrise.yml tab of the Workflow Editor on bitrise.io.

title: Using the Trigger Map to trigger builds
body: Update your Steps and Workflows on the graphical UI of the Workflow Editor. All changes will be reflected in the bitrise.yml file.

title: Using the Trigger Map to trigger builds
body:
---
format_version: 1.3.0
default_step_lib_source: https://github.com/bitrise-io/bitrise-steplib.git
trigger_map:
- push_branch: "*"
 workflow: primary
- pull_request_target_branch: "*"
 pull_request_source_branch: "*"
 workflow: primary
- tag: "*"
 workflow: primary
workflows:
 primary:
 steps:
 - script:
 inputs:
 - content: |-
 #!/bin/bash
 echo "$BITRISE_TRIGGERED_WORKFLOW_ID"

title: Using the Trigger Map to trigger builds
body: The above example bitrise.yml will select the primary branch for every code push (push_branch: "*"), tag push (tag: "*") and for every pull request (pull_request_target_branch: "*" & pull_request_source_branch: "*").

title: Using the Trigger Map to trigger builds
body: This configuration will start a build with the primary Workflow for every code push, but for nothing else (for example not for pull requests).

title: Components of the Trigger Map
body: A trigger_map is a list of filters, and the workflow is the given filters it should select in case of a matching trigger. Every filter item has to include at least one condition!

title: Components of the Trigger Map
body: This means that you can’t have an item which only specifies the workflow, at least one filter (push_branch / pull_request_source_branch / pull_request_target_branch / tag) has to be specified!

title: Components of the Trigger Map
body: The available filters:

title: Components of the Trigger Map
body: push_branch : A filter which is matched against code push events’ branch parameter.

title: Components of the Trigger Map
body: pull_request_source_branch : A filter which is matched against Pull Request events’ source branch parameter (the branch the pull request was started from).

title: Components of the Trigger Map
body: pull_request_target_branch : A filter which is matched against Pull Request events’ target branch parameter - the branch the pull request will be merged into.

title: Components of the Trigger Map
body: tag : A filter which is matched against Tag Push events’ tag (name) parameter.

title: Components of the Trigger Map
body: pattern : DEPRECATED - this filter was used for both code push and pull request events, in combination with is_pull_request_allowed. This filter is now deprecated, as the new filters allow better control over event mapping.

title: Components of the Trigger Map
body: One trigger = one build

title: Components of the Trigger Map
body: One trigger can only select a single Workflow / can only start a single build. The first item which matches the trigger will select the Workflow for the build!

title: Components of the Trigger Map
body: The order of the items also matters:

title: Components of the Trigger Map
body:
trigger_map:
- push_branch: "*"
 push_branch: "master*"
 workflow: primary

title: Components of the Trigger Map
body: By specifying a push_branch: master item after a push_branch: "*" item, the push_branch: master would never be selected as every code push event would match push_branch: "*" first, and the first item which matches the trigger will select the Workflow for the build!

title: Components of the Trigger Map
body: If you define multiple filters in a single item then all filters have to match in order to select that item’s workflow. For example:

title: Components of the Trigger Map
body:
trigger_map:
- pull_request_target_branch: "master"
 pull_request_source_branch: "develop"
 workflow: primary

title: Components of the Trigger Map
body: This will only select the primary workflow if the pull request’s source branch is develop AND the target branch is master.

title: Components of the Trigger Map
body: If you want to specify filters which should be treated separately, for example, to select primary for pull requests where the source is develop, as well as select for the ones which target master:

title: Components of the Trigger Map
body:
trigger_map:
- pull_request_target_branch: "master"
 workflow: primary
- pull_request_source_branch: "develop"
 workflow: primary

title: Components of the Trigger Map
body: Can't mix filters in the same item

title: Components of the Trigger Map
body: You can’t mix and match push_branch, tag and the pull_request filters in the same item. This would effectively mean that the workflow should be selected if the event is a code push and a pull request (or tag push) event at the same time. This is simply not possible, source code hosting services send separate webhooks for pull request (pre-merge state), tags and for code push events. A single webhook event will never be code push, tag push and pull request at the same time, a single webhook is always related to only one type (code push, tag push or pull request).

title: Building a single branch
body: If you want to build only a single branch for every code push, but for nothing else (no push to any other branch should trigger a build, nor any pull request or tag), then all you have to do is to specify a trigger_map which does not map anything else to any Workflow, only the branch you want to build.

title: Building a single branch
body: For example, if you only want to build the master branch on code push:

title: Building a single branch
body:
trigger_map:
- push_branch: master
 workflow: primary

title: Building a single branch
body: Or if you only want to build feature/ branches:

title: Building a single branch
body:
trigger_map:
- push_branch: feature/*
 workflow: primary

title: Building a single branch
body: Or the two together:

title: Building a single branch
body:
trigger_map:
- push_branch: master
 workflow: primary
- push_branch: feature/*
 workflow: primary

title: Building a single branch
body: This configuration will start a build for every code push which happens on either master or on a feature/ branch, and will use the same Workflow for both (primary).

title: Building a single branch
body: If you want to use a different Workflow for your master branch, then all you have to do is to change the workflow: for that trigger map item:

title: Building a single branch
body:
trigger_map:
- push_branch: master
 workflow: deploy
- push_branch: feature/*
 workflow: primary

title: Building a single branch
body: This configuration will use the Workflow deploy for every code push on master, and the Workflow primary for every code push on feature/ branches, and will not start a build for anything else.

title: Using wildcards in the trigger map
body: When you create a trigger map, you don't have to specify exact branch names: you can use wildcards to match patterns. Bitrise uses a simplified version of the glob syntax for this: you can use * as a wildcard. You can use multiple sections of * but other pattern matching features aren't supported.

title: Using wildcards in the trigger map
body: Using the wildcard

title: Using wildcards in the trigger map
body: Wildcards on the UI

title: Using wildcards in the trigger map
body: All examples below show how the trigger map looks like in the bitrise.yml file of the app. However, you can use wildcards on the Triggers tab of the Workflow Editor in the same way: Triggering builds automatically

title: Using wildcards in the trigger map
body: Trigger the primary Workflow any time code is pushed to a branch that contains the string dev anywhere in its name:

title: Using wildcards in the trigger map
body:
trigger_map:
- push_branch: "*dev*" 
 workflow: primary

title: Using wildcards in the trigger map
body: Trigger the primary Workflow any time a pull request is opened to a branch that contains both dev and feature anywhere in its name, with anything in between the two strings:

title: Using wildcards in the trigger map
body:
trigger_map:
- pull_request_source_branch: "*" 
 pull_request_target_branch: "*dev*feature*" 
 workflow: primary

title: Using wildcards in the trigger map
body: Trigger the primary Workflow any time a commit is pushed with a Git tag that ends in v1.0:

title: Using wildcards in the trigger map
body:
- tag: "*v1.0" 
 workflow: primary

title: Starting parallel builds with a single trigger
body: You can start multiple parallel builds by using the Bitrise Start for Build and the Bitrise Wait for Build Steps.

title: Starting parallel builds with a single trigger
body: Using Build Pipelines to start parallel builds with a single trigger

title: Starting parallel builds with a single trigger
body: If you have a credit-based account and you are planning on running multiple tasks parallel with a single trigger, we recommend using Build Pipelines. For more information, check out Build Pipelines.

title: Starting parallel builds with a single trigger
body: If you have more than one concurrency or you have a credit-based account, you can run more than one build simultaneously. And since we want to make life as easy for you as possible, these builds can be started automatically, with a single trigger. Let’s go through how it works!

title: Starting parallel builds with a single trigger
body: In the example, we have three Workflows of a single app set up to run at the same time. Let’s call these Workflows Trigger, Building and Testing. The workflow called Trigger will be triggered by a pull request, and then the workflow will trigger Building and Testing which will run simultaneously.

title: Starting parallel builds with a single trigger
body: All workflows run on separate, clean Virtual Machines. They can also run on different types of stacks: to choose the stack for any Workflow, go to the Workflow Editor of the app and select the Stack tab.

title: Starting parallel builds with a single trigger
body: If any of the builds fail, the build will be considered a failed build. If the build is triggered by a webhook, Bitrise will send a summarized build result to your Git provider. If any of the parallel builds fail, a failed status will be reported.

title: Starting parallel builds with a single trigger
body: No reports for "child" builds

title: Starting parallel builds with a single trigger
body: Bitrise will send a Git status report only for the original "parent" build, the one that triggered all the other builds. The "child" builds will not send back status reports to your Git provider!

title: Starting parallel builds with a single trigger
body: For example, if build A triggers builds B and C, a status report will be sent once A is finished. There will be no separate status reports for builds B and C, however.

title: Starting parallel builds with a single trigger
body: What you need:

title: Starting parallel builds with a single trigger
body: A Personal Access Token.

title: Starting parallel builds with a single trigger
body: A Secret Environment Variable storing the token.

title: Starting parallel builds with a single trigger
body: The Bitrise Start Build Step.

title: Starting parallel builds with a single trigger
body: The Bitrise Wait for Build Step.

title: Starting parallel builds with a single trigger
body: Bitrise Start Build Step on the CI

title: Starting parallel builds with a single trigger
body: Since the Bitrise Build Start Step heavily relies on the parameters of the currently running build (for example, the app slug, build slug and the build number) to call the API, you cannot use the Bitrise Build Start Step locally.

title: Starting parallel builds with a single trigger
body: bitrise.yml example

title: Starting parallel builds with a single trigger
body: You can edit your bitrise.yml file on the bitrise.yml tab of the Workflow Editor, or you can edit the file locally. The example below focuses on the Bitrise UI, but if you prefer to use YAML format, check out our example!

title: Starting parallel builds with a single trigger
body: Create a Personal Access Token for your user.

title: Starting parallel builds with a single trigger
body: Go to Profile Settings and select the Security option on the left side. Click the Generate new button.

title: Starting parallel builds with a single trigger
body: Copying the token

title: Starting parallel builds with a single trigger
body: Make sure the copy the token once it's generated: you won't be able to see it again!

title: Starting parallel builds with a single trigger
body: Create a Secret Environment Variable on the Secrets tab of the app’s Workflow Editor and add the token as its value.

title: Starting parallel builds with a single trigger
body: Feel free to use any key you wish for the secret. We recommend something simple like $ACCESS_TOKEN.

title: Starting parallel builds with a single trigger
body: Add the Bitrise Start Build Step to the Trigger Workflow.

title: Starting parallel builds with a single trigger
body: Note that the Bitrise Start Build Step will set an Environment Variable to all builds it starts: $SOURCE_BITRISE_BUILD_NUMBER. Each build triggered by the Step will have their own build numbers but the source build number will be the same for all of them.

title: Starting parallel builds with a single trigger
body: Add the secret env storing your personal access token to the Bitrise Access Token input of the Step: click the Select secret variable button and choose the key you created.

title: Starting parallel builds with a single trigger
body: Find the Workflows input of the Step, and add Building and Testing to it.

title: Starting parallel builds with a single trigger
body: Add the Bitrise Wait for Build Step as the last Step of the Trigger Workflow.

title: Starting parallel builds with a single trigger
body: Checking build statuses

title: Starting parallel builds with a single trigger
body: The Step checks statuses of the builds defined in the Step. The builds are defined in the Build slugs input: the slugs are the output of the Bitrise Start Build Step. As long as the builds defined by the slugs are running, the Step will hold the build it is running in. The build will fail if any of the builds included in the Step fail.

title: Starting parallel builds with a single trigger
body: Add the secret env storing your personal access token to the Bitrise Access Token input of the Step: click the Select secret variable button and choose the key you created.

title: Starting parallel builds with a single trigger
body: And you are done! Once you trigger the Trigger workflow, the Bitrise Start Build Step of the Workflow will trigger two more builds running simultaneously. If those two builds are successful, the Bitrise Wait for Build Step lets the first build finish. A single status report is sent to the git hosting provider, regardless whether the build is successful or not.

title: bitrise.yml example
body:
Trigger:
 steps:
 - build-router-start@0:
 inputs:
 - workflows: |-
 Building
 Testing
 - access_token: "$BITRISE_API_KEY"
 - build-router-wait@0:
 inputs:
 - access_token: "$BITRISE_API_KEY"

title: Skipping a given commit or pull request
body: Depending on your settings, every code change in your repository can trigger Bitrise builds. However, if you need to, you can skip a specific commit or pull request.

title: Skipping a given commit or pull request
body: Depending on your settings, every code change in your repository can trigger Bitrise builds. However, if you need to, you can skip a specific commit or pull request. Skipping means, in this context, that a code change will NOT trigger a build on Bitrise, even if the triggers are set up to do so.

title: Preventing a commit from triggering a build
body: To make sure a specific commit does not trigger a build, include either [skip ci] or [ci skip] in the commit message:

title: Preventing a commit from triggering a build
body: This is not important, please [skip ci]

title: Preventing a commit from triggering a build
body: Or:

title: Preventing a commit from triggering a build
body:
I just changed the README 

[ci skip]

title: Preventing a commit from triggering a build
body: Only the head/last commit message is checked!

title: Preventing a commit from triggering a build
body: If you push more than one commit, only the last (head) commit’s message will be checked for the skip ci pattern!

title: Preventing a commit from triggering a build
body: If you do want to start a build after all, you have two choices:

title: Preventing a commit from triggering a build
body: Rebase the commit (change the commit message).

title: Preventing a commit from triggering a build
body: Push another commit.

title: Preventing a commit from triggering a build
body: Pushing an empty commit

title: Preventing a commit from triggering a build
body: Git allows to create and push empty commits. If you want to build a skipped build you can do git commit --allow-empty -m "I decided to run this" on the related branch and push the commit.

title: Preventing a pull request from triggering a build
body: Pull requests are treated as (virtual) commits themselves, where the commit message is the title + description of the pull request. It is not the commit messages of the individual commits that make up the pull request.

title: Preventing a pull request from triggering a build
body: To skip a pull request include the skip ci pattern in the pull request’s title or description.

title: Preventing a pull request from triggering a build
body: Individual commit messages are not checked

title: Preventing a pull request from triggering a build
body: Putting the skip ci pattern in the commit message of individual commits that make up the pull request will not work: the pull request will trigger a build if the appropriate trigger is set up.

title: Preventing a pull request from triggering a build
body: Once you decide to not to skip the pull request / more commits in the pull request, you can simply remove the skip ci pattern from the pull request’s title or description. This should automatically trigger a new build with the latest commit, and all future commits of the pull request will be built too (unless you add a skip ci pattern again).

title: Exiting a build triggered by a draft PR
body: When you use the draft PR function of GitHub, Bitrise inserts a Environment Variable into the build Environment Variable list. If this Env Var is available in your build Env Var list, its value is always set to true.

title: Exiting a build triggered by a draft PR
body: You can spot the GITHUB_PR_IS_DRAFT Env Var in your build and abort the build immediately to save concurrencies/credits in two ways.

title: Exiting a build triggered by a draft PR
body: If you insert below script command into a Script Step, the command will catch the draft PR Env Var, if it is defined, and the build will fail.

title: Exiting a build triggered by a draft PR
body:
#!/usr/bin/env bash
# fail if any commands fails
set -e
# debug log
set -x

if [[ -z "${GITHUB_PR_IS_DRAFT}" ]]; then
 echo 'Not a draft PR'
else
 exit 1
fi

title: Exiting a build triggered by a draft PR
body: If you'd rather run an empty green build super quickly, we recommend that you insert below run_if command to each Step in your Workflow to skip the Steps.

title: Exiting a build triggered by a draft PR
body:
workflow1:
 steps:
 - script@1:
 run_if: '{{enveq "GITHUB_PR_IS_DRAFT" ""}}' 
 inputs:
 - content: |-
 #!/usr/bin/env bash
 # fail if any commands fails
 set -e
 # debug log
 set -x

title: Exiting a build triggered by a draft PR
body: Starting a new build after a draft PR

title: Exiting a build triggered by a draft PR
body: If you have previously used the draft PR on a build but now you are ready to merge changes to your code from the same PR, clicking the Ready for review button on GitHub won’t trigger a new build on Bitrise. The previous builds will also contain the draft PR related Env Vars. In this case, we recommend you manually start a brand new build from the website or trigger the CI with a new commit.

title: Caching
body: Every single Bitrise build runs on a clean virtual machine, but you can store your content in the build cache using either branch-based caching or key-based caching.

title: Caching
body: Every single Bitrise build runs on a clean virtual machine. This means that normally, without caching, everything must be done from scratch on the virtual machine, including, for example, installing your dependencies.

title: Caching
body: With caching, you can preserve the contents of selected files and directories, such as installed dependencies or files generated during the build.

title: Caching
body: There are two main methods of caching on Bitrise:

title: Caching
body: Branch-based caching: this uses the Bitrise.io Cache: Push Step and the Bitrise.io Cache: Pull Step to manage cache archives. Each cache archive is tied to a specific branch in your repository.

title: Caching
body: Key-based caching: It works by associating cache archives with a key. During a Workflow, you can restore a cache archive by referring to the key associated with it.

title: Key-based caching
body: Key-based caching on Bitrise works by associating cache archives with a key. A Workflow can restore a cache archive by referring to the key; the build files can be saved into the cache archive that the key indicates.

title: Key-based caching
body: Credit-based only

title: Key-based caching
body: Key-based caching is only available on credit-based accounts. Legacy concurrency-based accounts can use branch-based caching.

title: Key-based caching
body: Key-based caching works by associating cache archives with a key. A Workflow can restore a cache archive by referring to the key; at the end of the Workflow, the build files can be saved into the cache archive that the key indicates. This overwrites the cache archive.

title: Key-based caching
body: Cache keys can contain variables and other dynamic elements that are replaced at runtime. Users can set up caching that periodically creates new cache archives and automatically discard the old archives.

title: Key-based caching
body: A new cache archive is valid for seven days after creation. If the archive is updated, the timer restarts. If an archive is not updated for seven days, it is automatically discarded.

title: Using key-based caching
body: Key-based caching requires two Steps that must be used together:

title: Using key-based caching
body: Save Cache: saves the build files into a cache archive, identified by a key.

title: Using key-based caching
body: Restore Cache: restores build files into a cache archive, identified by a key.

title: Using key-based caching
body: Both Steps access cache archives via key strings. These keys need to be specified as the values of the Cache keys Step input; each key identifies a separate cache archive.

title: Creating a new cache archive
body: Key limitations

title: Creating a new cache archive
body: The maximum length of a cache key is 512 characters (longer keys get truncated). Commas (,) are not allowed in keys.

title: Creating a new cache archive
body: Add the Save Cache Step at the end of your Workflow.

title: Creating a new cache archive
body: In the Cache key input, define a cache key. This key will be used to identify the cache archive.

title: Creating a new cache archive
body: You can use templates and functions to create dynamic keys that change depending on the build environment or other factors.

title: Creating a new cache archive
body: You can specify multiple keys; the Step will evaluate them in order and match the first one. Read more: Key matching for cache archives.

title: Creating a new cache archive
body: Conditional caching with dynamic keys

title: Creating a new cache archive
body: You can configure the Step in a way that allows it to automatically skip archiving and uploading the cache if its content has not changed during the build: Using conditional caching with dynamic keys.

title: Creating a new cache archive
body: Creating a new cache archive with a key referring to the OS

title: Creating a new cache archive
body: In this example, we're creating a cache archive with a key that refers to the type of the operating system of the build machine.

title: Creating a new cache archive
body:
- save-cache@1:
 inputs:
 - key: |-
 npm-cache-{{ .OS }}

title: Creating a new cache archive
body: In the Paths to cache input, define the files and folders that you want to cache.

title: Creating a new cache archive
body: The input allows for wildcards: * and **. The input value is evaluated at runtime.

title: Creating a new cache archive
body: Caching all files and folders recursively in the node_modules folder

title: Creating a new cache archive
body:
- save-cache@1:
 inputs:
 - key: |-
 npm-cache-{{ .OS }}
 - paths: node_modules/

title: Creating a new cache archive
body: Dedicated key-based caching Steps

title: Creating a new cache archive
body: You can use dedicated key-based caching Steps, such as the Save NPM Cache, to cache npm or yarn dependencies.

title: Creating a new cache archive
body: For a full list of dedicated key-based caching Steps, check out Dedicated caching Steps for dependency managers.

title: Creating a new cache archive
body: Once a cache archive has been created, you can access it on the App Settings page: Accessing key-based cache archives.

title: Restoring an existing cache archive
body: Add the Restore Cache Step at the start of your Workflow.

title: Restoring an existing cache archive
body: In the Cache key input, type the key of the cache that you want to restore.

title: Restoring an existing cache archive
body: You can use templates and functions to create dynamic keys that change depending on the build environment or other factors.

title: Restoring an existing cache archive
body: You can specify multiple keys; the Step will evaluate them in order and select the first matching one. Read more: Key matching for cache archives.

title: Restoring an existing cache archive
body: Restoring a cache archive from one of two keys

title: Restoring an existing cache archive
body: In this example, we're restoring one of two keys:

title: Restoring an existing cache archive
body: First, we'll look for a cache archive with a key that includes the name of the current Workflow. For example, if the current Workflow's name is primary, the Step will look for an archive with the key npm-cache-primary.

title: Restoring an existing cache archive
body: Second, we'll look for an archive with a key that includes the name of the current branch. For example, if the current branch's name is main, the Step will look for an archive with the key npm-cache-main.

title: Restoring an existing cache archive
Key-based caching templates and functions
body: Both key-based caching Steps support using template elements in their Step inputs. The Steps evaluate the key template at runtime and the final cache key to be used can change depending on the build environment or on certain files in the repository.

title: Available caching templates
body: Key-based caching templates

title: Using functions in caching templates
body: The key-based caching templates support the use of two different functions:

title: Using functions in caching templates
body: checksum: This function computes the SHA-256 checksum of the contents of one or more files. This is useful for creating unique cache keys based on files that describe content to cache. Example 1, “.

title: Using functions in caching templates
body: getenv: This function returns the value of an Environment Variable (Env Var) or an empty string if the variable is not defined. Example 2, “

title: Using functions in caching templates
body: Using the checksum function

title: Using functions in caching templates
body: Use the checksum function to create a key that computes the checksum of the package-lock.json file:

title: Using functions in caching templates
body:
- save-cache@1:
 inputs:
 - key: npm-cache-{{ checksum "package-lock.json" }}
 - paths: node_modules

title: Using functions in caching templates
body: Use the checksum function to create a key that computes a checksum for any .gradle file and the gradle.properties file:

title: Using functions in caching templates
body:
- save-cache@1:
 inputs:
 - key: gradle-cache-{{ checksum "**/*.gradle*" "gradle.properties" }}
 - paths: AndroidApp

title: Using functions in caching templates
body: Using the getenv function

title: Using functions in caching templates
body: Use the getenv function to create a key that contains the value of the BITRISE_BUILD_NUMBER Env Var.

title: Using functions in caching templates
body:
- save-cache@1:
 inputs:
 - key: npm-cache-{{ getenv "BITRISE_BUILD_NUMBER" }}
 - paths: node_modules

title: Key matching for cache archives
body: It's possible to define more than one key in the Cache keys input of the key-based caching Steps. You can specify additional keys by listing one key per line. The list is in priority order, so the Step will first try to find a match for the first key you provided, and if there is no cache stored for the key, it will move on to find a match for the second key (and so on).

title: Key matching for cache archives
body:
inputs:
 key: |
 key-1
 key-2
 key-3

title: Key matching for cache archives
body: In addition to listing multiple keys, each key can be a prefix of a saved cache key and still get a matching cache archive. For example, the key my-cache- can match an existing archive saved with the key my-cache-a6a102ff. We recommend configuring the keys in a way that the first key is an exact match to a checksum key, and to use a more generic prefix key as a fallback:

title: Key matching for cache archives
body:
inputs:
 key: |
 npm-cache-{{ checksum "package-lock.json" }}
 npm-cache-

title: Using conditional caching with dynamic keys
body: You might not want to update a cache archive every time you run a build. By skipping caching, you can:

title: Using conditional caching with dynamic keys
body: Avoid saving potentially incorrect build data in the cache.

title: Using conditional caching with dynamic keys
body: Make the PR validation workflow faster.

title: Using conditional caching with dynamic keys
body: Limit the amount of data stored and transferred.

title: Using conditional caching with dynamic keys
body: If the cached content did not change during your build at all, the Save cache Step can automatically skip compressing and uploading the cache. To make this work, you need to make sure your cache archive has a unique cache key that changes whenever the contents of the cache change: in practice, this requires a dynamic key with a checksum and a file that describes the cached content. The checksum will be calculated based on the contents of the file; if the file remains unchanged, so does the checksum.

title: Using conditional caching with dynamic keys
body: We strongly recommend configuring the Step in a way to take advantage of this feature. Follow the steps below, or skip ahead to our YAML example.

title: Using conditional caching with dynamic keys
body: Skipping the Save cache Step entirely

title: Using conditional caching with dynamic keys
body: If you don't wish to update the cache archive even if the content that would be cached has changed, you can either remove the Save cache Step from your Workflow or you can set conditions for the Step: Enabling or disabling a Step conditionally.

title: Using conditional caching with dynamic keys
body: Open your app on Bitrise.

title: Using conditional caching with dynamic keys
body: Click the Workflows button on the main page.

title: Using conditional caching with dynamic keys
body: Open your Workflow and select the Save cache Step.

title: Using conditional caching with dynamic keys
body: Set the Unique cache key input to true.

title: Using conditional caching with dynamic keys
body: If the input is set to false, the Step can still skip uploading the cache but it will need to create the cache archive first to calculate its checksum. This takes time.

title: Using conditional caching with dynamic keys
body: In the Cache key input, create a key with a checksum for a file that describes the cached content.

title: Using conditional caching with dynamic keys
body: For example, npm-cache-{{ checksum "package-lock.json" }} is a dynamic key that remains unchanged as long as the package-lock.json file does not change.

title: Using conditional caching with dynamic keys
body: Add the same dynamic key to the Cache keys input of the Restore cache Step.

title: Using conditional caching with dynamic keys
body: If everything is configured correctly, if the keys in the two caching Steps match, the cache archive will not be updated.

title: Using conditional caching with dynamic keys
body: YAML example for using a dynamic key with checksum

title: Using conditional caching with dynamic keys
body: In this example, the cache key calculates the sum for any .gradle file and the gradle.properties file. Both the Restore cache and the Save cache Step looks for the same cache key:

title: Using conditional caching with dynamic keys
body:
workflows: 
 caching: 
 steps: 
 - restore-cache@1: 
 inputs: 
 - key: gradle-cache-{{ checksum "**/*.gradle*" "gradle.properties" }} 
 - save-cache@1: 
 inputs: 
 - key: gradle-cache-{{ checksum "**/*.gradle*" "gradle.properties" }} 
 - is_key_unique: 'true'

title: Accessing key-based cache archives
body: You can access your cache archives separately, without running a build. This allows you to keep track of several things:

title: Accessing key-based cache archives
body: What cache keys are associated with different cache archives.

title: Accessing key-based cache archives
body: How much storage space is taken up by your cache archives.

title: Accessing key-based cache archives
body: When each cache archive is due to expire.

title: Accessing key-based cache archives
body: In addition, you can download any cache archive - if it hasn't expired yet -, you can copy the cache keys, and you can delete archives.

title: Accessing key-based cache archives
body: To access your archives:

title: Accessing key-based cache archives
body: Admin access only

title: Accessing key-based cache archives
body: Only users with the role of admin on the app's team can access all functions of the App Settings page of an app.

title: Accessing key-based cache archives
body: Open your app on Bitrise.

title: Accessing key-based cache archives
body: On the main page of the app, click on the App Settings icon: .

title: Accessing key-based cache archives
body: On the left side, select Builds.

title: Accessing key-based cache archives
body: Scroll down to the Manage build caches section.

title: Accessing key-based cache archives
body: Select the Key-based caching tab.

title: Accessing key-based cache archives
body: You can:

title: Accessing key-based cache archives
body: Copy the cache key by clicking the Copy key icon.

title: Accessing key-based cache archives
body: Downloading the cache archive by clicking the Download icon.

title: Accessing key-based cache archives
body: Deleting the cache archive by clicking Delete icon.

title: Dedicated caching Steps for dependency managers
body: Key-based caching is powerful and flexible: you can use the Save cache and Restore cache Steps with any app, regardless of platform or the type of data you want to cache. However, these Steps require careful configuration and it is possible to make mistakes. If you are looking for a simple solution to cache dependencies of the most frequently used dependency managers, we offer dedicated Steps that require no configuration whatsoever.

title: Dedicated caching Steps for dependency managers
body: The dedicated caching Steps store their archives in the same storage space as the Save cache and Restore cache Steps but unlike those two, they automatically set up the appropriate cache paths and cache keys.

title: Dedicated caching Steps for dependency managers
body: The following dedicated Steps are available:

title: Dedicated caching Steps for dependency managers
body: Save Cocoapods Cache and Restore Cocoapods Cache

title: Dedicated caching Steps for dependency managers
body: Save SPM Cache and Restore SPM Cache

title: Dedicated caching Steps for dependency managers
body: Save NPM Cache and Restore NPM Cache

title: Dedicated caching Steps for dependency managers
body: Save Gradle Cache and Restore Gradle Cache

title: Dedicated caching Steps for dependency managers
body: Save Carthage Cache and Restore Carthage Cache

title: Dedicated caching Steps for dependency managers
body: Save Dart Cache and Restore Dart Cache

title: Dedicated caching Steps for dependency managers
body: To use these Steps, simply add the Restore version to the start of your Workflow and the Save version to the end of your Workflow. No other configuration is needed.

title: Branch-based caching
body: In branch-based (legacy) caching, every branch of your repository on which you run a build will have its own cache archive. You can only use a cache archive on the same stack it was generated on. The cache is stored as a single archive file: if the content of the cached paths changes in any way, the entire file gets updated.

title: Branch-based caching
body: Build cache expiry

title: Branch-based caching
body: The build cache, related to a specific branch, expires after seven days which means it is automatically deleted - but only if there’s no new build on that branch in the meantime. This means that if you do builds on a specific branch more frequently than a week, the cache won’t get deleted. If you don’t start a build on that specific branch for more than seven days, then the related cache will be deleted, and and your next build will run like the first.

title: Branch-based caching
body: The default branch cache is used as fallback

title: Branch-based caching
body: If a branch does not yet have a cache saved, the default branch’s cache will be used. Caching is not available for pull request builds of public Bitrise apps.

title: Branch-based caching
body: Every folder and file specified in the Cache paths input of the Bitrise.io Cache:Push Step gets cached, unless the Step is configured to ignore certain folders and files. In most cases, you don’t have to change the value of this input: you only need to add anything here if you want to cache files generated by a Step that doesn’t have its own caching function. A few examples of Steps with their own caching function:

title: Branch-based caching
body: Xcode Archive & Export for iOS

title: Branch-based caching
body: Android Build

title: Branch-based caching
body: Gradle Runner

title: Branch-based caching
body: Run Cocoapods install

title: Branch-based caching
body: Brew install

title: Branch-based caching
body: To find out how access the cache during builds, check out Using branch-based caching in your builds.

title: Technical notes on branch-based caching
body: The legacy, branch-based build cache feature is split into two parts:

title: Technical notes on branch-based caching
body: The Build Cache API.

title: Technical notes on branch-based caching
body: The Steps.

title: Technical notes on branch-based caching
body: The Build Cache API is a simple API. It makes sure that you have the required access rights to the resource (the build cache archive), and provides secure - time-limited and expiring - download and upload URLs. It does not process the files.

title: Technical notes on branch-based caching
body: The Steps are responsible for executing the logic of comparing caches and creating the cache archives. This means that you can write your own Steps and implement your own comparison and compression logic. The only requirement is that the Step has to use the Build Cache API to get download and upload URLs. There’s no restriction on the cache file format or on its content.

title: Technical notes on branch-based caching
body: Read more about developing your own Step in our dedicated guide: Developing a new Step.

title: Technical notes on branch-based caching
body: The cache might not be available

title: Technical notes on branch-based caching
body: It’s always a good idea to write your code in a way that your builds won’t fail if the cache can’t be accessed. Also keep in mind that the cache is downloaded over the internet. Storing a resource or dependency in Bitrise build cache might help if you have reliability issues with the usual download location but it doesn't necessarily save you time.

title: Using branch-based caching in your builds
body: You can use two dedicated Bitrise Steps for caching: Bitrise.io Cache Pull to tap into the cache and use the contents of it in your build, and Bitrise.io Cache Push to store information from your build in the cache.

title: Using branch-based caching in your builds
body: Branch-based caching vs key-based caching

title: Using branch-based caching in your builds
body: This guide is is about legacy, branch-based caching. For key-based caching, check out our in-depth guide: Key-based caching.

title: Using branch-based caching in your builds
body: You can read about our dedicated key-based caching Steps here: Dedicated caching Steps for dependency managers.

title: Using branch-based caching in your builds
body: The basics of using the cache in your builds are simple and it can work out of the box, depending on your Workflows: you just have to use the two dedicated Steps.

title: Using branch-based caching in your builds
body: Add the Bitrise.io Cache:Pull Step right before you need the cache.

title: Using branch-based caching in your builds
body: For example, in the case of an iOS app, you can insert the Bitrise.io Cache:Pull Step between the Git Clone Repository and the dependency installer Steps (such as the Run CocoaPods install or the Carthage Steps). You should not put the Bitrise.io Cache:Pull Step BEFORE the Git Clone Repository Step.

title: Using branch-based caching in your builds
body: Build cache expiry

title: Using branch-based caching in your builds
body: The build cache, related to a specific branch, expires after seven days which means it is automatically deleted - but only if there’s no new build on that branch in the meantime. This means that if you do builds on a specific branch more frequently than a week, the cache won’t get deleted. If you don’t start a build on that specific branch for more than seven days, then the related cache will be deleted, and and your next build will run like the first.

title: Using branch-based caching in your builds
body: Add the Bitrise.io Cache:Push Step as the last Step of the Workflow.

title: Using branch-based caching in your builds
body: For simple use cases, that’s it, that’s all you have to do. These Steps work out of the box alongside Steps with their own caching function. But if you wish to learn more and create your own caching configuration, read on!

title: Using branch-based caching in your builds
body: Pull request builds

title: Using branch-based caching in your builds
body: By default, if you run a build that is triggered by a pull request, the Bitrise.io Cache:Push Step won’t work: in this case, a pull request build can only read the build cache but can’t update it!

title: Using branch-based caching in your builds
body: We strongly recommend that you do not change this! From a security perspective, the best practice is to never allow pull request builds to alter anything that can affect other Bitrise builds.

title: Using branch-based caching in your builds
body: If you absolutely must change it, you need to use a run_if expression in the app’s bitrise.yml file. Read more about run_if expressions: Enabling or disabling a Step conditionally.

title: Using branch-based caching in your builds
body: You can find example build cache configurations/guides at our build-cache discuss page.

title: Including files and folders in the build cache
body: As mentioned before, every file and folder specified in the Bitrise.io Cache:Push Step’s Cache paths input gets cached, unless the Step is configured to ignore certain folders and files. In most cases, you don’t have to change this input. If you use Steps that have their own in-built caching function, you don’t have to worry about specifying files and folders unless you have a specific use case.

title: Including files and folders in the build cache
body: To check whether a Step has a caching function, take a look at their inputs. If there’s no input to turn caching on and off, the Step in question doesn’t have its own caching function.

title: Including files and folders in the build cache
body: To include files from Steps that do not have their own caching function:

title: Including files and folders in the build cache
body: In your Workflow, open the Bitrise.io Cache:Push Step.

title: Including files and folders in the build cache
body: Find the Cache paths input.

title: Including files and folders in the build cache
body: Add the path or paths for files and folders that you want to include in the cache. You can use either an absolute path, or a path relative to the root of your repository.

title: Ignoring files and dependencies
body: You can also tell the Bitrise.io Cache:Push Step to specifically ignore certain content. Ignoring means one of two things:

title: Ignoring files and dependencies
body: A file or folder isn’t checked for changes: if the specified path is included in the previous cache archive, it will be included in the new one with the same content as before.

title: Ignoring files and dependencies
body: A file or folder is completely excluded: in other words, it isn’t uploaded to the cache at all, regardless of its changes.

title: Ignoring files and dependencies
body: You can choose either option for any of your files or folders.

title: Ignoring files and dependencies
body: To ignore certain files or folders:

title: Ignoring files and dependencies
body: In your Workflow, open the Bitrise.io Cache:Push Step.

title: Ignoring files and dependencies
body: Find the Ignore Paths from change check input.

title: Ignoring files and dependencies
body: Add the path or paths for files and folders that you want to ignore. You can use either an absolute path, or a path relative to the root of your repository.

title: Ignoring files and dependencies
body: If you want to completely exclude a given path from the cache archive, prefix the path with !. For example, !my/path/.

title: Ignoring files and dependencies
body: If you want to exclude a given path from change checking, just add the path without any prefix. If a path is located inside an ignored cache path item and the path is NOT prefixed with an !, the path will be included in the cache archive, but it will not be checked for changes. For example, if you add my/path/ to the input, the path directory will be included in the archive but it will not be checked for changes.

title: Ignoring files and dependencies
body: You can, of course, specify certain patterns in the paths, too. For example:

title: Ignoring files and dependencies
body: Replacing a path element with *: a/*/b: this will match a/x/b

title: Ignoring files and dependencies
body: Replacing a part of the path with **: a/**/b will match a/x/y/z/b

title: Ignoring files and dependencies
body: Ignoring an entire directory with /. For example, /my/full/path/ ignores everything in the path folder.

title: Ignoring files and dependencies
body: Ignoring paths

title: Ignoring files and dependencies
body: You can’t ignore a path which results in an invalid cache item. For example, if you specify a/path/to/cache path to be cached, you can’t ignore a/path/to, as that would ignore every file and wouldn’t check for changes, hence no fingerprint could be generated for a/path/to/cache. This won’t fail the Step: you’ll simply receive the following warning: No path to cache, skip caching...

title: Ignoring files and dependencies
body: You can, however, ignore paths inside a cache path. For example, if your path is a/path/to/cache, you can ignore a/path/to/cache/.ignore-me, unless that’s the only file inside a/path/to/cache.

title: Downloading or deleting the build cache
body: You can download and delete build caches for every branch which generated a cache. You can check the size of the caches and the last time a given cache was used.
