title: Finding a build log
body: When you run a build, a build log is generated automatically. Every build has its own log, with its own unique build log URL. The build log URL contains the build slug: a hexadecimal identifier for a specific build.

title: Finding a build log
body: Assisting Bitrise Support

title: Finding a build log
body: When Bitrise Support asks for your build logs, the best thing to do is send the build URL.

title: Finding a build log
body: Find your app on the Dashboard, and select it.

title: Finding a build log
body: On the app's main page, select the build you want to check out.

title: Finding a build log
body: Make sure you have the Log tab selected.

title: Finding a build log
body: On the Log tab, you can see the Steps of the Workflow and their status. By default, all failed Steps are expanded.

title: Finding a build log
body: Expand any Step's info by clicking the downward arrow on the right to the Step. This will show the relevant part of the build log.

title: The build log page
body: The build log page shows all Steps that were part of the build, and their status. By default, failed Steps are expanded, with the error message highlighted for convenient troubleshooting. Expanding a Step also allows you to see:

title: The build log page
body: The start time of the Step's run.

title: The build log page
body: The Step ID. This is how the bitrise.yml configuration file identifies the Step. For more information, see Step reference/ID format.

title: The build log page
body: The current version of the Step. Underneath the version number, you can check the release notes for the Step. If the build didn't run with the latest version of the Step, you can also click Update to open the Workflow Editor and update the Step to a different version.

title: The build log page
body: Under Step resources, you can check out the Step's documentation on our Integrations page, as well as its source code and issue tracker on GitHub.

title: The build log page
body: To view a build log's contents in full, in a single file, download the log.

title: Following a build log live
body: You can check the log of a build live - that is, while the build is running. What’s more, you can even follow the log as the build is happening. That means that as the build progresses, the log will automatically scroll to the new sections as they appear.

title: Following a build log live
body: To do so:

title: Following a build log live
body: Start a build.

title: Following a build log live
body: Go to the build’s page.

title: Following a build log live
body: Scroll down to the log.

title: Following a build log live
body: Click Follow.

title: Following a build log live
body: To stop following, you just need to manually navigate anywhere within the log. You can restart following any time.

title: Downloading a build log
body: If you need to send your build logs to people who do not have access to the app on Bitrise, or you want to store your logs in your own archives, you can simply download the log file from Bitrise.

title: Downloading a build log
body: Log security

title: Downloading a build log
body: Please note that your build log can contain sensitive information! Make sure to check its contents before downloading the log file and sending it out to anyone. We recommend using Secrets to make sure nothing sensitive appears in build logs.

title: Downloading a build log
body: Find your app on the Dashboard, and select it.

title: Downloading a build log
body: On the app's main page, select the build you want to check out.

title: Downloading a build log
body: Open the Logs dropdown menu and click the Download logs button.

title: Deleting a build log
body: If necessary, you can delete the logs of any build on Bitrise. It can be handy if, for example, you do not want new team members to see potentially sensitive information that is displayed in previous logs.

title: Deleting a build log
body: Not all team members are authorized to delete logs: only those with either Admin or Owner role in the team can do it.

title: Deleting a build log
body: Deletion is final

title: Deleting a build log
body: Be aware that you cannot undo deleting a log. Once you delete it, there is no way to recover the log file.

title: Deleting a build log
body: Find your app on the Dashboard, and select it.

title: Deleting a build log
body: On the app's main page, select the build you want to check out.

title: Deleting a build log
body: Open the Logs dropdown menu and click the Delete Logs button.

title: Deleting a build log
body: In the pop-up window, click Delete logs.

title: Remote access
body: Remote access allows users to connect to their build’s virtual machines via SSH or a screenshare app, which you can access from your build's Build details page.

title: Remote access
body: Remote access allows users to connect to their build’s virtual machines via SSH or a screenshare app. A failed build can be rebuilt with remote access enabled to make troubleshooting a lot easier - for example, if the build logs don’t provide enough information about the error.

title: Remote access
body: Authorization

title: Remote access
body: Users who have the Testers/QA roles on the app CANNOT use remote access.

title: Remote access
body: There are two ways to use remote access on our build machines:

title: Remote access
body: SSH: this is available for both Linux/Docker based and MacOS machines.

title: Remote access
body: Screenshare: this is only available for MacOS machines. It uses the VNC system.

title: Remote access
body: With either method, you can access the build machine remotely during the build and for 10 minutes after the build is finished.

title: Remote access
body: Extending the availability of remote access

title: Remote access
body: If you would like to extend the availability of remote access, you can do so by adding a simple custom Script Step after the failed Step. Check out Extending the availability of remote access for more information.

title: Remote access with SSH
body: To access a Bitrise build machine with SSH, you will need a command line interface and the correct command and password:

title: Remote access with SSH
body: Open the app on Bitrise.

title: Remote access with SSH
body: On the main page of the app, find the build you want to re-run with remote access and click it.

title: Remote access with SSH
body: On the Rebuild button, click the downward arrow to open the dropdown menu.

title: Remote access with SSH
body: Select Rebuild with remote access. This starts a new build that you can access remotely.

title: Remote access with SSH
body: In the SSH section, find the Command and run it in a command line interface.

title: Remote access with SSH
body: And done! You should be able to access the virtual machine where your build is running.

title: Remote access with screenshare
body: To access a Bitrise build machine with a screenshare app, you will need the correct username, password, and address, as well as a VNC screenshare app:

title: Remote access with screenshare
body: macOS only

title: Remote access with screenshare
body: Remote access with screenshare is only available for Workflows that run on a macOS-based stack. If the Workflow's stack (or in absence of Workflow-specific stacks, the app's default stack) is a Linux-based one, you won't see the screenshare instructions at all.

title: Remote access with screenshare
body: Open the app on Bitrise.

title: Remote access with screenshare
body: On the main page of the app, find the build you want to re-run with remote access and click it.

title: Remote access with screenshare
body: On the Rebuild button, click the downward arrow to open the dropdown menu.

title: Remote access with screenshare
body: Select Rebuild with remote access. This starts a new build that you can access remotely.

title: Remote access with screenshare
body: Under the Screenshare option, find the required information:

title: Remote access with screenshare
body: Address

title: Remote access with screenshare
body: Username

title: Remote access with screenshare
body: Password

title: Remote access with screenshare
body: Open a VNC screenshare application.

title: Remote access with screenshare
body: The simplest option is using the default Screen Sharing application on macOS.

title: Remote access with screenshare
body: Fill out the required fields with the information from under the Screenshare option.

title: Remote access with screenshare
body: And done! You should now be able to access the virtual machine where your build is running.

title: Finding your files on the VM
body: Once you successfully logged in to the Bitrise virtual machine that ran your build, you can dive into the files themselves to see what’s happening in real time. After Bitrise finished cloning your app on to the VM, you can always access it at the following location:

title: Finding your files on the VM
body: /Users/Vagrant/git

title: Extending the availability of remote access
body: Remote access is available while the build is running and for 10 minutes after the build is finished. If this is not enough, there’s a simple workaround to make sure remote access is available for a longer time.

title: Extending the availability of remote access
body: Add a Script Step after the Step that causes the build to fail.

title: Extending the availability of remote access
body: Toggle the Run if previous Step failed option on to ensure the Script Step always runs.

title: Extending the availability of remote access
body: Add a command to let the build “sleep” for a time specified in seconds:

title: Extending the availability of remote access
body: sleep 5400

title: Extending the availability of remote access
body: This example lets the build run for 90 minutes. It should be no more than your build time limit, of course.

title: Extending the availability of remote access
body: That’s it. While the build is still running, you can look around on the virtual machine for the possible issues that caused it to fail.

title: Debugging your build on your own machine
body: If your build fails on Bitrise, we often recommend to try and run it locally. To debug: use a full clean git clone, and run the build on your machine with the Bitrise CLI.

title: Debugging your build on your own machine
body: If your build fails on Bitrise, we often recommend to try and run it locally, on your machine. To do this, do the following:

title: Debugging your build on your own machine
body: Do a full clean git clone of your project’s online repository.

title: Debugging your build on your own machine
body: Run the build on your machine with the Bitrise CLI.

title: Debugging your build on your own machine
body: This helps to eliminate, among other things, a very common issue: that uncommitted or gitignored files are in your working directory but they haven’t been committed into your git repository online and therefore they are not available when Bitrise clones the repository for running the build. Other possible issues include:

title: Debugging your build on your own machine
body: Code signing files are present on your local machine but not uploaded to Bitrise.

title: Debugging your build on your own machine
body: A difference in the version of the tool(s) used for the build.

title: Testing with a full clean git clone
body: Open your Terminal / Command Line interface on your machine.

title: Testing with a full clean git clone
body: Type in: cd /tmp

title: Testing with a full clean git clone
body: Clone your repository with: git clone REPOURL ./quick-repo-test --branch BRANCH-YOU-WANT-TO-TEST:

title: Testing with a full clean git clone
body: git clone https://github.com/bitrise-io/bitrise.git ./quick-repo-test --branch master

title: Testing with a full clean git clone
body: Type cd ./quick-repo-test.

title: Testing with a full clean git clone
body: Run the commands you want to test, to build your project, or to open the project file from this directory.

title: Testing with the Bitrise CLI
body: After doing a full clean git clone, run a build locally, using the Bitrise CLI.

title: Testing with the Bitrise CLI
body: Install the Bitrise CLI.

title: Testing with the Bitrise CLI
body: Download your app’s bitrise.yml file from bitrise.io.

title: Testing with the Bitrise CLI
body: Run the build with: bitrise run <workflow-name> (for example, bitrise run primary).

title: Testing with the Bitrise CLI
body: This should help reproducing the issues in most cases, and allows you to attempt to debug them on your own machine.

title: Testing with the Bitrise CLI
body: If the build succeeds under these conditions but still fails on Bitrise, contact our support!

title: Debugging your build on your own machine
body: Android projects

title: Debugging your build on your own machine
body: If you still can’t reproduce the issue locally, you might also want to delete the $HOME/.gradle (hidden) directory, to clear your Gradle caches. (Quick Terminal / Command Line command: rm -rf $HOME/.gradle).

title: Debugging your build on your own machine
body: Run docker from a clean git clone

title: Debugging your build on your own machine
body: If your project uses the Android/Linux environment, you can download and use the exact same environment as the one your build is running in on bitrise.io.

title: Debugging your build on your own machine
body: Ideally, you should first do a clean git clone and run docker from there, so that files which are in your .gitignore won’t affect the build, and the build can run the the same way as on bitrise.io.

title: Bitrise Checks on GitHub
body: Bitrise Checks is a Github app which provides an extended version of the classic status checks Bitrise sends back to GitHub.

title: Bitrise Checks on GitHub
body: Bitrise Checks is a Github app which provides an extended version of the classic status checks Bitrise sends back to GitHub. Bitrise Checks include a Bitrise build summary and a check status. You can view Bitrise Checks if you click the Details link of a pull request on GitHub. It unfolds the detailed build summary and build status Bitrise Checks attaches to your pull request on the Checks tab of GitHub.

title: Bitrise Checks on GitHub
body: GitHub Enterprise Server is not supported

title: Bitrise Checks on GitHub
body: Bitrise Checks is not supported in GitHub Enterprise Server deployments. If you would like to use Bitrise Checks in a GitHub Enterprise environment, we recommend using GitHub Enterprise Cloud.

title: Bitrise Checks on GitHub
body: There can be three different check statuses:

title: Bitrise Checks on GitHub
body: Success.

title: Bitrise Checks on GitHub
body: Failed.

title: Bitrise Checks on GitHub
body: Action required (in the case of manual pull request approval).

title: Installing Bitrise Checks
body: Using Bitrise Checks is just a few clicks away. Let’s do this!

title: Installing Bitrise Checks
body: Admin access only

title: Installing Bitrise Checks
body: Only users with the role of admin on the app's team can access all functions of the App Settings page of an app.

title: Installing Bitrise Checks
body: Open your app on Bitrise.

title: Installing Bitrise Checks
body: On the main page of the app, click on the App Settings icon: .

title: Installing Bitrise Checks
body: On the left, select Integrations from the menu options.

title: Installing Bitrise Checks
body: Click the install our Bitrise Checks app to your GitHub repository LINK under the toggle. Don’t toggle the switch just yet, since you first need to install Bitrise Checks.

title: Installing Bitrise Checks
body: This link will take you to GitHub's Bitrise Checks installation page.

title: Installing Bitrise Checks
body: On the Install Bitrise Checks page, select the user or GitHub Organization you want to add Bitrise Checks to.

title: Installing Bitrise Checks
body: Decide if you wish to install Bitrise Checks to all your repositories or just to a selected few. With this you grant rights to Bitrise Checks to integrate with your repository and use GitHub Checks to display check results.

title: Installing Bitrise Checks
body: In the GitHub prompt, provide your GitHub password.

title: Installing Bitrise Checks
body: If all goes well, you land on the Bitrise Checks page of GitHub. You should see a blue note at the top-left corner of the page that Bitrise Checks has been successfully installed on your GitHub account.

title: Enabling GitHub Checks on Bitrise
body: Once Bitrise Checks is installed on GitHub, you need to enable GitHub Checks on your app’s page on Bitrise.

title: Enabling GitHub Checks on Bitrise
body: Enabling GitHub Checks is limited

title: Enabling GitHub Checks on Bitrise
body: Please note that only Workspace owners and app admins can enable this toggle on the App Settings page of the app.

title: Enabling GitHub Checks on Bitrise
body: Admin access only

title: Enabling GitHub Checks on Bitrise
body: Only users with the role of admin on the app's team can access all functions of the App Settings page of an app.

title: Enabling GitHub Checks on Bitrise
body: Open your app on Bitrise.

title: Enabling GitHub Checks on Bitrise
body: On the main page of the app, click on the App Settings icon: .

title: Enabling GitHub Checks on Bitrise
body: On the left, select Integrations from the menu options.

title: Enabling GitHub Checks on Bitrise
body: Scroll down and toggle on the GitHub Checks switch.

title: Enabling GitHub Checks on Bitrise
body: Can't toggle the switch?

title: Enabling GitHub Checks on Bitrise
body: If you can't toggle the switch, check out Can't enable GitHub Checks.

title: Enabling GitHub Checks on Bitrise
body: And you’re done! Now any pull request you open to your app on GitHub will be validated with Bitrise Checks and a build will get automatically started on Bitrise (if the pull request trigger is properly set on Bitrise).

title: Enabling GitHub Checks on Bitrise
body: You can easily get to your app’s page on Bitrise. If you click on the build summary or on View more details on Bitrise Checks link on the Checks tab, you’ll quickly get to your app’s Build page.

title: Can't enable GitHub Checks
body: There are two main reasons why you might not be able to toggle the switch to enable GitHub Checks:

title: Can't enable GitHub Checks
body: You cannot toggle the switch unless you install Bitrise Checks FIRST. Once it’s done, you can go ahead and toggle the switch to the right to enable it.

title: Can't enable GitHub Checks
body: If you have renamed or moved the GitHub repository of an app which has already been added to Bitrise and you have installed Bitrise Checks on it. The repository’s GitHub URL has obviously changed. GitHub Checks switch can only work if the URL on Github and on Bitrise fully match (no redirect URL is allowed). So in this case, you have to manually update the Repository URL of your app.

title: Switching to Bitrise Checks from previous CI checks
body: If you have been already using status checks on pull requests prior to merging, it must have been the ci/bitrise/... check system. To be able to use Bitrise Checks, you have to manually switch from ci/bitrise/... to Bitrise to access those detailed checks. Let’s see how!

title: Switching to Bitrise Checks from previous CI checks
body: Go to the Settings tab of your repository.

title: Switching to Bitrise Checks from previous CI checks
body: Click Branches on the side menu. Under Require status checks to pass before merging, you can see ci/bitrise/... as the selected checks system.

title: Switching to Bitrise Checks from previous CI checks
body: Select Bitrise instead of ci/bitrise/....

title: Switching to Bitrise Checks from previous CI checks
body: Merge a pull request.

title: Disabling GitHub Checks
body: You can easily disable GitHub Checks on Bitrise if you toggle the ENABLE GITHUB CHECKS switch to the left on the Settings page of the app.

title: Disabling GitHub Checks
body: If you decide to uninstall Bitrise Checks from your GitHub account, you can click the Uninstall button on the Install GitHub Apps page.

title: GitHub Checks test summary
body: If your app’s repository contains any UI or unit tests, you can run those tests by using the appropriate testing Steps in your Workflow, and if you add the Deploy to Bitrise.io Step, your test results will be displayed in our Test Reports page and you can also see them on GitHub Checks, too.

title: GitHub Checks test summary
body: For example, if you have an Android app, you can use the Virtual Unit Testing for Android Step to be able to see all your test results on GitHub Checks.

title: Step by Step error report
body: If a CI build runs, GitHub Checks' test summary displays the Steps' successful and failed tests in separate tabs on the left sidebar. If you click on a Step, a more detailed report summary comes up where a number of tests are listed with actionable error report. The build summary is available on the Bitrise tab.

title: Step by Step error report
body: Please note that GitHub Checks' test summary can only print detailed information of the following Steps:

title: Step by Step error report
body: Xcode Test for iOS

title: Step by Step error report
body: Android Unit Test

title: Step by Step error report
body: iOS Device Testing

title: Step by Step error report
body: Virtual Device Testing for Android

title: Step by Step error report
body: Flutter Test

title: Step by Step error report
body: You can export test results generated by any other Step to the Deploy to Bitrise.io Step in two ways:

title: Step by Step error report
body: We strongly recommend using our Export test results to the Test reports add-on Step: this Step locates the test results based on your inputs.

title: Step by Step error report
body: You can configure your own custom Script Step that creates and exports the necessary files.

title: Checking the test results of a failed Step
body: If your build has some failed tests, here is how to access them in GitHub Checks:

title: Checking the test results of a failed Step
body: Click the Bitrise Checks dropdown.

title: Checking the test results of a failed Step
body: Click on a Step and view the error report of the specific Step.

title: Checking the test results of a failed Step
body: You can click on other Steps from here or the build summary. The View more details on Bitrise Checks link takes you to the build page on Bitrise.

title: Re-running a build using GitHub checks
body: Role requirement

title: Re-running a build using GitHub checks
body: To re-run a build using GitHub Checks, your GitHub account must connected to Bitrise, and you need to have at least Developer role in your app's team. If these conditions are not met, re-run checks will fail without an error.

title: Re-running a build using GitHub checks
body: For a complete list of user roles and role cheatsheets, check User roles on app teams.

title: Re-running a build using GitHub checks
body: If you would like to re-run a build using GitHub Checks:

title: Re-running a build using GitHub checks
body: Open the pull request on GitHub where you would like to re-run checks.

title: Re-running a build using GitHub checks
body: Open the Checks tab.

title: Re-running a build using GitHub checks
body: Click Re-run all checks.

title: Meercode
body: The Meercode add-on was sunset on February 1, 2023. Check out Bitrise Insights as a free alternative to monitor your build, test, and credit data.

title: Meercode
body: Meercode deprecation notice

title: Meercode
body: The Meercode add-on was sunset on February 1, 2023. Check out Bitrise Insights as a free alternative to monitor your build, test, and credit data.

title: Checking build details
body: You can find additional details about a specific build by accessing the build's Details & Add-ons tab.

title: Checking build details
body: You can find additional details about a specific build by accessing the build's Details & Add-ons tab.

title: Checking build details
body: To do so:

title: Checking build details
body: Find your app on the Dashboard, and select it.

title: Checking build details
body: On the app's main page, select the build you want to check out.

title: Checking build details
body: Select the Details & Add-ons tab.

title: Checking build details
body: Accessing this tab, you can find the following information about your build:

title: Checking build details
body: Triggered at: The exact time the build was triggered, and the trigger's source (e.g., webhook or a person)

title: Checking build details
body: Started at: The exact time the build started. This is usually a few seconds after the trigger.

title: Checking build details
body: Finished at: The exact time the build was finished.

title: Checking build details
body: Pull request description: If the build was initiated by a pull request, you will see the details here, otherwise this field is hidden.

title: Checking build details
body: Parameters: Information about the cloned git branch, such as commit message, branch name, commit hash, etc.

title: Checking build details
body: Tags: Your subscription plan, whether the build was scheduled, and the stack and machine type can all be found here.

title: Checking build details
body: Add-ons

title: Checking build details
body: In this tab next to the build details, you can see and access all available Add-ons. Accessing your Add-ons from here is the same as if you would open them from your app's Add-ons tab.

title: Code signing
body: During a Bitrise build, you can digitally sign your app regardless of platform. Bitrise has dedicated Steps for both Android and iOS code signing procedures.

title: Code signing
body: Code signing is the process of digitally signing your app, as a means of guaranteeing that the code has not been altered since signing. It provides security for deployment, and identifies the author.

title: Code signing
body: To deploy mobile apps to an online store, such as Google Play or the App Store, code signing is absolutely crucial. On Bitrise, we tried to make it as easy and convenient as possible.

title: iOS code signing
body: Every iOS app, native or cross-platform, needs code signing. At the minimum, two files are required:

title: iOS code signing
body: A provisioning profile.

title: iOS code signing
body: A signing certificate.

title: Automatic and manual code signing asset management
body: Bitrise supports automatic and manual code signing asset management:

title: Automatic and manual code signing asset management
body: The Steps, that support automatic code signing asset management, automatically download provisioning profiles and fix common issues through an already set up API key or Apple ID connection.

title: Automatic and manual code signing asset management
body: For manual code signing asset management, you have to manually upload the code signing certificate and provisioning profile to Bitrise and add the Certificate and Profile Installer Step along with a build Step.

title: Android code signing
body: Android code signing can be handled via our dedicated Step, via Android Studio, or in your Gradle configuration.

title: Android code signing
body: To sign an Android app, you will need a keystore file which requires a Google Play Developer account, and Google Play API access.

title: Android code signing
body: Before you distribute your Android app through Google Play Store, your APK or AAB file must be digitally signed. You can use the dedicated Bitrise Step or perform code signing with a Gradle configuration.

title: Android code signing
body: Before you distribute your app through Google Play Store, your APK file must be digitally signed.

title: Android code signing
body: You can specify the code signing configuration for your project in Android Studio or manually in your Gradle configuration. You can also use the Android Sign Step in your Bitrise Workflow Editor to have your APK signed automatically.

title: Android code signing using the Android Sign Step
body: You can create a signed APK using the Android Sign Step in your Bitrise Workflow. This Step is configured to run if you have already uploaded your keystore file on the Code signing tab of the Workflow Editor.

title: Android code signing using the Android Sign Step
body: You can create a signed APK using the Android Sign Step in your Bitrise Workflow. This Step is configured to run if you have already uploaded your keystore file on the Code Signing tab of the Workflow Editor.

title: Android code signing using the Android Sign Step
body: The Android Sign Step is not required if signing is configured in your project’s build.gradle file. If so, running the Android Build Step (or the Gradle Runner Step) signs the output (APK or AAB) automatically. Nevertheless, we recommend that you use the Android Sign Step to sign your project in an easy and secure way.

title: Android code signing using the Android Sign Step
body: jarsign and apksigner

title: Android code signing using the Android Sign Step
body: APKs can be signed with either jarsigner or apksigner. For APKs, if you wish to use apksigner to sign your project, then in the Android Sign Step you have to first set the Enables apksigner input to true and leave the APK Signature Scheme input on automatic. This way apksigner checks your APK’s minimum and target SDK versions and chooses the required schemes. It signs your project with V1 scheme if your minimum supported version is low and it also signs with other schemes for newer systems.

title: Android code signing using the Android Sign Step
body: Please note that AAB files can only be signed with jarsigner. The Step uses jarsigner if it detects a file ending with .aab

title: Android code signing using the Android Sign Step
body: Open your app on Bitrise.

title: Android code signing using the Android Sign Step
body: Click the Workflows button on the main page.

title: Android code signing using the Android Sign Step
body: Go to Code Signing > Android Code Signing.

title: Android code signing using the Android Sign Step
body: Drag-and-drop your keystore file to the Upload file field of the ANDROID KEYSTORE FILE section.

title: Android code signing using the Android Sign Step
body: A keystore URL automatically gets generated once you upload the keystore file. Bitrise assigns an Environment Variable (BITRISEIO_ANDROID_KEYSTORE_URL) to the download URL (which is a time-limited, read-only download URL) of the file as the value. No need to download it manually as the Android Sign Step downloads it automatically.

title: Android code signing using the Android Sign Step
body: Fill out the displayed three input fields with your credentials:

title: Android code signing using the Android Sign Step
body: Keystore password

title: Android code signing using the Android Sign Step
body: Keystore alias

title: Android code signing using the Android Sign Step
body: Private key password

title: Android code signing using the Android Sign Step
body: Click Save metadata.

title: Android code signing using the Android Sign Step
body: When you have successfully uploaded a keystore file to the ANDROID KEYSTORE FILE section, Bitrise will automatically export the following Environment Variables based on your input:

title: Android code signing using the Android Sign Step
body: $BITRISEIO_ANDROID_KEYSTORE_ALIAS

title: Android code signing using the Android Sign Step
body: $BITRISEIO_ANDROID_KEYSTORE_PASSWORD

title: Android code signing using the Android Sign Step
body: $BITRISEIO_ANDROID_KEYSTORE_PRIVATE_KEY_PASSWORD

title: Android code signing using the Android Sign Step
body: $BITRISEIO_ANDROID_KEYSTORE_URL

title: Android code signing using the Android Sign Step
body: Add the Android Sign Step to your Workflow after the Step that builds your APK or AAB file.

title: Android code signing using the Android Sign Step
body: Bitrise uses the above Environment Variables and sets them as inputs into the respective fields of the Android Sign Step. Once the Step runs, it produces either a signed APK or an AAB. The signed APK or AAB is used in deploy Steps, for example, the Google Play Deploy Step or the Deploy to Bitrise.io Step. The latter deploys the APK/AAB on the Artifacts tab. You can also use Ship to deploy your app once you built an APK/AAB file.

title: Android code signing using the Android Sign Step
body: Downloading your keystore file

title: Android code signing using the Android Sign Step
body: You can download your keystore file to the project directory from the ANDROID KEYSTORE FILE section using the File Downloader Step:

title: Android code signing using the Android Sign Step
body:
- file-downloader:
 inputs:
 - source: $BITRISEIO_ANDROID_KEYSTORE_URL
 - destination: "$HOME/keystores/my_keystore.jks" #native android#

title: Android code signing using the Android Sign Step
body: If a Step requires the keystore file, make sure to include that Step AFTER the File Downloader Step.

title: Android code signing using the Android Sign Step
body: After this Step, my_keystore.jks will be available at $HOME/keystores/my_keystore.jks.

title: Android code signing with Android Studio
body: You can specify the code signing configuration for your project in Android Studio before running a Bitrise build. You will need a keystore file, a key alias and a key password.

title: Android code signing with Android Studio
body: You can specify the code signing configuration for your project in Android Studio. You will need a keystore file, a key alias and a key password - have these ready before you start the procedure!

title: Android code signing with Android Studio
body: Open Android Studio.

title: Android code signing with Android Studio
body: Go to Project navigator.

title: Android code signing with Android Studio
body: Select your project and open Module Settings.

title: Android code signing with Android Studio
body: From Modules, select your module.

title: Android code signing with Android Studio
body: On the Signing tab, fill out the signing information. In our example, we used the following values:

title: Android code signing with Android Studio

title: Android code signing in Gradle

title: Android code signing in Gradle

title: Downloading a keystore file
body: You can define the location of the keystore file of an Android app in your build.gradle file. If the keystore file itself is missing from the location, you can use one of our file downloading Steps to download the keystore file from Bitrise and put it in the defined location.

title: Downloading a keystore file
body: A keystore file is required for Android code signing. You can define the location of the keystore file of an Android app in your build.gradle file. If the keystore file itself is missing from the location, you can use one of our file downloading Steps to download the keystore file from Bitrise and put it in the defined location.

title: Downloading a keystore file
body: Bitrise has two Steps which download files from the Code Signing tab. Which one to use in your workflow depends on where you uploaded your keystore file in the Code Signing tab:

title: Downloading a keystore file
body: File Downloader Step: If you have uploaded your keystore file to the ANDROID KEYSTORE FILE section, which is the recommended place for your keystore file, this is the Step you should use. Once the file is uploaded, Bitrise assigns an Environment Variable (BITRISEIO_ANDROID_KEYSTORE_URL) to the download URL (which is a time-limited, read-only download URL) of the file as the value.

title: Downloading a keystore file
body: Generic File Storage Step: If you have uploaded your keystore file to the GENERIC FILE STORAGE section on the Code Signing tab, this is the Step you should use. Bitrise assigns an Environment Variable ($GENERIC_FILE_STORAGE) to the download URL (which is a time-limited, read-only download URL) of the file as the value. If you use an Environment Variable in your build.gradle file, you can use a Script Step to overwrite the Environment Variable’s value with the destination path defined in the $GENERIC_FILE_STORAGE Environment Variable. Make sure you use envman and not just a simple export.

title: Downloading a keystore file
body: Add either the File Downloader or the Generic File Storage Step to your workflow. The Step should be added BEFORE the Gradle Runner Step.

title: Downloading a keystore file
body: If you use the File Downloader Step, fill out the following 2 input fields:

title: Downloading a keystore file
body: Download source url: Set the generated keystore URL you get when you upload your file to the ANDROID KEYSTORE FILE section of the Code Signing tab).

title: Downloading a keystore file
body: Download destination path: Set the location of the keystore file as a relative path. This path should be the same as the keystore path already defined in your build.gradle file (for example, $HOME/keystores/project_release.keystore).

title: Downloading a keystore file
body: Add the Gradle Runner Step right after your file downloading Step.

title: Downloading a keystore file
body: With that said, if you have successfully added the Steps to download your keystore file to the same location that you specified in your build.gradle file, you do not need the Android Sign Step in your workflow. Our Gradle Runner Step will sign and assemble your project.

title: iOS code signing
body: To install your iOS app on a new device or to distribute your app to App Store, you will need to provide code signing files. The code signing of iOS projects requires signing certificates issued by Apple and provisioning profile file(s) matching your project.

title: Collecting and exporting code signing files with codesigndoc
body: The open source codesigndoc tool runs a clean Xcode Archive on your Mac, and analyzes the generated archive file. It collects the code signing settings that Xcode used during the archive process, and prints the list of the required code signing files. You can also search for, export and upload these files using codesigndoc.

title: Collecting and exporting code signing files with codesigndoc
body: The open source codesigndoc tool runs a clean Xcode Archive on your Mac, and analyzes the generated archive file. It collects the code signing settings that Xcode used during the archive process, and prints the list of the required code signing files. You can also search for, export and upload these files using codesigndoc.

title: Collecting and exporting code signing files with codesigndoc
body: If your project contains UITest targets, codesigndoc can scan for those, too. It runs the xcodebuild build-for-testing action to create a test-Runner.app, and exports the necessary code signing files.

title: Collecting and uploading the files with codesigndoc
body: You can use codesigndoc for:

title: Collecting and uploading the files with codesigndoc
body: Xcode projects.

title: Collecting and uploading the files with codesigndoc
body: The app does not have to be a native iOS app: you can use the tool with an app built with a third-party framework, such as Flutter, if you have an .xcodeproj or .xcworkspace file.

title: Collecting and uploading the files with codesigndoc
body: You can install the latest version of codesigndoc with a simple one-liner or you can manually download and install the specific version you want to use:

title: Collecting and uploading the files with codesigndoc
body: In the below example, we’ll use the one-liners.

title: Collecting and uploading the files with codesigndoc
body: Open the Terminal.

title: Collecting and uploading the files with codesigndoc
body: Go to your project’s folder.

title: Collecting and uploading the files with codesigndoc
body: Enter the appropriate one-liner command, depending on your project type.

title: Collecting and uploading the files with codesigndoc
body: For a Xcode project:

title: Collecting and uploading the files with codesigndoc
body: bash -l -c "$(curl -sfL https://raw.githubusercontent.com/bitrise-io/codesigndoc/master/_scripts/install_wrap-xcode.sh)"

title: Collecting and uploading the files with codesigndoc
body: The tool will automatically scan your project and look for a .xcodeproj or .xcworkspace file and do the rest.

title: Collecting and uploading the files with codesigndoc
body: If the scanner does not find the files, open your Finder.app and drag-and-drop your project’s .xcodeproj or .xcworkspace file into the command line in your Terminal.

title: Collecting and uploading the files with codesigndoc
body: Once the code signing files are collected, codesigndoc will ask if you wish to upload the files to Bitrise:

title: Collecting and uploading the files with codesigndoc
body: Do you want to upload the provisioning profiles and certificates to Bitrise? [yes/no] :

title: Collecting and uploading the files with codesigndoc
body: If you wish to upload the files with codesigndoc, type yes and press Enter.

title: Collecting and uploading the files with codesigndoc
body: Provide your Bitrise access token:

title: Collecting and uploading the files with codesigndoc
body:
Please copy your personal access token to Bitrise.
(To acquire a Personal Access Token for your user, sign in with that user on bitrise.io,
go to your Account Settings page, and select the Security tab on the left side.) :

title: Collecting and uploading the files with codesigndoc
body: Select the Bitrise project as a target for the collected files:

title: Collecting and uploading the files with codesigndoc
body:
Fetching your application list from Bitrise...
Select the app which you want to upload the provisioning profiles
Please select from the list:

title: Collecting and uploading the files with codesigndoc
body: That’s all, you are done!

title: Scanning for UITest targets
body: If your Xcode project has UITest targets, you can use codesigndoc to export the necessary code signing files and generate an .xctestrun file. You need to do this if you want to run UI tests on real devices with the help of Bitrise - for example, with the iOS Device Testing Step.

title: Scanning for UITest targets
body: Make sure you have a scheme that has a valid UITest target that is enabled.

title: Scanning for UITest targets
body: Open the Terminal.

title: Scanning for UITest targets
body: Use our one-liner to launch the scanner and export the required code signing files:

title: Scanning for UITest targets
body: bash -l -c "$(curl -sfL https://raw.githubusercontent.com/bitrise-tools/codesigndoc/master/_scripts/install_wrap-xcode-uitests.sh)"

title: Scanning for UITest targets
body: This command runs the xcodebuild build-for-testing action to create a UITest runner .app file, and exports the necessary code signing files.

title: Scanning for UITest targets
body: Upload the files to Bitrise with codesigndoc.

title: Troubleshooting the UITest scanner
body: If the UITest scanner cannot find the desired scheme, follow these steps:

title: Troubleshooting the UITest scanner
body: Make sure your scheme is valid for running a UITest.

title: Troubleshooting the UITest scanner
body: It has to contain a UITest target that is enabled to run.

title: Troubleshooting the UITest scanner
body: Refresh your project settings:

title: Troubleshooting the UITest scanner
body: Select the Generic iOS Device target for your scheme in Xcode.

title: Troubleshooting the UITest scanner
body: Clean your project: ⌘ Cmd + ↑ Shift + K.

title: Troubleshooting the UITest scanner
body: Run a build for testing: ⌘ Cmd + ↑ Shift + U.

title: Troubleshooting the UITest scanner
body: Run codesigndoc again.

title: Manually installing and using codesigndoc
body: With manual install, you can specify which version of codesigndoc you want to use. Unlike with the one-liners used above, the manual install does not automatically run the scan command in the folder you use it in: it merely installs the tool.

title: Manually installing and using codesigndoc
body: Check out the available versions on the releases page of the codesigndoc tool.

title: Manually installing and using codesigndoc
body: Download the release you want by running a curl command:

title: Manually installing and using codesigndoc
body: Note: replace the VERSIONNUMBER with the actual number of the codesigndoc version you want.

title: Manually installing and using codesigndoc
body: curl -sfL https://github.com/bitrise-io/codesigndoc/releases/download/VERSIONNUMBER/codesigndoc-Darwin-x86_64 > ./codesigndoc

title: Manually installing and using codesigndoc
body: Make the downloaded binary executable:

title: Manually installing and using codesigndoc
body: chmod +x ./codesigndoc

title: Manually installing and using codesigndoc
body: Run the scan command any time you wish:

title: Manually installing and using codesigndoc
body:
## Xcode scanner
./codesigndoc scan xcode

## Xcode project scanner for UI test targets
./codesigndoc scan xcodeuitests

title: Best practices of using codesigndoc
body: You get the most accurate result if you run codesigndoc on the same state of your repository/code which is available after a clean git clone, as that will be the state of the code after the build server checks it out (for example, you might have files on your Mac which are in .gitignore, so it exists on your Mac but not in the repository or after a git clone on a new Mac).

title: Best practices of using codesigndoc
body: So, for the best results, we recommend you to:

title: Best practices of using codesigndoc
body: Do a clean git clone of your repository (into a new directory) on your Mac.

title: Best practices of using codesigndoc
body: Run codesigndoc in this directory (not in the directory where you usually work on the project).

title: Best practices of using codesigndoc
body: We also recommend generating an IPA on your local machine first, and run codesigndoc after that. The reason is that Xcode might download or update profiles in the background during the IPA export. If you run codesigndoc after you exported a IPA from Xcode, codesigndoc will able to collect all the files.

title: iOS code signing with automatic provisioning
body: Automatic code signing means automatically managing the provisioning profiles that are available on your Apple Developer Portal account. If you set up some form of authentication to your Apple account, Bitrise can download and install the provisioning profile for your app during the build process.

title: iOS code signing with automatic provisioning
body: On Bitrise, we're aiming to make iOS code signing as simple as possible for you. As such, we've done our best to automate a lot of the process. Several of our Steps have a built-in option for automatic code signing management to make configuration a lot more streamlined.

title: iOS code signing with automatic provisioning
body: Automatic code signing in this context means automatically managing the provisioning profiles that are available on your Apple Developer Portal account. If you set up some form of authentication to your Apple account, Bitrise can download and install the provisioning profile for your app during the build process.

title: Uploading iOS code signing certificates to Bitrise
body: We strongly recommend uploading BOTH the development and distribution signing certificates for your project. If you don't have an uploaded development signing certificate, Steps with automatic provisioning options will generate one on the fly every time you start a build. This can eventually lead to reaching the maximum number of certificates, blocking you from starting new builds.

title: Configuring the Steps for automatic provisioning
body: There are two ways to handle automatic provisioning on Bitrise:

title: Configuring the Steps for automatic provisioning
body: Using the official Xcode Steps that can both manage code signing files and build your app.

title: Configuring the Steps for automatic provisioning
body: Using the Manage iOS Code Signing Step.

title: Configuring the Steps for automatic provisioning
body: Table 1, “ describes the use cases for the two methods. To be able to configure the necessary Steps, check out either:

title: Configuring the Steps for automatic provisioning
body: Don't use the Certificate and profile installer Step

title: Using the Xcode Steps
body: You can use any of the Xcode Steps with built-in automatic management of code signing assets.

title: Using the Xcode Steps
body: Set up connection to Apple services.

title: Using the Xcode Steps
body: You can choose between API key authentication or Apple ID authentication. We generally recommend API key authentication.

title: Using the Xcode Steps
body: Add any of the following Steps to your Workflow, depending on what you need:

title: Using the Xcode Steps
body: Xcode Archive and Export for iOS: Builds your Xcode app and exports an IPA of the type you choose.

title: Using the Xcode Steps
body: Export iOS and tvOS Xcode Archive: Exports an IPA from an already existing archive.

title: Using the Xcode Steps
body: Xcode build for testing for iOS: Builds your Xcode app with the build-for-testing action.

title: Using the Xcode Steps
body: Set the Automatic code signing method input to the Apple service authentication type you set up.

title: Using the Xcode Steps
body: For example, if you chose API key authentication, choose the api-key option.

title: Using the Xcode Steps
body: YAML example for setting code signing method

title: Using the Xcode Steps
body: In this example, the Xcode Archive and Export for iOS Step is set to use API key authentication.

title: Using the Xcode Steps
body:
- xcode-archive@4: 
 inputs: 
 - automatic_code_signing: api-key

title: Using the Xcode Steps
body: In most cases, the default values for all other inputs are sufficient if you set up your Apple connection correctly.

title: Using the Manage iOS Code Signing Step
body: Use our dedicated Step for automatically managing code signing assets if you do not use one of the Xcode Steps to build your iOS app, or if you have a cross-platform app.

title: Using the Manage iOS Code Signing Step
body: Add the Manage iOS Code Signing Step after any dependency installer Step in your Workflow, such as Run CocoaPods install or Carthage.

title: Using the Manage iOS Code Signing Step
body: Set the Automatic code signing input to the Apple service connection you want to use.

title: Using the Manage iOS Code Signing Step
body: You can choose between API key authentication or Apple ID authentication.

title: Using the Manage iOS Code Signing Step
body: If you use Apple ID authentication, you should also enter your team ID to The Developer Portal team ID input.

title: Using the Manage iOS Code Signing Step
body: Make sure you do NOT modify your Xcode project after this Step.

title: Using the Manage iOS Code Signing Step
body: For example, don't change the bundle ID.

title: Using the Manage iOS Code Signing Step
body: Add a Step that builds and archives the app, such as the fastlane Step.

If you don't have an uploaded development signing certificate, Steps with automatic provisioning options will generate one on the fly every time you start a build. This can eventually lead to reaching the maximum number of certificates, blocking you from starting new builds.

title: Creating a signed IPA for Xcode projects
body: If you’re all set, proceed to setting up IPA export in your Workflow.

title: Creating a signed IPA for Xcode projects
body: The options are:

title: Creating a signed IPA for Xcode projects
body: auto-detect - Please note that this option is deprecated and will be removed. We do not recommend using it.

title: Creating a signed IPA for Xcode projects
body: app-store: Choose this if you want to deploy the app to the App Store. Requires a Distribution certificate and an App Store provisioning profile.

title: Creating a signed IPA for Xcode projects
body: ad-hoc: Choose this if you want to deploy the app to ad-hoc testers. Requires a Distribution certificate and an Ad Hoc provisioning profile.

title: Creating a signed IPA for Xcode projects
body: enterprise: Choose this if you have an Apple Enterprise account and want to use that to distribute your app.

title: Creating a signed IPA for Xcode projects
body: development: Choose this for internal testing. Requires a Developer certificate and a Development provisioning profile.

title: Creating a signed IPA for Xcode projects
body: Set the Automatic code signing input to the Apple service connection you want to use for code signing. The available options are:

title: Creating a signed IPA for Xcode projects

title: Creating a signed IPA for Xcode projects
body: api-key if you use API key authorization.

title: Creating a signed IPA for Xcode projects
body: apple-id if you use Apple ID authorization.

title: Creating a signed IPA for Xcode projects
body: Save the Workflow, and start a new build.

title: Creating a signed IPA for Xcode projects
