body: For a comprehensive overview on what Steps are available for code signing asset management, visit the iOS code signing page.

title: Signing an IPA with multiple code signing identities
body: You can create multiple IPA files with different code signing identities within a single Bitrise build.

title: Signing an IPA with multiple code signing identities
body: During the development of your iOS app you will need multiple types of distributions for different purposes, such as internal testing or deployment to the App Store. The good news is that this does not require setting up two separate workflows on bitrise.io.

title: Signing an IPA with multiple code signing identities
body: In this example we’ll be setting up a Workflow to create two signed IPA files: one with the development and one with the app-store export method.

title: Signing an IPA with multiple code signing identities
body: Make sure all the necessary code signing files are available for your build. Please note that you have to upload the certificates to the Code Signing tab while the Xcode Archive and Export for iOS Step downloads the provisioning profiles based on the Distribution method.

title: Signing an IPA with multiple code signing identities
body: Make sure you have the Xcode Archive & Export for iOS Step in your Workflow.

title: Signing an IPA with multiple code signing identities
body: In the list of input variables, navigate to Distribution method and select development from the dropdown menu.

title: Signing an IPA with multiple code signing identities
body: Set the Automatic code signing method input to the Apple service connection you want to use for code signing. The available options are:

title: Signing an IPA with multiple code signing identities
body: off if you don’t do automatic code signing.

title: Signing an IPA with multiple code signing identities
body: api-key if you use API key authorization.

title: Signing an IPA with multiple code signing identities
body: apple-id if you use Apple ID authorization.

title: Signing an IPA with multiple code signing identities
body: Add the Export iOS and tvOS Xcode archive Step to your Workflow. This Step reuses the archive generated by the Xcode Archive and Export for iOS Step and does a second export from the archive.

title: Signing an IPA with multiple code signing identities
body: Set the Automatic code signing method input to the Apple service connection you want to use for code signing. The available options are:

title: Signing an IPA with multiple code signing identities
body: off if you don’t do automatic code signing.

title: Signing an IPA with multiple code signing identities
body: api-key if you use API key authorization.

title: Signing an IPA with multiple code signing identities
body: apple-id if you use Apple ID authorization.

title: Signing an IPA with multiple code signing identities
body: In the list of input variables, navigate to Distribution method and select app-store from the dropdown menu.

title: Signing an IPA with multiple code signing identities
body: And you’re done! Feel free to add multiple Export iOS and tvOS Xcode archive Steps to your Workflows to create multiple different signed .ipa files if necessary.

title: iOS code signing for Ionic and Cordova projects
body: Bitrise supports both manual and automatic provisioning for the iOS code signing of Ionic and Cordova apps as well.

title: iOS code signing for Ionic and Cordova projects
body: Naturally, Bitrise supports iOS applications built with either Ionic or Cordova. However, the code signing process is slightly different compared to a native Xcode project.

title: iOS code signing for Ionic and Cordova projects
body: Bitrise supports both manual and automatic provisioning for Ionic and Cordova apps as well - and once again, the processes are somewhat different.

title: Ionic/Cordova code signing with manual code signing asset management
body: Generate the native Xcode project locally from your Ionic or Cordova project by calling cordova platform add ios or ionic cordova platform add ios.

title: Ionic/Cordova code signing with manual code signing asset management
body: Use our codesigndoc tool to collect the code signing files.

title: Ionic/Cordova code signing with manual code signing asset management
body: Upload the files to bitrise.io.

title: Ionic/Cordova code signing with manual code signing asset management
body: You can do this either on the website UI or with the codesigndoc tool itself.

title: Ionic/Cordova code signing with manual code signing asset management
body: Make sure you have the Certificate and profile installer Step in your Workflow.

title: Ionic/Cordova code signing with manual code signing asset management
body: Add the Generate cordova build configuration Step to your Workflow. It must come after the Certificate and profile installer Step.

title: Ionic/Cordova code signing with manual code signing asset management
body: Fill in the required inputs for the Step. Please note that both the Code Signing Identity and the Provisioning Profile are required inputs for iOS apps even though they are not marked as such.

title: Ionic/Cordova code signing with manual code signing asset management
body: Build configuration: you can set it to either debug or release.

title: Ionic/Cordova code signing with manual code signing asset management
body: Code Sign Identity: enter a Developer or a Distribution identity.

title: Ionic/Cordova code signing with manual code signing asset management
body: Provisioning Profile: enter the appropriate provisioning profile.

title: Ionic/Cordova code signing with manual code signing asset management
body: Packaging Type: this controls what type of build is generated by Xcode. Set the type of code signing you need.

title: Ionic/Cordova code signing with manual code signing asset management
body: Add the Cordova archive or the Ionic archive step to your workflow.

title: Ionic/Cordova code signing with manual code signing asset management
body: Fill in the required inputs.

title: Ionic/Cordova code signing with manual code signing asset management
body: The Platform input needs to be set to: device.

title: Ionic/Cordova code signing with manual code signing asset management
body: The Build command configuration input must match the Build configuration input of the Generate cordova build configuration Step.

title: Ionic/Cordova code signing with manual code signing asset management
body: This Step must come after the Generate cordova build configuration Step in the Workflow.

title: Ionic/Cordova code signing with manual code signing asset management
body: Run your build!

title: Ionic/Cordova code signing with automatic code signing asset management
body: Make sure your .p12 signing certificates are uploaded to bitrise.io.

title: Ionic/Cordova code signing with automatic code signing asset management
body: If you use codesigndoc to collect the files, note that you can tell the tool to export only the certificates, by calling:

title: Ionic/Cordova code signing with automatic code signing asset management
body: codesigndoc scan --certs-only xcode

title: Ionic/Cordova code signing with automatic code signing asset management
body: codesigndoc can also upload the files to the website, or you can do that manually.

title: Ionic/Cordova code signing with automatic code signing asset management
body: Add the Cordova prepare or the Ionic prepare Step to your Workflow. These Steps call the platform rm and platform add commands.

title: Ionic/Cordova code signing with automatic code signing asset management
body: Add the Manage iOS Code Signing Step to your Workflow. If you have both the Certificate and Profile Installer and the Manage iOS Code Signing Steps in your Workflow, your build might encounter unexpected issues.

title: Ionic/Cordova code signing with automatic code signing asset management
body: The Step will export:

title: Ionic/Cordova code signing with automatic code signing asset management
body: The project’s development team.

title: Ionic/Cordova code signing with automatic code signing asset management
body: The installed codesign identity’s name.

title: Ionic/Cordova code signing with automatic code signing asset management
body: The installed provisioning profile.

title: Ionic/Cordova code signing with automatic code signing asset management
body: One code signing Step only

title: Ionic/Cordova code signing with automatic code signing asset management
body: If you have both the Certificate and profile installer and the Manage iOS Code Signing Steps in your Workflow, your build might encounter unexpected issues.

title: Ionic/Cordova code signing with automatic code signing asset management
body: Select the Apple service connection method (based on the Apple service you have set up in Bitrise) and the Distribution method.

title: Ionic/Cordova code signing with automatic code signing asset management
body: Add the Generate cordova build configuration Step to your Workflow.

title: Ionic/Cordova code signing with automatic code signing asset management
body: Configure the Step to use the code signing settings exported by the Manage iOS Code Signing Step:

title: Ionic/Cordova code signing with automatic code signing asset management
body: Development distribution example:

title: Ionic/Cordova code signing with automatic code signing asset management
body:
- generate-cordova-build-configuration:
 inputs:
 - development_team: $BITRISE_DEVELOPER_TEAM 
 - package_type: development 
 - code_sign_identity: iPhone Developer
 - configuration: debug

title: Ionic/Cordova code signing with automatic code signing asset management
body: Production distribution example:

title: Ionic/Cordova code signing with automatic code signing asset management
body:
- generate-cordova-build-configuration:
 inputs:
 - development_team: $BITRISE_DEVELOPER_TEAM 
 - package_type: app-store 
 - code_sign_identity: iPhone Developer
 - configuration: release

title: Ionic/Cordova code signing with automatic code signing asset management
body: Add the Cordova Archive or the Ionic Archive Step to your Workflow.

title: Ionic/Cordova code signing with automatic code signing asset management
body: Fill in the required inputs.

title: Ionic/Cordova code signing with automatic code signing asset management
body: The Platform input needs to be set to: device.

title: Ionic/Cordova code signing with automatic code signing asset management
body: The Build command configuration input must match the Build configuration input of the Generate cordova build configuration Step.

title: Ionic/Cordova code signing with automatic code signing asset management
body: Set the Should remove platforms as prepare step? to false. This is crucial: it ensures the Step will not remove and re-add the platform of the native projects generated in the Cordova prepare or the Ionic prepare Step.

title: Ionic/Cordova code signing with automatic code signing asset management
body: Run your build!

title: Protecting your code signing files
body: You can set your code signing files to Protected mode: this means they cannot be downloaded from your bitrise.io account. Your builds will be able to use these protected files but no one will be able to reveal them and there is no way to overwrite them: you can only delete the files and upload new ones instead.

title: Protecting your code signing files
body: You can set your code signing files to Protected mode: this means they cannot be downloaded from your bitrise.io account. Your builds will be able to use these protected files but no one will be able to reveal them and there is no way to overwrite them: you can only delete the files and upload new ones instead.

title: Protecting your code signing files
body: Open your app on Bitrise.

title: Protecting your code signing files
body: Click the Workflows button on the main page.

title: Protecting your code signing files
body: Go to the Code Signing & Files tab.

title: Protecting your code signing files
body: Locate the file you wish to make protected and open the dropdown menu.

title: Protecting your code signing files
body: Select the Make protected option.

title: Protecting your code signing files
body: A pop-up window will warn you that this change is irreversible once you confirm it. You do not need to separately save your changes.

title: Protecting your code signing files
body: Once you are done, your only option in the file’s dropdown menu will be Delete.

title: Generating iOS code signing files
body: You can generate iOS code signing files either with Xcode or on the Apple Developer Portal.

title: Generating iOS code signing files
body: You’ll need two kinds of files to sign your app: certificates and provisioning profiles.

title: Generating iOS code signing files
body: The certificates - development or distribution - are the guarantee that you, the named developer, built this code, that you are a member of the developer program, and that Apple have issued you with a certificate to do so.

title: Generating iOS code signing files
body: To get a certificate, you need to generate a Certificate Signing Request with Keychain Access and send it to Apple. This will create a public/private key pair for you if you don’t have one already. Apple will then verify the information, and create a certificate for you.

title: Generating iOS code signing files
body: Provisioning is the process of preparing and configuring an app to launch on devices and to use app services. Development provisioning profiles holds the device identifiers (UUID) that is eligible to run your app. Distribution provisioning profiles can include App Store profiles that allow you to distribute your app to the App Store. Ad-hoc profiles are good for distributing to your testers.

title: Generating a code signing certificate with Xcode
body: First you have to add your Apple ID to Accounts preferences in Xcode. If you are already done with this, you can skip to Selecting your Apple ID.

title: Generating a code signing certificate with Xcode
body: Start Xcode.

title: Generating a code signing certificate with Xcode
body: Select Xcode > Preferences from the navigation bar.

title: Generating a code signing certificate with Xcode
body: At the top of the window select Accounts.

title: Generating a code signing certificate with Xcode
body: Click on the + on the lower left corner and select Add Apple ID…

title: Generating a code signing certificate with Xcode
body: A dialog will appear. Add your Apple ID and your password, then select Sign in. If you don’t have an account you can create your Apple ID by selecting Create Apple ID.

title: Generating a code signing certificate with Xcode
body: Select your Apple ID and your team from the right side bar, then click on View Details….

title: Generating a code signing certificate with Xcode
body: A dialog will appear where you will see your code signing identities and the provisioning profiles.

title: Generating a code signing certificate with Xcode
body: Under the signing identities locate the iOS Development and iOS Distribution profiles. If you have not created them you will see a Create button next to them. Simply select it and Xcode will issue and download your code signing identities for you.

title: Generating a code signing certificate with Xcode
body: When to click Reset next to Code Signing Identities

title: Generating a code signing certificate with Xcode
body: If you already have Code Signing Identities issued, you will see a Reset button next to them. You can issue new certificates with it, that Xcode will generate and download, however note that this will invalidate your previous certificate, so only do this if you’ve lost those files or if you know what you are doing!

title: Generating a code signing certificate manually
body: Open your Keychain Access app on macOS.

title: Generating a code signing certificate manually
body: Select Keychain Access > Certificate Assistant > Request a Certificate From a Certificate Authority…

title: Generating a code signing certificate manually
body: Fill in the User’s Email Address and the Common Name and select Saved to Disk.

title: Generating a code signing certificate manually
body: Click on Continue and save the generated certSigningRequest file locally.

title: Generating a code signing certificate manually
body: Go to https://developer.apple.com and log in to your account.

title: Generating a code signing certificate manually
body: Select Certificates, IDs & Profiles from the left sidebar.

title: Generating a code signing certificate manually
body: Go to Certificates and click on the + button on the top right corner.

title: Generating a code signing certificate manually
body: Select iOS App Development and click Continue.

title: Generating a code signing certificate manually
body: On the next page you see the instructions for creating the certSigningRequest file. Click Continue.

title: Generating a code signing certificate manually
body: Upload the created certSigningRequest to the form and click Continue. It will generate your code signing certificate for you.

title: Generating a code signing certificate manually
body: Download the certificate and double click to install it. Once installed it will be added to your Keychain Access app.

title: Generating a provisioning profile with Xcode
body: Xcode will automatically generate an App ID for your project, that matches your unique bundle ID for your project. An App ID is used to identify one or more of your apps. It can be an explicit App ID that only matches one unique bundle identifier or a wildcard App ID that can match multiple ones.

title: Generating a provisioning profile with Xcode
body: Xcode will also create a Team Provisioning Profile for your project automatically, so you can start deploying to your device automatically.

title: Generating a provisioning profile with Xcode
body: If you hit any issues you should make sure that the device is eligible, for example if the device doesn’t match the deployment target you will get an error. Also make sure that your app is connected to the correct Team.

title: Generating a provisioning profile with Xcode
body: To generate a provisioning profile using Xcode:

title: Generating a provisioning profile with Xcode
body: Select your project file from Xcode’s project navigator.

title: Generating a provisioning profile with Xcode
body: Go to the Signing section and under the Team select your correct team.

title: Generating a provisioning profile with Xcode
body: Build your project in Xcode.

title: Generating a provisioning profile with Xcode
body: To download a provisioning profile from Xcode:

title: Generating a provisioning profile with Xcode
body: Start Xcode.

title: Generating a provisioning profile with Xcode
body: Select Xcode > Preferences from the navigation bar.

title: Generating a provisioning profile with Xcode
body: At the top of the window select Accounts.

title: Generating a provisioning profile with Xcode
body: Select your Apple ID and your team, then select Download Manual Profiles.

title: Generating a provisioning profile with Xcode
body: Go to ~/Library/MobileDevice/Provisioning Profiles/ and your profiles should be there.

title: Generating a provisioning profile manually
body: To generate a provisioning profile manually, you need a working Apple Developer account, and you need to set up an App ID for your project.

title: Setting up an App ID
body: If you haven’t already created an App ID for your project, go to https://developer.apple.com and log in.

title: Setting up an App ID
body: Select Certificates, Identifiers & Profiles from the left sidebar.

title: Setting up an App ID
body: Navigate to Identifiers > App IDs.

title: Setting up an App ID
body: In the App ID Description add a recognizable name for your App ID.

title: Setting up an App ID
body: Select Explicit App ID and add your bundle identifier to the field.

title: Setting up an App ID
body: Select any additional App Services that you need.

title: Setting up an App ID
body: Click Continue.

title: Generating a provisioning profile
body: Go to https://developer.apple.com and log in.

title: Generating a provisioning profile
body: Select Certificates, Identifiers & Profiles from the left sidebar.

title: Generating a provisioning profile
body: Navigate to Provisioning Profiles > All.

title: Generating a provisioning profile
body: Select the + from the top right corner.

title: Generating a provisioning profile
body: For development select the correct project type under Development, or for distribution select the correct one under Distribution and click continue.

title: Generating a provisioning profile
body: Select the App ID you would like to use.

title: Generating a provisioning profile
body: Select the certificates you wish to include in the provisioning profile. These certificates will be able to build with this profile; click Continue.

title: Generating a provisioning profile
body: Select all the devices you would like to use with this profile and click continue.

title: Generating a provisioning profile
body: Name your provisioning profile and click Continue.

title: Generating a provisioning profile
body: Your profile is generated. You can download it to your device and double click to install it on your Mac.

title: Exporting iOS code signing files manually
body: If you don't want to use Bitrise's codesigndoc tool, you can export iOS code signing certificates and provisioning profiles manually, or using Xcode.

title: Exporting iOS code signing files manually
body: If you don't want to use our codesigndoc tool, you can export iOS code signing certificates and provisioning profiles manually, or using Xcode.

title: Exporting iOS code signing certificates with Xcode
body: Start Xcode.

title: Exporting iOS code signing certificates with Xcode
body: Select Xcode > Preferences from the navigation bar.

title: Exporting iOS code signing certificates with Xcode
body: At the top of the window select Accounts.

title: Exporting iOS code signing certificates with Xcode
body: Select your Apple ID and your team from the right side bar, then click on View Details....

title: Exporting iOS code signing certificates with Xcode
body: A dialog will appear where you will see your code signing identities and the provisioning profiles.

title: Exporting iOS code signing certificates with Xcode
body: Select the certificates and choose Export from the pop-up menu.

title: Exporting iOS code signing certificates with Xcode
body: Enter a filename in the Save As dialog. You can set a password and a verification to store it securely, but it’s not necessary.

title: Exporting iOS code signing certificates with Xcode
body: Xcode will export the requested certificate in .p12 format.

title: Exporting iOS code signing certificates manually
body: Start Keychain Access.

title: Exporting iOS code signing certificates manually
body: On the top left sidebar select login and on the bottom left select My Certificates.

title: Exporting iOS code signing certificates manually
body: This will list all your installed certificates and the associated private key.

title: Exporting iOS code signing certificates manually
body: Select the one that you would like to export and choose Export from the pop-up menu.

title: Exporting iOS code signing certificates manually
body: Enter a filename in the Save As dialog. You can set a password and a verification to store it securely, but it’s not necessary.

title: Exporting iOS code signing certificates manually
body: Keychain Access will export the requested certificate in .p12 format.

title: Exporting iOS provisioning profiles with Xcode
body: Start Xcode.

title: Exporting iOS provisioning profiles with Xcode
body: Select Xcode > Preferences from the navigation bar.

title: Exporting iOS provisioning profiles with Xcode
body: At the top of the window select Accounts.

title: Exporting iOS provisioning profiles with Xcode
body: Select your Apple ID and your team from the right side bar, then click on View Details....

title: Exporting iOS provisioning profiles with Xcode
body: A dialog will appear where you will see your code signing identities and the provisioning profiles.

title: Exporting iOS provisioning profiles with Xcode
body: Locate the profile that you are looking for under Provisioning Profiles.

title: Exporting iOS provisioning profiles with Xcode
body: If you don’t have it installed on the system, click on the Download button next to it.

title: Exporting iOS provisioning profiles with Xcode
body: Choose Show in finder from the pop-up menu, that will show you the installed provisioning profile for you.

title: Exporting iOS provisioning profiles manually
body: Go to https://developer.apple.com and log in.

title: Exporting iOS provisioning profiles manually
body: Select Certificates, Identifiers & Profiles from the left sidebar.

title: Exporting iOS provisioning profiles manually
body: Navigate to Provisioning Profiles > All.

title: Exporting iOS provisioning profiles manually
body: Find the Provisioning Profile you are looking for from the list or use the search to filter.

title: Exporting iOS provisioning profiles manually
body: Click on the selected Provisioning Profile, this will expand the details.

title: Exporting iOS provisioning profiles manually
body: If its status is invalid, you can click on the Edit button and save again.

title: Exporting iOS provisioning profiles manually
body: Click on the Download button to download it and double click to install on your macOS.

title: Troubleshooting iOS code signing
body: iOS code signing can be complicated, with several potential issues. We've collected some of the most common issues and their potential solutions.

title: Troubleshooting iOS code signing
body: iOS code signing can be complicated, with several potential issues. We've collected some of the most common issues and their potential solutions. Let’s look into what you can do to make sure code signing works!

title: Code signing and clean virtual machines
body: Every Bitrise build uses a clean virtual machine with no leftover files and configuration from previous builds. While you most likely have all the necessary code signing files (certificates and provisioning profiles) available on your local machine this is not the case with our virtual machines. They do not contain any code signing files relevant to your project, that is why you have to make sure:

title: Code signing and clean virtual machines
body: You choose the right code signing asset management option to upload the provisioning profiles to Bitrise. From here our Steps will download the files to the virtual machine at runtime.

title: Code signing and clean virtual machines
body: You upload the necessary signing certificates to the Code Signing tab.

title: Code signing and clean virtual machines
body: You have connected your Bitrise account to the Apple Developer portal. (This step is not needed if you use the Certificate and Profile Installer Step.) to Apple Developer portal.

title: Code signing and clean virtual machines
body: If you suspect an error is related to code signing, there is almost certainly a problem with one of these three. When trying to build an iOS app on Bitrise, we strongly recommend generating an .ipa file of the app locally, on your own machine first. If that fails, the build will certainly fail on Bitrise, too.

title: Code signing and clean virtual machines
body: Verbose logs

title: Code signing and clean virtual machines
body: If you are getting any issues, make sure you enable the Verbose log input in your code signing asset management or building Step to get more information on the nature of the issue.

title: iOS code signing Steps fail
body: Our iOS code signing Steps manage your provisioning profiles for you: they download the profiles from the Apple Developer portal and install them for you. Here’s what you can do if these Steps fail:

title: iOS code signing Steps fail
body: Before trying to use this Step, generate an .ipa file locally - with the same export method you want to use on Bitrise - to ensure that the profiles are uploaded to the Apple Developer portal.

title: iOS code signing Steps fail
body: Make sure that your Bitrise account is connected to the Apple Developer portal and that you have at least an Admin role in your Apple Developer team.

title: File count limit on provisioning profiles
body: The maximum number of provisioning profiles and .p12 certificates you can upload to the Code Signing tab on Bitrise is 30. If you’ve already reached this limit and wish to use even more, then here are a few tips on how to use even more provisioning profiles:

title: File count limit on provisioning profiles
body: Use a Step with automatic provisioning, such as Xcode Archive and Export for iOS, Export iOS and tvOS Xcode Archive, Xcode build for testing for iOS , or Manage iOS Code Signing. These Steps only require the code signing identities (certificates with .p12 extension) to be uploaded to Bitrise. You can download the provisioning profiles from the Apple Developer portal on-the-fly during the build if you have connected your Apple Developer account to Bitrise.

title: File count limit on provisioning profiles
body: You can create a .zip file containing the required certificates/profiles. In this case, you don’t need to upload any certificates/profiles on Bitrise. During the build you can download the .zip file and update the certificate/profile related inputs of the Certificate and Profile Installer Step to match the path to the certificate/profile on the build machine. Note that the Certificate and Profile Installer Step supports local paths and URLs for certificates and profiles.

title: File count limit on provisioning profiles
body: You can host the profiles and certificates yourself, and only add an URL that is pointing to a given certificate/profile to the workflow.

title: File count limit on provisioning profiles
body: Also note that multiple URLs can be specified for both the certificate and profile inputs. Make sure you separate them with a pipe (|) character.

title: Could not install the app on a device
body: To install iOS apps on a given device, you have to either:

title: Could not install the app on a device
body: Export an IPA file with the development export method, with the device’s UDID registered in the provisioning profile used for the export.

title: Could not install the app on a device
body: Export an IPA file with the ad-hoc export method and install the app via the public install page generated by the Deploy to Bitrise.io Step.

title: Could not install the app on a device
body: If you can't install an app on a given device:

title: Could not install the app on a device
body: Check that the device UDID is included in the app’s provisioning profile.

title: Could not install the app on a device
body: If you use manual provisioning, check the provisioning profile you uploaded to Bitrise.

title: Could not install the app on a device
body: Check the logs to see if the Xcode Archive & Export for iOS Step used the provisioning profile with the device’s UDID in it.

title: Testing
body: Bitrise has a number of dedicated Steps to help you with running your tests, and you can use custom Script Steps if you do not find what you need in our Step Library.

title: Testing
body: Testing your app is obviously a major part of the continuous integration process. Bitrise has a number of dedicated Steps to help you with running your tests, and you can use custom Script Steps if you do not find what you need in our Step Library.

title: Testing
body: Check out our testing Steps for iOS, Android, and cross-platform apps: from Xcode tests through Flutter tests to Android Lint, you can review and test your app on Bitrise, regardless of the frameworks and tools you use.

title: Test Reports
body: Use our Test Reports page to view your tests in one convenient location. You can use it with the supported Steps or with your own custom Script Steps.

title: Device testing
body: You can register your test devices on Bitrise for simple and convenient testing. Alternatively, you can use the Device testing for iOS and Virtual Device Testing Steps that utilize Google Firebase to run your tests on real and virtual devices.

title: Other testing guides
body: Check out our other testing guides for more information on how to run tests on Bitrise.

title: Test Reports
body: You can run both UI tests and unit tests on Bitrise. You can view them in Test Reports, which you can access from the Add-ons section on the Build Details page.

title: Test Reports
body: Test Reports allows you to view all your test results in a convenient way.

title: Test Reports
body: Use our testing Steps, and all your test results will be deployed to the same directory. From there, Test Reports can process and display them in a way that’s easy to read and analyze.

title: Test reports overview
body: You can run both UI tests and unit tests on Bitrise and with Test Reports, you can view the results of the different test types on the same page.

title: Test reports overview
body: To be able to use Test Reports, you need to make sure your test results end up in the correct directory and in the correct format. From that directory, the Deploy to Bitrise.io Step exports the results to the add-on.

title: Test reports overview
body: There are three ways to make sure your test results end up in the correct location and in the appropriate format:

title: Test reports overview
body: Using our dedicated testing Steps that automatically export their results. With these Steps, all you need to do is put both the testing Step and the Deploy to Bitrise.io Step to the Workflow and run the build.

title: Test reports overview
body: Using the Export test results to the Test reports add-on Step.

title: Test reports overview
body: Using a custom Script Step.

title: Test reports overview
body: Exporting the results from any testing Step

title: Test reports overview
body: Both the second and the third method allows you to export test results from any Step. Read the details in our Exporting to Test Reports from any Step guide.

title: Test reports overview
body: Test Reports can read and display test results that are in either of two formats:

title: Test reports overview
body: You can use Test Reports with five of our testing Steps by default. These Steps will run the tests defined in your repository and then store the output in an Environment Variable. The Deploy to Bitrise.io Step will do the rest: it can read the results and send it to Test Reports. The Steps are:

title: Test reports overview
body: Xcode Test for iOS.

title: Test reports overview
body: Android Unit Test.

title: Test reports overview
body: iOS Device Testing.

title: Test reports overview
body: Virtual Device Testing for Android.

title: Test reports overview
body: Flutter Test.

title: Test reports overview
body: With these Steps, you don't have to worry about the format or the location of the test results. All you need to make sure is that you include the Deploy to Bitrise.io Step at the end of your Workflow.

title: Test reports overview
body: Testing guides

title: Test reports overview
body: Check out our testing guides to read more about how to use these Steps on Bitrise:

title: Configuring Test Reports
body: Test Reports doesn’t require any sort of complicated configuration. All you need is to have tests in your repository, and two Steps in your Workflow.

title: Configuring Test Reports
body: Deploy to Bitrise.io version

title: Configuring Test Reports
body: The Deploy to Bitrise.io Step must be of version 1.4.1 or newer - older versions of the Step do NOT support Test Reports. We recommend using version 1.5.0 or higher for the best experience.

title: Configuring Test Reports
body: Add tests to your app’s repository.

title: Configuring Test Reports
body: Add the appropriate testing Steps to your Workflow. For example, if you have an Android project, you can use the Android Unit Test Step to run Android unit tests.

title: Configuring Test Reports
body: Make sure you have the Deploy to Bitrise.io Step in your Workflow.

title: Configuring Test Reports
body: Run your build.

title: Configuring Test Reports
body: And that’s it! Once the build is finished, you will be able to view your test reports.

title: Checking test results
body: Test Reports display the most important information about all the tests you ran on the Test Summary tab. You will see all the tests you ran, their duration, and their results. You can also click on the tabs of the individual tests to see their details.

title: Checking test results
body: To access the result of a particular test:

title: Checking test results
body: Find your app on the Dashboard, and select it.

title: Checking test results
body: On the app's main page, select the build you want to check out.

title: Checking test results
body: Go to the Tests tab.

title: Checking test results
body: On the Test Summary tab, find the test you want to check. Alternatively, on the top bar, click the tab of the test set you want to check out.To filter tests based on their results, open the menu on the top right, which is set to All by default.

title: Checking test results
body: Click Test cases to see the details.

title: Checking test results
body: UI tests are grouped according to device while unit tests are grouped according to test cases.

title: Checking test results
body: You will find:

title: Checking test results
body: The total number of tests you ran, as well as the ratio of successful and failed tests.

title: Checking test results
body: The duration of each individual test (both unit tests and UI tests).

title: Checking test results
body: In the case of UI tests, the orientation and the locale of the device.

title: Checking test results
body: You can check, depending on the test type:

title: Checking test results
body: Individual test cases

title: Checking test results
body: Performance data

title: Checking test results
body: Videos

title: Checking test results
body: Screenshots

title: Checking test results
body: Test artifacts

title: Checking test results
body: Logs

title: Checking test results
body: As noted above, this depends on test type, too: for unit tests, you won’t see screenshots or videos, of course.

title: Downloading files
body: Every file can be downloaded from Test Reports: that includes screenshots, videos, or APK and IPA files.

title: Downloading files
body: Open a test set.

title: Downloading files
body: On the left menu, click a tab that contains files.

title: Downloading files
body: For example, Test Artifacts.

title: Downloading files
body: Click Download next to the file name.

title: Downloading files
body: If you want to download all files available on the tab, click Download All Files.

title: Exporting to Test Reports from any Step
body: You can export Test Reports from any Step using the Export test results to the Test reports add-on Step. Alternatively, you could configure your own Script Step to export the files.

title: Exporting to Test Reports from any Step
body: Test Reports allows you to view all your test results in a convenient way. By default, five Steps support the Test Reports add-on:

title: Exporting to Test Reports from any Step
body: Xcode Test for iOS

title: Exporting to Test Reports from any Step
body: Android Unit Test

title: Exporting to Test Reports from any Step
body: iOS Device Testing

title: Exporting to Test Reports from any Step
body: Virtual Device Testing for Android

title: Exporting to Test Reports from any Step
body: Flutter Test

title: Exporting to Test Reports from any Step
body: To export the test results generated by any other Step to the Deploy to Bitrise.io Step, you have two options:

title: Exporting to Test Reports from any Step
body: We recommend using our Export test results to the Test reports add-on Step: this Step locates the test results based on your inputs. However, this Step cannot export screenshots or other images.

title: Exporting to Test Reports from any Step
body: You can configure your own custom Script Step that creates and exports the necessary files. If you need screenshots or other images, you need to export both the test results and the images in the same Script Step.

title: Using the Export test results to the Test reports add-on Step
body: You can use the Export test results to the Test reports add-on Step to make sure your test results appear in the Test Reports add-on, even if you use Steps that don’t automatically export their results.

title: Using the Export test results to the Test reports add-on Step
body: With the correct configuration, the Step finds the test results in your app’s repository, and puts them in the export directory.

title: Using the Export test results to the Test reports add-on Step
body: Screenshots and other images

title: Using the Export test results to the Test reports add-on Step
body: The Step can only export test results, in either .xcresult or JUnit XML format. If your test results are in an .xcresult file, screenshots generated as part of the test are included and exported to the Test Reports add-on.

title: Using the Export test results to the Test reports add-on Step
body: If you use the JUnit XML format, you need to export screenshots and other images using a Script Step: Exporting screenshots and other images to Test Reports. In this case, the test results themselves must be exported using the same Script Step. You cannot export screenshots and test results in separate Steps!

title: Using the Export test results to the Test reports add-on Step
body: Go to your app’s page on bitrise.io.

title: Using the Export test results to the Test reports add-on Step
body: Go to Workflows to open the Workflow Editor.

title: Using the Export test results to the Test reports add-on Step
body: From the WORKFLOW menu, select the Workflow you use to run your tests.

title: Using the Export test results to the Test reports add-on Step
body: Add the Export test results to the Test reports add-on Step AFTER the testing Step.

title: Using the Export test results to the Test reports add-on Step
body: In the The name of the test input, set the name of the test run. The test results will be under this name in the Test Reports add-on.

title: Using the Export test results to the Test reports add-on Step
body: In the Path where custom test results reside input, set the path where your test results can be found.

title: Using the Export test results to the Test reports add-on Step
body: We recommend setting a folder here, though you can also set a specific filepath. The default value is the source directory of your app. Example patterns:

title: Using the Export test results to the Test reports add-on Step
body: If your app’s root directory is app: app/build/test-results/testDemoDebugUnitTest/

title: Using the Export test results to the Test reports add-on Step
body: If your test results are within an app folder but app is not the root directory: ./app/build/test-results/testDemoDebugUnitTest/

title: Using the Export test results to the Test reports add-on Step
body: In the Test result search pattern input, set a pattern that matches your test result file.

title: Using the Export test results to the Test reports add-on Step
body: This search pattern is used to search every file and folder of the path that was set in the Path where custom test results reside input.

title: Using the Export test results to the Test reports add-on Step
body: If there is more than one match, the Step will export the first match with a warning in the logs. If you set a specific filepath in the previous input, just set * here.

title: Using the Export test results to the Test reports add-on Step
body: Example patterns:

title: Using the Export test results to the Test reports add-on Step
body: Matching all files within the base path: *

title: Using the Export test results to the Test reports add-on Step
body: Matching all files within a given directory of the base path: */build/test-results/testDemoDebugUnitTest/*

title: Using the Export test results to the Test reports add-on Step
body: In the Step’s test result directory input, make sure the path is correct.

title: Using the Export test results to the Test reports add-on Step
body: Do NOT modify this input’s value: this is the folder where the Deploy to Bitrise.io Step will look for the test results to export them. It should be set to the $BITRISE_TEST_RESULT_DIR Env Var.

title: Using the Export test results to the Test reports add-on Step
body: Make sure you have a Deploy to Bitrise.io Step in your Workflow.

title: Using custom scripts to export test results
body: You can use your own scripts in a Script Step to export your test results. You just need to make sure that:

title: Using custom scripts to export test results
body: Your test results are in a JUnit XML format.

title: Using custom scripts to export test results
body: You place the results in the $BITRISE_TEST_RESULT_DIR, which is an Environment Variable pointing to the correct path.

title: Using custom scripts to export test results
body: The results of each test run should be in its own sub-directory. You place a test-info.json file in each sub-directory to correspond to the test run.

title: Using custom scripts to export test results
body: The test-info.json file

title: Using custom scripts to export test results
body: The test-info.json file must have the name of the test run defined in it. Each test run should have its own test-info.json file. The value of test-name will appear as the name of the test run on the Test Reports page.

title: Using custom scripts to export test results
body: // Test Name ... { "test-name":"My first test" }

title: Using custom scripts to export test results
body: Here’s an example script to export your test results:

title: Using custom scripts to export test results
body:
#!/bin/env bash
set -ex

# Creating a sub-directory for the test run within the BITRISE_TEST_RESULT_DIR:

test_run_dir="$BITRISE_TEST_RESULT_DIR/result_dir_1"
mkdir "$test_run_dir"

# Exporting the JUnit XML test report:

cp "MY/TEST/REPORT/XML/FILE/PATH.xml" "$test_run_dir/UnitTest.xml"

# Creating the test-info.json file with the name of the test run defined:

echo '{"test-name":"MY TEST RUN NAME"}' >> "$test_run_dir/test-info.json"

title: Using custom scripts to export test results
body: If all goes well, you should be able to see your test results on the Test Reports page.

title: Exporting screenshots and other images to Test Reports
body: The Export test results to Test Reports add-on Step can only export test result files to the Deploy to Bitrise.io Step which supports two formats for results:

title: Exporting screenshots and other images to Test Reports
body: The .xcresult file for iOS apps.

title: Exporting screenshots and other images to Test Reports
body: A JUnit XML file for any app.

title: Exporting screenshots and other images to Test Reports
body: If your tests produce an .xcresult file, screenshots generated during the test run are part of the test result. As such, they will be exported to the Test Reports add-on.

title: Exporting screenshots and other images to Test Reports
body: If you use the JUnit XML format and want to export screenshots or other images, you cannot use the Export test results to Test Reports add-on Step.

title: Exporting screenshots and other images to Test Reports
body: You need to use a custom script to export both the result and the screenshots. The script to export both must be in the same Script Step, and you must have a test-info.json file with the necessary information about the test runs: Using custom scripts to export test results.

title: Exporting screenshots and other images to Test Reports
body: To export screenshots with the results, the script must place the images in the $BITRISE_TEST_RESULT_DIR folder.

title: Exporting screenshots and other images to Test Reports
body: Folder structure

title: Exporting screenshots and other images to Test Reports
body: The image files themselves must be in the $BITRISE_TEST_RESULT_DIR folder. They can't be nested in another folder within $BITRISE_TEST_RESULT_DIR.

title: Exporting screenshots and other images to Test Reports
body: Script to export an image

title: Exporting screenshots and other images to Test Reports
body:
#!/bin/env bash
set -ex

# Creating a sub-directory for the test run within the BITRISE_TEST_RESULT_DIR:

test_run_dir="$BITRISE_TEST_RESULT_DIR/result_dir_1"
mkdir "$test_run_dir"

# copying the image:

cp "MY/TEST/SCREENSHOTS/screenshot.png" "$test_run_dir/screenshot.png"

title: Exporting screenshots and other images to Test Reports
body: Associating images with test runs

title: Exporting screenshots and other images to Test Reports
body: You can associate an image with a specific test run by placing the image in the directory of that test run. In that case, the image will appear under all test suits of the given test run.

title: Running Xcode tests
body: You need two Steps to run Xcode tests and view their results: Xcode Test for iOS, and Deploy to Bitrise.io.

title: Running Xcode tests
body: To run Xcode tests on Bitrise, you need to have test targets defined in your projects. You need two Steps to run Xcode tests and view their results:

title: Running Xcode tests
body: Xcode Test for iOS.

title: Running Xcode tests
body: Deploy to Bitrise.io.

title: Running Xcode tests
body: Code signing files

title: Running Xcode tests
body: Running Xcode tests and deploying their results to Bitrise do not require any code signing files. So don’t worry about them just yet!

title: Running Xcode tests
body: The Xcode Test for iOS Step runs the pre-defined Xcode tests. It has a default configuration that will work if the tests are written correctly. You can find the same configuration options in Xcode, too.

title: Running Xcode tests
body: Package dependency errors when using the Xcode Test for iOS Step

title: Running Xcode tests
body: If you are experiencing package dependency errors when using Xcode Test for iOS Step, check out this Knowledge Base article for possible solutions.

title: Running Xcode tests
body: You can also generate code coverage files, and export the test results as a compressed zip file.

title: Running Xcode tests
body: Test reports

title: Running Xcode tests
body: Your Xcode test results will be exported to Test Reports: check out our Test Reports guide to find out how to make it work for you.

title: Configuring the Xcode tests on Bitrise
body: The default input values of the Xcode Test for iOS Step could work if your tests are written correctly. However, we recommend making sure that all the inputs have the value you want so the Step can do what you need!

title: Configuring the Xcode tests on Bitrise
body: Exporting the generated result

title: Configuring the Xcode tests on Bitrise
body: The Xcode Test for iOS Step generates an .xcresult bundle and exports it to a location set in the Env Var $BITRISE_XCRESULT_PATH.

title: Configuring the Xcode tests on Bitrise
body: Be aware that some tools, like xcov, will look for the results bundle in its default location, not at $BITRISE_XCRESULT_PATH. Because of this your build will fail when using those tools. You need to configure them to look for the bundle in the location set by the Env Var. Here’s an example xcov setup:

title: Configuring the Xcode tests on Bitrise
body:
xcov.report(
 scheme: 'ExampleScheme',
 workspace: 'example.xcworkspace',
 xccov_file_direct_path: ENV['BITRISE_XCRESULT_PATH'],
 include_targets: 'Example.app,ExampleShared.framework,ExampleWidget.appex'
)

title: Configuring the Xcode tests on Bitrise
body: Check the following required inputs of the Xcode Test for iOS Step before running a build. These inputs determine the sort of tests the Step will run.

title: Configuring the Xcode tests on Bitrise
body: Scheme: the Xcode scheme you use must be marked as Shared in Xcode!

title: Configuring the Xcode tests on Bitrise
body: Device: set it to the value that is shown in Xcode’s device selection dropdown menu.

title: Configuring the Xcode tests on Bitrise
body: OS version: set it to the value that is shown in Xcode’s device selection dropdown menu.

title: Configuring the Xcode tests on Bitrise
body: Platform: set it to the value that is shown in Xcode’s device selection dropdown menu.

title: Configuring the Xcode tests on Bitrise
body: Headless mode

title: Configuring the Xcode tests on Bitrise
body: From Xcode 9 onwards, tests are run in headless mode by default: this means that the simulator will run in the background only. To change it, go to the Step’s Debug input group and set the Run the test in headless mode? input’s value to no. However, with this option, tests will take more time.

title: Configuring the Xcode tests on Bitrise
body: Using xcpretty

title: Configuring the Xcode tests on Bitrise
body: The xcpretty output tool does not support parallel tests. If parallel tests are enabled in your project, go to the Step’s xcodebuild log formatting input group and set the Log formatter input’s value to xcodebuild or xcbeautify.

title: Rerunning failed tests (Not available in Xcode 13)
body: The Should retry test on failure? (Not available in Xcode 13+) input in the Debug section of the Xcode Test for iOS Step allows you to automatically rerun ALL your tests, not just the failed ones. If you set this input to yes, the Step will run xcodebuild one more time in the case of test failure.

title: Rerunning failed tests (Not available in Xcode 13)
body: From Xcode 13 and above the Should retry test on failure? (Not available in Xcode 13+) feature is not available anymore. We recommend you use Test Repetitions Mode (Available in Xcode 13+) input with the retry_on_failure option selected. This allows you to rerun only the failed test/s instead of running all your tests. You can find this test repetition feature with our Xcode Test for iOS Step from version 3.0.0 and above.

title: Test Repetitions
body: Xcode’s test repetition modes are available with the Xcode Test for iOS Step on stacks running Xcode 13 and above on Bitrise. With test repetitions, you can run any type of tests multiple times in various ways such as retry on failure, until failure and until max repetitions.

title: Test Repetitions
body: The Xcode Test for iOS Step’s Test Repetitions Mode (Available in Xcode 13+) input offers the following options:

title: Test Repetitions
body: none: The tests won’t repeat.

title: Test Repetitions
body: until_failure: Repeats a test until the test fails or until the maximum repetition. The default number of test runs is three.

title: Test Repetitions
body: retry_on_failure: Failed tests run until they succeed or until the repetition number you specify. The default number of test repetitions is three.

title: Test Repetitions
body: up_until_maximum_repetitions: Reruns all tests until maximum test repetition is reached regardless of the test outcomes.

title: Test Repetitions
body: Please note that these options are only available from Xcode Test for iOS version 3.0.0 and above.

title: Test Repetitions
body: With the Maximum Test Repetitions (Available in Xcode 13+) input you can specify the maximum number of test repetitions. Please note that you have to add a greater number than one if the Test Repetition Mode (Available in Xcode 13+) input is set to other than none.

title: Test Repetitions
body: Enable the Relaunch Tests for Each Repetition (Available in Xcode 13+) input to launch tests in a completely new process for each repetition.

title: Installing an .ipa file
body: You can install .ipa files either from the public install page or from the Artifacts tab of your build.

title: Installing an .ipa file
body: You can install .ipa files either from the public install page or from the Artifacts tab of your build.

title: Installing an .ipa file
body: Both the public install page and accessing the .ipa file from the Artifacts tab enables you to install .ipa files on provisioned and registered test devices. The allowed device types are: iPhone and iPad.

title: Installing an .ipa file
body: Installing an .ipa file on a test device consist of three phases: initiating the device compatibility check, installing a configuration profile on the test device, then finishing up with installing the app on the device.

title: Installing an .ipa file
body: In this tutorial we’re describing:

title: Installing an .ipa file
body: How to install an app on a registered test device without a Bitrise account (for anyone who has not subscribed to Bitrise but wishes to check out the current version of the app).

title: Installing an .ipa file
body: How to install an app on a test device which is yet to be registered on Bitrise (for Bitrise users).

title: Installing an .ipa file
body: Installing an .ipa file from the Artifacts tab

title: Installing an .ipa file
body: Installing an .ipa file from the Artifacts tab is only possible for Bitrise users.

title: Prepping for installation
body: Before installing the app on any test device, the app’s developer has to complete a couple of steps to build the app and share it with anyone:

title: Prepping for installation
body: The device, on which the app will be installed, is registered as a test device at the developer’s Apple account.

title: Prepping for installation
body: The device has to be included in the provisioning profile of the app.

title: Prepping for installation
body: The device meets the minimum OS requirements of the app.

title: Prepping for installation
body: Please note that if the test device is not registered on the Apple Developer portal, the developer has to manually add it to the device list, and re-build the app so that the .ipa file contains the test device/s the app can be installed on. We also recommend you register the test device on Bitrise as well.

title: Prepping for installation
body: Which browser should I use with the public install page?

title: Prepping for installation
body: Anyone who wishes to install the app on a test device has to make sure that the public install page of the app is opened in a native Safari session with non-incognito mode.

title: Installing an .ipa file from Bitrise's public install page to an iPad with iPadOS
body: If you are using an iPad running iPadOS, make sure that you open the Bitrise public install page in mobile mode.

title: Installing an .ipa file from Bitrise's public install page to an iPad with iPadOS
body: When you open the public install page of an .ipa file, Bitrise checks if the device is stored in the embedded provisioning profile or not. This check can only complete if you visit the public install page in mobile mode instead of the desktop version. We suggest that you switch to mobile mode temporarily.

title: Installing an .ipa file from Bitrise's public install page to an iPad with iPadOS
body: You can easily switch to mobile mode temporarily if you tap the ᴀA icon on the left corner of the Safari address bar and then tap the Show Mobile Website option.

title: Installing an .ipa file on test devices from the public install page
body: The public install page is a convenient way of sharing the latest version of your app with team members and any other stakeholders who wish to check the app out. The page includes all the important details of the build such as filename, size, version code, minimum SDK version, and build number. Anyone, whose email address or Bitrise team role you add before building the app, will receive an email from Bitrise with a link to the public install page. The public install page’s direct link can be shared with anyone as well. From there they can quickly install the app on their own test device.

title: Installing an .ipa file on test devices from the public install page
body: During this whole flow, use a native, non-incognito Safari session instead of any other in-app browser type. If you follow the link in the notification email you got from Bitrise, the public install page will automatically open in a native Safari session.

title: Installing an .ipa file on test devices from the public install page
body: Would you rather download the app?

title: Installing an .ipa file on test devices from the public install page
body: If you only wish to download the app and manually upload it somewhere else, you can find the download button on the Artifacts page of the build. Please note that downloading an app does not mean you can install it on the test device.

title: Installing an app on a test device without a Bitrise account
body: Long tap on the link you received from Bitrise. To open the link in native Safari, tap Open Link. It brings up the public install page in a native Safari session. If you copy the link from the email, make sure you paste it in a native Safari session.

title: Installing an app on a test device without a Bitrise account
body: Tap the link in the Click here to check device compatibility of this device with this app yellow message box. If you cannot see this message, you are most likely using another browser so switch to Safari.

title: Installing an app on a test device without a Bitrise account
body: Tap Allow on the pop-up to install the configuration profile on your device. This configuration profile makes the device’s UDID available to Bitrise for the compatibility check.

title: Installing an app on a test device without a Bitrise account
body: A pop-up confirms the configuration profile has been downloaded, and it can be installed in the Settings app. Tap Close.

title: Installing an app on a test device without a Bitrise account
body: Tap the Home button to go the the home screen.

title: Installing an app on a test device without a Bitrise account
body: Open Settings. You can find the downloaded profile at the top of the Settings. Tap Profile Downloaded menu item on the left to install the profile.

title: Installing an app on a test device without a Bitrise account
body: Tap Install.

title: Installing an app on a test device without a Bitrise account
body: Type your device’s passcode in the Enter passcode pop-up.

title: Installing an app on a test device without a Bitrise account
body: Tap Install again.

title: Installing an app on a test device without a Bitrise account
body: Wait until the profile is installed.

title: Installing an app on a test device without a Bitrise account
body: Once the profile is installed, you’re directed to the public install page. As you can see, the Install button is now available. Tap it!

title: Installing an app on a test device without a Bitrise account
body: Tap OK on the next pop-up.

title: Installing an app on a test device without a Bitrise account
body: As a final confirmation, tap on Install and press the Home button. Now you’re installing the app to your test device.

title: Installing an app on a test device without a Bitrise account
body: Wait till the app installs on your test device’s home screen.

title: Installing an app on a test device without a Bitrise account
body: Check out the app you’ve successfully installed on your test device.

title: Installing an app on a test device not registered to Bitrise
body: If you’re accessing the public install page from a test device which displays the below message, you’ll have to register the device on Bitrise which is only a few steps different from the above flow.

title: Installing an app on a test device not registered to Bitrise
body: Please note that you can only add a test device to Bitrise if you already have a Bitrise account.

title: Installing an app on a test device not registered to Bitrise
body: Tap Click here to start the device registration process.

title: Installing an app on a test device not registered to Bitrise
body: Tap Allow to download the configuration profile.

title: Installing an app on a test device not registered to Bitrise
body: When the configuration profile is downloaded, tap Close.

title: Installing an app on a test device not registered to Bitrise
body: Tap the Home button to go to your Settings app on your test device’s home screen.

title: Installing an app on a test device not registered to Bitrise
body: Open Settings. You can find the downloaded profile at the top of the Settings. Tap Profile Downloaded menu item on the left to install the profile.

title: Installing an app on a test device not registered to Bitrise
body: Tap Install.

title: Installing an app on a test device not registered to Bitrise
body: Type your device’s passcode in the Enter Passcode pop-up.

title: Installing an app on a test device not registered to Bitrise
body: Tap Install again in the Install Profile pop-up.

title: Installing an app on a test device not registered to Bitrise
body: Wait until the profile installation is complete. You automatically get redirected to the Register your test device page.

title: Installing an app on a test device not registered to Bitrise
body: Your device’s name and UDID gets populated automatically. You can only change the device name here. Tap Register Device.

title: Installing an app on a test device not registered to Bitrise
body: You land on the public install page where the Install button is now available. Tap it!

title: Installing an app on a test device not registered to Bitrise
body: Tap OK on the prompt.

title: Installing an app on a test device not registered to Bitrise
body: To install the app on your test device, tap on Install. Then press the Home button to follow the installment of your app.

title: Installing an app on a test device not registered to Bitrise
body: If all went well, you can find the installed app on your test device’s Home page.

title: Installing an .ipa file on test devices from the Artifacts tab
body: You can install an .ipa file from the Artifacts tab of your app's build. This provides a more secure way compared to the public install page but requires you to log in to your Bitrise account, making it less viable for external testers.

title: Installing an .ipa file on test devices from the Artifacts tab
body: To install an .ipa file from the Artifacts tab:

title: Installing an .ipa file on test devices from the Artifacts tab
body: Open your app on Bitrise.

title: Installing an .ipa file on test devices from the Artifacts tab
body: Select the build with the .ipa file you would like to install.

title: Installing an .ipa file on test devices from the Artifacts tab
body: Go to the Artifacts tab.

title: Installing an .ipa file on test devices from the Artifacts tab
body: Click on Download next to the .ipa file.

title: Installing an .ipa file on test devices from the Artifacts tab
body: Click Install, under the Install the app on your iOS device section.

title: Registering a test device
body: You can register a test device easily by opening Safari on your iOS device and accessing the Test devices page from your Profile. With other browsers, you can manually register one using the Register device manually button.

title: Registering a test device
body: You have multiple options to register test devices on bitrise.io:

title: Registering a test device
body: Open Safari on your iOS device and access the Test devices tab from your Profile settings page.

title: Registering a test device
body: Manually register a device from the Test devices tab from your Profile settings page.

title: Registering a test device
body: After registering your device on Bitrise, make sure to register it on the Apple Developer Portal as well. Alternatively, you can set the Xcode Archive & Export for iOS Step's Register test devices on the Apple Developer Portal input to true under the Automatic code signing category to register all available test devices of the app.

title: Registering a test device
body: Apple Developer Portal device limit

title: Registering a test device
body: There is a limit on registrable devices on the Apple Developer Portal, so make sure to check the list of available test devices of an app before you use the Xcode Archive & Export for iOS Step's Register test devices on the Apple Developer Portal input to register devices!

title: Register an iOS device using Safari
body: The most comfortable way to register your iOS test device on bitrise.io is to open bitrise.io with Safari. This way we can open your device’s Settings and create a temporary profile to get your Unique Device Identifier (UDID). This way you don’t have to look for it and manually copy/paste it.

title: Register an iOS device using Safari
body: Clear the cache

title: Register an iOS device using Safari
body: When trying to install an app from the public install page, you should clear the cache: click the link appearing in the If you synced your settings from your old device, you need to clear the cache and register your new device line. The link redirects to the Profile settings page where you can follow the procedure described below.

title: Register an iOS device using Safari
body: Read more about installing an app from the public install page in our Deploying an iOS app to Bitrise.io guide.

title: Register an iOS device using Safari
body: Open Safari in non-incognito mode on your iOS device and log into bitrise.io.

title: Register an iOS device using Safari
body: Go to your Profile.

title: Register an iOS device using Safari
body: Tap Account Settings.

title: Register an iOS device using Safari
body: Tap Test devices on the left.

title: Register an iOS device using Safari
body: Tap Register this device.

title: Register an iOS device using Safari
body: In the pop-up window, Tap Allow so that bitrise.io can show your configuration profile.

title: Register an iOS device using Safari
body: Tap Install when the Install Profile dialog appears.

title: Register an iOS device using Safari
body: Enter your devices’s passcode.

title: Register an iOS device using Safari
body: Tap Install on the Install Profile again. Now you can see your UDID and your iOS device name in the Register device dialog.

title: Register an iOS device using Safari
body: Tap Register device.

title: Register an iOS device using Safari
body: Register this test device to the Apple Developer Portal with the correct provisioning profile added to your device or use our Auto Provisioning step with enabling profile generation.

title: Register an iOS device using Safari
body: If you go back to Test devices, you can see the registered device:

title: Register an iOS device using Safari
body: You can delete the registered device any time if you click on the Remove button.

title: Register a test device manually
body: On bitrise.io, open the account selector menu on the top right and select Profile settings.

title: Register a test device manually
body: On the menu on the left side, select Test devices.

title: Register a test device manually
body: Click on Register device manually.

title: Register a test device manually
body: In the Register device dialog, fill out the Title field and the Identifier field with your device’s UDID.

title: Register a test device manually
body: Click Register Devices.

title: Register a test device manually
body: You can get your UDID if you plug your device into a computer, and open iTunes. Under Summary, you should see a Serial Number. If you click on it, it will reveal your device’s UDID which you can paste into the Identifier field on our Test Devices.

title: Register a test device manually
body: Register this test device to the Apple Developer Portal with the correct provisioning profile added to your device or use our Auto Provisioning Step with enabling profile generation.

title: Register a test device manually
body: Now you can see your registered test device under the Registered test devices section.

title: Register a test device manually
body: You can remove this registered device any time if you click the orange x icon.

title: Checking the available test devices for an app
body: For any Bitrise app, you can check out the registered test devices available on the App Settings page. This will show an aggregated list of all registered test devices associated with users who have access to your app, regardless of their role. You can use any of those devices to run tests of your app.

title: Checking the available test devices for an app
body: You can also download the list of registered devices as a .json file.

title: Checking the available test devices for an app
body: Admin access only

title: Checking the available test devices for an app
body: Only users with the role of admin on the app's team can access all functions of the App Settings page of an app.

title: Checking the available test devices for an app
body: Open your app on Bitrise.

title: Checking the available test devices for an app
body: On the main page of the app, click on the App Settings icon: .

title: Checking the available test devices for an app
body: On the menu on the left side, select Test devices.

title: Checking the available test devices for an app
body: Optionally, you can download the entire list as a .json file: click the Download as json button.

title: Device testing for iOS
body: With Bitrise’s iOS device testing solution, you can run iOS tests on physical devices without having to set up and register your own devices.

title: Device testing for iOS
body: With Bitrise’s iOS device testing solution, you can run iOS tests on physical devices without having to set up and register your own devices: you just need to use our dedicated Steps and set the device type(s) on which you want to test your app. There are no limits to using the Step, other than your overall build time limit.

title: Device testing for iOS
body: Our device testing solution is based on Firebase Test Lab: it uses real, production devices running in a Google data center to test your app. The devices are flashed with updated APIs and have customizable locale settings. You can find the resulting logs, videos and screenshots on Bitrise.

title: Device testing for iOS
body: For iOS apps, Firebase Test Lab runs XCTest tests. Find the list of the available devices here.

title: Device testing for iOS
body: Limitations

title: Device testing for iOS
body: You might be limited by your overall build time. Also note that a single build can contain only one iOS Device Testing Step, performing one type of test. This is because Bitrise sends the build slug to Firebase Test Lab. Sending the same build slug results in a Build already existserror.

title: Running device tests for iOS apps
body: To run device tests with the Firebase Test Lab solution, you will need to add two Steps to your Workflow:

title: Running device tests for iOS apps
body: Xcode Build for testing for iOS.

title: Running device tests for iOS apps
body: iOS Device Testing.

title: Running device tests for iOS apps
body: Beta status

title: Running device tests for iOS apps
body: Please note that currently, both Steps are in beta phase. They are already stable and work well but we’re working on improving them!

title: Running device tests for iOS apps
body: The Xcode Build for testing for iOS Step performs the xcodebuild command’s build-for-testing action: it builds the tests defined in your iOS app’s Xcode scheme. The Step exports a .zip file that contains your test directory (by default, it’s Debug-iphoneos) and the xctestrun file.

title: Running device tests for iOS apps
body: To use this Step, you will need code signing files for the test app: we recommend using codesigndoc to export the necessary files!

title: Running device tests for iOS apps
body: The iOS Device Testing Step takes the path to this .zip file - exported as an Environment Variable - as input to run your tests and export the test results to Bitrise.

title: Running device tests for iOS apps
body: Automatic vs manual code signing asset management

title: Running device tests for iOS apps
body: The Xcode Build for testing for iOS Step can manage your code signing assets without you having to manually manage your provisioning profiles. This only requires you to select the relevant inputs in the Step (see below) and upload the right certificates to the Code Signing tab. This is the automatic code signing asset management method.

title: Running device tests for iOS apps
body: If you decide to chose the manual code signing asset management, then add the Add the Certificate and Profile Installer Step before the Xcode Build for testing for iOS Step. The former will take care of the code signing asset management while the latter builds your project. Make sure the Automatic code signing method input of the Xcode Build for testing for iOS Step is set to off.

title: Running device tests for iOS apps
body: The instructions below detail the steps of setting up automatic code signing asset management on Bitrise with the Xcode Build for testing for iOS Step.

title: Running device tests for iOS apps
body: Add the Xcode Build for testing for iOS Step to your Workflow.

title: Running device tests for iOS apps
body: Note that it should come AFTER the Certificate and profile installer Step.

title: Running device tests for iOS apps
body: In the Scheme name input, set the Xcode Scheme you want to use. By default, the value of the input is the $BITRISE_SCHEME Environment Variable which is stored when your app is created.

title: Running device tests for iOS apps
body: By default, the scheme defines which configuration - for example, Debugor Release- will be used. In the Configuration name input, you can define the configuration type manually.

title: Running device tests for iOS apps
body: Set a destination option for xcodebuild in the Device destination input of the Step.The default value is generic/platform=ios. For the available values, call man xcodebuild on your local machine and check the Destinations section of the printout.

title: Running device tests for iOS apps
body: Set the Automatic code signing method input to the Apple service connection you want to use for code signing. The available options are:

title: Running device tests for iOS apps
body: off if you don’t do automatic code signing.

title: Running device tests for iOS apps
body: api-keyif you use API key authorization.

title: Running device tests for iOS apps
body: apple-idif you use Apple ID authorization.

title: Running device tests for iOS apps
body: Add the iOS Device Testing Step to the Workflow.The Step has to come after the Xcode Build for testing for iOS Step.

title: Running device tests for iOS apps
body: In the Test devices input field, specify the devices on which you want to test the app.Find the list of the available devices here.

title: Running device tests for iOS apps
body: Make sure you have the Deploy to Bitrise.io Step in your Workflow, with version 1.4.1 or newer. With the older versions of the Step, you won’t be able to check your results on the Test Reports page!

title: Running device tests for iOS apps
body: Start a build.

title: Running device tests for iOS apps
body: If all goes well, you should be able to view your results on the Builds page.
