title: Android unit tests
body: You can perform unit tests using the Android Unit Test Step, and view the results in the Test Reports Add-on.

title: Running a unit test
body: Unit tests are useful if you want to verify individual code blocks, catch bugs or prevent crashes as early as possible.

title: Running a unit test
body: This tutorial tells you how to run a unit test against your app and how to generate test reports using your primary workflow.

title: Running a unit test
body: Luckily, your Android primary workflow already contains the Android Unit Test Step which is responsible for performing unit test on your build.

title: Running a unit test
body: Using custom steps/scripts

title: Running a unit test
body: If you use custom steps or scripts, our Deploy to Bitrise.io Step by default deploys files/build artifacts from the $BITRISE_DEPLOY_DIR directory, so make sure that you move the generated app there.

title: Running a unit test
body: Alternatively, set the deploy directory or the file path input of the step to point to the location of the files/build artifacts.

title: Running a unit test
body: Please note, that if the specified path is a directory, then every file in that directory will be deployed. If there are subdirectories in the specified directory, they won’t get uploaded! You can upload a directory’s content recursively, if you use the Compress option, which will compress the whole directory including every subdirectory. And finally, if you specify a file path, then only the specified file will get deployed.

title: Running a unit test
body: Check your logs in the case of failed builds

title: Running a unit test
body: If your build has failed, click on Download logs on your Build’s page. In the last lines of your Step log, you can view the error message and fix the error accordingly. If you’re done, commit your changes to your repository, and a new build should start automatically.

title: Generating and checking test results
body: You can check your Android unit test results on the Test Reports page. The Android Unit Test Step generates and exports unit test reports into the $BITRISE_TEST_DEPLOY_DIR folder. Then the Deploy to Bitrise.io  Step exports those reports from the $BITRISE_TEST_DEPLOY_DIR folder to the respective build’s Test Reports page where you can view the test results.

title: Generating and checking test results
body: Step versions supporting Test Reports

title: Generating and checking test results
body: The Deploy to Bitrise.io Step must be of version 1.4.1 or newer and the Android Unit Test Step must be of version 0.10.0 or newer since older versions of the Steps do NOT support Test Reports.

title: Device testing for Android
body: With Bitrise’s Android virtual device testing solution, you can run UI tests on emulators without having to set up and register your own devices.

title: Device testing for Android
body: With Bitrise’s Android virtual device testing solution, you can run UI tests on emulators without having to set up and register your own devices.

title: Device testing for Android
body: Limitations

title: Device testing for Android
body: You might be limited by your overall build time. Also note that a single build can contain only one [BETA] Virtual Device Testing Step performing one type of test (instrumentation, robo or gameloop).

title: Device testing for Android
body: Our device testing solution is based on Firebase Test Lab. You can find the resulting logs, videos and screenshots on Bitrise.

title: Running tests
body: With Bitrise, you can choose from 3 different test types:

title: Running tests
body: robo (default test type in Bitrise).

title: Running tests
body: instrumentation.

title: Running tests
body: gameloop.

title: Running tests
body: If you want to read up on the difference between these test types, take a look at Firebase’s documentation.

title: Running tests
body: There is a small difference between configuring your workflow for robo and instrumentation tests, so let’s see them separately!

title: Running robo tests
body: Open the Workflow you want to use in the Workflow Editor.

title: Running robo tests
body: Add the Android Build Step after the Android Unit Test  Step to export an APK.

title: Running robo tests
body: Add the Debug task to the Variant Step input field. This will prepare an env var containing the APK path of your build. You will need this env var in the next step.

title: Running robo tests
body: Add [BETA] Virtual Device Testing for Android Step after the Android Build Step.

title: Running robo tests
body: Set the APK path input field.

title: Running robo tests
body: Check if robo is the selected Test type.

title: Running robo tests
body: Add the type of test device in the Test devices input field. If choosing a different device than the default, your input should have the format of deviceID, version, language, orientation separated with ,. Find the list of the available devices here.

title: Running robo tests
body: Start a build and check your test results.

title: Setting user input with Robo directives for successful robo tests
body: If your app needs specific user interaction for a successful robo test, you can use the Robo Directives input field to set those necessary inputs. For example, certain UI elements of the app are only accessible for robo testing if the required user inputs (username and email address) are populated for log in.

title: Setting user input with Robo directives for successful robo tests
body: Click the [BETA] Virtual Device Testing for Android Step in your workflow.

title: Setting user input with Robo directives for successful robo tests
body: Click the Robo Test section.

title: Setting user input with Robo directives for successful robo tests
body: Find the Robo directives input field and set your required user input directives.

title: Setting user input with Robo directives for successful robo tests
body: provide a comma-separated list of key-value pairs, where the key is the Android resource name of the target UI element, and the value is the text string. EditText fields are supported but not text fields in WebView UI elements. For example, you could use the following parameter for custom login:

title: Setting user input with Robo directives for successful robo tests
body:
username_resource,username,ENTER_TEXT
password_resource,password,ENTER_TEXT
loginbtn_resource,,SINGLE_CLICK

title: Setting user input with Robo directives for successful robo tests
body: One directive per line, the parameters are separated with , character. For example: ResourceName,InputText,ActionType.

title: Setting user input with Robo directives for successful robo tests
body: Based on the input you provide, you can successfully run a robo test (even on pages that are only accessible with a specific user input) and check the test results on the Test Reports page. The test results can be, for example:

title: Setting user input with Robo directives for successful robo tests
body: Screenshots.

title: Setting user input with Robo directives for successful robo tests
body: Recorded video.

title: Setting user input with Robo directives for successful robo tests
body: Logs.

title: Setting user input with Robo directives for successful robo tests
body: Files.

title: Setting user input with Robo directives for successful robo tests
body: Here is a screenshot of a successful robo test, where the robo test got all the way through to My application by populating the email and password fields first with the pre-defined directives from the Robo directives.

title: Running instrumentation tests
body: Open the Workflow you want to use in the Workflow Editor.

title: Running instrumentation tests
body: Add the Android Build for UI testing Step to your Workflow.

title: Running instrumentation tests
body: To export an APK and a Test APK, you have to set the following input fields in the Android Build for UI testing Step. The Step outputs will be BITRISE_APK_PATH (which is the path of the generated APK after filtering) and BITRISE_TEST_APK_PATH (which is the path of the generated test APK after filtering).

title: Running instrumentation tests
body: Project Location: the root directory of your Android project.

title: Running instrumentation tests
body: Module: set the module you wish to build.

title: Running instrumentation tests
body: Variant: set the variant you wish to build (usually debug).

title: Running instrumentation tests
body: The Step outputs will be BITRISE_APK_PATH (which is the path of the generated APK after filtering) and BITRISE_TEST_APK_PATH (which is the path of the generated test APK after filtering).

title: Running instrumentation tests
body: Add the [BETA] Virtual Device Testing Step right after the Android Build for UI testing Step.

body: Set the Test type to instrumentation. Our Android Build for UI Testing Step exports an APK and a Test APK and their paths get automatically set in the APK path and Test APK path input fields of the [BETA] Virtual Device Testing Step.

title: Running instrumentation tests
body: Add the type of test device in the Test devices input field. If choosing a different device than the default, your input should have the format of device ID,version,language,orientation separated with a  ,.

title: Running Detox tests on Bitrise
body: Detox is a gray box end-to-end tests and automation library for mobile apps built with React Native. If you have a React Native app on Bitrise, you can run Detox tests.

title: Running Detox tests on Bitrise
body: Detox is a gray box end-to-end tests and automation library for mobile apps built with React Native. It supports both iOS and Android apps. If you have a React Native app on Bitrise, you can run Detox tests.

title: Before you start
body: Running Detox requires:

title: Before you start
body: A Mac with a macOS (El Capitan 10.11 or newer version).

title: Before you start
body: Xcode 8.3 or newer version with Xcode command line tools.

title: Before you start
body: A working React Native app.

title: Before you start
body: Install and set up Detox for your project. You will need to install Homebrew, Node.js and applesimutils, as well as the Detox command line tools. Add Detox to your project and then create and run Detox tests locally. If you have an Android app, go through this guide after the initial setup process.

title: Before you start
body: Once you are done, you can test your Detox-configured project on Bitrise.

title: Running a Detox test
body: Create a release device configuration inside package.json under the detoxsection.

title: Running a Detox test
body: Example:

title: Running a Detox test
Running a Detox test
body: On bitrise.io, go to your project and open the Workflow Editor.

title: Running a Detox test
body: Switch to the Workflow you want to use.

title: Running a Detox test
body: Add a Run npm command Step to your Workflow.

title: Running a Detox test
body: Add the Detox install command to the The npm command with arguments to run input:

title: Running a Detox test
body: install -g detox-cli

title: Running a Detox test
body: Install a test runner.

title: Running a Detox test
body: For example, our sample app uses mocha, installed with the yarn Step. To install yarn dependencies, just set the The yarn command to run input’s value to install.

title: Running a Detox test
body: Add a Script Step to install the necessary utilities and then run Detox.

title: Running a Detox test
body:
#!/bin/bash
 
# applesimutils is a collection of utils for Apple simulators
brew tap wix/brew
brew install applesimutils
 
# we are building and testing a release device configuration
detox build --configuration ios.sim.release
detox test --configuration ios.sim.release --cleanup

title: Running a Detox test
body: You can, of course, put each of these commands in separate Script Steps, for the sake of modularity.

title: Running a Detox test
body: Run a build.

title: Running a Detox test
body: If the build fails, check out our example bitrise.yml file:

title: Running a Detox test
body:
---
workflows:
 primary:
 steps:
 - activate-ssh-key: {}
 - git-clone:
 inputs:
 - clone_depth: ''
 title: Git Clone Repo
 - yarn@0.0.8:
 inputs:
 - command: install
 - npm@1.0.1:
 inputs:
 - command: install -g detox-cli
 title: Install Detox CLI
 - script@1.1.5:
 inputs:
 - content: |-
 #!/bin/bash
 brew tap wix/brew
 brew install applesimutils
 
 detox build --configuration ios.sim.release
 detox test --configuration ios.sim.release --cleanup
 title: Detox - Build and Test Release App
 - deploy-to-bitrise-io@1.3.18: {}
Troubleshootin

title: Troubleshooting Detox tests
body: If you run into issues with using Detox on Bitrise, we recommend trying to rebuild the entire Detox package before running the test.

title: Troubleshooting Detox tests
body: To do so, run the following command in your Bitrise build:

title: Troubleshooting Detox tests
body: npm rebuild detox

title: Troubleshooting Detox tests
body: If your Detox tests still fail or hang, contact our support!

title: Measuring your code coverage with Codecov
body: Codecov is the leading code coverage solution for CI/CD pipelines, delivering coverage metrics right into your workflow. It integrates directly with Bitrise to provide valuable insights on code quality in order to allow users to ship healthier code with less risk.

title: Measuring your code coverage with Codecov
body: Codecov provides many features that make test coverage more available and actionable to speed up your development process and to deliver high-quality applications.

title: Measuring your code coverage with Codecov
body: Some of these features include:

title: Measuring your code coverage with Codecov
body: Coverage changes overlaid with your source code, making it even easier to identify needed test areas.

title: Measuring your code coverage with Codecov
body: Multi-language support so you can use Codecov right out of the box.

title: Measuring your code coverage with Codecov
body: Summary of coverage information directly in your Workflow so that you can add and update tests quickly and effectively.

title: Measuring your code coverage with Codecov
body: Status checks to block underperforming pull requests from being merged.

title: Measuring your code coverage with Codecov
body: Seamless coverage report merging for Workflows that upload multiple reports across jobs.

title: Measuring your code coverage with Codecov
body: Custom coverage information based on groupings using Codecov Flags.

title: Integrating Codecov with Bitrise
body: In order to start using Codecov, you must be generating coverage reports with your preferred coverage tool (for example, Xcode or Gradle).

title: Integrating Codecov with Bitrise
body: Create an account on https://codecov.io.

title: Integrating Codecov with Bitrise
body: Go to repository’s Settings tab on Codecov and copy the repository upload token.

title: Integrating Codecov with Bitrise
body: Add the Codecov Step to your Workflow on Bitrise. Make sure you add the Step after the Steps that test and collect coverage.

title: Integrating Codecov with Bitrise
body: Add the Codecov upload token as a secret variable, CODECOV_TOKEN, and set the Expose for Pull Requests option to true. Click Add new.

title: Integrating Codecov with Bitrise
body: Click Save and start a new build to get coverage metrics.

title: Integrating Codecov with Bitrise
body: Additional options

title: Integrating Codecov with Bitrise
body: The Codecov Step wraps around the Codecov bash uploader. You can add additional options in the Step listed in our arguments documentation.

title: Viewing your coverage reports on Codecov
body: To view your coverage on Codecov, you can do the following:

title: Viewing your coverage reports on Codecov
body: View the URL supplied on the Codecov Step on Bitrise.

title: Viewing your coverage reports on Codecov
body: Go to https://codecov.io and navigate directly to the applicable pull request or commit.

title: Viewing your coverage reports on Codecov
body: Click on the links provided by Codecov that are available on your code host’s status checks or pull request comment.

title: What's next?
body: Now that you have code coverage reports, you can take it to the next level with the following suggestions:

title: What's next?
body: Set non-blocking status checks to get your developers in the habit of thinking about code coverage.

title: What's next?
body: Start working towards code coverage by setting status checks to increase overall coverage on every pull request.

title: What's next?
body: Isolate your coverage reports for different types of tests or different parts of your system with Flags to measure what matters.

title: What's next?
body: Already using flags and don’t want to run your entire test suite with every Bitrise CI run? Try out Carryforward Flags to measure only what changes.

title: Measuring your code coverage with Codecov
Deploying
body: Deploy your apps to simulators, test devices, or app stores with the help of Bitrise. You can use our Steps or Ship, our dedicated deployment solution.

title: Deploying
body: Deployment can mean a number of things on Bitrise: you can deploy your app to test devices, or to bitrise.io, with a public install page that you can freely distribute so that anyone can test the app; you can deploy your app to a simulator, to conduct UI testing, for example; and of course you can deploy your apps to online stores, such as the App Store or the Google Play Store.

title: Deploying
body: We also recommend checking out Ship, our deployment solution that aims to save you a lot of headache in publishing your apps.

title: Android deployment
body: Deploy Android apps to either bitrise.io, for testing, or to the Google Play Store, for release.

title: Android deployment
body: Deploy Android apps to either bitrise.io, for testing, or to the Google Play Store, for release. Learn about Google Play API, keystore files and APK flavors.

title: Android deployment
body: We recommend checking out Ship, our deployment solution that aims to save you a lot of headache in publishing your apps: Deploying with Ship.

title: Deploying Android apps to Bitrise and Google Play
body: You can deploy your Android apps to Bitrise or to Google Play by using our dedicated Steps and correctly configuring your project in Google Play Console.

title: Deploying Android apps to Bitrise and Google Play
body: This guide describes how you can add your Android project to bitrise.io and deploy the APK or AAB built from your project to Google Play Store.

title: Deploying Android apps to Bitrise and Google Play
body: You need a new service account created in the Google Play Console so that Bitrise can authenticate with Google Play Deploy during your build. The new service account has to be invited to Google Play Console as a user with the appropriate permission.

title: Deploying Android apps to Bitrise and Google Play
body: To set up your project for the first time:

title: Deploying Android apps to Bitrise and Google Play
body: Register a Google Play Developer Account. If you already have a Google Play Developer account, and have already deployed your app to Google Play Store, skip to Setting up Google Play API access.

title: Deploying Android apps to Bitrise and Google Play
body: Go through Setting up Google Play deployment for the first time.

title: Setting up Google Play API access
body: Grant the Google Play API access to your project by either creating a new API project or linking an existing API project. In this tutorial, we’re creating a new one.

title: Setting up Google Play API access
body: Go to your Google Play Console and click Settings. Click API access on the left menu bar. On the Linked Google Cloud project page, select Create new project option.

title: Setting up Google Play API access
body: On the API access page, scroll down to Service accounts and click Create a new service account. Follow the instructions to get to Google Cloud Platform.

title: Setting up Google Play API access
body: On the Google Cloud Platform, click + CREATE SERVICE ACCOUNT on the top menu bar.

title: Setting up Google Play API access
body: A 3-step Create service account page comes up, where you have to provide a Service account name first. A Service account ID is automatically generated based on the Service account name you typed.

title: Setting up Google Play API access
body: At the Grant this service account access to project step, select Browser in the Role dropdown. Although the second and third steps of the process are marked optional on Google Cloud Platform, those are essential for Bitrise to be able to use the service account access.

title: Setting up Google Play API access
body: Fill out the Service account user role and Service account admins role fields of the Grant users access to this service account step. Hit DONE.

title: Setting up Google Play API access
body: You land back on the API Access page of the Google Play Console where you can create a key to your new service account. Bitrise will use the key to authenticate as the service account. Click the ellipsis next to the new service account and select Manage keys from the options.

title: Setting up Google Play API access
body: You are directed to the KEYS page of the Service accounts. Click the ADD KEY dropdown and select Create new key option.

title: Setting up Google Play API access
body: Select JSON as your Key type. Click CREATE. Once you created a key here, it automatically downloads to your local machine and you can upload it to the Code Signing tab of Bitrise. You may close your Google Cloud Platform window as we won’t need it any more.

title: Setting up Google Play API access
body: You are landing back on the API access page of Google Play Console where you can see your new service account under Service accounts. Click Grant access to link your project to the Google Console. The Google Cloud Platform (GCP) service account will be invited as a user to the Google Play Console, so GCP will have access to your apps in Play Console. Bitrise uses this service account to make changes in the Google Play Console.

title: Setting up Google Play API access
body: In the Invite user window, the Email address field is pre-filled. Under Permissions, the default ones are already selected. You can go with these. Click Invite user at the bottom of the page.

title: Setting up Google Play API access
body: Check out the Google Play Developer API guide if you need more information on the process.

title: Setting up Google Play API access
body: You have successfully prepared your Google Play Console project. A services credential account has been created which is authorized to manage your releases.

title: Setting up Google Play deployment for the first time
body: Deploying to Google play publishes your app to Google's online store. When you do it for the first time, this requires a bit more work than simply deploying to bitrise.io. Once the necessary configurations are in place, it becomes very simple.

title: Setting up Google Play deployment for the first time
body: When configuring Google Play deployment for the first time, you need to link your Google Play Developer account to an API project, set up API access, and upload the service account JSON key to Bitrise.

title: Setting up Google Play deployment for the first time
body: Upload the first AAB or APK manually to Google Play using the Google Play Console.

title: Setting up Google Play deployment for the first time
body: Link your Google Play Developer Console to an API project.

title: Setting up Google Play deployment for the first time
body: Set up API Access Clients using a service account: Please note when you create your service account on the Google Developer Console, you have to choose json as Key Type.

title: Setting up Google Play deployment for the first time
body: Grant the necessary rights to the service account with your Google Play Console. Go to Settings, then Users & permissions, then Invite new user. Due to the way the Google Play Publisher API works, you have to grant at least the following permissions to the service account:

title: Setting up Google Play deployment for the first time
body: Access level: View app information.

title: Setting up Google Play deployment for the first time
body: Release management: Manage production releases, manage testing track releases.

title: Setting up Google Play deployment for the first time
body: Store presence: Edit store listing, pricing & distribution.

title: Setting up Google Play deployment for the first time
body: As an optional step, you can add translations to your Store Listing: Translate & localize your app.

title: Setting up Google Play deployment for the first time
body: Open your app on Bitrise.

title: Setting up Google Play deployment for the first time
body: Click the Workflows button on the main page.

title: Setting up Google Play deployment for the first time
body: Go to the Code Signing & Files tab and upload the service account JSON key into the GENERIC FILE STORAGE.

title: Deploying an Android app to bitrise.io
body: In this section, we'll go through how to deploy your Android app to bitrise.io.

title: Deploying an Android app to bitrise.io
body: Deploying to bitrise.io means that the build artifacts generated during the build will be available for download once the build is finished. You can use this to test your app on your own test devices, for example.

title: Deploying an Android app to bitrise.io
body: To deploy your app to bitrise.io:

title: Deploying an Android app to bitrise.io
body: Make sure your Workflow contains the Android Build Step to build your app.

title: Deploying an Android app to bitrise.io
body: Optionally, you can build your app with the Gradle Runner Step. This requires a bit more configuration from you but allows for more extensive customization.

title: Deploying an Android app to bitrise.io
body: Add the Deploy to Bitrise.io Step to your Workflow.

title: Deploying an Android app to bitrise.io
body: Notifying other users

title: Deploying an Android app to bitrise.io
body: You can use the Notify: User Roles and the Notify: Emails inputs of the Step to set up notifications about your deploy.

title: Deploying an Android app to bitrise.io
body: Optionally, set the Enable public page for the App? input of the Step to true so the Step enables the public install page for your app.

title: Deploying an Android app to bitrise.io
body: Run a build.

title: Deploying an Android app to bitrise.io
body: The Deploy to Bitrise.io Step will deploy the app. You can share the generated binary with your team members using the build’s URL.

title: Deploying an Android app to bitrise.io
body: A bitrise.yml for deploying an Android app to Bitrise

title: Deploying an Android app to bitrise.io
body: In this example, we're building the debug variant of an Android app, and deploy it to bitrise.io, as.

title: Deploying an Android app to bitrise.io
body:
format_version: '11'
default_step_lib_source: https://github.com/bitrise-io/bitrise-steplib.git
project_type: android
app:
 envs:
 - opts: 
 is_expand: false 
 BITRISE_SOURCE_DIR: /app
workflows:
 docs-example-workflow:
 steps:
 - android-build@1:
 inputs:
 - variant: debug
 - deploy-to-bitrise-io@2: {}

title: Deploying to Google Play
body: Deploying to Google Play requires a signed APK or AAB file and the Google Play Deploy Step.

title: Deploying to Google Play
body: If you're trying to deploy your app for the first time, make sure your Google Play configuration is set up correctly.

title: Deploying to Google Play
body: Open your app on Bitrise.

title: Deploying to Google Play
body: Click the Workflows button on the main page.

title: Deploying to Google Play
body: Go to the Code Signing & Files tab and copy the Environment Variable key which stores your uploaded the service account JSON key file’s URL.

title: Deploying to Google Play
body: Copy the Environment Variable key which stores your uploaded file’s URL.

title: Deploying to Google Play
body: For example: BITRISEIO_SERVICE_ACCOUNT_JSON_KEY_URL.

title: Deploying to Google Play
body: Open your Workflow and add the Google Play Deploy Step to it.

title: Deploying to Google Play
body: In the Service Account JSON key file path input, paste the Environment Variable which was generated when you uploaded the service account JSON key in the GENERIC FILE STORAGE. Besides the generated Env Var, you can also add a file path right in the Step’s input field where the file path can be local or remote too:

title: Deploying to Google Play
body: For remote JSON key file you can provide any download location as value, for example, https://URL/TO/key.json.

title: Deploying to Google Play
body: For local JSON key file you can provide a file path url as value, for example, file://PATH/TO/key.json.

title: Deploying to Google Play
body: In the Package name input, add the package name of your app.

title: Deploying to Google Play
body: In the Track input, add the track where you want to deploy your APK (for example, alpha/beta/rollout/production or any custom track you set).

title: Deploying to Google Play
body: That’s all! Start or schedule a build and share the URL with external testers or distribute your app on an app store of your choice!

title: Deploying apps to Huawei AppGallery
body: You can deploy your Android apps to Huawei AppGallery via a verified Bitrise Step called Deploy to Huawei App Gallery. The Step can be used to deploy any APK file that you build on Bitrise.

title: Deploying apps to Huawei AppGallery
body: You can deploy your Android apps to Huawei AppGallery via a verified Bitrise Step called Deploy to Huawei App Gallery. The Step can be used to deploy any APK file that you build on Bitrise.

title: Deploying apps to Huawei AppGallery
body: The Step will need:

title: Deploying apps to Huawei AppGallery
body: The App ID of the app.

title: Deploying apps to Huawei AppGallery
body: The Client ID of the API client.

title: Deploying apps to Huawei AppGallery
body: The Key generated for the API client.

title: Deploying apps to Huawei AppGallery
body: To successfully deploy your app to Huawei AppGallery, you need a Workflow that:

title: Deploying apps to Huawei AppGallery
body: Builds and signs an APK or AAB file.

title: Deploying apps to Huawei AppGallery
body: Includes the Deploy to Huawei App Gallery Step to deploy the app.

title: Deploying apps to Huawei AppGallery
body: To configure deploying with the Deploy to Huawei App Gallery Step:

title: Deploying apps to Huawei AppGallery
body: Manually upload the first APK of the app to Huawei AppGallery using the website interface on AppGallery Connect.

title: Deploying apps to Huawei AppGallery
body: Create a team-level API client on AppGallery Connect.

title: Deploying apps to Huawei AppGallery
body: Open the Workflow Editor on Bitrise.

title: Deploying apps to Huawei AppGallery
body: Go to the Workflow that you want to use for deploying the app.

title: Deploying apps to Huawei AppGallery
body: Add the Deploy to Huawei App Gallery Step after the Steps that build and sign your APK.

title: Deploying apps to Huawei AppGallery
body: Open the Config input group.

title: Deploying apps to Huawei AppGallery
body: Fill in the required inputs.

title: Deploying apps to Huawei AppGallery
body: File path: If you used a Step that automatically exports the BITRISE_APK_PATH Environment Variable after building your APK, leave this unchanged. The Android Build Step is such a Step, for example.

title: Deploying apps to Huawei AppGallery
body: File name: The unique name of the APK file. This name will be used when uploading to the AppGallery Connect.

title: Deploying apps to Huawei AppGallery
body: App ID: The identified can be found in the App information section on AppGallery Connect.

title: Deploying apps to Huawei AppGallery
body: Client ID: The API client ID generated on AppGallery Connect.

title: Deploying apps to Huawei AppGallery
body: Key: The key generated with the API client on AppGallery connect.

title: Deploying apps to Huawei AppGallery
body: Take a look at the following bitrise.yml file to see an example configuration that uses the Deploy to Huawei AppGallery Step to deploy an app.

title: Deploying apps to Huawei AppGallery
body:
workflows:
 deploy:
 steps:
 - activate-ssh-key@4:
 run_if: '{{getenv "SSH_RSA_PRIVATE_KEY" | ne ""}}'
 - git-clone@4: {}
 - cache-pull@2: {}
 - install-missing-android-tools@2:
 inputs:
 - gradlew_path: "$PROJECT_LOCATION/gradlew"
 - gradle-runner@1.9:
 inputs:
 - gradle_file: "$GRADLE_BUILD_FILE_PATH"
 - gradle_task: assembleRelease
 - gradlew_path: "$GRADLEW_PATH"
 - sign-apk@1.7: {}
 - deploy-to-bitrise-io@1: {}
 - cache-push@2: {}
 - appgallery-deploy@0:
 inputs:
 - huawei_client_id: 'XXX'
 - huawei_client_secret: "$CLIENT_SECRET"
 - huawei_app_id: 'YYY'

title: Deploying apps to Huawei AppGallery
body: Run a build! If all goes well, you should see your app on Huawei AppGallery.

title: Generate and deploy multiple flavor APKs in a single Workflow
body: You can generate, code sign and deploy multiple flavor (multi-flavor) APKs/AABs in one workflow using our Gradle Runner Step.

title: Generate and deploy multiple flavor APKs in a single Workflow
body: You can generate, code sign and deploy multiple flavor (multi-flavor) APKs/AABs in one Workflow using our Gradle Runner Step. Flavor means enhancing an app’s core code with features resulting in different versions of the same app (just to mention the most common examples: free/paid, demo/full). Check out the official Android Studio guide on build types, flavors and build variants for more info! In this tutorial, you will need to do some settings to Android Sign and Google Play Deploy Steps - so keep your eyes peeled!

title: Generating multi-flavor APKs
body: To generate APK files for several different flavors:

title: Generating multi-flavor APKs
body: Open your app on Bitrise.

title: Generating multi-flavor APKs
body: Click the Workflows button on the main page.

title: Generating multi-flavor APKs
body: Select a Workflow from the WORKFLOW dropdown menu.

title: Generating multi-flavor APKs
body: Insert Gradle Runner Step after the Android testing Steps. Android Build Step can only build one variant so if this Step is part of your Workflow, then we advise you to replace it with our Gradle Runner Step.

title: Generating multi-flavor APKs
body: Click the Config section of the Step.

title: Generating multi-flavor APKs
body: Specify assemble Gradle tasks by adding your build variants’ task names in the Gradle task to run Step input field - as many task names as many build variants you want to build in one workflow. Each task name must be exactly the same build variant name what you have listed in the Build Variant window of Android Studio! Make sure you separate them only with a space, no need for a comma ! In this image, you can see the order of the Steps for the deploy workflow and the Gradle Task to run Step input with two build variants:

title: Generating multi-flavor APKs
body: assembleDemo and assembleFull (for APKs) or bundleDemo and bundleFull (for AABs)

title: Generating multi-flavor APKs
body: Gradle Runner generates a $BITRISE_APK_PATH_LIST / $BITRISE_AAB_PATH_LIST Environment Variable output that contains APKs/AABs built for ALL build variants defined above. We will need this output Environment Variable later.

title: Signing and deploying multi-flavor APKs
body: Open your app on Bitrise.

title: Signing and deploying multi-flavor APKs
body: Click the Workflows button on the main page.

title: Signing and deploying multi-flavor APKs
body: Select a Workflow from the WORKFLOW dropdown menu.

title: Signing and deploying multi-flavor APKs
body: Add one Android Sign Step AFTER the Gradle Runner Step if it’s missing from your Workflow.

title: Signing and deploying multi-flavor APKs
body: Set the App file path input to $BITRISE_APK_PATH_LIST or $BITRISE_AAB_PATH_LIST depending on which app format you built in the previous Gradle Runner Step.

title: Signing and deploying multi-flavor APKs
body: This will make sure all APKs or AABs get code signed with the keystore file you uploaded to the Code Signing tab. The Step will export either the $BITRISE_SIGNED_APK_PATH_LIST or the $BITRISE_SIGNED_AAB_PATH_LIST Environment Variable output which contains the path of the signed app files for each build variant.

title: Signing and deploying multi-flavor APKs
body: Make sure you set the following input fields in the Android Sign Step:

title: Signing and deploying multi-flavor APKs
body: Keystore url

title: Signing and deploying multi-flavor APKs
body: Keystore password

title: Signing and deploying multi-flavor APKs
body: Keystore alias

title: Signing and deploying multi-flavor APKs
body: Add the Google Play Deploy Step AFTER the Android Sign Step.

title: Signing and deploying multi-flavor APKs
body: Set the $BITRISE_SIGNED_APK_PATH or the $BITRISE_SIGNED_AAB_PATH Environment Variable in the APK or App Bundle file path Step input field so that the Google Play Deploy Step can release all your build variants to the app store.

title: Generating and deploying Android app bundles
body: Creating an Android App Bundle with Bitrise is almost the same as generating an APK. You have to tweak a few Step inputs to compile an Android App Bundle (.aab) file from your code, then get the bundle signed and deployed to Google Play Store.

title: Generating and deploying Android app bundles
body: Creating an Android App Bundle with Bitrise is almost the same as generating an APK. All you have to do is tweaking a few Step inputs to compile an Android App Bundle (.aab) file from your code, then get the bundle signed and deployed to Google Play Store.

title: Generating and deploying Android app bundles
body: Step versions supporting bundle creation

title: Generating and deploying Android app bundles
body: The following Steps must be of the indicated version or newer - older versions of the Steps do NOT support bundle creation.

title: Generating and deploying Android app bundles
body: Android Build 0.10.0 or newer

title: Generating and deploying Android app bundles
body: Gradle Runner 1.9.0 or newer

title: Generating and deploying Android app bundles
body: Android Sign 1.3.0 or newer

title: Generating and deploying Android app bundles
body: Deploy to Google Play 1.6.0 or newer

title: Generating an Android App Bundle file
body: You can create an Android App Bundle with either the Gradle Runner Step or with the Android Build Step.

title: Using the Gradle Runner Step
body: Open your app on Bitrise.

title: Using the Gradle Runner Step
body: Click the Workflows button on the main page.

title: Using the Gradle Runner Step
body: Select a Workflow from the WORKFLOW dropdown menu.

title: Using the Gradle Runner Step
body: Insert the Gradle Runner Step after the Android Unit Test and Android Lint Steps in your Workflow (if the build Step is not already there).

title: Using the Gradle Runner Step
body: Click the Config section of Gradle Runner.

title: Using the Gradle Runner Step
body: In the Gradle task to run input field, set, for example, bundleRelease or bundleDebug to create a bundle of your project.

title: Using the Gradle Runner Step
body: This way the Step will generate an Android App Bundle instead of an APK.

title: Using the Gradle Runner Step
body: If you wish to generate an Android App Bundle and an APK in one Workflow, you can specify an additional task in the Gradle task to run input field:

title: Using the Android Build Step
body: You can generate an Android App Bundle for your Android app with our Android Build Step as well:

title: Using the Android Build Step
body: Open your app on Bitrise.

title: Using the Android Build Step
body: Click the Workflows button on the main page.

title: Using the Android Build Step
body: Select a Workflow from the WORKFLOW dropdown menu.

title: Using the Android Build Step
body: Add the Android Build Step after the Android Unit Test and Android Lint Steps in your Workflow (if the build Step is not already there).

title: Using the Android Build Step
body: Provide the root directory of your Android project in the Project Location input field.

title: Using the Android Build Step
body: Go to Build type and select aab as build type.

title: Using the Android Build Step
body: If you wish to generate an APK and an Android App Bundle in one Workflow, add two Android Build Steps after each other and configure one to build an Android App Bundle and the other to build an APK.

title: Signing an Android App bundle
body: Signing an Android App Bundle file is the same as signing an APK.

title: Signing an Android App bundle
body: Before you start, make sure you have uploaded your keystore file to the Code Signing & Files tab of the Workflow Editor.

title: Signing an Android App bundle
body: Add the Android Sign Step AFTER the build Step in your Workflow.

title: Signing an Android App bundle
body: Make sure that the Keystore password, Key alias and the Key password input fields are filled out.

title: Signing an Android App bundle
body: Populate your input fields

title: Signing an Android App bundle
body: If you have uploaded your keystore file and filled out the required credentials, the Android Sign Step's Keystore url, Keystore password, Keystore alias, and the Private key password inputs will get populated automatically!

title: Signing an Android App bundle
body: Make sure the APK file path input field displays the same output env var as the output of the build Step you've been using.

title: Signing an Android App bundle
body: And you should be done! If you would like to read more about Android code signing, check out our guide.

title: Deploying your Android App Bundle to Google Play
body: Deploying an AAB file isn't significantly different from deploying an APK to Google Play.

title: Deploying your Android App Bundle to Google Play
body: If you want to check the bundle prior to app store distribution, you can add the Deploy to Bitrise.io Step after the Gradle Runner / Android Build Steps. It uploads the bundle into the Artifacts tab of your Build’s page.

title: Setting up Google Play deployment for the first time
body: Deploying to Google play publishes your app to Google's online store. When you do it for the first time, this requires a bit more work than simply deploying to bitrise.io. Once the necessary configurations are in place, it becomes very simple.

title: Setting up Google Play deployment for the first time
body: When configuring Google Play deployment for the first time, you need to link your Google Play Developer account to an API project, set up API access, and upload the service account JSON key to Bitrise.

title: Setting up Google Play deployment for the first time
body: Upload the first AAB or APK manually to Google Play using the Google Play Console.

title: Setting up Google Play deployment for the first time
body: Link your Google Play Developer Console to an API project.

title: Setting up Google Play deployment for the first time
body: Set up API Access Clients using a service account: Please note when you create your service account on the Google Developer Console, you have to choose json as Key Type.

title: Setting up Google Play deployment for the first time
body: Grant the necessary rights to the service account with your Google Play Console. Go to Settings, then Users & permissions, then Invite new user. Due to the way the Google Play Publisher API works, you have to grant at least the following permissions to the service account:

title: Setting up Google Play deployment for the first time
body: Access level: View app information.

title: Setting up Google Play deployment for the first time
body: Release management: Manage production releases, manage testing track releases.

title: Setting up Google Play deployment for the first time
body: Store presence: Edit store listing, pricing & distribution.

title: Setting up Google Play deployment for the first time
body: As an optional step, you can add translations to your Store Listing: Translate & localize your app.

title: Setting up Google Play deployment for the first time
body: Open your app on Bitrise.

title: Setting up Google Play deployment for the first time
body: Click the Workflows button on the main page.

title: Setting up Google Play deployment for the first time
body: Go to the Code Signing & Files tab and upload the service account JSON key into the GENERIC FILE STORAGE.

title: Deploying to Google Play
body: Deploying to Google Play requires a signed APK or AAB file and the Google Play Deploy Step.

title: Deploying to Google Play
body: If you're trying to deploy your app for the first time, make sure your Google Play configuration is set up correctly.

title: Deploying to Google Play
body: Open your app on Bitrise.

title: Deploying to Google Play
body: Click the Workflows button on the main page.

title: Deploying to Google Play
body: Go to the Code Signing & Files tab and copy the Environment Variable key which stores your uploaded the service account JSON key file’s URL.

title: Deploying to Google Play
body: Copy the Environment Variable key which stores your uploaded file’s URL.

title: Deploying to Google Play
body: For example: BITRISEIO_SERVICE_ACCOUNT_JSON_KEY_URL.

title: Deploying to Google Play
body: Open your Workflow and add the Google Play Deploy Step to it.

title: Deploying to Google Play
body: In the Service Account JSON key file path input, paste the Environment Variable which was generated when you uploaded the service account JSON key in the GENERIC FILE STORAGE. Besides the generated Env Var, you can also add a file path right in the Step’s input field where the file path can be local or remote too:

title: Deploying to Google Play
body: For remote JSON key file you can provide any download location as value, for example, https://URL/TO/key.json.

title: Deploying to Google Play
body: For local JSON key file you can provide a file path url as value, for example, file://PATH/TO/key.json.

title: Deploying to Google Play
body: In the Package name input, add the package name of your app.

title: Deploying to Google Play
body: In the Track input, add the track where you want to deploy your APK (for example, alpha/beta/rollout/production or any custom track you set).

title: Deploying to Google Play
body: That’s all! Start or schedule a build and share the URL with external testers or distribute your app on an app store of your choice!

title: Exporting a universal APK from an AAB
body: With Bitrise's Export Universal APK Step you can export a universal APK from the App Bundle, sign it with a keystore (or debug keystore), and deploy the APK to your test device before releasing the app to the Google Play Store.

title: Exporting a universal APK from an AAB
body: You can test an Android app on a test device even if the generated artifact is an App Bundle (.aab). With the Export Universal APK Step you can export a universal APK from the App Bundle, sign it with a keystore (or debug keystore), and deploy the APK to your test device before releasing the app to the Google Play Store.

title: Exporting a universal APK from an AAB
body: Configuring this Step is super simple:

title: Exporting a universal APK from an AAB
body: Insert the Export Universal APK Step after the Android Build Step in your Workflow.

title: Exporting a universal APK from an AAB
body: The Android App Bundle path input field is automatically filled out by the output of the previous build Step.

title: Exporting a universal APK from an AAB
body: The Keystore URL is automatically filled out based on the uploaded keystore file on the Code Signing tab.

title: Exporting a universal APK from an AAB
body: If you have already uploaded a keystore file to the Code Signing tab, the Keystore alias, Keystore password, and Private key password inputs are already populated with secret Environment Variables.

title: Exporting a universal APK from an AAB
body: You can override the default Bundletool version if you need a specific one but make sure you use the correct version.

title: Exporting a universal APK from an AAB
body: Run your Workflow.

title: Exporting a universal APK from an AAB
body: The Export Universal APK Step exports the APK to the $BITRISE_APK_PATH Environment Variable which the next Steps can pick up, or the Ship add-on if the Deploy to Bitrise.io Step is included in your Workflow.

title: iOS deployment
body: To use Bitrise to deploy an iOS app to any platform, you will need code signing files and you'll have to archive your Xcode project and export a signed IPA file.

title: iOS deployment
body: Once you built your app and ran unit tests and UI tests on it, it’s time to deploy it.

title: iOS deployment
body: To deploy an iOS app to any platform, you need:

title: iOS deployment
body: Code signing files.

title: iOS deployment
body: To archive your Xcode project and export a signed IPA file.

title: iOS deployment
body: Our guides delve into the specifics of these two basic requirements and show how to use our Steps to deploy the app in the exact way you want to!

title: iOS deployment
body: We also recommend checking out Ship, our deployment solution that aims to save you a lot of headache in publishing your apps: Deploying with Ship

title: Deploying an iOS app to Bitrise.io
body: Deploy an app to Bitrise to be able to download the IPA file and install it on devices specified in the app’s Development type provisioning profile. This way, your internal testers can easily test the app.

title: Deploying an iOS app to Bitrise.io
body: Deploy an app to Bitrise to be able to download the IPA file and install it on devices specified in the app’s Development type provisioning profile. This way, your internal testers can easily test the app.

title: Deploying an iOS app to Bitrise.io
body: Clear the cache

title: Deploying an iOS app to Bitrise.io
body: When trying to install an app from the public install page, you should clear the cache: click the link appearing in the If you synced your settings from your old device, you need to clear the cache and register your new device line. The link redirects to the Profile settings page where you can follow the procedure described in our guide.

title: Deploying an iOS app to Bitrise.io
body: Developer certificate and Development profile

title: Deploying an iOS app to Bitrise.io
body: To deploy an iOS app to bitrise.io, you will always need a Developer type certificate and a Development type provisioning profile. Even if you want to deploy to the App Store, these are still required: they are used to create the .xcodearchive file from the provided code in the process of exporting the IPA file.

title: Deploying an iOS app to Bitrise.io
body: Generate an IPA file on your own machine at least once.

title: Deploying an iOS app to Bitrise.io
body: Upload all necessary code signing files to Bitrise.

title: Deploying an iOS app to Bitrise.io
body: If you want your internal testers to test the app, register test devices.

title: Deploying an iOS app to Bitrise.io
body: Make sure the Xcode Archive and Export for iOS Step is in your Workflow.

title: Deploying an iOS app to Bitrise.io
body: Set the Automatic code signing input to the Apple service connection you want to use for code signing. The available options are:

title: Deploying an iOS app to Bitrise.io
body: offif you don’t do automatic code signing.

title: Deploying an iOS app to Bitrise.io
body: api-keyif you use API key authorization.

title: Deploying an iOS app to Bitrise.io
body: apple-idif you use Apple ID authorization.

title: Deploying an iOS app to Bitrise.io
body: Set the Distribution method input of the Step to development.

title: Deploying an iOS app to Bitrise.io
body: You can use other export methods, too, but if you only deploy to Bitrise and want to install your app on the specified devices of internal testers, development is sufficient.

title: Deploying an iOS app to Bitrise.io
body: Make sure the Deploy to Bitrise.io Step is in your Workflow.

title: Deploying an iOS app to Bitrise.io
body: By default, the value of the Enable public page for the App? input is set to true. This way, once the build runs, a public install page will be available with a long and random URL which can be shared with others who are not registered on Bitrise. This URL is sent to the users in an email. The Notify: User Roles and the Notify: Emails inputs determine which users get the email.

title: Deploying an iOS app to Bitrise.io
body: Start a build.

title: Deploying an iOS app to Bitrise.io
body: When the build is finished, go to the app’s Builds page and click the latest build.

title: Deploying an iOS app to Bitrise.io
body: Click the Artifacts tab to find your IPA file.

title: Deploying an iOS app to Bitrise.io
body: You can also find the public install URL here. Click the eye icon next to the IPA file to reveal the details and to find the toggle for the public install page. Make sure that’s toggled on so you’re able to send the link to non-Bitrise users.

title: Deploying an iOS app to Bitrise.io
body: To install an app from the public install page, you must use a native Safari browser of the iOS device. You cannot click the installation link if you’re browsing from a third-party app.

title: Deploying an iOS app to Bitrise.io
body: And that’s it! The file can now be installed on all the devices included in the app’s provisioning profile. Remember: the installation link must be accessed from an iOS device’s Safari browser!

title: Deploying an iOS app for external testing
body: Before deploying your app to the App Store, you might want to release it to external testers who can test it on their devices outside the development environment. If you do not want to use Testflight, then you can do this by exporting an IPA file with the app-store export method.

title: Deploying an iOS app for external testing
body: Before deploying your app to the App Store, you might want to release it to external testers who can test it on their devices outside the development environment. If you do not want to use Testflight, then you can do this by exporting an IPA file with the ad-hoc export method.

title: Deploying an iOS app for external testing
body: Using Testflight

title: Deploying an iOS app for external testing
body: If you wish to invite external testers using Testflight, you CANNOT use the ad-hoc export method. You need an IPA with the app-store export method.

title: Deploying an iOS app for external testing
body: Generate an IPA file on your own machine at least once.

title: Deploying an iOS app for external testing
body: Upload all necessary code signing files to Bitrise.

title: Deploying an iOS app for external testing
body: For the ad-hoc export method, you need a Distribution type certificate and an Ad Hoc type provisioning profile. Only upload a provisioning profile if you use manual provisioning: iOS code signing with manual provisioning.

title: Deploying an iOS app for external testing
body: Make sure the Xcode Archive & Export for iOS Step is in your Workflow.

title: Deploying an iOS app for external testing
body: Set the Distribution method input of the Step to ad-hoc.

title: Deploying an iOS app for external testing
body: Set the Automatic code signing method input to the Apple service connection you want to use for code signing. The available options are:

title: Deploying an iOS app for external testing
body: off if you don’t do automatic code signing.

title: Deploying an iOS app for external testing
body: api-key if you use API key authorization.

title: Deploying an iOS app for external testing
body: apple-id if you use Apple ID authorization.

title: Deploying an iOS app for external testing
body: Make sure you have the Deploy to Bitrise.io Step in your Workflow.

title: Deploying an iOS app for external testing
body: Start a build.

title: Deploying an iOS app for external testing
body: When the build is finished, go to the app’s Builds page and click the latest build.

title: Deploying an iOS app for external testing
body: Click the Artifacts tab to find your IPA file that you can distribute.

title: Deploying an iOS app to App Store Connect
body: You can deploy your Bitrise app to App Store Connect either to invite testers on Testflight or to release your app on the App Store.

title: Deploying an iOS app to App Store Connect
body: You can deploy an app to App Store Connect to:

title: Deploying an iOS app to App Store Connect
body: Invite testers on Testflight.

title: Deploying an iOS app to App Store Connect
body: Release your app on the App Store.

title: Deploying an iOS app to App Store Connect
body: On Bitrise, you can either simply just upload your binary to App Store Connect or you can also submit it for review.

title: Deploy to App Store Connect Steps
body: To deploy the app to App Store Connect, we have two Steps:

title: Deploy to App Store Connect Steps
body: Deploy to App Store Connect

title: Deploy to App Store Connect Steps
body: Deploy to App Store Connect - Application Loader

title: Deploy to App Store Connect Steps
body: Deploy to App Store Connect - Application Loader is simple: it simply pushes an .ipa or .pkg binary file to App Store Connect. With this Step, you cannot submit the app for review on the App Store, for example.

title: Deploy to App Store Connect Steps
body: With the Deploy to App Store Connect Step, you can:

title: Deploy to App Store Connect Steps
body: Submit your app to the App Store for review.

title: Deploy to App Store Connect Steps
body: You can upload apps of three different platforms (iOS, OS X, AppleTVOS).

title: Deploy to App Store Connect Steps
body: Tell Bitrise whether you want to upload your screenshots and the app’s metadata along with the binary.

title: Deploying the app to App Store Connect
body: Keep in mind that every time you want to push an app to App Store Connect, it must have a unique build and version number: increment either or both before deploying.

title: Deploying the app to App Store Connect
body: Make sure you have a working connection to your Apple Developer account.

title: Deploying the app to App Store Connect
body: Generate an IPA file on your own machine at least once.

title: Deploying the app to App Store Connect
body: Upload all necessary code signing files to Bitrise.

title: Deploying the app to App Store Connect
body: To deploy an app to App Store Connect, you need a Distribution type certificate and an App Store type provisioning profile.

title: Deploying the app to App Store Connect
body: Make sure the Xcode Archive & Export for iOS Step is in your Workflow.

title: Deploying the app to App Store Connect
body: Set the Automatic code signing input to the Apple service connection you want to use for code signing. The available options are:

title: Deploying the app to App Store Connect
body: off if you don’t use automatic code signing, or if you exclusively use Step inputs for Apple service authentication.

title: Deploying the app to App Store Connect
body: api-key if you use API key authorization.

title: Deploying the app to App Store Connect
body: apple-id if you use Apple ID authorization.

title: Deploying the app to App Store Connect
body: Set the Distribution method input of the Step to app-store.

title: Deploying the app to App Store Connect
body: The Step will store the path of the exported .ipa file in the $BITRISE_IPA_PATH Environment Variable.

title: Deploying the app to App Store Connect
body: Add the Deploy to App Store Connect Step to your Workflow.

title: Deploying the app to App Store Connect
body: Fill the required inputs.

title: Deploying the app to App Store Connect
body: Either the app’s Apple ID or its Bundle ID is a required input. One of the two must be provided.

title: Deploying the app to App Store Connect
body: If you set the Submit for Review to true, the Step will wait for your submission to be processed on App Store Connect and then submit the given version of the app for review.

title: Deploying the app to App Store Connect
body: The default value of the Skip App Version Update input is No. Change it only if you incremented the app version number in another way.

title: Deploying the app to App Store Connect
body: If you use an App Store Connect account that is linked to multiple teams, provide either a Team ID or a Team name!

title: Deploying the app to App Store Connect
body: Start a build.

title: Deploying the app to App Store Connect
body: If all goes well, your app will be submitted to App Store and you can distribute it via Testflight or via the App Store!

title: Deploying an iOS app for simulators
body: You can build and deploy your iOS application to a simulator, to show it off in a browser, for example. On Bitrise, we have a dedicated Step to build for a simulator: the Xcode build for simulator Step runs the xcodebuild command with an iOS simulator destination and generates an .app file.

title: Deploying an iOS app for simulators
body: The .app file can be run on any simulator. On Bitrise, we have a Step to upload your app to Appetize.io: the Appetize.io deploy Step. With this Step, you can deploy your app so you can run it in a browser.

title: Deploying an iOS app for simulators
body: To build the app for a simulator, you do not need code signing files!

title: Building an iOS app for a simulator
body: Open your app on Bitrise.

title: Building an iOS app for a simulator
body: Click the Workflows button on the main page.

title: Building an iOS app for a simulator
body: Select a Workflow from the WORKFLOW dropdown menu.

title: Building an iOS app for a simulator
body: Add the Xcode build for simulator Step to your Workflow.

title: Building an iOS app for a simulator
body: The Step should be after the Steps that install dependencies, such as Run Cocoapods install.

title: Building an iOS app for a simulator
body: Fill in the required inputs for the Step.

title: Building an iOS app for a simulator
body: Project (or Workspace) path: the path to your project’s .xcodeproj or .xworkspace file. By default, this is stored in an Environment Variable when you add your app to Bitrise.

title: Building an iOS app for a simulator
body: Scheme name: the Xcode scheme of your project. By default, this is stored in an Environment Variable when you add your app to Bitrise.

title: Building an iOS app for a simulator
body: Device model: the type of device you want to run the app on. Set it exactly as it appears in the device selection menu in Xcode.

title: Building an iOS app for a simulator
body: OS version: the version of device operating system you want to run the app on. The default value is latest.

title: Building an iOS app for a simulator
body: Platform: the platform you want to run the app on. The default value is iOS. Make sure that the values of the Device model input and the Platform input are compatible: for example, if you set Device model to Apple TV 1080p, set Platform to tvOS.

title: Building an iOS app for a simulator
body: The Step will produce the following outputs:

title: Building an iOS app for a simulator
body: BITRISE_APP_DIR_PATH: the path to the generated .app file.

title: Building an iOS app for a simulator
body: BITRISE_APP_DIR_PATH_LIST: the path to the generated .app file and the paths to every dependent target app. The paths are separated with the | character.

title: Building an iOS app for a simulator
body: BITRISE_XCODE_BUILD_RAW_RESULT_TEXT_PATH: the path to the log file of the raw build results.

title: Deploying the app to Appetize.io
body: An .app file built with our Xcode build for simulator Step works with just about any simulator. But if you want to easily and quickly integrate it to a simulator that allows you to run your app in a browser, we recommend using the Appetize.io deploy Step. It uploads your app to Appetize.io and provides a public URL to use the app in a browser.

title: Deploying the app to Appetize.io
body: Request an Appetize.io API token.

title: Deploying the app to Appetize.io
body: Open your app on Bitrise.

title: Deploying the app to Appetize.io
body: Click the Workflows button on the main page.

title: Deploying the app to Appetize.io
body: Select a Workflow from the WORKFLOW dropdown menu.

title: Deploying the app to Appetize.io
body: Add and configure the Xcode build for simulator Step to your Workflow.

title: Deploying the app to Appetize.io
body: Add the Appetize.io deploy Step to your Workflow.

title: Deploying the app to Appetize.io
body: Add the Appetize.io API token to the Appetize.io token input.

title: Deploying the app to Appetize.io
body: Enter the path to the .app file to the Application path input. The easiest solution is to use the BITRISE_APP_DIR_PATH_LIST Environment Variable that is an output of the Xcode build for simulator Step. Optionally, you can also enable verbose logging for more efficient debugging.

title: Deploying the app to Appetize.io
body: The Appetize.io deploy Step will produce one output: the APPETIZE_APP_URL Environment Variable. it is a public URL where you can access your app. Enjoy showing it off!

title: Bitrise OTA app deployment
body: Bitrise has an integrated app deployment system you can use to distribute your apps and other build artifacts. You can distribute your apps over the air for your app’s team members or any stakeholder, even if they don't have a Bitrise account.

title: Bitrise OTA app deployment
body: Bitrise has an integrated app deployment system you can use to distribute your apps and other build artifacts.

title: Bitrise OTA app deployment
body: You can distribute your apps over the air for your app’s team members or any stakeholder, even if they don't have a Bitrise account. You can also use it to archive your app and other build artifact files which will be available on the app’s Builds page for viewing and downloading.

title: Bitrise OTA app deployment
body: Here is a short recap on the different build Steps per platform.

title: Deploying with the Deploy to Bitrise.io Step
body: The Deploy to Bitrise.io - Apps, Logs, Artifacts Step can perform several different functions:

title: Deploying with the Deploy to Bitrise.io Step
body: It allows you to create and distribute a public install page for your app and notify users about new builds of the app.

title: Deploying with the Deploy to Bitrise.io Step
body: It uploads app binaries and other build artifacts to the Artifacts tab of the build's page.

title: Deploying with the Deploy to Bitrise.io Step
body: It can send test results and logs to the Test Reports add-on.

title: Deploying with the Deploy to Bitrise.io Step
body: It allows you to use Ship to deploy your app.

title: Deploying with the Deploy to Bitrise.io Step
body: In this guide, we'll talk about how to use the Step to deploy app binaries (IPA/APK/AAB files) and distribute the link to the public install page.

title: The deploy directory
body: The Deploy directory or file path input defines the path that the Step will check for files to deploy. If the input value is a file path, it will deploy that file. If the input value is a directory, it will deploy all files in the directory.

title: The deploy directory
body: The default value is the BITRISE_DEPLOY_DIR Environment Variable (Env Var). In most cases, you don't have to change this or worry about it in any way. If you use the official Bitrise Steps to build your apps, they will export all necessary files into this directory. In certain cases it's worth checking whether your files end up in the correct location for deployment:

title: The deploy directory
body: If you use a Script Step to build your app, the best practice is to configure the Step to export the files to the BITRISE_DEPLOY_DIR Env Var.

title: The deploy directory
body: If you use a Step that isn't maintained by Bitrise, check where the Step exports any files it generates. If it isn't the BITRISE_DEPLOY_DIR, set the input to point to that location.

title: The deploy directory
body: Compressing all files into a .zip

title: The deploy directory
body: If you wish to compress all files found in the deploy directory into a single .zip file, set the Compress artifacts into one file? input to true.

title: The public install page
body: The Enable public page for the App? input determines whether the app can be installed by accessing a publicly available web page. Anyone who has the link to the page can install the app on their device.

title: The public install page
body: Registering test devices

title: The public install page
body: For Android apps, you don’t have to register your test devices to be able to install the app on them, as Android apps don’t have per-device install restrictions. However you’ll have to enable the Unknown Sources option in Android to be able to install the APK/AAB from outside of the Google Play Store.

title: The public install page
body: For iOS apps, the test devices must be registered and provisioned otherwise you can't install the app from the public install page on them.

title: The public install page
body: The page includes all the important details of the build such as filename, size, version code, minimum SDK version, and build number. If the public install page is enabled, users defined in the Notify: Emails and Notify: User Roles inputs receive the link to the page.

title: The public install page
body: By default, the input value is set to true. If you disable the option, only the members of your app's Bitrise team will be able to install the app on their device. They can find the installable binary on the Artifacts tab on the build page.

title: Notifying users
body: The Deploy to Bitrise.io Step can send email notifications to specified users. The notification can include the build URL and the public install page link. The Step can notify users in two ways:

title: Notifying users
body: The Notify: User Groups input allows you to notify the users on the app's Bitrise team. If the Enable public page for the App? input is set to true, the notification includes the link to the public install page. If it's set to false, the specified user groups will receive the build URL instead.

title: Notifying users
body: The default value is everyone: this means everyone on the app's Bitrise team gets a notification. You can choose any other role: in that case, only users with that particular role will get a notification.

title: Notifying users
body: The Notify: Email input allows you to notify anyone via email. This includes people who don't have a Bitrise account. This way you can send the public install page to anyone, inviting them to install the app.

title: Notifying users
body: Public install page required

title: Notifying users
body: If the Enable public page for the App? input is set to false, the Notify: Email input is ignored!

title: Notifying users
body: Use a Secret

title: Notifying users
body: The input only takes Secrets as a value: you must create a Secret and specify the email addresses in the Secret's value.

title: Deploying with Ship
body: Ship is a deployment solution that aims to save users a lot of headache. With Ship, you have complete control over your app’s distribution, its version history, and all the important metadata - and you can manage all that in one place.

title: Deploying with Ship
body: Beta version

title: Deploying with Ship
body: Please note that this feature is still a BETA version.

title: Deploying with Ship
body: Ship is a deployment solution that aims to save users a lot of headache. With Ship, you have complete control over your app’s distribution, its version history, and all the important metadata - and you can manage all that in one place.

title: Deploying with Ship
body: Deployment with Ship includes automatic re-sign and artifact generation and we store all the previous versions too. The app’s metadata, all the marketing copy, and screenshots can also be edited on the spot and non-developer people can manage it.

title: Deploying with Ship
body: Ship language

title: Deploying with Ship
body: As of right now, Ship only supports English locale. No other language submissions are supported.

title: Deploying with Ship
body: You can do a whole lot of things with Ship:

title: Deploying with Ship
body: View all the build versions of your app.

title: Deploying with Ship
body: View and edit all the details of a given build version, including a description, screenshots, and the most important parameters, such as the app size or the supported device types.

title: Deploying with Ship
body: Send your app directly to testers with a link to the public install page.

title: Deploying with Ship
body: Deploy a given build version to App Store Connect and/or the Google Play Console, once you set up publishing.

title: Deploying with Ship
body: Switch between platforms on the Version History page in the case of cross-platform projects.

title: Getting started with Ship
body: To start using Ship, you'll need to build an app and export the generated binary to Ship. You need to expose the Workflow that builds the binary and make sure you include the Deploy to Bitrise.io Step in it.

title: Getting started with Ship
body: To start using Ship, you'll need to build an app and export the generated binary to Ship.

title: Getting started with Ship
body: You have two options to open Ship from Bitrise:

title: Getting started with Ship
body: On the Add-ons tab of the app: this option takes you to Ship’s home page.

title: Getting started with Ship
body: From the Builds page: this option takes you to the build’s Ship page.

title: Getting started with Ship
body: When first logging in, you might not have a single build version available to publish. But don’t worry, that can be fixed quickly.

title: Getting started with Ship
body: Step versions compatible with Ship

title: Getting started with Ship
body: Please note that the Deploy to Bitrise.io Step must be version 1.9.0 or higher and the Xcode Archive & Export for iOS Step for iOS apps must be version 2.6.0 or higher - older versions of the Steps do not support Ship.

title: Getting started with Ship
body: To be able to deploy an app with Ship:

title: Getting started with Ship
body: In one of your Workflows, you need a Step that builds your app. By default, Xcode Archive & Export for iOS, Gradle Runner and Android Build are automatically supported.

title: Getting started with Ship
body: The same Workflow must have the correct version of the Deploy to Bitrise.io Step after the Step that builds your app.

title: Getting started with Ship
body: The Deploy to Bitrise.io Step must export the relevant file: an APK file for Android apps and the .xcarchive file for iOS apps. If you use either one of the Xcode Archive & Export for iOS, Gradle Runner and Android Build Steps, you don’t have to change anything in the default configuration of the Deploy to Bitrise.io Step to export the relevant files.

title: Getting started with Ship
body: Using Ship with different build Steps

title: Getting started with Ship
body: By default, Xcode Archive & Export for iOS, Gradle Runner, and Android Build are automatically supported with Ship.

title: Getting started with Ship
body: If you want to build your app with any other Step, you can do so - it just requires a little extra configuration.

title: Getting started with Ship
body: Once you successfully built your app, you will be able to start using Ship.

title: Configuring an app for publishing with Ship
body: To publish an app on Ship, you need to build a binary with a Workflow that is exposed to Ship, with the settings properly configured.

title: Configuring an app for publishing with Ship
body: To publish an app on Ship, you need to:

title: Configuring an app for publishing with Ship
body: Build an app that has at least one exposed Workflow: Exposing a Workflow's artifacts to Ship.

title: Configuring an app for publishing with Ship
body: Make sure Bitrise has the necessary code signing files.

title: Configuring an app for publishing with Ship
body: Configure publishing on the Settings page.

title: Configuring an app for publishing with Ship
body: iOS and Android apps have their own set of settings on the Settings page; for cross-platform app, both iOS and Android settings must be configured.

title: Exposing a Workflow's artifacts to Ship
body: Exposing a Workflow’s artifacts means that the products of the Workflow will be available in Ship: for example, if your Workflow produces an APK, you can publish that using Ship. By default, all Workflows are exposed if they contain the correct version of the Deploy to Bitrise.io Step. If you are happy with that, just leave the field as is.

title: Exposing a Workflow's artifacts to Ship
body: If, however, you add a Workflow here, only that Workflow will be exposed.

title: Exposing a Workflow's artifacts to Ship
body: To expose a Workflow’s artifacts to Ship:

title: Exposing a Workflow's artifacts to Ship
body: Go to your app’s Ship page.

title: Exposing a Workflow's artifacts to Ship
body: Click Settings in the top right corner.

title: Exposing a Workflow's artifacts to Ship
body: Go to the General tab.

title: Exposing a Workflow's artifacts to Ship
body: In the Expose Artifacts From the Selected Workflow to Ship text box, add all the Workflows you need.

title: Exposing a Workflow's artifacts to Ship
body: Be aware that if your app is cross-platform, there are TWO such text boxes: one for iOS and one for Android. Separate the different Workflow names with a comma (for example, build, deploy, release_build_android) .

title: Exposing a Workflow's artifacts to Ship
body: Scroll down to the bottom of the page and click Save.

title: Code signing files
body: Code signing files are required to publish an app to any online store, or to install them to test devices.

title: Code signing files
body: On the Settings page, you can choose between different code signing files. You can upload these files - iOS provisioning profiles and certificates, Android keystore files and Service Account JSON files - to the Code Signing tab of your Bitrise app:

title: Code signing files
body: iOS code signing.

title: Code signing files
body: Android code signing.

title: Installing an app on a test device with Ship
body: You can install an app from Ship, either by using the public install page option, or by logging in to Ship from the device itself and install it there.

title: Installing an app on a test device with Ship
body: To install an app on a device using Ship, there are two options:

title: Installing an app on a test device with Ship
body: Send either the public install page link or a QR code that takes you to the public install page when scanned to all the testers and other stakeholders.

title: Installing an app on a test device with Ship
body: Log in to Ship from the device and install it directly from there.

title: Accessing the public install page in Ship
body: To send the public install page link or the QR code to your stakeholders:

title: Accessing the public install page in Ship
body: Artifact types

title: Accessing the public install page in Ship
body: The public install page is not available for all type of artifacts.

title: Accessing the public install page in Ship
body: For iOS, it’s only available if your app is signed with a Debug, Development or Ad-hoc type provisioning profile.

title: Accessing the public install page in Ship
