body: For Android, it’s only available if your Workflow builds an APK which is NOT split or if it builds a universal APK which is split. For AABs, there will be no public install page link.

title: Accessing the public install page in Ship
body: Make sure you have a Deploy to Bitrise.io Step in your Workflow that builds the installable file.

title: Accessing the public install page in Ship
body: Make sure that the Enable public page for the App? input of the Step is set to true.

title: Accessing the public install page in Ship
body: Log in to Ship.

title: Accessing the public install page in Ship
body: Expose the Workflow and run a build on Bitrise.

title: Accessing the public install page in Ship
body: Go back to Ship. Open the Details page of your app’s chosen build version.

title: Accessing the public install page in Ship
body: On the right, find the Public Install Page link or the QR code.

title: Accessing the public install page in Ship
body: Copy the one you need and send it to the stakeholders (by email, for example).

title: Installing directly from Ship
body: To install an app to a registered device directly from Ship:

title: Installing directly from Ship
body: Build your app on Bitrise.

title: Installing directly from Ship
body: Log in to Ship from a supported device.

title: Installing directly from Ship
body: Click on the Devices tab to find out if a given device is registered. Read our guide on how to register your devices on Bitrise.

title: Installing directly from Ship
body: Under the name of the app, find and click the Install button.

title: Publishing an app to a store with Ship
body: Ship supports publishing to Apple's App Store and to Google Play. To successfully publish to either of these stores, you need to build an app on Bitrise, make sure Ship has access to code signing files, and successfully configure the app in Ship.

title: Publishing an app to a store with Ship
body: Ship supports publishing to Apple's App Store and to Google Play. To successfully publish to either of these stores, you need to build an app on Bitrise, make sure Ship has access to code signing files, and successfully configure the app in Ship.

title: Publishing an iOS app to the App Store with Ship
body: To be able to publish an iOS app to the App Store Connect (formerly known as iTunes Connect) with Ship, you have to:

title: Publishing an iOS app to the App Store with Ship
body: Build the app.

title: Publishing an iOS app to the App Store with Ship
body: Choose the provisioning profiles and code signing identities to be used.

title: Publishing an iOS app to the App Store with Ship
body: Set the app specific password.

title: Publishing an iOS app to the App Store with Ship
body: Set the Apple Developer Account email.

title: Publishing an iOS app to the App Store with Ship
body: Set the App SKU: this is a unique ID you give to your app for internal tracking. It’s not visible to customers.

title: Publishing an iOS app to the App Store with Ship
body: Using Ship with different build Steps

title: Publishing an iOS app to the App Store with Ship
body: By default, Xcode Archive & Export for iOS, Gradle Runner, and Android Build are automatically supported with Ship.

title: Publishing an iOS app to the App Store with Ship
body: If you want to build your app with any other Step, you can do so - it just requires a little extra configuration.

title: Publishing an iOS app to the App Store with Ship
body: Make sure you've configured the Xcode Archive & Export for iOS Step correctly: the Distribution method input must be set to app store and it should be built with a Release configuration.

title: Publishing an iOS app to the App Store with Ship
body: Make sure you have a Deploy to Bitrise.io Step in your Workflow.

title: Publishing an iOS app to the App Store with Ship
body: Open your app’s Ship page and click Settings in the top right corner.

title: Publishing an iOS app to the App Store with Ship
body: Go to the General tab.

title: Publishing an iOS app to the App Store with Ship
body: Go to the iOS Settings section.

title: Publishing an iOS app to the App Store with Ship
body: Expose the Workflow that creates the IPA file you want to publish, and run the Workflow on Bitrise.

title: Publishing an iOS app to the App Store with Ship
body: In the iOS Settings section, select the code signing files you want to use.

title: Publishing an iOS app to the App Store with Ship
body: Make sure you choose the files appropriate for the export method you used to create the .ipa file. For example, if your .ipa was exported using the app-store method, choose an App Store provisioning profile and a Distribution certificate (code signing identity).

title: Publishing an iOS app to the App Store with Ship
body: Enter the Apple Developer Account Email and the App Specific Password to be able to publish to the App Store.

title: Publishing an iOS app to the App Store with Ship
body: Enter the App SKU.

title: Publishing an iOS app to the App Store with Ship
body: Go back to the Details page and click Publish.

title: Publishing an Android app to Google Play with Ship
body: To configure publishing an Android app to Google Play Console in Ship, you have to:

title: Publishing an Android app to Google Play with Ship
body: Choose the Android keystore files and the Service Account JSON file.

title: Publishing an Android app to Google Play with Ship
body: Set the track you want to use to release your app.

title: Publishing an Android app to Google Play with Ship
body: Once you configured publishing for the app, you do not have to set these options every time, only if you want to change some of them.

title: Publishing an Android app to Google Play with Ship
body: Using Ship with different build Steps

title: Publishing an Android app to Google Play with Ship
body: By default, Xcode Archive & Export for iOS, Gradle Runner, and Android Build are automatically supported with Ship.

title: Publishing an Android app to Google Play with Ship
body: If you want to build your app with any other Step, you can do so - it just requires a little extra configuration.

title: Publishing an Android app to Google Play with Ship
body: Open your app’s Ship page and click Settings in the top right corner.

title: Publishing an Android app to Google Play with Ship
body: Go to the Android Settings section.

title: Publishing an Android app to Google Play with Ship
body: Expose a Workflow that creates the APK you want to publish.

title: Publishing an Android app to Google Play with Ship
body: Make sure the exposed Workflow includes either the Android Build or the Gradle Runner Step, and the Deploy to Bitrise.io Step.

title: Publishing an Android app to Google Play with Ship
body: Build a release version of your app with the exposed Workflow.

title: Publishing an Android app to Google Play with Ship
body: Depending on the Step you use, you have two options:

title: Publishing an Android app to Google Play with Ship
body: Make sure the Android Build Step’s Variant input field contains release (for example release or demoRelease).

title: Publishing an Android app to Google Play with Ship
body: Make sure the Gradle Runner Step’s Gradle task to run input field contains Release (for example, assembleRelease or assembleDemoRelease)

title: Publishing an Android app to Google Play with Ship
body: Enter the track you want to use to publish to the Google Play Console.

title: Publishing an Android app to Google Play with Ship
body: If your Android app contains multiple modules, enter the exact module under Module.

title: Publishing an Android app to Google Play with Ship
body: Choose the appropriate keystore file and the Service Account JSON file.

title: Publishing an Android app to Google Play with Ship
body: Head back to the Version History page and select the version you wish to publish. If your app has multiple flavors, you can filter for the right flavor and select it for publishing.

title: Publishing an Android app to Google Play with Ship
body: Fill out the Details page and click Publish.

title: Publishing status and logs
body: Once you clicked Publish in Ship, the process starts according to the configured settings. You can view the status of the active publishing process on top of the Details page of the app.

title: Publishing status and logs
body: To view the logs of any publishing process, go to the Activity tab. From there, you can download the logs by clicking Download Build Log to troubleshoot any errors after a failed publish.

title: Using Ship for apps built with cross-platform frameworks
body: You can use Ship for any binary that you build on Bitrise: you just need to make sure it ends up in the BITRISE_DEPLOY_DIR directory so that Deploy to Bitrise.io Step can find it.

title: Using Ship for apps built with cross-platform frameworks
body: By default, Ship works with the Android Build, Gradle Runner and the Xcode Archive & Export for iOS Steps. The output of these Steps are automatically exported by the Deploy to Bitrise.io Step to Ship.

title: Using Ship for apps built with cross-platform frameworks
body: However, for apps built with cross-platform frameworks, such as React Native or Flutter, you might not use these Steps in your Workflows. But don’t worry: you can use Steps that are not supported by default to build your app and still deploy it with Ship. All you need to do is make sure the right files end up in the right place.

title: Publishing iOS apps built with cross-platform frameworks
body: You can use Ship to publish an Android app built with, for example, Flutter or React Native even if you don't use our Xcode Archive & Export for iOS Step.

title: Publishing iOS apps built with cross-platform frameworks
body: The Deploy to Bitrise.io Step looks for an .xcarchive.zip file to export to Ship in the case of an iOS app. If you do not want to use the Xcode Archive & Export for iOS Step, you just need to make sure that:

title: Publishing iOS apps built with cross-platform frameworks
body: There is a Step in your exposed Workflow that exports an .xcarchive.zip file of your app. That is, the Step you use needs to create an Xcode Archive and needs to package it in a zip file.

title: Publishing iOS apps built with cross-platform frameworks
body: This Step exports the .xcarchive.zip file into the BITRISE_DEPLOY_DIR directory.

title: Publishing Android apps built with cross-platform frameworks
body: You can use Ship to publish an Android app built with, for example, Flutter or React Native even if you don't use our Android Build or Gradle Runner Steps.

title: Publishing Android apps built with cross-platform frameworks
body: The Deploy to Bitrise.io Step looks for an APK or an AAB file in the BITRISE_DEPLOY_DIR directory.

title: Publishing Android apps built with cross-platform frameworks
body: If you do not want to use the Android Build or the Gradle Runner Steps, you just need to make sure that:

title: Publishing Android apps built with cross-platform frameworks
body: There is a Step in your exposed Workflow that exports an APK or AAB file of your app.

title: Publishing Android apps built with cross-platform frameworks
body: This Step exports the APK or AAB file into the BITRISE_DEPLOY_DIR directory.

title: App details in Ship
body: On the app details page in Ship, you can update the most important information about your app so all that info is available in the online stores you publish your app to.

title: App details in Ship
body: The purpose of the app's Details page is to update the most important information about your app - for example, you can make sure all relevant information appears in your online store of choice.

title: App details in Ship
body: The details include:

title: App details in Ship
body: A description of the app.

title: App details in Ship
body: Screenshots and feature graphics of the app, arranged by the different supported devices.

title: App details in Ship
body: Metadata such as version number, size, version code, SDK version, and so on. The exact parameters depend on the type of the app. This is automatically exported to Ship by the Deploy to Bitrise.io Step.

title: Adding screenshots or feature graphics
body: You can add screenshots for an app to be published. Once you added screenshots or graphics to one build version of the app, they are automatically added to all subsequent versions. If you want to display different screenshots, you can modify it, otherwise you can leave it alone.

title: Adding screenshots or feature graphics
body: To add screenshots or feature graphics to your app details page:

title: Adding screenshots or feature graphics
body: Open the Details page in Ship of your app’s chosen build version.

title: Adding screenshots or feature graphics
body: Go to Screenshots or Feature Graphic, depending on what you want to upload.

title: Adding screenshots or feature graphics
body: Drag and drop a file OR click Browse files and select the ones you wish to upload.

title: Adding screenshots or feature graphics
body: Once done, click Save in the top right corner.

title: Updating the app's descriptions
body: You can update the app’s description, or all its other textual details in the same way. The types of text fields that you have available depend on the type of the app.

title: Updating the app's descriptions
body: Open the Details page in Ship of your app’s chosen build version.

title: Updating the app's descriptions
body: Go to the field you want to edit and click in the content field.

title: Updating the app's descriptions
body: Edit the content.

title: Updating the app's descriptions
body: Click Save in the top right of the Details tab.

title: Ship notifications
body: Ship can send emails about three different events: a new build version becoming available, successful publishing, and failed publishing.

title: Ship notifications
body: Ship can send emails about three different events:

title: Ship notifications
body: A new build version of an app is available in Ship.

title: Ship notifications
body: Ship successfully published the app.

title: Ship notifications
body: Ship failed to publish the app.

title: Ship notifications
body: These notifications can be sent to any number of different email addresses. When a new email address is added to the notifications list, Ship sends a confirmation email to the address: after confirmation, notifications should work.

title: Adding a new email address in Ship
body: To add a new email address to the notification list for an app:

title: Adding a new email address in Ship
body: Open your app’s Ship page.

title: Adding a new email address in Ship
body: Click Settings.

title: Adding a new email address in Ship
body: Go to the Notifications tab.

title: Adding a new email address in Ship
body: In the input field under Email notifications, type the email address.

title: Adding a new email address in Ship
body: Click Add.

title: Adding a new email address in Ship
body: The address should appear in the list below, with Pending as its status. An email is sent to the address: the recipient must click Confirm Notifications in the email to start receiving notifications.

title: Configuring notifications in Ship
body: You can pick and choose the Ship events about which you want to notify different people. For example, it’s possible to only send notifications about a failed publishing event if you do not want to be bothered when things go well! And of course you can send different notifications to different email addresses.

title: Configuring notifications in Ship
body: Open your app’s Ship page.

title: Configuring notifications in Ship
body: Click Settings.

title: Configuring notifications in Ship
body: Go to the Notifications tab.

title: Configuring notifications in Ship
body: Use the toggles under the different event types.

title: Configuring notifications in Ship
body: Hit Save once all notifications are set.

title: Deploying apps to Applivery
body: Applivery is a mobile app distribution platform for iOS and Android that provides a powerful mobile app management and distribution system to simplify app delivery for both testers and employees, with a focus on an easy-to-use experience.

title: Deploying apps to Applivery
body: Applivery is a mobile app distribution platform for iOS and Android that provides a powerful mobile app management and distribution system to simplify app delivery for both testers and employees, with a focus on an easy-to-use experience.

title: Deploying apps to Applivery
body: Applivery has many features to better manage your in-development and production-ready apps that will help speed up your development, get better feedback and deliver better applications.

title: Deploying apps to Applivery
body: Some of the features are:

title: Deploying apps to Applivery
body: Single or Multi App customized App Stores with a seamless user experience for non-technical users.

title: Deploying apps to Applivery
body: Multi-track and fully customized app distribution with multiple security configurations including SSO, non-registered users, password protected and unlisted apps.

title: Deploying apps to Applivery
body: Automatic and forced in-app updates.

title: Deploying apps to Applivery
body: Feedback and bug reporting.

title: Deploying apps to Applivery
body: Combined with Bitrise, you can cover the entire development life cycle, from testing and building to delivery and feedback.

title: Deploying your app to Applivery
body: Add the Applivery iOS Deploy or the Applivery Android Deploy Step to your Workflow. Make sure you add the Step after the Steps that build your app.

title: Deploying your app to Applivery
body: Get your Applivery App Token to link your Bitrise app with your Applivery app. Read more about how to get your App Token.

title: Deploying your app to Applivery
body: Open your app on Bitrise and click the Workflows tab to open the Workflow Editor.

title: Deploying your app to Applivery
body: Go to the Secrets tab.

title: Deploying your app to Applivery
body: Click Add New and type APPLIVERY_APP_TOKEN in the key input field.

title: Deploying your app to Applivery
body: Paste your Applivery App Token in the value input field and click Save.

title: Configuring the Applivery Step
body: There are many optional parameters that you can customize for a better and deeper integration:

title: Distribution with Applivery
body: Applivery provides multiple different ways for app distribution from customized App Stores (public or private) to Distribution Pages (public, private, unlisted, or password-protected shareable installation links). It also enables multitrack app delivery based on the information gathered from your Bitrise workflows, such as GitHub Branches, Tags or customized labels.

title: Deploying apps to DeployGate from Bitrise
body: DeployGate is a mobile app distribution platform for iOS and Android, delivering your in-development iOS/Android apps to your dev team, members, employees, QA testing team in your organization or testers outside of your company.

title: Deploying apps to DeployGate from Bitrise
body: DeployGate is a mobile app distribution platform for iOS and Android, delivering your in-development iOS/Android apps to your dev team, members, employees, QA testing team in your organization or testers outside of your company.

title: Deploying apps to DeployGate from Bitrise
body: DeployGate has many features to accelerate your app development cycle including QA testing and app improvement with beta tester’s feedbacks.

title: Deploying apps to DeployGate from Bitrise
body: DeployGate offers:

title: Deploying apps to DeployGate from Bitrise
body: Real-time App distribution with automatic version control, even without requiring accounts for testers

title: Deploying apps to DeployGate from Bitrise
body: Flexible user account management with granular access control

title: Deploying apps to DeployGate from Bitrise
body: Git-like multi-track distribution allows individual version/user/device management for the same app

title: Deploying apps to DeployGate from Bitrise
body: With DeployGate and Bitrise, you can quickly build a fully automated in-house dogfooding environment for your team. To see more details, please visit DeployGate Features.

title: Deploying apps to DeployGate from Bitrise
body: To upload your app to DeployGate, add the DeployGate Upload Step to your bitrise Workflow.

title: Deploying apps to DeployGate from Bitrise
body: This Step should be added after the Step that builds your app's binary that will be uploaded. You need to set several required parameters as below:

title: Deploying apps to DeployGate from Bitrise
body: You can also set optional variables for using advanced features as below:

title: Deploying apps to DeployGate from Bitrise
body: These options are based on DeployGate API. For more details, please read the references at DeployGate.com.

title: Deploying apps to DeployGate from Bitrise
body: You can use DeployGate's Distribution Page (Shareable link) feature to generate a landing page for the app installation of your app’s specific version.

title: Deploying apps to DeployGate from Bitrise
body: When you upload an app to DeployGate, the system automatically assigns a sequential number (we are calling it **Revision Number**) for each uploaded build. On the Distribution Page, you can choose specific revision of app to distribute for each group of testers. This feature is handy for distributing your app to multiple tester groups for different purposes such as QAs, Dog Fooding, or Test Marketing.

title: Deploying apps to DeployGate from Bitrise
body: You can also generate a distribution page when you upload an app from Bitrise with DeployGate Upload Step. Please refer to the optional variables above.

title: Deploying your app to Appaloosa
body: Appaloosa helps you distribute your mobile apps privately, collect feedback and analyse your deployment’s efficiency. Use a dedicated Step to deploy to Appaloosa with Bitrise.

title: Deploying your app to Appaloosa
body: Would you like to beta test and deploy your app to 1 or thousands of users? Appaloosa helps you distribute your mobile apps privately, collect feedback and analyse your deployment’s efficiency. Check it out!

title: Deploying your app to Appaloosa
body: Appaloosa is a simple and secure enterprise App Store. They help mobile & digital teams build, test and deploy their apps privately.

title: Deploying your app to Appaloosa
body: You can manage your apps on Android, iOS and Windows Phone, all in the same place. Appaloosa also provides a native app store to increase your users’ engagement. They will receive a push notification on each update of the app and be able to test and use the latest version of your mobile apps.

title: Deploying your app to Appaloosa
body: Appaloosa also gives you great insight on the efficiency of your deployment with download and usage stats as well as feedbacks and ratings from the users.

title: Deploying your app to Appaloosa
body: They are entreprise ready with LDAP, OAuth, SAML and Active Directory integrations as well as a RESTful API. Get in touch for more details. Plus your mobile apps can be targeted to groups of users or distributed to all collaborators.

title: Deploying your app to Appaloosa
body: To deploy your app on Appaloosa, simply add the Appaloosa Step to your app’s Workflow. If you don’t already have an account on Appaloosa, it will be created on the go.

title: Deploying your app to Appaloosa
body: As a registered user you simply need your store id and API Key.

title: Deploying your app to Appaloosa
body: As an unregistered user, an email address is enough.

title: Deploying your app to Appaloosa
body: Optionally you can provide a description, screenshot urls (up to 5) and, if registered, group ids.

title: Deploying your app to Appaloosa
body: With Bitrise and Appaloosa, you can focus on your mobile app development and we take care of the rest!

title: Deploying to TestFairy with Bitrise
body: TestFairy is a deployment service that gives you plenty of insights about your app. You can deploy to TestFairy with Bitrise by using a dedicated Step.

title: Deploying to TestFairy with Bitrise
body: If you are looking for a deployment service that also gives you lots of insights about your application, then TestFairy is a great service to check out.

title: Deploying to TestFairy with Bitrise
body: When testing apps in the crowd, you never know what exactly was tested and what exactly went wrong on the client side. TestFairy solves this problem by providing a video of everything that happened on the mobile device, including detailed internal metrics such as CPU, memory, GPS, network, logs, crash reports, and a lot more. To get these insights on iOS you need to integrate their iOS SDK into your app.

title: Deploying to TestFairy with Bitrise
body: To deploy your app on the TestFairy platform you just simply need to add the TestFairy Step to your app’s Workflow (on bitrise.io).

title: Deploying to TestFairy with Bitrise
body: The only required parameter you have to add is your API Key on TestFairy. To get it you should navigate to your account preferences on TestFairy and find the key under your API Key menu.

title: Deploying to TestFairy with Bitrise
body: Email notifications and Auto update

title: Deploying to TestFairy with Bitrise
body: You can also enable or disable the email notifications and set the tester groups you would like to notify. There’s an option to make your users always upgrade to the latest build by enabling Auto update in the Step, and you can also start recording video and set the length of it.

title: Deploying to TestFairy with Bitrise
body: There’s nothing else you need to do, simply work on your awesome app and we ensure your app is automatically deployed to TestFairy every time you update your code.

title: Release Management [BETA]
body: Release Management add-on

title: Release Management [BETA]
body: Bitrise's Release Management is an add-on that offers a new type of Bitrise service in addition to our core CI/CD product. For more information about add-ons, check out Bitrise add-ons.

title: Release Management [BETA]
body: Release Management offers a high-level overview of your app's release workflow. This provides transparency and enables all team members to understand the progress of upcoming releases, helping them to coordinate their work more efficiently.

title: Release Management [BETA]
body: Release Management also serves as a one-stop solution for all release-specific tasks, such as creating release branches or uploading release candidates to TestFlight.

title: Release Management requirements
body: Release Management requirements

title: Apple App Store support only
body: Release Management does not support Android projects at the moment.

title: Apple Service Connection
body: Release Management requires a connected API key Apple Service connection for iOS projects. Make sure you have an active API key Service Connection and it’s assigned to the iOS Project. For more information, check out Connecting to an Apple service with API key.

title: Registered iOS app on App Store Connect
body: You can release your iOS app using Release Management to App Store connect. You will have to specify the app when you create a new release. Learn more about App Store Connect apps.

title: Registered iOS app on App Store Connect
body: White label app support

title: Registered iOS app on App Store Connect
body: Each new release can be connected to another App Store Connect app, so you can release multiple App Store apps from one Bitrise Project if you want.

title: A Bitrise Workflow that can generate an .ipa or an .xcarchive file from your app
body: Release Management requires a Workflow capable of generating an .ipa or an .xcarchive file. If both files are available Release Management will use the .ipa file during the release candidate stage.

title: A Bitrise Workflow that can generate an .ipa or an .xcarchive file from your app
body: The easiest way to do it is by adding the Xcode Archive & Export for iOS Step and the Deploy to Bitrise.io - Apps, Logs, Artifacts Step to your Workflow. For more information, check out Selecting a release candidate for the release candidate stage.

title: Getting started with Release Management
body: You can use the Release Management tool to automate release specific tasks, like monitoring feature readiness or sending your app to App Store reviews. To get started with Release Management you will have to access the Releases page of an app first.

title: Getting started with Release Management
body: There are two methods to access the Releases page of an app:

title: Getting started with Release Management
body: From the Release Management page using the "" button.

title: Getting started with Release Management
body: From your app's page using the Releases button.

title: Accessing the Releases page of an app from the Release Management page
body: To access the Releases page of an app from the app's page:

title: Accessing the Releases page of an app from the Release Management page
body: Log in to bitrise.io.

title: Accessing the Releases page of an app from the Release Management page
body: Click on the Releases button on the top navigation bar.

title: Accessing the Releases page of an app from the Release Management page
body: This will open up the Release Management page. From here, you can access a project's Releases page by clicking on the "" button.

title: Accessing the Releases page of an app from the app's page
body: You can access the Release Management page the following way:

title: Accessing the Releases page of an app from the app's page
body: Go to your Dashboard and select the iOS app you need.

title: Accessing the Releases page of an app from the app's page
body: Click on the Releases button.

title: Releases page of an app
body: The Releases page of an app lists the app's upcoming and previous releases. The next release is displayed on the top of the page, while the other planned upcoming releases will be listed under Upcoming iOS releases. The finished releases are listed in the Previous iOS releases section. You can add new releases using the Add new release button, as detailed in Adding a new release.

title: Adding a new release
body: You can add a new release from the Releases page of your app:

title: Adding a new release
body: Access your app's Releases page.

title: Adding a new release
body: Click on the Add new release button.

title: Adding a new release
body: This opens the Add new release for iOS page.

title: Adding a new release
body: Select a setup method under the Setup method field.

title: Adding a new release
body: Select Start with a blank release if you want your new release to not inherit any configuration from a previous releases.

title: Adding a new release
body: Select Copy from a selected release, and select one of your other releases from a dropdown menu if you want your new release to inherit the selected app, checklists, automations and settings from that release.

title: Adding a new release
body: If you selected Start with a blank release, select an app you would like to add to your release under the App Store connect field.

title: Adding a new release
body: Connection to an Apple service with API key is required

title: Adding a new release
body: If you cannot see your API key under the App Store connect field, make sure that you have connected to an Apple service using an API key. For more information, check out our guide.

title: Adding a new release
body: In the Release information field, specify a release version below the Release Version input and optionally add a description of the release under the Description input.

title: Adding a new release
body: Release description is internal only

title: Adding a new release
body: The release description is internal only, and it will not be included in the App Store review submission (metadata).You can modify the description of your release anytime in the Release Configuration window after creating the release.

title: Adding a new release
body: Click Add release.

title: Adding a new release
body: That's it! Your new release is ready, and you will be taken to the release configuration page.

title: Configuring a release
body: After adding a release, you are automatically taken to the release configuration page.

title: Configuring a release
body: You can also reach this page from the Releases page by clicking on the "" button next to a release.

title: Configuring a release
body: You can use the menu options on the left navigation bar to switch between the configuration of the release and the release stages. Each of these options enables you to manage your release in different ways:

title: Configuring a release
body: Configuration: Edit your release description, schedule release stages, and delete the release.

title: Configuring a release
body: Release candidate: Specify which branch you want to release from, and a Workflow that can generate an .xcarchive file (for example, with the Xcode Archive & Export for iOS Step).

title: Configuring a release
body: TestFlight upload: Upload the selected Release Candidate to TestFlight (App Store Connect).

title: Configuring a release
body: Approvals: Create tasks for each stakeholder and/or team member whose approval is needed to continue with the App Store review.

title: Configuring a release
body: App Store review: Send your app to App Store review.

title: Configuring a release
body: Release: Monitor the status of an automatic release or manage the release of your app.

title: Configuring a release
body: After completing a stage, it will have a green checkmark next to it on the left menu. After finishing all stages your app will be released.

title: Editing the description of a release
body: To edit the description of an existing release:

title: Editing the description of a release
body: Release description is internal only

title: Editing the description of a release
body: The release description is internal only, and it will not be included in the App Store review submission (metadata).You can modify the description of your release anytime in the Release Configuration window after creating the release.

title: Editing the description of a release
body: Open the release configuration page of a release.

title: Editing the description of a release
body: Select Configuration on the left navigation bar.

title: Editing the description of a release
body: Click on the Edit information button to open the Edit Release details window.

title: Editing the description of a release
body: After updating the description, click Save.

title: Scheduling stages for the release
body: You can set up a timeline for the main stages of your release to transparently communicate to your team when each stage will be expected to be finished.

title: Scheduling stages for the release
body: To do so:

title: Scheduling stages for the release
body: Open the release configuration page of a release.

title: Scheduling stages for the release
body: Select Configuration on the left navigation bar.

title: Scheduling stages for the release
body: Click on Schedule stages.

title: Scheduling stages for the release
body: In the Edit Timeline window, fill out each relevant stage's target date.

title: Scheduling stages for the release
body: Click Save.

title: Deleting a release
body: Deleting a release is permanent!

title: Deleting a release
body: Deleting a release is irreversible and you will lose all data of the release in Release Management.

title: Deleting a release
body: Your data in TestFlight and in App Store Connect will not be lost, and ongoing processes in the App Store will not be affected. App Store review will not be canceled. The app will be automatically released as configured.

title: Deleting a release
body: If you want to delete a release, follow these steps:

title: Deleting a release
body: Open the release configuration page of a release.

title: Deleting a release
body: Select Configuration on the left navigation bar.

title: Deleting a release
body: Scroll down to the Danger zone section, and click on Delete release.

title: Deleting a release
body: Click Delete once more to confirm.

title: Enabling Slack notifications for Release Management events
body: You can enable Slack notifications for Release Management events. To do so:

title: Enabling Slack notifications for Release Management events
body: Open your release.

title: Enabling Slack notifications for Release Management events
body: Select Notification settings on the left navigation bar.

title: Enabling Slack notifications for Release Management events
body: Click Edit.

title: Enabling Slack notifications for Release Management events
body: Copy and paste your Slack webhook URL in the Slack webhook url field.

title: Enabling Slack notifications for Release Management events
body: Slack webhook URLs

title: Enabling Slack notifications for Release Management events
body: For more information on how to set up a Slack webhook, check out Slack's official guide.

title: Enabling Slack notifications for Release Management events
body: Click Save.

title: Enabling Slack notifications for Release Management events
body: And you are done! From now on, you will receive a Slack notification for the following events:

title: Enabling Slack notifications for Release Management events
body: Notification events

title: Selecting a release candidate
body: In the release candidate stage you can specify a release branch, and select a Workflow that can generate an .ipa or an .xcarchive file. (for example, with the Xcode Archive & Export for iOS Step).

title: Selecting a release candidate
body: You can also choose to automatically upload a new release candidate each time you finish a build on the selected release branch with the specified Workflow.

title: Selecting a release candidate

title: Selecting a release candidate
body: Open your release.

body: Select Release candidate on the left navigation bar.

body: Under the Configuration section, click on the Change button.

title: Selecting a release candidate

title: Selecting a release candidate

title: Selecting a release candidate

title: Sending your app to App Store review
body: If you opt for a phased release, at first, only some of your users will have access to the contents of your release. Gradually, over a 7-day period, all of your users will get access.

Your app will only be released after the date you specified under Your local date and time if you selected Automatically release this version after the App Review, no earlier than .

title: Insights
body: Insights is a monitoring tool that allows you to track metrics detailing the performance of your Bitrise builds.

title: Insights
body: Insights is a monitoring tool that allows you to track metrics detailing the performance of your Bitrise builds. Track your metrics on app-, Workflow-, and Step-level and use the data to optimize your builds. With the Insights tool, we are targeting three main areas:

title: Insights
body: Stability: Which errors have the highest impact on your builds?

title: Insights
body: Velocity: Which area should you focus on to improve the speed of your builds?

title: Insights
body: Usage: Which Steps and Workflows take the most time in your builds?

title: How Insights works
body: Every Workspace has its own Insights instance. Insights tracks the metrics of all the apps belonging to that Workspace. For each app, you can view three main types of metrics:

title: How Insights works
body: Build stats: on an app's page, you can check aggregated metrics for the app's builds, including detailed data on Workflows and Steps.

title: How Insights works
body: Test stats: look at the detailed metrics of all test cases of an app, including data on individual test runs.

title: How Insights works
body: Credits spent: the amount of credits spent on each app, build, or Workflow.

title: How Insights works
body: You can create personalized dashboards to categorize charts and view them in one place.

title: How Insights works
body: Insights also helps you track bottlenecks: it shows you which of your Workflows and tests take the longest time and cost the highest amount of credits.

title: Getting started with Insights
body: The Insights Overview page offers both aggregated and app-level metrics to check the CI/CD health of your app. Compare values of the same point in time across charts and quickly assess whether there are any negative trends that need your immediate attention.

title: Getting started with Insights
body: Insights constantly tracks the performance of all the apps of your Workspaces. You can get aggregated build data of all your apps, detailed metrics of each app, and you can even categorize the metrics as you see fit using dashboards. Insights also allows you to view bottlenecks: it shows you the Workflows and tests that take the most time or cost you the highest amount of credits.

title: Getting started with Insights
body: To get to your Workspace's Insights page:

title: Getting started with Insights
body: Log in to your Bitrise account.

title: Getting started with Insights
body: In the top right corner, open the account selector dropdown menu and select a Workspace.

title: Getting started with Insights
body: On the header, click Insights. This takes you to the Overview page of the selected Workspace.

title: The Overview page
body: On the Overview, you can see aggregated build data of the selected Workspace. You can see both aggregated build data and app-level build data in the form of charts that cover the selected timeframe.

title: The Overview page
body: You can switch between Workspaces at any time: in the top right corner, open the account selector dropdown menu and select a Workspace.

title: Accessing the build metrics
body: You can get to the detailed build metrics of your Workspace or a specific app in two ways: you can simply select Builds on the left, or you can choose a specific metric from the Overview page of the Workspace. We'll go through the second method:

title: Accessing the build metrics
body: Open the Overview page of your Workspace.

title: Accessing the build metrics
body: Find the metric you need. For example, Build failure rate.

title: Accessing the build metrics
body: Click View details.

title: Accessing the build metrics
body: If you have more than one app in the Workspace, on the Details page you will see the aggregated metrics for all apps of the Workspace by default.

title: Accessing the build metrics
body: From the leftmost dropdown menu, select the app you need.

title: Accessing the build metrics
body: Optionally, you can dig deeper by adding filters using the Add filter button to view specific data. You can filter for:

title: Accessing the build metrics
body: Pipelines: metrics of builds that ran with a specific Pipeline of the app.

title: Accessing the build metrics
body: Stages: metric of builds that ran with a specific Stage of a Pipeline.

title: Accessing the build metrics
body: Workflows: metrics of builds that ran with a specific Workflow of the app.

title: Accessing the build metrics
body: Branches: metrics of builds of a specific branch.

title: Accessing the build metrics
body: Machine types: metrics of builds that ran on a specific machine type.

title: Accessing the build metrics
body: Stacks: metrics of builds that ran on a specific stack.

title: Accessing the build metrics
body: Scroll down to see individual builds, their data, including the Steps they ran with.

title: Accessing the build metrics
body: For the available build metrics, check out Available metrics in Insights.

title: Accessing the testing metrics of an app
body: Insights allows you to keep track of testing metrics, right down to the level of individual testing modules. To do this, you need a testing Step that exports its results to the Deploy to Bitrise.io Step. The following Steps do this automatically, without any need for additional configuration:

title: Accessing the testing metrics of an app
body: Xcode Test for iOS

title: Accessing the testing metrics of an app
body: Android Unit Test

title: Accessing the testing metrics of an app
body: iOS Device Testing

title: Accessing the testing metrics of an app
body: Virtual Device Testing for Android

title: Accessing the testing metrics of an app
body: Flutter Test

title: Accessing the testing metrics of an app
body: If you use any of these Steps to run your tests, you can check your metrics in Insights:

title: Accessing the testing metrics of an app
body: Open Insights.

title: Accessing the testing metrics of an app
body: On the left, select Tests.

title: Accessing the testing metrics of an app
body: From the leftmost dropdown menu, select the app you need.

title: Accessing the testing metrics of an app
body: Optionally, you can dig deeper by using filters to view specific testing data. You can filter for:

title: Accessing the testing metrics of an app
body: Test suites

title: Accessing the testing metrics of an app
body: Test cases

title: Accessing the testing metrics of an app
body: Modules

title: Accessing the testing metrics of an app
body: Branches

title: Accessing the testing metrics of an app
body: Scroll down to see the individual test cases.

title: Accessing the testing metrics of an app
body: For the available test metrics, check out Available metrics in Insights.

title: Bottlenecks
body: The Bottlenecks section helps you understand where you can save the most time or credits. We show you which of your Workflows and tests take the longest time and cost the highest amount of credits.

title: Bottlenecks
body: To access the Bottlenecks page, simply select Bottlenecks on the left. The bottlenecks are divided into the three basic categories we use for all metrics: Builds, Tests, and Credits. Each category has three metrics:

title: Bottlenecks
body: Failing Workflows/Failing tests: these are the failing Workflows or test cases that have the highest impact on the time or credits used on your builds.

title: Bottlenecks
body: Build time/Run time: Workflows with increasing build times, or test cases with increasing run times.

title: Bottlenecks
body: Usage/Flakiness: Workflows that consumed the highest amount of resources (either time or credits), or test cases with the most flaky runs.

title: Viewing data from a specific timeframe
body: By default, all Insights pages display your metrics on a weekly basis from the last 12 weeks. Modify the basis and timeframe by opening the respective dropdown menu in the top right of the page, and selecting the options you need.

title: The Dashboards page
body: You can use the Insights Dashboards page to categorize the charts of your Workspace so that you can view them in one place.

title: The Dashboards page
body: You can combine charts from the Builds, Tests, and Credits tab into a single dashboard, and you can have as many dashboards as you want.

title: Creating a new dashboard
body: You can create a new dashboard either from the Dashboards page or by clicking on the Add to dashboard button () and clicking the Create dashboard button. We will focus on the former method in this guide:

title: Creating a new dashboard
body: Open Insights.

title: Creating a new dashboard
body: On the left, select Dashboards.

title: Creating a new dashboard
body: Click on Create dashboard to open the Create dashboard window.

title: Creating a new dashboard
body: Add the name of the dashboard under the Dashboard name filed and optionally add a description under the Description field.

title: Creating a new dashboard
body: Select the default view of granularity and time range. You can also change these options later.

title: Creating a new dashboard
body: Click on Create.

title: Accessing a dashboard
body: To access a dashboard:

title: Accessing a dashboard
body: Open Insights.

title: Accessing a dashboard
body: On the left, select Dashboards.

title: Accessing a dashboard
body: Click on the name of the dashboard or the arrow icon ("") to open a specific dashboard.

title: Accessing a dashboard
body: From here, you can see the charts you previously added to your dashboard. For more information, check out Adding a chart to a dashboard.

title: Adding a chart to a dashboard
body: You can add any chart from the Builds, Tests, and Credits tabs to your dashboard:

title: Adding a chart to a dashboard
body: Open Insights.

title: Adding a chart to a dashboard
body: Select the Builds, Tests, or Credits tab on the left.

title: Adding a chart to a dashboard
body: Search for the metric you want to add to your dashboard.

title: Adding a chart to a dashboard
body: Click on the Add to dashboard ( ) button next to it.

title: Adding a chart to a dashboard
body: Insert a name under the Chart name field.

title: Adding a chart to a dashboard
body: Select the dashboard where you want to place this chart using the dropdown menu.

title: Adding a chart to a dashboard
body: Click Add.

title: Adding a chart to a dashboard
body: That's it! From now on you will be able to see your chart on the Dashboard page.

title: Adding a chart to a dashboard
body: Removing a chart from a dashboard

title: Adding a chart to a dashboard
body: You can remove a chart from a dashboard using the edit mode. For more information, check out Editing a dashboard.

title: Editing a dashboard
body: Once you have created a dashboard, you can edit it as you see fit. Among other things, you can edit the default time range or delete charts you may no longer need. To do so, you must use the Edit mode:

title: Editing a dashboard
body: Open Insights.

title: Editing a dashboard
body: On the left, select Dashboards.

title: Editing a dashboard
body: Access the dashboard you would like to edit.

title: Editing a dashboard
body: Click on the "" icon, then click on Edit mode.

title: Editing a dashboard
body: In the edit mode, you may change the dashboard's general settings by clicking on the Settings button. You can also change the name of previously added charts or remove them using the icons next to them.

title: Editing a dashboard
body: Click on Save after you finish editing the dashboard.

title: Available metrics in Insights
body: There are numerous available metrics in Insights, such as build success rate, the number of builds, the median time of a successful builds, etc.

title: Available metrics in Insights
body: Insights allows you to track three categories of metrics:

title: Available metrics in Insights
body: Build metrics.

title: Available metrics in Insights
body: Test metrics.

title: Available metrics in Insights
body: Credits usage.

title: Build metrics
body: You can access build metrics from the charts on the Overview page or by selecting Builds on the left. The build metrics are available on app-, Pipeline, Stage, Workflow-, and Step level as well:

title: Build metrics
body: Top build time (p90): The 90th percentile of build times of successful builds. In other words, out of 100 successful builds, the 90th slowest build took this long. This metric is calculated based on your Pipelines' run time, if you don't have any filters selected.

title: Build metrics
body: Typical build time (p50): The median time of a successful build. In other words, out of 100 successful builds, the 50th slowest build took this long. This metric is calculated based on your Pipelines' run time, if you don't have any filters selected.

title: Build metrics
body: Failure rate: The rate of failed builds, or the rate at which a given Workflow failed. For example, if a Workflow failed six times out of ten, its failure rate is 60%. This metric is calculated based on your Pipelines' failure rate, if you don't have any filters selected.

title: Build metrics
body: Build count: The total number of builds started of the app or Workflow, based on the filters and the timeframe you set.

title: Build metrics
body: Total duration: The total duration of all builds of the app or Workflow, based on the filters and the timeframe you set.

title: Test metrics
body: Access testing metrics by selecting Tests on the left. Similarly to basic build metrics, you can apply filters to test runs: you can filter for individual test suites, test cases, or modules, as well as to branches of your app's repository.

title: Test metrics
body: Top duration (p90): The 90th percentile of a test suite or a test case duration. If you filter on a specific test case, `Top duration (p90)` shows the 90th percentile duration of the specific test case. Otherwise, it shows the 90th percentile duration of the test suite(s) of the app or Workflow, based on the filters and the timeframe you set. 90th percentile means that out of 100 successful test executions, the 90th slowest took this much time to finish.

title: Test metrics
body: Typical duration (p50): The median (50th percentile) of a test suite or a test case duration. If you filter on a specific test case, `Typical duration (p50)` shows the 50th percentile duration of the specific test case. Otherwise, it shows the 50th percentile duration of the test suite(s) of the app or Workflow, based on the filters and the timeframe you set. 50th percentile means that out of 100 successful test executions, the 50th slowest took this much time to finish.

title: Test metrics
body: Failure rate: Test failure rate shows you how frequently a test suite or test case fails. For example, if you performed the test suite or test case 100 times, if 10 out of 100 failed, that's a 10% failure rate. If you filter on a specific test case, `Failure rate` shows the failure rate of the specific test case. Otherwise, it shows the failure rate of the test suite(s) of the app or Workflow based on the filters and the timeframe you set.

title: Test metrics
body: Total duration: The total duration of all tests of the app or Workflow, based on the filters and the timeframe you set.

title: Test metrics
body: Test runs: The total number of test runs.

title: Test metrics
body: Flaky runs: The number of test runs that produce inconsistent results despite no changes in the code.

title: Credits usage
body: Insights tracks the amount of credits used on each app and, if you need it, each Workflow of a given app. To check your usage, open Insights and on the left, select Credits.

title: Credits usage
body: The Credit usage chart shows the total credit usage of the app or Workflow, based on the filters and the timeframe you set.

title: Insights tutorials
body: This section contains in-depth tutorials for some of the most common use cases for Insights. The guides walk you through why a given use case is important for mobile development, how to find and track the relevant metrics in Insights, and what those metrics can mean for the health of your builds.

title: Monitoring and optimizing your slowest mobile builds
body: Slow builds result in people having to wait for the build to finish. Even if they switch to do something else while the build is running, there will be a context switch when they have to switch back once the build is done.

title: Monitoring and optimizing your slowest mobile builds
body: During a pull request review, you might have to do multiple builds, as you do changes and improvements based on the reviewer’s feedback or based on automatic linters. The slower the mobile build, the more you’ll have to wait throughout the pull request process.

title: Monitoring and optimizing your slowest mobile builds
body: Slow builds are even worse if the build fails afterward. In that case, you’ll have to fix or change something and then do the build again — costing you even more build time. If the build takes a long time, you’ll have to wait a lot for the build to fail, and then fix the issue and start a new build, and wait for that too. This is especially bad if a release or deploy build fails, where you usually have to fix it as soon as possible and try it again.

title: Monitoring and optimizing your slowest mobile builds
body: Another impact of slow builds is how quickly you can iterate on the mobile build’s configuration. Whenever you make changes you’ll want to test the new configuration by starting a new build. If that build takes a long time your iterations will be slow. This is even more important if you then have to do follow-up changes, either because that test build fails, or because you forget to add something to the configuration — or maybe you’ll just want to clean up a few things. If the build is slow you’ll have to wait a long time between every iteration. The faster you can iterate the more things you can try, the more improvements you can do, and the more chances you’ll have to make mistakes and fix them in a given amount of time.

title: Monitoring and optimizing your slowest mobile builds
body: The main goal is to reduce the wait time throughout the development process. If you have mobile builds which take a long time to finish that means that sooner or later you’ll have to wait for it, and most likely lose time either 1) because of context switching or, 2) because you can’t do anything useful while you’re waiting for the results of that build.

title: Finding slow builds
body: So, how can you monitor your build time and how can you diagnose and improve them using Bitrise Insights?

title: Finding slow builds
body: When you open Bitrise Insights you can find the Successful build time chart on the Overview page. Here you can see your overall build time trends in the whole Workspace and you can also see the top 5 slowest apps' build time trends.

title: Finding slow builds
body: From here you can continue your investigation using either the View details button or by clicking the Builds page under the Explore section in the left sidebar:

title: Finding slow builds
body: When you open the Build Explore page there are two relevant metrics you can check related to build times. The Top build time (p90), which is the 90th percentile, and the Typical build time (p50), which is the 50th percentile.

title: Finding slow builds
body: Percentile definitions

title: Finding slow builds
body: 50th percentile means that out of a hundred builds the 50th slowest one took this long to finish. The 90th percentile means that out of a hundred builds 90 finished around this time or faster.

title: Finding slow builds
body: On the Build Explore page, you can start from the Workspace level, which you can see on the upper chart if there are no filters applied. Using the intelligent breakdown (the 2nd chart) you can drill into the data to find which application, which Workflow, and which Step is affecting the build time trend that you are checking.

title: Finding slow builds
body: Let's go through an example. Here on the breakdown chart, you can see that we have this application which is the slowest in this Workspace:

title: Finding slow builds
body: Filter down to that app in the dropdown menu on the top left, and on the next level, you'll find the per Workflow breakdown. The upper chart now shows you what is filtered on, so in this case, it's the selected app's p90 build time.

title: Finding slow builds
body: On the lower breakdown chart, you can see which Workflow takes the longest.

title: Finding slow builds
body: Let's filter down to that Workflow.

title: Finding slow builds
body: The upper chart now reflects this filtering, and the breakdown chart switched over to per-step build times. Using the breakdown chart you can find out which Step is causing the build time trend that we are investigating.

title: Finding slow builds
body: Under the graphs, you can also see the build history which is filtered based on the filters that you set at the top and also on the time range that you set in the top right corner.

title: Finding slow builds
body: When you find the builds that correlate with the trend that you're checking then you can quickly jump to the relevant build's page and then continue your investigation there:

title: Diagnosing bottlenecks in your builds
body: On the Bottlenecks page, Insights shows you negative trends from the last 7 days. The relevant bottleneck to look out for is the Build time one, which lists workflows that became slower in the last 7 days compared to the previous 7 days.

title: Diagnosing bottlenecks in your builds
body: It lists the Workflows based on the time impact of that slowing trend. This is usually a good place to check, as the time impact calculated here reflects both the % increase in the 50th percentile build time. It also takes into account how many builds you had in the last 7-day period. For example, one of your Workflows took 2 minutes more to build, but you only had a few builds with that Workflow — on the other hand, another Workflow had only a 1-minute build time increase, but had tens or hundreds of builds with that Workflow. In this case, the second Workflow will have a higher time impact and will be listed higher on Bottlenecks.

title: Diagnosing bottlenecks in your builds
body: If you don’t have any Workflows listed in the Build time section that means that none of your Workflows had a significant build time increase.

title: Diagnosing bottlenecks in your builds
body: Monitor and improve the most important metrics, and you'll reduce the wait time in your app development process. In addition to that, you'll also improve developer productivity and happiness!

title: Monitoring and optimizing your slowest mobile builds
body: If you have any questions or feedback, please let us know using the Give feedback button in the bottom left corner on any of the Bitrise Insights pages!

title: Tracking build failure rate
body: For every failed build, you’ll most likely have to 1) spend time to fix the failure, 2) then try the build again, and 3) then wait for the retried build to finish. Even if you can switch to do something else while the build is running there will be a context switch when you have to switch back once the build is done.

title: Tracking build failure rate
body: If your build failure rate is high on a specific app’s or Workflow’s builds, that means people frequently spend time on debugging, fixing and then retrying builds.

title: Tracking build failure rate
body: Failure rate is especially crucial for long builds, as the engineers will have to wait even more when they do a fix and then run a new build. Tracking and reducing the frequency of failed builds can help minimizing the time and effort spent on resolving build failures and increase the overall efficiency and productivity of your team.

title: Tracking build failure rate
body: The main goal is to reduce the wait time throughout the development process. If you have builds which fail frequently that means that sooner rather than later you’ll have a failing build, where you’ll have to check why it failed, fix the issue, and then try it again and wait for the build to hopefully pass. As part of this you’ll likely lose time either because of context switching or because you can’t do anything useful while you’re waiting for the results of that build.

title: Finding frequently failing builds
body: When you open Bitrise Insights, you can find the Build failure rate chart on the Overview page.

title: Finding frequently failing builds
body: Here you can see your overall build failure rate trend in the whole Workspace and you can also see the top 5 most frequently failing apps' build failure rate trends.

title: Finding frequently failing builds
body: From here you can continue your investigation using either the View details button or by clicking the Builds page under the EXPLORE section in the left sidebar.

title: Finding frequently failing builds
body: After you open the Builds page switch to the Failure rate tab.

title: Finding frequently failing builds
body: On the Builds page, depending on which filters are applied, you can start from the Workspace level which you can see on the upper chart. Using the intelligent breakdown (the 2nd, lower chart) you can drill into the data to find which application, which workflow, which step is causing the build failure rate trend that you are checking.

title: Finding frequently failing builds
body: Let's go through an example. Here on the breakdown chart you can see that we have this application which is failing most frequently in this Workspace:

title: Finding frequently failing builds
body: Filter down to that application, and on the next level you'll find the per Workflow breakdown.

title: Finding frequently failing builds
body: The upper chart now shows what is filtered on, so in this case it's the selected app's failure rate. On the lower, breakdown chart you can see which is the Workflow which fails most frequently.

title: Finding frequently failing builds
body: Let's filter down to that Workflow:

title: Finding frequently failing builds
body: The upper chart now reflects this filtering, and the breakdown chart switched over to per Step failure rate. Using the breakdown chart you can find out which Step is causing the failure rate trend that we are investigating.

title: Finding frequently failing builds
body: Under the graphs you can also see the build history which is filtered based on the filters that you set at the top and also on the time range that you set in the top right corner.

title: Finding frequently failing builds
body: Hovering on the bars you can see how long specific Steps took and in which build that step failed.

title: Finding frequently failing builds
body: When you find the builds which correlate with the trend that you're checking then you can quickly jump to the relevant build's page and then continue your investigation there.

title: Diagnosing bottlenecks causing builds to fail
body: There’s another page that is worth checking periodically in Insights: the Bottlenecks page:

title: Diagnosing bottlenecks causing builds to fail
body: On the Bottlenecks page Insights shows you negative trends from the last 7 days. The relevant bottleneck is the Failing Workflows one, which lists Workflows which consumed the most amount of time to fail. It lists the Workflows based on the time impact of the failing builds.

title: Diagnosing bottlenecks causing builds to fail
body: This is usually a good place to check as the time impact calculation here reflects both how frequently the builds of a given Workflow fail as well as how long those failing builds take. The time impact listed on this page is the total amount build time of the failing builds for that Workflow in the last 7 days. In the example above it means that the bullseye app’s test Workflow builds failed in 73.68% of the cases, and in total those failed builds consumed 1 hour and 38 minutes in the last 7 days.

title: Diagnosing bottlenecks causing builds to fail
body: By listing the Workflows based on time impact instead of based on just the failure rate, the Bottlenecks page helps you to focus on the most impactful build failure trends. As an example, if you have a Workflow which had only a few builds and those all failed, while another Workflow had tens or hundreds of builds and it failed in 50% of the cases, if both Workflows builds are about the same length the second Workflow will be ranked higher, as overall those failed builds caused more wait time for engineers.

title: Diagnosing bottlenecks causing builds to fail
body: Keeping an eye on and improving your build failure rate helps you to reduce wait time during the app development process and to increase the efficiency and productivity of your team.

title: Tracking test failure rate
body: When your mobile app’s tests fail in a continuous integration (CI) environment, it typically indicates that the build has also failed. This means that someone will need to make code changes or fixes and then retry the build and test it again, leading to a cycle of iterations. Even if someone switches to other tasks while the test and build are running, there will be a context switch when they have to return to the task once the test and build are done.

title: The importance of test failure rate
body: A high mobile app test failure rate suggests that people frequently spend time debugging, fixing, and then retrying — and waiting for — tests and builds. Failure rate is especially critical for long tests and builds as engineers will have to wait even more when they do a fix and then run a new build and test.

title: The importance of test failure rate
body: By tracking and analyzing where and why your mobile app’s tests fail the most, teams can improve their testing process and make it more resilient over time. Meaning, the time and effort spent on resolving test failures are minimized and the overall efficiency and productivity of your team are increased.

title: The importance of test failure rate
body: The main goal of tracking your mobile app’s failing tests is to reduce the wait time throughout the development process. If you have tests that fail frequently, it means that sooner or later you’ll have to wait for that test and the related build, fix the issue, and then try it again. As part of this cyclical process, you’ll likely lose time either due to 1) context switching or, 2) because you can’t do anything useful while you’re waiting for the results of that test and build.

title: Finding frequently failing tests
body: When you open Bitrise Insights, you can start with the Build failure rate chart on the Overview page to find the most frequently failing apps and builds. If you’re only interested in tests, you can switch to the Tests page under the EXPLORE section in the left sidebar.

title: Finding frequently failing tests
body: After you open the Tests page, switch to the Failure rate tab.

title: Finding frequently failing tests
body: On all of the Tests metric pages. you’ll see two charts. The upper chart always shows you data for the filters you set. The lower chart is called the breakdown chart and it shows data one level deeper than what you filtered on.

title: Finding frequently failing tests
body: If you have only a single app in your Workspace then Insights will automatically select that app when you open any of the Explore pages. However, if you have multiple apps in your Workspace, when you open the Tests page the upper chart it will show you the overall test failure rate of the Workspace — based on test suite failure rates in all of your apps in the workspace.The lower chart, in this example, shows you the same data — but on a per-application basis. From this you can see which app’s test suites are failing the most.

title: Finding frequently failing tests
body: Here’s a working example. On the breakdown chart, you can see the application that has the most frequently failing test suites in the Workspace. When filtering down into that app, you'll find the per test suite breakdown:

title: Finding frequently failing tests
body: The upper chart now shows what is filtered — so in this case, the selected app's test suite failure rate is being displayed. On the lower, breakdown chart, you can see which test suite failed most frequently.

title: Finding frequently failing tests
body: Let's filter down to that test suite.

title: Finding frequently failing tests
body: The upper chart now reflects this filtering, and the breakdown chart switched over to per branch failure rate. Under the graphs, you can see the Test cases list, which is filtered based on the filters that you set at the top and also on the time range that you set in the top right corner.

title: Finding frequently failing tests
body: Using this Test cases table, you can find which test case is failing most frequently (Failure rate) or which test case failed the most amount of times (Failure count) in the selected time period, app, and test suite.

title: Finding frequently failing tests
body: Select the most frequently failing test case to continue your investigation.

title: Finding frequently failing tests
body: This will set the relevant filters for you to focus only on this specific test case. As a result, the charts at the top will now only show the failure rate trend of this specific test case.

title: Finding frequently failing tests
body: Under the charts, the Insights filter automatically switched over to the Related test case runs tab:

title: Finding frequently failing tests
body: Using the Related test case runs table, you can see all the previous runs of this specific test case, how long that run was, and whether it was successful or not. Using the buttons on the right side you can quickly jump to the relevant build’s page and to the relevant test report’s page and then continue your investigation there:

title: Finding frequently failing tests
body: Keeping an eye on and improving your test failure rate helps you to reduce wait time during the app development process and to increase the efficiency and productivity of your team.

title: Tracking flaky tests
body: Flaky tests are a persistent issue that can make a mobile developer's life frustrating and challenging. Failing tests that produce different results even when the code hasn’t changed can cause confusion and setbacks, leading to time-consuming and frustrating debugging sessions. Eliminating flaky tests is essential for ensuring a stable and reliable testing process. This article explores the importance of tracking flaky tests with Bitrise Insights, and how to diagnose the causes behind them. Additionally, it also discusses how Bitrise Insights can detect flaky tests, and how developers can use the tool to track, identify, and diagnose the flakiness of their tests.

title: The importance of tracking flaky tests
body: First, what is a flaky test and how is it calculated? A test is flaky if it produces different results even when the code isn’t changed. For example, this simple code will sometimes fail and other times it’ll be successful, without any code change:

title: The importance of tracking flaky tests
body:
randNum := r1.Intn(100)
2require.Equal(t, true, randNum > 40, "More than 40?")

title: The importance of tracking flaky tests
body: Flaky tests are a special case of failing tests, and probably the most crucial ones to fix.

title: The importance of tracking flaky tests
body: Flaky tests are a persistent problem that can make a developer's life frustrating and challenging. They are a unique type of failing tests that may cause confusion and setbacks even when the code change being made is functioning as intended. Unlike other failing tests, flaky tests can cause failures in seemingly unrelated parts of the code, leading to time-consuming and frustrating debugging sessions. Fixing flaky tests is essential for ensuring a stable and reliable testing process.

title: The importance of tracking flaky tests
body: Eliminating flaky tests is not only important to prevent time waste, but is also crucial to improving developers' confidence in the tests. If tests fail randomly, developers will start to ignore test failures over time.

title: The importance of tracking flaky tests
body: Bitrise Insights can detect when a test produces inconsistent results for the same code state. For builds which have a code commit hash information specified when triggered (usually all builds except manually triggered and scheduled ones) it can detect this across builds (where the commit hash is the same, but the test had multiple different results on the same commit hash). Insights can also detect flaky tests in a given build, if the same test was performed multiple times in a single build, even if the build did not have a commit hash specified when it was triggered (common for manual and scheduled builds).

title: Finding flaky tests
body: When you open Bitrise Insights, you start on the Overview page. From here, you can go to either the Bottlenecks page, which lists the top 3 most flaky tests, or you can go to the Tests page under the EXPLORE section to list and filter all your flaky tests. This will help you track and investigate flaky tests.

title: Finding flaky tests
body: Let’s check the Bottlenecks page first. When you open the Bottlenecks page you’ll see all the negative trends and issues Bitrise Insights detected in the last 7 days. When you’re checking flaky tests you can use the Flakiness section:

title: Finding flaky tests
body: This Bottlenecks section lists the test cases which had the most flaky runs in the last 7 days. Click on any of them and you’ll land on the relevant section of the Tests page.

title: Finding flaky tests
body: Another way to go about it, is to go to the Tests page and switch to the Flaky runs metric tab:

title: Finding flaky tests
body: Just like on any other Tests metric pages, you’ll see two charts. The upper chart always shows you data for the filters you set. The lower chart is called the breakdown chart and it shows you data “one level deeper” than what you filtered on.

title: Finding flaky tests
body: If you only have a single app in your Workspace, Bitrise Insights will automatically select that app when you open any of the Explore pages. If you have multiple apps in your workspace, when you open the Tests page, the upper chart will show you the overall flaky runs of the workspace across all of your apps in that specific workspace.

title: Finding flaky tests
body: The lower chart in this case shows you the same data but on a per app basis. From this you can see which app had the most flaky runs in the selected time period:

title: Finding flaky tests
body: Here, on the breakdown chart you can see that we have this application which had the most amount of flaky test runs in this workspace. Filter down to that app, and on the next level you'll find the per test suite breakdown:

title: Finding flaky tests
body: The upper chart now shows selected filters view, which in this case is the selected app's flaky test runs. On the lower breakdown chart, you can see which the test suite which had the most flaky test runs:

title: Finding flaky tests
body: Let's filter down to that test suite to investigate it a little further:

title: Finding flaky tests
body: The upper chart now reflects this filtering, and the breakdown chart switched over to per branch flaky runs. Under the graphs you can see the Test cases list, which is filtered based on the filters that you set at the top and also on the time/date range that you set in the top right corner.

title: Finding flaky tests
body: Using this Test cases table you can find which test case is flaky most frequently (Flaky rate) or which test case had the most amount of flaky runs (Flaky runs) in the selected time period, app, and test suite.

title: Finding flaky tests
body: Select the test case which had the most flaky runs to continue your investigation.

title: Finding flaky tests
body: This will set the relevant filters for you to focus only on this specific test case. As a result, the charts at the top will now only show the flaky run trends of this specific test case.

title: Finding flaky tests
body: Under the charts, Bitrise Insights automatically switched over to the Related test case runs tab:

title: Finding flaky tests
body: The Related test case runs table lists the specific executions of the test case which had inconsistent results, either in a given build, or across builds with the same commit hash. As you can see on this example, the testFlakyFeature() test case had both successful and failed results for the same commit (for commit f74ca14 and also for c84f1fd).

title: Finding flaky tests
