body: Using the Related test case runs table you can see all the previous flaky runs of this specific test case, how long that run was and whether it was successful or not. Using the buttons in the test run popup you can quickly jump to the relevant build’s page and to the relevant test report’s page and then continue your investigation there:

title: Finding flaky tests
body: Keeping an eye on and fixing flaky tests helps you to reduce time waste during the app development process and to increase the overall test confidence of the team.

title: Credit usage
body: Credit-based plans only

title: Credit usage
body: This article is only relevant if you are on a credit based (pay-by-minute) subscription plan. Users who aren’t on a credit based plan don’t see the Credits page on Insights.

title: Credit usage
body: Keeping an eye on your credit usage can help to avoid surprises caused by changes which result in increased credit usage. Using Bitrise Insights you can see your credit usage trends and if you notice any negative trend you can use Insights to track down what is causing that.

title: Tracking overall credit usage
body: When you open Bitrise Insights you start on the Overview page.

title: Tracking overall credit usage
body: Scroll down to the Credit usage section to see your Workspace’s overall credit usage and the top 5 apps using the most amount of credits.

title: Tracking overall credit usage
body: If you want to predict your credit usage switch over to the Credits page, either by clicking the Credits option under the EXPLORE section in the left sidebar, or click the View details button in the Credit usage section.

title: Tracking overall credit usage
body: On the Credits page by default you’ll see your last 12 weeks (3 months) credit usage trend on a week-by-week basis.To predict how much credits you’ll use you have a few options.

title: Tracking overall credit usage
body: Switch to monthly view to see your last 6 months credit usage, the trend of your credit usage, and the current month’s usage so far.

title: Tracking overall credit usage
body: Alternatively you can also switch to daily view (Last 30 days) and change the chart to Cumulative to see how much credit you used in the last 30 days and the trend of it:

title: Tracking overall credit usage
body: If the trend is fairly stable (no large jumps and drops) then most likely you’ll use about the same amount of credits than what you did in the last 30 days, which you can see in the upper left corner under Credit usage.

title: Tracking overall credit usage
body: Comparing this daily to the monthly view should give you a good guidance about how much credit usage you should expect in the month and how that compares to your previous months' credit usage.

title: Credit usage by app, Workflow or Step
body: Open the Credits page under the EXPLORE section in the left sidebar. You can also switch to weekly view, to the last 12 weeks, if you’re not already in weekly view:

title: Credit usage by app, Workflow or Step
body: Just like on any other Explore pages you’ll see two charts. The upper chart always shows you data for the filters you set. The lower chart is called the breakdown chart and it shows you data one level deeper than what you filtered on.

title: Credit usage by app, Workflow or Step
body: If you have only a single app in your Workspace then Insights will automatically select that app when you open any of the Explore pages. If you have multiple apps in your Workspace, when you open the Credits page the upper chart shows you the overall credit use of the Workspace across all of your apps in the Workspace.

title: Credit usage by app, Workflow or Step
body: The lower chart in this case shows you the same data but on a per app basis. From this you can see which app used the most amount of credits in the selected time period.

title: Credit usage by app, Workflow or Step
body: Here on the breakdown chart you can see that we have this application which used the most amount of credits in this Workspace. Filter down to that app, and on the next level you'll find the per Workflow breakdown.

title: Credit usage by app, Workflow or Step
body: The upper chart now shows what is filtered on, so in this case it's the selected app's credit usage. On the lower, breakdown chart you can see which is the Workflow which used the most credits.

title: Credit usage by app, Workflow or Step
body: Let's filter down to that Workflow.

title: Credit usage by app, Workflow or Step
body: The chart now reflects this filtering and shows the credit usage trend of the Workflow.

title: Credit usage by app, Workflow or Step
body: From here we should find out what is causing this credit usage increase in this Workflow. This might be caused by slower builds, increased amount of builds, or by changing the machine type to one which uses more credits per minute.

title: Credit usage by app, Workflow or Step
body: To investigate this switch over to the Builds page. When you switch to any other Explore pages the filters you previously selected will carry over, so you won’t have to select the same app and Workflow again.In this case going through the metric tabs most metrics seem stable during this period, but we can see a similar pattern on the Total duration metric:

title: Credit usage by app, Workflow or Step
body: Similar to the Credits page, the Builds page also has 2 charts on it. The top one shows the selected metric (Total duration in this case) for the relevant filters (for the selected app and Workflow).

title: Credit usage by app, Workflow or Step
body: The lower breakdown chart shows the per step distribution of the total build duration. From this we can see that the iOS Device Testing Step took the most amount of time and it also correlates with the overall trend.

title: Credit usage by app, Workflow or Step
body: As build times and build count was consistent for the whole 12 weeks, and the only other metric which had a change during this period was Failure rate, let’s switch over to that tab:

title: Credit usage by app, Workflow or Step
body: What we can see here is that where we had the drop in credit usage as well as in total duration the iOS Device Testing Step had a 100% failure rate. As failed Steps usually take less time to finish, let’s check the related builds as well in the Related builds section under the charts.

title: Credit usage by app, Workflow or Step
body: To find the relevant builds we’ll zoom into the period where failure rate increased. The easiest way is to click-hold-and-drag on the chart.

title: Credit usage by app, Workflow or Step
body: Let’s filter down to just this single Step as well in the Related builds section:

title: Credit usage by app, Workflow or Step
body: Now we can scroll through the build history and see how the build time of this Step changed. At the end of the period, where the failure rate was 100% we can see that it only took a few seconds:

title: Credit usage by app, Workflow or Step
body: As we keep scrolling we can see that back in early December where we still had successful builds the Step took multiple minutes to complete:

title: Credit usage by app, Workflow or Step
body: So in this case the drop on the total duration (and in credits) was caused by this Step failing a lot, which meant that builds completed quicker, until the issue with the tests was fixed, when the Step and the builds once again took longer to finish, but could actually run and finish the tests.

title: Credit usage by app, Workflow or Step
body: Another place which worth to be checked periodically is the Bottlenecks page:

title: Credit usage by app, Workflow or Step
body: On this page you can find a Credits section where Bitrise Insights highlights you negative trends which consumed the most amount of credits.

title: Credit usage by app, Workflow or Step
body: Failing Workflows shows you Workflows which had a lot of credit usage on failed builds. On the example above you can see that the Workflow called test failed in 73.68% of the cases in the last 7 days and those failed builds consumed 624 credits in total.

title: Credit usage by app, Workflow or Step
body: Build time shows slowing build trends, where the build took longer in the last 7 days than in the 7 days before that, and tells you the credit impact of that negative trend.

title: Credit usage by app, Workflow or Step
body: The Usage bottleneck simply lists you the Workflows which used the most amount of credits in the last 7 days.

title: Credit usage by app, Workflow or Step
body: Clicking any of these bottleneck items will open the relevant Explore page filtered down to the Workflow.

title: Bitrise CLI
body: The Bitrise CLI is Bitrise's open source runner. The CLI is used to run your builds on bitrise.io. You can install and run it on your own computer to run builds locally.

title: Bitrise CLI
body: The Bitrise CLI is Bitrise's open source runner. The CLI is used to run your builds on bitrise.io and you can install and run it on your own computer to run builds locally.

title: Bitrise CLI
body: To use the CLI locally, you don't need a Bitrise account. You just need to install the CLI.

title: Bitrise CLI
body: In this section of the documentation, you'll learn how to install and update the CLI, how to run builds and manage Secrets locally, and how to set up and use the offline Workflow Editor.

title: Installing and updating the Bitrise CLI
body: Installing the Bitrise CLI is super simple. It is distributed as a single binary for macOS and Linux which you can acquire in several ways. All you need to do is download it and make it executable.

title: Installing the Bitrise CLI with curl
body: Run the following command in a bash shell:

title: Installing the Bitrise CLI with curl
body: curl -fL https://github.com/bitrise-io/bitrise/releases/latest/download/bitrise-$(uname -s)-$(uname -m) > /usr/local/bin/bitrise

title: Installing the Bitrise CLI with curl
body: You can check the latest release of the Bitrise CLI on its releases page.

title: Installing the Bitrise CLI with curl
body: Make the downloaded binary executable:

title: Installing the Bitrise CLI with curl
body: chmod +x /usr/local/bin/bitrise

title: Installing the Bitrise CLI with curl
body: Run bitrise setup.

title: Installing the Bitrise CLI with curl
body: This will verify if everything that is required for Bitrise to run is installed and available. If you skip this, the CLI will perform the setup anyway the first time you call bitrise run.

title: Installing the Bitrise CLI with Homebrew
body: If you have the Homebrew package manager installed on your Mac, you can use it to install the Bitrise CLI.

title: Installing the Bitrise CLI with Homebrew
body: Open the Terminal app on your Mac and run:

title: Installing the Bitrise CLI with Homebrew
body: brew update && brew install bitrise

title: Installing the Bitrise CLI with Homebrew
body: Run bitrise setup.

title: Installing the Bitrise CLI with Homebrew
body: This will verify if everything that is required for Bitrise to run is installed and available. If you skip this, the CLI will perform the setup anyway the first time you call bitrise run.

title: Updating the Bitrise CLI
body: Updating the Bitrise CLI is easy, and it doesn’t matter if you installed it with Homebrew or from the GitHub release.

title: Updating the Bitrise CLI
body: Simply run bitrise update - that’s it! The CLI checks for updates once every day and notifies you as soon as there is a new version.

title: Adding a new app from a CLI
body: You can register a Bitrise app from a command line interface and start building. You can create a bitrise.yml file in advance and use that, or have our project scanner scan your project and generate one for you.

title: Adding a new app from a CLI
body: You can easily register a new Bitrise app from any command line interface: the process is guided and simple to follow. And it’s fast: if, for example, you have the bitrise.yml file you want to use for the app, you do not have to wait for the project scanner to detect the app type and generate your bitrise.yml file. Just plug in the existing file and you are good to go!

title: Adding a new app from a CLI
body: Adding an app with the API

title: Adding a new app from a CLI
body: You can also use the Bitrise API to add a new app: Adding and managing apps

title: Adding a new app from a CLI
body: Before you try adding a new app to Bitrise via our CLI, make sure a few things are in order:

title: Adding a new app from a CLI
body: You need a Bitrise account, with a connected Git provider.

title: Adding a new app from a CLI
body: Your project must have a local Git repository on your machine and a remote repository at a Git provider. If you want to use an SSH key to access the repository, the remote repository URL must be an SSH URL! For example, git@github.com:example-user/example.git.

title: Adding a new app from a CLI
body: You can also create a bitrise.yml in advance and you will be able to add that to your app during the creation process. This is optional: you can have the project scanner generate one for you during the process, just like on our website!

title: Adding a new app from a CLI
body: This procedure guides you through adding an app which Bitrise will access with an SSH key. This requires that the app’s remote repository has an SSH URL, such as git@github.com:example-user/example.git.

title: Adding a new app from a CLI
body: You can, of course, use an HTTPS URL to access your remote repository, too: in that case, you will not set an SSH key for your app. We only recommend using HTTPS URLs for public apps (open source projects).

title: Adding a new app from a CLI
body: Go to the Create New App from CLI page.

title: Adding a new app from a CLI
body: You can reach this page from your Dashboard: click the Add new app button on the right, and then select Add New App from CLI.

title: Adding a new app from a CLI
body: Set the account that will own the app, and the privacy of the app.

title: Adding a new app from a CLI
body: Copy the curl command you find there.

title: Adding a new app from a CLI
body: Open a command line interface.

title: Adding a new app from a CLI
body: Change the directory to your project’s location.

title: Adding a new app from a CLI
body: Paste the curl command and hit Enter.

title: Adding a new app from a CLI
body: Select the repository URL: choose the SSH option.

title: Adding a new app from a CLI
body: This prompt only comes up if your local repository’s remote has an SSH URL. If the remote repository has an HTTPS URL, you won’t see this prompt.

title: Adding a new app from a CLI
body:
Remote URL: git@github.com:example-user/example.git

? Select repository URL::
 https://github.com/example-user/example.git
 > ssh://git@github.com:example-user/example.git

title: Adding a new app from a CLI
body: Register an SSH key.

title: Adding a new app from a CLI
body:
Specify how Bitrise will be able to access the source code: 
 > Automatic
 Add own SSH

title: Adding a new app from a CLI
body: You can select either the automatic registration or choose to add your own.

title: Adding a new app from a CLI
body: If you choose automatic, Bitrise will automatically generate a key pair. If you need to use additional private repositories or submodules, choose the I need to option when prompted and follow the instructions. If not, select the No, auto-add SSH key option: this automatically adds the public key to your repository.

title: Adding a new app from a CLI
body: If you choose to add your own, you have to provide the path to the SSH key file: either enter it manually, or drag and drop the file, as that will input the path.

title: Adding a new app from a CLI
body: Decide what bitrise.yml file you want to upload.

title: Adding a new app from a CLI
body:
? What bitrise.yml do you want to upload? 
 > Run the scanner to generate a new bitrise.yml
 Use the bitrise.yml found in the current directory or specify manually

title: Adding a new app from a CLI
body: You can either have the scanner generate one based on your project files or you can provide a file. If your repository already contains a bitrise.yml file, the path to it will be automatically filled in.

title: Adding a new app from a CLI
body: Select the branch you want to use.

title: Adding a new app from a CLI
body: The default option is the current active branch.

title: Adding a new app from a CLI
body:
The current branch is: master (tracking: origin master),
 
? Do you want to run the scanner for this branch?
 > Yes
 No

title: Adding a new app from a CLI
body: If you select No, you will be prompted to check out the branch you wish to use, and then hit Enter again so the scanner can start.

title: Adding a new app from a CLI
body: Once the scanner is done, it will either detect your app’s type or it will switch to manual configuration. Manual configuration means you have to select the type of your app (iOS, Android, React Native, Flutter, and so on) and you have to provide the path to the relevant configuration file. For example, a config.xml in the case of an Ionic app. In this guide, we’ll proceed with automatic detection.

title: Adding a new app from a CLI
body: Select the stack you want to use.

title: Adding a new app from a CLI
body: If the scanner detects your project type, a stack will be automatically recommended but you can change it in the CLI if you want to. If you performed manual configuration as described above, you will have to choose the stack, too.

title: Adding a new app from a CLI
body: Finish the process with setting up webhooks and code signing files.

title: Adding a new app from a CLI
body: You can decide to skip webhook registration but it’s required to automatically trigger builds on Bitrise. For more information: Webhooks

title: Adding a new app from a CLI
body: You can upload code signing files: depending on your app’s type, you will be asked if you want to upload iOS code signing files - the tool will run codesigndoc for you - and/or an Android keystore file. You can upload these files any time on the website. For more information: Code signing

title: Adding a new app from a CLI
body: And that’s it! You are done: the URL to your new app will be printed out, and you can also view the app on your Dashboard.

title: Initializing a Bitrise project locally
body: You can use the bitrise init plugin to initialize a new Bitrise app on your own computer, without adding it to Bitrise online.

title: Initializing a Bitrise project locally
body: When you add a new app to Bitrise, we detect the type of your project and generate a basic bitrise.yml file for you, with Workflows that are appropriate for your project type.

title: Initializing a Bitrise project locally
body: With the Bitrise CLI, you can make this work on your own computer:

title: Initializing a Bitrise project locally
body: Install the Bitrise CLI on your computer.

title: Initializing a Bitrise project locally
body: Make sure that $GOPATH/bin is added to $PATH on your computer.

title: Initializing a Bitrise project locally
body: By default, your Go workspace is at $HOME/go/bin.

title: Initializing a Bitrise project locally
body: Installing Go

title: Initializing a Bitrise project locally
body: If you don't have Go installed on your computer, bitrise init will automatically install it for you.

title: Initializing a Bitrise project locally
body: Start the bitrise init plugin:

title: Initializing a Bitrise project locally
body: bitrise init

title: Initializing a Bitrise project locally
body: Wait while the plugin runs all available scanners to determine your project type.

title: Initializing a Bitrise project locally
body: Depending on the detected project type, the scanner asks for some input. Follow the instructions.

title: Initializing a Bitrise project locally
body: For example, with an iOS project, it asks the user to specify an export method:

title: Initializing a Bitrise project locally
body:
Select: ipa export method
Please select from the list:
[1] : app-store
[2] : ad-hoc
[3] : enterprise
[4] : development
(type in the option's number, then hit Enter) :

title: Initializing a Bitrise project locally
body: Based on the scanner outputs, the plugin generates a Bitrise configuration, with a bitrise.yml file. In the automatically generated Workflows, every required input will have a valid value.

title: Initializing a Bitrise project locally
body: The plugin also generates a bitrise.secrets.yml file. You can store your Secrets in this file.

title: Installing and upgrading the offline Workflow Editor
body: Bitrise Workflow Editor is designed in such a way that you can run it offline on your Mac/PC without having to log into bitrise.io. The Workflow Editor is open source, you can find its repository here. You can also join the discussion around Workflow Editor here.

title: Installing the offline Workflow Editor to your computer
body: Install the Bitrise CLI.

title: Installing the offline Workflow Editor to your computer
body: Make sure you have Go installed on your local computer.

title: Installing the offline Workflow Editor to your computer
body: Run bitrise setup to install offline Workflow Editor as part of the Bitrise Plugins.

title: Installing the offline Workflow Editor to your computer
body: Running bitrise setup also checks if Bitrise Core tools, OS X tools, Bitrise Plugins and Toolkits are installed on your local machine. If not, the command will automatically install them.

title: Starting the offline Workflow Editor
body: cd into a directory where you have your bitrise.yml.

title: Starting the offline Workflow Editor
body: Run bitrise :workflow-editor command to start your offline session.

title: Starting the offline Workflow Editor
body: Here is the overall look and feel:

title: Upgrading Workflow Editor version
body: You can upgrade to the latest version of the Workflow Editor by running bitrise plugin update workflow-editor command.

title: Running your first local build with the CLI
body: Run a Bitrise build locally with the Bitrise CLI and a bitrise.yml file. To do so, use the bitrise run command once you have the correct YAML configuration.

title: Running your first local build with the CLI
body: To run a Bitrise build locally, you only need to:

title: Running your first local build with the CLI
body: Install the Bitrise CLI.

title: Running your first local build with the CLI
body: A build configuration: that is, a bitrise.yml file.

title: Running your first local build with the CLI
body: If you use bitrise.io, you can download your app’s bitrise.yml from there: open the Workflow Editor of the app on bitrise.io, under the bitrise.yml section.

title: Running your first local build with the CLI
body: If you want to create a bitrise.yml yourself, simply create a bitrise.yml file in the root of your project. You can use this as the base content of the bitrise.yml:

title: Running your first local build with the CLI
body:
format_version: 11
default_step_lib_source: https://github.com/bitrise-io/bitrise-steplib.git

app:
 envs:
 - MY_NAME: My Name

workflows:
 test:
 steps:
 - script@1.1.3:
 inputs:
 - content: echo "Hello ${MY_NAME}!"

title: Running your first local build with the CLI
body: This defines an Environment Variable with your name and a Workflow called test. To run this build:

title: Running your first local build with the CLI
body: Open the Terminal or some other CLI app.

title: Running your first local build with the CLI
body: Go to the directory where you saved the bitrise.yml file.

title: Running your first local build with the CLI
body: Run bitrise run with the name of the Workflow you defined in the file.

title: Running your first local build with the CLI
body: bitrise run test

title: Running your first local build with the CLI
body: That’s it: your first build is running with the Bitrise CLI.

title: Managing Secrets locally
body: When you run a build locally, with the Bitrise CLI, the Secrets are read from a .bitrise.secrets.yml file, which is expected to be in the same directory where the bitrise.yml is, and where you run the bitrise run command.

title: Managing Secrets locally
body: When you run a build locally, with the Bitrise CLI, the Secrets are read from a .bitrise.secrets.yml file, which is expected to be in the same directory where the bitrise.yml is, and where you run the bitrise run command.

title: Managing Secrets locally
body: If you want to store your Secrets somewhere else, you can specify the location of the Secrets file with the --inventory flag of the bitrise run command. For example: .

title: Managing Secrets locally
body: bitrise run my-workflow --inventory /path/to/secrets.yml

title: Managing Secrets locally
body: Make sure to gitignore your Secrets file

title: Managing Secrets locally
body: As a best practice, you should always make sure that the .bitrise.secrets.yml is added to your .gitignore, so that it will never be committed into your repository! The best is if you gitignore everything that starts with .bitrise, which can be done by adding the line: .bitrise* to your .gitignore file.

title: Managing Secrets locally
body: The Secrets YAML file has to include a root envs: item and then the list of Secret Environment Variables.

title: Managing Secrets locally
body:
envs:
- SECRET_ENV_ONE: first Secret value
- SECRET_ENV_TWO: second Secret value

title: Managing Secrets locally
body: The Secrets defined in the .bitrise.secrets.yml file can be used just like any other Environment Variable.

title: Managing Secrets locally
body:
format_version: 11
default_step_lib_source: https://github.com/bitrise-io/bitrise-steplib.git

workflows:
 test:
 steps:
 - script@1.1.3:
 inputs:
 - content: |
 #!/bin/bash
 echo "SECRET_ENV_ONE: ${SECRET_ENV_ONE}"
 echo "SECRET_ENV_TWO: ${SECRET_ENV_TWO}"

title: Managing Secrets locally
body: You can just bitrise run test in the directory, and the Script Step will print the values specified in the secrets file:

title: Managing Secrets locally
body:
SECRET_ENV_ONE: first secret value
SECRET_ENV_TWO: second secret value

title: Managing Secrets locally
body: As Secrets are the first Environment Variables processed when you execute a bitrise run command, you can use the Secrets everywhere in your bitrise.yml.

title: API
body: The Bitrise API allows you to build deep, custom integrations with your preferred tools and processes to create even more efficient development pipelines.

title: API
body: The Bitrise API allows you to build deep, custom integrations with your preferred tools and processes to create even more efficient development pipelines.

title: API
body: The API provides you with control of - and access to - the features and data available through the Bitrise website and CLI. By using the API, you gain the ability to fully customize Bitrise’s functionality to fit your process.

title: API
body: The API is work-in-progress

title: API
body: The API is work-in-progress: we will add new endpoints and possibly update the existing ones in the future.

title: API
body: You can track the progress of the API: join the discussion! Follow it and get notified about new endpoints and changes, we announce those there.

title: API
body: Feel free to contribute! If you want to request a new API feature or a new endpoint, you can do so!

title: API
body: The Bitrise API’s host is: https://api.bitrise.io/

title: API
body: Every endpoint except the root one is versioned. The version has to be included in the URL right after the host: for example, https://api.bitrise.io/v0.1/me is the endpoint for your own user account.

title: API
body: Right now we have only one version, v0.1.

title: API
body: There’s no long term compatibility promise for v0.1, although we try to do our best to not to break anything unless we have to. Once we’re happy with v0.1 we’ll “freeze” it as v1.0, for which we’ll provide long term support.

title: Authenticating with the Bitrise API
body: You need to create a personal access token to authenticate with the Bitrise API. The token is needed for all endpoints.

title: Authenticating with the Bitrise API
body: The current API supports only one type of authentication: user generated personal access tokens. Workspaces do not have their own access tokens.

title: Authenticating with the Bitrise API
body: Every API endpoint requires authentication, except the “root” URL (https://api.bitrise.io).

title: Authenticating with the Bitrise API
body: Create a personal access token.

title: Authenticating with the Bitrise API
body: Save it in a secure way.

title: Authenticating with the Bitrise API
body: Add an Authorization header with the access token to your API calls.

title: Authenticating with the Bitrise API
body: curl -H 'Authorization: THE-ACCESS-TOKEN' https://api.bitrise.io/v0.1/me

title: Pagination of API calls
body: With the Bitrise API, you can use pagination to iterate through list of items in the responses of certain endpoints. You can configure the properties of pagination.

title: Pagination of API calls
body: When you call an endpoint that returns a list of items, you might not get the whole list in a single response. You’ll have to iterate through the pages to retrieve all the items.

title: Pagination of API calls
body: The response of such endpoints include a paging object, with total_item_count and page_item_limit properties. If there is a “next” page available, it’ll also include a next “anchor” item. For example, the response will show the app slug of the first app on the next page.

title: Pagination of API calls
Pagination of API calls
body: The next property of the paging object

title: Pagination of API calls
body: The next property of the paging object is only included if there’s at least one more page available. If there’s no next property inside paging that means that there’s no more page to retrieve.

title: Pagination of API calls
body: Limit the number of response pages with the limit parameter:

title: Pagination of API calls
body: https://api.bitrise.io/v0.1/me/apps?limit=10

title: Pagination of API calls
body: This call sets the page_item_limit property to 10. The default (and maximum) value of the parameter is 50.

title: Pagination of API calls
body: Iterate through response items:

title: Pagination of API calls
body: Call the endpoint without any pagination parameters.

title: Pagination of API calls
body: From the response process the paging object.

title: Pagination of API calls
body: If the paging object includes a next item, call the exact same endpoint with an additional next= query parameter, and pass the value you got in the response as the value of the next parameter.

title: Pagination of API calls
body: Iterating through all your registered apps

title: Pagination of API calls
body: Call https://api.bitrise.io/v0.1/me/apps.

title: Pagination of API calls
body: Process the items (data property).

title: Pagination of API calls
body: Check the paging (root) property.

title: Pagination of API calls
body: If there’s a next property inside paging, call the endpoint again, with the next query parameter

title: Pagination of API calls
body: Example: https://api.bitrise.io/v0.1/me/apps?next=NEXTVALUE, where NEXTVALUE is the value of the next property you got in your previous response.

title: Pagination of API calls
body: Repeat this until the paging object does not include a next property, which means that the page you received was the last one.

title: Adding and managing apps
body: You can add new apps on Bitrise with the API: add the app, generate SSH keys, and set up the app’s initial configuration.

title: Adding and managing apps
body: You can add new apps on Bitrise with the API: add the app, generate SSH keys, and set up the app’s initial configuration.

title: Adding and managing apps
body: In addition, you can list all apps belonging, for example, to a single user or to a specific Workspace.

title: Adding a new app with the API
body: Endpoints used in adding a new app with the Bitrise API

title: Adding a new app with the API
body: Apps with HTTPS Git URLs

title: Adding a new app with the API
body: The procedure and the examples are aimed at adding a private app with an SSH git URL. If you want to add an app with an HTTPS git URL, you can skip adding an SSH key.

title: Adding a new app with the API
body: Register the app by calling the register endpoint and setting all required parameters.

title: Adding a new app with the API
body: You need to set your git provider, the repository URL, the slug of the repository as it appears at the provider, and the slug of the owner of the repository. You also need to add the slug of the Workspace that will own the app: due to legacy naming conventions, you need the organization_slug parameter.

title: Adding a new app with the API
body:
curl -X POST -H 'Authorization: ACCESS-TOKEN' 'https://api.bitrise.io/v0.1/apps/register' -d \
'{
 "provider": "github",
 "is_public": false,
 "organization_slug": "$ORG_SLUG"
 "repo_url": "git@github.com:api_demo/example-repository.git",
 "type": "git",
 "git_repo_slug": "example-repository",
 "git_owner": "api_demo"
 }'

title: Adding a new app with the API
body: Changing the name of your app

title: Adding a new app with the API
body: By default, when you register an app, it will inherit the name of your git repository.

title: Adding a new app with the API
body: If you would like to add the app with a different name, you can append the "title" parameter to your POST request using the following syntax:

title: Adding a new app with the API
Adding a new app with the API
body: You can also change the name of your app after creating it, by sending a PATCH request and calling the apps endpoint. For more information, see Managing an existing app.

title: Adding a new app with the API
body: Once done, call the register-ssh-key endpoint to set up the SSH keys you created so that Bitrise can clone your repository when running a build.

title: Adding a new app with the API
body: You need to provide both your private and public SSH key. Please note that if you wish to copy the private key manually, you need to escape all the line breaks with \n.

title: Adding a new app with the API
body: You can also set whether you want to automatically register the public key at your git provider: set the is_register_key_into_provider_service parameter to either true or false.

title: Adding a new app with the API
Adding a new app with the API
body: Finish the app registration process by calling the finish endpoint.

title: Adding a new app with the API
body: This endpoint allows you to configure your apps: set the project type, the stack on which the build will run (this may vary based on your app), and the initial configuration settings.

title: Adding a new app with the API
body: You can also set Environment Variables, as well as immediately specify a Workspace that will be the owner of the application. Please note that the mode parameter must be set to the value of manual.

title: Adding a new app with the API
Managing an existing app
body: Endpoints related to managing an existing app with the Bitrise API

title: Managing an existing app
body: The response to any GET request regarding one or more apps will contain the app slug, its project type, the git provider, the repository’s owner and URL:

title: Managing an existing app
body:
{
 "data": [
 {
 "slug": "eeeeefffff00000",
 "title": "sample-app",
 "project_type": "android",
 "provider": "github",
 "repo_owner": "example-user",
 "repo_url": "git@github.com:example-user/sample-app.git",
 "repo_slug": "android-gradle-kotlin-dsl",
 "is_disabled": false,
 "status": -1,
 "is_public": false,
 "owner": {
 "account_type": "organization",
 "name": "Test Org",
 "slug": "fffffeeeee00000"
 },
 "avatar_url": null
 },
 {

title: Managing an existing app
body: You can also download the existing bitrise.yml file of any app: the response will contain the full YAML configuration.

title: Managing an existing app
body: Would you like to change the title or the default git branch of an existing app? You can update an existing app's parameters by calling the PATCH method of the apps endpoint.

title: Managing an existing app
body: Required role

title: Managing an existing app
body: You must have an admin or owner role on the app's team to update an existing app's parameters using the Bitrise API.

title: Managing an existing app
body: For a complete list of user roles and role cheatsheets, check User roles on app teams.

title: Managing an existing app
body: The required parameter is:

title: Managing an existing app
body: slug

title: Managing an existing app
body: The optional parameters are:

title: Managing an existing app
body: apple_credential_user_id: The new apple credential user ID (recommendation: use the UI to set this)

title: Managing an existing app
body: apple_credential_user_slug: The new apple credential user slug (recommendation: use the UI to set this)

title: Managing an existing app
body: default_branch: The new default branch for the application.

title: Managing an existing app
body: is_public: The new the value if the application should be publicly visible.

title: Managing an existing app
body: repository_url: The new repository URL for the application.

title: Managing an existing app
body: services_credential_user_id: The new service credential user ID (recommendation: use the UI to set this).

title: Managing an existing app
body: title: The new title of the application.

title: Managing an existing app
body: Changing the name and the default branch of an existing app

title: Managing an existing app
body: Request:

title: Managing an existing app
body: curl -X 'PATCH' 'https://api.bitrise.io/v0.1/apps/THE-APP-SLUG' -H 'accept: application/json' -H 'Authorization: ACCESS-TOKEN' -H 'Content-Type: application/json' -d '{"default_branch": "main", "title": "Example_app_title_3"}'

title: Managing app access roles for Workspace groups
body: You can grant Workspace groups access to application teams on Bitrise. It means that all members of the group will be able to work on the app in the role assigned to the group.

title: Managing app access roles for Workspace groups
body: List all groups that have been granted a given role on an app's team by using the GET /apps/{app-slug}/roles/{role-name} endpoint. The role-name parameter takes three possible values:

title: Managing app access roles for Workspace groups
body: admin

title: Managing app access roles for Workspace groups
body: manager: this is the equivalent of the Developer role on bitrise.io.

title: Managing app access roles for Workspace groups
body: member: this is the equivalent of Tester/QA on bitrise.io.

title: Managing app access roles for Workspace groups
body: In this example, we're querying a list of Workspace groups that have been granted Admin role to a specific app:

title: Managing app access roles for Workspace groups
body:
curl -X 'GET' \
 'https://api.bitrise.io/v0.1/apps/APP-SLUG/roles/admin' \
 -H 'accept: application/json' \
 -H 'Authorization: ACCESS-TOKEN'

title: Managing app access roles for Workspace groups
body: Grant access to existing Workspace groups by using the PUT /apps/{app-slug}/roles/{role-name} endpoint. This endpoint requires a groups object that contains the slugs of all the groups that are granted access with the specified role.

title: Managing app access roles for Workspace groups
body: Specify all groups

title: Managing app access roles for Workspace groups
body: This endpoint replaces all previous groups that had the specified role on the app's team. If, for example, you call the endpoint to grant the groups Alpha and Beta the Admin role on the app's team, only Alpha and Beta will have Admin access to the app afterwards. If another group - let's call it Delta - previously had Admin role on the team, it will be removed.

title: Managing app access roles for Workspace groups
body: Getting the group slugs

title: Managing app access roles for Workspace groups
body: To get the group slugs of your Workspace, use the GET /organizations/{org-slug}/groups endpoint.

title: Managing app access roles for Workspace groups
body: In the following example, we'll be granting several groups Admin access:

title: Managing app access roles for Workspace groups
Deleting an app using the API
body: Deletion is final

title: Deleting an app using the API
body: Be aware that you cannot undo deleting an app. Once you delete it, there is no way to recover the app.

title: Deleting an app using the API
body: You can delete apps with the Bitrise API. The only required parameter is the app slug of the app you want to delete:

title: Deleting an app using the API
body: curl -X DELETE -H 'Authorization: ACCESS-TOKEN' 'https://api.bitrise.io/v0.1/apps/THE-APP-SLUG'

title: Uploading a new bitrise.yml file
body: Required role

title: Uploading a new bitrise.yml file
body: You must have an admin or owner role on the app's team to upload a new bitrise.yml file.

title: Uploading a new bitrise.yml file
body: For a complete list of user roles and role cheatsheets, check User roles on app teams.

title: Uploading a new bitrise.yml file
body: The bitrise.yml file contains the configuration of your builds. You can modify the current one via the API by posting a full YAML configuration. In the below example, we are:

title: Uploading a new bitrise.yml file
body: Creating a bitrise.yml with format version 11.

title: Uploading a new bitrise.yml file
body: Setting the Bitrise Step Library as the default Step source.

title: Uploading a new bitrise.yml file
body: Setting the stack to Xcode 14.

title: Uploading a new bitrise.yml file
body: Setting the BITRISE_PROJECT_PATH Environment Variable to point to the build.gradle file.

title: Uploading a new bitrise.yml file
body: Adding a Script Step.

title: Uploading a new bitrise.yml file
body: Creating a trigger map that triggers the primary Workflow if code is pushed to any branch of the app's repository.

title: Uploading a new bitrise.yml file
Uploading a new bitrise.yml file
body: By calling this endpoint, you replace the app’s current bitrise.yml file. You can, of course, modify this uploaded bitrise.yml either via the API or on the website itself.

title: Changing the location of the app's bitrise.yml file
body: The app's bitrise.yml configuration file can be stored in two places:

title: Changing the location of the app's bitrise.yml file
body: On bitrise.io. This is the default setting for all apps.

title: Changing the location of the app's bitrise.yml file
body: In your app's repository. This way you have full control over the versioning and maintenance of the config file. You can still use the graphical Workflow Editor on bitrise.io to modify your configuration but you will need to commit your changes to the repository.

title: Changing the location of the app's bitrise.yml file
body: You can get and change the location of the file using the API.

title: Changing the location of the app's bitrise.yml file
body: Admin access required

title: Changing the location of the app's bitrise.yml file
body: Both endpoints related to the location of the bitrise.yml file require admin level access to the app.

title: Changing the location of the app's bitrise.yml file
body: With the GET/apps/{app-slug}/bitrise.yml/config endpoint, you can get the location of the file. Location here means that calling the endpoint tells you whether the file is stored on bitrise.io or in the repository. The endpoint takes no parameters and it returns one of two values in the response:

title: Changing the location of the app's bitrise.yml file
body: "location": "bitrise.io"

title: Changing the location of the app's bitrise.yml file
body: "location": "repository"

title: Changing the location of the app's bitrise.yml file
body:
curl -X 'GET' \
 'https://api.bitrise.io/v0.1/apps/APP-SLUG/bitrise.yml/config' \
 -H 'accept: application/json' \
 -H 'Authorization: ACCESS-TOKEN'

title: Changing the location of the app's bitrise.yml file
body: With the PUT/apps/{app-slug}/bitrise.yml/config endpoint, you can change the location of the file: that is, you can tell Bitrise whether to look for the config file on bitrise.io or in your repository. This endpoint takes one of two values in a JSON object:

title: Changing the location of the app's bitrise.yml file
body: "location": "bitrise.io" to store the config file on bitrise.io.

title: Changing the location of the app's bitrise.yml file
body: "location": "repository" to store the config file in your repository.

title: Changing the location of the app's bitrise.yml file
body: Commit the config file into your repository

title: Changing the location of the app's bitrise.yml file
body: Please note that changing the location to repository merely tells Bitrise to look for the bitrise.yml file in the app's repository. If the file does not exist in the repository, the endpoint won't return an error but you won't be able to run builds because Bitrise won't find the config file.

title: Changing the location of the app's bitrise.yml file
body:
curl -X 'PUT' \
 'https://api.bitrise.io/v0.1/apps/APP-SLUG/bitrise.yml/config' \
 -H 'accept: application/json' \
 -H 'Authorization: ACCESS-TOKEN' \
 -H 'Content-Type: application/json' \
 -d '{
 "location": "bitrise.io"
}'

title: Managing app notifications
body: You can change the email notification settings of your apps via an API call at any time with the PATCH/apps/{app-slug}/update-email-notifications endpoint. The endpoint takes two parameters:

title: Managing app notifications
body: on_failure: Email notification settings for failed builds.

title: Managing app notifications
body: on_success: Email notification settings for successful builds.

title: Managing app notifications
body: Both parameters take three possible values:

title: Managing app notifications
body: always: Always send notification. The default value for failed builds.

title: Managing app notifications
body: never : Never send notification.

title: Managing app notifications
body: change: Send notification only when the build status changes compared to the previous build on the same branch. The default value for successful builds.

title: Managing app notifications
body: For example, if you wish to receive a notification for a failed build only when the previous build was successful, you need to set the value of the on_failure parameter to change (replace the APP-SLUG in the example with your app's slug and ACCESS-TOKEN with your personal access token):

title: Managing app notifications
body:
curl -X 'PATCH' \
 'https://api.bitrise.io/v0.1/apps/APP-SLUG/update-email-notifications' \
 -H 'accept: application/json' \
 -H 'Authorization: ACCESS-TOKEN' \
 -H 'Content-Type: application/json' \
 -d '{
 "on_failure": "change",
}'

title: Triggering and aborting builds
body: You can use the Bitrise API to trigger and abort builds of your apps. Define parameters for the build: for example, branch, tag or git commit to use. Custom Environment Variables can be defined as well.

title: Triggering and aborting builds
body: Endpoints related to triggering and aborting builds with the API

title: Triggering and aborting builds
body: You can trigger and abort builds with the Bitrise API. Define parameters for the build: for example, branch, tag or git commit to use. Custom Environment Variables can be defined as well.

title: Triggering a new build with the API
body: To trigger a new build with the Bitrise API, call the /apps/{APP-SLUG}/builds endpoint. You need to specify an app slug and at least one build parameter in a JSON object:

title: Triggering a new build with the API
body: A git tag or git commit hash

title: Triggering a new build with the API
body: A branch

title: Triggering a new build with the API
body: A Workflow ID

title: Triggering a new build with the API
body: Required role

title: Triggering a new build with the API
body: You must have a developer, admin, or owner role on the app's team to trigger a new build using the API.

title: Triggering a new build with the API
body: For a complete list of user roles and role cheatsheets, check User roles on app teams.

title: Triggering a new build with the API
body: The JSON object must also contain a hook_info object with a type key and bitrise as the value of the key.

title: Triggering a new build with the API
body: Here’s a minimal sample JSON body which specifies main as the value of the branch parameter:

title: Triggering a new build with the API
Triggering a new build with the API
body: And here’s the curl request syntax for triggering a build on the main branch:

title: Triggering a new build with the API
Triggering a new build with the API
body: Interactive cURL call configurator

title: Triggering a new build with the API
body: You can find an interactive cURL call configurator by clicking on the Start/Schedule a build button on your app’s bitrise.io page and switching to Advanced mode in the popup. At the bottom of the popup you can find a curl call, based on the parameters you specify in the popup.

title: Triggering a new build with the API
body: In the previous example, we passed this JSON payload as a string: to be precise, as a JSON object serialized to a string.

title: Triggering a new build with the API
body: You can also pass it as an object (for example, if you want to call it from JavaScript). To do so, include a root payload element or, alternatively, set the JSON object as the value of the payload POST parameter.

title: Triggering a new build with the API
body: Here’s a jQuery example using the payload parameter:

title: Triggering a new build with the API
Triggering a new build with the API
body: You can specify several different build parameters when triggering a build. The parameters should be set in the build_params object.

title: Setting a branch, commit or tag to build
body: You can set Git-specific parameters in your call. The branch parameter specifies the source branch to be built. This is either the branch of the git commit or, in the case of a pull request build, the source branch of the pull request.

title: Setting a branch, commit or tag to build
Setting a branch, commit or tag to build
body: You can also build a specific git commit or even a git tag: you just need to set either the commit hash or the tag in the build_params object. You can also set a commit message for the build with the commit_message parameter.

title: Setting a branch, commit or tag to build
Setting a branch, commit or tag to build
body: Parameter priority

title: Setting a branch, commit or tag to build
body: The Git Clone Step has the following parameter priority:

title: Setting a branch, commit or tag to build
body: commit_hash

title: Setting a branch, commit or tag to build
body: tag

title: Setting a branch, commit or tag to build
body: branch

title: Setting a branch, commit or tag to build
body: If you provide multiple parameters, the parameter with lower priority will be ignored.

title: Setting a branch, commit or tag to build
body: The ignored parameters will still be logged. They will be available for Steps and they will be visible on the Build’s Details & Add-ons page but the Git Clone Step will use the most specific parameter for checkout.

title: Setting parameters for pull request builds
body: For a pull request build, use the branch_dest parameter to set up the destination or target branch of the pull request. The PR will be merged into this branch but before that, Bitrise will build your app based on how the code would look like after merging. This is what happens when a PR build is automatically triggered by a webhook, for example.

title: Setting parameters for pull request builds
body: The branch_repo_owner and branch_dest_repo_owner parameters are used to identify the owners of the repositories, to unambiguously identify the branches involved in the pull request.

title: Setting parameters for pull request builds
body: Pull request builds from forks

title: Setting parameters for pull request builds
body: If you do not specify the branch_repo_owner and branch_dest_repo_owner parameters, the API will assume pull request builds are coming from a fork. As such, they might be put on hold pending manual approval: Approving pull request builds.

title: Setting parameters for pull request builds
body: To identify the PR itself, use the pull_request_id parameter: it takes an integer; for example, the number of the PR on GitHub.

title: Setting parameters for pull request builds
Setting parameters for pull request builds
body: If your git provider supports it, you can also use the pull_request_merge_branch parameter to build the pre-merged state of the branch of the PR. Another alternative is the pull_request_head_branch parameter: this is a special git ref that should point to the source of the PR.

title: Setting parameters for pull request builds
body: If you want to trigger a build from a PR opened from a fork of your repository, use the pull_request_repository_url parameter. The value should be the URL of the fork.

title: Skipping Git status reports
body: If you have a webhook set up, Bitrise will send status reports to your git provider about your builds. However, this can be disabled via the API: use the skip_git_status_report parameter. If it is set to true, no build status report will be sent.

title: Skipping Git status reports
Specifying Environment Variables
body: You can define additional Environment Variables (Env Vars) for your build. These additional variables will be handled with priority between Secrets and App Env Vars, which means that you can not overwrite Env Vars defined in your build configuration (for example, App Env Vars), only Secrets.

title: Specifying Environment Variables
body: Define additional Env Vars with the environments parameter. This parameter must be an array of objects, and every item of the array must include at least a mapped_to property. This must contain:

title: Specifying Environment Variables
body: The key of the Env Var.

title: Specifying Environment Variables
body: The value of the Env Var.

title: Specifying Environment Variables
body: Replacing Env Var names

title: Specifying Environment Variables
body: By default, Env Var names inside values will be replaced in triggered build by actual value from the target environment. This behavior can be disabled by setting the is_expand flag to false.

title: Specifying Environment Variables
body:
"environments":[
 {"mapped_to":"API_TEST_ENV","value":"This is the test value","is_expand":true},
 {"mapped_to":"HELP_ENV","value":"$HOME variable contains user's home directory path","is_expand":false},
]

title: Setting a Workflow for the build
body: By default, the Workflow for a triggered build will be selected based on the content of build_params and your app’s trigger map. This is the same as how webhooks select the Workflow for the build automatically, based on the Trigger Map.

title: Setting a Workflow for the build
body: With the API, you can overwrite this selection and specify exactly which Workflow you want to use.

title: Setting a Workflow for the build
body: Add a workflow_id parameter to your build_params and specify the workflow you want to use for that specific build. Here’s an example call where we specify the deploy workflow:

title: Setting a Workflow for the build
Aborting a build
body: You can abort running builds, and set the reason for aborting, as well as specify if email notifications should be sent about the build.

title: Aborting a build
body: Required role

title: Aborting a build
body: You must have an admin or owner role on the app's team to manage incoming or outgoing webhooks using the API.

title: Aborting a build
body: For a complete list of user roles and role cheatsheets, check User roles on app teams.

title: Aborting a build
body: To simply abort the build, call the /apps/APP-SLUG/builds/BUILD-SLUG/abort endpoint. It requires three parameters:

title: Aborting a build
body: The app slug.

title: Aborting a build
body: The build slug.

title: Aborting a build
body: The build abort parameters body. This can be left empty if you don't want to set any specific parameters for the abort: -d "{}".

title: Aborting a build
body: curl -X POST -H "Authorization: ACCESS-TOKEN" "https://api.bitrise.io/v0.1/apps/APP-SLUG/builds/BUILD-SLUG/abort" -d "{}"

title: Aborting a build
body: You can set a reason for aborting the build by using the abort_reason parameter. This parameter takes a string and it will show up on your app’s build page.

title: Aborting a build
body: curl -X POST -H "Authorization: ACCESS-TOKEN" "https://api.bitrise.io/v0.1/apps/APP-SLUG/builds/BUILD-SLUG/abort" -d '{"abort_reason": "aborted for a reason"}'

title: Aborting a build
body: Normally, aborted builds count as failed builds. Use the abort_with_success parameter to abort a build but still count it as a successful one. The status report sent to your git provider will show the build as successful though on bitrise.io it will be displayed as Cancelled.

title: Aborting a build
body: curl -X POST -H "Authorization: ACCESS-TOKEN" "https://api.bitrise.io/v0.1/apps/APP-SLUG/builds/BUILD-SLUG/abort" -d '{"abort_with_success": true}'

title: Aborting a build
body: Depending on your app settings, Bitrise might send email notifications to team members when a build is aborted. If you do not want notifications, set the skip_notifications parameter to true.

title: Aborting a build
body: curl -X POST -H "Authorization: ACCESS-TOKEN" "https://api.bitrise.io/v0.1/apps/APP-SLUG/builds/BUILD-SLUG/abort" -d '{"skip_notifications": true}'

title: Managing an app's builds
body: You can use the Bitrise API to list an app's build, get all information about a specific build, view the build logs, and view archived builds that are older than 200 days.

title: Managing an app's builds
body: You can use the Bitrise API to list an app's build, get all information about a specific build, view the build logs, and view archived builds that are older than 200 days.

title: Managing an app's builds
body: Endpoints used in managing an app's builds

title: Viewing the build data of an app
body: You can access all relevant build information with the help of the API.

title: Viewing the build data of an app
body: You can get all builds of an app with the GET /apps/{app-slug}/builds endpoint. You can set additional parameters, such as the Workflow that was used for the build, to act as filters. Set parameters in the following format:

title: Viewing the build data of an app
body: GET /apps/{app-slug}/builds?parameter_name=parameter_value&other_parameter_name=other_parameter_value

title: Viewing the build data of an app
body: The full list of parameters can be found in the API reference documentation.

title: Viewing the build data of an app
body: Build retention for 200 days

title: Viewing the build data of an app
body: On the Builds page of your app, we only show builds from the last 200 days. The same limit applies if you are searching for specific builds on the page. This limitation also applies to most API calls: the GET/apps/{app-slug}/builds endpoint and related endpoints can only return builds from the last 200 days.

title: Viewing the build data of an app
body: However, there are two methods to get a build that is older than 200 days:

title: Viewing the build data of an app
body: If you know the exact build URL, you can access the build.

title: Viewing the build data of an app
body: You can use the GET/apps/{app-slug}/archived-builds API endpoint: Listing the archived builds of an app.

title: Viewing the build data of an app
body: Listing builds that built the development branch with the primary Workflow

title: Viewing the build data of an app
body: Request:

title: Viewing the build data of an app
body: curl -X GET 'https://api.bitrise.io/v0.1/apps/$APP-SLUG/builds?branch=development&workflow=primary' -H 'accept: application/json' -H 'Authorization: $ACCESS_TOKEN'

title: Viewing the build data of an app
body: To get the same data for a specific build, call GET /apps/{app-slug}/builds/{build-slug}. You can also view the bitrise.yml file of the build by adding /bitrise.yml to the end of the URL.

title: Viewing the build data of an app
body: Listing failed builds using the status integer

title: Viewing the build data of an app
body: You can use the status integer to filter your builds based on build statuses. The status integers are:

title: Viewing the build data of an app
body: 0 - Not finished (these are builds that are either starting, running, or on hold)

title: Viewing the build data of an app
body: 1 - Successful

title: Viewing the build data of an app
body: 2 - Failed

title: Viewing the build data of an app
body: 3 - Aborted with failure

title: Viewing the build data of an app
body: 4 - Aborted with success

title: Viewing the build data of an app
body: Request:

title: Viewing the build data of an app
body: curl -X GET 'https://api.bitrise.io/v0.1/apps/$APP-SLUG/builds?branch=development&status=2' -H 'accept: application/json' -H 'Authorization: $ACCESS_TOKEN'

title: Viewing the build data of an app
body: You can try any of these endpoints in the API reference documentation.

title: Listing the archived builds of an app
body: By default, you can only view builds that aren't older than 200 days. This is true for most API endpoints, too. However, you can also view older, archived builds by calling the GET /apps/{app-slug}/archived-builds endpoint.

title: Listing the archived builds of an app
body: The endpoint has two required parameters:

title: Listing the archived builds of an app
body: after

title: Listing the archived builds of an app
body: before

title: Listing the archived builds of an app
body: Both parameters are dates represented using Unix timestamps and both are required! In other words, you have to specify the exact time period in which you want to see your archived builds.

title: Listing the archived builds of an app
body: Listing all archived builds between 2021-01-01 and 2022-01-01

title: Listing the archived builds of an app
body:
curl -X 'GET' \
 'https://api.bitrise.io/v0.1/apps/APP-SLUG/archived-builds?after=1609459200&before=1640995200' \
 -H 'accept: application/json' \
 -H 'Authorization: THE_ACCESS_TOKEN'

title: Incoming and outgoing webhooks
body: Both incoming and outgoing webhooks can be set up with the Bitrise API. They are important for automatic build triggering and the reporting of build events to other services.

title: Incoming and outgoing webhooks
body: Both incoming and outgoing webhooks can be set up with the Bitrise API. They are important for automatic build triggering and the reporting of build events to other services.

title: Incoming and outgoing webhooks
body: Endpoints related to incoming and outgoing webhooks

title: Registering an incoming webhook with the API
body: Incoming webhooks enable users to set up automatic triggers for their apps on Bitrise: for example, a Bitrise webhook registered on GitHub can automatically trigger a build when code is pushed to the GitHub repository.

title: Registering an incoming webhook with the API
body: Required role

title: Registering an incoming webhook with the API
body: You must have an admin or owner role on the app's team to manage incoming or outgoing webhooks using the API.

title: Registering an incoming webhook with the API
body: For a complete list of user roles and role cheatsheets, check User roles on app teams.

title: Registering an incoming webhook with the API
body: To set up a webhook, you must connect your Bitrise account to your Git provider account: this allows Bitrise to register the webhook automatically.

title: Registering an incoming webhook with the API
body: Register a webhook by calling the register-webhook endpoint with an existing app slug:

title: Registering an incoming webhook with the API
body: curl -X POST -H 'Authorization: ACCESS-TOKEN' 'https://api.bitrise.io/v0.1/apps/APP-SLUG/register-webhook'

title: Registering an incoming webhook with the API
body: This will register a webhook to the Git provider of the app. Afterwards, you can set up automatic triggers either on the website or via the Trigger Map in the app’s bitrise.yml file.

title: Creating outgoing webhooks with the API
body: Outgoing webhooks enable integration with other services: specifically, they are used to notify other services. Currently, only build event notifications are supported. There are two supported build events: triggering a build and finishing a build.

title: Creating outgoing webhooks with the API
body: Build status reports

title: Creating outgoing webhooks with the API
body: Notifying your Git provider about the build status does not require outgoing webhooks.

title: Creating outgoing webhooks with the API
body: To set up an outgoing webhook for an application, you need to specify the app itself and at least two of the creation parameters:

title: Creating outgoing webhooks with the API
body: The webhook URL: you can get this from the service you want to integrate with Bitrise.

title: Creating outgoing webhooks with the API
body: The events that trigger the webhook. Currently, this takes two possible values: all and build.

title: Creating outgoing webhooks with the API
body: Required role

title: Creating outgoing webhooks with the API
body: You must have an admin or owner role on the app's team to manage incoming or outgoing webhooks using the API.

title: Creating outgoing webhooks with the API
body: For a complete list of user roles and role cheatsheets, check User roles on app teams.

title: Creating outgoing webhooks with the API
body: You can also set up custom headers by specifying a key/value pair in the request.

title: Creating outgoing webhooks with the API
body: A new outgoing webhook with the URL 'example.webhook.com'

title: Creating outgoing webhooks with the API
body: Request:

title: Creating outgoing webhooks with the API
body: curl -X POST "https://api.bitrise.io/v0.1/apps/APP-SLUG/outgoing-webhooks" -H "accept: application/json" -H "Authorization: ACCESS-TOKEN" -H "Content-Type: application/json" -d "{ \"events\": [ \"build\" ], \"url\": \"example.webhook.com\", \"headers\": { \"KEY\": \"value\" }}"

Modifying and deleting outgoing webhooks with the API
body: To modify an existing webhook, you need to specify all the mandatory parameters in your request. In other words, even if you only want to change the URL, the request still has to contain a valid value for the events parameter.

title: Managing iOS code signing files
body: You can upload, update, list, and delete iOS code signing files with the Bitrise API: we have separate endpoints for certificates and provisioning profiles.

title: Managing iOS code signing files
body: This guide describes how to manage your iOS code signing files with the Bitrise API. If you’d like to learn more about how to do the same on the UI, please check out iOS code signing

title: Managing iOS code signing files
body: You can upload, update, list, and delete iOS code signing files with the API. In this guide we show you how and in what order to use those code signing endpoints.

title: Managing iOS code signing files
body: Endpoints related to iOS provisioning profiles

title: Managing iOS code signing files
body: Endpoints related to iOS code signing certificates

title: Creating and uploading an iOS code signing file
body: Required role

title: Creating and uploading an iOS code signing file
body: You must have an admin or owner role on the app's team to manage iOS code signing files using the Bitrise API.

title: Creating and uploading an iOS code signing file
body: For a complete list of user roles and role cheatsheets, check User roles on app teams.

title: Creating and uploading an iOS code signing file
body: You can add a new iOS code signing file to a Bitrise app of your choice. You'll need to:

title: Creating and uploading an iOS code signing file
body: Call the POST method of the provisioning-profiles or build-certificates endpoint with the upload_file_name and upload_file_size parameters.

title: Creating and uploading an iOS code signing file
body: The upload_file_name parameter should specify the path to an existing provisioning profile. This call creates a temporary pre-signed upload URL.

title: Creating and uploading an iOS code signing file
body: Upload the file to AWS using the upload_url parameter from the response.

title: Creating and uploading an iOS code signing file
body: Confirm the file upload with a POST call of the uploaded endpoint.

title: Creating and uploading an iOS code signing file
body: This sets the processed flag of the file to true. This flag can't be changed again afterwards!

title: Creating and uploading an iOS code signing file
body: Creating and uploading a new provisioning profile

title: Creating and uploading an iOS code signing file
body: Creating the file:

title: Creating and uploading an iOS code signing file
body: curl -X POST -H 'Authorization: THE-ACCESS-TOKEN' 'https://api.bitrise.io/v0.1/apps/APP-SLUG/provisioning-profiles' -d '{"upload_file_name":"sample.provisionprofile","upload_file_size":2047}'

title: Creating and uploading an iOS code signing file
body: Response:

title: Creating and uploading an iOS code signing file
Creating and uploading an iOS code signing file
body: The file name, its size, slug, and a pre-signed upload URL are retrieved (along with some attributes that you can modify). This pre-signed upload URL is a temporary link which you will use to upload the iOS code signing file to its destination.

title: Creating and uploading an iOS code signing file
body: Uploading the file to AWS using the value of the upload_url parameter:

title: Creating and uploading an iOS code signing file
body: curl -T sample.provisionprofile 'https://concrete-userfiles-production.s3-us-west-2.amazonaws.com/build_certificates/uploads/30067/original/certs.p12?X-Amz-Algorithm=AWS4-HMAC-SHA256&X-Amz-Content-Sha256=UNSIGNED-PAYLOAD&X-Amz-Credential=AKIAIOC7N256G7J2W2TQ%2F20180216%2Fus-west-2%2Fs3%2Faws4_request&X-Amz-Date=20180216T124240Z&X-Amz-Expires=600&X-Amz-SignedHeaders=content-length%3Bhost&X-Amz-Signature=2bf42176650f00405abfd7b7757635c9be16b43e98013abb7f750d3c658be28e'

body: Confirming the upload:

title: Creating and uploading an iOS code signing file
body: curl -X POST -H 'Authorization: THE-ACCESS-TOKEN' 'https://api.bitrise.io/v0.1/apps/APP-SLUG/provisioning-profiles/PROVISIONING-PROFILE-SLUG/uploaded'

title: Updating an uploaded iOS code signing file
body: You can perform minor updates to an uploaded iOS code signing file using the PATCH method. If you’ve uploaded your file to Bitrise, you can visually check any changes to it on the Code Signing & Files tab.

title: Updating an uploaded iOS code signing file
body: Required role

title: Updating an uploaded iOS code signing file

body: For example, to make a provisioning profile protected, you can set the is_protected flag of your provisioning profiles to true.

title: Updating an uploaded iOS code signing file

title: Updating an uploaded iOS code signing file
body: For a build certificate you can set the same attributes as above but you can modify the password too:

title: Updating an uploaded iOS code signing file
body: curl -X PATCH -H 'Authorization: THE-ACCESS-TOKEN' 'https://api.bitrise.io/v0.1/apps/APP-SLUG/build-certificates/BUILD-CERTIFICATE-SLUG -d '{"certificate_password":"s0m3-v3ry-s3cr3t-str1ng"}'

body: You can set the is_protected, is_exposed and processed attributes of the files you've uploaded:

title: Updating an uploaded iOS code signing file
body: When the value of is_protected is true, then the is_expose flag cannot be set to another value.

title: Updating an uploaded iOS code signing file
body: Once the processed flag is set to true, then its value cannot be changed anymore.

title: Managing files in Generic File Storage
body: You can upload, delete, update, and list any project files to the Generic File Storage on Bitrise. You can access the files either via the API or in the Workflow Editor.

title: Managing files in Generic File Storage
body: You can upload, delete, update, and list any project files in the GENERIC FILE STORAGE section of Bitrise.

title: Managing files in Generic File Storage
body: Endpoints related to the Generic File Storage

title: Creating and uploading files to the Generic File Storage
body: Required role

title: Creating and uploading files to the Generic File Storage
body: You must have an admin or owner role role on the app's team to manage files in the Generic File Storage using the Bitrise API.

title: Creating and uploading files to the Generic File Storage
body: For a complete list of user roles and role cheatsheets, check User roles on app teams.

title: Creating and uploading files to the Generic File Storage
body: You can add new files to an application and store it in the GENERIC FILE STORAGE section of the Code Signing tab. When calling the relevant API endpoint, a new temporary pre-signed upload URL is created which you will use to upload the file to the GENERIC FILE STORAGE. (Please note that this pre-signed URL is time-limited and expires after 10 minutes.)

title: Creating and uploading files to the Generic File Storage
body: You'll need to:

title: Creating and uploading files to the Generic File Storage
body: Call the POST method of the generic-project-files endpoint.

title: Creating and uploading files to the Generic File Storage
body: This call creates a temporary pre-signed upload URL. The required parameters are:

title: Creating and uploading files to the Generic File Storage
body: slug: the app slug of the Bitrise app. You can get the slug by opening the app on Bitrise and copying it from the URL of the main page, or by calling the GET /apps endpoint and finding your app in the list.

title: Creating and uploading files to the Generic File Storage
body: upload_file_name: the name of the file, including the file extension. For example, MyFile.txt. The file should be in the same folder where the command is run.

title: Creating and uploading files to the Generic File Storage
body: upload_file_size: the size of the file in bytes. On macOS, you can get the file size by running the stat -f%z <filename> command.

title: Creating and uploading files to the Generic File Storage
body: user_env_key: you can add any name to the user env key.

title: Creating and uploading files to the Generic File Storage
body: Upload the file to AWS using the pre-signed upload URL.

title: Creating and uploading files to the Generic File Storage
body: Confirm the file upload.

title: Creating and uploading files to the Generic File Storage
body: This sets the processed flag to true which means the file is now available on Bitrise. This flag can't be changed again afterwards!

title: Creating and uploading files to the Generic File Storage

title: Managing build artifacts
body: You can list, retrieve, update, and delete any build artifacts with the Bitrise API.

title: Managing build artifacts
body: If you add the Deploy to bitrise.io Step to your Workflow, once the build has run, you can access the build artifacts in the build's Artifacts tab on bitrise.io.

title: Managing build artifacts
body: You can also manage the generated artifacts with the Bitrise API.

title: Managing build artifacts
body: Build retention for 200 days

title: Managing build artifacts
body: On the Builds page of your app, we only show builds from the last 200 days. The same limit applies if you are searching for specific builds on the page. This limitation also applies to most API calls: the GET/apps/{app-slug}/builds endpoint and related endpoints can only return builds from the last 200 days.

title: Managing build artifacts
body: However, there are two methods to get a build that is older than 200 days:

title: Managing build artifacts
body: If you know the exact build URL, you can access the build.

title: Managing build artifacts
body: You can use the GET/apps/{app-slug}/archived-builds API endpoint: Listing the archived builds of an app.

title: Managing build artifacts
body: Endpoints related to managing build artifacts with the API

title: Listing build artifacts
body: Required role

title: Listing build artifacts
body: You must have a tester/QA, developer, admin, or owner role on the app's team to list build artifacts using the API.

title: Listing build artifacts
body: For a complete list of user roles and role cheatsheets, check User roles on app teams.

title: Listing build artifacts
body: To be able to use build artifact endpoints, you have to first list all artifacts that belong to an app’s build. The response will list all artifacts along with their slug which you will need later.

title: Listing build artifacts
body: The required parameters are:

title: Listing build artifacts
body: app slug

title: Listing build artifacts

Creating or updating Secrets
body: Required role

title: Creating or updating Secrets
body: You must have an admin or owner role on the app's team to create/update Secrets using the Bitrise API.

title: Creating or updating Secrets
body: For a complete list of user roles and role cheatsheets, check User roles on app teams.

title: Creating or updating Secrets
body: You can create or update Secrets using the PUT method of the secrets endpoint.

title: Creating or updating Secrets
body: If a Secret does not exist with the secret-name you provide, a new Secret will be created. If the Secret already exists, it will be updated with the new values you provided.

title: Creating or updating Secrets
body: The required parameter are:

title: Creating or updating Secrets
body: app slug

title: Creating or updating Secrets
body: secret's name

title: Creating or updating Secrets
body: Optional parameters are:

title: Creating or updating Secrets
body: expand_in_step_inputs: Set to true if you want Bitrise CLI to expand Secret before passing it on to Steps.

title: Creating or updating Secrets
body: is_exposed_for_pull_requests: Set to true if you want Secret to be exposed for pull requests.

title: Creating or updating Secrets
body: is_protected: Set to true if you want your Secret's value to be protected. (You will not be able to view Secret's value using the GET method.)

title: Creating or updating Secrets
body: value: The value stored in the Secret.

title: Creating or updating Secrets
body: Creating a new Secret called "test"

title: Creating or updating Secrets
body: Request:

title: Creating or updating Secrets
body: curl -X PUT -H 'Authorization: THE-ACCESS-TOKEN' 'https://api.bitrise.io/v0.1/apps/THE-APP-SLUG/secrets/test' -d '{"expand_in_step_inputs": true, "is_exposed_for_pull_requests": true, "is_protected": false, "value": "123ld2"}'

title: API reference
