title: References
body: References help you understand and create both basic and advanced Bitrise configurations not just on the graphical UI but in YAML mode, too.

title: References
body: This section is a reference for Bitrise configuration: the goal is to help you understand and create both basic and advanced configurations not just on the graphical UI but in YAML mode, too.

title: Basics of bitrise.yml
body: The bitrise.yml file is the heart of your Bitrise configuration. The Bitrise CLI needs this file to be able to run Bitrise builds, either locally or on our website.

title: Basics of bitrise.yml
body: The bitrise.yml file is the heart of your Bitrise configuration. The Bitrise CLI needs this file to be able to run Bitrise builds, either locally or on our website.

title: Basics of bitrise.yml
body: A bare minimal bitrise.yml is as simple as:

title: Basics of bitrise.yml
body: format_version: 11

title: Basics of bitrise.yml
body: The above configuration is valid but does not include anything to execute with run.

title: Basics of bitrise.yml
body: A minimal configuration which you can bitrise run:

title: Basics of bitrise.yml
body:
format_version: 5
workflows:
 test:

title: Basics of bitrise.yml
body: The above configuration can be executed with bitrise run test. The Bitrise CLI won’t give you any errors, but there’s still nothing declared to do.

title: Basics of bitrise.yml
body: Let’s continue with an example that executes a single Script Step when you run it with bitrise run test.

title: Basics of bitrise.yml
body:
format_version: 11
default_step_lib_source: https://github.com/bitrise-io/bitrise-steplib.git
project_type: android
app:
 envs:
 - MY_NAME: My Name
workflows:
 test:
 steps:
 - script@1.1.5:
 inputs:
 - content: echo "Hello ${MY_NAME}!"

title: Basics of bitrise.yml
body: A quick walk through of this sample configuration:

title: Basics of bitrise.yml
body: format_version : declares the minimum Bitrise CLI format version. Get your Bitrise CLI’s supported highest format version with bitrise version --full.

title: Basics of bitrise.yml
body: Format version number

title: Basics of bitrise.yml
body: The format version number determines what Bitrise CLI versions will be able to run the configuration. For example, if you set the format_version to 11 that means that Bitrise CLI versions which don’t support the format version 11 or higher won’t be able to run the configuration. This is important if you use features which are not available in older Bitrise CLI versions.

title: Basics of bitrise.yml
body: default_step_lib_source : specifies the source to use when no other source is defined for a Step.

title: Basics of bitrise.yml
body: project_type : defines your source project’s type (for example, android, ios, flutter).

title: Basics of bitrise.yml
body: app - envs : specifies the Environment Variables (Env Var) which will be available for every build, workflow and step.

title: Basics of bitrise.yml
body: workflows : is the collection of separate build configurations which you can run with bitrise run WORKFLOWID.

title: Basics of bitrise.yml
body: In our example the only workflow is test, which you can perform with bitrise run test. If you’d have a second workflow called main, you could run both bitrise run test and bitrise run main.

title: Basics of bitrise.yml
body: steps : lists the Steps which should be executed when the Workflow is run.

title: Basics of bitrise.yml
body: In our example the test workflow includes only a single script Step. If multiple Steps are declared, they are performed one by one.

title: Basics of bitrise.yml
body: script@1.1.5 : a Step (reference) to perform. This reference does not have a StepLib Source declaration, which means that the default_step_lib_source will be used as the StepLib Source.

title: Basics of bitrise.yml
body: inputs : specifies Step inputs.

title: Basics of bitrise.yml
body: Multiple inputs

title: Basics of bitrise.yml
body: A Step can have many inputs. Specify only those input in the bitrise.yml which you want to set or overwrite.

title: Basics of bitrise.yml
body: content : the input you want to set.

title: Basics of bitrise.yml
body: In our example, we specified the content of the Script Step.

title: Basics of bitrise.yml
body: echo "Hello ${MY_NAME}!" : this is the value we specified for the content input.

title: Basics of bitrise.yml
body: bitrise.yml size limitation

title: Basics of bitrise.yml
body: If you edit your Workflow on bitrise.io (either in the Workflow Editor or on the bitrise.yml tab) and your bitrise.yml exceeds its size limitation, the UI will display the following warning upon trying to save your changes:

title: Basics of bitrise.yml
body: Error saving! Error saving app config: Validation failed: App config validation 784: unexpected token at 'Argument list too long - bin/bitrise

title: Basics of bitrise.yml
body: This is because the total, combined size of the bitrise.yml and the bitrise.secrets.yml file cannot exceed 400KB.

title: Customizing the bitrise.yml config
body: Any tool that can edit bitrise.yml can add custom properties to it. This way you can add special properties or notes to your env vars, or even try new configurations of your Workflow in bitrise.yml. All you have to add is add a meta field and a namespace label with key and value to the right place.

title: Customizing the bitrise.yml config
body: Any tool that can edit bitrise.yml can add custom properties to it. This way you can add special properties or notes to your Env Vars, or even try new configurations of your Workflow in bitrise.yml. All you have to add is add a meta field and a namespace label with key and value to the right place.

title: Customizing the bitrise.yml config
body: Use the following format to add custom values to your configuration:

title: Customizing the bitrise.yml config
Customizing the bitrise.yml config
body: Using your own version of the Workflow Editor

title: Customizing the bitrise.yml config
body: You can fork our Workflow Editor and use your own version of it. Then you can use meta: for example, let's say you want to keep an eye on one of the Environment Variables (Env Var), you want to know when it was last modified and by who.

title: Customizing the bitrise.yml config
body:
app:
 envs:
 - ASXaS: "`ZX`ZX"
 opts:
 is_expand: false
 meta:
 audit: # used by the Audited Workflow Editor imaginary tool: that works like the WFE but it also saves the modifier and modification date, and displays it
 last_modified_at: 2018.09.12.
 last_modifier: Jane Doe

title: Customizing the bitrise.yml config
body: Adding background color to an Environment Variable

title: Customizing the bitrise.yml config
body: You can use meta to add background color to an env var in your own tool:

title: Customizing the bitrise.yml config
Customizing the bitrise.yml config
body: You can see meta in action on bitrise.io as well. For example, when you select a different stack for your Workflow than the default stack. Just click Workflow Editor on the UI and pick another stack type for your Workflow/s on the Stacks & Machines tab. This way you can test how your Workflow runs in the new Stack.

title: Customizing the bitrise.yml config
body: If you head back to the bitrise.yml tab, a bitrise.io meta is added to the deploy Workflow:

title: Customizing the bitrise.yml config
body:
workflows:
 deploy:
 steps:
 - activate-ssh-key@4.0.3:
 run_if: '{{getenv "SSH_RSA_PRIVATE_KEY" | ne ""}}'
 - git-clone@4.0.11: {}
 - script@1.1.5:
 title: Do anything with Script step
 - deploy-to-bitrise-io@1.3.15: {}
 meta:
 bitrise.io:
 stack: osx-xcode-12.1.x

title: Customizing the bitrise.yml config
body: Since this meta is only interpreted on bitrise.io and not locally or on the Bitrise CLI, it is categorized by a bitrise.io namespace (where the stack is the key and osx-xcode-12.1.x is the value). The Workflow Editor always validates the saved variable and throws an error if there is a syntax error, but with meta added, its content is fully ignored by the Workflow Editor validation process.

title: Workflow reference
body: All bitrise.yml properties

title: Workflow reference
body: You can find the complete list of available properties in the bitrise.yml format specification / reference docs of the CLI.

title: Workflow reference
body: A Workflow is a collection of Steps, Environment Variables, and other configurations for a single bitrise run command.

title: Workflow reference
body: The only requirement for a Workflow is an ID. As an example, in this configuration we declared one Workflow with the ID test.

title: Workflow reference
body:
format_version: 1.3.1
workflows:
 test:

title: Workflow reference
body: You can define multiple Workflows and run a specific Workflow with bitrise run WORKFLOWID.

title: Workflow reference
body: Defining two Workflows:

title: Workflow reference
body:
format_version: 1.3.1
workflows:
 first:
 second:

title: Workflow reference
body: List all available Workflows in a bitrise.yml file:

title: Workflow reference
body: bitrise run

title: Workflow reference
body: Or, alternatively:

title: Workflow reference
body: bitrise workflows

title: Workflow reference
body: To add Steps to a Workflow simply include steps: and then add the Step(s).

title: Workflow reference
body:
format_version: 11
default_step_lib_source: https://github.com/bitrise-io/bitrise-steplib.git

workflows:
 test:
 steps:
 - script:
 title: First step
 - script:
 title: Second step

title: Workflow reference
body: You can define Workflow-specific parameters and Environment Variables. A Workflow’s Environment Variables are used when the Workflow is executed, and are available for every Step in the Workflow:

title: Workflow reference
body:
format_version: 11
default_step_lib_source: https://github.com/bitrise-io/bitrise-steplib.git

workflows:
 test:
 envs:
 - ENV_VAR_ONE: first value
 - ENV_VAR_TWO: second value

title: Workflow reference
body: You can chain Workflows to run multiple Workflows before and/or after a specific Workflow.

title: Workflow reference
body:
format_version: 1.3.1
default_step_lib_source: https://github.com/bitrise-io/bitrise-steplib.git

workflows:
 send-notifications:
 steps:
 # send notifications

 setup:
 steps:
 # setup Steps to run

 test:
 before_run:
 - setup
 envs:
 - IS_TEST: "true"
 steps:
 # test Steps to run

 ci:
 before_run:
 - test
 after_run:
 - send-notifications

 deploy:
 before_run:
 - test
 steps:
 # steps to deploy
 after_run:
 - send-notifications

title: Workflow reference
body: Based on the above example, if you run:

title: Workflow reference
body: bitrise run send-notifications: only the Steps of the send-notifications workflow will be executed.

title: Workflow reference
body: bitrise run setup : only the Steps of the setup Workflow will be executed.

title: Workflow reference
body: bitrise run test : first the Steps of the setup Workflow will be executed, then the Steps declared in test Workflow.

title: Workflow reference
body: bitrise run ci: will execute the Steps of the Workflows in the following order:

title: Workflow reference
body: setup

title: Workflow reference
body: test

title: Workflow reference
body: ci (the ci Workflow doesn’t have any Steps, but that’s not an issue. It just means that no Step will be executed here and the build will continue with the next Workflow in the chain).

title: Workflow reference
body: send-notifications

title: Workflow reference
body: bitrise run deploy: will execute the Steps of the Workflows in the following order:

title: Workflow reference
body: setup

title: Workflow reference
body: test

title: Workflow reference
body: deploy

title: Workflow reference
body: send-notifications

title: Workflow reference
body: This means that you can define what a setup and test should do in your project in the setup and test Workflows only once, and then you can reuse those in other Workflows. There’s no need to duplicate Steps between Workflows.

title: Workflow reference
body: The Bitrise CLI supports a small notation, called utility Workflow: a Workflow whose ID starts with an underscore character, for example, _setup. A utility Workflow can't be executed directly with a bitrise run command: they can be referenced with before_run and after_run properties.

title: Workflow reference
body: You can find utility Workflows at the end of the Workflow list if you run bitrise run or bitrise workflows:

title: Workflow reference
body:
The following workflows are available:
 * ci
 * deploy

You can run a selected workflow with:
$ bitrise run WORKFLOW-ID

The following utility workflows are defined:
 * _send-notifications
 * _setup
 * _test

title: Steps reference
body: A Step encapsulates a build task: the code to perform that task, the inputs and parameters you can define for the task, and the outputs the task generates.

title: Steps reference
body: A Step encapsulates a build task: the code to perform that task, the inputs and parameters you can define for the task, and the outputs the task generates.

title: Steps reference
body: For example the Git Clone Step performs a git clone of the specified repository, with the specified inputs, such as the branch or the commit to clone.

title: Steps reference
body: From a technical perspective, a Step is a semver versioned repository which includes the code of the Step and the interface definition of the Step.

title: Steps reference
body: The Step interface definition is defined in the step.yml file for every Step. It includes:

title: Steps reference
body: The dependencies of the Step.

title: Steps reference
body: The inputs and outputs of the Step.

title: Steps reference
body: The title and description of the Step.

title: Steps reference
body: Properties such as the issue tracker or support URL, or certain filter properties.

title: Steps reference
body: To include Steps in your Workflow, you have to reference them in the bitrise.yml file of your app. To do so, you will need the correct reference format for the Step. In the configuration file, you can also specify input values for the inputs defined in the Step's interface definition.

title: Step reference/ID format
body: To refer to a Step in a bitrise.yml file, you need to include at least the Step ID. Optionally, you can specify the StepLib source and the Step version, too.

title: Step reference/ID format
body: A Step reference can contain three components:

title: Step reference/ID format
body: The StepLib source: a library of Step repositories, such as the official Bitrise Step Library.

title: Step reference/ID format
body: The Step ID: every Step must have an ID as part of its step.yml definition.

title: Step reference/ID format
body: The Step version: the numerical version of the Step you want to include.

title: Step reference/ID format
body: Use the following syntax to reference a Step:

title: Step reference/ID format
body: <step_lib_source>::<step-id>@<version>:

title: Step reference/ID format
body: From these three components only the Step ID is required. For example:

title: Step reference/ID format
body: - script:

title: Step reference/ID format
body: This could be written as:

title: Step reference/ID format
body: https://github.com/bitrise-io/bitrise-steplib.git::script@1.1.3:

title: Step reference/ID format
body: If the version is not defined, the latest version of the step will be used.

title: Step reference/ID format
body: If the StepLib source is not defined, the default_step_lib_source will be used.

title: Step reference/ID format
body: We recommend using the specific version of a Step, for example, 1.1.3.

title: Special Step sources
body: There are two special Step sources:

title: Special Step sources
body: git::

title: Special Step sources
body: and path::

title: Special Step sources
body: When you use one of these sources, the Step won’t be identified through a Step Library but through the ID data you specify.

title: The git:: source
body: The git:: source is the repository of the Step on your git hosting provider. The script Step’s GitHub source is: https://github.com/bitrise-io/steps-script. To reference the script Step directly through a git reference, you can use the git:: source, the Step’s git clone URL, and the branch or tag in the repository.

title: The git:: source
body: To reference the 1.1.3 version tag of the script Step’s repository:

title: The git:: source
body: - git::https://github.com/bitrise-io/steps-script.git@1.1.3:

title: The git:: source
body: In general, whenever you can use a Step version through a Step Library, you should do that, instead of using the git:: source type. Features like local step caching, network caching, or alternative download URLs are only supported for Steps shared in a StepLib.

title: The git:: source
body: But this type of referencing allows certain things you can’t get through a StepLib. For example, the git:: source type can be used for not-yet-published or work-in-progress states of a Step. If you develop your own Step, you can use this git:: source type to test your step before you publish it in a StepLib.

title: The git:: source
body: To reference soon-to-be-released branch of your repository where you're developing a Step:

title: The git:: source
body: - git::https://github.com/bitrise-io/steps-script.git@soon-to-be-released:

title: The path:: source
body: The path:: source specifies a local path to a Step's repository, and it requires no version information. Both absolute and relative local paths are supported. A relative path is relative to the folder containing the bitrise.yml file.

title: The path:: source
body:
- path::/path/to/my/step:

- path::./relative/path:

title: The path:: source
body: This is useful for Step development. It can also be used if you want to include your build Steps in your app’s source code.

title: Step data in the bitrise.yml file
body: The Step data and information you specify in the bitrise.yml file are the parameters of the Step you want to change, compared to the Step’s default definition.

title: Step data in the bitrise.yml file
body: The Step data and information you specify in the bitrise.yml file are the parameters of the Step you want to change, compared to the Step’s default definition.

title: Step data in the bitrise.yml file
body: To see the Step’s raw interface definition you can check it in the step library. The Step interface definitions can be found in the StepLib’s steps directory.

title: Step data in the bitrise.yml file
body: If you don’t specify any input or other Step property in the bitrise.yml configuration, only the Step (reference/ID), the Step will run with the default values as defined by the Step’s developer in the interface definition.

title: Step data in the bitrise.yml file
body: Let’s see an example with a single Script Step, which will be executed when you run bitrise run test:

title: Step data in the bitrise.yml file
body:
format_version: 11
default_step_lib_source: https://github.com/bitrise-io/bitrise-steplib.git
 
workflows:
 test:
 steps:
 - script:

title: Step data in the bitrise.yml file
body: Specify inputs for the Step with the inputs: list property. An input consists of a key and a value:

title: Step data in the bitrise.yml file
body: Indentation

title: Step data in the bitrise.yml file
body: Indentation in the YAML format is very important! You should use two- or four-space indentation, and you can’t use tabs to indent!

title: Step data in the bitrise.yml file
body:
format_version: 11
default_step_lib_source: https://github.com/bitrise-io/bitrise-steplib.git
 
workflows:
 test:
 steps:
 - script:
 inputs:
 - content: "echo 'Hello World!'"

title: Step data in the bitrise.yml file
body: If the Step doesn’t have any required inputs you don’t have to specify an input. You can specify values for as many inputs as you want to.

title: Step data in the bitrise.yml file
body: Step input values are always string / text values and they are passed to the Step as Environment Variables. The value can be multiline too, using the standard YAML multiline format:

title: Step data in the bitrise.yml file
body:
format_version: 11
default_step_lib_source: https://github.com/bitrise-io/bitrise-steplib.git

workflows:

 #!/bin/bash

format_version: 1.3.1
default_step_lib_source: https://github.com/bitrise-io/bitrise-steplib.git

workflows:
 test:
 steps:
 - script@1.1.3:
 is_always_run: true
 inputs:
 - content: "puts 'Hello Ruby!'"
 - runner_bin: ruby

default_step_lib_source: https://github.com/bitrise-io/bitrise-steplib.git

workflows:

 - runner_bin: ruby

title: Step properties
body: Step properties provide important data of a Step, such as its project type, its source code or the dependencies it requires. A Step’s inputs and outputs are also defined as Step properties.

title: Step properties
body: Step properties provide important data of a Step, such as its project type, its source code or the dependencies it requires. A Step’s inputs and outputs are also defined as Step properties. Let’s take a look at the properties!

title: Step properties
body: title, summary and description : metadata, for comments, tools and GUI.

title: Step properties
body: Meta properties as permanent comments

title: Step properties
body: These meta properties can be used for permanent comments. Standard YML comments are not preserved when the YML is normalized, converted to JSON or otherwise generated or transformed. These meta properties are.

title: Step properties
body: website : official website of the Step / service.

title: Step properties
body: source_code_url : the url where the Step’s source code can be viewed.

title: Step properties
body: support_url : url to the Step’s support / issue tracker.

title: Step properties
body: published_at : auto-generated at share - the StepLib publish date of the Step’s version

title: Step properties
body: source : auto-generated at share git clone information.

title: Step properties
body: asset_urls : auto-generated at share Step assets (StepLib specific), like icon image.

title: Step properties
body: host_os_tags : supported operating systems. Currently unused, reserved for future use.

title: Step properties
body: project_type_tags : project type tags if the Step is project type specific. Example: ios or android. Completely optional, and only used for search and filtering in Step lists.

title: Step properties
body: type_tags : generic type tags related to the Step. Example: utility, test or notification. Similar to project_type_tags, this property is completely optional, and only used for search and filtering in Step lists.

title: Step properties
body: deps : specifies the required dependencies of the Step. To declare a dependency, specify a package manager and then the dependency you wish to install.

title: Step properties
body: inputs : inputs (Environments) of the Step.

title: Step properties
body: outputs : outputs (Environments) of the Step.

title: Step inputs reference
body: Step inputs are environment items that tell the Bitrise CLI how to run a given Step. The inputs of a Step are defined in the step.yml file of every Step by setting the inputs property..

title: Step inputs reference
body: Step inputs are environment items that tell the Bitrise CLI how to run a given Step. The inputs of a Step are defined in the step.yml file of every Step by setting the inputs property..

title: Step inputs reference
body: Step inputs have the same syntax as every environment property. It consists of two main parts: a KEY: value pair and an opts field.

title: Step inputs reference
body:
inputs:
- my_key_for_the_env: "default value" 
 opts: 
 title: An example env var item 
 is_dont_change_value: false 
 category: example

title: Step inputs reference
body: my_key_for_the_env: the key of the input (required).

title: Step inputs reference
body: default value: the default value of the input. You don’t always have to provide a default value.

title: Step inputs reference
body: opts: optional properties.

title: Step input properties
body: The available properties for Step inputs:

title: Step input properties
body: title, summary and description : metadata, for comments, tools and GUI.

title: Step input properties
body: Meta properties as permanent comments

title: Step input properties
body: These meta properties can be used for permanent comments. Standard YML comments are not preserved when the YML is normalized, converted to JSON or otherwise generated or transformed. These meta properties are.

title: Step input properties
body: is_expand : can be set to true or false. The default value is true so the Bitrise CLI expands Environment Variables (Env Vars) before passing it on to the Step. That means that if a Step input's value is an Env Var, the Bitrise CLI will pass the variable's value to the Step. If set to false, the CLI will pass the Env Var's key as a string.

title: Step input properties
body: skip_if_empty : can be set to true or false. If set to true, the input will not be used if its value is empty.

title: Step input properties
body: category : used to categorize the input. Inputs with the same category will appear grouped under one menu on the website UI, for the sake of convenience.

title: Step input properties
body: value_options : list of the available values.

title: Step input properties
body: is_required : can be set to true or false. If set to true, the step requires a non-empty value to be set for the input.

title: Step input properties
body: is_dont_change_value : can be set to true or false. If set to true, the value of the input should not be changed and/or should be hidden on UIs. Mainly used for debug inputs and for “connection” inputs (set to outputs of other Steps, to connect this Step with another one).

title: Step input properties
body: is_template : can be set to true or false. If set to true

title: Step input properties
body: the input’s value will be evaulated as a Go template.

title: Step input properties
body: is_sensitive: marking an input as sensitive means that it will only accept a Secret Environment Variable as its value. It is most frequently used for sensitive information such as passwords, API keys, tokens, but any input can be marked sensitive.

title: Using template expressions for Step inputs
body: If you need a Step to use a certain value only in certain circumstances, use template expressions as Step inputs. Template expressions are evaluated before the Step uses the input. They are written in Go’s template language.

title: Using template expressions for Step inputs
body: Set the is_template property in the step.yml file of your project to use template expressions.

title: Using template expressions for Step inputs
body: Open the step.yml file of your project.

title: Using template expressions for Step inputs
body: Find the Step in which you wish to use a template expression.

title: Using template expressions for Step inputs
body: Add an opts field to the content of the Step.

title: Using template expressions for Step inputs
body: Add the is_template property to opts and set its value to true.

title: Using template expressions for Step inputs
body: Add the template expression to the Step’s content.

title: Using template expressions for Step inputs
body: Checking if the Bitrise CLI is in CI mode

title: Using template expressions for Step inputs
body:
- script:
 title: Template example
 inputs:
 - content: |-
 {{if .IsCI}}
 echo "CI mode"
 {{else}}
 echo "not CI mode"
 {{end}}
 opts:
 is_template: true

title: Step outputs reference
body: Step outputs are environment items that are the result of running a given Step. You can check out the default outputs of a Step in the Workflow Editor on bitrise.io or in the step.yml file of the Step.

title: Step outputs reference
body: Step outputs are environment items that are the result of running a given Step. For example, the Deploy to Bitrise.io Step generates two output envs by default:

title: Step outputs reference
body: $BITRISE_PUBLIC_INSTALL_PAGE_URL

title: Step outputs reference
body: BITRISE_PUBLIC_INSTALL_PAGE_URL_MAP

title: Step outputs reference
body: You can check out the default outputs of a Step in the Workflow Editor on bitrise.io or in the step.yml file of the Step.

title: Step outputs reference
body: Step outputs can be defined in the step.yml file of the project by setting the outputs attribute. They have the same syntax as every environment property. It consists of two main parts: a KEY: value pair and an opts field. The key and the value are required, the opts field is optional.

title: Step outputs reference
body:
- MY_KEY_FOR_THE_ENV: my value for the env
 opts:
 title: An example env var item
 is_dont_change_value: false
 category: example

title: Step outputs reference
body: MY_KEY_FOR_THE_ENV: The key of the environment item (required).

title: Step outputs reference
body: my value for the env: The value of the item (required).

title: Step outputs reference
body: opts: Optional attributes.

title: Step outputs reference
body: The default outputs of a Step cannot be changed by the user in the bitrise.yml file of the project: they can only be changed in the step.yml file. However, you can export the output in a custom Environment Variable. This is useful, for example, if you have the same step twice in your Workflow and you wish to use the generated output of both steps:

title: Step outputs reference
body:
workflows:
 primary:
 steps:
 - gradle-runner:
 outputs:
 - BITRISE_APK_PATH: ALIAS_APK_PATH

title: Step outputs reference
body: In this example, the value for the BITRISE_APK_PATH Environment Variable will be exported under the ALIAS_APK_PATH key.

title: Available Environment Variables
body: Environment Variables (Env Vars) consist of a key and a value, as well as optional attributes. They can be defined on the level of apps, Workflows or Steps.

title: Available Environment Variables
body: Environment Variables (Env Vars) consist of a key and a value. They can also include optional attributes. They can be defined on the level of apps, Workflows or Steps.

title: Available Environment Variables
body: You can set your own Env Vars but there is a selection of Env Vars that are exposed automatically by either the Bitrise CLI or bitrise.io.

title: Available Environment Variables
body: Env Vars exposed by the Bitrise CLI are available everywhere, even if you run the build on your own computer.

title: Available Environment Variables
body: Env Vars exposed by bitrise.io are available for builds running on bitrise.io virtual machines.

title: Available Environment Variables
body: Pipeline Env Vars exposed by bitrise.io are only available for Pipeline builds running on bitrise.io virtual machines.

As basically any Bitrise Step can expose outputs this way, we won't list them all but you can find all Environment Variables related to the git cloning process: Table 4, “.

title: Bitrise add-ons
body: Bitrise offers several add-ons providing additional functionality to our services.

title: Bitrise add-ons
body: These add-ons have two types:

title: Bitrise add-ons
body: Add-ons that provide additional functionality to the core CI/CD product. For example, Test Reports.

title: Bitrise add-ons
body: Add-ons that offer a new type of Bitrise service. For example, Release Management.

title: Glossary
body: AppAn app on Bitrise represents a Git repository that stores source code and has been connected to Bitrise to be able to run builds on it. As such, a Bitrise app isn't necessarily an actual application: it's just the code on which you run builds with Bitrise.

title: Glossary
body: An app on Bitrise represents a Git repository that stores source code and has been connected to Bitrise to be able to run builds on it. As such, a Bitrise app isn't necessarily an actual application: it's just the code on which you run builds with Bitrise.

title: Glossary
body: bitrise.ymlThe bitrise.yml file stores your entire build configuration for an app. It specifies your stack and the build triggers, and defines the Workflows of the app. When you make changes on the graphical UI of our Workflow Editor, you actually modify the bitrise.yml file.

title: Glossary
body: The bitrise.yml file stores your entire build configuration for an app. It specifies your stack and the build triggers, and defines the Workflows of the app. When you make changes on the graphical UI of our Workflow Editor, you actually modify the bitrise.yml file.

title: Glossary
body: PipelineA Bitrise Pipeline is the top level of the Bitrise CI/CD configuration. Pipelines can be used to organize the entire CI/CD process and to set up advanced configurations with multiple different tasks running parallel and/or sequentially.

title: Glossary
body: A Bitrise Pipeline is the top level of the Bitrise CI/CD configuration. Pipelines can be used to organize the entire CI/CD process and to set up advanced configurations with multiple different tasks running parallel and/or sequentially.

title: Glossary
body: Project scannerThe project scanner is a tool that identifies the given project’s type and generates a basic Bitrise configuration. Each supported project type has its own scanner: these scanners are stored as separate packages.

title: Glossary
body: The project scanner is a tool that identifies the given project’s type and generates a basic Bitrise configuration. Each supported project type has its own scanner: these scanners are stored as separate packages.

title: Glossary
body: SecretA Secret is a specific type of Environment Variable: they hide their information in an encrypted format and their value is not exposed in the build logs nor in the bitrise.yml configuration. You can store confidential information, such as passwords or API keys as Secrets.

title: Glossary
body: A Secret is a specific type of Environment Variable: they hide their information in an encrypted format and their value is not exposed in the build logs nor in the bitrise.yml configuration. You can store confidential information, such as passwords or API keys as Secrets.

title: Glossary
body: StackA build stack indicates the full configuration of the virtual machine that Bitrise uses to run your build. Each stack includes an operating system, and a large number of pre-installed software and tools. For example, our Xcode stacks run on macOS operating systems and contain, among many other tools, the Xcode version that is indicated in the name of the stack.

title: Glossary
body: A build stack indicates the full configuration of the virtual machine that Bitrise uses to run your build. Each stack includes an operating system, and a large number of pre-installed software and tools. For example, our Xcode stacks run on macOS operating systems and contain, among many other tools, the Xcode version that is indicated in the name of the stack.

title: Glossary
body: StageA Stage is a collection of Workflows. Stages are the top-level building blocks of Pipelines. A Stage can contain multiple Workflows, which all run in parallel in the same Stage. If all Workflows are successful in a Stage, the Pipeline moves on to the next Stage. If any of the Workflows fail, the Pipeline ends without running the other Stages unless you configure a given Stage to always run.

title: Glossary
body: A Stage is a collection of Workflows. Stages are the top-level building blocks of Pipelines. A Stage can contain multiple Workflows, which all run in parallel in the same Stage. If all Workflows are successful in a Stage, the Pipeline moves on to the next Stage. If any of the Workflows fail, the Pipeline ends without running the other Stages unless you configure a given Stage to always run.

title: Glossary
body: StepA Step is a block of script execution that encapsulates a build task on Bitrise: the code to perform that task, the inputs and parameters you can define for the task, and the outputs the task generates.

title: Glossary
body: A Step is a block of script execution that encapsulates a build task on Bitrise: the code to perform that task, the inputs and parameters you can define for the task, and the outputs the task generates.

title: Glossary
body: step.ymlThe interface definition of a Bitrise Step. It defines the Step inputs and the generated outputs, as well as any other Step property such as the category and the description of the Step. It also points to the Step's source code.

title: Glossary
body: The interface definition of a Bitrise Step. It defines the Step inputs and the generated outputs, as well as any other Step property such as the category and the description of the Step. It also points to the Step's source code.

title: Glossary
body: TriggerA trigger or build trigger is a configuration for automatically launching a Bitrise build when a specified event happens. Triggers require a webhook set up at your Git hosting provider.

title: Glossary
body: A trigger or build trigger is a configuration for automatically launching a Bitrise build when a specified event happens. Triggers require a webhook set up at your Git hosting provider.

title: Glossary
body: WorkflowA Workflow is a collection of Steps, Environment Variables, and other configurations. When Bitrise starts a build, it runs one or more Workflows according to the configuration defined in the bitrise.yml file.

title: Glossary
body: A Workflow is a collection of Steps, Environment Variables, and other configurations. When Bitrise starts a build, it runs one or more Workflows according to the configuration defined in the bitrise.yml file.

title: Glossary
body: Workflow EditorWFEThe Bitrise Workflow Editor allows you to edit your Workflows, configure Steps, upload files (including code signing files) and manage your app's triggers and stacks on a graphical user interface. It is available both online and offline.

title: Glossary
body: The Bitrise Workflow Editor allows you to edit your Workflows, configure Steps, upload files (including code signing files) and manage your app's triggers and stacks on a graphical user interface. It is available both online and offline.

title: Glossary
body: WorkspaceA Workspace is an environment that allows you to manage your Bitrise apps and the team members working on the apps. You can create multiple Workspaces, and you can be invited to Workspaces by other Bitrise users. To be able to add apps and run builds, you either need to be part of a Workspace, or you have to be an outside contributor on an app's team.

title: Glossary
body: A Workspace is an environment that allows you to manage your Bitrise apps and the team members working on the apps. You can create multiple Workspaces, and you can be invited to Workspaces by other Bitrise users. To be able to add apps and run builds, you either need to be part of a Workspace, or you have to be an outside contributor on an app's team.

title: 404 - Page Not Found
body: Sorry, we couldn't find the page you were looking for. Go back to the home page, or check out some of our most popular content:

title: Optimizing your build times
body: You can improve your build times with the following tips.

title: Including your dependencies in your repository
body: Including your dependencies (like CocoaPods) in your repository can speed up your builds. Once the git clone of your repository is done, everything will be in place to do your build.

title: Including your dependencies in your repository
body: For example, in case of CocoaPods, you can delete the CocoaPods Install step from your workflow if you include your Pods directory and the CocoaPods generated .xcworkspace file in your repository.

title: Using the Build Cache
body: The Build Cache feature can also help to speed up your builds. Note: the efficiency of the Build Cache depends on the size of the files you want to cache, as well as on the number of files you want to cache.

title: Turning off the Clean build option of Xcode Steps
body: All Xcode Steps at Bitrise have an option called Do a clean Xcode build…?. With this option, you can tell the Step whether to perform a full, completely clean build of your Xcode project when it runs, or alternatively, to access the cache of previous Xcode Steps in the same Workflow.

title: Turning off the Clean build option of Xcode Steps
body: Setting this option to no can speed up your build by reducing the compilation time of the Step. However, if you have only one Xcode Step - for example, Xcode Archive & Export for iOS - in your Workflow, that one Step will always have to do a clean Xcode build.

title: Turning off the Clean build option of Xcode Steps
body: Please note that this option does NOT mean that the Step can access the build cache of different builds. This option is only relevant if you have several Xcode Steps in the same Workflow.

title: Teams plan FAQ
body: As part of our efforts to introduce a credit-based model, we’re now offering our new Teams plan. You can sign up for a free trial, or subscribe to the full plan. Here’s everything you need to know about it!

title: How to sign up for the trial?
body: Signing up for the free trial

title: How to sign up for the trial?
body: The free trial is only available on new accounts when you create your first Workspace.

title: How to sign up for the trial?
body: Find the Workspace name input field, and add a name.

title: How to sign up for the trial?
body: Click Create Workspace.

title: How to sign up for the trial?
body: Once you’re done with setting up the Workspace, your trial will start automatically.

title: If I sign up for a trial, when will it end?
body: As of now, Teams plan trials are indefinite, there’s no time limit on using it. You can use the Teams plan trial as long as you have credits.

title: Can I sign up for the full Teams plan?
body: Yes, if you are the owner of a Workspace. To do so:

title: Can I sign up for the full Teams plan?
body: Log in to Bitrise.

title: Can I sign up for the full Teams plan?
body: On the Dashboard, find the account selector in the top right corner.

title: Can I sign up for the full Teams plan?
body: Open the dropdown menu, and find the Workspace you want to use.

title: Can I sign up for the full Teams plan?
body: Click the little gear icon next to its name. This will take you to the Workspace settings page.

title: Can I sign up for the full Teams plan?
body: On the left, find the Plan & billing tab and click it. This will take you to the Workspace’s Plan & billing page.

title: Can I sign up for the full Teams plan?
body: On the Plan & billing page, click Upgrade to Teams plan and follow the instructions. You’ll need to provide payment details. Once the first payment is authorized, your subscription starts immediately.

title: What features does the Teams plan have?
body: Switching to the Teams plan from our credit-based Hobby plan has numerous benefits, including:

title: What features does the Teams plan have?
body: Unlimited private apps.

title: What features does the Teams plan have?
body: Unlimited team members and all the team management features.

title: What features does the Teams plan have?
body: Multiple machines types to choose from.

title: What features does the Teams plan have?
body: Add-ons, such as Test Reports and Ship.

title: How do I get credits?
body: You get 500 credits for the trial. Once you run out, your trial ends.

title: How do I get credits?
body: On the full Teams plan, you get a certain amount of credits each month, depending on your credit tier. If you need more credits, you need to upgrade to a higher credit tier. You can do that on the Plan & billing tab of your Workspace.

title: Will I lose my unused credits if I switch to a different plan?
body: It depends on whether you upgrade to a higher credit tier or downgrade to a lower credit tier.

title: Will I lose my unused credits if I switch to a different plan?
body: If you upgrade to a higher tier before the end of your current billing cycle, the upgrade happens immediately and a new billing cycle starts right away. When you pay for the new credit tier, we calculate the cost of the time remaining from your previous billing cycle and subtract it from your first charge. For example, if your previous subscription fee was a 100 USD every 30 days and you decide to upgrade to a higher tier with exactly 15 days remaining in the last billing cycle, you’ll be charged the price of the new subscription minus 50 USD when upgrading.

title: Will I lose my unused credits if I switch to a different plan?
body: When downgrading to a lower credit tier, it’s very simple: the downgrade happens at the end of the current billing cycle. Until then, you can use all your remaining credits.

title: How do I use my credits?
body: Just trigger a build! Each build will use a certain amount of credits per minute, depending on the type of stack you use.

title: What happens if I run out of credits?
body: On a trial of the Teams plan, running out of credits means your trial ends. To keep building, subscribe for the full plan!

title: What happens if I run out of credits?
body: In Pay-As-You-Go mode, you can keep running builds and we’re counting the Pay-As-You-Go credits you use up. This incurs additional costs on top of your monthly or annual subscription fee: the cost of running builds in Pay-As-You-Go mode is 1.5 times per credit compared to a regular build. You are billed for this fee separately each month, even if you are on annual subscription. Your monthly Pay-As-You-Go limit is half of the credit amount of your monthly bundle. If you exceed this limit, you won’t be able to run builds any more, though running builds will never be aborted.

title: What happens if I run out of credits?
body: For example, if you receive 100 credits each month, and each credit costs 1 USD, your monthly fee is 100 USD. Once you use up all 100 credits, you are switched to Pay-As-You-Go mode. In this mode, you can use up 50 more credits, but each credit costs 1.5 USD so if you reach your Pay-As-You-Go limit, your additional Pay-As-You-Go fee will be 75 USD. If, however, your Pay-As-You-Go fee is only 5 USD or less, you won’t be billed.

title: What happens if I run out of credits?
body: If you often go into Pay-As-You-Go mode, we recommend upgrading to a higher credit tier!

title: Will a build be aborted if I run out of credits?
body: No, running builds will never be aborted. You can always finish a running build, even if you exceed your Pay-As-You-Go credit limit.

title: Will unused credits roll over to the next month?
body: No. At the start of each month, you'll receive your monthly credit bundle, resetting your credit balance.

title: How many apps can I have?
body: On the Teams plan trial, you can have as many apps as you want.

title: Do the different machine types have different credit costs?
body: Yes: more powerful machines have a higher credit cost. Check out our pricing page for more detailed information, including the exact credit cost of each machine type.

title: How is the credit cost calculated for minute fractions?
body: Your build cost is calculated based on the stack of your choice multiplied by the number of started minutes.

title: How is the credit cost calculated for minute fractions?
body: For example, if you are using a stack that costs 2 credits/minute, and your build takes 3 minutes and 12 seconds to complete, that will cost 8 credits.

title: How many builds can I run at the same time?
body: You can run 10 builds on macOS stacks and 30 builds on Linux stacks in parallel.

title: Is there a time limit for builds?
body: There is a hard limit of three and a half hours for a single build. Please be aware that if your build hangs for some reason, this can mean unwanted credit consumption. If you wish to lower the build time limit for safety reasons, contact our support!

body: Type Description

title: Build stacks
body: Pre-booted If a stack is available as pre-booted, and there’s enough pre-booted machines with that stack configuration, your build can start right away, without waiting for the build environment to boot. In case there’s no more available pre-booted machine with that stack configuration, your build will start on an on-demand configuration.

title: Build stacks
body: On-demand If a stack is available as on-demand configuration and there’s no (available) pre-booted configuration for the stack, our system will have to create a virtual machine for your selected configuration when your build starts. This means that your build will be in preparing environment state while the related virtual machine is created & booted. For a macOS configuration the boot process usually takes about 1 - 1.5 minutes. The prepare time (of course) is not counted into the build time, it won’t affect how long your build can run.

title: iOS code signing
body: Methods How it works When to use it

title: iOS code signing
body: Automatically managed provisioning profiles (recommended) You only need to upload the code signing certificate(s) to Bitrise and to establish an Apple Service connection (either via App Store Connect API key or through an Apple ID). Bitrise will download, create or renew the provisioning profile(s) and handle App ID and test device registration automatically. This is the recommended option for most apps. With this option, managing your provisioning profiles is seamless and it's much easier to set up your Workflows.

title: iOS code signing
body: Manually managed provisioning profiles You need to upload the code signing certificate(s) and also the provisioning profile(s) to Bitrise and keep the provisioning profile(s) updated with your iOS project. Choose this option if: You cannot connect your App Store Connect API key or Apple ID to Bitrise.You store or handle your code signing files in a unique way.You wish to use code signing files from multiple Apple Developer Accounts. You might also prefer this option if you are using an account with Apple Developer Enterprise Program. In this case only Apple ID-based authentication is supported. This has certain limitations: for example, needs to be renewed every 30 days.

title: Apple services authentication for automatic provisioning
body: Authentication method How it works When to use

title: Apple services authentication for automatic provisioning
body: API key authentication (recommended) You connect your App Store Connect account to Bitrise using an API key. We recommend using this option unless you are using an account with Apple Developer Enterprise Program. If you do not receive the option to create an API key and the request access is greyed out, you need to contact your account holder to accept a license agreement with Apple to use API authentication.

title: Apple services authentication for automatic provisioning
body: Apple ID authentication You connect your Apple ID to Bitrise. If two-factor authentication is enabled on your Apple account, you will have to provide the App-specific password during this process. Your authentication expires in 30 days and you will have to refresh the connection. You should only use this solution if: You cannot access API key for any reason.you are using an account with Apple Developer Enterprise Program. You can also consider using manual provisioning.

title: Configuring the Steps for automatic provisioning
body: Xcode Steps: Xcode Archive and Export for iOSExport iOS and tvOS Xcode ArchiveXcode build for testing for iOS These Steps set up code signing in your Xcode project automatically with nearly zero configuration. We recommend using these Steps in most scenarios.

You can use this dedicated Step if: You are building the app from script or fastlane.You have a cross-platform project. For example, React Native, Flutter, Ionic or Cordova.You are building a macOS app.

title: Deploying apps to DeployGate from Bitrise
body: API Key Set upload user’s DeployGate API Key from Account Settings. If you want to upload apps as organization account, please use organization’s API Key. Upload account will be shown on the activity timeline.

title: Deploying apps to DeployGate from Bitrise
body: Owner Name App owner’s account name in DeployGate. You can use username or organization name.

title: Deploying apps to DeployGate from Bitrise
body: App file path App’s binary file (IPA/APK) to be uploaded. For default setting, use $BITRISE_APK_PATH for Android or $BITRISE_IPA_PATH for iOS

title: Deploying apps to DeployGate from Bitrise
body: Input Variables Description

title: Deploying apps to DeployGate from Bitrise
body: Short Message Summary of update shown on DeployGate. You can use $BITRISE_GIT_MESSAGE if you want to use the commit message, the pull request title, or the message you specified when you triggered the build manually.

title: Deploying apps to DeployGate from Bitrise
body: Distribution Key You can make multiple public install links (we called it Distribution Page) for a different version of app binary in the same app. By specifying the distribution page’s hash, that distribution page will be updated simultaneously. The “xxxx” portion of the distributed page’s URL like https://deploygate.com/distributions/xxxx

title: Deploying apps to DeployGate from Bitrise
body: Distribution Name Specify the name of the updated distribution page. If nothing exists, a new distribution page will be created. Possible usage includes creating distribution pages for each Git branch name. (for example $BITRISE_GIT_BRANCH)

title: Deploying apps to DeployGate from Bitrise
body: Release Note Message for the new release in distribution page. This message will be notified to your distribution page’s testers

title: Deploying apps to DeployGate from Bitrise
body: Disable Notify(iOS Only) There is no DeployGate client app in iOS platform. By default, we use email notifications for release updates. If you don’t need email notification, please set this option as true

title: Available Environment Variables
body: Env Var key Description

title: Available Environment Variables
body: $BITRISE_TRIGGERED_WORKFLOW_ID The ID of the Workflow that was triggered. This Env Var is exposed regardless of whether the Workflow was triggered manually or automatically.

title: Available Environment Variables
body: $BITRISE_TRIGGERED_WORKFLOW_TITLE The title of the Workflow that was triggered. This Env Var is exposed regardless of whether the Workflow was triggered manually or automatically.

title: Available Environment Variables
body: $BITRISE_BUILD_STATUS The current status of the build. The available options are: 0: Successful.1: Failed. A successful current status means that none of the previous Steps in the build failed.

title: Available Environment Variables
body: $BITRISE_SOURCE_DIR Path to the base working directory. By default, it’s the directory where Bitrise runs, unless you provide a different value. This can be overwritten during the build, which will change the working directory for subsequent Steps in the build.

title: Available Environment Variables
body: $BITRISE_DEPLOY_DIR Path to the directory that stores artifacts and files for deployment. It’s a temporary directory created by the Bitrise CLI by default, and can be overwritten before starting the Bitrise CLI. The Deploy to Bitrise.io Step looks for your build artifacts - such as an IPA or APK of the app -, test results, and other files in this directory.

title: Available Environment Variables
body: $CI Indicates whether the Bitrise CLI is running in Continuous Integration mode. The possible values are: truefalse

title: Available Environment Variables
body: $PR Indicates whether the Bitrise CLI is running in PR (Pull Request) mode. Running in Pull Request mode means that Bitrise builds your code in the state as if the Pull Request was already merged. The possible values are: truefalse

title: Available Environment Variables
body: Env Var key Description

title: Available Environment Variables
body: $BITRISE_BUILD_NUMBER Build number of the build on bitrise.io.

title: Available Environment Variables
body: $BITRISE_APP_TITLE The title of your app on bitrise.io. You can change it any time on the Settings tab of the app.

title: Available Environment Variables
body: $BITRISE_APP_URL The URL or your app on bitrise.io. This is not the same as the git repository URL! An app URL has the following format: app.bitrise.io/APP-SLUG/ For example: https://app.bitrise.io/app/31e481ce08e0xfd9.

title: Available Environment Variables
body: $BITRISE_APP_SLUG The slug that uniquely identifies your app on bitrise.io. It’s part of the app URL, too.

title: Available Environment Variables
body: $BITRISE_BUILD_URL The URL of the build on bitrise.io.

title: Available Environment Variables
body: $BITRISE_BUILD_SLUG The slug that uniquely identifies a build on bitrise.io. It’s part of the build URL, too. For example, let’s take a look at this build URL: https://app.bitrise.io/build/d75abbebxfc9ca4e. The build slug is d65abbebxfc9ca4e in this example.

title: Available Environment Variables
body: $BITRISE_BUILD_TRIGGER_TIMESTAMP The date and time when the build was triggered.

title: Available Environment Variables
body: $GIT_REPOSITORY_URL The URL of the Git repository that hosts your app. This can be changed in the Settings tab of the app. It can be in either SSH or HTTPS format.

title: Available Environment Variables
body: $BITRISE_GIT_BRANCH The git branch that is built by Bitrise. For example, main.

title: Available Environment Variables
body: $BITRISEIO_GIT_BRANCH_DEST Used only with builds triggered by pull requests: the destination/target branch of the pull request that triggered the build. For example, a pull request wants to merge the content of a branch into the branch main. In this case, this Env Var’s value is main.

title: Available Environment Variables
body: $BITRISE_GIT_TAG If a build is triggered by a Git Tag, this Env Var stores the tag used.

title: Available Environment Variables
body: $BITRISE_GIT_COMMIT The commit hash of the Git commit that triggered the build, when applicable.

title: Available Environment Variables
body: $BITRISE_GIT_MESSAGE The commit message, pull request title, or the message you specified if you triggered the build manually.

title: Available Environment Variables
body: $BITRISEIO_GIT_REPOSITORY_OWNER The owner of the Git repository of the app.

title: Available Environment Variables
body: $BITRISEIO_GIT_REPOSITORY_SLUG The slug of the Git repository of the app.

title: Available Environment Variables
body: $BITRISE_PULL_REQUEST The ID of the pull request that triggered a build.

title: Available Environment Variables
body: $BITRISEIO_PULL_REQUEST_REPOSITORY_URL The URL of the repository from where the pull request that triggered a build has been sent.

title: Available Environment Variables
body: $BITRISEIO_PULL_REQUEST_MERGE_BRANCH The pre-merge branch - if the Git hosting provider supports and provides the pre-merged state of a pull request on a special merge branch.

title: Available Environment Variables
body: $BITRISEIO_PULL_REQUEST_HEAD_BRANCH The pull request head branch, if the Git hosting provider system supports and provides this. This special git ref should point to the source of the pull request.

title: Available Environment Variables
body: $BITRISE_PROVISION_URL The URL of the Apple provisioning profiles uploaded to bitrise.io. If there is more than one provisioning profile uploaded for your app, a pipe character (|) separates the URLs in the list. This is only relevant for iOS apps and for cross-platform apps with iOS versions.

title: Available Environment Variables
body: $BITRISE_CERTIFICATE_URL The URL of the Apple certificates uploaded to bitrise.io. If there is more than one certificate uploaded for your app, a pipe character (|) separates the URLs in the list. This is only relevant for iOS apps and for cross-platform apps with iOS versions.

title: Available Environment Variables
body: $BITRISE_CERTIFICATE_PASSPHRASE The passphrase you set for the uploaded Apple certificates on the app’s Code Signing & Files tab. If there is more than one certificate with a passphrase, a pipe character (|) separates the phrases in the list. This is only relevant for iOS apps and for cross-platform apps with iOS versions.

title: Available Environment Variables
body: $BITRISE_IO Indicates that the build is running in a bitrise.io environment. Value is set to true by Bitrise when it starts a build.

title: Available Environment Variables
body: Env Var key Description

title: Available Environment Variables
body: $BITRISEIO_PIPELINE_ID The ID of the running Pipeline build. This Env Var is exposed regardless of whether the Pipeline was triggered manually or automatically.

title: Available Environment Variables
body: $BITRISEIO_PIPELINE_TITLE The name of the running Pipeline build. This Env Var is exposed regardless of whether the Pipeline was triggered manually or automatically.

title: Available Environment Variables
body: $BITRISEIO_FINISHED_STAGES The status of previously finished Stages and Workflows in a build. Please note that the value of this Env Var may change in the future!

title: Available Environment Variables
body: $BITRISEIO_PIPELINE_BUILD_STATUS The current status of the Pipeline build. The value of this Env Var can be: succeeded, succeeded_with_abort, failed, and aborted. While the Pipeline is running, the Env Var's status is based on the previously finished Stages.

title: Available Environment Variables
body: $BITRISEIO_PIPELINE_BUILD_URL The URL of the Pipeline build.

title: Available Environment Variables
body: Env Var key Description

title: Available Environment Variables
body: $GIT_CLONE_COMMIT_HASH The hash of the commit that the build uses (the cloned commit).

title: Available Environment Variables
body: $GIT_CLONE_COMMIT_MESSAGE_SUBJECT The subject of the commit message of the cloned commit.

title: Available Environment Variables
body: $GIT_CLONE_COMMIT_MESSAGE_BODY The body (content) of the commit message of the cloned commit.

title: Available Environment Variables
body: $GIT_CLONE_COMMIT_COUNT The commit count of the cloned commit. This Env Var is influenced by the clone_depth Step input. For more information, check out the Git Clone Step description.

title: Available Environment Variables
body: $GIT_CLONE_COMMIT_AUTHOR_NAME The name of the author of the cloned commit.

title: Available Environment Variables
body: $GIT_CLONE_COMMIT_AUTHOR_EMAIL The email of the author of the cloned commit.

title: Available Environment Variables
body: $GIT_CLONE_COMMIT_COMMITER_NAME The name of the committer of the cloned commit.

title: Available Environment Variables
body: $GIT_CLONE_COMMIT_COMMITER_EMAIL The email of the committer of the cloned commit.

title: Bitrise tools
body: Name Type Description Link

title: Bitrise tools
body: Bitrise CLI CLI The Bitrise CLI which is used on bitrise.io to run builds. You can use it to run builds locally. https://github.com/bitrise-io/bitrise

title: Bitrise tools
body: stepman CLI tool The Step Collection Manager used for managing the Step Library. https://github.com/bitrise-io/stepman

title: Bitrise tools
body: envman CLI tool The Environment Variable Manager used by the Bitrise CLI to isolate and manage Environment Variables during the build. It can also be used independently of the Bitrise CLI. https://github.com/bitrise-io/envman

title: Bitrise tools
body: init CLI core plugin Use this plugin so that our project scanner can detect the type of your project locally and generate a Bitrise configuration. https://github.com/bitrise-io/bitrise-plugins-init.git

title: Bitrise tools
body: step CLI core plugin Use this plugin to list, retrieve Step information or create Steps. https://github.com/bitrise-io/bitrise-plugins-step

title: Bitrise tools
body: workflow-editor CLI core plugin Use this plugin to configure your builds’ bitrise.yml config locally with the offline Workflow Editor. https://github.com/bitrise-io/bitrise-workflow-editor.git

title: Bitrise tools
body: bitrise-plugin-io CLI core plugin Use this plugin to manage your apps on bitrise.io right from the Terminal / command line. https://github.com/bitrise-io/bitrise-plugins-io

title: Bitrise tools
body: codesigndoc iOS code signing tool A tool used to collect and upload code signing files from your Xcode projects. https://github.com/bitrise-io/codesigndoc

title: Bitrise tools
body: bitrise webhooks Webhook processor This Bitrise Webhooks processor transforms various incoming webhooks (for example, from GitHub, Bitbucket, or Slack) to bitrise.io’s Build Trigger API format, and calls it to start a build. https://github.com/bitrise-io/bitrise-webhooks
